text:
Pacita Abad (Pacita Barsana Abad) was a painter and printmaker. She was born in Batanes on 5 Oct 1946. She died in Singapore on 7 Dec 2004. She was the daughter of Jorge Abad and Aurora Barsana. She was married to Jack Garrity. She received her bachelor’s degree in 1968 from the University of the Philippines and her master’s degree in 1972 from the University of San Francisco. She attended the Corcoran School of Art in Washington, DC, 1975-77, and studied at the Art Students League of New York in 1978.

While Abad did paintings and prints, her principal medium was trapunto, the art of joining together and quilting pieces of plain or printed cloth with an embossed design produced by outlining the pattern with single stitches and then padding this with yarn or cotton. The artist enhanced the figurative designs with rickracks, ribbons, and buttons. She created from this process large wall hangings of a joyous warmth and vivacity. Her art reflected her many travels; Ramayana figures mingled with Dicka African chiefs and Papuan goddesses, which entered in colorful procession. Abad is known for her literally and metaphorically layered visual treatises on the global motility of Filipinos and other diasporic peoples. Her influence is also manifested in the sharing of her technical processes done through art school extension programs in the Philippines during respites from her many travels.

Abad created more than 4,500 artworks from 1974 to 2004. She held over 60 solo exhibitions at museums and galleries in Asia, the United States of America, Europe, Africa, and Latin America.

She exhibited abroad in the following sites: Dhanmondhi Studio, Dhaka, Bangladesh, 1978; New England Center for Contemporary Art, Connecticut, 1980; Boston University Art Gallery, Massachusetts, 1981; and Hong Kong Art Center. Locally she had exhibitions at the Luz Gallery and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1984 and 1985, and Ayala Museum in Makati, 1986. She was artist in residence at Altos de Chavon, Dominican Republic, in 1982. She also participated in more than 70 group and traveling exhibitions around the world. In 2003, her Circles in My Mind was exhibited at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute and her Endless Blues in Siuntio, Finland, and Hadeland, Norway. In 2000, she launched a Wayang Dinnerware Collection in Jakarta, Indonesia. Also in 2003, she opened her Batik Dinnerware Collection in Jakarta. In 2004, she had several exhibitions of Circles in My Mind at the Genome Institute of Singapore, CCP, and Andrew Shire Gallery, Los Angeles, California. In 2005, the School of Economics of Singapore Management University organized a posthumous tribute for her, A Special Tribute to Pacita Abad: A Philippine-American Artist. In 2006, an exhibition, Pacita: Through the Looking Glass, was held in Esplanade-Theatres on the Bay, Singapore.

Her Philippine awards and citations include the Ten Outstanding Young Men Award, 1984; the Likha Award as part of the celebration of the centennial of Philippine independence, 1998; and the Pamana ng Pilipino Award from Malacañan, 2000. Her American awards include the National Endowment for the Arts Visual Arts Fellowships, 1989-90; DC Commission on the Arts Award, 1992; Gwendolyn Cafritz Award from the Washington DC Commission for the Arts and the Mid-Atlantic Arts Regional Fellowship, 1993; New York State Council on the Arts Grant for Visiting Artists Program, and the Excellence 2000 Awards for the Arts from the US Pan Asian American Chamber of Commerce, Washington, DC, 1995.

In 2005, the National Museum of the Philippines organized a Parangal for Pacita Abad (Tribute to Pacita Abad), hosted by the Ateneo Library of Women’s Writings. This was also the year that the Pacita Abad Art Estate, a nonprofit private organization, was established in Singapore to preserve all materials related to the artist’s career. It produced two films: Groovy, on Abad’s artistic career, and Pacita’s Painted Bridge, on her painting of the Alkaff Bridge, a 55 m long bridge that spans Singapore River at Robertson Quay. The bridge, covered with 2,350 multicolored circles, is Singapore’s first “Bridge of Art” inaugurated in Jan 2004.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, Rosa Concepcion Ladrido, and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

 

 

Sources

Abad, Pacita. 2013. Website. Accessed 25 May. www.pacitaabad.com.

Brown, Ian Findlay. 1994. “Assailing the Senses: The Trapunto Art of Pacita Abad.” Asian Art News 4, no. 2 (Apr).

CNN Travel. 2013. “Best Bridges in Singapore.” Accessed 27 May. www.travel.cnn.com

Manipon, Roel Hoang. 2004. “Pacita Abad: A Painted Passing.” National Commission for Culture and the Arts website. Posted 3 Dec. Accessed 18 May 2013.

Singapore Art Bridge. 2013. Website. Accessed 27 May. www.singaporeartbridge.com.

Paz Abad Santos (Paz del Castillo Singson-Abad Santos), also known as Ching Abad Santos, is a painter. She was born in Manila on 26 Mar 1943. She is the daughter of Julian C. Singson and Ramona del Castillo. She spent her primary, secondary, and tertiary education at the Assumption Convent. After 18 years of marriage, she took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) where she graduated magna cum laude in 1981 and was chosen as the Most Outstanding Student in Painting by the UP College of Fine Arts Alumni Foundation.

Her medium for her tapestry hangings is basically painted burlap embellished or encrusted with indigenous materials, such as abaca fiber, coconut shells, and dried leaves. Her art is sometimes referred to as fiber art and has been linked to the weaving traditions practiced by women. In 2006, she developed the strand system of cardboard tiles, which allows visually impaired people to detect colors and compose paintings. This system has been part of her art therapy sessions for the blind, old, and elderly people, held in her studio home.

She donated many of her early works to the St. Luke’s Medical Center and two large works, Lent and Easter, to the Church of the Holy Trinity at Forbes Park.

Her solo exhibitions include Strands, 1981, held at the Heritage Gallery and the City Gallery; T’nalak and Beyond, 1989, De La Salle University; and T’nalak Evolution, 1990, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and Australian Center, 1993. She has also participated in more than 58 group shows, including Thinking Big, 1995, with Pacita Abad, at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.

Working consistently, she garnered numerous awards. Developing her medium in indigenous materials, she won a gold medal in the 33rd Annual Competition of the Art Association of the Philippines in 1981 for her work Delirious Spin. In 1982, she was a Mobil Art awardee, and in 1984 she was a finalist at the International Art Competition held in Los Angeles, California, USA. In 1992, she was named one of the CCP Thirteen Artists. She was honored as the Best Quezon City Woman Painter in 1995.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rina Corpuz and Cecilia S. De La Paz
ABELARDO, JUAN  (See Theater volume.)

Martino Abellana (Martino Alcoseba Abellana), also known as Tinong, was a painter and art educator. He was born in Carcar, Cebu on 30 Jan 1914. He died in 1988. His parents were Teofilo Abellana and Filomena La Orden Alcoseba. His grandfather, Saloy Abellana, was an apprentice to Isabelo Tampinco in Manila; his father Teofilo, a school principal, worked as sculptor in Carcar; his elder brother Sindulfo was also a sculptor who worked on the sculptures for the rotunda in Carcar while another elder brother, Ramon, a dentist, was also a sculptor and musician. His nephews Romulo Galicano and Gabriel Abellana are also painters. Abellana was married to Natividad Castillo Noel. He finished his formal art education in 1938 at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, where among his peers were Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, Ricarte Puruganan, and Simon Saulog. He subsequently taught freehand drawing and rendering to architecture students at Cebu Institute of Technology. Later he became the head of the fine arts program of UP in Cebu.

An admirer of classical music, Abellana believed that music cannot be separated from painting. He described his artistic process as “expressive of creative purpose, like the unfolding of an intimate concerto” (Maceda 2015). Using the mediums of oil, pastel, charcoal, and watercolor in his body of works, his influence lay primarily in portraiture employing realism and impressionism on landscapes inspired by the coastal environs of Cebu.

Working in the artistic environment of the debate between academic and modern art, Abellana was concerned with the reconciliation of the figurative and abstract modes. At the 1952 second watercolor exhibition of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), Abellana won first prize in the conservative category for The Farmer’s Son. The following year, another entry, Job Was Also Man, again grouped with the conservatives, won first prize at the semiannual exhibition of the AAP, while Fernando Zobel won first prize in the modern category. In 1958, he won a special award for Rocks at the 11th AAP annual exhibition. Up to the 1980s, Abellana continued to head group shows of Cebuano artists in Cebu and Manila. Known as the “Dean of Cebuano Painters,” Abellana was mentor to an entire generation of Cebuano artists. Among his students were Romulo Galicano, Sofronio Y. Mendoza aka SYM, Jose Kimsoy Yap Jr, Mariano Vidal, Cecilio Pepito, Adeste Deguilmo, Sonia Yrastorza, and Titing Baguio, all well-known Cebuano artists. Abellana’s mentorship to Cebuano artists helped bolster the art scene in Cebu City and the Visayas region. A retrospective exhibit, Ang Kalibutan sa mga Mata ni Martino Abellana (The World through the Eyes of Martino Abellana), was held on 29 Jan to 28 Feb 2015 at the North Wing Atrium of SM City Cebu.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro and Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Teresita G. Maceda.

 

Source

Maceda, Teresita. 2015. Foregrounding the Ordinary: The World through the Eyes of Martino Abellana. Exhibit catalog for Ang Kalibutan sa mga Mata ni Martino Abellana (The World through the Eyes of Martino Abellana), a retrospective exhibit on the life and art of Martino Abellana, 29 Jan–28 Feb, SM City Cebu.

Liddy Abes (Lidwina Ojeda Los Baños-Abes) was a weaver and industrial designer. She was born in Legaspi City on 14 Apr 1949. She died in Muntinlupa on 13 Jul 2002. She was the daughter of Luis Los Baños and Pura Ojeda. She married Generoso Abes with whom she had two children. She graduated with a bachelor of fine arts degree from the College of the Holy Spirit. Later, she pursued fine arts studies at Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid, Spain, and master of arts in psychology at Ateneo de Manila University. She authored the curriculum on industrial design at the Philippine Women’s University College of Fine Arts where she was dean from 1979 to 1987. She was consultant for product design in the Design Center of the Philippines, 1988-90.

In her 1987 exhibit at the Hiraya Gallery, she exhibited various fiber works made from indigenous plants, such as saluyot (jute) and banana. Some of these were installations using macrame techniques and which recalled forest canopies. Others were tapestries or hangings incorporating decorative weaving techniques in such a way that they alluded to landscapes with birds flying about. Colors and tones were used to create contrasts, and the woven fibers ranged from heavy and irregular to the smooth and silky. Her work amply demonstrated the artistic potential of indigenous plants and grasses in decorative textiles.

Abes was commended for her unique industrial designs here and abroad. She won Best Product Design awards for Stars, 1989, and Marie Claire, 1991, in Paris; and for Katha (Fiction) in Manila, 1990. In the constant quest to explore textile as form and the pushing of the boundaries of her craft, Abes shifted her creative process from designing tapestries to the reworking of ecclesiastical garment motifs (Ramirez 2015).   Written by Annaliza B. Villar and Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

Source

Ramirez, Eileen. 2015. “Crossbred and Émigré: Visual Art in a Flux”. NCCA. Posted 15 Apr. http://ncca.gov.ph/aboutculture-and-arts/articles-on-c-n-a/article.php?i=172&igm.

Manix Abrera (Manuel Luis Lorenzo Abrera) is a comic book artist and cartoonist. He was born in Pasay City on 8 Feb 1982. He is the son of cartoonist Jess Abrera (Jesus Pabico Abrera Jr) and Ma. Bernadette Gregorio Lorenzo. Abrera graduated from the University of the Philippines under the bachelor of fine arts (visual communication) program in 2003, which gave him the Best Undergraduate Thesis award. He went on to take graduate studies in the same institution.

Abrera was a cartoonist for the Philippine Collegian or Kule during his undergraduate years. He developed his own voice and identity while producing weekly comic strips, editorial cartoons, and article illustrations for Kule. He also started publishing Garapata Blood (Flea Blood) for the Philippine Daily Inquirer during his sophomore year in 2000. Garapata Blood was a comic strip that Abrera created with his bandmates John Paul Cuison and Bheng Densing. When he was offered his own comic strip space, he started Kikomachine Komiks, named after their band Kiko Machine.

Kikomachine Komiks, published in the Philippine Daily Inquirer from Monday to Saturday, and the comic strip compilations that issued out of them brought Abrera to prominence among a particular youth demographic. Abrera also eventually developed a web comic series called News Hardcore, which comes out in GMA News Online every Monday. Beginning 2005, Kikomachine Komiks was compiled yearly into books and published by Visprint Inc. As a daily strip in mass circulation, Kikomachine Komiks became a popular series as it dealt with Filipino culture and everyday life. Abrera relates that his creative process involves taking daily events he observed and amplifying these graphically while using colloquial language. Though sometimes criticized for making the text heavy, dialogue is a key part of Abrera’s pieces. His use of text as visual element, sometimes running around or deliberately inverting the comic frame, has also set his work apart from other daily strips. The use of spare lines in every panel and often simply outlined figures make Abrera’s characters easy to read visually. Similar to most comic strips, the expressions and gestures of the characters are often exaggerated. This style is also observed in his News Hardcore, which relates the travails of a young journalist. The series focuses on the office life of the young working population. While still employing simple lines to delimit figures with exaggerated movements and facial expressions, News Hardcore stylistically differs in its use of colored tints and shading, particularly of the background, as these elements are absent in Kikomachine Komiks.

Abrera’s most notable work is his graphic novel titled 12, 2009, also by Visprint Inc. As a wordless graphic novel, it is comprised of 12 short stories wherein he goes beyond the limitation of daily panels that his comic strips impose. Each story line is thus developed more elaborately and plays with flow and slower pacing. In this work, Abrera’s witty verbal humor previously demonstrated in the comic strips was replaced by a more philosophical and existential tone. While still counting upon the tropes of everyday life, 12 is given to unlikely and reflective readings. His experimental use of wordlessness here pushes the boundaries of the comic genre as it leaves more room for the reader to craft meaning from the work.

Abrera was given the Reader’s Choice Awards in Komikon or the Annual Philippine Komiks Convention in 2011 for 12 and Kikomachine Blg. 6 “Venn Mann at Iba Pang Kalupitan ng Kapalaran” (Kikomachine No. 6 “Venn Mann and Other Cruelties of Fate”). He has been an active participant of Komikon since its inception in 2005. Through it and parallel efforts, Abrera involves himself in the creation of a local comics community.   Written by Maria Portia Olenka Placino

Napoleon Abueva (Esabelio Napoleon Veloso Abueva), also known as Billy Abueva, was a sculptor and National Artist for visual arts. He was born in Bohol on 26 Jan 1930. He died in Quezon City on 16 Feb 2018. He was the son of Congressman Teodoro Abueva and Purificacion Veloso, both executed by the Japanese in 1944 for their guerrilla activities. He married Sergia Valles. They have three children, one of whom, Mulawin, is also a sculptor. As a boy, Abueva apprenticed with the Cebuano sculptor Fidel Araneta. Later, on a scholarship given by Pura Villanueva Kalaw, he studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, where Guillermo Tolentino was his mentor. He then took his master’s degree at Cranbrook Academy of Art in Michigan on a Smith Mundt-Fulbright grant. He further trained in sculpture and ceramics at the University of Kansas and took graduate units in art history at Harvard in 1956.

Abueva posed the challenge of modernism to his mentor Tolentino and, through his prolific and energetic work, significantly tilted the balance in favor of modernism. It was in the 1950s that he firmly established his reputation as the pioneering modernist in sculpture. Abueva’s artistic influence continued in his capacity as professor and former dean of the UP College of Fine Arts from 1978 to 1989. In 1993, he was given an honorary doctorate in humanities and promoted to university professor. He retired from UP in 1995 and was later given the honor of Professor Emeritus in 2003.

Abueva’s works have spread far and wide in galleries, schools, public buildings, residences, campuses, and parks both here and abroad. His versatility in both medium and expression eludes conventional categorization. He has done sculpture in a wide range of media: in metals such as iron, bronze, brass, and stainless steel; in stones such as adobe, marble, alabaster, and coral; and in woods such as molave, narra, kamagong, ipil, and bamboo. But he had admitted to be happiest working with Philippine hardwoods, bringing out their grained texture and natural sheen in the process of direct carving. He has often combined different materials, such as wood with metal and stone, and has worked in techniques proper to the materials used.

Although he identified his original influence as Brancusi, Abueva has constantly searched for new forms and modes of expression. In 1957, he created the double crucifix for the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice at the UP Diliman campus. He created many public sculptures for the UP Diliman campus such as the UP Gateway, 1967, on the University Ave; Siyam na Diwata ng Sining (Nine Muses of the Arts), 1994, at the UP Faculty Center; Three Women Sewing the First Philippine Flag, 1996, at the UP Donor’s Garden, as part of the centennial celebration of the 1896 Philippine Revolution; and Magdangal (Honor), 2008, located in front of the College of Arts and Letters Building.

As his work progressed in complexity and maturity, it became more and more characterized by a rich blend of wit and imagination—qualities that stemmed from an artistic individualism that enabled him to pursue his art without inhibition or self-consciousness. Among Abueva’s many important works are the buoyant sculpture Moses, 1951, floating on water; Rice Planting, 1952, an early modernist work with large, vigorous rhythms; Allegorical Harpoon, a work in molave which was the Philippine entry in the 32nd Venice Biennale in 1964; the stylized Water Buffalo, 1968, in bronze; Birds, 1971, in veined marble; the opalescent and compact Alabaster City, 1973; and the life-size To and from the Sea, 1978, with its rugged male figures carrying a banca. One of his largest works is the Transfiguration, 1979, a towering Christ figure, at the Eternal Gardens Memorial Park in Caloocan. He carved the 14 Stations of the Cross in hardwood, installed all along the circular inner walls of the Claret School Chapel in Teacher’s Village, Diliman. He also did a bronze figure of Teodoro M. Kalaw in front of the National Library; marble sculptures for the National Heroes Shrine in Mount Samat, Bataan; Sunburst, 1994, at the Peninsula Manila Hotel and other public sculptures in Makati City. He performed the death mask procedure on the late Cardinal Sin and Fernando Poe Jr. He has done altars in wood with metal trim, combining modern with folk in the ornate reliefs. A number of aspects emerged from his work: the purely figurative, the fantastic, the constructional, the highly stylized, the abstract, and the functional.

One important aspect of Abueva’s work is his enduring interest in the functional side of sculpture. He said, “I work on functional objects on the basis of sculptural problems, rather than on utilitarian objective, as diversion from pure sculpture.” Along this vein, he has done numerous doors in relief, benches, lounging chairs, a many-angled mirror tree, fountains, machines for grating coconuts, and a fantastic chariot that he himself rode in the complete regalia of a Roman centurion. Describing sculpture as primarily manual work, he stressed that the sculptor must also be a carpenter, mason, welder, electrician, and even a weight lifter. His work is characterized by a strong sense of form and material, by flexibility and invention, and by a fertile imagination, by turns whimsical, literary, erotic, and fantastic.

Done in modernist idiom, his adobe sculpture, The Kiss , won the second prize in the fourth Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) annual exhibition in 1951. In a separate sculpture exhibition in the same year, he won first prize for Mother and Child and best entry in plaster for Chukie Warren. His other AAP awards are as follows: first prize, Rice Planting, 1952; second prize, Mother and Child, 1952; first prize, Kaganapan (Fulfillment), 1952; second prize, Father and Son, 1954; first prize, Figure, 1958; third prize, Manila: The First Years, 1977; and honorable mention, Bagong Buhay (New Life), 1974. While he was studying abroad, his Kiss of Judas, 1955, Water Buffalo, 1968, and Unknown Prisoner won international awards. He received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1966. In 1976, he was proclaimed National Artist in sculpture. In 1995, he won the fourth ASEAN Achievement Award for the Visual Arts in Singapore. In 1999, he was honored with the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts. In 2010, a book on his life and works titled Abueva by Cid Reyes was launched.  Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Jerson Silerio

 

Sources

Inquirer.net. 2010. “Masters of Modernism.” Updated 8 Mar. Accessed 8 Oct 2014. http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/artsandbooks/artsandbooks/view/20100308-257314/Masters_of_modernism.

Lanelle Abueva-Fernando (Marie Lanelle Encarnacion Abueva-Fernando) is a potter. She was born on 23 Jan 1956. She is the daughter of Jose V. Abueva and Ma. Socorro Encarnacion. She was married to Teodoro Fernando, with whom she has two children. She received her elementary and secondary education in various schools in the USA and in the Philippines, including the Assumption Convent and Silliman University, where she finished her high school in 1973. She took art studies at Padma Kanya College in Kathmandu, Nepal; the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts; and the Ceramics School in Higashi Ginza, Tokyo, Japan. She served her apprenticeship as a ceramics artist with master potter Shokichi Aoki in Hachijo-jima, Japan, in 1978-80 and with Jim Romberg at the Sun Valley Center for the Arts and Humanities in Idaho, USA, in 1980-81.

In 1981, she started her own ceramics studio workshop at her home in Antipolo, Rizal, where she specializes in functional and handmade stoneware ceramics. She taught ceramics at Sining Kamalig Gallery, UP, and the Summer Arts Camp in Miag-ao, Iloilo. After participating in several ceramic group shows in Idaho, USA, Abueva-Fernando held her first solo show, Ceramics by Lanelle Abueva, at Sining Kamalig Gallery in Manila in 1983. Since then, she has done other solo exhibits at Hiraya Gallery, 1986 and 1991; Gallery Ched, 1992; Manila Midtown Hotel, 1993; and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

She has also been active in numerous group shows, including Contemporary Pottery in the Philippines, CCP, 1990; ASEAN Ceramics Exhibition and Workshop at the Philippine Trade and Training Center, 1991; Walong Filipina (Eight Filipino Women) at Liongoren Gallery, 1992; Artistree II, Ayala Museum, 1992; Ceramics by Lanelle Abueva-Fernando, Greenbelt Square, 1993; A Christmas Story (Belen), Ayala Museum, 1993; The Abuevas: Sculptural Expressions, Galleria de las Islas, 1994; Group Show, Pinto Gallery, 2002; and Color and Form in Genes, Avant, 2012, with her uncle National Artist Napoleon Abueva and his son. Abueva-Fernando received the silver medal (salt-fired piece category) and special mention (Tenmoku piece category) at the 1982 International Amateur Pottery Exhibition in Tokyo, Japan.   Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

 

Source

Kintanar, Thelma B., and Sylvia Mendez Ventura. 2003c. “Lanelle Abueva Fernando: Earth, Hand and Fire; The Potter’s Art.” In Self-Portraits 2: Fourteen Filipina Artists Speak, 159-93. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Ronald Achacoso (Ronald Araña Achacoso) is a painter and art critic. He was born in Quezon City on 7 Feb 1966. He is the son of Arturo Rivera Achacoso and Anita Davis Araña. He graduated with a degree in fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (UP CFA) in 1989. He also taught at the UP CFA from 1994 to 1995.

Achacoso has produced paintings in oil on canvas and mixed media which explore the visual connections between art, ecology, and science. Interested in the various interfaces between painting, writing, and scientific disciplines, his images over the years have ranged from those appropriating figurative icons of flora and fauna to those representing cellular and abstract forms. His interest in such themes was evident early on in his solo exhibitions such as Terrain, 1993, at West Gallery where he explored imagery and surfaces culled from natural history and geological strata, and analogies between the visual and scientific. This inquiry is sustained decades later in shows such as Abstraction of Beasts, 2011, which responds to images found in scientific journals and taxonomic studies. From the late 1980s onward, Achacoso’s explorations have extended from evolutionary and natural sciences to the fields of astronomy and geology and the visual processes of map making and topographic studies. These have led to the production of paintings consisting of emblems, patterns, and archetypes as culled images.

His earliest solo exhibitions On the Origin of the Species, 1988, and Descent of Man, 1991, were held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Since 1987, he participated in group exhibitions at the CCP, Pinaglabanan Galleries, Alliance Française, SM Megamall Art Center, Lopez Museum, Big Sky Mind, Mag:net Gallery, and the UP Vargas Museum.

A writer and critic, Achacoso produced catalogue texts and articles about exhibitions of Philippine contemporary art. He won the Art Association of the Philippines’ Leo Benesa Award for Art Criticism twice in 1993 and 1994. He has co-curated exhibitions with Nilo Ilarde, including Here Be Dragons: Topology of Allegory, 2009, at Manila Contemporary and Destroy All Monsters, 2007. Achachoso has pursued his interest in botany as a member of the Philippine Native Plant Conservation Society Inc since 2008. Achacoso received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2000.  Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

 

Sources

Dayao, Dodo. 2011. “Ronald Achacoso: Abstraction of Beasts.” http://www.aaa.org.hk/Collection/Details/47586.

Galleria Duemila. 2003c. “Ronald Achacoso.” http://www.galleriaduemila.com/WEB2003/artists/rac/racabout.html.

Ito, Lisa C. 2014b. Interview with Ronald Achacoso. 25 Jun.

Daniel Aguila (Daniel Doroteo Dumuk Aguila), also known as El Dani, was an illustrator and painter. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 24 Sep 1928. He died in Nashville, Tennessee, USA on 28 Sep 2010. He finished his basic education at Bauang Central Primary, Bauang Intermediate School, and the Silliman University High School. As a Ramon Roces scholar, 1948-49, and while working as part-time staff artist at Pan Pacific Advertising Co., he obtained his degree in fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1952. In 1951, he also served as artist and editorial assistant of the Philamlife Newsletter. He later attended Syracuse University, New York, studying advertising design, photojournalism, audiovisual education, and educational TV. He taught photojournalism at the UP Institute of Mass Communication, 1964-66, and cartooning at the Nashville School of Art, Tennessee, 1987. He was president of the Society of Philippine Illustrators and Cartoonists, 1966-67, and director of the National Press Club, 1966. He served as director of various prestigious offices in Nashville, such as the Financial Institute Services Inc, 1976-85; WDCN-Public TV 8, 1973-75; and R.G. Field Advertising, 1968-73. He was also art director of the United Methodist Communications and was a cartoon instructor in 1987-89 at the Watkins School of Art, Tennessee, USA. He was the first non-American elected as president of the Art Directors Club of Nashville in 1978, as well as the first Asian elected as president of the International Association of Business Communicators.

While in the Philippines, Aguila was known for his editorial line cartoons, whereas in the United States he honed his painting skills. He did portraits and American-style genre scenes, particularly in pencils and pastels, and caricature. He participated in group shows of the Association of American Editorial Cartoonists Annual Shows, 1981-91; Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), 1965; Society of Philippine Illustrators and Cartoonists, 1962-67; National Press Club of the Philippines, 1965-67; and Asian Institute of Journalism, 1974.

Aguila won his first gold medal for his cartoon Famous Menagerie at the AAP art competition, 1952. At the Tennessee Art Fair, he won several awards: for American Gothic: Now, acrylic on canvas, first prize, 1980; for Year of the American Eagle, mixed media, first prize, 1982; and for Granddaughter Kathy, colored pencils and pastel, first prize, 1990. He was included in the Who’s Who in the South and South West, 14th edition, 1975-76. In 1976, he received the Outstanding Sillimanian Award in communication arts as part of Silliman University’s diamond jubilee celebration.  Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

 

Sources

Suacona.com. 2013. “Daniel Aguila Obituary.” Accessed 18 May. http://www.suacona.com/clients/16856/file/Daniel_Aguila_obituary/pdf.

WittyWorld Who’s Who. n.d. “International Who’s Who in Cartooning.” www.wittyworld.com.

Lee Aguinaldo (Leopoldo Aguinaldo Jr) was a painter. He was born in New York, USA on 5 Sep 1933. He died in Quezon City on 16 Jan 2007. At age 14, he was sent to a military school in the United States. When he returned to the Philippines, he took up commerce at De La Salle University. He had no formal art education, but as a young boy he was already interested in it. During his stay in New York, he frequented the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he was exposed to the works of Titian, Rembrandt, and other Dutch masters.

Aguinaldo held his first exhibit at the Philippine Art Gallery in 1958. His early works were influenced by Jackson Pollock. Through the years, he developed several styles of painting: “flick” painting, where he “flicked” paint from a palette knife on canvas; “galumphing,” which incorporated a few pop images largely influenced by Robert Motherwell; and “linear” painting in his geometric abstract phase. He was best known for this hard-edge minimalist style, which influenced a new generation of abstractionists in the 1960s such as Ben Maramag, Rodolfo Gan, and Rodolfo Samonte.

Aguinaldo’s works were featured in several exhibitions. In 1992, the Lopez Memorial Museum organized the exhibition and publication of a portfolio of Aguinaldo’s selected pen-and-ink drawings titled Rembrandt’s Light Series based on Rembrandt’s numerous versions of his self-portraits. In May 1993, Galleria Duemila held a two-man exhibit by Aguinaldo and Justin Nuyda. This joint show was Aguinaldo’s last exhibition. In 2010, the Ateneo Art Gallery marked its 50th anniversary with a posthumous exhibit, Lee Aguinaldo: In Retrospect, which featured paintings, drawings, and mixed-media works that spanned Aguinaldo’s different styles and period. In 1994, he underwent a major heart operation. He recovered but he never painted again. In 2011, Vibal Foundation launched The Life and Art of Lee Aguinaldo.

Aguinaldo won numerous awards at the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competitions and exhibitions, including second prize for White City, 1961; first prize for Explosion in Gold, 1962; and honorable mention for Explosion in Red City, 1963. He also received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1975.  Written by R. Chu, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

 

Sources

 

Herrera, Ma. Victoria, Clarissa Chikiamco, Cid Reyes, and Rod Paras-Perez. 2011. The Life and Art of Lee Aguinaldo. Quezon City: Vibal Foundation Inc.

Zulueta, Lito B. 2007. “Lee Aguinaldo: ‘Mr. Cool of Philippine Art’: 73.” Philippine Daily Inquirer, 19 Jan.

Leonardo Aguinaldo (Leonardo Lachica Aguinaldo) was a visual artist. He was born in Baguio on 6 Nov 1967. His parents are Bartolome Aguinaldo Sr and Petra Lachica, both originally from Candon, Ilocos Sur. He took architectural drafting at the Baguio Colleges Foundation in 1989 before joining the Baguio Arts Guild (BAG) in 1991. Early in his career, Aguinaldo was a magazine illustrator and a cartoonist for the Baguio-based paper The Midland Courier. He also did illustrations for a number of books done by the Cordillera Green Network.

Learning printmaking, mixed media art, and installation art while assisting more senior artists such as Ben Cabrera and Santiago Bose in conducting BAG workshops, Aguinaldo developed his abilities in hand printing calendars, T-shirts, and cards for the tourist market in Sagada. His need for paper led him to innovate with materials, and in 2000, he started using carved rubber as both painting surface and primary sculpted material. Aside from evocative anecdotal narratives on environment, culture, and society, his art stands out because of this medium he has chosen to work with repeatedly. He draws on rubber and carves out the voids, then he brushes bright hues of acrylic paint to color the incised patterns. Printer’s ink and oil paints are applied with a roller for the raised areas. Instead of printing this out on paper to make artworks in multiples, the plate itself is presented as the finished work.

Aguinaldo participated in the Baguio Arts Festivals from 1989 to 1993 and has had numerous group and solo exhibitions since then in Philippine and international venues. Most notable among his solo shows are his first, Ap-Apo ni Tuo (Ancestors of the People), 1994, at the Pasilyo Guillermo Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), where he showed a set of painted images on handmade paper depicting traditional stories of the Benguet people, and Creative Isolation, 2002, at the Hiraya Gallery, where he first publicly showed his output using ukir on rubber. As an offshoot of his first show at the CCP, Aguinaldo’s work was published in a coffee-table book, Ap-Apo ni Tuo, 1997, which had his paintings appearing alongside stories and myths of the Cordillera. Out of his own initiative, Aguinaldo toured this set of works to Benguet schools and local government units (LGUs). He also held art workshops and donated copies of this book to LGU libraries.

Aguinaldo’s international exhibitions include Northern Exposure, 2007, in Utterly Art Singapore and Cultural Crossing, 2009, at the Vermont Studio Center’s Red Mill Gallery as part of his Freeman Fellow residency. Other international exhibitions were held in South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, Japan, Germany, France, and Australia. In 2003, he was conferred the CCP Thirteen Artists Award. He also received the grand prize in the Philip Morris ASEAN Art Awards in 2004, where he was named Best Emerging ASEAN Artist.   Written by Kelly P. Ramos

Saud Ahmad (Ib’n Saud Salipyasin Ahmad), also known as Saudi Ahmad, was a painter, musician, and dancer. He was born in Kabasalan, Zamboanga Sibugay on 2 Nov 1952. His father is Hadji Salip Ahmad, a Samal Balangingi, and his mother is Salip Aisa Salipyasin, a Maguindanaon. His wife is Eulida Mancao with whom he has three children. Although of mixed ethnic origin, Ahmad was raised as a Maguindanaon in Sibugay, Zamboanga peninsula. The Maguindanaon trace their roots in Zamboanga since the 1780s when Sibugay—then a center of Subanon culture—was an autonomous region under the Maguindanao sultanate headed by Datu Dakula. The latter exercised jurisdiction over a large area of what is now politically subdivided into the provinces of Zamboanga del Norte, Zamboanga Sibugay, Zamboanga City, and the western part of Zamboanga del Sur. According to the painter, his lineage comes from the Royal House of Salipyasin, which later conferred him the title of Sharif Datu Manukur.

At age five, in the late 1950s, Ahmad became fascinated with films like Three Musketeers, Tarzan, and Durango Kid, which screened at the clubhouse of the Americans who then controlled the Kabasalan rubber plantations. The movies in his mind were transformed into drawings using pencil or crayons. Largely self-taught, his only formal training was a drafting course taken at the Zamboanga School of Arts and Trade in Zamboanga City. He then worked as a graphic artist and rendered pop art designs for tricycles and ice cream carts.

He developed his own figurative style in watercolor, which recreates scenes from an unknown past and from forgotten customs and traditions drawn from childhood memories. Ahmad preserves these important rituals, traditions, and beliefs through his intricate watercolors, which employ a tedious technique that involves painting two different colors one on top of the other. The top layer is then gently erased using a fine brush and applying only the precise amount of water so as not to cause any blotting. This is calculated to produce delicate lines that reveal the underlying color.

Islamic and ethnic traditions are important influences on his art, as exemplified by the work Thanksgiving, which depicts men who sit around a long table laden with sumptuous food, illustrating the segregation of men and women in certain Muslim rites. His paintings of women are meticulously executed to show great detail in indigenous adornment and clothing, as seen in Utarah (The Midday Wind), 1994. Ahmad’s belief in the supernatural is made evident in Soratan (Soulmates), 2003, which portrays men and women awaiting their destined partners, one of whom is a female deity descending to her beloved. With his continuous production of artworks that show the unique culture of the ethnic groups of the province, Ahmad renders a magnanimous picture of Zamboanga Sibugay, a place sometimes associated with cases of kidnapping and other lawless acts. His house in Kabasalan, which also functions as a workshop and gallery, is an architectural landmark and a tourist destination.

His works have been exhibited at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and the National Museum of the Philippines. In 1995, he held a solo exhibit at the Philippine Center and the Hilton Hotel in New York, USA. He has also presented his works in Germany, Italy, Austria, and Singapore. Ahmad was part of the show titled Glimpses of Mindanao: Peace in the Land of Promise, sponsored by the Philippine Embassy and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, held in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in 2013.   Written by Rosalie Matilac

Jess Aiko (Jesus Ramos Ayco), also known as Jess Ayco, was a painter, choreographer, and director. He was born in Pasig, Manila on 8 Aug 1916. He died in Bacolod on 2 May 1982. He was the son of Leon Conde Ayco and Encarnacion Ramos. He adopted an artistic name (Jess Aiko) in 1967. He obtained his early schooling at Ateneo de Manila. He took courses in painting at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts in 1935-36. He also studied architecture at the University of Santo Tomas. He traveled to Europe and studied in London and Paris for some time. He held his first one-person show at the Philippine Art Gallery in May 1956, which was followed by group and solo shows in Bacolod, Cebu, Iloilo, and Dumaguete cities. In his shows, he displayed an avant-garde sensibility borne out by his experiments in enamel and tempera. He was instrumental in the formation of the Art Association of Bacolod. He lived in Bacolod City for most of his life.

Well-traveled and well-read, Ayco witnessed the vigor of abstract painting in Paris. His canvases were covered with splatterings of enamel paint. The density and tensility of his medium became the very subject of his paintings. An early work of Ayco, Young Widow by the Church, 1947, showed his expressionistic tendency, quite advanced for the period in the context of Philippine art history. However, he also used the patterns formed by the medium to evoke shapes derived from life as in Sylvan Idyll, 1956.

Ayco designed for dance and drama presentations, and choreographed dances in Bacolod, Iloilo, and Cebu. He was involved in the Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe from the 1950s through the 1960s, the Negros Occidental Dance Troupe (NODT) in the 1970s, and in the Kaanyag Pilipinas Dance Company, formerly the West Negros College Dance Company, in the 1980s. As artistic director of the NODT, he worked with dance directors Elsie Yelo-Enriquez and Virgie Gallespen. Under his direction, they strung together Philippine folk dances into theatrical programs like The Lost Earring and Fiesta, which included another original treatment of Alejandro Roces’s story “The Cockfight.” In 1965, he staged Scintilla, which fused Philippine folklore, stories, music, and choreography, and in 1966, the dance drama Igpat sang Bulawan (Glow of Gold), about the barter of Negros and Panay that antedated the Dularawan: Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: Golden Salakot) in Manila.

He was also involved with Visayan theater groups in plays and musicals. He staged Oklahoma in Bacolod, The Sound of Music and Carousel in Iloilo, and The King and I in Cebu. He produced and directed Medea and Oscar Wilde’s Salome, among others. He also designed for most of the dance productions of Bacolod’s choreographer Lydia Madarang-Gaston, and for the first Asian tour of the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe in the 1960s.

Aiko won the following prizes in the Art Association of the Philippines art competition: honorable mention in photography, Pitang, 1952; second prize in non-objective painting, Anterean Dance, 1958; and second prize in non-objective painting, Plutonian Passage, 1962.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Benjamin Alano (Benjamin Pagsisihan Alano) was a painter. He was born in Bagong Bayan, Taguig, Rizal on 20 Aug 1920. He died on 10 Jan 1991. Painter. His parents were Fausto Alano and Genoveva Pagsisihan. He married Leticia Custodio, also a painter. His father, an employee of the Philippine National Bank, collected paintings which filled their house. Being constantly surrounded by these paintings inspired Alano to study art and become a painter himself. He attended the Singalong Elementary School and the Arellano High School. In 1948, he graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts with a degree in painting. The first public exhibition of his works was in a group show organized in 1949, featuring the works of members of the Philippine Arts Guild. He co-owned his first gallery with Serafin Serna. In the 1950s, Alano taught art lessons to naval officers’ wives at Sangley Point, Cavite, and for 20 years maintained his own studio at Ermita, Manila.

Alano was a disciple of Fernando Amorsolo. Of the members of the Amorsolo School, Alano effectively captured Amorsolo’s warm sunlight colors, which he used in representing the Filipino’s sun-kissed complexion and innate energy. Alano, however, was original in his subjects, avoiding Amorsolo’s farm scenes and focusing on full-figure or half-figure renditions of workers, particularly fisherfolk. He was known for painting images of young boys holding their catch, with a glistening pond in the background.

Toward the end of his life, his genre scenes were regularly bought by German art dealers such that the German art world of that period came to know the Philippines through Alano’s paintings of rural scenes. One of Alano’s last important works is San Lorenzo Ruiz for the Our Lady of Peace Chapel on EDSA corner Ortigas Ave.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

Raymundo Albano (Raymundo Pidad Albano), also known as Ray Albano, was a painter, printmaker, and cultural administrator. He was born in Bacarra, Ilocos Norte on  27 Jan 1947. He died in Quezon City on 6 Aug 1985. His parents were Pastor Albano and Alejandra Pidad. Albano obtained his bachelor of arts degree, major in English literature, at Ateneo de Manila University in 1968.

From 1970 until his death, Albano played a major role in the art world when he joined the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and became its visual arts director, succeeding his mentor Roberto Chabet. As curator he actively promoted conceptual art in CCP’s major exhibitions, gaining acceptance for this relatively new form of art. He launched in 1980 the bimonthly CCP art publication Philippine Art Supplement. During his term at the CCP, Albano designed many posters for the center, mainly for the theater productions of Bulwagang Gantimpala, for which he also designed sets and lights. Albano also founded the photography club for CCP employees and participated in international exhibitions. As artist and/or administrator, he attended and officially represented the Philippines in various international conferences, symposia, and exhibitions such as the Asian Art Festival in Fukuoka, Japan; the Munich Summer Festival; the ASEAN Exhibition of Painting and Photography; the Philippine Sceneries Show in Beijing, China; and the Biennale de Paris.

As an artist, Albano was considered to be an abstractionist, experimentalist, and a conceptualist. His works studied and played with the process of art production by exploring and pushing the boundaries of time and space surrounding the artist during the creative process and within the work and the characteristics of the materials used in art making. The breaking of preconceived ideas about art and its processes became Albano’s major concern. He once took 100 shots of a subject who did not change her pose throughout the session. Albano’s investigation on time revealed many different changes going on in the background even if the subject never moved.

Albano received the John Mulry Award for Literary Excellence from Ateneo in 1968. He also received the Thirteen Artists Award from the CCP in 1970. In 1977, he received a grant as artist in residence under the Fulbright-Hayes Fund International Exchange of Scholars at the University of the Pacific in Stockton, California. He won honorable mention in the 1974 Tokyo International Biennale of Prints.   Written by Rachel Mayo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

Cesare Alberoni and Giovanni Dibella were Italian stage-scenery painters active ca 1875-91. Alberoni and Dibella revolutionized scenographic art in the Philippines, introducing 18th- and 19th-century styles in interior decoration and stage scenery painting. Both Italian natives, the two artists arrived in the Philippines as members of the Italian opera troupe Compañia Assi-Panadis on 24 Mar 1875. The two were immediately contacted by the Augustinians who were currently redecorating the Church of San Agustin, Intramuros, Manila. Alberoni and Dibella assessed the expenses at 6,000 pesos to which the priests eventually added another 2,000 pesos. The project, unveiled the following year, resulted in a stupendous work, such that the priests were criticized for their extravagance. However, this achievement opened the eyes of the Filipino community to a new cultural sensibility. The two artists became instant celebrities and were persuaded to stay. As early as 1876, they began redecorating the interior of the Malacañan Palace.

As toasts of the town and owing to their distinctive personalities, Alberoni and Dibella were the first artists to be featured in a Philippine magazine. Alberoni was described as a “bohemio de la raza” (true-to-form beatnik) “dressed up and coiffed like a true painter.” Dibella, on the other hand, was described as looking more like a “seminarian.” “If Alberoni were a genius,” read the article, “he would be as vain and conceited as Cellini, as irascible as Michaelangelo and as pedantic as Courbet … Dibella in contrast, would be like a semitheologian like Rembrandt … and would, like Fortuny, settle down into a model padre de familia …” (Ilustracion del Oriente 1878).

As soon as they began work in Manila, the two hired local painters as assistants, encouraging apprenticeship, because they could not do all their commissions by themselves. Dibella returned to Europe on 3 May 1881 but Alberoni remained, and established on 19 Sep 1884 a school specializing in scenographic art. The courses offered were linear drawing, ornamental drawing, and figure drawing. The classes were held in a building located on Calle Quiotan in Santa Cruz, Manila. Matriculation per annum was “un real fuerte.” Before Dibella left, the two painted the interior of the Santo Domingo Church and the mansion of Jose Rocha. They had also decorated the set of Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig) staged on 8 Dec 1880 at Ateneo de Manila with music by Blas Echegoyen and lyrics by Jose Rizal.

The San Agustin Church is today the only completely preserved project done by Alberoni and Dibella. The decorations are a blend of Filipino floral motifs, classical architectural ornaments, and religious symbols. The central nave was divided into six sections filled with liturgical allusions. They employed, for effect, trompe l’oeil, such that when seen from a distance, the paintings gave the impression of being real, carved bas-reliefs. The set of Junto al Pasig, on the other hand, is described as a “hall filled with columns creating an illusion of ample space.” The set itself was collected by Toribio Antillon, who, together with Emilio Alvero, trained under the two Italians.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar

Gus Albor (Augusto Besido Albor) is a painter and sculptor. He was born in Naga City, Camarines Sur on 28 Aug 1948. He is the son of Proceso Albor and Asuncion Besido. He married artist and writer Teresa Bargielska, an American, with whom he has three children. Albor graduated from the University of the East School of Music and Fine Arts in 1973 and received a one-year British Council study grant at the West Surrey College of Art in England in 1978.

He has participated in major exhibitions: the First Selection of Philippine Art by the Museum of Philippine Art (MOPA), 1981; the ASEAN Exhibition of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1981; and 100 Years of Philippine Painting Exhibition held in the Pacific Asia Museum in Pasadena, California, 1984; and many other international exhibitions and art events in Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, and China. He has held one-person shows for many years in various galleries such as at Galleria Duemila and Art Informal, both in 2014, and at institutions such as Vargas Museum in 2010. Albor also participated in Personal Structures: Crossing Borders, an exhibition hosted by the European Cultural Center, which simultaneously mounted this in the same building as the Philippine Pavilion of the 2015 Venice Biennale.

Albor also produces sculpture with the qualities that one finds in his two-dimensional works: pensive abstractions demonstrating a concern with combining and contrasting human-made materials and those from nature. An overlying industrial metallic quality distinguishes his work.

Albor won a number of awards such as the Thirteen Artists Award from the CCP in 1976 and the Art Association of the Philippines Award for his painting Refuge in 1977. In 2010, Albor collaborated with art critic Cid Reyes and book designer Aman Santos to produce the book Immaterial, which surveys four decades of Albor’s works. Albor continues to produce transmedia work, occasionally collaborating quietly with performance artists, and serving as artist-juror for competitions such as the Metrobank Art Competition.   Written by Rachel Mayo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

 

Source

Villalon, Augusto. 2010. “Book Does Justice to Gus Albor’s Art.” Philippine Daily Inquirer, 16 Aug.

Larry Alcala (Lauro Zarate Alcala) was a cartoonist and art educator. He was born in Daraga, Albay on 18 Aug 1926. He died on 24 Jun 2002. He was the son of Ernesto Alcala and Elpidia Zarate. He was married to Guadalupe Valdes with whom he had three children. Alcala finished his fine arts degree at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1950 after obtaining a scholarship grant from Ramon Roces, publisher of the Manila Times. He then taught at UP, 1951-81. He introduced the first college courses in commercial design in 1953, and the first 8 mm film production of animated cartoons for the Department of Visual Communications in the UP College of Fine Arts in 1972. Upon his retirement in 1981, he was chairperson of the Department of Visual Communications in UP. He was also president of the Samahang Kartunista ng Pilipinas. He was one of the founding members of the Philippine Board on Books for Young People (PBBY).

He started his career as a cartoonist at 17 while still in school by doing comic strips for Liwayway. His first popular comic strip, Islaw Palitaw (Islaw the Floating Rice Cake), published 1946-48 in Liwayway, was made into a movie. Cartoons he created include Project 13 for Pioneer Komiks, 1966-72; Barrio Pogspak for Holiday Komiks, 1966-72; Kongressman Kalog (Funny Congressman) for Aliwan Komiks, 1966-72; Smolbateribol (Small but Terrible) for Darna, 1972-84; Snickerteens for TSS Magazine, 1973-84; and Bing Bang Bung for Pilipino Funny Komiks, 1978-81. Other comic strips include Kalabog en Bosyo (Kalabog and Bosyo) for Pilipino Komiks, 1949-83, and Manila Times, 1984-95; Mang Ambo for the Weekly Graphic, 1963-65, Weekly Nation, 1965-72, and Manila Standard, 1993-98. His English comic strips are This Business of Living, 1961-72, and Mang Ambo, 1963-72, both for Weekly Graphic and Weekly Nation; Siopawman for Philippine Daily Express, 1972-83; Mod Caps for Mod, 1974 onward; Asiong Aksaya (Wasteful Asiong), which appeared in almost all dailies and magazines in 1979-84; Laugh and Live for Life Today, 1981-2002; and Slice of Life for Weekend, 1980-86, Sunday Tribune 1986-87, Sunday Times, 1987-95, and Philippine Star, 1995-2002. Slice of Life won several awards, including Best in Humor from the Catholic Mass Media Awards in Feb 1988.

He was also credited with creating the first locally produced animated cartoons in 1965 and 1967 for television commercials. Alcala was much influenced by the American cartoonist Al Capp. His own satirical cartoons reflect the foibles of Filipinos. So popular were his characters Kalabog and Bosyo that two screenplays were made of these characters, starring the comedy duo Dolphy and Panchito, teamed-up for the first time in 1959, and once again in 1986. Tipin, made for Hiwaga Komiks, 1951-66, was produced by Premiere Productions with Lani Oteyza in the lead.

Some of his published works include The Best of Mang Ambo, 1988; The Best of Larry Alcala’s Mang Ambo: Book 2, 1992; The Latest of Larry Alcala’s Mang Ambo, 2001; and Congressman Kalog, 2003.

In 1997, PBBY gave Alcala the title “Dean of Filipino Cartoonists” and named one of its prizes after him: the Alcala Illustrators’ Prize. He received the Animahenasyon Lifetime Achievement Award in 2007. An exhibit of Alcala’s works was held at the 2nd Animahenasyon Pinoy Animation Festival in 2008 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. An exhibition of his works titled Slice of Life was held at the Yuchengco Museum, Makati City, in 2009.   Written by Rene B. Javellana, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Jose P. Alcantara was a sculptor. He was born in Pasay City on 15 Dec 1911. He died in Binangonan, Rizal on 18 Mar 2005. Alcantara had no formal education in fine arts. He was first introduced to wood carving as an apprentice to Gonzalo Puyat, famous wood-carver and furniture maker, and also through training at the Taller de Escultura de Tampinco.

Alcantara’s earliest production belonged to the classical tradition. In 1951, his entries in the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) sculpture exhibition were already marked by simplification and stylization of form, which would characterize his sculptures. Philippine abstract sculpture then was still in its early stage and was mainly influenced by the style of Henry Moore. Yet Alcantara’s works evoked a markedly Philippine sensibility, being thematically sourced from genre painting. Moreover, his working mainly on wood with polished surfaces and fluid lines enhanced his themes of maternal tenderness, as in Mother and Child, 1953. On the other hand, Ina ng Ani (Mother of Harvest), 1954, shows the full figure of a stylized woman carrying a child in native rural costume that recalls the rich embroidery of the barong tagalog in its ornate border designs.

Alcantara’s awards from the AAP include special prize for Ina ng Lahi (Mother of the Race) and third prize for The Kiss, both in 1951; first prize for Mother and Child, 1953; third prize for Ina ng Ani, 1954; and second prize for Susmariosep (Jesus, Mary, Joseph), 1955. Alcantara also won first prize at the First Southeast Asia Art Conference and Competition for Behold the Man in 1979.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

JUAN ALCAZAREN (Juan Gonzalez Alcazaren III), also known as Johnny Alcazaren, is a visual artist. He was born in Quezon City on 24 Oct 1960. He is the son of Juan Alcazaren Jr and Rolinda Gonzalez, and the brother of architect Paulo Alcazaren. Johnny, with another sibling, filmmaker-artist Mike, established the Alcazaren Bros Production company in 1989. He is also the uncle of young filmmaker Whammy Alcazaren. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) with a bachelor’s degree in landscape architecture in 1983 and took courses in sculpture at the UP College of Fine Arts, where he served as lecturer from 1993 to 1995.

Alcazaren’s animation practice appears to dovetail directly with the way he craftily manipulates and activates found domestic and industrial objects to effect sensory experiences of re-materialized form. Alcazaren’s planar and object productions come out of a range of processes, from concatenating things to merely presenting them as they are but in a way that beholders are made to think upon the working out and working over of surface upon surface, color upon color, texture upon texture, and other decision points that figure in his production method.

Among his solo exhibitions are Arthropophilia, 1992, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); FRNAUT and Bigger than a Breadbox, both in 1995 at West Gallery; Quotidian Gray, 2000, SM Art Center; 9 Objects: A Tribute to Marcel Duchamp, 2001, Big Sky Mind and Alliance Française; Familiarity Breeds, 2003, SM Megamall Art Center; Crime and Decoration, Theo Gallery, 2004; SENI: Art and the Contemporary, Singapore Art Museum, 2004; The Sedimentation of the Mind Is a Jumbled Museum, Vargas Museum, 2004; Coming Misconceptions, 2005, Finale Art File; Filipiniana, 2006, Centro Cultural Duque Madrid; Not Your Garden Variety Earth ly Delight, 2006, Finale Art File; Room for Error, 2007, West Gallery; Low Tide, 2007, Finale Art File; Test, 2008, Mag:net Gallery Katipunan; Gone to Seed, 2008, Finale Art File; Mixed Signals, 2010, Utterly Art; Choking Hazard, 2009, Mag:net The Columns; Sisyphus 3, 2010, Finale Art File; Save Me from What I Want to Save, 2011, Finale Art File; and Zero Ground, 2014, The Drawing Room. Group exhibitions include Shoot Me and I Have Nothing to Paint and I’m Painting It, both in 2007 at Mo Space; Etudes for More than Two Hands, Mo Space, 2008; Inaugural Show Part 1, Finale Art File, 2008; Inaugural Show, Mag:net Gallery The Columns, 2008; Interior Motives, Mo Space, 2009; Juan Alcazaren and Bernardo Pacquing: Recent Works, Finale Art File, 2009; The Mag:net Art Tables, Mag:net Gallery Katipunan, 2010; Cube, Finale Art File, 2010; Small Works, Mag:net Gallery Katipunan, 2010; Incidential Pleasure, Mo Space, 2011; No Talking Points, Taksu, Singapore, 2011; Munnyfestation, Blanc, 2011; Collage Drop Outs, Finale Art File, 2011; I Miss the 20th Century, Manila Contemporary, 2011; Red, Mag:net Gallery Katipunan, 2011; Points of Ellipsis …, Osage Kwun Tong, Hong Kong, 2011; Complete and Unabridged, Institute for Contemporary Art Singapore, 2011; Abstraction Is Homeless, Manila Contemporary, 2012; Boxed, Nova Gallery, 2012; Juan Alcazaren’s Last Show, Finale Art File, 2012; and Abstraction Is Homeless, Manila Contemporary, 2013, and Art Stage Singapore, The Drawing Room Gallery, 2015.

Alcazaren’s short work Vexations was awarded second place in the Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Bidyo in 1996, resulting in its circulation in local and international festivals. Alcazaren was also a Juror’s Choice awardee for sculpture in the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition, 1993. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2000.   Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

FEDERICO AGUILAR ALCUAZ  (Federico Alcuaz Aguilar) was a painter and National Artist for visual arts. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 6 Jun 1932. He died on 2 Feb 2011. He was the son of Mariano Aguilar and Encarnacion Alcuaz. He was married to Ute Schmitz, a German, with whom he had three children. He finished early schooling at Dr Albert Elementary School and San Beda High School. He studied law at Ateneo de Manila University. He took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1949 and at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid. The latter was the Spanish Academy attended by a number of eminent Filipino painters of the 19th and early 20th centuries, such as Juan Luna, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, Fabian de la Rosa, and Fernando Amorsolo. Alcuaz stayed for long periods in Spain and Czechoslovakia. Although based abroad, either in Germany or Spain, he visited the Philippines often and donated paintings to UP, Ateneo de Manila University, San Beda, and other institutions.

Alcuaz is best known for his tapestries and abstract paintings, although he also produced figurative works like portraits, nudes, still lifes, and landscapes. In 1963, at his first solo exhibition, his abstracts were dark and convoluted, allusive of organic shapes, vegetal or visceral. They had the energy and spontaneity of the subconscious, but of unusually vivid colors and textures, with much of their visual pull emanating from the play of shapes. A prominent subject for his landscapes is the Walled City, of which he did a panoramic mural. Alcuaz’s memory hinged upon his deft draftsmanship and equally accomplished proclivity toward densely layered gestural and planar abstraction demonstrated throughout his peripatetic practice.

He had more than 40 exhibitions since 1963. In 1998, he had a solo exhibition at Galerie Borkowski, Hannover, Germany. Alcuaz suffered from chronic subdural hematoma in 2003 and recovered completely but stopped painting. The Ayala Museum in 2005 organized a one-man retrospective of his works titled Passionate Eyes. It featured 200 artworks from the collections of Benjamin Gayubar of Barcelona, Spain, and Eddie and Norma Chua of Quezon City. In 2008, Alcuaz and his family opened a collection of unexhibited works called Barcelona Series, consisting of paintings mostly done in the artist’s studio on Aragones St, Barcelona, Spain. Alcuaz’s works are included in the collections of some 20 museums and cultural institutions in the world today such as the Museum of Contemporary Art in Barcelona, the Museum of Contemporary Art of Madrid, the Gulbenkian Foundation Museum of London, the Museum of Modern Art of Warsaw, Poland, and the Philips Cultural Museum of Netherlands.

Alcuaz received the following awards: first prize for Roadside Squatters, Shell National Students Art Competition, 1954; Prix Montcada y Reixach, 1957; Prix Francisco Goya, 1958; Diplome d’Honneur, Exhibition Internationale d’Art Libre, Paris, 1961; second prize, Fourth Biennial of Tarrasas, Barcelona, Prix Vancell, 1964; Decoration of Arts, Letters and Sciences, French Government, 1964; Order of the French Genius, 1964; Republic Cultural Heritage Award, Philippines, 1965; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan and Araw ng Maynila Award from the city of Manila in 1966 and 1984, respectively.

In 2006, Alcuaz was given the Presidential Medal of Merit by the Philippine government for his outstanding contribution to visual arts. In 2009, he was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar and Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

EYASMIN ALMONTE (Eyasmin Bautista Almonte), also known as Yasmin Almonte, is a painter and art educator. She was born in Caloocan City on 14 Jan 1957. She is the stepdaughter of Juan Daniel Misa and daughter of Marcelina Barela Bautista. She has three children, one of whom is theater actress and educator Melissa-Vera “Missy” M. Maramara. She completed a master of art, 1996, at the University of Northern Iowa. She holds a baccalaureate degree in art, emphasis on art education, kinder to 12th grade, graduating summa cum laude, from the University of Northern Iowa and a bachelor of fine arts degree, major in painting, magna cum laude, from the University of the Philippines (UP). She was named as one of the 10 Outstanding Students of the Philippines by the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports in 1991.

Almonte is known for her large-scale figurative paintings which have represented the female form as vessels of both celebration and sufferance. Since publicly exhibiting her work in the early 1990s, she has painted women’s bodies not as passive objects but as testimonies of strength and survival. Over the years, her work sought symbolic and erotic parallels between corporeal forms and images of fruits and flowers. She also explored the use of mixed media and assemblage in shows such as Talambuhay (Biography), 2005, at the Liongoren Gallery, merging biographical and Biblical narratives and creating retablos (altarpieces) from found objects. Her mixed media on board series Ano Ka Ba Maria, Ba’t Ka Nahulog sa Grasya? (Hey Mary, Why Did You Fall from Grace?), 2006, delves into how the female form embodies trauma. She has also incorporated dance and performance in her exhibitions. Since 2010, she has also produced nonfigurative works on paper, departing from large, figurative paintings. Her solo show Ngiti (Smile), 2013, at the UP College of Fine Arts Gallery featured a series of small works on paper, wielding both color and gesture as cathartic and celebratory elements in her visual acts of expression.

Almonte’s works were exhibited in the Philippines and in the United States, beginning with her first show, I See Red, in 1993 at Hiraya Gallery. Other shows were at the Brix Gallery, Liongoren Gallery, Boston Gallery, Pinto Art Gallery, University of Northern Iowa in Cedar Falls, Ateneo de Manila University, and the UP Fine Arts Gallery. Her group exhibitions include the Asia-wide Women Imaging Women, 1999; the survey show 100 Filipina Artists, 2005; and the international art exhibition Trauma, Interrupted, 2007—all at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Almonte has also produced cover art for the childrens’ book series Philippine Heroes, 1993, produced by Tahanan Publications.

As art educator, she has formally taught at institutions such as the International School of Latvia, Ateneo de Manila University, and UP while facilitating art workshops. She is an associate professor at the UP College of Fine Arts and has received the Golden Jubilee Professorial Chair, 2013-14; Tito de Santos Professorial Chair, 2012; Fernando Amorsolo Professorial Chair, 2007; and the Diamond Jubilee Professorial Chair, 2005.

Almonte received an Award of Excellence from the 12th Shell National Students Art Competition in 1989. She has been a member of the group Kasibulan since 2004 and was involved with the Ilustrador ng Kabataan from 1992 to 1994. She is also a member of the Kappa Delta Pi Honor Society in Education, 1999, and the International Honor Society of Phi Kappa Pi.   Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

AUREO ALONZO (Aureo Roldan Alonzo) was a fashion designer. He was born in Navotas, Rizal on 19 Jul 1928. He died in Makati City on 7 Jul 2014. He was the son of Domingo Alonzo Sr and Sixta Roldan. Considered one of the top designers of the 1960s, Alonzo was a self-taught couturier known for his intricate beadwork and craftsmanship. As a young designer, he was fondly called “Niño Bonito” by the fashion promoter and head of the Karilagan fashion shows, Conchita Sunico. Members of Manila’s elite who modeled for Karilagan referred to him as “Auring.” Later in life, he would be known as “Tatang” to those working in the growing Philippine fashion industry and “Prince of Philippine Haute Couture” to the lifestyle media. A tribute titled A Toast to the Prince of Philippine Haute Couture was staged by his colleagues in Nov 2013.

Alonzo began as a hair stylist, putting up a beauty parlor after studying at the Helen Curtis School in Manila. However, he continued to make cocktail dresses for his five sisters and the praise lavished upon his home-sewn creations encouraged Alonzo to open his own dress shop. An early member of the Philippine Couture Association, his work garnered international acclaim through the Karilagan shows produced by Sunico in the 1960s. In the 1970s, Alonzo regularly participated in Fiesta Filipina, a traveling showcase of Philippine contemporary fashion and costume initiated by the travel and aviation entrepreneur Roquito Ablan. In 1975, he won the Camel Award of International High Fashion in Servignio, Italy, where, as the only Asian in competition, his work was judged by Yves Saint Laurent, British bespoke tailor Henry Poole, and American sculptor Beverly Pepper. In December of that same year, he was also given the Premio Internazionale Cavalieri della Nuova Europa (International Prize of the Knights of New Europe) at the Palazzo Barberini in Rome.

Aside from his high society clientele, which included Philippine first ladies and Princess Margaret of England, Alonzo’s richly beaded and embroidered garments would also adorn statues of the Virgin Mary. As a devotee, he dressed the Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception at the Manila Cathedral, Our Lady of La Naval at the Santo Domingo Church in Quezon City, the Virgin of Manaoag in Pangasinan, and the Our Lady of Peace and Good Voyage in Antipolo, among other venerated Marian images.   Written by Alice Sarmiento

NUNELUCIO ALVARADO (Nunelucio Pagubayan Alvarado), also known as Nune Alvarado, is a painter. He was born in Fabrika, Sagay City, Negros Occidental on 5 May 1950. He is the son of Tomas Alvarado and Paula Pagubayan. He married Rosalia Daanoy. He received the Kabayao-Ledesma Scholarship Grant in Painting as a fine arts student at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. He also studied advertising at the La Consolacion College School of Architecture and Fine Arts, Bacolod City. Since 1980 he has been active as founding member of organizations like the Black Artists of Asia and Pamilya Pintura. He also founded the Pintor Kulapol in Fabrica in 1988.

Much of Alvarado’s work has dwelt on the plight of the sakada (seasonal cane workers). A striking aspect of his work is his original style of figuration. He has developed a style suitable to his folk subjects—the peasants and farm laborers, which he depicts as squat and angular to show their closeness to the earth as well as their strength in production. He uses vivid colors to enhance the sense of vitality and energy, while conveying strong emotion. More importantly, the artist uses symbols to convey the inimical forces that surround them: the crocodile at the heart of the sugarcane field, the thorns in the cornfields. He shows peasants in family groups, often in mourning over the grave of the victim of the harsh society. His peasant figures show strength and defiance that is at the same time dignified and moving. In recent works, he has combined painting with elements of installation. Alvarado has worked in terra-cotta, as well as popularized silkscreened T-shirts with strong folk-social themes from the sugar industry.

These groups have stimulated artists’ social involvement in the rural communities. He has had many solo exhibitions of works of strong social impact. His first show was Hampang-Hampang Lang ’Ni Pero Tuod Tuod (Playful But True), 1979, Sining Kamalig, Manila. His other solo exhibits include Welcome to Your Nightmare, 1980, Manila Hotel; Kabayehan sa Uma (Women on the Farm), 1981, Heritage Art Center, Quezon City; Kaupod (Companion), 1982, Hiraya Art Gallery, Manila; Gilok (Itch-Inducing Substance), 1990, UP Visayas Art Gallery, lloilo City; Piesta: Art Common, 1992, Barangay Fabrica, Negros Occidental; Tagimata (Mirage), both in 2000, Metropolitan Museum of Manila and Atelier Frank & Lee, Singapore. He has also taken part in major group exhibitions in the country such as Piglas: Art at the Crossroads (To Be Free: Art at the Crossroads), 1986, and Terra non Terra (Earth Ground), 1992, both at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, Manila. He did shows abroad in collaboration with Australian artist George Gittoes and Tokyo-based artist Theresa Kabayashi.

Alvarado was among the Thirteen Artists awardees of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1992 and the nine Philippine representatives to the First Asia Pacific Triennial in Brisbane, Australia, in 1993. In 1997 and 1999, he won grand prize in the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards. In 2004, he was honored by the city of Manila with the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Rosalinda Galang, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro and Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

Sources
