EMILIO ALVERO (Emilio Vera Alvero) was a painter and sculptor. He was born in Quiapo, Manila on 8 Feb 1886. He died in 1955. He married Rosa Sevilla, writer and founder of the Instituto de Mujeres. Among the couple’s children was Aurelio Alvero, a poet and renowned art collector who wrote his poetry and art criticism under the nom de plume “Magtanggol Asa.” Emilio Alvero finished his basic education at the Quiapo Parochial School. He studied painting privately under Lorenzo Guerrero, sculpture under Romualdo de Jesus, and scenographic painting under Cesare Alberoni. He was a contemporary of Fernando Amorsolo and Alejandro Cawed at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts.

As a painter, Alvero is known for his realistic still lifes. In Excursion, Alvero’s subject matter is boiled rice rendered so realistically, complete with spilled vinegar rolling down a banana leaf. Alvero’s Table Delicacies, 1928, is outstanding not only because of the realism of the dish of tuna, the cantaloupe, and the basket of vegetables in the background, but also because the composition consists of mostly oval shapes which are echoed in the oval shape of the painting itself and the concave glass cover of the painting. At least six other still life paintings by this artist are preserved, one remarkable for its portrayal of makopa and balimbing, another a rich person’s setting of sumptuous dishes laid out on a realistically depicted crocheted table mantel.

Alvero also painted other scenes. A Nipa Hut, which is outstanding for its realistic capturing of the rugged materials of the house, is in the Lourdes V. Ongpin collection. He also depicted the Catafalque of Jose Mabesa in Hongkong in oil, also found in the same collection.

Alvero is also known to have designed houses, such as that of Dr Santiago Barcelona in San Juan, Manila.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar

FERNANDO AMORSOLO (Fernando Cueto Amorsolo) was a painter and a National Artist for visual arts. He was born in Paco, Manila on 30 May 1892. He died in Manila on 26 Feb 1972. He is the son of Pedro Amorsolo, a bookkeeper, and Bonifacia Cueto. His younger brother is the painter Pablo Amorsolo. He married Salud Jorge in 1916, and they had six children. When Salud died in 1931, Amorsolo married Maria del Carmen, with whom he had eight children. He spent his youthful days in Daet, Camarines Norte. When his father died, his mother moved the entire family to Manila to live with her first cousin, painter Fabian de la Rosa. To raise money, Amorsolo sold watercolor postcards to a bookstore which paid him 10 centavos a piece, while his mother took on embroidery. Somehow he managed to complete his schooling at the Liceo de Manila, where he gained honors, especially in drawing and painting. At 17, he enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, where his uncle taught. He was one of its first graduates in 1919, receiving several medals for excellence. During his college days he was influenced by the works of the Spanish painter Diego Velazquez and other European painters, such as Sargent, Zorn, Sorolla, and Zuloaga. While a student, Amorsolo lived in a rented accesoria (row houses) and, in order to survive, joined competitions and did illustrations for publications like Severino Reyes’s first novel, Parusa ng Diyos (God’s Punishment). He also designed chairs for the Bureau of Public Works. Upon graduation, he became an instructor at UP, while continuing as a draftsman at the Public Works and chief artist of Pacific Commercial.

For 38 years, he taught at the UP School of Fine Arts, and served as its director, 1938-52. He was such a formidable influence that his younger brother Pablo had to make a conscious effort not to imitate him. In 1916, entrepreneur Enrique Zobel de Ayala gave him a grant to visit Spain, Europe, and the United States. In 1922, Amorsolo made his first important painting, Rice Planting, which became one of the most popular images of the Commonwealth period, appearing in several versions in calendars, posters, and tourist brochures. During his peak years in the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s, he widely exhibited both in the Philippines and abroad, including New York and Belgium. His works covered a wide range which included portraits, landscapes, and genre. He also did illustrations for children’s textbooks and novels, commercial designs, cartoons for the magazine The Independent, and illustrations for Philippine Magazine and Telembang, Renacimiento Filipino, and Excelsior. In his canvases, Amorsolo popularized the image of the beautiful and modest dalagang Filipina (Filipino maiden) in her traditional domestic roles. Of great influence was his ideal feminine type: the smiling, young woman of fair complexion and slender figure, wearing a colorful native costume which showed no sign of wear and tear from work and the tropical weather. He idealized the peasant, whom he situated in a rural idyll where nature was ever bountiful, and hunger and strife were unknown. He was the first to extensively portray traditional Filipino customs and manners, fiestas, and occupations like fishing, planting, going to market, washing laundry, cooking, and reading. He also did a series of historical canvases on precolonial scenes, such as Early Filipino State Wedding, Traders, and Sikatuna, as well as events surrounding the colonization of the Philippines, such as The First Mass in the Philippines, The Building of Intramuros, and Burning of the Idol. At one point, these works, had come under criticism, specifically in the way Muslim women had been represented. Nonetheless, these images have been reproduced in many textbooks and calendars, and have shaped the visual imagination of many generations of Filipino children.

Amorsolo is credited with having captured the elusive quality of Philippine light. In his landscapes and genre paintings, he used the technique of backlighting in which the figures are situated against the light, thus outlining them with a golden glow. He preferred to paint in natural light, learning to be quick and decisive in his work since “light changes rapidly and you have to be fast in order to catch the mood with which you started out.” In the 1930s, he was earning enough from his painting that he gave up commercial art work. His idyllic genre scenes were a favorite with American officials and visitors in search of tropical exotica. A master of portraiture, he was lionized by the moneyed and powerful for whom he painted countless works. Over the years, he took to photographing his works, mounted them in an album, and asked prospective patrons to choose what they wanted and indicate the size they needed. Amorsolo did not make exact replicas, varying some elements in the painting. The volume of paintings, not to mention sketches and studies, that came from Amorsolo is formidable.

A complete listing of his works is yet to be made. Some have unfortunately been lost or stolen. In 1999, the mural he painted for the Metropolitan Theater, History of Music, was restored. Also remarkable was his speed at executing his works—three life-size paintings for the Philippine Pavilion in the 1931 Paris Exposition were finished in less than a month. In the 1950s till his death, he averaged 10 paintings a month; but during his final years, diabetes and cataracts and the death of two sons affected his works. When another generation of Filipino painters wanted to break new paths in the 1930s, it took the form of a revolt against the Amorsolo school, which had been dominant for at least three decades. Modernism arose largely as a reaction to Amorsolo’s style. He and sculptor Guillermo Tolentino were the objects of a diatribe led by such moderns as Victorio Edades and Galo B. Ocampo.

After his death, Amorsolo’s achievements were commemorated in numerous exhibitions. In May 1975, the National Museum held an Amorsolo retrospective. In Jun 1989, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila held an exhibit titled Lupang Hinirang: Alay ni Amorsolo (Chosen Land: Amorsolo’s Offering). In celebration of Amorsolo’s centennial year, the Presidential Commission on Culture and Arts launched the Amorsolo Centennial in May 1992 at Galleria de las Islas, El Amanecer, Intramuros, Manila. In the same year, a number of exhibitions followed: The Corporate Amorsolo, Ayala Museum; Amorsolo Drawings, Lopez Museum; and Larawan (Portrait), National Museum. In 1993, the works of Amorsolo and his children and grandchildren titled The Amorsolo Legacy were shown in the PICC Art Gallery. In 2000, the exhibit Fernando, Fernando was shown in Ayala Museum; in 2002, Brush with History was shown in the same museum. In 2006, the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco, USA, exhibited Pioneers of Philippine Art: Luna, Amorsolo, Zobel. In 2008, a seven-museum retrospective exhibit on Amorsolo titled His Art, Our Heart was organized by Ayala Museum, GSIS Museum of Art, Lopez Memorial Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, National Museum of the Philippines, UP Jorge B. Vargas Museum and Filipiniana Research Center, and Yuchengco Museum.

Among the honors he received are: the Outstanding UP Alumnus Award, 1940; the Rizal Pro-Patria Award, 1961; an honorary doctorate in the humanities from the Far Eastern University, 1961; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila, 1963; the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, 1967; and the Gawad CCP para sa Sining, 1972. In 1973, he became the first artist to be proclaimed National Artist. After his death, Amorsolo received the CCP Centennial Honor for the Arts in 1999 and the Parangal Sentenyal from the University of the Philippines in 2008.   Written by Rene B. Javellana, Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

 

Source

 

Amorsolo, Fernando. 2013. Website. Accessed 22 May. www.fernandoamorsolo.com.

PABLO AMORSOLO (Pablo Cueto Amorsolo) was a painter. He was born in Daet, Camarines Norte on 26 Jun 1898. He died in Antipolo, Rizal in 1945. His parents were Pedro Amorsolo and Bonifacia Cueto. When he was eight, his family went to Manila where he studied drawing under the tutelage of his uncle, Fabian de la Rosa. His brother, Fernando Amorsolo, like their uncle, was also a master painter and was known for his pastoral scenes and portraits. Pablo Amorsolo completed elementary and secondary schooling at Liceo de Manila, and graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1924. Two years later, he was appointed assistant instructor in the UP School of Fine Arts, where he taught until World War II broke out.

Amorsolo, while admiring classical art, also strongly advocated modern art. In the 1930s, he was one of the most prolific editorial pen-and-ink illustrators for such publications as the Graphic, Tribune, La Vanguardia, and Herald. He also served as artist for the Manila Times. His illustrations, which portrayed a wide variety of domestic and social situations, contributed to the rise of genre art in the country.

When portraits were in vogue during the pre-World War II years, Amorsolo was one of the best portrait painters. His skilled brushwork could breathe life into his subjects, which he painted truthfully and without idealization. He painted subjects from all social classes and age levels. It was in these portraits that he showed his deep understanding of distinct human personalities. Historical subjects also interested him, as seen in his paintings Magellan and the Natives and The Discovery of the Philippines, a large-scale piece painted in 1944. Few of Pablo Amorsolo’s paintings are extant because a large number of his works were destroyed in a fire in 1945.

Pablo sincerely advocated the Greater East-Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere and served as a colonel in the Kempetai. When the Americans returned, he was captured by Philippine troops and was killed by a guerrilla firing squad in Antipolo.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar and Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

RONALD ANADING (Ronald Capito Anading), also known as Poklong Anading, is a visual Artist. He was born in Manila on 1 Aug 1975. He is the son of Delia Capito and Arnold Seña Anading, both deceased. Anading graduated from secondary school from the Marikina Institute of Science and Technology in 1992, then proceeded to the University of Santo Tomas for a year of studies in Electrical Engineering, before transferring to the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts to finish his Studio Arts degree in 1999.

Anading is primarily known for his installations and video work taking on objects and experiences from everyday life and translating these into visual as well as tactile statements that draw from common sense and streetwise wit. For instance, in the work Road to Mountains, 2015, he assembles a collection of disused rubber tires ubiquitously used across the country as makeshift speedbumps. In displacing these roadside obstacles to instead become a static display in a gallery, he not only makes them visible but indirectly evokes the contradictions present in runaway urbanization and survivalist tactics. His broad body of work also employs photography, drawing, painting, and performative aspects particularly in mediatized form.

Anading’s work has appeared in local and international group exhibitions including Three Chairs, Big Sky Mind, Quezon City, 2000; Video Programme 2002-Video Art from Asia, Nikolaj Contemporary Art Center, Copenhagen and The 4th Gwangju Biennale: Pause, Gwangju, 2002; Flippin’ Out: Maynila to Williamsburgh, Goliath Visual Space, New York, 2005; Metropolitan Mapping, Hong Kong Cultural Centre, 2006; Coffee, Cigarettes and Pad Thai, Contemporary Art in Southeast Asia, Eslite Gallery, Taipei, Taiwan, and Room 307: Inkling, Gutfeel & Hunch, National Art Gallery, Manila, 2008; Jakarta Biennale 2009: Fluid Zone, Indonesia, 2009; The Sta. Mesa Diaries, Centre for Contemporary Photography, Victoria, 2011; Phantoms of Asia: Contemporary Awakens the Past, Asian Art Museum, San Francisco, 2012; No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York, Move on Asia, Video Art in Asia 2002-2012, ZKM Zentrum fur Kunst und Medientechnologie, Karlsruhe, Sharjah Biennal 11: Re:emerge, Sharjah, and Glitch in the System, The 8th Vladivostok Biennale of Visual Arts, 2013; What does it all matter as long as the wounds fit the arrows, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), Manila, 2014; 5th Asian Art Biennial:Artist Making Movement, National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts, Taichung, and Video Spotlight: Philippines, Asia Society, New York, 2015.

Anading’s solo exhibitions include Disappearance Resonates, Theo Gallery, Makati City, Anonymity, Finale Gallery, Mandaluyong City, Visible Darkness, National Commission on Culture and the Arts, Manila, 2005; Anonymity, The Cross Art Projects, Sydney, Faulty Wings, Future Prospects, Quezon City, and Blindspot, Mag:net Gallery, Makati City, 2006; Between Intersections, Ateneo Art Gallery, 2007; Fallen Map, Mag:net Gallery, Quezon City, 2008; Drunken Revelry, Ateneo Art Gallery, Tattooed Heart, Mag:net Gallery Katipunan, Quezon City, and Untitled (Landmark), West Gallery, Quezon City, 2009; pocket coffin, Galerie Zimmermann Kratochwill, Graz, Austria, 2012; Copy Select All, Selasar Sunaryo Art Space, Bandung, Indonesia, every water is an island, Bangkok University Gallery, locus, Silverlens, Gillman Barracks, Singapore, 2013; and Urban Canyon, 1335MABINI, Manila, 2015.

Among Anading’s awards are the 12th Gawad Cultural Center of the Philippines citation for Experimental Video, 2000, and the Ateneo Art Award, 2006 and 2008, which afforded him residencies at The Kings Cross Art Project in Sydney, Australia, Common Networks Foundation in Bandung, Indonesia, and in the Centre Intermondes in La Rochelle, France. Anading received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2006.   Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Isidro Ancheta (Isidro Gabriel Ancheta) was a painter. He was born in San Miguel, Manila on 15 Oct 1882. He died on 1 Apr 1949. He finished elementary and secondary education as well as a bachiller en artes (bachelor of arts) at Ateneo de Manila, his tertiary degree obtained in 1904. He studied art at Liceo de Manila, Escuela de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado, and the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura run by Teodoro P. Buenaventura in the early 1900s. He was represented with eight paintings in the Philippine section at the Saint Louis Universal Exposition, 1904. He taught at the Philippine Normal School from 1918 to 1926. Before World War II, his landscape paintings were found in classrooms all over the country.

Reared in the academic tradition, Ancheta drew his subjects through firm lines, solidly defined shapes, and a realistic but dark palette. His earliest phase from early 1900 to the 1920s was his most outstanding. This period produced the views of various gates of the Walls of Intramuros of which one version is in the Central Bank Collection. This piece is remarkable for its organization of shapes, the interplay of light and dark to suggest depth, and the pleasant combination of yellow, brown, green, and pinks that realistically render the thriving foliage on the walls. In the 1930s, Ancheta began painting seashore scenes of fishing boats. These pieces demonstrate how his colors became richer pastel shades of pink, orange, and lavender.

Ancheta’s A Victim of War received an honorable mention at the Universal Exposition in Saint Louis, Missouri, in 1904. In 1941, his Tienda del Barrio (Barrio Store) won second honorable mention in the Filipiniana category of the National Art Competition sponsored by the University of Santo Tomas.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar

ANG KIUKOK was a painter and National Artist for visual arts. He was born in Davao City on 1 Mar 1931. He died in Quezon City on 9 May 2005. He was born to immigrant Chinese parents, Ang Sy Pang and Lim Chen. He was married to Mary de Jesus, an accountant, and they had four children. His father ran an abaca, dry goods, and grocery business in Davao. Ang Kiukok was originally named Hua Shing (Chinese born) but an elder cousin had a similar name so he was renamed Kiukok (save the country) amidst the japanese invasion of manchuria in sep 1931 in China. He started school at the age of five in Davao Chinese High School where he met Tan Kok King, a Chinese from China who taught arts and crafts, and who selected Ang as a promising student. In 1947, he was an unpaid apprentice to an itinerant commercial artist and they painted billboards for movie houses in Cotobato. He convinced his father to support him for a year in art studies and in 1952, he went to Manila and enrolled in the University of Santo Tomas (UST), as a special status student, where he met Ong Bungian. The Chinese students taking up art in UST during this period included Antonio Austria, Veronica Lim, Ting Ping Lay, and James Ong Le Pho. Ang’s teachers in UST were Diosdado Lorenzo for life drawing class; Victorio Edades, life painting class; Jose garcia Llamas, portraiture; and Francesco Monti, sculpture. He also studied under galo Ocampo, Virginia Ty, and Bonifacio Cristobal. He had to stop his studies in 1954 as his father’s store was affected by the nationalization of retail trade under the Magsaysay administration. Ang became a Filipino citizen in 1975.

He taught art in 1956 in Sulu for overseas Chinese children. Back in Manila, he stayed in Wellington Building in Binondo and got an art teacher job at Sam Bin Chinese Elementary School in Azcarraga. In 1963, he was teaching art at Chiang Kai Shek High School on Abad santos St, Manila. He was an artist with the Ramon Roces publications with Manansala. He assisted Manansala in painting the murals of the Chapel of the Holy sacrifice in University of the Philippines Diliman.

On 10 Dec 1954, Ang held his first one-man show, Ang Kiukok: Watercolors, at Manuel Rodriguez’s Contemporary Art Gallery on Mabini St, Manila. He exhibited 29 watercolors and two oil paintings. In 1957, he had his second solo exhibition at Lyd Arguilla’s Philippine Art gallery and showed Pieta and Moro Boats among his works. On 3 Dec 1959, he held his third solo exhibition in the opening of a new department store, DRB (Del Rosario Brothers) Building, on Santa Mesa Blvd. In Oct 1964, the Museum of Modern Art in Hawaii acquired some of his works. In 1966, he had a one-man show at the Luz gallery. The National Manpower and Youth Council commissioned him to do the mural Men at Work in 1979.

He is known for his expressionistic interpretations of themes, like the mother and child, Christ crucified or suffering, heaps of junk, roosters crowing, dogs fighting, and a couple making love. In 2000, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila held Ang Kiukok’s first retrospective. Other recent exhibits include New Works, 2004, Finale Art Gallery, and Kiukok: Recent Works 2000-2004, 2005, SM Megamall Art Center through Finale Art Gallery. In 2005, the Museum of De La salle University sponsored an exhibition titled Homage to ang Kiukok, which featured 50 paintings from the Ang family collection and Wili and Doreen Fernandez’s art collection.

In 1955, he won third prize in the modernist category for a watercolor titled calesa (Horse-Drawn Carriage) in the Fifth Shell National Students Art Competition. He received a 100-peso check from First Lady Luz Banzon Magsaysay. He was awarded several times by the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP). In 1959, his oil painting Blind Musicians received a special award at the AAP 12th Annual Art Exhibition; in the same year, his still life was awarded honorable mention at the AAP’s semiannual art exhibition. He was commissioned to paint a mural at the Davao Insular Hotel in 1961, the same year he was selected as an Outstanding Overseas Chinese in Art in Taipei. He was awarded a bronze medal in 1962 for his Pieta at the First International Art Exhibition in saigon, Vietnam. Ang won second prize for his work Fish at the 16th AAP Annual Show in 1963 and third prize for an oil painting, Still Life in red, at the AAP semiannual show in 1964. In 1976, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila. In 1978, he was given an outstanding alumnus award by the University of Santo Tomas. He received the silver medal at the Mobil Art Awards in 1980 for his images of modern angst. In 1990, he was featured with Onib Olmedo and Solomon Saprid in a show titled Three Figurative Expressionists held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). He was conferred the title National Artist for visual arts in 2001. In 2002, he received the Jose Rizal Award for excellence from the Manila Times and Kaisa Foundation. His works are displayed in various collections, such as the Philippine National Museum, the Ateneo Art Gallery, the CCP, and the National Historical Commission in Taipei.   Written by R. Chu, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

TORIBIO ANTILLON (Toribio Asona Antillon) was a painter. He was born in San Juan, La Union on 1 Nov 1856. He died on 19 Sep 1913. He was the son of Eriberto Antillon and Maria Asona, both of Ermita, Manila. Antillon married Margarita Borja and they had a daughter, Concepcion.

Antillon studied at the Escuela Normal de Maestros, 1872-74, at the same time that he enrolled at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura. While still a student, he apprenticed under two scenographic painters, Giovanni Dibella and Cesare Alberoni, who traveled to Manila with an Italian opera troupe. Staying in the Philippines, the two Italians painted drop curtains for operatic presentations. When they began accepting contracts to decorate the interiors of private homes, public buildings, and churches, Antillon became their assistant.

Antillon later established a shop of his own and developed his own clientele. He executed decorative paintings for the Teatro de Variedades and Teatro de Tondo in Manila; the telones (backdrops) used during the inauguration of the Teatro Zorrilla in 1893; murals, ceiling and panel works for Ateneo de Manila, Colegio de San Juan de Letran, and Colegio de San Francisco Javier.

Tagalog drama flourished as a reaction to the American occupation at the beginning of the 20th century, and Antillon’s services were in great demand. For instance, he painted the drop-curtains for the production of Pedro Paterno’s Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), the first Filipino opera that debuted on 16 Aug 1902.

Antillon painted the interiors of the churches of San Sebastian, Ermita, and Malate in Manila; of Daraga, Tabaco, and Guinobatan in Albay; of Batangas, Bauan, and Taal in Batangas; and of San Fernando and Guagua in Pampanga. He also painted the ceiling of the old church of Antipolo, Rizal. Antillon was also well known for decorating house interiors for upper-class Filipinos at the time. His decorative works are reputed to have “liveliness, a transparency, and delicacy.” Unfortunately, few of his works survive today.

Antillon also worked in watercolor and taught the art to a number of students, among them Juan Abelardo, who later became a backdrop painter himself.   Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

ANGELITO ANTONIO (Angelito Garcia Antonio) is a painter and art educator. He was born in Malolos, Bulacan on 3 Feb 1939. He is the son of Mariano Antonio, painter, decorator, and clothes designer, and Virginia Garcia. He married painter Norma Belleza. In 1963, he received a bachelor of fine arts degree from the University of Santo Tomas (UST), where he subsequently taught from 1963 to 1979.

Antonio started out with a black-and-white series but later developed his own color schemes. While some of his works bear a hue that can be described as “acidic yellow,” he used black charcoal-like strokes and strong color as a structuring principle in his works. One of his series demonstrated how he would experiment with particular hues to delineate figures. His subjects revolved around folk genre, which included cockfighters, vendors, ice cream peddlers, and balloon sellers. In the 1960s and 1970s, he also focused on street confrontations, which were expressive of the political temper of the time.

Many of Antonio’s works show the influence of Vicente Manansala, in the style evident in the latter’s Neo-Realist and cubist tendencies. The affinity is also present in terms of subject—namely, folk genre. It is by way of these explorations and proposed deviations that Antonio has, through the years, developed a style distinctly his own.

His works were first exhibited in the Philippine Art Gallery. Antonio continues to hold exhibitions and shows such as Masters of Modernism: Angelito Antonio, 2013, at Galerie Joaquin and La Musique (The Music), 2014, with Michael Cacnio and Dominic Rubio, at Galerie Stephanie, Libis.

Antonio received awards in the Shell National Students Art Competition: third prize, The Beginning Is Green, 1958; second prize, Kristo (Christ), 1963; and certificate of merit, Mag-iisda (Fish Seller), 1964. His awards from the Art Association of the Philippines include the following: third prize, Mananahi (Seamstress), 1962; second prize, Deposition, 1963; honorable mention, He, 1969; first prize, Oracion (Evening Prayer), 1970; special award, Procession, 1970; and major award, Pangarap sa Buhay (Life’s Dream), 1972. He won first prize in the Travellers Life art competition, 1961; first prize in the UST 300th Anniversary, 1962; second prize in the Travellers Life art competition, 1963; and first prize in the Philippine Airlines art contest, 1968. He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1970. He was given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila in 1984.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

HAJA AMINA APPI was a mat weaver. She was born in Tandubas, Tawi-Tawi on 5 Jun 1925. She died on 2 Apr 2013. Her parents were Abubakar Bitao and Malak I. Bitao. Appi belongs to the Sama indigenous group from Tawi-Tawi, where the knowledge and practice of mat weaving is traditionally upheld by women in the community. From harvesting and preparing the pandan (pandanus) leaves, to designing and weaving the mat, the women in the Sama culture are knowledge-bearers of the materials, processes, and mat designs that abide by the principles of applied mathematics. Although Appi uses the traditional processes of mat weaving, she has also introduced innovative designs through the Sama mats, which in her hands take three months to create.

First, wild pandan leaves are harvested from the forest, preferably the thorny leaf variety that produces stronger and sturdier matting strips. Appi used a jangat deyum or stripper to make long and even strips from the pandan leaves that were then left to dry under the sun for three to four days. Using a large log, the strips were made to go through the process of pinaggos (pressing) until these became pliant enough for weaving. The strips were then dyed by boiling in a vat with hot water mixed with anjibi or commercial powder dye. Appi created colorful mats featuring complex geometric patterns with a sense of symmetry and proportion. Not satisfied with the color saturation of commercial dyes, she was known to have experimented with the use of anjibi in creating her own color palette and developing her own tints to obtain the strong and vibrant hues she preferred in her creations. She favored the colors red, purple, and yellow, featuring up to eight colors for a complicated design.

The process of weaving starts from the central strip to form the mat’s backbone, expanding outward to the tabig or edges, keeping in mind the principles of symmetry wherein the geometric designs mirror or complement each other. Working on a base of 10-20 strips, Appi used strong visualization techniques in creating the designs, rather than relying on any mathematical formula. A plain white outer mat served as backing for the colorful woven mat she made.

Appi was awarded the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA in 2004. Before Appi’s passing in 2013, she was able to share her knowledge with her daughters and granddaughters, who remember her as a patient and gentle teacher who strove for perfection and had a sense of pride in the art of mat weaving.   Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Maricris Jan Tobias and Rizzi Gorospe

ALFREDO AQUILIZAN / ISABEL AQUILIZAN (Alfredo Juan Doran Aquilizan / Maria Isabel Gaudinez-Aquilizan) are visual artists. He was born in Cagayan Valley on 31 Jan 1962, while she was born in Manila on 11 Oct 1965. Alfredo’s parents are Alfredo A. Aquilizan and Iluminada Doran, while Isabel’s parents are Florencio Gaudinez and Aurora Constantino. The Aquilizans are married and have five children. Their son Miguel is also an artist. They live and work in Brisbane, Australia. Alfredo received his bachelor of fine arts from the Philippine Women’s University in 1986. He finished his master of fine arts at Anglia Polytechnic University in Norwich, United Kingdom, in 1997 and his doctor’s degree at Queensland College of Art in Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia, in 2012. Isabel received her degree in communication arts, major in theater arts production, from Assumption College. Alfredo and Isabel have taught visual and theater arts respectively at the Philippine High School for the Arts. Alfredo also taught at the University of the Philippines Los Baños.

Together, they create collaborative art projects that invite reflection on notions of identity, home, culture, and community. Their works are largely shaped by their experience of displacement and migration, having to relocate to Australia in 2006 to earn a living and raise a growing family. Often process-based, their installations relate to their condition as artists in transit to accomplish projects even while tending to their own home. From 1997 to 2007, they worked on Be-longing, a cumulative project involving the participation of communities they worked with through the collection of materials, to other aspects of their creative process which includes sharing personal stories revealing what these mostly domestic objects mean to their owners and why they would be willing to part with them as part of the Aquilizans’ assemblages and installations. The materials they use are often recyclable or ephemeral; they may also be mundane objects collected over time. Personal possessions are employed to harness referential qualities, to evoke ideas about the act of remembrance itself. Project Be-longing # 2 consisting of salt, household items, sound and olfactory elements, was installed as part of the Third Asia Pacific Triennial (APT) of Contemporary Art, 1999. Presences and Absences involved gathering thousands of toothbrushes that were put together in an installation for the 6th Havana Biennial in Cuba, 1998. The objects they install are imbued with personal or collective narratives, as exemplified by Wings, 2009, a work comprised of translucent slippers collected from Singaporean prison inmates. These objects were fashioned into angels’ wings as an expression of yearning for freedom. Another example is the Dream Blanket Project, a dense and orderly arrangement of blankets coupled with sound articulating the dreams of its participants. It was exhibited in Manila and Busan in 2002, and in Queensland and the Echigo-Tsumari Art Triennale in 2006.

The movement of things, people, and ideas in the contemporary world is a recurring theme in the work of the Aquilizans. Another Country gave rise to projects such as Address, an installation of the artists’ personal things formed into a large cube; In-habit, where a miniature city of cardboard boxes encroach upon the exhibition space; and In-flight a project for APT 6, 2009, which used recycled materials and involved museum visitors co-creating handheld airplane toys. Also launched in 2009, the Mabini Art Project reconfigured landscape paintings the Aquilizans purchased from Antonio Calma into a room-size installation that contemplates the transvaluation of art. 100 Paintings, an offshoot of the aforementioned work, was exhibited as part of the Sharjah Biennial in 2013 and is part of the Ateneo Art Gallery collection.

The Aquilizans have been invited to participate in numerous international biennials and triennials across the world. In 2003, their work titled Project M201: In God We Trust was exhibited as part of the Zone of Urgency in the 50th Venice Biennale.   Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

RENE AQUITANIA (Rene Mallari Aquitania) is a performance artist. He was born in Baguio City on 18 Aug 1961. He is the youngest child of Carlos Padrique Aquitania and Juanita Naku Mallari. Aquitania’s art encompasses theater, performance, installation, printmaking, and painting. He was introduced to art by older cousins Bayard Aquitania (of the now defunct Baguio Arts Council) and Benjie Mallari. Although he spent a semester at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts, he is essentially self-taught. He is well-read and with substantial exposure to protest organizations and artists from academe and cultural institutions. He takes inspiration from nature and what he calls the “ephemeral world of spirits.”

He is known for striking performances done as part of the protest movement in the politically charged atmosphere of the Philippines ca 1980-90. He performed in a variety of venues: streets, parks, Malate bars, the Cultural Center of Philippines (CCP) Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino (also known as the CCP Little Theater), Music Museum, Pinaglabanan Gallery in Manila, and Café Amapola’s Renaissance Gallery in Baguio. In 1980, he served as resource person for Makiling-trained and CCP artists bound for theater performances and art events in Baguio. He enrolled in UP when Jose Joya was dean of the College of Fine Arts, but the economic and political turmoil triggered by the death of Ninoy Aquino in 1983 found him out of school and back in Baguio. He then started earnestly performing his pieces; getting ideas for concepts from reading papers on issues of the day, from Japanese Kabuki theater, and from fellow Baguio artist Roberto Villanueva. Aquitania and Villanueva were engaged in a form of community art making in and around Baguio as BenCab, Santiago Bose, Kidlat Tahimik, and Katrin de Guia all decided to settle in the city. These artists along with David Barradas, Tommy Hafalla, Willy Magtibay, Briccio Santos, and Vince Villareal became the core founders of the Baguio Arts Guild in 1987.

Finding himself in Belgium after the 1990 Baguio earthquake, Aquitania took formal studies in printmaking. Upon returning to the Philippines, he taught theater and printmaking in poverty-stricken communities at art workshops with the Baguio Arts Guild. He then immersed himself for two years in a Cavite slum. It was during this period that his work consisted of the ritualistic cleaning up of abandoned public spaces and turning these into active art spaces. Of the more formal and documented of his performances, the most prominent is Art for Peace, 1986. This was a 129-mile walk done over five days straight on the highway from Baguio to the CCP during which Aquitania was lugging a makeshift vegetable pushcart. Objects accumulated during this journey was displayed along with the pushcart in a group exhibition at the CCP titled “The Nature of Influence.” Another work, Proposal: Tocucan Bridge, 1992, was performed a few times as part of Ballet Philippines’ Neo-Filipino program at the CCP Little Theater. The concept for this piece comes out of a Cordillera rite that brought two tribes together through the act of making a bridge to span the breadth of the river separating them.

The participatory aspects of Aquitania’s work surfaced when he was in his 20s, when he began collaborating with ballerinas schooled in the classical tradition, Pinoy rock stars, street children, and beggars. This willingness to engage various publics informed by a consistent desire to conflate art making and everyday life continues to influence the practice of emergent performance, film, and visual artists both within and beyond Baguio, which continues to be Aquitania’s work base and home.   Written by Kelly P. Ramos
