FIDEL ARANETA (Fidel Trinidad Araneta) was a sculptor. He was born in Cebu on 24 Dec 1912. He died in Bogo, Cebu on 29 Oct 1975. He studied fine arts at the University of the Philippines, 1932-34. At the age of 26, his works attracted the attention of the American press and was featured in magazines such as Sculpture Outside and Inside New York. He is credited with having made the main altar of the Cebu City Cathedral. He operated the Araneta Sculptural Works Studio in Cebu City and is acknowledged as the first mentor of Napoleon V. Abueva, National Artist for visual arts.

Araneta is also known for portraiture. His style may be described as impressionistic, as in a sketch that captures the essence of the subject but without the rendition being thoroughly detailed. His Ike, 1953, on wood, at the National Museum is a good example, perhaps based on a line drawing of American president Dwight Eisenhower laughing heartily. Araneta enlivened this work through the use of texture, obtained by minutely chiseling the expanse of the entire surface. The artist has two other works at the National Museum—namely, Portrait of Sergio Osmeña, 1952, and Bust of Lapulapu, 1954. Araneta is also reputed to have done the replica of Guillermo Tolentino’s Oblation at the University of the Philippines campus in Cebu City, based on his design adapted from the 1935 version.

Araneta won first prize for Ike at the Art Association of the Philippines exhibition of 1953. He was featured in Life magazine in 1952 for his achievements as a sculptor.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar

JERRY ARAOS (Jerusalino Villamor Araos) was a sculptor and landscape artist. He was born in Manila on 5 Jul 1944. He died in Manila on 23 Dec 2012. The son of Severiano Araos and Juliana Villamor, he was married to Melendre Valencerina with whom he had six children, among whom are visuals artists Julian and Liwa. He studied English at the University of the East. Araos was founder of the artists’ guild Sanayan Lapat Kamay Inc (Salakai).

A self-taught sculptor with little formal training, he formed structure-ensembles from old weathered wood, planks, beams, stairs, and various architectural relics from demolished houses. He composed his materials into interrelated modular arrangements occupying a large space. In his heavy constructions, the dialogue between solid material and interior/exterior space is experienced as the viewer moves in and around the structures. His themes draw from the issues and concerns of the present: freedom, personal and national, or the lack of it. The modular approach is found in the Bartolina (Isolation Cell) series composed of cell-like units, which can be arranged and rearranged at will into levels of barred compartments.

Araos invites his viewers to walk into prisonlike structures for an experience of cramped physical confinement with dehumanizing effect. In a well-known work, the large multisided form of the balimbing fruit shows pairs of nude backs carved in relief on both sides of several suspended planes. This work was a political comment on the duplicity and opportunistic jockeying for power by traditional politicians during the transition period from the Marcos to the Aquino government.

On the more formal side, Araos produced a number of nudes in wood in which the veins and marks of the material enhance the plasticity of the form.

As a landscape artist, he designed outdoor spaces such as Kasalikasan at Bonifacio Global City. The Araos Garden in Antipolo also features his Luklukan Chairs, wooden sculptures of the human torso carved to accommodate the rumps of people sitting on them, a way of promoting the user’s well-being.   Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rina Corpuz

 

Source

Inquirer.net. 2012b. “Jerry Araos: Artist Who ‘Competed with Bakeries’ for His Wood Sculptures.” Posted 31 Dec. http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/83523/jerry-araos-artist-who-competed-withbakeries-for-his-wood-sculptures-68#ixzz3EzlMy4yV.

JUAN ARCEO, also known as Juan Arzeo, was a painter. He was born ca 1785. He died ca 1870. He was one of the earliest recorded oil painters in the history of Philippine art. The details of Arceo’s life, the dates of his birth and death, remain unconfirmed although it is known that he was a resident of San Fernando de Dilao (now Paco) in the mid-19th century. The peak of his activity seems to have been the 1840s to the 1850s, when he attracted the attention of three seminal writers. Sinibaldo de Mas, in his Informe Sobre el Estado de las Islas Filipinas en 1842 (Brief on the State of the Philippines in 1842) compared Arceo to Vicente Lopez, the Spanish court painter of the 1840s. He stated: “the Lopez of Manila, is actually called Alceo [sic] who works from a bamboo easel and has done various large canvases of the martyrs in China and Japan in the convents …” Jean Mallat in Les Philippines (The Philippines), 1846, related that among the outstanding paintings in Manila were the church paintings and oil portraits of Arceo. On the other hand, Rafael Diaz Arenas in Memorias Historicas (Historical Notes) wrote: “After Damian [Domingo], Arceo excelled in the art of portraiture, the former residing in Tondo and the latter in Paco.”

The statements of de Mas, Mallat, and Arenas are corroborated by the existence of several signed and/or dated works by Juan Arceo, many of them life-size. The earliest is the portrait of Arch Fray Juan Antonio Zulaybar, signed and dated 1820, in the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Museum. Characterized by rigid frontal presentation of the subject, this is evidently an early work of the artist. La Extasis de San Pascual Baylon (The Ecstasy of Saint Paschal Baylon), which is signed and dated 16 Apr 1836, on the other hand, shows the full maturity of Arceo’s art. In the central kneeling figure of the saint framed by the vignettes of his life are seen the delicacy of the artist’s miniaturistic techniques, his masterful handling of the oil medium to evoke realistic textures, and his deep psychological characterization of the subject.

Arceo’s portrait of Fr Manuel Blanco, author of Flora de Filipinas (Plants of the Philippines), appears as a print in the book. His portrait of Fray Pedro de Santa Teresa, signed and dated 1840, shows the subject in his study cell with capiz (oyster shell) windows in the background. He is depicted writing on the page of a book.

Juan Arceo’s two portrait paintings of the Azcarraga family in the 1820s show the family of General Marcelo Azcarraga in their formal wear, showing the fashion of the times inspired by Napoleon Bonaparte, including empire-waisted dresses. Retrato de la Familia Azcarraga (Portrait of the Azcarraga Family), 1824, features the general’s parents, Jose Azcarraga y Ugarte and Maria Isidra Palmera y Bersoza, with his two sisters and the maid, dated “February 16, 1824.” The 1827 painting features a child, Jose Jr, on a rocking horse with his sister Pilar and maid, dated Nov 1827 (Nakpil 2015). The presence of the ninera or yaya (maid) in saya (skirt), tapis (overskirt), and pañuelo (shawl) with peineta (hair comb) gives an interesting dynamic relationship in the family portrait.

There are many other extant signed works by Arceo as well as unsigned ones attributed to him. As the successor to Damian Domingo who died in 1834, he painted hundreds of canvases for the churches and convents of Intramuros. Before World War II, the Dominicans transferred many of Arceo’s canvases from the convent in Intramuros to the new UST building on España, thus saving several of the master’s works from destruction.   Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

Source

 

Nakpil, Lizza Guerrero. 2015. “Anonymous Billionaire Brings Masterpieces Back Home to Manila.” Inquirer.net, 15 Nov. Accessed 12 Dec 2015. http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/213217/anonymous-billionaire-brings-masterpieces-back-home-tomanila#ixzz3u3mUgLId.

ARCILLA, ELY is a jewelry maker. He was born ca 1945. Arcilla is a jewelry maker in Paracale, Camarines Norte, who makes gold filigree in traditional designs, continuing Paracale’s jewelry tradition coming from the Spanish times. Paracale, a gold-mining town since the early days of Spanish colonial rule, was the base of a Hispanic jewelry-making tradition, which evolved such traditional styles as the agrimon, also called alpajor or alakdan, a flat necklace chain used in the 18th century, and the tamburin, an intricate filigree bead necklace that became popular in the 19th century.

Among Paracale’s 1,000-strong population of panday (goldsmiths), Arcilla is reputed to be the only one faithful to tradition, maintaining the use of tools, methods, and designs of two centuries prior. He was trained in the craft by one of the town’s elders since Arcilla was 14 years old. He continued to produce high-carat, intricate jewelry, distinguished by a reddish patina, which is obtained by an ardent process called sinasapo.

In 1990, Arcilla was one of the first folk artists conferred by the Cultural Center of the Philippines the honor Manlilikha ng Bayan “for preserving and continuing the old and endangered traditions of gold filigree jewelry making in Bicol Province.” Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

ARCILLA, ROSALIO JR (Rosalio Beltran Arcilla Jr) was a sculptor. He was born in Caramoan, Camarines Sur on 1 May 1938. He died in Parañaque on 24 Jul 2006. Rosalio’s parents are Rosalio Arcilla Sr and Trinidad Beltran. He finished his early education at Caramoan Elementary School and secondary education at Caramoan High School. He obtained his degree in fine arts at the University of the Philippines in 1960. Arcilla pursued advanced studies in sculpture at the University of Hawaii in 1975. He also received a scholarship grant to the Ecole de Beaux Arts, Paris, from the French government. He taught sculpture at the University of the East and was a board member of the Society of Philippine Sculptors. He held his first solo exhibition at the Manila Hilton in 1971.

Arcilla is primarily known for figurative abstraction in bronze. Sometimes he adds other materials for contrast or to enhance his themes. His forms are schematic to convey the essence of the subject, mainly through geometric simplification. His elegant lines infuse dignity and life in his human figures and compensate for their characteristic lack of facial features.

Arcilla’s The Dream, 1978, won the grand prize as well as first prize for the sculpture category at the Art Association of the Philippines annual exhibition and competition of that year. He was chosen to represent the Philippines in the International Art Exhibition in Osaka, Japan, 1967, and at the Paris-Sud Biennale, 1973. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

Source

Obitwaryo.com. n.d. “Rosalio B. Arcilla Jr.” http://obitwaryo.com/obituary/rosalio-b-arcilla-jr.

ARELLANO, AGNES (Agnes Almario Arellano) is a sculptor. She was born in Manila on 21 Nov 1949. She is the daughter of Liwayway Almario and Otilio Arellano. She was married to Michael Adams with whom she has a daughter, the singer-composer-musician Mishka Adams. She completed her bachelor’s degree in psychology at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, and returned to take on a second degree in fine arts, major in sculpture, at the UP College of Fine Arts, 1984-90.

She is co-founder and president of the nonstock, nonprofit Pinaglabanan Galleries Inc and is director of various corporations. Built on the site of her ancestral home, which was razed in a 1981 fire that killed her parents, Pinaglabanan Galleries ran an exhibition space that was first directed by Roberto Chabet, Arellano’s mentor, from 1984 to 1990. It was the site of many cutting-edge presentations of installation, performance, and multimedia art, such as the 1989 exhibition Lemuria, which was put together by the Baguio-based trio of filmmaker Kidlat Tahimik (pseud. of Eric de Guia), painter and psychologist Katrin de Guia, and musician Shant Verdun. Pinaglabanan also fostered interactions between the literary and the visual arts with Chromatext, a series of exhibitions initiated by the Philippine Literary Arts Council (PLAC). Pinaglabanan Galleries now serves as an organizer and sponsor of exhibitions in other venues, and as a source of support for researchers.

Arellano usually works in plaster or marble that is modeled and cast from her own body, creating life-size figures that are filled with motifs appropriated from a vast range of religious, historical, literary, and biographical sources, and subsequently recombined in ways that can be ambiguous and bewildering. She has produced thematically related groups of sculptures that she calls “inscapes.” Used by the English poet Gerard Manley Hopkins to refer to the design that distinguishes the identity of one individual from another, the term, in Arellano’s lexicon, pertains to the integration of concept and form into a meaningful whole.

Her habitual deployment of myths, particularly her references to gods and goddesses, and her use of the female nude have given rise to the charge that her art may, on the one hand, celebrate women, but, on the other hand, also reduce them to a fixed, universal essence based on their biological and, especially considering the erotic connotations of her sculptures, sexual characteristics. She has insisted, however, that her imagery and art-making processes constitute metaphors for the continuous exploration and uncovering of her identity as a woman.

Her first solo show was Myths of Creation and Destruction I, held in Manila in 1988. It consisted of two pieces—namely, Carcass-Cornucopia, 1987, and Music for Making the Sun Rise, 1987. The latter, consisting of a long box filled with lines of coarse sand and small skulls, is an example of “sound sculpture.” Arranged purely on visual considerations, it was then interpreted as a musical composition by several instruments and male and female voices.

Arellano has also been involved in group shows at home and abroad, including Iskultura: From Anito to Assemblage (Sculpture: From Anito to Assemblage), 1991, at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila and Who Owns Women’s Bodies, 2000-02, a traveling exhibition. She has participated in the Fifth and Sixth Havana Biennales, 1994 and 1997; the First Johannesburg Biennale, 1995; and the Third Asia-Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art, 1999. She has twice been recognized by the city of Manila with its Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for her contributions to art and culture: in 1988 for the visual arts—specifically, for Pinaglabanan Galleries—and in 2002 for sculpture. Arellano received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1988. Written by Jaime Oscar Salazar

 

Sources

Araneta, Elvira. 2013. “Remembering Pinaglabanan Galleries.” Inquirer.net, 18 Nov. http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/137495/remembering-pinaglabanan-galleries.
Arellano, Juan (See architecture volume.)

AREVALO, BONIFACIO (Bonifacio Flores Arevalo) was a sculptor. He was born in Quiapo, Manila on 14 May 1850. He died in 13 Dec 1920. He was the son of Justo Arevalo and Esperanza Flores. His father was a sculptor who died when Bonifacio was seven years old. Bonifacio was married twice. His first wife was Trinidad Arevalo, with whom he had a son named Juan Arevalo, who became one of the Philippine revolutionaries in Cavite. His second wife was Benita Ocampo, with whom he had a daughter. Arevalo also had a son with Carmen Ordax.

Bonifacio was brought up by his uncle Jose Arevalo, also a sculptor, who gave him his first lessons in wood carving. He was sent to study dentistry and train at the San Juan de Dios Hospital, and in 1876 he opened a dental clinic in Quiapo. One of the few licensed dentists of Manila at the time, he enjoyed a lucrative practice and became the first president of the Sociedad Dental de Filipinos. He supported the Philippine Revolution and joined Emilio Aguinaldo’s government, for which he was imprisoned first by the Spaniards in 1896, then by the Americans.

Aside from the practice of his profession, Arevalo engaged in cultural activities. He executed sculptural works and was a patron of the arts. He was the financier and manager of Banda Arevalo, one of the finest bands of the period which furnished music at the seat of the revolutionary government in Malolos. He also built a komedyahan or moro-moro theater in his backyard and assembled a company of players that staged komedya performances.

His sculptural works fall into three categories: those with religious subjects or motifs; tipos del pais or pieces depicting local customs, scenes, and occupations; and portraits. Some of his religious works are La Purisima Concepcion (The Immaculate Conception), one for the Iloilo Church and another for the Dagupan Church; San Rafael (Saint Raphael); Cristo de Velasquez (Christ of Velasquez), a copy in wood of Diego Velazquez’s painting; Ecce Homo (Behold the Man); and Calvario (Calvary). Examples of his tipos del pais are Bayad (Payment), Magmamais (The Corn Vendor), and Zapatero (The Cobbler), all miniature studies. He sometimes employed a doll technique, as in Mga Pulubi (Beggars), in which the heads and hands of the figures are carved in wood and the garments fashioned from cloth. His portraits include those of the emperor and empress of Japan, which were exhibited at the Hanoi Exposition of 1902, and the busts of Gov-Gen Ramon Blanco and Cayetano Arellano for which he used lanite and santol wood.

Arevalo won a gold medal in the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) held in Manila in 1895. His works shown in the Hanoi Exposition of 1902 also received awards. Written by E. Arsenio Manuel, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

Sources

 

Manuel, E. Arsenio. 1955b. Dictionary of Philippine Biography. Vol. 1. Quezon City: Filipiniana Publications.

Quirino, Carlos. 1995. Who’s Who in Philippine History. Makati: Tahanan Books.

ARGUILLA, LYD (Lydia Cendron Villanueva-Arguilla) was a painter. She was born on 3 Aug 1914. She died on 20 Dec 1969. She married fictionist Manuel Arguilla who died during World War II. Dancer Benjamin Villanueva was her half-brother. She finished journalism at the University of the Philippines and was associated with the Veronicans, an organization of writers. She took postgraduate studies at Columbia University through several study grants, and served as editor of the Philippines Herald before World War II.

In 1951, Arguilla helped found the Philippine Art Gallery, which was instrumental in encouraging the development of modern art in the Philippines. She organized the first Philippine Cultural Exhibition in New York City and Washington, DC, as well as the Cultural Exposition of the Republic of the Philippines that traveled to various countries of Southeast Asia in 1962. Other exhibitions she organized were those at the Philippine Pavilion of the New York World’s Fair, 1964; Sydney, 1963; Bonn, 1966; and Geneva, 1968. Until her demise, she served as vice-consul to Geneva after being promoted from the position of cultural attaché.

Arguilla started painting in 1950. She experimented in a lot of media, but her major output consisted mostly of oils. She also created outstanding watercolors. In her works in both media, she was concerned with capturing a Filipino essence in abstract stylized forms. Thus she used earth colors particularly for rendering the complexion of human figures. Working during the ferment of the Neo-Realist movement, she also adopted the use of a narrow, tilted sense of space in her own work, which led to an enhanced filled-up effect in compositions desired by artists then. In Patterns of Leaves and Woman’s Faces, she adopted the multi-exposure device from photography to create an abstract composition out of the patterns of shapes of leaves and faces.

Arguilla won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: second prize, Portrait 1950; third prize, Noon Shadows, 1950; honorable mention, Gabi Gabihan (Every Night), 1950; Two Children, honorable mention, 1951; Landscape, honorable mention, 1951; and gold medal for Best Criticism of Contemporary Art in the 1960s. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

ART ASSOCIATION OF THE PHILIPPINES (AAP) The AAP was founded on 15 Feb 1948 as an alumni association of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts, through the initiative of Purita Kalaw-Ledesma. There were 13 charter members: Diosdado Lorenzo, Antonio Dumlao, Ramon Peralta Jr, Nemesio Faustino, Severino Fabie, Virginia Flor Agbayani, Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Candido Alcantara, Dominador Castañeda, Francesco Monti, Alfredo Pestaño, Fermin Sanchez, and Purita Kalaw-Ledesma, who became its first president. Its constitution was patterned after the Artists’ Equity, an American organization. Membership was open to painters, sculptors, graphic artists, art collectors, art patrons, and art lovers. Its first public activity was a retrospective exhibit of Fabian de la Rosa.

The AAP sought to raise artistic standards and offered incentives to artists. Its goals were accomplished primarily through annual art competitions. At the First AAP National Art Exhibition, held at the National Museum on 3 Jul 1948, the first prize went to Carlos V. Francisco. Other prizewinners were Demetrio Diego, Vicente Manansala, Cesar Legaspi, Diosdado Lorenzo, and Hernando R. Ocampo. From 1948 to 1950 the competitions were in painting; in 1951 sculpture was added. Due to increasing tension between the moderns and conservatives, two categories—the conservative and the modern—were instituted in 1949. The struggle between the two camps came to a head in the 1955 Annual Art Competition, which coincided with the Rotary Golden Anniversary Award. In the AAP art competition, the first prize in the conservative category went to Oscar T. Navarro and the second prize to Gabriel Custodio; prizes in the modern category went to Arturo Luz and Vicente Manansala, while Jose P. Alcantara won in sculpture. In the Rotary Awards, Galo B.Ocampo received first prize; Manuel Rodriguez Jr aka Boy Rodriguez, second prize; and Manansala, third prize. The conservative camp believed the panel of judges to be biased against them. They walked out from the AAP exhibit and instead displayed their artworks along Mabini St, Manila, thereby forming the Mabini Artists group.

Among those who served as presidents of the AAP are Arturo Luz, Wenceslao Garcia, Fernando Zobel, Jose Joya, Napoleon Abueva, Allan Cosio, Raul Isidro, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Orlando Castillo, Eduardo Castrillo, Virgilio Aviado, Ramon Orlina, Salvador Convocar, and Fidel Sarmiento. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

ASUNCION, JOSE MARIA (Jose Maria Raymundo Asuncion) was a painter. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 14 Dec 1869. He died on 2 May 1925. He was born to Marcela Raymundo and Hilarion Asuncion, a portraitist and painter of religious subjects who was the son of Leoncio Asuncion, a wood-carver. He is the grandnephew of painters Antonio Mariano (known as el mayor, who was gobernadorcillo or mayor of Santa Cruz in Manila in 1805), Ambrosio and Justiniano, and sculptor Manuel Tarsilo—all brothers of Leoncio Asuncion. He married Juana Hubero, with whom he had three children. Asuncion obtained his bachelor’s degree at Ateneo de Manila in 1888. He also studied at the Escuela de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado, 1884-89, and at the Universidad de Santo Tomas. Upon the advice of his teacher, the painter Felipe Roxas, he went abroad to take advanced studies. He studied at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando, 1891-95. While his compatriots excelled in painting, he was mainly interested in the philosophical and historical aspects of art, winning first prize in his history of art and costume classes, and second prize in his art theory class.

Upon his return to Manila in 1895, Asuncion worked as an assistant in the School of Arts and Trade in Iloilo until 1898. He took an active part in the second stage of the Philippine Revolution and was forced to retreat to the hinterlands in the face of advancing American forces. However, after a while, he managed to reach Leyte. There he painted landscapes and drop curtains for local komedya and set up a photography business with his brother. In 1905, he left for Manila and studied law. He joined the Partido Independista and contributed articles to several publications: the party’s organ La Independencia, El Ilonquillo (where his illustrations also appeared), La Voz de Mindanao, La Union, El Estudiante, El Renacimiento, The Independent, and Dia Filipino. Together with Rafael Enriquez, Asuncion established the Sociedad Internacional de Artistas and, in 1908, organized the Exposicion de Bellas Artes y Industrias Artisticas (Exposition of Fine Arts and Artistic Industries) to welcome a visiting American squadron. The following year, he began teaching at the new University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts and served as its secretary from 1911 until his death in 1925.

Jose Maria Asuncion submitted 12 paintings to the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in 1895 and two pieces to the Saint Louis Universal Exposition in 1904. He also contributed studies on the history of Philippine art and sketches of Filipino costumes. Fabian de la Rosa considered his still lifes outstanding. However, only three of his pieces seem to be extant today: San Juan River, Tacloban River, and View of Samar. Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Santiago A. Pilar

ASUNCION, JUSTINIANO (Justiniano Molo de San Agustin Asuncion) aka Capitan Ting was a painter. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 24 Sep 1816. He died in Bulan, Sorsogon on 24 Oct 1896. He was the son of Mariano Asuncion, who was gobernadorcillo (mayor) of Santa Cruz in Manila in 1805. His mother was Maria de la Paz Molo de San Agustin, a Chinese-Portuguese mestiza. He married Justina Parafina Gomez and lived in Sorsogon in 1886 until his death in 1896. He was the eighth and youngest son in a family of 12 artistically talented children. His brothers Antonio, Mariano Jr, and Ambrocio grew up to be painters, while Manuel Tarsilo and Leoncio became eminent sculptors. Some of them, including Justiniano himself, also served as gobernadorcillo of Santa Cruz. During his incumbency, he inaugurated the street now called Oroquieta, which at that time led to the San Lazaro Hospital.

Justiniano trained in the studio of his elder brothers and must have gone to the Academia de Dibujo under Damian Domingo, from whom he probably acquired his mastery of a style called miniaturismo. In this style, the minutest details are painted as realistically as possible, even if the painting ground were as small as a thumbnail, as it is in the case of lockets. Every trace of brushwork is also carefully concealed. Another proof of Domingo’s influence was that Justiniano did at least three sets of albums of Filipino costumes, called album de trajes, which were similar to what Domingo worked on before he died in 1834. While Justiniano signed these folios “Justiniano Assumpcion,” he signed most of his oils “J.A.” His earliest signed and dated painting is San Bonifacio, 1838.

By the 1850s, he came to be known for his exquisite portraits of the elegant ladies of his time. In one portrait of his niece Romana Asuncion Carillo, a sunset lies in the background to highlight the serenity of the sitter. This is the first time in Philippine art history in which the landscape is used for psychological and romantic realism. His portraits were done in miniaturistic realism, with the embroidery of the blouses of the ladies delicately rendered. Asuncion also executed locket-size and palm-size miniatures. He also painted the portraits Dolores Paterno and Filomena Asuncion-Villafranca.

Asuncion became so skilled in rendering realistic figures and scenes that his works became illusionistic. A two-dimensional painting would give viewers the impression that what they were seeing was three-dimensional and real, as evident in the Virgen de Antipolo (Virgin of Antipolo). To further this, the artist is said to have used his skills to play jokes. At one time he painted a set of coins on the lid of a chest, prompting the beholders to comment on the carelessness of the owner. He also painted a falling child on the wall directly under a window, which evoked cries of fright from passersby. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

ASUNCION, LEONCIO (Leoncio Molo de San Agustin Asuncion) was a sculptor. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 1813. He died in 1888. He was one of the 12 artistically gifted children of Mariano Asuncion, gobernadorcillo (mayor) of Santa Cruz, Manila, in 1805. His mother was Maria de la Paz Molo de San Agustin, a Chinese-Portuguese mestiza. He was the brother of painters Antonio, Mariano Jr, Ambrosio, and Justiniano; and sculptor Manuel Tarsilo. Leoncio Asuncion married Petrona Eloriaga and became the father of painter Hilarion Asuncion, b. ca 1840, who in turn was the father of Jose Maria Asuncion, 1869-1925, the first secretary of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts. When he was a child, there was yet no formal school in which to study the art of sculpture. He entered one of the talleres (studios) in his district Santa Cruz, which has been a beehive of artists and artisans since 1741. He probably studied under the earliest recorded sculptor from Santa Cruz, Anastacio de Jesus. In 1839, he and his brother Manuel Tarsilo established their own studio on Calle Santa Rosa (now Evangelista). Manuel Tarsilo died in 1854, thus it would be Leoncio who would become known for sculptural masterpieces. By the 1850s, his career as a carver was already established. Many of the younger generation of carvers went to apprentice in his shop, like Domingo Teotico y Eugenio, 1853-1904, also an outstanding sculptor.

A carver during that time had to be versatile in two mediums: wood and ivory. Asuncion is remembered for his life-size group sculpture positioned as the ninth Station of the Cross, also known by its Spanish title Tercera Caida. This work was found in the Santa Cruz Church and was carried around in procession during Holy Week. There are only a few pieces authenticated as his work—among them, a Santo Cristo (Crucifix) and La Purisima Corazon de Maria (The Purest Heart of Mary), both made of ivory. The Santo Cristo is depicted in the expirante (expired) stance, which suggests the moment when Christ called out, “Father, why hast thou abandoned me?” On the other hand, the Purisima is a half-figure of Mary adorned at the bosom with a heart stabbed by a dagger. Both are of the quita y pone variety, in which the image is an assemblage of smaller parts. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

ASUNCION, MARIANO (Mariano Molo de San Agustin Asuncion) was a painter. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila in 1802. He died on 7 Nov 1885. His parents were Mariano Asuncion el mayor and Maria de la Paz Molo de San Agustin. He is the brother of painters Antonio, Ambrosio, Mariano Jr, and Justiniano, and sculptors Leoncio and Manuel Tarsilo. The Academia de Dibujo was established in 1823 and it is presumed that Mariano Asuncion, 21 years old at the time, had gone to study there, as was evident in his miniaturistic style, which was taught at the academy.

Acclaimed for his religious paintings, Asuncion produced hundreds of works, of which some 20 signed and dated pieces are still in existence. His earliest work is the Vera Efigie de San Agustin (Authentic Portrait of Saint Augustine), 1838, which is remarkable for the suppleness of the saint’s features and brilliance of color as rendered. The next dated piece is the mural-sized Milagro de Nuestra Señora del Carmen (Miracle of Our Lady of Carmel), 1850. Then there is the Extasis de San Francisco (Ecstasy of Saint Francis), 1864, in which many objects are realistically rendered to the minutest detail.

Mariano is especially known for his many versions of the Nuestra Señora del Rosario (Our Lady of the Rosary). These paintings show Mary from the waist up, with a rosary in her right hand as she carries the child Jesus, who also holds a rosary. They were mainly commissioned by the affluent for their private altars, and eloquently expressed the prosperity of the patrons. The figures of Jesus and Mary are richly robed, wearing crowns studded with gems. Both are rendered with double chins.

Mariano was a member of the Venerable Orden Tercera de San Francisco. His obituary translates thus: “Mariano Asuncion/The Virtuous Elderly Religious Limner/Dean of Native Painters/Juan de Juanes, Valencian Painter.” The last phrase compared him to the master of religious painting from Valencia, Spain. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

ATELIER OF MODERN ART The Atelier of Modern Art is the first Filipino educational institution to comprehensively offer pedagogical techniques in art making utilizing the modernist framework. It was opened on 15 Jun 1938 under the mentorship of Victorio C. Edades, Diosdado M. Lorenzo, and Galo B. Ocampo. It was located at the Union College at 622 Marcelo H. del Pilar St, Ermita, Manila. After a few months, the atelier moved to another branch of the Union College on Taft Ave. The atelier was closed in 1939 due to lack of funds. Its first director was Edades who resigned shortly after it opened. He was succeeded by Lorenzo, who continued on as director until the atelier closed. Lorenzo was designated as professor in charge of the atelier, while Ocampo served as the atelier’s secretary and assistant to the professorial staff. A Mr Gutierrez handled interior decoration classes, while Elsie Concepcion handled art classes for children. Concepcion was also supposed to collaborate with Edades in pioneering a modern children’s art pedagogy program patterned after the Van Cizek method in Vienna, but no further progress came after Edades resigned. Students enrolled in classes via individual tickets, which were sold at two pesos per session of three hours each.

The atelier’s 1938 prospectus lay down its principles of teaching art based on the following precepts: “to fulfill a long-felt need … (for) a student wishing to take art training in the methods used by the great Moderns … where anyone interested may drop in and paint or sketch under guidance; … each student has his own aptitudes (sic) which will be encouraged according to the progressive methods prevailing in the great modern art schools of America and Europe.” The atelier prided itself in creating innovation in Philippine art teaching methods through the practice of the “atelier” system of instruction, wherein advanced art students were given their own studio space and a model for such students to paint without supervision, but those who would like to discuss their problems with each other in “a frank and friendly way” were given the opportunity to do so. In addition, the atelier also offered a special class in art appreciation “to those who understand the principle that underlie all great art masterpieces. This class will constitute of illustrated lectures supplemented by laboratory work in drawing, painting in oil, or watercolor sketching.” Finally, the prospectus also declared that “no school in the world can teach art, but the Atelier of Modern Art can guide the student along his particular inclination in a full expression of the best that is in him.”

The atelier’s use of the Parisian atelier method challenged art pedagogy in the academic system then being implemented by the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, where professorial supervision and correction still occurred on a class-wide basis, and where individual creativity (specifically, that which deviates from the purely “retinal” or “photo-realist” rendition of subjects) was disallowed, thereby creating a homogenous school of graduates whose work was patterned after the style of their professors. Moreover, the atelier challenged the academic and conservative method of UP through an equally dogmatic interpretation of Modernism. Eventually, however, this polarization gave way to artists’ attempting “virile” expression in Filipino art making, which negotiated Western avant-garde concepts alongside the rediscovery of both traditional or “folk” arts. In addition, the atelier also pioneered art appreciation as a separate and specialized course that was tailored to art students, as well as the lay person interested in learning about aesthetics, art history, and art criticism. The atelier system would not prosper in Philippine art educational institutions until after the war. Modern pedagogies of drawing from real life and creative composition would be pursued at the University of Santo Tomas by Edades and by the 1950s at the UP, under modernist faculty like Napoleon Abueva, Jose Joya, and Constancio Bernardo. Art appreciation would later on be taught by Fernando Zobel at Ateneo in the early 1950s and by Rod Paras-Perez at UP in the 1960s.

In its first and only year of operation, the Atelier of Modern Art boasted art lectures from architects like Juan Arellano, Juan Nakpil, and Pablo Ocampo. An art exhibition featuring the works of Edades, Lorenzo, and Ocampo also served as a highlight, along with their respective profiles printed in the Atelier Prospectus. Other courses offered were drawing and painting, and fresco painting. Some of the atelier’s most promising students and other faculty were subsequently listed by Edades in 1939 as the Thirteen Moderns of Philippine Art. Aside from Edades, Lorenzo, and Ocampo, the faculty included Demetrio Diego, Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, and Vicente Manansala; while the students were Arsenio Capili, Bonifacio Cristobal, Anita Magsaysay (later Mrs. Ho), Hernando Ruiz Ocampo, Jose Pardo, and Ricarte Puruganan. Other artists who were associated with the atelier but were not listed under the Thirteen Moderns by Edades were Ramon Estella and Simplicia “Nena” Saguil who, along with Edades, Francisco, Legaspi, Manansala, and Hernando Ocampo would make up the postwar group called the Neo-realists. Despite the atelier’s brief existence, it was thus instrumental in the group formation of the early Philippine Moderns just as it also represented a breakthrough in art pedagogic method that would influence teaching in larger and longer-running institutions such as the University of Santos Tomas and UP. Written by Reuben Ramas Cañete

 

Sources

 

Guerrero, Amadis Ma., and Purita Kalaw-Ledesma. 1979. Edades: National Artist. Makati: Filipinas Foundation.

Guillermo, Alice G. 2009. Diosdado Magno Lorenzo: Art Rebel to Legend. Manila: Philippine-Italian Association and Tantoco-Rustia Foundation.

Paras-Perez, Rodolfo. 1995. Edades and the 13 Moderns. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Torres, Emmanuel. 2003b. Nena Saguil: Landscapes and Inscapes from the Material World to the Spiritual. Quezon City: Ateneo Art Gallery.

ATLAS, LORENZO (Laurentius Atlas) aka Laureano Atlas, Laur. Atlas. He was a printmaker, who was active from 1738-71. He was one of several highly accomplished engravers on copper in the 18th century. Lorenzo Atlas (previously identified as Laureano but with recent evidence seems to be Laurentius in Latin or Lorenzo in Spanish) is also one of the few 18th-century printmakers with extant examples of both his loose-leaf editions and book illustrations. Another engraver bearing the family name Atlas was active in the late 18th and early 19th centuries—namely, Vicente or Vicente Antonio, whose works were less interesting than Lorenzo’s.

Atlas’s grandest work, Verdadera Ymagen de la Nuestra Señora del Rosario de la Naval (Authentic Portrait of Our Lady of the Rosary of La Naval), 1759, is an engraving on copper impressed on silk cloth. This is a rare example of a loose-leaf print that graced Filipino private altars. In 1743, he drew and etched the portrait of Arch Juan Angel Rodriguez, also on copper, the earliest known portrait of an individual who actually lived in the Philippines (no oil portrait antedates this). This appeared in El Moyses Verdadero (The True Moses), the biography of the subject by Fr Esteban de Roxas y Melo. Atlas’s other works include Glorioso Martyrio de los Veinte y Tres Protomartyres Franciscanos de Japon (The Glorious Martyrdom of the 23 First Franciscan Martyrs of Japan) in volume 3 of Chronicas de la Apostolica Provincia de San Gregorio (Account of the Apostolic Province of Saint Gregory), 1744, by Fr Juan Francisco de San Antonio; Nuestra Señora de la Rosa y Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buen Viaje (Our Lady of the Rose and Our Lady of Peace and Good Voyage) in Historia de la Provincia de Philipinas de la Compañia de Jesus (History of the Province of the Society of Jesus), 1749, by Pedro Murillo Velarde; Señor San Miguel (Lord Saint Michael) in a novena in honor of the saint, 1751, and Santa Rosa de Lima (Saint Rose of Lima) in Astro Brillante en el Mundo (Brilliant Star on Earth), 1754, by Doña Leonarda Gil Gama. Atlas also engraved maps such as those of the ports of Caagayan and Sisiran, which illustrated the Adicion de la Ordenanza de Marina (Addendum to the Maritime Ordinance), 1757, by Pedro Manuel de Arandia.

That Atlas attained the highest degree of refinement in engraving is evident in his consummately detailed cross-hatching and stippling, which approximated all possible degrees of shading in drawing and painting. Not having had lessons in drawing from life, his renditions of the human figure show anatomical flaws. This is evident in Aspecto Symbolico del Mundo Hispanico (Symbolic Aspect of the Spanish World), which illustrated the doctoral thesis of Vicente de Memije. Atlas’s last known work is the San Francisco de Asis (Saint Francis of Assisi), which appeared in a life of the saint by Fr Antonio Bozal, 1771.

His works were appreciated by the Spaniards of his time. His pen-and-ink drawing of the catafalque raised in Manila in memory of Queen Maria Amalia of Saxony was sent to the Spanish court. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

AUSTRIA, ANTONIO (Antonio Gilbuena Austria) was a painter. He was born in Shanghai, China on 5 May 1936. He is the son of Pedro Austria and Lucila Gilbuena. He married Tarcila Estepa with whom he has two children. He studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he taught painting since 1969. He retired from teaching after 27 years and thereafter devoted his time to painting. His subjects are drawn from the elite and the ordinary, the urban and the rural: vendors, fortune-tellers, sari-sari (variety) stores, jeepneys, folk games, fiestas. His human figures, short and squat with flat, tubular limbs and stubby hands and feet, are simply and clearly defined, outlined in blue or other colors. His jeepneys are flattened out on the same plane as decorative patterns and motifs.

Compositionally, Austria’s use of space follows the folk penchant for covering the entire field with elements of different shapes and colors. Such an approach stems from a passion for visually naming the objects of the material world rather than from any obsessive need to fill up vacant space. His fiesta paintings show outdoor settings with numerous figures massed around an activity, as an outdoor komedya (long hyperbolic verse plays), full of colorful costumes and lively movement as in his triptych Pista. It features three paintings done in 1978. The first work, Prusisyon (Procession), has rich colors that contribute to the sense of a religious fiesta. The second, Moro-Moro, shows a lit-up stage with actors against a cardboard castle backdrop. The third painting, Palabas (Sideshow) depicts a sideshow with acrobats, and jugglers against carnival freak-show posters.

Austria has joined several exhibitions locally (Luz Gallery, 1966; Ateneo Art Gallery, 1967; Cultural Center of the Philippines [CCP], 1976; Manila Peninsula Hotel, 1989) and abroad (Saigon, 1961; Australia, 1962; Bangkok, 1963; New York, 1964; Washington, DC, 1978; Madurodam, Netherlands, 1980; Fukuoka, Japan, 1980; Seattle and Honolulu, 1985). A major retrospective of his works titled Decades of A.G. Austria was mounted by the CCP in 2016.

Austria won awards: third prize, Life Painting Silver Jubillee Art Competition, UST, 1955; special award, Magpapalayok (Claypot Vendor), Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), 1959; first honorable mention, Taniman (Fields), AAP, 1961; third prize, The Carver, High Land Art Exhibition sponsored by the Bureau of Travel and Tourist Industry, 1962; second prize for Suka (Vinegar) and Best in Show for Halamanan (Garden), Contemporary Arts of Asia Tour, 1965; third prize, Sari-sari (Variety), AAP, 1969; and first prize, Magtanim Hindi Biro (Planting Is No Joke), PNB Art Contest, 1976. He was a semifinalist and finalist in the Mobil Art Foundation in 1980 and 1982, respectively. He was one of the first recipients of the CCP Thirteen Artists award in 1970. In 2002, he was awarded the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan by the city of Manila. Written by Annaliza B. Villar and Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

AUSTRIA, TAM (Atanacio Pefaranda Austria) is a painter. He was born in Tanay, Rizal on 25 Aug 1943. He is the son of Mariano Austria and Reymunda Pefaranda. He is married to Mary Divine Sagara with whom he has two children. At age four, he saw the illustrations of National Artist Fernando Amorsolo, and in 1949 he completed his own illustration—a portrait of his mother (Aguilar 1999, 267). Austria had his early training under Carlos V. Francisco, master painter of Angono. Later he went to the University of Santo Tomas (UST) School of Fine Arts where he graduated with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts in 1954.

Austria ventured into advertising illustrations, sign painting, and on-the-spot painting on the streets of Ermita and Mabini. He became an illustrator for the Ayala Museum in 1967, creating the designs for the museum’s diorama of Philippine history. Later, the Zobel de Ayala family commissioned him to create a mural for the Santuario de San Antonio in Forbes Park, Makati.

A regional artist, Austria is known for his folk genre and interpretation of Philippine myths and legends. Among his early works were a Madonna-and-child series in somber tones, avoiding the usual sentimentality of the subject. In his folk genre works, mostly in sepia brown, a recurrent subject is a family traveling in a bull cart hung with an assortment of woven baskets. He works in a meticulous style, revelling in the details of numerous objects. One theme that Austria shares with the Laguna de Bay artists is the cult of woman, which is part of native folk romanticism. In one of his many versions of Mariang Makiling of folk legend, he shows the diwata (deity) in a forest idyll by a stream, playing with white doves perched on her delicate hands. In another painting, a woman with long tresses dressed in 19th-century costume reclines, fanning herself as she is borne in a rattan hammock by rugged men through the forest. Like many artists, Austria has also dealt with the fiesta and with folk rituals such as the Moriones festival. While his use of color is tempered, his paintings are marked by linear elegance and the filling up of space.

He has held numerous exhibits here and abroad. Austria’s Mother and Child won fourth place in the 1982 Mobil Art Foundation. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Therese de Silva

 

Sources

Artodyssey. 2013. “Tam Austria.” Posted Aug. Accessed 29 Sep 2014. http://artodyssey1.blogspot.com/2013/08/tam-austria.html.

Duldulao, Manuel D. 1976. Tam P. Austria. Manila: [Manual D. Duldulao].

AVELLANA-COSIO, IVI (Ivi Hontiveros Avellana-Cosio) is a painter. She was born in Manila on 22 May 1942. She is the daughter of National Artists Lamberto Avellana, a film and stage director, and Daisy Hontiveros, a stage director and actor. She is married to painter Allan Cosio. She studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas in 1959-61 and took special courses in painting at the Philippine Women’s University. She studied under Manuel Rodriguez Sr in his Contemporary Arts Workshop. She was co-founder of the Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP) in 1968.

As printmaker, she did collagraphs which she constructed from beaten thumbtacks, bottle caps, discarded machine parts, and white glue markings. Flag for Jasper Jolens, 1968, and Insight Out #3, 1971, are examples of this technique. Blue Movie, 1970, is a collagraph print made from waste film strips that she glued, punched, and combined with beaten metal. In the 1980s, she concentrated on doing minimalist hard-edge paintings. Describing her process during this phase of her art as pure abstraction, she relates how she proceeded: “Painting the square exactly in the middle of a larger square, moving it in another direction, pushing it against the border of a canvas, tilting it, enlarging or reducing it, using different tonalities, give unlimited possibilities.” She however freely vacillates from geometric rigidities to organic and soft edges. In 1988-89, she used the same purely abstract design strategy in creating mixed media works, incorporating ethnic Philippine syllabary and embroidery motifs. Five Falls and Yakan Midnight are examples of this experimentation which she rendered in handmade rice straw and mulberry paper combined with fiber, shells, and ethnic decorative bands. In 1992, her large-scale works collectively called Lumang Abakada (Old Syllabary) further explored this style.

Her solo exhibitions include Recent Paintings, Lopez Museum, 1987; Tropical Flora, Finale Art File, Makati, 1988; Thirteen Nudes, Finale Art File, Makati, 1989; Papel Hibla Atbp. (Paper Thread Etc.), Ayala Museum, 1989; Tropical Flora II, West Gallery, 1990; Lumang Abakada, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1990; Lumang Abakada Muli (Old Syllabary Again), Finale Art File, 1994; Lumang Abakada / Intwilas, Galleria Duemila, SM Megamall, Alibata Atbp., Arts and Associates Gallery, 1999; Natura, Miriam College, 2000; Sulat Alibata (Precolonial Philippine Script), Galleria Duemila, 2000; Floriade, Le Souffle Bistro, 2011; and Ancêtres/Ninuno (Ancestors), Total Gallery, Alliance Française de Manille, 2011.

She won second prize (graphic arts) in the first Philippine Airlines art contest in 1967 and first honorable mention (mixed media) in the first annual PAP competition in 1968. Her Insight Out #3 won the grand prize in the fourth PAP annual competition in 1971. She also won an award for sculpture from the Art Association of the Philippines in 1975. She participated in the 7th International Biennale of Art in Valparaizo, Chile, in 1985. In 1991, she was awarded a CCP project grant. Other awards include the Jurors’ Choice in 1994, 1995, and 1997, Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards; finalist, 1997 Philip Morris ASEAN Art Awards; and Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for painting given by the city of Manila in 1999. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

 

 

Source

 

Kintanar, Thelma B., and Sylvia Mendez Ventura. 2003b. “Ivi Avellana-Cosio: State-of-the-Art Alibata.” In Self-Portraits 2: Fourteen Filipina Artists Speak, 77-101. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

AVIADO, VIRGILIO (Virgilio Arguelles Aviado) aka Pandy Aviado. He is a printmaker and cultural administrator. He was born in Manila on 29 Apr 1944. He is the son of Ramon Aviado Sr and Lutgarda Arguelles. Aviado was educated at Ateneo de Manila University and had his first brush with art under painter Araceli Dans in 1961. Later, he apprenticed himself with printmaker Manuel Rodriguez Sr, 1963-65. He developed his skill in printmaking as a scholar at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid, Spain, 1969-71. He also joined a number of workshops: lithography under Dimitri Papaguerguio; printmaking under the brothers Sanchez-Toda, 1970; the Smithsonian Experimental Workshop in Printmaking, 1971; print workshops in Cuenca, Spain, 1972; Intaglio Printing for Grupo Quince; and workshops at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, France, 1974.

Aviado has been active in academic and organizational work. He served as acting dean of the College of Fine Arts at the Philippine Women’s University, 1986-89, and as director of the Coordinating Center for Visual Arts, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1991-92. He was president of the Philippine Association of Printmakers, 1990, and the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), 1991, and was head of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) Committee on Visual Arts, 1995-98.

Aviado has held over 20 one-person shows since 1967, and has participated in over a hundred group shows since 1964. His style ranges from the highly detailed and nearly surreal compositions to minimal constructions of paper collage. His subject matter includes antique images of santos, as well as social and political themes drawn from the 1970s and 1980s. As of 2011, Aviado has had over 32 solo shows. In 2013, his exhibit For Love of Heritage at the NCCA Gallery also occasioned the launching of Saul Hofileña Jr’s book on him, titled The Last Bohemian: The Life and Art of Virgilio Aviado. His art practice also includes being one of the curators for the national art exhibition for the 1st Sungdu-an Festival, 1996; as writer for the NCCA Pananaw: Journal of Visual Arts; and as actor for Nick Deocampo’s film Edades, 2004.

Aviado’s awards in the Shell National Students Art Competition include first prize, Home, Sweet Home, 1964; honorable mention, Sarimanok, 1964; honorable mention, Wood Engraving, 1965; third prize, Manila Bay (from the Manila Yacht Club), 1966; and certificate of merit, Vegetation, 1966. The AAP awarded him second prize for Auto Retrato (Self-Portrait) and first prize for H. to E.T. in 1966. He was named one of the Thirteen Artists of the CCP in 1970. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for graphic arts in 1988 and the Araw ng Maynila award for painting in 2009, both from the city of Manila. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

 

 

Source

AVILA, CANUTO aka Maestro Canuto was a painter. He was born in San Nicolas, Cebu on 18 Jan 1878. He died on 13 Nov 1968. He had two children: Ricardo and Ma. Salome (Mary), who has herself done oils and watercolors on religious and historical themes as well as soap carvings.

Avila studied under a Spanish tutor at age 15 and then enrolled at the Colegio-Seminario de San Carlos in Cebu. In the early years of the 20th century, he produced religious murals for around 20 churches and convents in Cebu, Bohol, and other parts of the Visayas. In 1917, he was commissioned to do a series of religious paintings to decorate the ceiling of Cebu’s Santo Niño Church. He is known to have suffered a near-fatal accident when he fell off a scaffolding while painting a church ceiling. He also did other works, including a portrait of Sergio Osmeña in 1914. More importantly, he painted Visayan rural landscapes in vertical canvas format, showing scenes depicting activities and occupations, such as farmers in the field and peddlers on the road. His landscapes also showed the influence of Japanese and Chinese scroll paintings.

Like his contemporary Gonzalo Abellana, Avila also painted backdrops for plays, using what was called the de aqua technique, which uses Muralo powder in water-based paints. His other contemporaries include Raymundo Francia, Simeon Padriga, and Lucas Perez. Written by Erlinda Alburo
Ayco, Jess (See AIKO, JESS.)

BACOLOR, FELIX is a visual artist. He was born in 27 Nov 1967. Bacolor attained a degree in painting from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1989. He helped organize the First Dagupan National Arts Festival in Pangasinan in 2005.

An interest in living history is greatly evident in Bacolor’s artistic practice. Whether with maps and actual artifacts, or the most ordinary objects like mass-produced toys or raw meat, the power of his art lies in its capacity to alter the way the objects are used, and then recast into assemblages and installations. Bacolor likens his practice to an “archaeologist excavating artifacts.” In the exhibit Leavings, 2012, at the West Gallery, the artist gathered the remains of art making from his studio. Through installations strategically placed in the gallery, Bacolor reassembled not only the discards of his art process but traced as well the inner workings of production.

Constant in Bacolor’s art are the strategies of experimentation and play. Most of his exhibitions combine video, photography, sculpture, and installation work. The endless combination of these forms and the avid research that informs them characterize Bacolor’s art as inquisitive, provocative, and whimsical. In Toy Stories at Nova Gallery in 2013, Bacolor incorporated mass-produced plastic toys he had collected from Divisoria where they were bought in bulk. While the pieces referenced notions of play and childhood games, they were made to pivot on two central concepts: those of violence and collecting. The artist skilfully crafted them into pieces strategically installed in the gallery space, with one work leading to another, in a chain of signification that Bacolor deftly manipulated for viewers to discover and pursue.

His exhibitions take into consideration the space and context where his pieces are installed. For the exhibition Setting, 2014, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, Bacolor reconstructed the famed Manila Bay sunset in a video installation that incorporated a shallow pool of water, industrial fans to mimic surface ripples, and a sphere projected on a wall to represent the sun crawling toward the horizon. The piece, however, was devoid of drama and compelling beauty often associated with a sunset. Instead, in Bacolor’s rendition the sunset appeared minimal and spare, stripped of emotion and human presence.

Bacolor participated in group exhibitions in the Philippines and abroad including Marcel Duchamp in Southeast Asia, Equator Art Projects, Singapore, 2012; Slipping Transmission, Osage Soho, Hong Kong, 2011; and Futuramanila, Singapore and Hong Kong, 2008. Bacolor won second prize in the 1999 National Art Competition organized by the Art Association of the Philippines. Written by Tessa Maria Guazon
