BAGAY, NICOLAS DE LA CRUZ was an engraver and printer. He was born in Tambobong (now Malabon) ca 1701. He died ca 1790. He was associated with the Imprenta del Colegio de la Compañia de Jesus from 1743 to 1768. Bagay and Francisco Suarez are noted for having appended “Indio Tagalo” (Tagalog native) to their names as these appeared in the 1734 map of the Philippines charted by the Jesuit Pedro Murillo Velarde.

Bagay was earlier known as an engraver, and his first known work depicted the coat of arms of Gov-Gen Valdes Tamon which adorned the title page of the sermon of Fr Juan de Arechedera in praise of the Nuestra Señora del Rosario in 1731. In 1734, he executed the 13 plates for Navegacion Especulativa y Practica (Theoretical and Practical Navigation), a primer on navigational charts and shipbuilding by Jose Gonzalez Cabrera. One of Bagay’s works is a detailed drawing of a ship, above which is a legend containing the names of all its parts. In the same year, he worked on the Velarde map and a border panel consisting of six pictures showing various inhabitants of the colony. In 1760, he collaborated with Francisco and Luis Suarez to illustrate Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Caloloua nang Tauong Naghihingalo (Prayers of Guidance for the Soul of the Dying) and its appendix Mahal na Passion ni Jesu Christong Panginoon Natin na Tola (The Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ in Verse) by Gaspar Aquino de Belen. The plates depicted different stages of Christ’s suffering and his death.

Bagay is the most prolific of the 18th-century engravers, with some 30 prints attributed to him. Other impressive works include San Andres Apostol (Saint Andrew the Apostle), 1735; Santo Cristo (Holy Christ), 1739; San Francisco Javier (Saint Francis Xavier), 1741; La Santisima Trinidad sobre el Purgatorio (The Holy Trinity above Purgatory), 1755; and an equestrian portrait of Fernando VI, 1758. His figures were characterized by rhythmic movement, and his scenes were presented from a multilevel or isometric perspective. His hatchings, cross-hatchings, and stipplings ranged from extremely fine to widely spaced. In some works, blocks of black areas contrasted with white, lending visual variety to his compositions. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

BAGUIO ARTS GUILD aka BAG. Founded 1987 at the Renaissance Gallery of Café Amapola on Session Road, the Baguio Arts Guild is one of the longest-running art groups in the Philippines. BAG incorporators and first board members are David Baradas, Santiago Bose, Benedicto Cabrera, Irineo Geslani, Eric de Guia, and Roberto Villanueva. The founding members are John Alaban, Rene Aquitania, Roland Bay-an, Teodoro Caja, Norman Chow, Jojo Elmeda, Katrin de Guia, Tommy Hafalla, Monette Minas, Jordan Mang-osan, Christopher Mero, Nancy Pobanz, Virgilio Paterno, Eduardo Silayan, Fernando Torio, and Shant Verdun.

The Baguio Arts Guild is best known for the six international festivals it organized from 1988 to 2002 during which Philippine culture and the arts were celebrated and showcased in events that fostered good relations between artists and communities. The festivals enabled cross-cultural linkages within the Philippines and with countries around the Asia-Pacific region, with Japan and Australia as close partners. Locally, stronger ties were also forged with Makiling artists and artists from Negros. Participation and support came from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, the city government, private organizations and corporations, schools and universities, and other art groups of different disciplines composed of dancers, musicians, theater actors, and writers.

Baguio artists explored the use of indigenous materials and multimedia as they worked on themes dealing with nature, the environment, sociopolitical realities, and the quest for what is Filipino in art. Performance and installation art figured prominently. The festivals brought these art forms and concerns to a wider audience. After the festivals, Roberto Villanueva’s striking installations using runo and bamboo were seen outside of Baguio: Archetypes: Cordillera Labyrinth, 1989, at the CCP; The Dream Weaver, 1992, in Fukuoka, Japan; and Bridge of Cross Culture, 1992, in Lake Naguri, Japan.

Through the years, BAG members have made a mark on the artistic landscape of the country, the most prominent being three of the founders: Benedicto Cabrera who became a National Artist in 2006 and established the BenCab Museum in Baguio City, Kidlat Tahimik who is widely regarded among filmmakers as independent cinema pioneer, and Santiago Bose who championed indigenous motifs and pop references to deliver postcolonial critiques through his installations and multimedia work. Bose received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1976. A good number of visual artists associated with BAG have also received this award since then—namely, William Magtibay, Rene Aquitania, and Tommy Hafalla in 1992; Alwin Reamillo in 1994; Leonardo Aguinaldo in 2003; and Kawayan de Guia in 2009.

Between its members and across the organization, BAG earned many more awards and distinctions, both national and international. Kidlat Tahimik won first place for Orbit 50 in the 1992 Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video. Maria Luisa Aguilar-Cariño was a consistent winner at the Don Carlos Palanca Awards for Literature. The BAG itself received a PILAK CCP Service Award for Culture and the Arts in the Community in 2004 and was given a Builder of Baguio Centennial Award in 2009 for being one of the organizations that became instrumental in shaping the city.

Over time, BAG members have gone on to pursue their own artistic paths, some successfully establishing art groups of their own. Today the guild has dwindled in membership; but the organization still forges on with community-based activities, with members serving in committees, participating in public events, lecturing, judging art contests, exhibiting, and offering art workshops in partnership with nongovernment organizations. Written by Kelly P. Ramos

 

 

Sources

 

Baguio Arts Guild. 2013. Files prepared by Baguio Arts Guild secretary Jenny Marsha Agtani.

SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission). n.d. Articles of Incorporation.

BALDEMOR, FRED (Fred Sarmiento Baldemor) is a sculptor. He was born in Paete, Laguna 1944. He is the son of Antero Baldemor and Marianita Sarmiento. He is the nephew of Angelo and Manuel Baldemor—well-known painters and wood-carvers. He graduated with a bachelor of science degree in commerce from the Union College of Laguna.

A wood-carver from Paete, Baldemor is best known for having originated the image of Santo Niño de Palaboy (Holy Child the Vagrant) done in molave in 1974. Venerated in an annual religious feast, this has since become iconic folk imagery sculpted by every Paete carver. He produced a body of work called Sining Kahoy (Wood Art), which he exhibited in Gallerie Bleue in 1979, and Mga Batang Paete (Paete Children), exhibited at the same gallery in the same year. In 1981, he produced a series of sculptures in ivory on the subject of Filipino myths and legends.

His works were also exhibited at the Philippine Center in New York in 1984, the II Bienal de la Havana in 1986, and the Tokyo International Art Show in 1993.

The Art Association of the Philippines awarded him an honorable mention for Invierno (Winter) in 1977, and silver medal for Offspring in 1978. Written by Imelda C. Endaya, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

BALDEMOR, MANUEL (Manuel Dailo Baldemor) aka Manny Baldemor is a painter. He was born in Paete, Laguna on 26 Mar 1947. He is the son of Perfecto Baldemor and Felicitas Dailo. He is brother to sculptor Angelito. He belongs to an artists’ clan of Paete, a town known for wood carving. Baldemor is a product of both folk art tradition and fine arts training. He graduated from the University of Santo Tomas in 1968. Because of his exposure and training in the workshops of the wood-carvers and santeros (makers of religious images) of Paete, Baldemor decided to work on sculptural reliefs. Later, he also tried to develop the Paete industry of taka (papier-mâché) by designing flat wall taka depicting rural scenes.

A consistent subject of his art has been his hometown, its people, their day-to-day activities, and their celebrations. He first attracted attention in the early 1970s with his pen-and-ink drawings, capturing in meticulous detail the folk spirit of Paete. A typical work would show flat superimpositions of winding streets, landscapes, wooden houses, ornaments of flower boxes, hanging plants, a figure of Christ or a saint surrounded by cloudlike garlands of sampaguita and ylang-ylang—all in a charming, decorative arrangement. Like Vicente Manansala and Galo B. Ocampo before him, he indigenized subjects such as religious feasts and the Last Supper by giving the characters a local cast.

Baldemor has also worked in printmaking, many of his prints being still lifes of folk objects and utensils, as well as fruits and vegetables of backyard gardens. He has done a series of genre scenes using textile collage in his paintings. His style, while of a lively folk quality, also shows the influence of Manansala in its cubistic idiom. Baldemor’s awards include the Art Association of the Philippines’ major awards for Filipino Home and Paete in 1972 and 1973, respectively; honorable mention, Huling Tagay (Last Drink), 1974; and best entry, From a Farmer’s Son, 1982. In Oct 2007, his painting titled Karo ng Sorbetes (Ice Cream Cart) was instrumental in capturing a UNESCO seat for the Philippines during the 34th general conference in Paris. His art is well known internationally as he worked as UNICEF’s designer for 18 years, from 1990 to 2008. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1992. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rina Corpuz

 

 

Source

 

Manila Bulletin. n.d. “Manuel Baldemor.” http://www.mb.com.ph/manuelbaldemor/.

BALDOVINO, DICK (Richard Fletcher Baldovino) was a photographer. He was born in Manila on 11 Jul 1937. He died in Quezon City on 6 Jan 2007. He was the son of Guillermo Baldovino and Dulcina Fletcher. He married Josefina Joya, sister of National Artist Jose Joya. In 1957, Baldovino started as a news photographer covering the International Airport for the Philippine News Service. From then on he either joined or contributed as a freelancer to other newspapers like The Manila Times, Manila Chronicle, Daily Mirror, Sunday Times, and Philippines Herald Magazine. Baldovino joined film productions as a still photographer in Gerardo de Leon movies like Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1961; The Moises Padilla Story, 1961; El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1962; and Daigdig ng mga Api (World of the Oppressed), 1965. In 1963, Baldovino became the first Filipino photographer to be hired by a foreign international publication, The Asia Magazine. This enabled him to travel extensively in the countries of Europe, the Middle East, Southeast Asia, and other Asian Pacific countries.

In 1966, Baldovino’s photo essay on the Iglesia ni Cristo was included in the Penrose Annual, a yearly compilation of the world’s best publications that feature the best in photojournalism. After martial law was declared in 1972, Baldovino turned to advertising where his photographs were used for annual reports, company brochures, posters, and print ads.

Baldovino conducted photography workshops, judged photography competitions here and abroad, and exhibited his works in key cities around the world. One of his more important shows consisted of a national traveling exhibition of his collection of black-and-white photographs featuring National Artist Carlos V. Francisco, first shown at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Baldovino is known for photographs that focus on visual arts and artists. He photographed for a number of coffee-table books: The Joya Book of Drawings, Sanso, Juan Luna, Edades, Kayamanan: Paintings from the Central Bank Collection, Old Italian Masters, Joya by Joya: Book of Drawings, Damian Domingo, A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces, Art Philippines, Jose Blanco, Ang Kiukok, Cesar Legaspi, Piña, Aba Ginoong Maria (Hail Mary), Kasalan (Wedding), Philippine Religious Paintings, and Antipolo: A Shrine to Our Lady.

In 1986, Baldovino received the Outstanding Achievement Award during the Philippine Photography Week. He is cited in Best of the Philippines and Who’s Who in the Philippines for photography. He won the Anvil Award in 1973 and 1975. Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Rachel Mayo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

 

Source

 

Baldovino, Dick. 2007. “Dick Baldovino, 69: A Key Figure in Philippine Photography.” The Manila Times, 8 Jan, A3.

BANAL, YASON (Jason Baluyut Banal) is an artist. He was born in Manila on 26 Aug 1972. He is the son of Jorge Lerma Banal Sr and Charminia Nuqui Baluyut. He earned his bachelor of arts in film at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1995 and his master of fine arts from Goldsmiths, University of London, in 2002. He teaches experimental film, queer cinema, and special topics at the UP Film Institute (UPFI) and was coordinator for theater services in charge of the UPFI Film Center from 2009 to 2012. Banal has also served as visiting lecturer at the Tokyo National University of Fine Art and Music and the London Metropolitan University.

Banal founded and ran the short-lived but seminal site-specific project Third Space from 1998 to 2000 at a juncture when artist-initiated spaces were on the rise as emergent artists were also hosting exhibitions and programs at Surrounded by Water and Big Sky Mind. Third Space was a house turned laboratory space for alternative art lessons, film screenings, exhibitions, and happenings, including off-site interventions such as Kaka- at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), Queenly Matter in SM Megamall, and Masa de Gala in various churches and cruising spots. Banal’s conceptual approach to work extends to curating and writing, which he occasionally does under the moniker Sonja Laban, even adopting an artist alias, WWW.KX3.BIZ. His whimsical and cryptic texts often appear as artist’s curatorial statements and would, in one form or other, constitute the content of Banal’s now-defunct column, Sleepwalking, in The Philippine Star.

Banal’s creative and critical practice encompass photography, video, performance, text, and installation. He infuses these with references to culture, language, and art history, usually with a playful tenor that allows him to slip critiques through the art world’s own gatekeeping mechanisms. Done through performative and object-based approach often within institutional spaces themselves, Banal’s interventions—such as a sold-off Christie’s cyber domain, a starlet’s suicide note emblazoned on the wall at the Ateneo Art Awards, the booths and passageways of art fairs, and even the display perimeters of canon-drawing survey shows—get his ideas enfolded into the systems he himself as an artist needs to work in.

His shows are somehow linked, as they are all in varying ways on trial modes of art production, display and valuation, and the possible suppressed ties among the formal, the economic, the institutional and the social. His CCP exhibition A Reading of Brightness Dark Clouds Surrounding displayed documents related to the Metropolitan Museum’s White Cube gallery for rent, banner portraits of 13 beautiful male artists (in lieu of the CCP 13 Artists), Super 8 film footage of the renovation of the former Senate Hall inside the National Museum, an original artwork by Damien Hirst guarded by CCP security, theory books and costume jewelry in vitrines, and scraped vinyl text from a commissioned work in the first Art Fair Philippines. He had Andy Warhol look-alikes in a standoff at the Tate Modern, Marina Abramovic styled mannequins reading El Filibusterismo (Subversion) at Art Stage and art world gatherings shot in different cities and reimagined as a bourgeois horror film. His photographs include portraits of male figures, mega gallery signages, grainy narratives, and screenshot collages. Sculptures have involved consumed wine and champagne bottles crushed and shaped into minimalist cubes, faux kamagong structures lathered in pastel acrylic and tightening lotion, tarpaulin banners, neon light hyperlinks, and bronze pomegranates. His paintings perform a double take—black abstractions done in various brands of oil paint and studded with pearls, pastel impastos soaked in acid and the disintegration halted and preserved by a museum conservator, and green and blue paintings that double as chroma screens for film and photo shoots. A keen interest in norms, powers, and forms—their histories, economics, aesthetics, and agendas—has proven useful in exploring the tangled networks of art and society, their performers and markers, framing devices, and possible triggers.

Residencies include Rijksakademie Amsterdam, Arts Initiative Tokyo, Platform 3 Indonesia, and Center for Contemporary Art Singapore. Solo exhibitions include Galerie Zimmermann, Edel Assanti, The Drawing Room, Osage Gallery, Mo Space, and Vargas Museum. Group exhibitions include Tate Modern, Tate Britain, IFA Berlin, Oslo Kunsthall, Queens Museum of Art, Bangkok Art and Culture Center, Garage Museum of Art Moscow, Frieze Art Fair, Christie’s, Sotheby’s, Art Stage, Singapore Biennale, Shanghai Biennale, Jakarta Biennale, Sharjah Biennale, and Asia Pacific Triennale. Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

article_title: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Art Collection
text:
BANGKO SENTRAL NG PILIPINAS ART COLLECTION The art collection of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), the country’s central monetary authority, consists of over a thousand paintings, sculptures, prints, and drawings spanning two centuries, as well as gold and pottery of the 8th to the 13th century, and numismatic (coins, bank notes, and medals) items. Pieces of the collection are on perennially rotated public exhibitions at a permanent space within the Metropolitan Museum of Manila and at the Money Museum, both located within the BSP complex in Malate, Manila. There are also paintings at the Philippine International Convention Center, the BSP main office building, and the BSP regional offices and branches. The collection has been variously featured in the Kayamanan book series, 1981-83, in Ginto: History Wrought in Gold, 2004, and in the Tanaw books, 2005, all published by the BSP.

In the late 1950s, paintings, including some so-called Mabini artworks, began to be acquired to adorn the offices of the former Central Bank of the Philippines in Intramuros, Manila. During the term of Gov Gregorio S. Licaros (1970-81), the Central Bank moved to its present site in a building complex designed by Gabriel Formoso. Paintings by Ang Kiukok, Fernando C. Amorsolo, Jose T. Joya, Arturo Luz, and other artists were added to the bank collection at this juncture.

The collection further grew under Gov Jaime C. Laya (1981-84) who systematized, expanded, and documented the art collection to include “the origins of Philippine paintings” as well as pre-Hispanic and colonial artifacts. Select pieces were featured in the books Kayamanan: 77 Paintings from the Central Bank Collection, Kayamanan: Pottery and Ceramics from the Arturo de Santos Collection, and Kayamanan: The Philippine Jewelry Tradition.

During the terms of Gov Rafael B. Buenaventura (1999-2005) and Gov Amando M. Tetangco Jr (2005-16), the BSP constituted a panel of experts to review its inventory and estimate the market value of each work. The books Tanaw: Perspectives on the BSP Painting Collection and Tanaw: Catalog of the BSP Painting Collection were consequently published in 2005. As of 2011, the painting collection, which was originally acquired for 68 million pesos, was conservatively appraised at nearly two billion pesos.

The BSP painting collection holds representative works of almost all of the Philippine National Artists and the “Thirteen Moderns.” Nineteenth-century religious paintings, conceptual art, social realist works, and graphic arts are likewise featured in the collection. Expanded acquisitions and collection strategies have also been put in place to enhance its contemporary art collection. Tanaw: The BSP Art Competition, a biennial painting competition, was launched in 2010. Written by Roberto Eliseo Paulino

 

 

Sources

 

Arzadon, Cristina. 2013. “Bangko Sentral Brings Art Collection to Communities.” Philippine Daily Inquirer, 4 Aug.

BSP (Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas). 2012a. “The BSP Tanaw Art Competition 2012.” Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas website. Accessed 20 Jul 2014. http://www.bsp.gov.ph/publications/media.asp?id=2973.\

———. 2012b. “Invitation for Entries for the 2nd Tanaw Art Competition.” Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas website. Posted 4 Sep. Accessed 20 Jul 2014. http://www.bsp.gov.ph/publications/media.asp?id=2973.

Bunye, Ignacio R. 2011a. “BSP’s Painting Collection.” Sun Star, 19 Nov.

———. 2011b. “A Storehouse of Philippine Culture.” Sun Star, 1 May.

———. 2012a. “The BSP’s New Art Collections.” Sun Star, 19 Nov.

———. 2012b. “Patron of the Arts.” Sun Star, 26 Nov.

———. 2012c. “Patron of the Arts.” Sun Star, 3 Dec.

———. 2012d. “Philippine Treasures.” Sun Star, 28 Oct.

Buo, Cristina. 2013. “Exploring Three Centuries of Philippine Art.” CNN iReport, 14 Oct. Accessed 22 Jul 2014. http://ireport.cnn.com/docs/DOC-1048447.

Laya, Jaime C., Alice G. Guillermo, Cid Reyes, Ma. Victoria T. Herrera, and Fatima J. Lasay. 2005. Tanáw: Perspectives on the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Painting Collection, edited by Ramon E. S. Lerma. Manila: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

Metropolitan Museum of Manila. 2012. “New Works at the BSP Art Collection.” Metropolitan Museum of Manila website. Accessed 22 Jul 2014. http://www.metmuseum.ph/downloads/pdfs/pr/PRENDURING.pdf.

Peralta, Jesus. 1982. Kayamanan: Pottery and Ceramics from the Arturo de Santos Collection. Foreword by Jaime C. Laya. Manila: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

Torres, Emmanuel. 1981. Kayamanan: 77 Paintings from the Central Bank Collection. Manila: Central Bank of the Philippines.

Villegas, Ramon N. 1983. Kayamanan: The Philippine Jewelry Tradition. Foreword by Jaime C. Laya. Manila: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

———. 2004a. Ginto: History Wrought in Gold. Manila: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

———. 2005. Introduction to Tanáw: Catalogue of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Painting Collection. Manila: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas.

BANZON, GENARA (Genara Fernandez Banzon) is an installation and multimedia artist. She was born in Manila on 28 Nov 1953. She is the daughter of Julian Banzon, a nationally honored research scientist, and Vivencia Fernandez, a physician. Genara earned her bachelor of fine arts from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1974, and completed a master’s degree in development communication at UP Los Baños in 1978. In 1992, she completed a master of fine arts in studio for interrelated media at the Massachusetts College of Art in Boston.

From 1974, Banzon worked closely with Roberto Chabet and Ray Albano’s group of conceptual artists who exhibited regularly at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Her works stood out as they focused on natural, creative processes. Banzon states: “My main interest as an artist is to investigate indigenous and ‘non-art’ materials, to invent procedures and systems in art making. I am concerned with making alive the forces or energies of local character and establishing installation as an art form.” Her works were included in the exhibits Site Works I and II at the UP Los Baños, Art of the Regions in Baguio, Five Directions at the Museum of the Philippine Art, Trends in Philippine Sculpture and Fiber as Art both at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.

Based in Massachusetts since the late 1980s, Banzon has developed a multifaceted art career. She evolved a body of work that innovatively integrated use of natural materials (such as leaves, butterfly wings, and sand) and current technology (such as video and X-ray plates) to comment on contemporary issues using her life experiences as an exile. Encouraging self-examination within the Filipino-American community, her work interweaves personal narratives with issues of migration. She has dealt with themes such as mail-order brides, the sex tourism industry, stereotyping of Asian women, and sociohistorical aspects of US and Spanish colonialism in the Philippines.

Her major works in multimedia installation include Bukid Art Inn (Farm Art Inn) at the First Baguio Arts Festival and at the Black Swan Gallery in Australia; Likha: La Orana Maria (Creation: La Orana Maria) at the ARX ’87 in Perth, Australia; Love Par Avion at the Powerhouse Museum and Performance Space Gallery in Sydney in 1989; Mahal Ba Kita?: The Economics of Love (Do I Love You?: The Economics of Love) at the World Bank in Washington, DC; and A Woman’s View: Equality, Development and Peace at the Art Gallery in the University of California, Irvine.

Her works have also been exhibited at the Third Asian Art Show at the Fukuoka Museum, Institute of Contemporary Art Boston Harvard Neighbors Gallery, the Fuller Museum of Art in Massachusetts, and the Dia Center for the Arts in New York. She received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1978. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya

BARREDO, GABRIEL (Gabriel Imutan Barredo) is a sculptor and installation artist. He was born in Manila on 6 Oct 1957. His parents are Eugenio Barredo and Criselda Imutan. Born to an artistic family, he wanted to be a ballet dancer and musician; in the mid-1980s he joined his sister Maniya Barredo in a ballet company in Atlanta where he did costumes and sets, including huge screens. He studied sculpture at the University of Santo Tomas.

While many of his works consist of chairs, seats, lamps, screens, and mirror or dock stands, their functional aspect is overshadowed by their sculptural quality. They even bear a relation to painting in their linear refinement and rich imagery. Often, the sculptural form, while integral in itself, doubles as a web for grouping of figures. Caught in the borderline between reality and fantasy, the question of material and process comes to the fore. Figures are molded and hardened with layers of resin imparting a translucent glow. To execute his designs, he uses discards such as rods from bent and welded electric fan covers, broken particles of car windshields that have a crystalline appearance, and various materials like wood, paper, wrought iron, antique radios, coconut husks, bottle caps, bedsprings, fire hose coils, conveyor belts, wooden beads, computer and refrigerator parts, and cement grinders. Found objects and junk are transformed as elements of the sculptural form.

He held his first one-person show Mindscape, 1993, at the Gallery Genesis at the Megamall, Mandaluyong City. Since then, he has done solo and group shows here and abroad. He was the Philippine representative to the Havana Biennale in Cuba in 1985, and the Sao Paulo Biennale in Brazil in 1994. In 2016, he created a monumental three-level set for Ballet Philippines’ Opera, which interpreted themes of birth, death, and rebirth through three-dimensional white figures of decapitated mannequins (some with smaller figures trapped inside their hollow torsos), floating body parts, curled fetuses, and an array of human and animal skeletons as well as two-dimensional blowups of anatomical studies dissecting the human body parts.

The Art Association of the Philippines awarded him the grand prize for Inner Vision in 1981 and gold medal for Primal Scream in 1982. The Metrobank Foundation awarded him first prize for Mindscape No. 6 in 1985. In 1994, he received the Diwa ng Sining Awards from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the city of Manila in 1998. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

BARRIOQUINTO, ANDRES (Andres Santos Barrioquinto) aka Andy Barrioquinto is a painter. He was born in Manila on 6 Apr 1975. He is the son of journalist Cesar Barrioquinto and Ma. Socorro Santos. He is a painter and is married to fellow artist Iya Consorio with whom he has two children, Mazzy Star and Coco Rosie. During his youth, Barrioquinto lived in Hong Kong with his family for several years because of his father’s work. This is where he experienced the darker and violent tendencies of city living. Prior to leaving Manila, the young Barrioquinto would hang out in the art department of the newspaper where his father worked. Upon his return to Manila, he attended an art workshop at the University of the Philippines before he eventually enrolled in the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he graduated in 2000 as a painting major.

Labeled by media pundits as the “Dark Man of Philippine Art,” his works often show the gloomy side of people, occasionally even venturing into the hysterical and nightmarish. This tendency was already obvious even in his first solo exhibitions Stop Killing Me and My Love Gone Wrong Songs, both in 2001. This propensity toward bleakness has persisted in later works, although these are more characteristically nuanced in the way they draw upon psychological feelings of terror internally induced by evoking the viewers’ imagination instead of relying on recognizably horrific visual elements. His early work as a professional painter often referenced variable styles evoking apparition-like forms in Stop Killing Me to the caricatures of Ugaling Baboy (Pig’s Ways), 2004, with its distortions of the human face and body.

Barrioquinto’s preference for the color blue surfaced in 2005 in Altered States shown at Singapore’s Utterly Art gallery. In 2008, the exhibition Unexamined Failure/Disorder showed him experimenting with a blend of realism and cubism, as in the painting Wilderness, which also manifested the beginnings of his now recurring motif of floral patterns serving as both figure and ground. In 2009, his works making up The Gods of Small Things featured the heavy use of Japanese print patterns and other Japanese imagery, which he stylistically integrated into his pieces. Although Barrioquinto has become known for these paintings that involve appending a small canvas to a larger canvas that come layered with patterns and mostly somber faces, such as in Shadow Dancer, 2011, he still occasionally veers away from this mode of image-making as in the show Black Days, 2012, in which he reverted to expressionistically distorted figures.

Barrioquinto has held solo and group exhibitions in various galleries in the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, and the United Kingdom. He was awarded an honorable mention in the watercolor category of the 30th National Student Competition of the Shell Art Awards and the third prize in the 50th Annual Art Competition of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), both citations handed in 1997. He also received the grand prize at the 15th Young Painters Annual National Painting Competition of the Metrobank Foundation, 1998; juror’s choice, 1st Nokia Arts Awards–Asia Pacific, Singapore, 1999; juror’s choice in the 52nd AAP Annual Art Competition, 1999; honorable mention in the 9th Taiwan International Biennial Print and Drawing Competition, 1999; the UST Benavides Award, 1999 and 2000; best entry, lithography category, Print Association of the Philippines, 2000; and ACES Award for Continuing Excellence, Metrobank Foundation, 2009. Barrioquinto received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2003. Written by Iris S. De Ocampo

BARTOLOME, HUGE is an intermedia artist. He was born on 5 Nov 1955. He studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts.

Bartolome’s only solo show on extant records is Lung at the Small Gallery (now Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1976, which in fellow artist-peer Judy Freya Sibayan’s words was an “idea exhibition,” reflective of the still tentative visual categories of the period. Lung consisted of nested plastic bags placed strategically at the entrance of the Small Gallery. Visitors were instructed to take two bags each, breathe into and place these into the alcoves of the interior space that was curtained off from easy view. Still in keeping with the early insistence of these artists to mine the everyday, Lung was further framed by Sibayan as “space being turned into sculpture” with collective human breath defining the shape and possible motion tracks of these accumulated transparent membranes flitting or sitting within the bounds of the static but now made plastic gallery site. One seemingly final appearance of Bartolome was dated to Feb 1988, where writer Nonoy Espina reports that the artist disrobed and enacted a crucifixion and rebirth alluding to his casting off of the worldliness he asserted was hounding artists and other practices of personal faith.

Bartolome’s group exhibitions include Untitled Painting No. 1 and Other Paintings, 1974, CCP Small Gallery; Portfolio: Problems Definite, Solutions Infinite, 1976, CCP Main Gallery; CCP Annual, 1981, CCP Main Gallery; and Mixed Media, 1985, Pinaglabanan Galleries. While little data are available on Bartolome’s own work at this juncture, it is evident that he was part of the series of theme/artistic problem-related projects done at the CCP during the term of Director Ray Albano. As indicated in the show titles themselves, Bartolome and his peers would receive a curatorial prompt to which they would respond with a work. Portfolio, for instance, was proffered as an exploration of “aesthetic relationships” bound up in discreet units with a discernibly logical affinity. Bartolome specifically seemed to have responded to the notion of a portfolio as potentially occasioning a “sequence of movements” as in the case of film. For the exhibition, he turned in Terrestrial Transports I, II, and III.

Bartolome’s collaborations with former CCP curator Judy Freya Sibayan are accessible primarily through Sibayan’s autobiographical project, The Hypertext of HerMe(s). She describes her work with Bartolome and Ray Albano in Thanksgiving Day on 21 Sep 1978 at Liwasang Bonifacio as an early morning ritual-like laying out of mirrors at Liwasang Bonifacio, which simultaneously taunted vandals and a crowd apparently indifferent to the antics of artists. Other collaborative performances with Sibayan include To and Fro, 1974, UP Diliman Sunken Garden; Eating, 1977, UP Diliman College of Fine Arts; Three Pieces, 1977, CCP End Room; Three Pieces, 1977, with Sibayan and Albano, Thomas Jefferson Cultural Center; and Hide Park, 1979, again with Albano and Sibayan, UP Diliman Lagoon.

Bartolome posthumously figured in the exhibition Filipiniana, 2006, at the Centro Cultural Conde Eduque, Madrid. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1976. Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

 

Sources

 

Espina, Nonoy. 1991. “Shock It to Me.” Sunday Standard Magazine, 11 Aug, p. 7.

Legaspi-Ramirez, Eileen. 2011. “For the Record: Agency and the Crafting of Discourse around Performance Art from the Philippines.” MA thesis, College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Sibayan, Judy Freya. 1976. “Two Idea Exhibitions.” Marks. Cultural Center of the Philippines Museum.

———. 2014a. Curriculum vitae. Nov.

BAUTISTA, GLENN (Glenn Angeles Bautista) was a painter. He was born in Orion, Bataan on 20 Mar 1947. He died on 6 May 2014. His father, the Rev Ignacio P. Bautista, was a church minister of the United Methodist Church for 39 years; his mother, Eugenia Angeles, was a deaconess. He has a son with his wife Lorna. The family resided in Houston, Texas, USA, since 2009. He studied at Santa Ana Elementary School, 1959, and Union High School, 1963, in Manila after which he majored in advertising at the University of Santo Tomas (UST). In 1969, he earned a fine arts certificate in advertising at the University of the Philippines (UP). From there he proceeded to the Brooks Institute School of Fine Arts in Santa Barbara, California, where he obtained a bachelor’s degree in fine arts, major in painting, with honors in 1972. He studied lithography in the winter semester, 1982-83, at the Staatliche Kunstakademie in Dusseldorf, Germany.

Bautista began in the mid-1960s as a painter of portraits and religious objects. While these early works were Christian, his art acquired an increasingly eclectic character, drawing on elements from the different traditional Asian religions to create a spiritual synthesis of modes of religious worship. In the 1970s, his imagery shifted to the surreal, as in his Inner Light series, which showed multilevel rock landscapes punctuated with personal symbols. He has worked in numerous media, including painting in oil and pastel, watercolor, photography, collage, cogon and abaca paper, lithography, and pencil and has used street rubbings, bas reliefs, cutouts, and sculptures.

A number of his solo and group exhibitions are the following: his first one-man show Inscapes, Ateneo Art Gallery, 1969; Glenn’s Works in Transparencies, Savoy-Hyatt Hotel, 1971; Pilipinas, Philippine Consulate, New York, 1972; Thirteen Artists, 1974, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Inner-Light Series, Metro Gallery, 1975; In Search of the Divine, Sining Kamalig, 1976; Abstractions, Sining Kamalig, 1978; Philippine Paintings, Madurodam Complex, The Hague, 1980; Abstractions, ABC Galleries, 1982; 1985 ASEAN Show, National Museum of Singapore; Cut-Outs in Paper and Wood Series, 1985, on permanent display at the Galerie Art204, Dusseldorf, Germany; Nature and Technology, Gallery Genesis, 1985; and Halo-Halo (Mash-up), CCP, 1987. In 2009-10, he participated in group exhibits of the Weatherford Art Association at the Firehouse Gallery and Art Center, Texas. He began doing art talks and exhibits in Houston, Texas, since 2010.

He won first prize for The Event in the International Christmas Art Competition sponsored by the World Literary and Christian Literature in New York, 1965. The Shell National Students Art Competition gave Bautista a certificate of merit for Chinese Garden in 1967 and first prize for Fort Santiago in 1968. Other awards include first prize, The U.P. Entrance, 1967, on-the-spot painting contest, UP President’s Committee on Culture; third prize, Main Building, 1968, UST 37th Anniversary Foundation Day on-the-spot painting contest; second prize, Arts and Sciences Building, 1968, on-the-spot painting contest, UP President’s Committee on Culture; and first prize, Aguinaldo Portrait Mural, 1969, Aguinaldo Centennial Commission. He was named one of the Thirteen Artists by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1974. Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Rosa Concepcion Ladrido, updated by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

 

Sources

 

Bautista, Glenn A. n.d. Website. www.glennbautista.com.

Santos, Mariano. 2014. “Artist Glenn A. Bautista, 67, Passes Away in Houston, Texas.” Inquirer.net, 15 May. http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/159929/artist-glenn-a-bautista-67-passes-awayin-houston-texas#ixzz3yRNQ9ySi.

BAUTISTA, JOE (Jose Degollado Bautista) aka Jobau is an intermedia artist. He was born on 15 Jan 1951. He is the son of Juan O. Bautista and Teodora Degollado. Bautista enrolled in a bachelor of arts in advertising course at the University of the East College of Fine Arts from 1969 to 1972. He went through a vocational track in his last two years at the Arellano High School. This armed him with skills in graphic arts, carpentry, and automotive and TV repairs. This technical aptitude allowed him to tinker and look at industrial and found objects as resource for his art. Bautista was apparently deeply sensitive about his perceived outside status, coming as he did from the University of the East and having only heard of then Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Museum Director Roberto Chabet through fellow Shell awardee Rodolfo Gan. Not being interested in producing traditional art, Bautista introduced himself to Chabet and earned his approval and, eventually, that of Chabet’s successor Ray Albano. Among Bautista’s cheekiest works were his box-type dextrose tube installation injected with luminous paint for a two-man show with Marciano Galang; his papering over the gallery walls with a reverse shot of the ceiling in Post No Bill, the inaugural CCP Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo (also known as Small Gallery) exhibition; and his turning in 100 paper bags and a toilet bowl plunger he called Bomba (Bomb) for the 1973 Objects exhibition.

Of the Shop 6 artists who brazenly produced ephemeral work in the early 1970s, Bautista’s practice possibly most dramatically demonstrates the intersections between artists inclined to a type of homespun or organically evolved conceptualism while injecting social commentary. His 1979 Bubong (Roof), for instance, which appeared in the Five Contemporary Sculptors exhibition at the CCP Bulwagang Juan Luna (also known as Main Gallery) led to the cutting short of the exhibition run, as it coincided with an International Monetary Fund event whose delegates, according to Bautista, Imelda Marcos did not want exposed to such a jarring representation of squalor. As was the case with many of his peers, Bautista’s work would demonstrate an interest in seriality and repetition as well as a dislodging of structure, often using the most mundane of materials such as bamboo, sand, mongo seeds (mung beans), laurel leaves, activist paraphernalia, hospital sanitary discards, chicken coop fencing, a hula hoop, water, machine oil, plastic, books, magazine clippings, a mouse trap, a face towel, tea bags, rags, among others.

Albano describes Bautista’s capacity to create “situations,” citing specifically 100 Paper Bags and The End in the 1972 CCP summer exhibition where his predilection to playing off meaning and materiality would find witty realization. The artist is also remembered for the upended triangle of grass atop mirror work called Bermuda Triangle and for Piet Mondrian ’84 which pairs a lowly woven kitchen rag with a printed reproduction of Mondrian’s gridded color strips. Both works appeared at Pinaglabanan Galleries, as the latter took on the experimental art mantle alongside the CCP.

Bautista participated in group exhibitions that included the CCP Summer Exhibition, 1972; Shop 6 Inaugural, 1974, Sining Kamalig; 101 Artists, 1974, Shop 6; Shop 6: Early Works / Circa 1975, Rizal Park; Shop 6 at the CCP, 1975; Contemporary Art in the Philippines, 1976, inaugural Contemporary Art Museum of the Philippines exhibit; First CCP Annual, 1976, CCP Main Gallery; Pencil and Paper, 1977, CCP Small Gallery; Roots, Basics, and Beginnings, 1977, CCP Small Gallery; Gridworks, 1978, CCP Main Gallery; Third CCP Annual, 1978, CCP Main Gallery; A Decade of Developmental Art, 1979, CCP Main Gallery; CCP Annual, 1979, CCP Small Gallery; Wordworks, Graffiti, and Other Works with Words, 1979, CCP Small Gallery; Preview, 1984, Pinaglabanan Galleries; 33 Artists, 1984, Pinaglabanan Galleries; Recent Abstractions, 1985, Pinaglabanan Galleries; Mixed Media, 1985, Pinaglabanan Galleries; Sikat: Two Decades of Philippine Art, 1969-89 (Ray of Sun / Famous: Two Decades of Philippine Art, 1969-89), CCP Main Gallery; and Articulating Structures and Mediums: A Group Exhibition, 2011, Nova Gallery.

Bautista worked with the Population Commission through 1986 and exhibited less aggressively since, tending to design and trade business to support his family. He was awarded first prize for his work Mechanical Frame in the sculpture category of the 1969 Shell Art Competition. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1972. Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

BELLEZA, NORMA (Norma Jaciledo Belleza) is a painter. She was born in San Fernando, Pampanga on 3 May 1939. She is the daughter of Alfonso Belleza and Artemia Jaciledo. Her family members were movie marquee and billboard painters. She is married to painter Angelito Antonio. Their children Fatima, Emil, and Marcel are also painters. A fine arts graduate of the University of Santo Tomas, she held her first exhibit at the Philippine Art Gallery in 1963. Her early years as a young artist were difficult but she developed a distinctive style.

At first, Belleza’s paintings were dark and somber representations of religious subjects, but she progressed into colorful and detailed work on folk genre subjects, including women vendors, potters, peasants in various rural activities, and Metro Manila aides. Her figurative works placed emphasis on her subjects’ physical strength and appearance. Color has remained of primary importance in her work—for instance, blue for outlining figures has created the effects of both volume and movement while white has intensified the play of colors. The rich details of dress such as floral designs and stripes, accessories like umbrellas, and the vast array of wares, flowers and fruits, fish and fowl have been used to bring out the entire spectrum of color in her paintings.

The Shell National Students Art Competition gave her second prize for Dead Christ, 1961. The Art Association of the Philippines awarded her honorable mention for Betrayal and third prize for Pieta, both in 1963. She won second prize in the Travellers Life Art Competition, 1961, and a silver medal in the Travellers Life Religious Art Contest, 1962. In 1993, she was given the Araw ng Maynila award for painting. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

Source

Heritage Art Center. 2010. “Norma Belleza.” http://www.heritageartcenter.com/2010/11/norma-belleza_28.html.

BENCAB (Benedicto Reyes Cabrera) is a painter and National Artist for visual arts. He was born in Manila on 10 Apr 1942. He is the son of Democrito Cabrera and Isabel Reyes. He is the brother of fellow artist Salvador Cabrera. He was married to Caroline Kennedy. Cabrera took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP), 1959-63. He first worked as an illustrator in the Sunday Times Magazine of the Manila Times, 1965-68, before he was encouraged to go full time into painting by painters like Virgilio Aviado, Marciano Galang, and Alfredo Liongoren.

His early paintings of scavengers, derelicts of the city, and the barong-barong (shanties) were reflections of his growing-up years in places like Tondo, Bambang, and Mayhaligue. He did many sketches of a madwoman named Sabel as she scavenged around garbage cans. Cabrera acknowledged the female German artist Kathe Kollwitz as having had the greatest influence on his works, especially those dealing with the lower classes—like beggars, scavengers, and laborers—and the mother-and-child theme.

Later, Cabrera became concerned with the Philippines’ colonial past. Based on old photographs, his later paintings took on the form of social commentaries on the influences of American and Spanish colonizers. Pit-a-Pit Metamorphosis shows a young Igorot boy undergoing a process of colonization. Types of True Filipinos Waiting to Be Called Americans depicts the servility of Filipinos to the Americans. Surveying the New Territory is a painting of a white man astride a horse surveying some land. Brown Brother’s Burden shows a white man on a palanquin being carried by four Cordillera tribespeople. Aside from painting, Cabrera has done a lot of etchings, aquatints, and prints. He also explored handmade paper as a medium for visual expression.

His first exhibition was in 1960 at the Indigo Gallery in Ermita, Manila. Throughout the 1970s and the 1980s, he had solo or group shows nearly every year. In the early 1970s, Cabrera and his wife moved to England. While in London, he held various solo exhibitions in reputable galleries. While in Europe, he also joined several Philippine shows in The Hague, Netherlands; the Six Artistes Contemporains Philippines en Europe (Six Contemporary Filipino Artists in Europe) in Paris; Philippine Printmakers at the Royal Festival Hall in London; the Philippine Graphic Art Exhibition in Munich; and the 8th Biennale Internationale de Arts in Valparaiso, Chile.

BenCab is a recognized cultural leader in Baguio City. He has a studio in Tubao, Benguet, where artists meet. Together with a small group of artists, he established the Baguio Arts Guild in 1987. In the late 1990s, Cabrera’s input was a critical element in the creation of Tam-awan Village, an assembled cluster of conserved Cordillera indigenous houses, which has become a site for fusing art, cultural, environmental, and historical advocacy. To showcase his personal art collection as well as his own artworks, he built and continues to manage the BenCab Museum in Baguio City.

Cabrera won awards and distinctions such as second prize for Blue Serenity in the 1962 Shell National Students Art Competition; first prize in the UP Student Council Art Competition, 1963; and first prize for Yero (Galvanized Iron), second prize for Manok (Chicken), and third honorable mention for Pader (Wall) in the Art Association of the Philippines photography competition in 1967. Books on his artworks were written by Alfredo Roces, Jun Terra, Nick Joaquin, Beatriz Romualdez Francia, Gloria G. Goloy, Leonidas Benesa, and Amadis Ma. Guerrero. He received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 1992. He was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts in 2006. The University of the Philippines conferred upon him an honorary doctor of humanities degree in 2009. A yearlong retrospective exhibit in 2015 marked BenCab’s 50th anniversary as an artist. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rina Corpuz

 

Source

 

BenCab Museum. 2014. Website. Accessed 1 Oct. http://www.bencabmuseum.org/national-artist/.

BENESA, LEONIDAS (Leonidas V. Benesa) was a poet, essayist, and art critic. He was born in Bangued, Abra on 28 Jan 1928. He died in 1984. He had his early schooling in his home province and obtained his bachelor of arts and master of arts in English at Ateneo de Manila University. He studied at the University of California on a scholarship grant. At one time, he was executive secretary of the Operations Brotherhood in Laos. During the Marcos administration, he served as head of the film division of the Bureau of Standards for Mass Media of the Ministry of Public Information and was managing editor of Archipelago, a publication of the ministry. He was one of the founders of the International Association of Art Critics.

His works in art criticism include his columns for the Weekend (the Friday supplement of the Philippine Daily Express) under the title The Arts, and A Brief History of the Modern Art Movement in the Philippines from 1928 to 1962, 1963, which was commissioned by the National Museum. He published Joya Drawings, 1973, and Galo B. Ocampo: 50 Years of Art, 1982. He also published books on the history of printmaking in the Philippines such as The Printmakers, 1975; The Art of Fine Prints: A View of 25 Years, 1980; and Okir: The Epiphany of Philippine Graphic Art, 1981.

Benesa’s poems “Poet in the City” and “Parable of the Young Man” appeared in Signatures in 1956, while his “Ryoan-ji at 6 P.M., Kyoto” was included in Sinaglahi (Light of the Race), 1975, edited by M. L. Santaromana. He edited Signature, vol. 2, no. 1 (Mar 1958).

Benesa won the Joseph Mulry Award from Ateneo for his psalm “Deserts of God” and first prize from the Art Association of the Philippines for his art criticism. He also received the Tanging Parangal award from the city of Manila in 1979. In 2000, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts published What Is Philippine about the Philippine Arts?, a collection of his essays from 1975 to 1981. Benesa is recognized for his poetic style in art writing and communicating the pensive and transcendent qualities of an artwork to his readers. Written by E. R. Galang, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

 

Source

 

Panitikan.com.ph. n.d. “Leonidas Benesa.” http://www.panitikan.com.ph/content/leonidas-benesa.

BERNARDO, CONSTANCIO (Constancio Anastacio Bernardo) was a painter. He was born in Obando, Bulacan on 22 Dec 1913. He died in Quezon City on 8 Aug 2003. He was the son of Pedro Ma. Bernardo and Cecilia Anastacio. He studied at Obando Elementary School, 1920-25. In 1929, he transferred to Manila West, which is now Florentino Torres High School in Tondo, Manila, and there finished high school in 1933. He obtained a bachelor of fine arts degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1948. He was one of the students of Pablo and Fernando Amorsolo at the UP School of Fine Arts, 1940-41. He got a second bachelor’s degree and a master’s degree in fine arts from Yale University in 1952. He married Nieves de Guzman and they had two sons. In 1953, he resumed teaching at the UP School of Fine Arts, until his retirement in 1978.

In 1979, he held a retrospective of his paintings at the Museum of Philippine Art. Bernardo was one of the earliest and most consistent exponents of abstract art in the country. He worked in series, combining geometrism and color research in such work groupings as the Bernardian series, the Rhapsody Square series, and the Wildflower series. The most striking of these are his series of paintings with a tilted central square of softly modulating hue that transmutes into transparent polygonal shapes determined by mathematical relationships. The square, a principal obsession of the artist, is developed exclusively in the Rhapsody Square series, which takes after the legacy of Josef Albers’s Homage to the Square. In the Rhapsody Square series, Bernardo deals with the same concept of a colored square within a square of a different hue. This is based on the research into color perception begun by Albers and color experiments done at the Bauhaus. In the Wildflower series, color is no longer handled scientifically but becomes symbolic of emotions and values, at the same time that the human figure, specifically the female nude, is brought into a hitherto abstract domain.

The artist received the Alab ng Sining award from the UP College of Fine Arts in 2007. A centennial retrospective of his works, titled Constancio Bernardo, 1913-2003, 2013, was held at the Ayala Museum and at the Cultural Center of the Philippines from Nov 2014 to Feb 2015. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

BIGYAN, UGU (Augusto Lusido Bigyan) is a potter. He was born in Tiaong, Quezon on 14 Aug 1963. He is the son of Justino Bigyan Sr and Ursula T. Lusido. He graduated with a bachelor of science degree in accounting from Manuel S. Enverga University Foundation in 1984. He was a student of potters Jaime and Anne de Guzman. Bigyan’s work in his seventh one-person exhibit at the Ayala Museum has been described as “a play of solid forms, altered pieces, wax-resist decoration, stoneware textures, batik prints on ceramics and new experimental discoveries in studio pottery. He is known for his well-crafted pottery, for imaginatively incorporating natural fibers such as rattan and abaca, twigs and roots with fired clay, and for constantly exploring the limits and possibilities of clay.” The lack of proper school training did not hinder Bigyan from producing art pieces marked by artistry and innovativeness, as seen in his Two-Bodied Nude of a Woman. He has been a member of Putik Foundation since 2004.

Living near the slopes of Mount Banahaw, Bigyan uses his surroundings to his advantage, drawing inspiration from nature to come up with original and uniquely Filipino designs, such as pots, vases, spoons, candleholders, garlic crushers, wind chimes of ceramic sea horses, which he accents with roots, hemps, vines, and other found objects. His artistry was eventually recognized, mostly by Europeans who travel all the way to his studio-gallery in Quezon province. Bigyan has also established quite a number of outlets for his work in Manila and was, at one juncture, exporting pieces to Holland, France, Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Australia.

Bigyan’s one-person shows include High on Fire at the Ayala Museum, 1988; Fire Works, Madrigal Center, 1989; Art on Fire, Ayala Museum, 1991; Capers and Clay, Luz Gallery, 1992; Fire Works (II), Ayala Museum, 1992; Potters Wheel, Liongoren Art Gallery, 1994; Inspire, Ayala Museum, 1995; and Poetry of Fire, Ayala Museum, 1996. He won third place at the Asean International Lantern Festival in 1998. In 1990 and 1993, he was awarded the Best Product Design at the Manila FAME exhibition. Written by Annaliza Villar, updated by Rosa Concepion Ladrido

 

 

Source

BITANCOR, JEHO (Jeho Leander Bitancor) is a painter and performance artist. He was born in Baler on 24 Oct 1967. He is the son of Gregorio Bitancor and Peladia Leander. His brother is Jose Johann Bitancor, a graphic designer and abstract painter based in California. Bitancor graduated from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts, with majors in both painting and visual communication (advertising), in 1990. He also attended the Art Student’s League and New York University’s School of Continuing and Professional Studies where he finished courses in painting in 1997 and graphic design in 2008, respectively. He is the founder of the Baler Art Group. He was an active member of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) in the 1990s and was also the facilitator of the Philippine International Performance Art Festival in 2003. In 2005 and 2006, he organized the first two Sining-Silangan Visual and Literary Arts Festivals in Baler, Aurora.

Developing from early quasi-surrealist symbology in his work from the 1980s, as well as drawing from his extensive experience in the field of advertising, Bitancor’s paintings bring a concise use of formal elements and symbolism to the fore. He couples these with lenses of subjective observation and direct experience in order to thresh out his reflections on social structures, ideology, and the effects of these on daily individual struggles, demonstrated in pieces such as Lunting-Tinig (Green-Voice), 2015. As with his paintings, Bitancor’s performance works also deal with issues within the thematic ranges of social realism. In his performances, he often assumes the persona of a corporate male thrown into variable narratives that employ a similar symbolic approach to that of his paintings such as in White Lies, 2005, and Blind Faith, 2012. At times, however, Bitancor eschews the closed narrative format in favor of what he calls “live installation” in order to better exploit the immediacy of both his body and the particular sites in which he performs. This latter tendency can be seen in the work Dreaming Green done during the Tutok Perspektiba (Focus Perspective) exhibition at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 2007.

Bitancor’s first solo painting exhibition was at the Shangri-La Plaza Manila in 1995. Titled Takipsilim (Dusk) it was sponsored by the AAP. Since then, he has staged 20 solo exhibitions both here and abroad, including Pilapinas (Get in Line Philippines), 1997, at the Liongoren Gallery; Jeho Bitancor: One Man Show, 1997, at the Vermont Studio Center; Color the Sky Blue, 2007, in Utterly Art Singapore; and Splendid Squalor, 2013, at Art Galilea, Bonifacio Global City. Since 1984, Bitancor has participated in over 70 group exhibitions in varied institutions and galleries here and overseas. These include those staged by artists groups such as the AAP and government institutions such as the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts; regional selections such as the grant-based Fifth ASEAN Youth Painting Exhibition, 1987, and the ASEAN Art Today, 2001; and art fairs, fund-raisers, and various cause-related exhibitions.

Apart from the festivals and events he has organized, Bitancor’s performance work has been featured in a number of platforms in Manila, Baguio, Bangkok, and New York. Among these were the works Spitting at the Red Apple 1 at the ASIATOPIA Performance Art Festival in Bangkok, 2006; In Between Histories, 2007, featured in the Tutok Perspektiba show at UST; Colonizador (Colonizer), 2009, at the Grace Exhibition Space, New York; In Memoriam, 2012, Bliss on Bliss Art Projects, New York; and Ecdysis, 2015, at the exhibition Performance Anxiety, Culture Fix, New York.

Bitancor garnered distinctions from various local and foreign bodies such as the AAP, frequently making the Juror’s Choice list before winning Best Entry for his painting Musmos (Innocence) in 1998; the Freeman Foundation Asian Artists Fellowship Award in Vermont in 1997; the Dangal ng Aurora award for visual arts in his native Baler, Aurora, in 2005; and the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2006. Written by Antares Bartolome

 

Sources

 

Bitancor, Jeho. n.d.a. Curriculum vitae.

BITANGA-PERALTA, ROSARIO (Rosario de Lara Bitanga-Peralta) is a painter. She was born in Laoag on 28 Oct 1934. She is the daughter of Pedro Bitanga and Epifania de Lara. She is married to the anthropologist-writer Jesus Peralta, with whom she has three children. After finishing preparatory law at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), she decided to study fine arts, earning her bachelor’s degree in 1958 at UST and her master’s degree at the Cranbrook Academy of Art, Michigan, USA, 1960. She has been a member of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP); Pontiac Society of Artists and Bloomfield Art Association in Michigan, USA; Christian Art Society of the Philippines; and the Partuat Iloko Group of the Philippines of the National Museum.

Bitanga’s works show her concern for aesthetic masses and gestural movement as she derives these from observation of natural form and motion. Coda, 1961, her largest abstract work in bluish, bold, rushing strokes, was described by critic Alice Guillermo as “total image that seems to be cold, petrified flames spreading art from a deep center.” Since her student days, Bitanga has been active in group exhibitions, including the Art Exhibition of the 7th International Conference of the Pan-Pacific Women’s Association, 1955; the Philippine Contemporary Arts Gallery Group Show Annual Exhibition, 1956; the First Southeast Asian Art Conference and Competition, 1957; the annual and semiannual AAP exhibitions; the group show of the Australian Tour of Philippine Art, 1960; the Filipino Women Artist’s Exhibition, 1966; the All Asian Christian Art Exhibition, 1984; and Pagtipon (Gathering) ’86 at the National Museum. She held her first one-person show at the Cranbrook Academy of Arts in 1960; succeeding ones include those at the Philippine Contemporary Arts Gallery, 1960; University of California, Davis, 1975; the Manila Hilton Art Center, 1985; Ayala Museum, 1987; Artist of the Month, Visual Artists Cooperative, House No. 8, Plaza San Luis Complex, Intramuros, 1992; De La Salle University Art Gallery; Asia Art Gallery, Shangri-La Plaza, 1995 and 1997.

In 1993, she delivered the country report at the Sixth Asian Art Biennale in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Her Moonleaves, a postal card collection, was included in the Artists and Master of the 20th Century, Les Editions Arts et Images du Monde, Paris, France. In 1998, she was a co-designer of the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan medallion of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA).

Bitanga won third prize for Encore, Shell National Students Competition, 1957; first prize for portraiture and second prize for composition, both from UST; and top prize in watercolor landscape, AAP, 1958. She won first honorable mention in sculpture, 13th Annual Exhibition, AAP, 1960; third prize for Galloping Horses from the Pontiac Society of Artists Competition in Michigan, 1959; first honorable mention for Famille, 1960, AAP; and honorable mention, Modality, 1963, AAP. In 1999, the NCCA awarded her the Kababaihang Makasaysayan sa Larangan ng Sining at Kalikasan. She received the Millennium Role Model Award, Sarrat, Ilocos Norte, in 2000. In 2004, she received the Outstanding Thomasian Alumni award for visual arts from UST. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya and Rosalinda Galang, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

BLACK ARTISTS IN ASIA (BAA) A Negros-based artist’s organization, Black Artists in Asia was described by art critic Emmanuel Torres as “the most vital [group] to emerge outside Metro Manila”since its founding in 1986. Among its original members are Norberto Roldan, Nunelucio Alvarado, Dennis Ascalon, Charlie Co, Perry Argel, Boysie Imperial, and Mario Stephen Regollo. Its precursor was Pamilya Pintura, a member organization of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines. BAA’s focus on “socially and politically progressive practice” differentiated it from the more conservative Art Association of Bacolod (AAB) founded in 1975 by Edgardo Lizares.

As with the rest of the archipelago during the 1980s, Negros underwent economic and political upheaval toward the end of the Marcos regime. Due to the steep decline in the price of sugar in the international market, the majority of Negrenses who worked in the sugarcane fields and mills suffered extreme hardship and deprivation. To alleviate this, the AAB initiated the Masskara Festival in 1982 where people wore large smiling masks made of papier mâché to celebrate Bacolod’s charter day. On the other hand, in line with its socially committed stance, BAA (as did Pamilya Pintura before it) contributed artworks in the form of murals and effigies for mass actions. Despite its members’ varied styles and techniques, the BAA is associated with the Social Realists aggressively pursuing their practice across the Philippines. Eventually, many of BAA’s members went on to have successful individual careers. Those remaining active in this circle of artists presently gravitate around Orange Gallery, an artist-run space spearheaded by Charlie Co.

In 1990, under the leadership of Norberto Roldan, the BAA led the first Visayas Islands Visual Arts Exhibition and Conference (VIVA ExCon), sponsored by the Cultural Center of the Philippines. This exhibit-conference biennale was envisioned not only to “showcase contemporary works of visual arts from the different islands but also to promote visual art forms reflective of the islands’ cultural influences, historical traditions and current social situations aside from encouraging innovative, experimental or collaborative works among Visayan visual artists” (VIVA Excon Folio 1990, quoted in Locsin-Nava, n.d.).Held in Mambucal Resort, Murcia, on 22-28 Feb 1990, VIVA ExCon I attracted many artists and cultural workers from outside the Visayas region—notably, Bobi Valenzuela, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Pablo Baens Santos, and Roy Veneracion—as well as Baguio-based artists BenCab, Santiago Bose, and Roberto Villanueva.

VIVA ExCon II, held in Bacolod on 13-15 Mar 1992, was participated in by 92 artists, including several from Japan, which promoted further cultural exchanges here and abroad. In 1994, VIVA ExCon IV was sponsored for the first time by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Since then, the biennale has been managed by various Visayas-based artist organizations. The 13th VIVA ExCon was held on 13-16 Nov 2012, with founding BAA members Dennis Ascalon and Charlie Co in the working committee. The subsequent biennale was held in Dumaguete under the leadership of Antonio Alunan Wenceslao and project-managed by the artists’ organization PUSOD, with the succeeding installment planned for VIVA ExCon’s homecoming in Bacolod in 2014. BAA itself is now registered under the Securities and Exchange Commission as Black Artists in Asia Association Inc. Written by Sofia G. Guillermo

BLANCO, JOSE (Jose Villones Blanco) aka Pitok Bunggan was a painter. He was born in Angono, Rizal on 19 Mar 1932. He died in the same town on 14 Aug 2008. He was the son of Ismael Blanco, a fisher, and Manuela Villones, a store owner. His mother’s uncle, Pedro Piñon, was a religious artist of the late 19th century. His wife Loreto “Loring” Blanco and his seven children, Glenn, Noel, Michael, Joy, Jan, Gay, and Peter Paul, are also painters. He obtained his fine arts degree from the University of Santo Tomas in 1953. Upon graduation, he worked as art director in an advertising company. In 1971, he resigned and devoted his full time to painting.

Blanco painted for some time under the influence of Carlos V. Francisco aka Botong, but he always resisted being absorbed by the strong personality of his mentor. He sought his own style, at first with difficulty, then with increasing confidence until he came into his own. The Philippine genre style of painting, or what the art critic Alice Guillermo termed as “folk realism,” became his forte. He painted murals of genres, using vibrant earthly colors in depicting Philippine folk life, revealing his intimate familiarity with it. While he had had subjects ranging from the Tagalog pastoral scenes to memorializing and documenting Philippine folk traditions, he is best known for his large-scale works of folk genre in the rural Angono setting by the Laguna Lake. One of his most notable works was the Angono Town Fiesta, a 2.43 x 4.57 m mural that brings together a large number of Angono folk, each of them in an individual portrait, celebrating the fluvial procession of San Clemente in November. Another mural, Burning of Angono, 1990, depicts somber and dark themes said to be reminiscent of his World War II experiences. His work attracted the attention of Imelda Marcos, who commissioned a series of murals on Pres Ferdinand Marcos’s war exploits.

In 1971, he held his first one-person show at the Manila Hilton Art Center. He commemorated this event with the painting Tulungan (Cooperation), which shows his family moving house over Laguna Lake on a raft steered by townspeople to the other shore. His first commissioned murals were Three Regions for Santa Clara Plywood and Bayanihan (Cooperation) for Unilab. In 1996, two of his major paintings about the Virgin Mary of Antipolo were hung at the Basilica of the Immaculate Concepcion in Washington, DC, as part of the commemoration of the 101st Philippine Independence. As a family, Pitok and his children held an exhibit at the National Museum in 1978. They also had an exhibit in Xiamen, China, 1986, and on Fifth Ave in New York, 1999. His works, along with the works of his family, are exhibited in the Blanco Family Museum along Ibañez St in Angono, Rizal. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Ma. Giesil Carina Merin

BOHOL SCHOOL OF PAINTING A center of artistic activity in the 19th century, Bohol island is known for its icons, executed in a vigorous style and flamboyant coloring. Although many other artistic hubs flourished during the time, such as Lucban (now in Quezon Province) and San Vicente, Ilocos Sur, only the pieces of Bohol have survived. The isolation of the island saved it from the encroachment of the chromolithograph during the American colonial period, as well as spared the churches and old houses in the towns from heavy damage during World War II. Artistic activity in Bohol persisted until just before the war.

The earliest painters of Bohol seem to have been Chinese artisans who migrated to the remote provinces like Bohol due to the periodic expulsions, bans, and campaigns of persecution against them. This theory is supported by the prevalence of expressive elements identifiable as Chinese-inspired in many of the early Bohol paintings. The paintings did not originate from just one master. Moreover, the extant pieces, mainly dated to the 19th century, were undertaken under the initiative of the Recollect Fathers and not by the Jesuits, who were expelled from the country in 1768.

One of the earliest pieces from Bohol has been called the Kuan-Yin Nuestra Señora del Rosario, apparently inspired by the image of Kuan-Yin, the Chinese goddess of mercy. It must have been made ca 1825, based on the condition of the pigments as compared with those of later dated pieces. The painter of the Kuan-Yin apparently influenced the next active painter, one of whose works is the set of Stations of the Cross, which features one unit with the year 1830. The influence is evident in the way the eyes of the personages are depicted.

Only one name is known of the Bohol painters, Liberato Gachalian, who signed the set of the Passion of Christ originally in the parish church of Dawis, Bohol. His inscription states that he was commissioned in 1854 by Fr Antonio Obeda to execute the paintings. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

BORLONGAN, ELMER (Elmer Misa Borlongan) is a painter. He was born in Manila on 7 Jan 1967. The son of Pascual Borlongan and Dolores Misa, he married fellow artist Plet Bolipata. Borlongan had his first formal lessons from his father, and then under Fernando Sena at the Children’s Museum and Library. Later, Borlongan became apprentice to his teacher in workshops in Montalban and Antipolo. It was during this time that the young art student became exposed to the grassroots. He also went on painting trips with the Kabataang Tondo Art Group founded by Sena. He studied with Sena until 1983, after which he took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines in 1987. The turning point in his practice came in his sophomore year when he was chosen as delegate to Malaysia in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) art exhibit and workshop with the theme “People of the ASEAN.” When he returned to the Philippines, the young artist sought to return to his indigenous roots, and stayed in Banaue for a short while. After the 1987 Mendiola massacre, Borlongan joined ABAY, a visual arts organization with a sociopolitical thrust. He became active doing murals, illustrations, comics, and posters for cause-oriented groups. Later, Borlongan co-founded the Salingpusa group, going back to painting.

Borlongan describes his style as figurative expressionism, dominated by human figures with distorted and often surreal shapes and hues. In particular, the subject of the “bald man” is an iconic image in Borlongan’s body of work and allows the exploration of sociopolitical issues in urban life. In 2002, he and his wife moved to Zambales where they built their studios. Borlongan began painting rural scenes with vivid colors, featuring genre scenes from a fishing community. He also worked for the defunct Manila Chronicle, illustrating fables in the lifestyle section using charcoal drawings.

He was an artist in residence in ARCUS Ibaraki, Japan, in 1996. Borlongan has been exhibiting widely since the late 1990s with shows in Tokyo, New York, Sydney, Singapore, Irvine, Brisbane, Honolulu, and Kuala Lumpur, among others. His works are in the collection of the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum and the Singapore Art Museum.

Borlongan has won several prizes in various national competitions, including the Metrobank Foundation painting contest: second prize, Rehimen (Regime), 1988; and second prize, Tampuhan (Lover’s Quarrel), 1992. He received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 1994. In 2004, he received the Award for Continuing Excellence and Service from the Metrobank Foundation. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rina Corpuz and Cecilia S. De La Paz

BOSE, SANTIAGO (Santiago Pavila Bose) aka Santi Bose was a painter. He was born in Baguio City on 25 Jul 1949. He died on 3 Dec 2002. He was the son of Mariano Bose and Lourdes Pavila. He took up architecture at Mapua Institute of Technology, 1965-67, and finished fine arts at the University of the Philippines in 1972. While in college, he received several awards in photography, editorial design, and advertising. In recognition of his long interest in indigenous art making, he was awarded a grant by the Linang Project of the Council of Living Traditions in 1980.

Bose was a founding member and served as the chairperson of the Baguio Arts Guild in 1992 and 2001. He was a tireless experimenter in the use of different media including performance art. He pioneered in the use of indigenous materials. None of his paintings are in the academic oil-on-canvas. He has used, among others, old doors, bamboo nose flutes, driftwood, estampita (small holy pictures), paper bills, empty bottles, even carpets in collage. Sometimes he invents his own medium, such as the one in Drown My Soul in the Chico Dam, which incorporates volcanic ash baked in a kiln for a hard sculptural effect. He has used Philippine precolonial symbols, such as the Manunggul jar and the bulol (sculpture of rice harvest gods), at times ironically juxtaposed with Western symbols. He also did a series on migrant Filipinos for a show in the United States, 1989. Drawn to the nativist millennarian groups of Mount Banahaw, Bose did the installation Pasyon at Rebolusyon (Passion and Revolution), 1983, with a striking use of indigenous and organic materials. Dried branches massed together to form an improvised altar-like structure (Bernardo Carpio’s mystic altar) above which, forming a colorful retablo (sculpted altar), are three vertical banners painted with native religious imagery common to the site, while a native saint brandishing a bolo rides forth to the revolution.

In 1994, Bose was a visiting research fellow at the Southern Cross University, Lismore, Australia. In 1998, his works were included in the Alab ng Puso centennial exhibition of Philippine art at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. In 2000, he was a visiting artist in residence at the Pacific Bridge Gallery in Oakland, California. He was awarded the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for sculpture by the city of Manila in 2001. In 2003, Babilonia 1808, the international contemporary art program of the Babilonia Wilner Foundation in Berkeley, California, presented Bose’s works in Power and Poetics: Remembering Santiago Bose (1949-2002). In 2004, a retrospective at the Cultural Center of the Philippines titled In Memory of a Talisman: An Exhibition of Works of Santiago Bose was held. In the same year, his book Espiritu Santi: The Strange Life and Even Stranger Legacy of Santiago Bose was published. He was also awarded the Gawad CCP para sa Sining (visual arts) in 2004. In 2010, another retrospective of the artist titled Remix, Santiago Bose was held at the Yuchengo Museum. In Mar 2011, his book titled Baguio Graffiti-Gatos Callejeros (Baguio Graffiti-Stray Cats), 2006, was launched by Instituto Cervantes in Manila. In 2012, the Vargas Museum, commemorated his 10th death anniversary with an exhibition Can’t Go Home Again: Santiago Bose in the Family Collection. This consisted of the artist’s work and documentation from the collection of the Bose family.

Bose exhibited internationally in seminal events such as the Havana Biennial, 1989; the First Asia-Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art at the Queensland Art Gallery, Brisbane, Australia, 1993; Memories of Overdevelopment, University of California Irvine, 1996; and At Home and Abroad: 20 Contemporary Filipino Artists at the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco, 2000.

He received a certificate of merit in the on-the-spot painting contest of the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1971. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1976. He was given the grand prize for print by the Art Association of the Philippines in 1981, and was a finalist in the 1982 Mobil Art Awards. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez
