BUENAVENTURA, TEODORO (Teodoro Pascual Buenaventura) was a painter. He was born in Paombong, Bulacan on 1 Apr 1863. He died in 5 Feb 1950. Fatherless at 14, Buenaventura went to Manila to look for work. The mother of his employer, Ramon Salas, saw a copy of a historical painting that he made and was very impressed. She sent him to the Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado de Manila. He eventually became one of the founding teachers of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts, where he taught from 1909 to 1935.

Buenaventura is one of the early masters of classical realism in the Philippines. In 1895, he entered three oils—Despues del Baño (After the Bath), Cabeza del Estudio (Head Study), and Estudio de Natural (Study From Life)—at the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition). One of the three works obtained a bronze medal. In 1899, he opened a portrait shop in San Jose, Trozo. In many issues of Chizpazos in Jul 1908, his Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, located at No. 35, San Jose, Trozo, was advertised. In 1908, his Ya Vienen (They Are Here) won one of the silver medals at the art exhibition sponsored by the Asociacion Internacional de Artistas.

The bulk of Buenaventura’s major works were destroyed during World War II. Most of those preserved are small landscapes and genre pieces that prove his consummate skills as a realist in the old school. His most popular works today are the pair of portraits at the Central Bank of the Philippines—namely, Portrait of Rufino Valencia and Portrait of Ramona Valencia, the latter mistakenly identified as the artist’s mother in Kayamanan (Treasure). Both show the artist’s uncanny skill for strongly modeled forms and a sensitive eye for vital features that identify his sitters. Buenaventura is especially remembered as an art teacher admired by his students—among them, Serafin Serna, Tomas Bernardo, and Mauro Malang Santos. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

BUNAG-GATBONTON, ESPERANZA (Esperanza Alpa Bunag-Gatbonton) is an essayist and art historian. She was born in Manila on 29 Sep 1938. Her parents are Nicolas Bunag and Luisa Alpa. She is married to essayist-fictionist Juan T. Gatbonton. From elementary to college, she studied journalism at St. Theresa’s College in Manila. She got a master’s degree in English literature from Ateneo de Manila University and a doctor’s degree in Philippine studies from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 2014. Bunag-Gatbonton taught at UP Manila and the University of Santo Tomas. She served as consultant to the Intramuros Administration in 1979-82, and as heritage sites director for the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). She was member of the governing board of the Southeast Asian Ministry of Education Project in Archaeology and the Fine Arts in 1986-89.

Bunag-Gatbonton’s published works include A Heritage of Saints: Colonial Santos in the Philippines, 1979; Intramuros: A Historical Guide, 1980; Philippine Religious Carvings in Ivory, 1983; Intramuros of Memory, 1983, co-written with Jaime Laya and Nick Joaquin; Bastion de San Diego, 1984; Ang Kiu Kok: The Artist and His Works, 1991, co-written with Juan Gatbonton; and Vigan Album: Memories and Images of a Town, 2002. She wrote the introduction to Philippine Religious Imagery in Ivory, 1982, and Venerated Virgins of Intramuros, 1982, and did the pictorial research and captions for Aba Ginoong Maria: The Virgin Mary in Philippine Art, 1990. She also served as editor for the following: Faces from Maitum: The Archaeological Excavation of Ayub Cave, 1996, by Eusebio Z. Dizon and Rey A. Santiago; The Philippines after the Revolution: 1898-1945, 2000; and Shell Ornamentation of La Purísima Concepción Parish Church, Guiuan, Eastern Samar, 2003, with Angel Bautista.

She received certificates of appreciation from the National Museum in 1978 and 1992, and from the Intramuros Administration in 1985. In 2005, the NCCA honored her with the Pama-as Gintong Bai award for her dedication to the preservation and conservation of Philippine cultural heritage. Written by E. R. Galang, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro and Cecilia S. De La Paz

BUNOAN, RINGO (Maria Angelica Santos Bunoan) is a visual artist, curator, writer, and researcher. She was born in Mandaluyong City on 3 Aug 1974. She is the daughter of Santiago Bunoan and Lourdes Amor Santos. She graduated with a bachelor of fine arts, major in art history, from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (UP CFA) in 1997. She taught art history at the UP CFA from 1997 to 1998 and has written articles for various publications over the years.

Bunoan produces installations that explore the affective and conceptual possibilities of materials such as found and ephemeral objects, photography, and sound recording. Her works have addressed connections between themes such as memory and transience, presence and absence, demise and loss.

Early on, Bunoan utilized photography as a main element of her installation work. One of her earliest works, White Noise, 1997, positioned a photograph of a bed and two pillows in front of a CD player with looped recordings of ambient, everyday sounds. This vein of work employing notions of time and place extends up to the present with Untitled [Price List], 2008, where she arranges images of price lists of exhibitions done over past years in various galleries. The photos are placed on tables, displaying them as both archival elements and art objects. In 1999, she started collaborating with Poklong Anading on video-based installations, producing works such as SOS, 2003, featuring two TV monitors projecting an image of either artist sending flashlight signals to the other. Returning to the Philippines in 2007 after three years in Nepal, Bunoan produced a series of installations utilizing pillows as memorials of the corporeal. In the Same Breath, 2003, is a radial installation that incorporates pillows and photos of tombstones in tribute to her late mother who similarly passed away on the indicated date on the pictured graves. The Wall, 2008, uses hundreds of found pillows, stacked on top of each other to form a structural barrier embodying human presences that ultimately fall, given their own precarious positionality.

As a curator, Bunoan has contributed to the flourishing of alternative art spaces in the Philippines in the 1990s to the 2000s. In 1999, Bunoan and artist Katya Guerrero co-founded Big Sky Mind, a gallery-café that evolved into an independent artist-run space from 2001 to 2004.

Bunoan has also worked in close collaboration with Roberto Chabet, eventually creating an archive of materials on his artistic and curatorial work while working as a researcher for Philippine contemporary art at the Asia Art Archive in Hong Kong from 2007 to 2013. Her third solo exhibition Archiving Roberto Chabet, 2009, translated this period of archival research into material work by salvaging his undocumented pieces and physically producing otherwise unrealized concepts. In 2010, she co-founded King Kong Art Projects Unlimited, which organized the exhibition series Chabet: 50 Years, 2011-12, in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Manila.

Her work has been featured in exhibitions in the Asia-Pacific region and in the United States, including USEBy: Asia Pacific Artist Initiative Project, 2000, Center for Contemporary Photography, Australia; PAUSE: The 4th Gwangju Biennale, 2002, South Korea; Episode: Asia Art Now, 2004, Cheong-ju Center Gallery, Seoul, Korea; the Singapore Art Museum, 2004 and 2009; Phantoms of Asia: Contemporary Art Awakens the Past, 2012, Asian Art Museum, San Francisco, California; Move On Asia: Video Art in Asia 2002-2012, 2013, ZKM Media Museum, Germany; and Erasure: From Conceptualism to Abstraction, 2013, Osage Gallery and City University, Hong Kong.

Bunoan received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 2003. She was awarded a Silverlens Foundation grant in 2007. She has juried for the Ateneo Art Awards and the CCP Thirteen Artists Award. Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

CAANCAN, JOSE (Jose Dalhag Caancan) was a sculptor. He was born in Paete, Laguna on 20 May 1877. He died in 8 May 1965. He was the youngest of 10 children born to Valeriano Caancan and Ines Dalhag. Caancan’s father was a furniture carver by occupation, and musician by avocation. His mother was a dressmaker who also did intricate embroidery work for draperies or religious statues. Orphaned at age four, he stopped schooling as he had to make a living for himself, first as lathe operator in a furniture shop and then as wood-carver. He married twice but sired no children. His adopted son Gregorio Caancan continued Jose’s tradition of wood carving.

In 1894, Caancan was one of the ambitious young men who responded to Jose Rizal’s search for working scholars to support during the latter’s exile in Dapitan. Caancan was also known to be Rizal’s barber. Mutual influences in the sculpture of Rizal and Caancan constitute a promising case study. After a year of stay in Dapitan, Caancan returned to Paete to work on wood carving all his life. Although he was accustomed to doing religious statuary, he decided to concentrate on doing genre themes, such as Boy on a Carabao in three dimensions, Couple Pounding Rice in bas relief, and Boy Fetching Water, which became very marketable during the early 1900s. His workshop was virtually a school as he trained young boys on the rigors of sculptural anatomy. Among his pupils were Mariano Edjawan, Jess Limlengco, Luis Obial, and Isaac Cagandahan.

Caancan was known to have won awards for religious statues he exhibited at the Golden Gate Exposition and an exposition in Paris. In the 1924 Philippine Exposition, he won first prize for his portrait of Leonard Wood. A relief carving on a Dapitan scene by Caancan is kept in Jose Rizal’s house in Calamba. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya

CABANGIS, BENJIE (Benjamin Isla Cabangis) was a painter. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 22 Feb 1957. He is the son of Arturo Cabangis and Purita Isla. He is married to Flora Bajar and they have four children: Zean is a painter, Aaron is a filmmaker, Neen is a graphic artist, and Li is an industrial designer. Cabangis obtained his fine arts degree, major in painting, from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1978 and took up his graduate degree in fine arts in the same school. He was visual arts instructor at the Philippine High School for the Arts at the National Arts Center in Mount Makiling, Laguna, 1978-80, and served as resource person and lecturer for the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Artists’ Workshop, 1983-85, and the Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization Project for archaeology and fine arts, 1985. He was a member of the Technical Committee for Fine Arts and Interior Design for the Commission on Higher Education from 2010 to 2013. He was chairperson of the Department of Studio Arts from 1978 to 1998 at the UP College of Fine Arts (CFA) where he is a full professor of painting and curator of the Corredor Gallery.

Cabangis had his first one-man show in 1976, two years before he obtained his bachelor of fine arts from the UP CFA. Following this are 25 other solo exhibitions through 2014 at the CCP, the Philippine Center New York, Art Informal Gallery, West Gallery, and Corredor Gallery. He has participated in numerous group exhibitions at the CCP Bulwagang Juan Luna (also known as Main Gallery) and CCP Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo (also known as Small Gallery), Museum of Philippine Art, Metropolitan Museum, Manila Contemporary, among other exhibition venues.

He was among the Philippine representatives to Young Art in Asia Now, Hong Kong Arts Centre, 1980; ASEAN Painting and Photography Exhibition, Indonesia, 1980; Philippine Abstract Art, Alffield Gallery, Hong Kong, 1985; the ASEAN Travelling Exhibit of Paintings in ASEAN countries, 1988-89; Cornerstones: Southeast Asian Contemporary Art, Philippine Star Building; the 17th Asian International Art Exhibition, Daejeon, Korea, 2002; and the Asean-Japan Fine Arts Colleges Network 2015, Yogyakarta, Indonesia. His works can be found in public, private, and corporate collections here and abroad. Endangered Icons I and II, his diptych painting, represents the Philippines in the International Finance Corporation of the World Bank art collection, Washington, DC.

Cabangis was among the Thirteen Artists awardees of the CCP in 1978. He received the Gawad Chanselor as UP’s Outstanding Visual Artist in 1999, the Fernando Amorsolo Professorial Chair in painting in 1992, 1996, 2002, and 2004, and the UP Arts Productivity Award in 2014. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

 

Source

 

Cabangis, Benjie. n.d. Pers. comm.

CABIGTING, ANNIE RACHEL aka Princess Cabigting is a painter. She was born in Makati City on 14 Aug 1971. Her sister Reina Cabigting aka Moppet was a University of the Philippines (UP) Filipiniana Dance Troupe member. Her daughter is Una C. Ilarde. Cabigting received a bachelor of fine arts in painting from UP Diliman in 1994.

Cabigting explores the potential of figurative painting to reference itself. She is recognized for depicting viewers in the act of viewing a painting, or capturing a painting within a painting. Viewers are prompted to critically reflect on their looking practices through her emphasis on the process of representation and impersonal response, the latter being suggested by backs turned against the actual viewers of the work. Such is exemplified in the suite of paintings she did for the exhibition Under the Influence of Paintings, 2012, Art Stage, Singapore.

The artist’s invoking of techniques of appropriation allows her to reconstruct minor histories of destruction and accounts of art heists, which often go untold in relation to the historicizing of the works of modern artists and masters from the Western world. In the exhibition Pictures of Pictures, 2009, and specifically in a painting she titled Splitting 32, Cabigting reinterprets a house dismembered by the architect-artist Gordon Matta-Clark. She also imagines the condition of rejected artworks in Destroyed Painting: After Francis Bacon and Barnett Newman and an Unidentified Woman Who’s Afraid of Yellow, Red, and Blue.

Cabigting’s painting and intermedia approaches draw attention to the dynamism of the art world she inhabits. Counting on conceptualism’s tendency to harness ideas and to focus on research-based practices, she exposes the presence of in-between states in artistic processes. In the exhibition Title Withheld: Three Paintings, 2010, Cabigting drew attention to a note or a file folder; or a scene in class in which students learned about Josef Albers’s square motif. In Dietro Mona Lisa, 2007, Cabigting reconstructed the verso of Leonardo da Vinci’s much celebrated portrait, Mona Lisa. Based on conservation documents, she featured both images replete with minute details. Here, the aura of mystique did not originate from the frontal figure but rather from its obverse. The theme of reversal was also gleaned in Cabigting’s exhibition Under Wraps, 2012, where she concealed her canvases behind white cloth in order to emphasize often disregarded aspects of painting.

Cabigting has held many solo exhibitions in the Philippines—primarily in Finale Art File, Silverlens, and West Gallery—and abroad in Richard Koh Fine Art, Malaysia, and Artesan Gallery, Singapore. Among her group exhibitions are those at the Cultural Center of the Philippines; Primo Marella Gallery, Italy, 2009; Prague Biennale, Czech Republic, 2009; and Art Beirut, Lebanon, 2013. She received the Ateneo Art Award in 2005. Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

CACNIO, ANGEL (Angel Cruz Cacnio) is a painter. He was born in Malabon on 31 May 1931. He is the son of Flaviano Cacnio and Telesfora Cruz. He married Amelia Reyes with whom he has four children, two of whom are sculptors, Michael and Ferdinand. As a young boy in Malabon, Cacnio was fascinated by folk designs such as those of caretela or horse-drawn rigs. In high school, he would be late for classes because he would spend a lot of time copying his favorite comics, such as Hagibis by his favorite artist Francisco Coching, or works by Carlos V. Francisco aka Botong Francisco. A consistent college scholar at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (UP CFA), his classmates and friends Salvador Cabrera and Federico Aguilar Alcuaz, as well as his professor Toribio Herrera, encouraged him to persevere in art. In 1957, Cacnio joined the staff of the Ramon Roces Publications where he had as colleagues Cesar Legaspi, Vicente Manansala, and Ang Kiukok. During this period, Cacnio did illustrations for the Liwayway magazine. He stayed in this job for more than 20 years.

In 1971, he was commissioned to do paintings of cockfights by aficionados of the sport. From then on, he developed his own style and experimented in employing variable textures. In his genre work, he has always been concerned with rendering individual portraits of people in dynamic relationships. In 1977, with the success of his first oil paintings, Cacnio decided to be a full-time painter. His first real break came in 1977 when he participated in the Seven by Seven show at the Silangan Gallery, featuring the works of seven professors of the UP CFA with seven of their former students. It was in 1985 that Cacnio was able to gather enough paintings for a one-person show at Gallery Genesis. This was followed by shows at the Ayala Museum in 1989, and at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990. In 1991, he was also sponsored by Alegria Work and Art.

Cacnio won twice in the Shell National Students Art Competition. He received third prize for Gathering Shells, 1951, and first prize for Tatlong Sabungero (Three Cockfighters), 1953. He also won first place for his entry in the Apolinario Mabini Centennial Art Competition. In 1967, he won various prizes at the Central Bank of the Philippines coin design contest. His winning designs were Lapulapu, for the one-centavo coin; Marcelo H. del Pilar, for the 50-centavo coin; and Tandang Sora for the five-centavo coin. In 1981, he was recognized by his hometown in the Gintong Parangal ng Malabon for Art. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

CAEDO, ANASTACIO (Anastacio Tanchangco Caedo) was a sculptor. He was born in Batangas, Batangas on 14 Aug 1907. He died in 12 May 1990. He was the son of Arsenio Caedo and Genoveva Tanchangco. Caedo entered primary school at Batangas Elementary School at age 11 and completed his elementary education at Calaca Elementary School, Batangas. Dr Juan Tanchangco, an uncle, then a student at the University of the Philippines (UP), persuaded Anastacio’s father to send his son to the UP School of Fine Arts, which the former had entered in 1925. It was a practice in those days at the School of Fine Arts to admit students even if they had not graduated from high school. Nevertheless, Anastacio studied high school at the Manila University while taking up fine arts at UP. Caedo managed to win all the major awards in the yearly school competition. Guillermo E.Tolentino, fresh from studies in Italy at that time and recruited to the UP faculty, saw Caedo’s potential.

From 1925 onward, Tolentino and Caedo worked as a team. Caedo assisted Tolentino in most of Tolentino’s landmark commissions like the UP Oblation; the Bonifacio Monument, Caloocan City; the life-size figure of Pres Ramon Magsaysay at the Government Service Insurance System lobby, Arroceros, Manila; the Rizal Monument in front of the Rizal Provincial Capitol; the Shaw Monument at Shaw Boulevard, Mandaluyong; and all the dancing figures at the Malacañan Palace Reception Hall and Music Hall.

After World War II, Caedo established himself as a major sculptor doing commissions for the Jesuits, starting with a 14-foot statue of Saint Thomas More, which adorned the Ateneo College of Law on Padre Faura St. Caedo executed at least eight major works for the Jesuits. In 1951, he became a faculty member of the UP School of Fine Arts, serving the school for 20 years.

A product of the classical school that prevailed at UP until the mid-1960s, Caedo produced commissioned representational sculptures, mainly monuments of national heroes and successful Filipino politicians, businessmen, and educators. Ranging from full figures to busts, these statues featured the actual but idealized appearance of their subjects. Caedo knew how to inject vitality or movement into his works, primarily through the subtle grouping of masses in a figure for the said purpose.

Among Caedo’s most popular works are the seven larger-than-life figures of Gen Douglas MacArthur and company at the Polo Red Beach, Leyte; the Benigno Aquino monument at the corner of Ayala Ave and Paseo de Roxas, 1986; and the yearly trophies of the Film Academy of the Philippines.

From 1925 to 1929, he accumulated eight certificates of recognition and six medals. His Dying Soldier won the gold medal at the Philippine National Heroes Day Competition on 30 Nov 1920. His Trece Martires de Cavite (Thirteen Martyrs of Cavite) and Padre Jose Burgos (Fr Jose Burgos) won top awards from 1931 to 1932. He also won second prize in the sculpture competition of the Art Association of the Philippines in 1952. In 1961, while his bust of Jose Rizal only won third prize in the competition sponsored by the Jose Rizal National Centennial Commission, the copies of this artwork became the official token given to diplomats. His sculptures of Rizal may also be found in Germany and the USA. Written by Eric Catipon, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

 

Source

 

Philstar.com. 2008. “NHI honors Batangueño artist Anastacio Caedo.” Philstar.com, 16 Nov. Accessed 12 May 2016. www.philstar.com/sunday-life/415432/nhi-honors-batangueno-artistanastacio-caedo.

CAJIPE-ENDAYA, IMELDA (Imelda Baisas Cajipe-Endaya) is a printmaker and painter. She was born in Manila on 16 Sep 1949. She is the daughter of Pedro Cajipe and Felipa Baisas. She is married to Simplicio Endaya, with whom she has three children. She finished her fine arts degree at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1970.

As a printmaker, Cajipe-Endaya won recognition for her experimentation with technique and her exploration of Filipino visual imagery initially in printmaking, painting, and assemblage, and eventually in her installations. From 1976 to 1979, she produced a series of prints collectively titled Mga Ninuno (Ancestors), which brought together images from 19th-century engravings and novenas, the Boxer Codex, and Damian Domingo’s albums. Done in etching, collagraphy, and serigraphy, these were interplayed in an abstract order, in reference to the complex issue of national identity. In her 1981 individual show at the City Gallery, she used female figures and windows as motifs for social issues such as labor export and Third World cultural domination. In 1982, she began to take a feminist direction, focusing on the plight of the Filipina in her various contemporary roles. Cajipe-Endaya’s works, which often allude to events and conditions like militarization, struggle for land, and colonial mentality, convey the turmoil and passion accompanying social change. She uses various materials and symbolic elements, indigenous and folk, to convey the textures and colors of Philippine culture as well as rich social and historical connotations. She has added sawali (plaited and woven bamboo) panels to collaged crocheted lace, denims, and various objects to endow them with a familiar immediacy. Some examples are May Bukas Pa, Inay (Mother, There Is Tomorrow), 1982, and Sa Lupang Golgota (In the Land of Golgota), 1984. She continues to experiment with mediums and materials, incorporating aspects of sculpture and painting in more recent installations. Some of her major works are in the following collections: Bintana ni Momoy (Momoy’s Window), 1983, Ateneo University Art Gallery; Pasyong Bayan (A Nation’s Passion), 1983, Metropolitan Museum of Manila; Sa Lupang Golgota, 1984, Fukuoka Asian Art Museum, Fukuoka, Japan; Mansanas sa Almusal (Apple for Breakfast), 1988, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); and Solidarity Sisters, 1999, Central Bank of the Philippines.

She has held solo exhibitions in the Philippine Center New York, Walsh Gallery, Seton Hall University, New Jersey, United Nations Headquarters in New York, all in 2006; Executive Gallery, Goshen, New York, 2007; UP Vargas Museum, UP Diliman, Quezon City, 2010; Museo ng Katipunan, San Juan City, 2011; and Liongoren Gallery, Quezon City, 2011. Her major installations in international exhibitions and biennales of contemporary art include FDH: Foreign Domestic Helper, 1993, Cheju Pre-Biennale, Korea; Memories of Overdevelopment, University of California–Irvine Fine Arts Gallery and Plug-In Gallery, Winnipeg, Canada; Filipina: DH in Traditions/Tensions, 1996-97, Asia Society and the Queens Museum in New York, Vancouver Art Gallery, Art Gallery of Western Australia in Perth, and Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts; and Our Terms, Sangandaan Arts and Media Festival, CCP, 2003.

She was also involved in art-related activities. She is one of the founding members and president of a collective of women visual artists, Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan or Kasibulan, 1988-93. She was researcher-writer for art and culture publication projects of the National Library, 1976-86. She established Pananaw: Philippine Journal of Visual Arts and was Pananaw’s first editor in chief as part of her involvement with the Committee on Visual Arts of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) from 1997 to 2002. Her essays were published in Zone-D, Archipelago, Filipinas Journal, Katipunan, and Kultura magazines. She coauthored Filipino Engraving, 1980, which was given the Gintong Aklat award for nonfiction book. She edited and designed the books Manuel Rodriguez Sr: Into the Threshold, 2010, and Art at the Philippine Center New York, 2010. In 2013, she was contributing writer and book designer of Fe B. Mangahas’s Kasaysayan ng Ating Bayan / Ang Pilipinas Noon at Ngayon (History of Our Nation / Philippines Then and Now).

Endaya was given a certificate of merit in the on-the-spot painting contest in the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1969. She was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1990. In 1998, she received the city of Manila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan for painting. In 1999, she received the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts. In 2008, she received the Ateneo de Manila ALIWW Honors for Women in the Arts and the Irwin and Florence Zlowe Memorial Art Award from the American Society of Contemporary Artists, New York. In 2009, the NCCA awarded her its Ani ng Dangal. In 2013, her alma mater honored her with its College of the Holy Spirit Centennial Award. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

 

 

Source

 

Cajipe-Endaya, Imelda. 2013. Curriculum vitae.

CALUBAYAN, BUEN (Buen Franklin Anthony Capulong Calubayan) is a visual artist. He was born in Lucena City, Quezon Province on 29 Oct 1980. He is the son of Leonito Calubayan and Francisca Capulong. He is married to the curator and writer Jocelyn Tullao. Calubayan has a degree in advertising from the University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Architecture, where he taught and took graduate studies until 2007. He has also given lectures to art students at Kalayaan College, Marikina.

The foreign and its juxtaposition to that which is not, called by various names—the local, the native, the home-grown—is a central impetus in Calubayan’s art. It becomes a lens through which he examines the contradictions and disparities of his artistic milieu. For a 2011 artist residency in Japan, he volunteered as an assistant to a fellow resident, gathered dust on adhesive tape from his apartment, and cooked adobo, a world-famous local dish that he then served to fellow artists. Amidst these seemingly mundane activities, Calubayan recorded the experience of being elsewhere, placed within a context wherein local identities were scrutinized, and to a certain degree defined and assessed.

Calubayan’s 2014 project Idiot Knows No Country is a pun on the toast made by national hero Jose Rizal to fellow Filipinos Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, who were honored for their victories at the Madrid Exposition of 1884. Calubayan’s project explores the many facets of identity and its complex constructions. The artist combines processes that carry the semblance of rituals through everyday practices and whose documentations are conjured as process-based or object-oriented outcomes. All these amount to a scrutiny of his identity as a Filipino artist circumnavigating the routes of the contemporary art world, at home and elsewhere. In these endeavors, Calubayan courageously tests the limits of art making and places his art practice under duress. By doing so, he reveals the inner workings of the world wherein his art thrives and his identity simultaneously fractures and flourishes.

He continues the project by juxtaposing his ritualistic visits to Mount Banahaw to exhibition visits in Australia where he completed another residency. Guided by Reynaldo Ileto’s landmark work Pasyon and Revolution, 1979, Calubayan embarks on his own search for liwanag or light, like the 19th-century revolutionaries who trekked Mount Banahaw. Parallel to this, the artist journeys across continents and seeks the light to bridge artistic expressions. In the process, he likewise encounters centuries-old gaps that indeed cannot be in any way bridged but can only be revealed and scrutinized. Idiot Knows No Country culminates in an exhibition for which Calubayan constructs a hammock from the pages of Ileto’s book, an object that contains light limned from a revolutionary project and a concurrent attempt to redefine it.

Among Calubayan’s exhibitions since 2007 are Idiot Knows No Country, 2014, in Bendigo, Australia; Biography, 2013, Blanc Gallery; and Spoliarium, 2013, Now Gallery. His works have been included in several group exhibitions including the survey exhibition The Philippine Contemporary, 2013, at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila; Kulo (Boil), 2011, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); and Extensions at the Lopez Museum where Calubayan affiliated with an independent collective called Plataporma. Calubayan received the Ateneo Art Award in 2013 for which he completed a residency at La Trobe University’s Visual Art Center in Australia. He was awarded the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2009. Written by Tessa Maria T. Guazon

CAPILI, ARSENIO was a painter. He was born on 28 Oct 1914. He died ca 1945. Capili entered the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1930, studying there until 1935. His earliest works were in the traditional representational manner as taught by the academically trained instructors of UP. However, because of the influence of Carlos V. Francisco and Galo B.Ocampo, he began emboldening his lines, simplifying his figures as he used a palette knife to emphasize tonal contrast, which pleased Victorio Edades. The latter thus named him as one of the Thirteen Moderns.

Capili’s Bagobo Chieftain, 1936, at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Art Gallery is also inscribed as “Davao,” confirming the artist’s presence in and affinity for the place. This work demonstrates his penchant for bright colors, which helped project the rugged way of life of his sitter while at the same time highlighting his guileless nature. Capili’s Impasto, on the other hand, captured the rich texture of the chieftain’s dress and the ruggedness of his surroundings. Tinguian Woman, 1941, shows Capili capitalizing on the bold and rugged patterns of the woman’s dress. It was also through this work that he demonstrated the formal expressiveness of modernism as then understood by Edades’s group.

In 1941, Capili obtained third honorable mention for Lux Mundi (Light of the World) in the Religious Category at the National Art Competition sponsored by UST. His Bagobo Chieftain was described in the show Modang Modern (Modern Fad), 1990, as indicative of Capili’s promise as a painter. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

CARATING, NORBERTO (Norberto de Guzman Carating) is a painter and signer. He was born on 7 Jan 1948. He is the son of Rafael Carating and Susana de Guzman. He graduated with a fine arts degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1970. Aside from his career as a visual artist, he has also performed on stage as a baritone.

Two of the major themes in Carating’s work are underground life and the weather. He is well known for his series on the lamang lupa (earth creatures) and “underwaterscapes,” which he calls the Anilao State. Art critic Leonidas Benesa describes his paintings on the weather as “mood paintings, tone poems in another discipline, but in a light rather than serious vein.” The lyrical quality of Carating’s works as much as his preferred subjects has led him to be categorized by art critics as an impressionist rather than an expressionist.

Carating has had over eight one-man shows and several retrospectives, one of which was held at the Bulwagan ng Dangal, UP Diliman, in Jul 2012. His works were exhibited in several major group exhibitions in the country and abroad, including the Second Havana Biennial in Cuba. Along with Augusto Albor, Carating exhibited during the 2015 Venice Biennale via the Personal Structures: Crossing Borders platform.

Carating won twice in the on-the-spot painting competition of the Shell National Students Art Competition: fourth prize for Fort Santiago in 1968 and first prize in 1969. He was also awarded by the Art Association of the Philippines: honorable mention, Barong-Barong (Shanty), 1971, and 12th, Lamang Lupa (Earth Creatures), 1973. He was named one of the Thirteen Artists by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

 

Source

 

Ong, James P. 2012. “45 Years of Norberto Carating’s Art.” Inquirer.net, 2 Jul. http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/55547/45-years-of-norberto-carating%E2%80%99s-art.

CARMELO, ALFREDO (Alfredo Casas Carmelo) was a painter. He was born in Binondo, Manila on 8 Jul 1896. He died in Manila on 25 Aug 1985. His parents were Eulalio Carmelo, an engraver, who was a Lacandola of the old Tondo aristocracy, and Maxima Casas, Eulalio’s second wife. His father and the German Guillermo Bauermann co-founded the lithographic shop of Carmelo and Bauermann. He married Elvira Ullmann, a French mestiza, whose family put up a jewelry business in the Philippines. Alfredo obtained his early education at San Beda College and Ateneo de Manila. He later enrolled at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura under Rafael Enriquez. In 1914, he went to Leipzig, Germany, to train in lithography in preparation for taking over his father’s place in the family firm. There he continued his artistic training and also took his first flying lessons. Carmelo pursued these two interests all his life, becoming the Philippines’ only marine painter and the first licensed civilian pilot in the country. He was eventually nominated for the Aerospace Hall of Fame in San Diego, California.

Through research and firsthand observation, Carmelo assiduously acquainted himself with features of different sailing ships down to their last detail. These were the subjects of his marine paintings, which fall under five groups: famous or historical ships in the high seas or docked in a harbor, Chinese junks and vessels in a Hong Kong harbor, vessels docked in Manila Bay with genre scenes, boats and ships plying the Pasig River in its heyday, and vessels in interisland ports. His works were documented in Alfredo Carmelo: His Life and Art, 1990.

Carmelo received two awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: in 1953 for Bergantine Goleta Waiting for the Tide, and in 1954 for The Saxon. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

 

Source

 

Roces, Alejandro R. 2009. “The Legacy of Alfredo Carmelo.” Philstar.com, 7 Mar. http://www.philstar.com/opinion/445905/legacyalfredo-carmelo.

CASTAÑEDA, DOMINADOR (Dominador Hilario Castañeda) was a painter and a teacher. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila on 8 Apr 1904. He died in 27 Nov 1967. At the age of six, he could draw a cat better than he could spell it. After graduating at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1924, he continued his studies at the Chicago Art Institute, and from 1929 to 1931 traveled across Mexico for an educational and sketching tour. He won first prize in a national competition sponsored by the Philippines Free Press in 1939 and first prize for his treasury note design in a national competition sponsored by the Central Bank of the Philippines in 1949. Castañeda taught at UP and eventually replaced Guillermo Tolentino as director of the School of Fine Arts. He wrote the pioneering history of Philippine art, Art in the Philippines, published in 1964.

Although a close contemporary of Fernando Amorsolo, Castañeda deliberately avoided being identified with the Amorsolo school. His early works were characterized by firm modeling and the use of dark hues. His landscapes are predominantly rendered in white and light blue tones, evoking a cool atmosphere in contrast to Amorsolo’s yellow and orange-flecked sceneries. After the end of World War II, Castañeda produced several paintings depicting the cruelty of the Japanese occupation forces. These pieces exhibit solidly defined shapes under strong contrasts of light and shadow, which give drama to the scenes.

Castañeda was posthumously given the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award by the city of Manila in 1971. Among his students was the painter and essayist Alfredo Roces, who cited Castañeda as his first art teacher. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

 

Source

 

Roces, Alfredo R. 2007. “Homage to Dominador Castañeda.” http://alfredo-roces.blogspot.com/2007/10/homage-to-dominadorcastaeda.html.

CASTILLO, ORLANDO (Orlando Garduque Castillo) is a painter and printmaker. He was born in Camalaniugan, Cagayan on 31 Dec 1947. He is the son of Florencio Castillo and Luz Garduque. He studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1965. He began as an abstract painter, shifting later to the graphic arts where he made his mark, winning five first prizes and becoming president of the Philippine Association of Printmakers, 1973-75. He served as president of the Art Association of the Philippines, 1983-84, and was a founding member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines.

In his etchings, Castillo’s strength lay in his inventive sense of design and exuberant use of folk motifs. Around 1972, sociopolitical concerns began to appear in his work, and he was detained for activism. He subsequently did a series of etchings on such themes as human rights violations and the people’s struggle in the countryside. The only concession he made to his natural penchant for baroque fantasy consisted in his infusion of flying angels, which he posed as symbols of the liberative spirit.

In 1975, Castillo left painting for printmaking. His show at the Quad Gallery made use of a stenciling technique, with subjects drawn from the 19th-century revolution as allegories for the contemporary one. During his social realist period, he painted peasants in struggle and peasant portraits based on a sojourn he took in the countryside.

Castillo was a Benavides awardee of the UST twice, in 1970 and 1971. He was recognized by the Shell National Students Art Competition for the following: third prize, on-the-spot painting, and first prize in graphic arts for Himig sa Bukid (Tune in the Field) both in 1970; first prize and runner-up in graphic arts, Hangal na Daigdig (Foolish World) and Fruits of Summer, respectively, both in 1971. Castillo is involved in activities concerning human rights and labor issues.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

 

 

Source

CASTRILLO, EDUARDO (Eduardo de los Santos Castrillo) was a sculptor. He was born in Santa Ana, Manila on 31 Oct 1942. He died in Muntinlupa on 18 May 2016. He was the son of Santiago Castrillo and Magdalena de los Santos. He studied at Don Bosco Technical College and Ateneo de Manila University. He finished with a bachelor of arts degree in advertising at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1962. He has held a number of solo exhibitions in the United States: at the Agra Gallery, Washington, DC; Plaza Hotel, New York; and Via de Parigi, Palon Beach. He participated in the Fukuoka International Art Exhibition in Japan. Castrillo was a faculty member of the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1974. In 1983, he held the artist-in-residence post at Far Eastern University, Manila. Castrillo was the president of the Art Association of the Philippines in 1984, and was reelected in 1987-88. In 1985-90, he was the representative for the visual arts to the UNESCO Commission on Culture in Manila. He was the vice president of the Society of Philippine Sculptors in 1990-92.

Castrillo contributed significantly to the development of sculpture in the Philippines. He made his mark in the 1960s with his public sculptures for memorial parks, like Pieta and the Redemption, and public monuments such as the Spirit of Pinaglabanan. At the other pole of these massive pieces is his miniature sculpture jewelry. He worked in a wide variety of media—including bronze, brass, stainless steel, chrome, plexiglass, glass, and scrap metal—and processes like hammer-outs, reliefs, assemblages, and bronze casting. He did mobiles of chrome and plexiglass, as well as stabiles and other huge environmental sculptures, which are mostly abstract. Many of his works are modular, allowing different compositional arrangements, so that the work is not fixed once and for all but is continually redefined in an active creative process. He also did figurative hammer-outs in which the expressive human forms are infused with the artist’s social vision.

Among his other works are Fountain Sculpture, 1984; Kiuala Trengganu, Malaysia; Benigno S. Aquino Monument, 1986; Andres Bonifacio Monument, 1987; Reflective Form, 1990; Bantayog ng mga Bayani (Monument of the Heroes), 1992; People Power Monument, 1993; Our Lady, Mediatrix of All Nations, 1995; Alapan and Tejeros Freedom Trails, 1998; Spirit of EDSA, 2001; Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seed of Freedom), 2002; Gat Andres Bonifacio, 2003; Spiral, 2006; Suppressing the Voice of the People: Tribute to the Slain and Tortured Members of the Mass Media, 2009; and Heritage of Surigao, 2010.

Castrillo received several awards such as the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila, Outstanding Makati Resident Award, the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in art, and the Ten Outstanding Young Men award, all in 1971. He was twice recognized by the Art Association of the Philippines: with an honorable mention in 1964, and a major award for Deaf Touch of Joy in 1968. He was named one of the Thirteen Artists by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1970. He was the Philippine representative in sculpture to the Paris Biennial. In 1986, he represented the Philippines to the Fourth ASEAN Square Sculpture Symposium in Brunei Darussalam. In 2007, he received the Thomasian Meritorius Award given by the UST Alumni Association Inc. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido
