CEBU ARTS ASSOCIATION aka CEARTAS. The oldest still-active organization for artists in the Philippines, the Cebu Arts Association (CAA) was formed on 22 Aug 1937 by Julian N. Jumalon, along with Oscar Figuracion, Ricardo Avila, Fidel Araneta, Silvestre Orfelia, Emilio Olmos, and Jose Trinidad Alcoseba. The founding group started as a fellowship of artists who regularly flocked to Jumalon’s studio on Colon St, and originally had as its acronym CEARTAS. They were later joined by Martino Abellana, Carmelo Tamayo, Virgilio Daclan, Mary Avila, Sergio Baguio, Emeterio Suson, and Jesus Rosa. The original principles of the CAA were to promote community awareness for the visual arts in Cebu, as well as to provide a venue for the exchange of ideas among artists.

Its leaders, Jumalon and Abellana, were both educated at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, and approached art making based on an academic realist system derived from the works of Fabian de la Rosa and Fernando Amorsolo. Through their long period of stay in Cebu, these two artists shaped the sensibility of many CAA members through the teaching and artistic production of works that hewed closely to this academic style, primarily portraits, landscapes, and still lifes. Works from the CAA members were then exhibited in venues in Cebu City that catered to the small public of local patrons and occasional visitors from Manila or abroad.

After World War II, the modernist persuasion started to dominate the CAA, through the efforts of such artists as Fidel Araneta, a UP School of Fine Arts alumnus who studied under Guillermo Tolentino but hewed to a more expressionistic style, and who was the first teacher of Napoleon Abueva in 1947-48; Alfredo Carmelo, who returned to Cebu from studies at the University of Santo Tomas in 1952, where he was a classmate of J. Elizalde Navarro; Virgilio Daclan, classmate of Abueva who subsequently taught fine arts at UP Diliman; and Fr Virgilio Yap, a Jesuit who was the first to advocate abstraction in Cebu during the 1960s and 1970s. The CAA membership from the 1950s to the 1980s thus reflected both conservative and modern persuasions, although a great majority still adhered to the conservative due to the postwar dominance of Abellana. Subsequent members included Sofronio, Teofilo, and Godofredo Mendoza; Jose “Kimsoy” Yap, Antonio Alcoseba, Gamaliel Subang, Romulo Galicano, Gig de Pio, and Mardonio Cempron.

With the advent of numerous art groups and competing art associations in Cebu starting in the late 1980s, the CAA went into hiatus by 2000. It was recently revived in 2014 via an exhibition titled A New Beginning, featuring works by a reconstituted membership from older as well as younger generations of Cebuano artists. Written by Reuben Ramas Cañete

 

 

Source

 

Montera, Dennis. 2014. “History of CEARTAS.” Pers. comm, 4 Aug.

CHABET, ROBERTO (Roberto Chabet Rodriguez) aka Bobby was a visual artist, teacher, and curator. He was born in Manila on 29 Mar 1937. He died in Manila on 30 Apr 2013. The son of Jose Rodriguez and Trinidad Chabet, he chose to use his mother’s name for his artistic career. He earned a degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1961. In the same year, he held his first individual exhibition at the Luz Gallery, thereby launching one of the most original and influential artistic careers. His stimulating influence on younger artists has been demonstrated not only through their art practices but also through proof of Chabet’s work as a teacher mentoring students way beyond their formal school years.

His professional career was dedicated largely to teaching. He first taught architectural design, theory, and history at the UST College of Architecture and Fine Arts (1964-70) and later studio arts courses at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (1971-2002). While teaching, Chabet pursued his own practice as an artist and a curator. He led the conceptual art group Shop 6 and organized landmark exhibitions of vanguard works by young artists of the day, from the 1970s and into the next four decades. These were held in institutional venues such as the Museum of Philippine Art and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), and in private galleries such as Pinaglabanan Galleries, Finale Art File, West Gallery, and MO Space.

Identified as the main proponent of conceptual art in the country, Chabet espoused a practice that gave precedence to idea over form. Moreover, his teaching style challenged students and pushed them toward critical thinking and experimentation beyond the boundaries of traditional art making. Having taught for more than three decades, Chabet mentored generations of artists, many of whom became the most innovative Manila-based artists from the 1970s onward.

He is known for his distinct drawings, collages, sculptures, and installations that are highly allegorical and innovative. His choice of materials functions as markers of a time in history—for example, the use of plywood and GI sheets reference his experience of post-World War II Manila. He treated his collages and installations like paintings, composed and assembled in layers of found and fabricated objects. Working in a broad range of media, he favored the use of collage with paper and paper products such as envelopes and brown bags, photographs, maps, and readymades such as tables and chairs. He stimulated a nonconventional view of familiar things to evolve a conceptual art more interested in raising artistic and other questions through visual techniques rather than simply presenting works. In 1980, he held an exhibit titled The Making of King Kong, which demonstrated his acuity in employing popular culture and other sources of predigested ideas to provoke contrarian readings. Another challenging idea that ran across Chabet’s work was his de-privileging of authorship, which could be seen in how he worked closely with his former students who later became close collaborators in many of his installation projects.

After retirement, Chabet continued teaching but in nonformal settings such as artist-run spaces and the Internet. The latter was through the daily online postings of “Angel Flores Jr,” the son of a fictive character he created in the late 1960s, together with two high school classmates, Ramon Katigbak and Benjamin Bautista.

Chabet was the first museum director of the CCP, a position he held from 1967 to 1971. His appointment began during the center’s planning stage. During this period, he also received a one-year travel grant from the Rockefeller Foundation to observe current trends in contemporary art and museum practices, particularly at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. Chabet conceived of the Thirteen Artists in 1970 as a curatorial project featuring young artists whose works “show a recentness, a turning away from the past and familiar modes of art-making.” This later evolved into the CCP Thirteen Artists Awards, now a triennial program that continues to give recognition to innovative artists. He also started the acquisition of CCP’s contemporary art collection, which includes historical works such as Victorio Edades’s The Builders and Napoleon Abueva’s Allegorical Harpoon.

Chabet received the 1972 Republic Cultural Heritage Award, the 1972 Araw ng Maynila Award for visual arts, the 1999 CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts, and the 2015 Gawad CCP para sa Sining. In 2011, King Kong Art Projects Unlimited, a group comprised of his former students, organized a yearlong retrospective project to celebrate his 50 years of art practice in exhibitions undertaken in cooperation with various museums and galleries in Metro Manila, Singapore, and Hong Kong. Chabet’s work was also the subject of Who Was Roberto Chabet?, a research-based project and exhibition undertaken by the Mori Art Museum, Tokyo, 2015. Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Ma. Victoria T. Herrera

CHING, MARIANO (Mariano Chan Ching) aka Nano Ching is a painter, illustrator, printmaker, and photographer. He was born in Manila on 26 May 1971. He is the son of Arsenio Ching and Chan Chaw Wa. He is married to visual artist Yasmin Sison, with whom he has a son, Haraya. Ching graduated with a bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1998. From 2002 to 2004, he studied printmaking at Kyoto City University of Fine Arts in Japan on a Monbusho scholarship.

First joining group exhibitions in 1996, Ching is among the artists who co-founded the art group and alternative space Surrounded by Water, 1998-2006, based in Angono, Rizal, and Pasig City. It was at Surrounded by Water where Ching held his earliest solo shows starting in 1999. Another solo exhibition of linocut prints, Rubber Soul, 2000, followed at the British Council, Manila.

Ching’s work as an artist is characterized by its sense of whimsical juxtaposition, merging fiction, fantasy, and figuration in his paintings. He has primarily worked in acrylic on canvas, positioning hybrid and detailed figures, compositions, and landscapes against sparse and still space. Conjuring miniature dystopias, Ching’s work comes across as multiple states born of the human imagination amidst an ecology of the world beyond self.

Ching has also explored the use of shaped canvases and various alternative media as a ground for painting such as silkscreen on black iron, 2008; acrylic on galvanized iron and stainless steel sheets, 2009; painting on vinyl records for his participation in the exhibition Foreign Chinese in Contemporary Art, for the 2010 inaugural Aichi Triennale in Nagoya, Japan; and pyrography on wood, 2011.

His work was included in exhibitions such as Pulse Art Fair, 2009, New York; Surrounded by Water, 2012, Equator Art Projects, Singapore; and Panorama: Recent Art from Contemporary Asia, 2013, Singapore Art Museum. Ching and Sison have also collaborated as artists in several shows such as Fan Fiction, 2009, West Gallery; and Collidoscope, 2011, Valentine Willie Fine Art, Singapore.

Ching’s work as an illustrator of children’s books, such as Adarna Publishing House’s Mayroon Akong Isang Puno (I Have a Tree), 1998, and Bakit Matagal ang Sundo Ko? (Why Is It Taking So Long to Fetch Me?), 2001, has earned for him the Alcala Illustrators’ Prize from the Philippine Board on Books for Young People. He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2006. Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

 

Sources

 

Ching, Mariano. 2014. Bio-data. Silverlens Galleries archives.

Francisco, Francis, ed. 2010. “Mariano Ching.” In Without Walls: A Tour of Philippine Paintings at the Turn of the Millennium. Philippines: Winrum Publishing.

Gaba, Marc. 2009. Catalogue for the exhibition Dead Ends and False Starts. Silverlens Galleries.

PBBY (Philippine Board on Books for Young People). n.d.b. “Roster of Awardees, Alcala Prize.” http://www.pbby.org.ph.

CHUA-LUA, KENGKENG aka Chua Keng Keng-Lua is a painter and educator. He was born in Fukien, China on 11 Jan 1932. She is the daughter of Chi Seng Ong and Tan Chai. Chua-Lua received her education in China. Migrating to the Philippines at a young age, she received further education at the University of Santo Tomas where she obtained her fine arts degree in 1955. Upon graduation, she involved herself in education.

In 1957, she began teaching at St. Stephen’s High School, where she presided over art subjects, language courses, and others, being also a foreign language supervisor. She taught art at Saint Theresa’s College from 1956 to 1964. In 1953, the artist further advanced her skills in the traditional Chinese manner by studying with Professor Tao of Taiwan. In 1979, she was a member of the first delegation of artists formed by the Association for Philippines-China Understanding, which visited five cities in China. Because of her expertise, she was hired as a faculty member of the People’s University of China, Beijing, and associate director of the Foreign Language Reference Research Center, Peking, 1980-84. Chua-Lua’s artistic output may be categorized into chronological periods. Her Dawning, 1952, blends Philippine setting with the Chinese watercolor technique. Her second-period works were influenced by Neo-Realism, exemplified by To the Fields, 1957, and Sidewalk Vendor, 1958.

Her works from this second period used earth colors to evoke the brown Filipino complexion, warm hues for the tropical atmosphere, tilted or cramped space as opposed to the Western linear perspective and boldly stylized shapes of the human limbs to evoke the thickset Filipino physique. The artist’s third stylistic phase shows a return to the Chinese scroll tradition, but the images definitively show a more personal touch.

Chua-Lua had three major shows: in 1957 at Northern Motors, Manila; in 1969 at the Philamlife Building; and in 1987 at the Midtown Hotel. Her earliest works in the Chinese painting style include Stork, a silk painting for which she won the third prize in a Chinese-sponsored competition in 1951. Dawning, 1952, won for her second prize at the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) annual watercolor exhibition. To the Fields, 1957, won first prize in the abstract category during the Southeast Asian Art Conference and Competition held in the Philippines. Sidewalk Vendor received the Best Philippine Genre Prize in the AAP Annual Art Competition, 1958. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

CO, CHARLIE (Charlie Sia Co) is a painter and sculptor. He was born in Bacolod on 5 Nov 1960. He is the son of Co Pau and Pacita Sia. He studied fine arts at the Philippine Women’s University and interior design at the Philippine School of Interior Design. Co is a former director of the Bacolod Art Association, a member of Pamilya Pintura, and the chairperson of Black Artists in Asia. He was actively involved in organizing the Visayan Islands Visual Arts Exhibition and Conference in 1990 and 1992.

Although identified as a social realist emerging in the mid-1980s, Co has been described as a purveyor of figurative expressionism bordering on surrealism. His stylistically distorted figures—at times angry, at times sentimental—inhabit highly colorful metaphysical landscapes that are largely dreamlike but in which can be found familiar images of electric posts, a stopwatch, fish, cars, and the American flag. Co also does small sculpture pieces in low-fired terra-cotta accented with soot. Although his subjects are political refugees, factory and sugar farm workers, he imbues them with universalized features expressing human endurance and courage, rather than particularized characterization. He has combined his colorful painting and raw terra-cotta into successful reliefs.

He held his first solo exhibition, Ekspresyon (Expression), 1983, in Bacolod City. Since then, he has exhibited in Bacolod, Iloilo, Cebu, and Metro Manila; among his shows were Pagpapahilabot (Intervention), There Is Something Wrong with Freedom, and Philippines ’83, which formed part of his 1985 exhibitions: Terracotta Sculpture, 1986, at the Hiraya Gallery, Manila, and Framed Allegory, 1992, at the Alliance Française. Co also had one-person shows in Sydney, Australia, in 1989 and 2002, and in Hong Kong in 2007. He has participated in group exhibitions in Holland, Japan, and Australia organized by the Black Artists in Asia. Co has also participated in a number of group exhibitions such as Who Owns Women’s Bodies? at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 2001 and Landscapes in Southeast Asian Art: Works from the Singapore Art Museum Permanent Art Collection, Singapore, 2000.

Co was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1990. He was Philippine representative to the 1992 Lake Naguri Open Air Art Exhibition in Naguri, Japan; the 1995 Asian Modernism, at the Japan Foundation ASEAN Culture Center, Tokyo, Japan; the 1996 Sao Paulo Biennale in Sao Paulo, Brazil; and the 1997 International Clay Symposium Exhibition in Gifu, Japan. In 1999, he was awarded the Jurors Choice at the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards.Written by Rosalinda Galang and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

 

 

Source

 

Galleria Duemila. 2013b. Website. http://www.galleriaduemila.com/.

COBANGBANG, LENA (Lena Villena Cobangbang) is an intermedia artist and curator. She was born in Quezon City on 13 May 1976. She is the daughter of Ruben Cobangbang and Julieta Villena. She earned units in advertising from the College of the Holy Spirit in Manila and majored in painting at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, from 1995 to 2002.

Cobangbang’s wide-ranging artistic practice overlaps with her training in production and set design, having worked as a freelance art director and prop stylist since 2005. Visually compelling, her series of photographs titled Terrible Landscape, 2005, shown at the Second Singapore Biennale, 2008, involved the skillful staging of leftover food in order to recreate scenes of disaster.

Cobangbang’s individual works could also be described as quirky and playful, employing craft materials, found objects, and discards, as exemplified by her solo exhibition Velvet Landing, 2010. Her works often find resonance in past collaborative works such as Alice and Lucinda, a “fluid mask persona” which Cobangbang and fellow artist Yasmin Sison embodied beginning 1999 and which led to the producing of zines, photographs, video, performance, and installation, culminating in an exhibition of the Alice and Lucinda archive at the UP Vargas Museum in Quezon City and MO Space in Taguig in 2012. Cobangbang also collaborated with Mike Crisostomo in The Weather Bureau, through which the two artists created imaginary environments using set design and studio photography in conjuring an aftermath of a natural disaster as exemplified by the work Experiments in Degree Zero, 2011.

Cobangbang has actively taken part in local and international artist residency programs since 2003. She completed her first yearlong residency in the artist-run space Big Sky Mind, which advocated “crossover and collaboration.” Cobangbang’s involvement with alternative spaces has presented her opportunities to strengthen international linkages as was the case in her curatorial residency under the Philippines-Slovenia Short Circuit Tactical Project, 2010, where she represented Green Papaya Art Projects. In 2013, she was also artist in residence at San Art, Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam, where she represented The Weather Bureau. Search and Destroy Missions, 2000, Cobangbang’s first solo exhibition, was held in the artist-run space Surrounded by Water. As part of the collective Surrounded by Water, she witnessed and participated in defining a critical phase where alternative spaces spawned the early careers of contemporary artists from UP. Cobangbang has held several solo shows including The Care for Dead Horses, 2010, Finale Art File, Makati City, and Raping the Muse, 2012, Galerie Zimmermann, Kratochwill, Graz, Austria. She participated in group exhibitions like Kingdom Come, 2013, Blanc Gallery, Quezon City; Manila Vice, 2013, Musee International des Arts, Modestes, Sete, France; Surrounded by Water, Over the Water, Equator Art Projects, Gillman Barracks, Singapore; and the Bastards of Misrepresentation series curated by Manuel Ocampo in various exhibition venues such as Freies Museum, Berlin and 8.Salon, Hamburg, Germany, in 2010, and Queens Museum Project Space, New York, and H Gallery Bangkok, Thailand, in 2012.

Cobangbang received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2006 and was later invited to curate the award exhibition in 2012. She also received the Asian Culture Council Starr Foundation Visual Art Fellowship together with Yason Banal and Jeona Zoleta in 2012. In recent years, Cobangbang has also developed her commitment to art writing and project management, conducting lectures and other similar work parallel to her curatorial practice. Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

COBCOBO, JOEY (Joey Vendiola Cobcobo) is a painter, printmaker, and mixed media artist. He was born in Umingan, Pangasinan on 6 May 1983. He is the son of Claudio Cobcobo and Marcelina Vendiola. His father is an Igorot while his mother is from Pangasinan. He is married to Ella Aquino with whom he has two sons, Ark Daniel and Bezaleel Buhay. Cobcobo graduated cum laude with a degree in fine arts, major in advertising, from Technological University of the Philippines (TUP), 2004. He has been a faculty member of TUP since 2010 and is secretary external of the Printmakers Association of the Philippines.

Cobcobo’s work process often involves developing pieces across different art forms—for instance, images from prints are translated as clay sculptures that he uses as reference for paintings. The work Crown Him King, which won the Juror’s Choice of Excellency during the 2010 Philippine Art Awards, is an example of an oil painting that was developed in this way.

His first solo exhibitions—Black Saturday, 2007, and Evangelio (Gospel), 2008, in Big & Small Gallery, and 7 Heads and 10 Horns in Avellana Art Gallery, 2009—are all heavily inspired by his Baptist beliefs. His Lola 101 series of exhibitions, 2010 and 2012, were inspired by how his mother became a grandmother after he had his first son. She participated in the art-making process by doing the crochet work against which the prints inspired by his interviews of grandmothers were set. This series also informed the resulting exhibition for his 2013 Koganecho Bazaar, Japan residency, Grand Ojisan/Obasan. The subsequent exhibition I’m Doing My Father’s Business in Avellana Art Gallery, on the other hand, was inspired by his son and is another collaboration in that the images came from his son’s drawings then transferred to red bricks used as intaglio plates.

Among his international group exhibitions are Invitational Mini-Exhibition, Post Office Gallery, The Arts Academy of Ballard Victoria, Australia, 2008; the 26th Asian International Art Exhibition, Hangaram Art Museum, Seoul, 2011; Pinoy Ako (I Am a Filipino), held in various venues in Ho Chi Minh, 2012; and Printmaking, Pinoy Printmakers, Philippine Center, Manhattan, New York, 2013. His group exhibitions in the Philippines include those at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), BenCab Museum, Ayala Museum, and the Ortigas Foundation Library.

Cobcobo was awarded the grand prize in the 2nd Art Petron National Students Painting Competition, 2002, and at the 2003 National Piñana Art Competition. He was recognized twice by the Philippine Art Awards: as NCR winner, 2009, and as Juror’s Choice of Excellency awardee, 2010. He was shortlisted for the Ateneo Art Awards in 2009, 2010, and 2013. Cobcobo received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2012. Written by Iris S. De Ocampo

Francisco V. Coching (Francisco Vicente Coching) is a komiks illustrator and National artist for visual arts. He was born in Buting, Pasig, Rizal on 29 Jan 1919. He died on 1 Sep 1998. He was the son of novelist Gregorio Coching and Juana Vicente. His brother Vito is a sculptor, and another brother, Greco, is a set designer. He was married to Filomena Navales with whom he had six children, two of whom are portrait artists—Maridel and Lourdes. Francisco left school at an early age to work for the magazine Liwayway where his father was a novelist. Coching apprenticed with Tony Velasquez.

In 1934, he created his first komiks character, Bing Bigotilyo, for the magazine Silahis and the year after, Marabini or “marahas na binibini” (reckless maiden), which was abruptly ended by the onset of war. During the war years, he joined a guerrilla group, the Kamagong Unit of the Hunters-ROTC. After the war, he created Bulalakaw. However, it was Hagibis, his next work, that won him fame. Hagibis, which was inspired by Kulafu of Francisco Reyes and Tarzan of Edgar Rice Burroughs, ran for 15 years in Liwayway and was followed by sequels: Anak ni Hagibis (Son of Hagibis) and Si Gat Sibasib (Gat Sibasib). Coching’s creations were sought out by producers who made movies from them, such as Hagibis, 1947, with Fernando Poe and Erlinda Cortes; Satur, 1951, with Manuel Conde; Sabas: Ang Barbaro (Sabas: The Barbarian), 1951, with Pancho Magalona; Palasig, 1952, with Gloria Romero; Maldita (Naughty), 1953, with Rita Gomez; and Movie Fan, 1956, with Amalia Fuentes. All but five of his komiks novels were made into movies. His other well-known works are Bertong Balutan, Don Cobarde, El Ligio, Espada (Sword), Agilang Itim (Black Eagle), El Indio (The Native), Pedro Penduko, Dumagit, Lapu-Lapu, Salabusab (Greedy), Pusakal (Hardened Criminal), Ang Maton (The Tough Guy), Taga sa Bato (Cut on a Stone), Talipandas (Wayward), Vengativo (Prone to Vengeance), Thor, Pistolero (The Gunman), Dimasalang, El Vibora (The Viper), Ang Kaluluwa ni Dante (Dante’s Soul), Pagano (Pagan), Haring Ulupong (King Cobra), Bulalakaw (Shooting Star), Waldas (Spendthrift), and Contravida (Villain). Many of these appeared in Liwayway. At his peak, he was writing and illustrating three weekly serials simultaneously. Coching both wrote and illustrated his stories. His works had a strong narrative flow, brimmed with drama, and were punctuated by action and suspense. His illustrative style belonged to the romantic tradition of komiks illustration, which he dominated from 1934 to 1974, the year he retired, authoring 63 komiks novels.

His last novel, El Negro, was published in Liwayway and was turned into a film in 1974. The style was characterized by dynamic curvilinear lines and tonal modeling with a fluid, undulating effect. The leading male characters are stalwart in build, and of handsome mestizo or Malay looks, with curly hair and rippling muscles. The female leads are beautiful, graceful of build, and usually with long curly tresses. It is a style that gives life to the myths and legends of yore and to fantasies of love and adventure. Coching influenced other artists, such as Nestor Redondo, Larry Alcala, Emil Quizon-Cruz, and Emil Rodriguez, to pursue the art of komiks illustration.

An exhibit of his works opened at Nayong Pilipino in 1987. In 2001, an exhibit titled Komiks: Katha at Guhit ni Francisco V. Coching (Komiks: Stories and Drawings of Francisco V. Coching) opened at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). In 2009, another exhibit titled Francisco V. Coching: Filipino Master Komiks Artist was shown in New York and Hawaii. Coching’s restored El Indio: A Graphic Novel was published by Vibal Foundation. A dual exhibit with National Artist Carlos V. Francisco, titled Telling Modern Time: The Life and Art of Botong Francisco and Francisco Coching, opened at the National Museum also in 2009.

In 1981, he received the Makasining ng Komiks Award at the Tanging Parangal for Comics Art given by the Manila Commission of Arts and Culture. In 1984, he was given a Lifetime Achievement Award by the Komiks Operation Brotherhood Inc. Other awards include an Award for Excellence by the Pasay City government in 1998 for his contribution to the local art scene and a Gawad CCP para sa Sining for visual arts in 2008. Coching was declared National Artist for visual arts in 2014.  Written by Alice G. Guillermo and Rene B. Javellana, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

 

 

Sources

 

Flores, Patrick D., ed. 2010. The Life and Art of Francisco Coching. Quezon City: Francisco V. Coching Foundation and Vibal Foundation.

San Diego, Bayani Jr. 2006. “Kuwentong Coching.” Inquirer.net, 28 Aug. http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/entertainment/entertainment/view/20060828-17700/%91Kuwentong%92_Coching.

CONCEPCION, FLORENCIO (Florencio Balajadia Concepcion) was a painter and teacher. He was born in San Nicolas, Tondo on 20 Feb 1933. He died in 2006. His parents were Florencio Concepcion Sr and Jacinta Balajadia. He finished his early education at Pedro Guevarra Elementary School during the Japanese period and secondary training at Arellano High School in 1949. He was one of the first graduates of the four-year fine arts course at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. Before he entered UP, he took up cartooning through the Cartoonist Exchange and Correspondence School based in Ohio. Thus, while studying, he illustrated for comic magazines like Action, Halakhak, Pilipino, and Bulaklak. After college, he obtained a scholarship to study in Italy from the Italian government. He obtained a master of arts degree at the Regge Accademia di Belle Arti in Rome in 1964.

Upon his return to the Philippines, he joined the faculty of the School of Fine Arts at the University of the East where he served as dean until 1994.

Concepcion’s earliest exhibition works were impressionistic scenes executed in thick impasto. In the 1960s, he turned abstract expressionist along a lyrical vein. His characteristic evocation of spatial depth through the texture of his medium complements his keen eye for color harmony or tonal contrast, which he describes as inspired by his deep appreciation of music. Concepcion is also a highly disciplined watercolorist and a master of figure drawing. In 1990, he authored a manual on figure drawing.

He received the diploma of merit at I Mostra Internazionale d’Arte in Rome, 1962; a silver medal at I Mostra Nazionale di Pittura Estemporanea in Segni, Italy, 1962; honorable mention at I Mostra Internazionale d’Arte di Tivoli, Italy, 1962; and third prize at I Mostra di Pittura, Lazio, 1963, at the Galleria d’Arte del Palazzo delle Esposizione in Rome. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

 

Source

 

Galarpe, Karen. 1996. “Florencio Concepcion: Master of Expression.” Manila Times, 19 Aug. K Monitor (blog). Accessed 28 Apr 2016. https://karengalarpe.wordpress.com/2010/01/13/florencio-concepcion-master-of-expression/.

article_title: Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP) (See LITERATURE volume.)
text: Concerned Artists of the Philippines (CAP)(See LITERATURE volume.)

CONGSON, GABINO (Gabino Reyes Congson) was a painter and illustrator. He was born in Catbalogan, Samar on 13 Feb 1910. He died in 2008. His parents were Juan Congson and Paz Reyes. He was married to Filomena Alday of Tacloban, Leyte. Congson is a self-taught artist who grew up in Manila. He studied at the Landon School of Illustration and Cartooning, an international correspondence school based in Ohio, USA. He also took courses in magazine illustrating and figure drawing at the Federal Schools Inc. In 1948, he became a certified public accountant. Congson started his employment at the Manila Electric Company or Meralco in 1930, first as a cleaner of tranvias, then as a meter reader, clerk, chief accountant, personnel manager, and assistant vice president. Before retiring from Meralco in 1973, he was the executive assistant to Eugenio Lopez Sr.

In Oct 1933, Congson offered his services to the editor and publisher of the Philippine Magazine, AVH Hartendorp, as he thought the position of illustrator could provide him a good source of income. At that time, the magazine was considered a platform for new writers and artists to show their work. His first commissioned illustration for the magazine was for a short story by Bienvenido N. Santos, Christmas Idyll, published in Dec 1933. The Feb 1936 issue of the magazine featured the first cover illustration by Congson. By 1937, Hartendorp noted the growing popularity of Congson’s work among the readers of the Philippine Magazine, composed mainly of American readers, teachers, and students. Congson continued to submit illustration covers to the magazine until it closed in 1941 upon orders of the Japanese occupation forces during World War II.

Congson’s illustrations and vignettes may be considered social commentary and satire on everyday life in prewar Manila. Infused with humor, his subject matter are Filipinos doing their work or activities with a sense of playfulness. Some examples of his works are the following: When the Mistress Is Away, 3 Sep 1936; The Dog Catcher, 5 Nov 1936; Fifty-Fifty, 6 May 1937; Going to the Market, 9 Aug 1937; Christmas Lantern, 13 Dec 1937; Cinderella, 15 Apr 1938; No Gun Powder, 17 Jul 1938; A Stitch Takes Time, 18 Sep 1938; Vacation Cruise, 22 May 1939; Rainy Days, 23 Jun 1939; Cuya Goes Acourting, 24 Jul 1939; and Yo-yo Enthusiast, 29 May 1941. Many of these vignettes are seen from the perspective of two boys observing their elders in unglamorous poses, sometimes with a dog or a cat creating chaos in the scene. The Dog Catcher, 1936, depicts a grim-faced man holding a net while the two boys hide a dog behind their backs. In Cinderella, 1938, a woman is depicted coloring her eyebrows by using a blackened palayok (earthen pot), beautifying herself before a small mirror. The irony of the title and the image is apparent to the viewer as a commentary on vanity and resourcefulness.

Congson won first and second prizes in a government-sponsored anti-usury poster contest in 1934.

In 2014, the Ayala Museum held the exhibit The Printed Word: The Lost Art of Gabino Reyes Congson. Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Faye Cura

 

 

Source

 

Filipinas Heritage Library. 2014. The Printed Word: The Lost Art of Gabino Reyes Congson. Accessed 26 Jan 2016. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3IfkDM97sOA.

CONICONDE, PEDRO (Pedro Velasco Coniconde) was an illustrator and cartoonist. He was born in San Pedro, Laguna on 18 Jan 1901. He died on 18 Feb 1974. His father, Domingo Coniconde, was a sculptor and a singer in the Santa Ana Church choir. He studied at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts and then became director of the Philippines Herald and illustrator for the Tribune.

He specialized in the “Spanish-style cartoon,” which upheld a realistic or idealized rendition of the subject’s face but reduced the rest of the figure. During the 1930s to the 1950s, when illustration flourished in the country, Coniconde excelled in character studies of political as well as sports celebrities. He created a series of drawings representing various sports like tennis, basketball, and baseball, with faces of the top athletes idealized but their bodies rendered diminutively. He also executed portraits of the country’s presidents, rendering them with extremely fine hatching, cross-hatching, and stippling. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

CONTRERAS, REY (Rey Paz Contreras) is a sculptor. He was born in Parañaque, Rizal on 31 Aug 1950. He is the son of Antonio Contreras and Librada Paz. He married Estrella Isla who also became a sculptor and writer. They have a daughter, sculptor Carlota Contreras Korterbay. He finished a bachelor of science degree in commerce, major in accounting, at the Manuel Luis Quezon University in 1974. He is a member of the Concerned ArtistsofthePhilippines.

Contreras held his first one-person show at Galerie Bleue in 1975. He has done sculpture using trabieza (discarded railroad tracks made of weathered hardwood), often in assemblage with other materials such as indigenous textiles and artifacts. One of his notable works is the giant crucifix titled Human Rights Violations, which was installed at the Paco train station. In the piece, the Christ figure, made from a single piece of trabieza, powerfully expresses an image of suffering.

Contreras has also dealt with ethnic and protest themes revolving around the struggles of indigenous ethnolinguistic communities against displacement from their ancestral land and exploitation by elites, as in his Our Sacred Land series. In the work, he combines masks, anito figures such as the Cordillera bulol, granary deities, and farm implements. Contreras’s preferred material may be associated with the belief that the anitos dwell in the hollows of tree trunks, radiating a primeval energy and converging the power of ancestral traditions. He has also carved wooden masks of a highly expressive aspect, embellished by various ethnic artifacts, such as implements, real or imaginary weapons, tribal jewelry, and costume fragments.

His other works relate to contemporary issues, such as the mock composite musical instrument called Noise Barrage, whose title refers to a form of protest against the Marcos government, in which urban communities raised a collective sound barrage at a designated time. There is likewise a functional side to his art in his sculpture-furniture combining wood and heavy stone or marble.

His solo exhibitions include Treasures from Abandoned Wood, 1994; New Works, 1995; and Dream Series, 1996, all at the SM Art Center, Mandaluyong; Bakal, Bote, at Iba Pa (Iron, Glass, and Others), 1997, Alliance Française, Makati; The Trees, 1997, the first public sculpture installed in Bonifacio Global City, Taguig; Sculptural Hybridity, 1999, Art Space, Makati; Homage to the Sacred Land, 2003, SM Art Walk, Mandaluyong; Rostros de Jesus (Faces of Christ), 2004, Quezon City; and New Works, 2012, Contreras Sculptures, SM Art Center, Mandaluyong.

He was the grand prize winner in sculpture at the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Open Art Competition in 1992. In 1994, he was awarded by the city of Manila the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for sculpture. In 1997, he was an awardee of the first Bonifacio Public Art Competition, Bonifacio Art Foundation Inc. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Zeny May D. Recidoro

COQUILLA, DANIEL (Daniel Alvarez Coquilla) aka Dansoy is a painter. He was born in Panabo City, Davao del Norte on 3 May 1970. He is the son of Ladislao Coquilla and Rosita Alvarez. Coquilla moved to Manila in 1988 after completing a comics workshop by Vincent Kua Jr. It was in Manila where he met visual artist and gallery owner Alfredo Liongoren who, with his wife gallery owner Norma Liongoren, encouraged him to take up fine arts and later guided his artistic career. Coquilla enrolled in the certificate program in painting of the College of Fine Arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1990. In 1992, Coquilla became video editor at the UP National Institute for Science and Mathematics Education Development.

His two-year stint as comics illustrator helped him develop a unique compositional style of rendering crowds in everyday settings. Offering an aerial perspective, his works recreate life and culture on the streets, revealing the vigorous communal functions of solitary and mundane acts. His canvases are playful and imaginative, yet teeming with sociopolitical commentary. He is best recognized for his paintings of cockeyed human figures with ovoid or bulging heads and distorted limbs, their faces turned upward (nakatingala) with their eyes set upon the viewer of the work. His expressive use of form, vivid color, and brushwork is akin to the styles of Danilo Dalena, Norma Belleza, and Onib Olmedo, artists from whom Coquilla gained inspiration.

His paintings feature vignettes of life in UP and nearby areas, inspired no doubt by his more than two decades on campus as a student and an employee. Oblation Run, 2004, captures a bird’s-eye view of naked male neophytes emulating the iconic school symbol (Guillermo Tolentino’s Oblation) and partaking in an annual rite of passage as they streak through the campus. In the exhibition Drawing on Board, 2012, Coquilla reconfigured the roof of a jeepney as installation, painting the interior with cramped passengers. The installation engages viewers as they find their reflection on the mirror overhead echoing the point of view of the figures in his drawings. Another recurring theme in Coquilla’s works is the popular street food isaw (chicken/pork innards). His first painting in this vein was Mamang Isaw (Mr Isaw), a work he submitted as a plate in Prof. Roberto Chabet’s class in 1992.

Coquilla’s solo exhibitions include Top Shot, Utterly Art, Singapore, 2010; Drawing on Board, Vargas Museum, UP Diliman, Quezon City, 2012; IN eks, Boston Gallery, 2012; and Top Face, Boston Gallery, Cubao, 2013. His group exhibitions include BSP Tanaw Art Competition Exhibit, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, 2011; Alay 13, Boston Gallery; 12 x 9, West Gallery, Quezon City; and the inaugural show at Pinto Art Museum, Antipolo City, 2010.

Coquilla received the Award of Excellence from the Shell National Students Art Competition, 1992; the UP Diliman Gawad Chanselor para sa sining biswal and the grand prize in the annual painting competition of the Art Association of the Philippines, 1996; Juror’s Choice in the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards and the ASEAN Art Award for the work K-H, 1997. He won in the Winsor and Newton Worldwide Millennium Painting Competition in 1999. In 2006, he received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award. Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

CORDERO, LOUIE (Luisito Ramos Cordero) is a visual and installation artist. He was born in Tondo, Manila on 24 Feb 1978. He is the son of Benjamin Gungon Cordero and Marina Hernandez Ramos. Cordero studied at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts. He graduated in 2001, receiving both a degree in studio arts and the Gawad Dominador Castañeda for Best Thesis. As a student, Cordero also worked as a freelance illustrator for McSweeney’s Quarterly Concern and Pulp, a music magazine.

Cordero’s My We, a large-scale narrative installation that combined sculpture, video, and painting, was shown at the 2011 Singapore Biennale and acquired by the Singapore Art Museum. Through illustration, painting, and sculpture, Cordero has put a humorous and often satirical spin on the serious themes and darker issues that shroud Philippine society. His practice often combines classical techniques with unconventional media and materials, a track that might be perceived as putting artists at risk when it comes to developing stylistic niches. Yet, Cordero maintains a distinct aesthetic, which is evident in Nardong Tae (Nardo the Shit Guy), which features a scatological superhero whose story the artist has told in a fold-and-staple comic book, and whose fan base has expanded through lines of limited-edition figurines and T-shirts. Precisely because of Cordero’s pop culture references, his works are generally very readable to local audiences, more so for those attuned to cultural nuances evoked in his image-making. However, even as international audiences may miss out on the multiple facets of Filipino humor informing Cordero’s puns and visual jokes, they are nonetheless introduced to how Filipinos take to the grotesque without overshadowing the possibility of finding beauty in strange places.

Internationally, Cordero has contributed work and participated in both group and solo exhibitions, beginning with Faith in the City: A Survey of Contemporary Filipino Art, at the La Salle SIA College of the Arts in Singapore, 2000. This exhibition traveled to the Valentine Willie Fine Art Gallery, Malaysia, in 2001 and was also mounted at the Metropolitan Museum in Manila and at Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok, both in 2002. He has since also exhibited in Indonesia, Hong Kong, Taipei, Fukuoka, Sydney, Melbourne, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Berkeley, Austin, Philadelphia, New York, Paris, and London. Cordero was a resident at the Vermont Studio Center in the United States, 2003. This residency was followed by his participation in another residency at the Big Sky Mind Foundation in Quezon City, 2003-04, and in Bangkok University, 2012. Cordero won the grand prize in the painting category at the 8th Annual Freeman Foundation Awards at the Vermont Studio Center during his residency. In 2004, he received the Ateneo Art Award for which he was also a finalist in 2005. In 2006, Cordero was recognized as one of the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists awardees.Written by Alice Sarmiento

COSETENG, ALICIA (Alicia Guanco Marquez Lim-Coseteng) is a writer, educator, diplomat, and cultural worker. She was born in Iloilo City on 1 Apr 1931. She died in Manila on 22 Jun 2001. She was the daughter of Jose Asensi Marquez Lim and Judith Siguenza Guanco. She was married to Emerson Tan Coseteng. She finished AB English at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1954, MA English at Cornell University in 1957, and MA Communications at Stanford University in 1967. She studied the colonial art of Mexico under a scholarship from the Mexican government. She taught at the University of the Philippines Diliman, 1958-79, and was principal of the Diliman Preparatory School, 1987-2000. She was president of the Diliman Educational Corporation, 1969-2000; chairman of the San Leonardo Charcoal Briquetting Corporation, 1980-2000; chairman and director of the Diliman Holding Inc and Asia-Pacific Training Institute, 1994-98; and chief of mission, Class II Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to Mexico for the Department of Foreign Affairs, 2000-01. She also served as chairman of the Mass Communication Committee of the UNESCO National Commission, 1965-82; secretary-general, UNESCO National Commission, 1982-83; and chairman of the graduate studies program of the College of Mass Communication, UP Diliman, 1973-79. She was a member of the Association Internationale des Critiques d’Art based in Paris, France.

As a writer and art critic, Coseteng was the art columnist for The Manila Chronicle, 1960-61; editorial staff writer for art and cultural editor at the weekly Graphic Magazine, 1965-66; and feature writer in the 1960s for The Manila Times, The Manila Daily Bulletin, and Manila Chronicle Magazine. Her solo-authored books include Spanish Churches in the Philippines, 1971; Folk Media in the Philippines, 1975; and The Philippine Senate, 1997. As editor, she published Philippine Modern Art and Its Critics, 1972. As co-author, she contributed chapters to A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces, 1986, and Art Philippines, 1992. Her research interests included colonial churches in the Philippines, art critical discourses in the Philippines, Philippine folk media and family planning, and teaching humanities in the Philippines. Coseteng’s interests lay primarily in establishing the “criollo” nature of Philippine Art. Her fascination with Mexican folk art and its influence on Philippine crafts and culture during the Spanish colonial period was a leitmotif that strung together many of her writings, chiefly Spanish Churches in the Philippines. In addition, her art criticism hewed closely to the formalist method in vogue in the late 1950s to mid-1970s, privileging Philippine expressionists and abstractionists in her critical writings.

She received the Outstanding Book Award from the National Academy of Sciences and Technology in 1999 for her work The Philippine Senate. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya and Reuben Ramas Cañete

 

 

Source

 

Coseteng, Alicia. 2014. Biodata. Nov.

COSIO, ALLAN (Allan Vazquez Cosio) is a painter, sculptor, and tapestry artist. He was born in Bacolor, Pampanga on 20 Jun 1941. He is the son of Flavio Cosio and Añiana Vasquez. He married Ivi Avellana, a painter and printmaker.

While also a good portraitist in pastel, Cosio has done abstract paintings in the op art style characterized by mathematical precision and illusionism. His sculptures, on the other hand, are massive blocks of unpolished wood, forming structures that suggest altars for primitive rites. In some of his works, he also draws inspiration from indigenous sources such as the Philippine banig (mat).

He has done a series of tapestries and wall hangings, heavily built with a wooden frame for support. Most of these wall hangings are done discontinuously, by means of a series of horizontal bolsters upon which the fibers or other kinds of material, such as capiz shell squares, are bound. Importance is given to the qualities of the medium. The fibers are of various striking hues, with strongly tactile textures. The sheen of the capiz shells is brought out fully. Some of his tapestries seem to be three-dimensional because of their structural quality and use of heavy materials.

Cosio was a prizewinner for five consecutive years, 1975-79, in the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition. In 1980, he won the grand prize and a British Council study grant in the AAP competition. He was a prizewinner in the 1986 Baghdad International Art Festival. Cosio was awarded a grant by the Pollock-Krasner Foundation of New York and received the city of Manila’s award for painting and sculpture. Written by Alice G. Guillermo

CRISTOBAL, BONIFACIO (Bonifacio Nicolas Cristobal) was a painter and art educator. He was born in Sorsogon, Sorsogon on 16 Jun 1911. He died in Manila on 20 May 1977. He was the son of Damian Cristobal and Teodora Nicolas. Cristobal completed his early education at Sorsogon Provincial High School. He obtained a certificate in painting from the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1937. Later, he attended the Academie Julien in Paris to study master in figure painting in 1938. In 1939, he studied under Carlo Siviero at the Regge Academia di Belle Arti in Rome, then later transferred to the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Florence, under Felice Carena. He staged his first one-person show at UP in 1940. He taught at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) from 1947 to 1976.

Cristobal was one of the Thirteen Moderns. Schooled in Europe, his paintings in the late 1930s, though representational, were achieved with impressionist vigorous impasto, although his forms tended to be expressionistic. The artist, however, later reverted to conservative representationalism, characterized by solid modeling and strict adherence to colors inspired by the actual world. This reversion is best observed in his portrait of Jorge B. Vargas as President of Boy Scout, Philippines, 1950, a straightforward portrait. Cristobal used flat tones of colors for the face and clothes of the subject so that all subsidiary colors would stand out in intensity, providing decorative relief to an otherwise ordinary subject. The subject matter of his works are religious themes such as Mother and Child, 1950, as well as landscapes, still lifes, and portraits.

Cristobal received an award in 1938 at the Spring Exhibition in Paris; the first prize at the Art Association of the Philippines–Boys’ Town Carnival for his painting Hingutuhan (Removing Lice), 1949; and first prize in the Marian Year Centennial Art Competition, for Madonna of the Sampaguita, 1954.

In 2012, the Government Service Insurance System Museum mounted a retrospective exhibit of his works in Damian’s Son: A Century of Bonifacio N. Cristobal. In 2015, the Beata Angelico Main Gallery in UST honored Cristobal with an exhibit, Bonifacio Cristobal: An Artist and Pioneer Thomasian Educator, to coincide with the book launch of Anatomical Notions for Art Students, authored by Cristobal. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

 

 

Sources

 

Bonifacio Cristobal. 2016. Blog. Accessed 28 Apr. https://bonifaciocristobal.wordpress.com/.

de la Paz, Christiane L. 2012. “Bonifacio Nicolas Cristobal: Rediscovering a Forgotten Great.” Artes de las Filipinas. Accessed 28 Apr 2016. http://www.artesdelasfilipinas.com/archives/132/bonifacio-nicolas-cristobal-rediscovering-a-forgotten-great.

CRUZ, EMILIO AGUILAR (Emilio Aguilar Cruz) aka Abe Cruz was a painter, fictionist, and essayist. He was born in Magalang, Pampanga on 5 Jun 1915. He died in Manila on 19 Dec 1991. He is the son of Apolonio Cruz and Ciriaca Aguilar. His family moved to San Fernando where he received his first lessons in drawing and music. He later studied for one year, 1930-31, at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts. He was influenced by Fabian de la Rosa, particularly with respect to impromptu landscape painting. In 1968, he co-founded the Dimasalang Group of artists with Sofronio Y. Mendoza aka SYM, Ibarra de la Rosa, Romulo Galicano, and Andres Cristobal Cruz. Aside from landscapes, he also did portraits and genres in realist, impressionist, and expressionist styles in oil, pastel, and watercolor.

Cruz also had literary inclinations. He joined literary circles and frequented the UP campus on Padre Faura. He published his first short story in the Graphic around 1931, after which he was invited to join its staff, becoming associate editor before the outbreak of World War II. During the war, he joined the guerrilla ranks while he worked as translator for Liwayway magazine under the supervision of Japanese censors. His short story “Paghihintay” (Waiting) was chosen as one of the best short stories of 1943. In 1946, he resumed newspaper work at the Tribune, which became the postwar Times. In 1949, he helped to establish the Daily Mirror. Aside from writing, he did editorial cartoons. He and Salvador Cabrera, jointly signed as Kabiting, did the comic strip Bindoy for the Times. When he became editor-in-chief of the Daily Mirror in 1968, he was able to give more time to painting.

From 1978 to 1981, he was permanent Philippine representative to UNESCO in Paris where he subsequently published a compilation of his writings, Maynila and Other Explorations, 1978. He also translated works from French to English for the National Historical Institute, among them Paul de la Gironiere’s Journey to Majayjay, 1983, and Duc D’Alencon’s Luzon and Mindanao, 1986. In 2006, his son Larry Cruz published Abe: A Frank Sketch of E. Aguilar Cruz, Writer, Artist, Bon Vivant, authored by Nick Joaquin. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

CRUZ, MARIA (Maria Ferreras Cruz) is a painter, intermedia artist, and educator. She was born in Manila on 24 Jan 1957. She is the daughter of Pablo S. Cruz and Maria Brousseau Ferreras. She graduated with a bachelor of arts (BA) in visual arts at the Sydney College of Arts in 1983. She took up postgraduate studies in the same university in 1984, and proceeded to Kunstakademie Düsseldorf, Germany, where she was a student in the class of Professor Klaus Rinke. In 1999, she finished her masters in visual arts at Sydney College of Arts, University of Sydney. Cruz was lecturer at the Canberra Institute of Arts, Australian National University; and at the Sydney College of Arts, University of Sydney, from 1990 to 1999. The following year, she was appointed senior lecturer at the School of Contemporary Arts, University of Western Sydney, where she taught for eight years. She lives and works in Manila and Berlin.

The majority of Cruz’s paintings feature elements of abstraction with strong conceptual tendencies. Process figures importantly in her practice. She has produced numerous text-based paintings employing hard-edged typography set against a solid background. Such works are influenced by the conceptual tradition of prompting the viewer to read words, exposing the structures of language and painting in the process. Appearing either as deliberately ambiguous or provocative, Cruz’s text-based art plays on references to popular culture, as exemplified in her works for Psychology Today, 2014, Cultural Center of the Philippines, which excerpted advertorial texts from a 1971 issue of Esquire Magazine; You Have Every Right, 2013, Ateneo Art Gallery, Manila, which gathered statements from Celso Ad. Castillo’s 1970s sex film Nympha; and No No No, 2004, Penrith Regional Gallery, New South Wales, Australia, which was based on the discography of Yoko Ono. The latter is part of a project the artist began in 1998.

Described as “visually eclectic” (Ewington 1993), Cruz’s paintings are a result of using varying techniques, from realistic portraits to the expressive splashing of colors and painting without a brush. The artist’s calculated selection of painting method is shaped by particular frameworks, stories, and other information. In the exhibition Painting Rituals, Ritual Paintings, 2012, Galleria Duemila, Manila, the artist rendered patterns formed by organizing the basic elements of line, shape, and color akin to those found in ritual objects such as masks and textiles. As the title suggests, the artist draws attention to the act of painting as habit-forming. Another work that adheres to the process as content is One Million Dollars, 2006, Art Space Sydney, Australia, which oscillated from performance to painting and installation. The multitude of spherical forms stamped on to the spacious wall of the gallery evokes traces of coins or dollars. Cruz’s work is a poignant reflection on the interplay of product, value, and labor, and the latter’s obscurity in an imbalanced system of relations. Earlier works in this series are smaller in scale, including Cruz’s Palette with Coins, 2002, Sarah Cottier Gallery, Australia, and Coins, 2005, Kaliman Gallery.

As an artist almost always formulaically positioned within the Filipino diaspora, Cruz’s work often poses unsettling questions to those encountering it. Among recent showings in this vein was her 2010 association with the loose grouping of artists called the Bastards of Misrepresentation in the Freies Museum, Berlin exhibition, Doing Time on Filipino Time. In 2003, she co-founded the Shangri-La Collective, a gathering of female artists for an exhibition of music videos that imagines a “temporary utopia.”

Cruz received various international grants and residencies including those from the University of Woolongong, Faculty of Creative Arts: The Visual Arts and Crafts Funds Arts Council of Australia; Karl Hoffer Gesselschaft, International Studio, Berlin; Asialink; the PS1 International Studio Program, New York Artist Development Grant; and the Australia Arts Council City of Hobart Contemporary Art Prize. Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

 

 

Sources

Asia Art Archive. 2015b. “Shangri-la Collective: A Maria Cruz Project.” Accessed 25 Jan. http://www.aaa.org.hk/WorldEvents/Details/610.

Cruz, Maria. 2013. Curriculum vitae. Nov.

Ewington, Julie. 1993. “Splash Art: Julie Ewington Interviews the Australian-Filipina Artist Maria Cruz.” Art and Asia Pacific Quarterly Journal 1 (1).

CRUZ, MARINA (Marina Rubio Cruz) aka Tun Cruz is a visual artist. She was born in Hagonoy, Bulacan on 3 Mar 1982. She is the daughter of Nicomedes Manansala Cruz and Elisa Domingo Rubio. She is married to fellow visual artist Rodel Tapaya. Cruz graduated with honors from the University of the Philippines Diliman College of Fine Arts in 2003.

Objects and history are tightly entwined in Marina Cruz’s art. Her realist paintings of the trove of dresses from women relatives, flower arrangements from domestic settings, and rooms from her childhood home convey her sensitive understanding of how image and form are able to relay and transform personal history. She weaves a network of life histories through paintings of dresses worn by her mother and aunt who are twins, presenting them through paintings filled with delicate details. Cruz paints creases and folds, torn seams, and faded cloth alongside fine spun embroidery, intricate textile patterns, and dress silhouettes. Through these forms, she crafts stories of resilience and strength. Aged clothing breathes new life in her 2008 exhibition Un/Fold at the Ateneo Art Gallery. She enlivens dress through images, stories, and words. Encased in laminated frames, depicted in realist paintings, shown inside cabinets, the dresses are transformed into objects that speak through vision, touch, and smell. Through the life stories of her mother and aunt, Cruz creates a chain of connections between past and present.

The details of her pieces engage and suffuse us, yet she is able to simultaneously create distance and nearness in the way she renders objects as vessels of meaning. Her exhibitions combine two-dimensional pieces, installation works, and sculptures. Cruz assembles an archive of forms, tracing personal memory through art that is engaging, brimming with meaning, and indelibly current. Referencing objects from the past and imbuing them with life through her art makes Cruz’s versions of history immediate and palpably contemporary. The exhibit Flower Arrangements, 2013, at Finale Art File illustrates how the everyday is contained in the most mundane of forms: tattered dresses, faded blooms, and shrivelled petals. In this solo show, Cruz assembled a garden of budding forms, cast in resin from the petticoats of dresses that once belonged to her mother and aunt.

Cruz has done solo exhibitions in the Philippines, Taiwan, China, Australia, and Singapore. She participated in group exhibitions including Sungdu-an 4: Extensions, Cagayan de Oro, 2007; 2nd Dumaguete Terracotta Biennale, 2007; and babaylan@kasibulan.net, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 2004. Her works have also been shown in international art fairs including Art Stage Singapore, 2008 and 2013; Beijing Art Fair, 2008; and Hong Kong International Art Fair, 2008.

She received the Ateneo Art Award in 2008 together with a residency at La Trobe University’s Visual Art Center. She was also awarded the Freeman Foundation fellowship at Vermont Studio Center, 2008. She won the grand prize at the Philippine Art Awards in 2007, and received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2012.   Written by Tessa Maria T. Guazon

 

 

Sources

Finale Art File. 2014a. “Marina Cruz Flower Arrangements.” Accessed 20 Jun. http://finaleartfile.com/wpsite/marinacruz-flower-arrangements/.

CRUZ, MIDEO (Mideo Manalad Cruz) b. Cabanatuan, Nueva Ecija 8 Aug 1973. Cross-disciplinary artist. He is the son of Leonicio F. Cruz and Carmen P. Manalad. He is married to the performance artist Raquel de Loyola. Cruz earned his bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, from the University of Santo Tomas (UST), 1995. As a student activist and artist, Cruz was a member of UGATLahi and Kulay Kabataan. It was during this period when his practice acquired a didactic strain of aesthetics running parallel to the discourse of the political left. Cruz specifically took the route of exploring alternative forms such as performance art and effigy making.

His background in activism would later manifest in his works, particularly in performance art pieces, installation, and other cross-disciplinary work. Though he is an active participant in the art gallery circuit, Cruz still explores alternative modes of art circulation that do not necessarily involve object-creation. He specifically draws upon notions of trauma and multi-sensorial engagements in his artistic and discursive production. He uses found objects from his immediate environment and employs these as he attempts to intervene and engage with his public.

Cruz became embroiled in media controversy in 2011 because of his installation Poleteismo. It was exhibited in the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) as part of Kulo, an exhibition commemorating Jose Rizal’s 150th birth anniversary and the 400th anniversary of UST. The installation, which dealt with social, political, and religious imagery, initially captured the attention of broadcast media and was repeatedly invoked in undercontextualized accounts in both mass and social media. The controversy led to the premature closure of the exhibition, a senatorial inquiry, and the filing of criminal and administrative cases against the artist, curators, and the CCP. The Office of the Ombudsman eventually dismissed the criminal and administrative cases in 2013.

His notable works include Banquet, 2006, and The Great American Experience Series, 2009. Banquet was first performed in the CCP’s Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo and was later re-performed in Singapore, 2006, and Switzerland, 2008. The Great American Experience Series was a performance-installation done at Lunduyan Gallery, Quezon City; Williamsburg, New York; and Brooklyn, New York. Cruz has had several solo exhibitions including Everything Must Go, 2009, Edge Zones, Miami; Into the Wild, 2010, Utterly Art Gallery, Singapore; Divinities, 2011, Modejar Gallery, Zurich; Spectacle of Excess, Bliss on Bliss, New York, 2013; and Geographical Sketches, Kanto Artist-Run Gallery, 2014.

Cruz participated in the Sungdu-an 3: Making the Local, a national touring exhibition of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2003. He participated in several group exhibitions and art events in the United States, Myanmar, China, Singapore, France, Canada, Italy, Japan, Malaysia, Taiwan, Thailand, Germany, Indonesia, and Korea. He was awarded the Dawang Artist Residency in Shenzen, China, 2012, and residencies at Headlands Center for the Arts, San Francisco, USA, 2008; Gallery Gachet Vancouver, Canada, 2007; and Modern Fuel Artist Run Centre, Ontario, Canada, 2004. Cruz was also a fellow of the Asian Cultural Council, New York, USA, 2008 and 2009.

Cruz runs Bangan Art Space in Gapan, Nueva Ecija, as an initiative to provide space for artistic training, exploration, and eventual exhibition. He is also a creative consultant for Kanto Artist-Run Space. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2003 and the Ateneo Art Award in 2006.Written by Maria Portia Olenka Placino

CUIZON, NOEL (Noel Soler Cuizon) aka Nuqui. b. Manila 3 Jan 1962. Visual artist, performance artist, curator. He is the son of Antonio Aquino Cuizon and Barbara Fajardo Soler. He is the nephew of visual artist Brenda Fajardo. Cuizon received his bachelor of fine arts degree, major in painting, in 1987 and master of fine arts degree in 2013, both from the Philippine Women’s University. Cuizon is program coordinator of the university’s School of Fine Arts and Design Painting and gallery curator. He became treasurer of the Board of Directors of Filipino Visual Arts and Design Rights Organization in 2011, creative director of slash/art artist initiative in 2006, and resident curator of Nineveh Art Space in Laguna in 2004. He was also a faculty member of Asia Pacific College, 2006-11, an art instructor in Escuela sa Museo of Ayala Museum, 1996-98, and production design assistant at the Philippine Educational Theater Association, 1991-93. Cuizon has been actively organizing workshops, informal education, and talks with professional and nonprofessional artists, and pursuing collaborative projects under various artists’ collective initiatives.

The search for identity and a need to adopt an objective vista of his country and people foreground Cuizon’s overriding philosophy about art. Most of his art pieces transcend the usual two-dimensional depiction of meanings and understanding of visual elements. Often employing dual-tone sepia assemblage of objects and acrylic on canvas, Cuizon is inclined toward creating a feeling of embedded depth upon his painting surface. Themes related to personal struggle, social alienation, and identity politics recur in most works. Reflections about colonization of the Philippines as seen in different levels of divergent cultures resound in his portraits. His subjects range from men and women of different social classes to famous figures in politics and media. The play of objects and baybayin texts in his works offers up the artist’s distinct temperament. Cuizon’s sense of nationalism is expressed in the use of symbols and in the motifs of varied folk-religious and ethnolinguistic groups.

Cuizon had his first solo exhibition, Hugot-Bunot sa Mayo Onse (Draw and Pick on May 11), 1992, at the Hiraya Gallery, followed by Hugot-Bunot, Kinapos (Draw and Pick, Fall Short) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in the same year. He has had nine solo exhibitions and has shown in group exhibitions in Hong Kong, Australia, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, and Brunei Darussalam. Cuizon’s works belong to the collections of different institutions in the Philippines, Malaysia, and Singapore.

Since 1987, Cuizon has been actively participating in various expositions locally and internationally. He represented the Philippines in the 3rd ASEAN Travelling Exhibition, 1993; the Quinta Bienal de la Habana in Havana, Cuba; and the 4th Asian Art Show in Fukuoka, Japan, 1994. Cuizon won an honorable mention at the 2nd Biennial of Arts in Makurazaki City, Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan, in 1991 and the Mention du Jury at the 26th Festival International de la Peinture, Chateau Musee de Cagnes-sur-mer in France. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1994 and was a fellow of the Asian Cultural Council in 1998-99. Written by Manuel Agustin Singson

Sources:

Cuizon 2014a, 2014b; Sy 2005; Valenzuela 2014.

CULTURAL CENTER OF THE PHILIPPINES (CCP) The CCP is the leading institution in the country that plans and implements programs for the development and promotion of the arts—music, dance, theater, visual, literary, cinematic, and broadcast arts. Since 1969 when it was created by Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, it has sponsored programs and activities such as festivals, exhibitions, competitions, and publications to preserve, promote, and enhance the artistic and cultural heritage of the Filipino people, and to develop audiences that will appreciate and support artistic and cultural work. It is home to nine resident companies that present regular seasons of productions, workshops, and outreach performances: Ballet Philippines , Bayanihan Philippine NationalFolkDance Company, Philippine Ballet Theatre, Philippine Madrigal Singers, Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Tanghalang Pilipino, and UST Symphony Orchestra.

Sitting on a 60-hectare complex on Roxas Boulevard in Pasay City, the CCP is part of a vast international network of arts and culture organizations that provide exchange opportunities between Filipino artists and artists from all over the world. This network also brings in performances and exhibitions that allow local audiences to experience arts and cultures from elsewhere. These organizations include the Association of Asia Pacific Performing Arts Center, the Conseil International des Organisations de Festivals de Folklore et d’Arts Traditionnels, the World Dance Alliance, the International Theater Institute, the Asian Theater Alliance, the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information, and the ASEAN–Korea Traditional Music Orchestra.

The CCP is composed of several departments that promote arts education, direct outreach and exchange programs all over the country, mount productions and exhibitions, manage cultural holdings, and develop its assets. In its first two decades the CCP focused on what were later perceived as elitist performing arts—theater, ballet, opera, and similar shows—a bias that was shaped by its first board of trustees chair, then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos. Following the successful EDSA revolt against Marcos and his martial rule and the subsequent change in the country’s leadership, the CCP expanded its scope to include literature, film, and broadcast arts, among others. It also reoriented its direction to emphasize original Filipino artistic and cultural expressions rooted in the Philippines and the participation of the regions in the definition of a national culture.

Music. The CCP is home to the country’s premier symphonic orchestra, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO). Established in 1973, the PPO (then known as the CCP Philharmonic Orchestra) initially accompanied local and foreign performing artists at the CCP. It later evolved as one of the best music ensembles in the Asia-Pacific region, premiering works by Filipino and foreign composers, and promoting music appreciation throughout the country. Past conductors and musical directors of the PPO include Luis Valencia, Oscar Yatco, Ruggero Barbieri, Olivier Ochanine, and Yoshikazu Fukumura.Among the internationally renowned conductors who have performed with the PPO are Mendi Rodan, Piero Gamba, Enrique Batis, Sebastian Bereau, and Nicholas Koch. Some of the world’s best Filipino and foreign artists have also performed with the PPO, including Van Cliburn, Renata Tebaldi, Judith Engel, Anthony Camden, David Benoit, Cecile Licad, Raul Sunico, and Lea Salonga . The PPO is now on its 34th concert season. It has toured in Europe, Asia, and more recently, the United States, when it performed for the first time at the Carnegie Hall. Aside from its regular concert seasons at the CCP, the PPO also participates in the CCP Outreach Program by performing in public spaces and conducting workshops in the provinces.

Another resident company of the CCP is the Philippine Madrigal Singers. Organized in 1963 by Andrea O. Veneracion, later National Artist for music, the choir is composed of students, teachers, and alumni from the various colleges of the University of the Philippines. Performing a wide repertoire of various styles and forms, the ensemble has consistently won all the top prizes in most of the world’s prestigious choral competitions. The choir also maintains an active outreach and concert schedule every year and is regarded as one of the country’s most active ambassadors of goodwill and one of the world’s most traveled choirs.

The UST Symphony Orchestra is also a resident performing group of the CCP. It holds regular concerts at the CCP and participates in the CCP Outreach and Exchange Program. It also serves as a pool for additional players as the needs of the PPO dictate.

In 1987, the CCP launched the Filipino Artists Series (FAS), a monthly program featuring solo performances of acclaimed and emerging Filipino musical artists. Among those featured in the FAS were bass baritone Jonathan Zaens; flutist Antonio Maigue; cellist Wilfredo Pasamba; pianists Corazon Kabayao, Mariel Illusorio, Peter Porticos, and Rene Dalandan; violinists Gilopez Kabayao , Gina Medina, and Denise Huang; and sopranos Clarissa Ocampo and Maria Cristina Viguilla-Navarro. FAS was discontinued in 2009 but was later revived in 2012 as the Special Concert Series. Some of the performing artists in this series are pianist Charisse Baldoria, soprano Katrina Saporsantos, cellist Antoni Josef Inacay, trumpet player Raymond de Leon, percussionist Aimee Mina dela Cruz, and flutist Sarah Mae Gabuyo.

The CCP also embarked on the production of Filipino operas as well as Western operas that were adapted to a Philippine setting. In 1970, it partnered with the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines in producing El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the operatic adaptation of Jose Rizal ’s novel, with music by Felipe Padilla de Leon and libretto by Guillermo Tolentino. De Leon and Tolentino’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), first staged at the FEU Auditorium in 1957, was also restaged at the CCP in 1974, with Don David as Ibarra, Ruby Salazar as Maria Clara, Jimmy Melendres as Padre Damaso, and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa. In 1984, the CCP and Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines commissioned Francisco Feliciano to create the three-act opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf), with libretto by Cuyugan-Asensio. In 1987, the CCP partnered with Music Theater Foundation in another restaging of Noli… this time with Nolyn Cabahug as Ibarra, Andion Fernandez as Maria Clara, and Cuyugan-Asensio as Sisa (alternating with Luz Morete). Rolando Tinio’s Philippine adaptation of La Traviata and La Boheme were also produced by and staged at the CCP in 1991 and 1992, respectively. Two major opera productions of the CCP in the 21st century were Spoliarium , 2003, and Madame Butterfly, 2012. Spoliarium was inspired by Juan Luna ’s life and masterpiece, with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, and co-produced by the CCP with the Opera Guild of the Philippines and Music Theater Foundation of the Philippines. Madame Butterfly was a co-production of the CCP and MusicArtes, Inc, with director Anton Juan giving local flavor to Puccini’s famous opera.

The CCP is also the organizer and main proponent of major music festivals including the biennial Andrea Veneracion International Choral Festival and the CCP International Jazz Festival which was merged with the Orchestra and Symphonic Band Festival, and the annual Flute/Woodwind Festival. It has also been actively supporting the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) since its inception in 1973. The CCP Arts Education Department also organizes masterclasses of renowned musical artists as well as yearly workshops in rondalla music, choral music, and band music.

Dance. The CCP has four resident dance companies: Ballet Philippines (BP), which is based at the CCP Main Building, and Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFC) which are all based outside the CCP.

Since its founding in 1969, BP has performed over 400 works at the CCP, ranging from full-length classical ballets to modern dance and neo-ethnic pieces, under its founding artistic director Alice Reyes, later National Artist for Dance, and after her, Denisa Reyes, Cecile Sicangco , Noordin Jumalon , Alden Lugnasin, Augustus Damian III, Alan Hineline, Max Luna III, and Paul Moral es . The company has also collaborated with prominent foreign and local choreographers, dancers, librettists, actors, and set, costume, and lighting designers. Notable productions of BP include Amada, Itim Asu (The Onyx Wolf), Rama, Hari, Tales of the Manuvu, Te Deum, For the Gods, Encantada (Enchantress), and La Revolucion Filipina (The Filipino Revolution). It has also produced some of the country’s top ballet dancers who have undergone training at BP’s official school, the CCP Dance School. BP also stages the yearly Neo-Filipino, a dance showcase featuring the latest works of the best and leading choreographers in the country.

Founded in 1987 by artistic directors of different ballet companies, PBT has become one of the country’s leading dance companies specializing in classical ballet. PBT’s regular performance season at the CCP consists of such classics as Romeo and Juliet , Carmen, The N utcracker, Cinderella, Carmina Burana, and Swan Lake. PBT has been managed by a series of artistic directors, all belonging to the PBT Council, namely, Inday Gaston-Mañosa, Julie Borromeo, Eddie Elejar, Gener Caringal, and Ronilo Jaynario.

The Bayanihan, under choreographer Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, later National Artist for Dance, and later, under executive director Susie Benitez and dance director-choreographer Ferdinand Jose, and the ROFG under artistic director Ramon Obusan, later National Artist for dance, and later, under Dulce Obusan, have been acclaimed nationally and worldwide for their continuing efforts to research, perform, preserve, and perpetuate Philippine folk music and dance traditions. Both companies participate in CCP’s outreach programs by conducting folk dance workshops around the country.

Dance-related festivals organized or initiated by the CCP include the Pang-alay, which featured different Philippine folk dance groups; the Fiesta Folkloriada, an annual festival of folk dance groups all over the world where the Bayanihan is an active participant; the biennial CCP Ballet Festival where various ballet schools in the country gather and perform classical, modern, and neo-ethnic works; and Dance.MNL: The Philippine Dance Festival which was held for the first time in 2016. Dance.MNL is also intended to be a biennial festival which aims to unite and celebrate the Filipino dance community.

The CCP has also given grants or financial assistance to local dance groups which represented the Philippines in international competitions or festivals.
