Among the grantees were the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Dureza Ballet School, Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance, and St Anne’s Dance and Music Studio in 1988; Dance TheaterPhilippines, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, St Anne Dance Theater Company (Taguig), La Salle Dance Troupe, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Odon Sabarre and the People’s Center School of Dance, and Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center in 1989; Dance Concert Company and Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance in 1990; and Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement, Chameleon Dance Company, Araullo University Dance Troupe, and Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe in 1991.

In 2014, the CCP launched its first ever Ballet Competition held at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino. The biennial competition has a Junior and Senior category and requires contestants to perform both classical and contemporary pieces.

Theater. The CCP, in partnership with the NCCA, has organized the National Theater Festival (NTF), a quinquennial event that gathers theater artists, practitioners, scholars, and enthusiasts from all over the country in a 10-day celebration of the latest achievements in Philippine theater. The NTF, which started in 1992 and was last held in 2012, usually includes performances from various theater groups, a conference, exhibits, and film screenings.

During the first NTF, production and festival grants, as well as six workshop and one research grant, were given to the nine participating regional theater groups. These are Adela Community Organization of Silay City, Negros Occidental; the Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc.-UHAY of Malolos, Bulacan; Cebu Central Colleges Theater Workshop Company and University of San Carlos Theater Guild of Cebu City; Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company of Iloilo City; Komedya ng San Dionisio of Paranaque; Kulturang Atin Foundation Inc., and Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao City; and the Salidummay Music Theater Company and Tadec Group of Baguio City. Production grants were also given to seven Metro Manila-based groups, namely Bulwagang Gantimpala, Dulaang UP, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, and Tanghalang Pilipino. Many other groups have availed of these grants in subsequent CCP National Theater Festivals.

The CCP has also supported theater groups outside Metro Manila through its Outreach and Exchange Unit. It provided financial assistance to deserving applicants for the touring of produced local productions to different sites within the region. Theater companies that received touring grants are: in 1988, the Dula Agus Ensemble of Butuan City, Salidummay of the Cordillera, and Teatro Amakan of Iloilo; in 1989, the Sining Pananadem in Marawi City, Dance Theater of Tacloban City, and Susi ng Tayabas in Quezon; in 1991, Pantanghalang Sining ng Laguna and the Adela Community Organization from Silay City, Negros Occidental; in 1992, Sining Kambayoka Ensemble of the Mindanao State University and the Kaliwat Theater Collective of Davao; in 2014, the community-based theater guild in Sorsogon, Teatro Ambahanon and Kabpapagariya Ensemble of General Santos City, the Youth Advocates thru Theater Arts in Dumaguete City, the Integrated Performing Arts Guild in Iligan City, and the Sining Kambayoka Ensemble in Marawi City; and in 2015, Barasoain Kalinangan Foundation Inc. of Malolos City, Artista Sillimania of Dumaguete City, Kuntaw Mindanao of Davao del Norte, and Kaliwat Performing Arts Collective of Davao City. Meanwhile, production venue and full grants were given to Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, UP Playwrights Theater, Telon, Sining Silangan, Philippine Drama Company, UP Repertory Company, Teatro Santa Ana, and Teatro Umalohokan.

In 1994, the CCP Coordinating Center for Dramatic Arts awarded playwriting fellowships to four writers, giving them cash grants to develop their full-length plays. The fellows chosen were JB Capino for his play Los Indios Bravos (The Brave Natives), Dennis Marasigan for Aves de Rapina (Birds of Prey), V. E. Carmelo Nadera for Hermano Puli, and Bebot Rodil for Datu Matu.

Prior to its reorganization after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the CCP was the home of two local theater companies: Teatro Pilipino, under artistic director Rolando Tinio, and Bulwagang Gantimpala Theater, under artistic director Tony Espejo. Teatro Pilipino, the first resident theater company of the CCP from 1976-86, staged Filipino translations of plays by William Shakespeare, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, August Strindberg, and Tennessee Williams, as well as a few Filipino works like Francisco Baltazar ’s Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Bienvenido M. Noriega ’s Bayan-bayanan (Little Country), and Tinio’s May Katwiran ang Katwiran (Reason Has Its Reason).

Bulwagang Gantimpala started out as the production arm of the winning works from the CCP Literary and Playwriting Contest. It staged original Filipino works like Jomar Fleras ’s adaptation of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, titled Kanser (Cancer), Bonifacio Ilagan ’s Katipunan: Mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan: Children of the People), Rene O. Villanueva ’s Hiblang Abo (Strands of Gray), and Noriega’s Bongbong at Kris (Bongbong and Kris). In 1987, it became an independent theater company and has since moved its office elsewhere.

Tanghalang Pilipino (TP) is now the resident drama company of the CCP. Established in 1987, TP has staged more than 150 productions and is now on its 30th season. Its founding artistic director was Nonon Padilla who directed the company for 17 years until he was replaced by Herbie Go, Dennis Marasigan, and Nanding Josef. Its repertoire consists of original works by Filipino playwrights, restagings of Filipino sarsuwela, and translations and adaptations of foreign plays. TP maintains a stable of professional actors known as the Tanghalang Pilipino Actors’ Company. The company regularly conducts acting workshops and has also toured some of its productions in various provinces.

TP has also partnered with the CCP, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and the Writer’s Bloc, Inc. in producing the highly successful Virgin Labfest , a laboratory festival of new, unproduced, and untested one-act plays by amateur and veteran playwrights. This yearly project which started in 2005 has now become one of the most anticipated theater events in the country and has also produced a canon of acclaimed works.

In 2011, the CCP and the NCCA organized the first Monodrama Festival, a four-day event featuring monologues and one-actor performances. In 2013, the CCP produced Triple Threats, a series of concerts featuring the stalwarts of Philippine musical theater. Among the artists who have performed for this series are Nonie Buencamino, Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, Audie Gemora, and Bituin Escalante. The series has also featured composers Rony Fortich and Vincent de Jesus in 2015 and ensemble players in 2016.

Visual Arts. The CCP through its Visual Arts and Museum Division (VAMD) implements and manages the year-round contemporary art, design, and festival-related exhibitions at the various venues at the CCP. These exhibitions provide a showcase for current directions, trends, and movements in Philippine contemporary art, including the fields of architecture, sculpture, photography, digital art, and the allied arts. Aside from managing exhibit venues, providing curatorial assistance, and organizing forums, lectures, and talkback sessions with artists and designers, the VAMD also coordinates with the visual arts community on the activities and concerns of the visual artists all over the country.

The VAMD has organized and presented exhibits featuring artworks of notable Filipino artists among them: Fernando Amorsolo, Victorio Edades, Carlos V. Francisco, Cesar Legaspi, H. R. Ocampo, Vicente Manansala, Fernando Zobel, Lee Aguinaldo, Constancio Bernardo, Jose Joya, Napoleon Abueva, Roberto Chabet, Arturo Luz, Rodolfo Paras-Perez, Ang Kiukok, Justiniano Nuyda, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Romulo Olazo, Ray Albano, Nonon Padilla, Prudencio Lamarroza, Impy Pilapil, Ileana Lee, Danilo Dalena, Onib Olmedo, Jaime de Guzman, Julie Lluch, Solomon Saprid, Ben Maramag, Bencab, Tony Velasquez, Mars Ravelo, Francisco Coching, Roberto Feleo, Kidlat Tahimik, Mark Justiniani, Karen Flores , Claude Tayag, and Agnes Arellano. The VAMD has also presented exhibits of artists’ groups such as the Social Realists, Kasibulan Women Artists, Paete artists, Black Artists of Asia, Abstract Expressionists, Figurative Expressionists, Mabini Art Movement, Salingpusa, Baguio Arts Guild, VIVA Excon, and artists from various schools like the University of the Philippines, University of Santo Tomas, and the Philippine High School for the Arts.

The VAMD also gives recognition to Filipino artists through the 13 Artists Awards. Started by former CCP museum director Roberto Chabet in 1970, the 13 Artists Awards later became a biennial award under the management of Ray Albano, and a triennial award in 2009. The award is given to artists who take “the chance and risk to restructure, restrengthen, and renew art making and art thinking.” Since 2009, the recognition has been given to more than 170 artists in the fields of painting, sculpture, mixed and multi-media, and installation art. The most recent awarding was held in 2018 and the recipients were Zeus Bascon, Bea Camacho, Cian Dayrit, Janos Dela Cruz, Carlo Gabuco, Dina Gadia, Guerrero Habulan, Eisa Jocson, Doktor Karayom, Raffy Napay, Archie Oclos, Lynyrd Paras, and Shireen Seno. The awarding usually coincides with a month-long exhibition of the awardees’ works.

Literature. The Literary Arts division of the CCP, now known as the Intertextual Division (ID), undertakes activities that deal with literary text, performance text, and hypertext. Among its accomplishments is the publication of ANI (Harvest), a literary journal which is now on its 39th edition. The journal features short stories, essays, and poems in Filipino, English, and other Philippine languages. It also took care of other CCP special publications like Himala y Balagtas and Himalay Rizal.

In previous years, the CCP sponsored literary contests and awarded writing grants to writers in Filipino, English, and the major regional languages. It began sponsoring a playwriting contest in 1969 in both English and Filipino. The first winners of the CCP Playwriting Contest were: In Frailty’s Grace by Elsa V. Martinez, first prize; And the Day But One by Jose Ma. Hernandez, second; and The Onyx Wolf by Virginia Moreno, third; Tabak at Tanikala (Bolo and Chain) by Dionisio S. Salazar; Status Quo by Angel R. Makiling, and Halik sa Kampilan (Kiss the Sword) by Cipriano V. Ilagan, honorable mention.

A verse writing category was added in 1973. The first winners in the English division were Artemio Tadena for “The Bloodied Envelope,” first prize; Gemino Abad for “In Another Light,” second prize; and Federico Licsi Espino for “Scope of Movement,” third prize. The poets given honorable mention in the English division were Alfrredo Navarro Salanga for “Twelve,” Jolico Cuadra for “The Possibilitation Poems,” and Simeon Dumdum Jr for “Rainy Day.” In the Filipino division, the first winners were Teo Antonio for “Pilipino sa Isang Lawa ng Chicago” (A Filipino by the Lakeside in Chicago), first prize; Vict. V. de la Cruz for “Isang Pag-aalay sa Sining, sa Bayan, sa Bathala” (An Offering to Art, to Country, and to God), second prize; and Victor S. Fernandez for “Mga Bulaklak sa Parnaso” (Flowers on Parnasus), third prize. Given honorable mention were Gonzalo K. Flores for “Bahay sa Looban” (A House in the Interior), Eduardo P. Garrovillas for “Ang Bagong Pilipino” (The New Filipino), and Virgilio S. Almario for “Doktrinang Anakpawis” (Doctrine of the Laborer).

The following categories were added in 1974: epic narrative, won by Luwalhati C. Marquez for “Balante”; short story, won by Reynaldo Duque for “Bagani Ubbong at Iba Pang Kuwento” (Bagani Ubbong and Other Stories); novel, won by Benjamin P. Pascual for “Utos ng Hari” (King’s Command); essay, won by Pablo R. Glorioso for “Pamana ng Panitik at Iba Pang Sanaysay” (Legacy of Letters and Other Essays) and Virgilio S. Almario for “Ang Makata sa Panahon ng Makina” (The Poet in the Machine Age). A biography category was added in 1979. Honorable mention was given to Lydia Ingle for “Edades: Kites and Visions,” 1980 in the English division and to Lamberto Ma. Gabriel for “Padre Gregorio L. Crisostomo, Ulirang Pilipino” (Father Gregorio L. Crisostomo, a Model Filipino), Filipino division. Hernando J. Abaya won the grand prize when the award for the category was resumed in 1984 for “The Making of a Subversive.”

The novel category was also instituted in 1979. The first co-winners in the English division were F. Sionil Jose for Tree and Edith Tiempo for His Native Coast. In the Filipino division, the prize went to Dominador B. Mirasol for Ginto ang Kayumangging Lupa (Gold is the Brown Earth).

A new category—criticism—was added in 1984. In the English division, an Appreciation Award was shared among Nick Nicolas Jr for “Theater, Films and Others: A Compendium of Critical Reviews,” Wilhelmina Q. Ramas for “Sugbuanon Theater: From Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar,” and Soledad S. Reyes for “Criticism and Ideology.” In the Filipino division, the grand prize in criticism was given to Virgilio S. Almario for “Taludtod at Talinghaga: Mga Sangkap ng Katutubong Pagtula” (Verses and Metaphor: The Elements of Folk Poetry).

In 1987, the annual literary contest was transformed into the Gawad CCP Para sa Panatikan under the supervision of the CCP’s Coordinating Center for Literature. The contest dropped the English category in favor of an all-Filipino rule. The categories were poetry, short story, one-act play, three-act play, dance libretto (one-act dance drama), and the full-length musical drama.

The winners in the poetry category that year were Fidel D. Rillo for “Musa Insurekta” (Insurgent Muse), first prize; Teo Antonio for “Cespora Personata at Iba Pang Pagbubulay-bulay” (Cespora Personata and Other Ruminations), second prize; and Danton Remoto for “Kuwaderno” (Notebook), third prize. In the short story category, the winners were Reynaldo Duque for “Ang Gamugamo sa Lampara ni Julio Madarang” (The Firefly About Julio Madarang’s Lamp), first prize; Chit Balmaceda-Gutierrez for “Kulas,” second prize; and Tomas F. Agulto for “Ang Walang Lubay na Istasyon ng Pag-asa at Paghahanap” (The Eternal Station of Hope and Searching), third prize. The critical essay category on the different arts was instituted a year later.

The winning poems and stories in the Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan have also been published in ANI, while the critical works have appeared in Kultura, the CCP magazine for critical essays. The Gawad CCP Para sa Panitikan was discontinued in 1990.

The CCP has also given grants to writers who applied for writing grants for drama in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in Filipino or a regional language, or for criticism in the performing arts. Grantees in drama are Reynaldo Duque, 1988, and Jose A. Bragado, 1989, for Ilocano; Ruperto Alaura, 1988, RobertoVillanueva, 1989, and Leonilo Estimo, 1993, for Cebuano; Carlos Ojeda Aureus, 1992, for Bicolano; Julian Jagudilla, 1989 and 1990, andJose Galiza and Eugenio de Pablo, 1991, for Hiligaynon/Karay-a; and Rene O. Villanueva, 1988, and Ariel N. Valerio, 1993, for Filipino.

In 2015, the ID spearheaded the biennial event called Performatura 2015, Performing Literatures, a three-day intertextual festival held in various venues at the CCP. The event included conversations with National Artists; Chromatext Rebooted, an exhibit merging text and visual arts; performance poetry featuring young poets; and workshops on the poetic joust balagtasan, speech choir, and ventriloquism.

Film. The Media Arts Division is the main implementor of the CCP’s year-round film, broadcast, and emerging media events, which include screenings, productions, festivals, awards, workshops, and fora. It also coordinates with all sectors of the film community—both local and international, independent and mainstream, contemporary and classic.

In 1987, the CCP started to give recognition to Filipino alternative films and video. Known as the Gawad CCP Para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Bidyo or Gawad Alternatibo, this is considered the longest-running independent film competition of its kind in the Asian region. Gawad Alternatibo annually cites the best efforts of Pinoy filmmakers in four categories: Animation, Experimental, Documentary, and Short Feature. Each winner receives a cash prize and a certificate. Special citations are also awarded to the best work from the regions, as well as works on/for/by children. Many of today’s outstanding filmmakers and media practitioners are awardees of Gawad Alternatibo.

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival is one of the CCP’s most important cinema-related undertakings every year. Established in 2004, the festival has given birth to some of Philippine cinema’s contemporary masterpieces and is regarded as one of the most prestigious independent film competitions in the country, and a much awaited cultural event as well. Some of today’s acclaimed filmmakers have launched their careers via the annual festival and competition, including Kanakan Balintagos aka Aureaus Solito, Lawrence Fajardo, Chris Martinez, Jun Robles Lana, Alvin B. Yapan, Francis Pasion, and Eduardo Roy Jr. Simultaneous film-related events are also held during the festival, including the Cinemalaya Film Congress, a two-day conference that looks at all aspects of independent filmmaking and distribution; the Cinemalaya Sine Taktakan, a forum with the year’s batch of new Cinemalaya filmmakers; exhibitions that include Tributes to Past Indie Mavericks of Pinoy Cinema; a Cinemalaya Kids’ Treats; World Premieres of New Digital Works (the Cinemalaya/NETPAC Prize); and a host of other activities.

The CCP also holds annual film lectures and retrospectives on Filipino filmmakers and actors, like Gerardo de Leon, Manuel Conde, Lucia no B. Carlos , Mona Lisa, Jaclyn Jose, and Fernando Poe Jr, as well as foreign film artists like Akira Kurosawa, Isabelle Huppert, and Olivier Assayas.

Broadcast Arts. In recognition of the broad reach and powerful influence of radio and television, the CCP established in 1987 a Coordinating Center for Broadcast Arts which was one of the units of the then Visual, Literary, and Media Arts Department. While all these units have been replaced by the Media Arts Division, the CCP—then and now—has continued efforts to equip ordinary citizens with the skills to produce radio programs and videos that reflect their realities and that allow them to promote their sectoral interests through broadcasting. It conducts hands-on training-workshops on radio and television production and scriptwriting, accepts apprenticeships, and awards production grants. While bringing its training program to as far north as Batanes and as far south as Tawi-tawi, the CCP encourages the use of Filipino languages in the programs and videos produced by its trainees. Among those who complete the training programs and are given grants to produce their own radio programs are farmers, fisherfolk, social development and cultural workers, students, and local leaders who produce and host talk shows, historical documentaries, instructional programs, public service announcements, music shows, and dramatizations of Filipino myths and legends. Their productions are aired in cooperation with local radio stations.

The CCP produces television programs as well as videos. In 1990 it produced Pinoy Eh, a magazine show aired on ABC Channel 5. Directed by Marilou-Diaz-Abaya and hosted by Ces Quesada, it had 13 episodes on such topics as the Filipino language, music, cinema, architecture, literature, dance, rituals, ethnic groups, and places. Another television production is the 1992 13-episode drama series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) based on Jose Rizal’s novel, written and directed by National Artist for cinema Eddie Romero, starring Joel Torre and Chin-chin Gutierrez. The series is also available in DVD. The Red Carpet was a monthly program aired on Net 25 in 2009-12, featuring the shows at CCP and the cultural and artistic scene in the country. On Set, also on Net 25, 2009-12, highlighted the country’s top caliber artists such as Lea Salonga, Ryan Cayabyab, and Bienvenido Lumbera.

CCP is also on radio. Following the 1986 EDSA revolt, it produced the weekly radio magazine Kultura ng Bayan (Culture of the People), aired on DZRV in 1986-92, then on DZRM until 1996. It featured Filipino music and theater, talked about arts and culture in the Philippines, and held the balagtasan on current socio-political issues. Among CCP’s current radio programs is the weekly Culture Carousel, which has been airing on DZFE since 1990. It features CCP music artists as well as visiting music artists and airs their performances. Another production is DiskArte (Artistic Strategy) which discusses social issues using the arts. It airs on DZRH in partnership with the Manila Broadcasting Corporation (MBC). The program was formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon (Fight Corruption) which aired on DZRH in 2004-08 until it was reformatted. It was awarded The Freedom Project 2013 Jury Prize and the People’s Choice Award by The Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom of Germany. Another CCP radio production was the children’s show Wan Dey Isang Araw (One Day), aired on DZAS in 2005-13, which tried to revive the tradition of storytelling in the Philippines. It featured stories by Luis P. Gatmaitan, Eugene Evasco, Augie Rivera, and Grace Chong.

In 1987-98, the CCP gave out the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon (CCP Awards for Television), annually to outstanding television programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and other content producers. Among the awardees were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing For You) and Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music With Ryan), the drama series Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and Lovingly Yours, Helen, the children’s show Batibot (Small but Strong), the talk show Pep Talk, the public affairs programs Probe Team, Public Forum, and Viewpoint, and the gag show Sic O’Clock News. In 1990-1998, the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo (CCP Awards for Radio) was given at the same time as the television awards, to outstanding radio programs, producers, directors, scriptwriters, performers, and music and sound designers. The radio awards were henceforth given every two years. Among the awardees in 1990 were the documentary Parangal (Tribute), on DZRM; the drama series Drama Filipina on DZEC, the arts and culture show Filipiniana on DZLC in Lucena, the music magazine shows Yukbo sa Musika on DYMR and Salam in sa Kaliwat on DXWG, both in Cebu, and radio pioneer Francisco “Koko” Trinidad for his contribution to Philippine radio.

Other Programs. The CCP organizes various year-round arts-affiliated events, such as Pasinaya, the biggest multi-arts festival in the country. Started in 2010, Pasinaya is an annual one-day open-house festival which serves as a gathering of CCP resident companies, patrons, and the general public. Simultaneous events are held in all of CCP’s venues, with designated zones for dance, theater, music, literature, film, visual arts, children and family, variety, and the artists market. There are also crash workshops, film screenings, visual arts exhibitions, food booths, and activities for children. Some of the resident companies also perform excerpts from their upcoming shows or past productions.

Outreach and exchange programs include: KUTITAP: Isang Piging ng Kabataang Makasining, an annual three-day event for children and young people that started in 2009 and is aimed at raising their awareness of and appreciation for indigenous arts, culture, and traditions; Ugnayan sa Sining, an annual series of cultural exchanges and community tours featuring some of the country’s prominent regional cultural groups; Lakbay Sining, a national touring program which features performances from CCP resident companies or art exhibitions previously mounted at the CCP; Kaisa sa Sining, a program which links CCP to regional cultural groups in order to facilitate regional cultural development, exchanges, artistic programs, and collaborations; Lakbay Sine, a project of CCP Media Arts Division; and Lakbay Harana , a joint project of the CCP and Tribung Pilipino Foundation which aims to promote and reawaken the public’s, and especially the young generation’s, interest and appreciation for Philippine traditional music like the kundiman, balitaw, danza, and immortal Filipino love songs. The CCP through its Cultural Exchange Department also provides local tour grants for regional performing groups. It is also active in giving art therapy workshops—called Kalinga ng Sining—in provincial areas devastated by natural calamities or armed conflicts.

The CCP has occasionally engaged in film production. It produced two movies: Hari sa Hari, Lahi sa Lahi (King and Emperor), 1987, directed by Eddie Romero, and Emir, 2010, directed by Chito Roño.

A heritage project of the CCP is the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art. First published in 1994, the CCP Encyclopedia remains to be the most authoritative and most comprehensive sourcebook on Philippine art, with volumes on the peoples of the Philippines, architecture, visual arts, dance, music, theater, film, literature, and broadcast arts. Prior to the encyclopedia, the CCP also published beginning in 1989, 28 videos and monographs on the seven arts, known collectively as Tuklas Sining. The first essays on the seven arts were compiled and published in a coffee table book with the same title in 1991. To encourage the staging of more sarsuwela, the CCP came out with the sarsuwela series which made available to scholars and performing groups the scripts and music of the classic Tagalog sarsuwela Paglipas ng Dilim (After the Darkness), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), and Walang Sugat (No Wounds) as performed and staged by Tanghalang Pilipino. The initial publication in 1991 included the cassette tapes and books for Paglipas ng Dilim and Dalagang Bukid, and in 1994, for Walang Sugat. The videotaped performances of Dalagang Bukid and Walang Sugat were released in DVD format in 2007.

The Gawad CCP Para sa Sining is the highest recognition awarded by the CCP to artists or groups of artists who have produced a body of outstanding works and excelled in their chosen artform. The award is also given to cultural workers who have helped in enriching Philippine art through their works in research, curatorship, and administration. The Tanging Parangal is given to individuals or organizations to honor their outstanding contributions to the development of the arts in the country.The first Gawad CCP Para sa Sining, then called by another name, was given in 1977 to Hubertus Kuhne (for cultural administration). The award was given annually from 1989 up to 1994, and thereafter every three years. The most recent conferment was in 2015 and the awardees were: Denisa Reyes for Dance; Fides Cuyugan-Asensio for Music; Antonio Mabesa for Theater; Roberto Chabet for Visual Arts; Ricardo Lee for Literature; Nora Aunor for Film and Broadcast Arts; Paulo Alcazaren for Architecture; and Ben Farrales for Design.Leoncio Deriada, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Basilio Esteban Villaruz, Talaandig School of Living Traditions, and The Missionary Society of St. Columban received the Tanging Parangal.

The Order of the National Artists, the highest state honor given every three years to individuals who have made significant contributions in Philippine arts, was administered by the CCP from 1972 to 1992, and after that, by the CCP and NCCA. The award is conferred by the President of the Republic of the Philippines upon the recommendation of the CCP and NCCA.Fernando Amorsolo was posthumously conferred the first National Artist Award in 1977. The award was most recently conferred in 2018to Larry Alcala(visual arts, posthumous), Resil B. Mojares and Ramon Muzones (literature), Francisco Mañosa (architecture), Ryan Cayabyab(music), and Kidlat Tahimik (film).Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez, Lily Grace Tabanera, and Elmer L. Gatchalian

CUSI, RAFAEL (Rafael Arenillo Cusi) b. Bongabon, Oriental Mindoro 24 Oct 1950. Painter. Cusi finished bachelor of fine arts at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), where he received a most outstanding student award in 1979. An intense early inclination for the arts inspired Cusi to study painting at PWU. From 1975 onward, he joined various group shows and entered almost every art contest in the country.

Having grown up in the countryside, Cusi’s artistic expression leans toward a traditional orientation. His works are characterized by neat organization, rich harmonious colors, noble themes, or moving anecdotes. He has an intuition for innovative devices that enrich his compositions and render them up-to-date or relevant to current representational expression. Magsasarangola (The Kite Maker), 1977, shows a child in sleeveless shirt and short pants, seated in a quiet corner, intently polishing bamboo sticks that he is going to fashion into the frame of a flying kite. Juxtaposed with the figure situated at the lower half of the painting is a wall on which can be seen the drawing of an airplane with a parachute, perhaps a visualization of the boy’s thoughts. Its sketchy rendition and the realistic representation of the rough wooden texture of the wall, however, stand out as experimental pop or art brut devices felicitously appropriated by Cusi to inject a contemporary sensibility into what could have just been a skillfully executed but regular genre scene.

Cusi received many travel and study grants and was awarded the grand prize at the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition, 1980, for his Halik sa Kalawang (Kiss the Rust). Written by Santiago A. Pilar

CUSTODIO, GABRIEL (Gabriel Velasco Custodio) b. Cavite 18 Mar 1912. d. 1993. Painter. He was the son of Ildefonso Custodio, employed as a chief cook in the American Navy, and Rosa Velasco. His grandaunt Valentina Velasco, a nun-painter-sculptor, taught him the rudiments of art. He grew up in Tanza and studied at Cavite High School, which granted him a scholarship to the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts.

To earn his keep, he worked as janitor at the Albert Allen Dormitory. He also painted on banca (native boats), caretela (native passenger carts), and nicho (earth-level tombs). In 1952, he opened a studio on Taft Ave. In 1959, he had a show together with MiguelGalvez sponsored by the Department of Foreign Affairs. He also exhibited in Australia. Among his most important works are his murals at the Saint George Greek Orthodox Church on Makati Ave built by George Lucas Adamson.

A painter in the academic representational tradition, Custodio asserted his individuality by employing thick impasto, which gave his paintings a rich textural quality. His still lifes stand out for their realism due to this technique. The impasto that rendered the curling petals of a rose, for instance, gave it a distinctive three-dimensionality. He also rendered bamboo leaves, adorning his many paintings of creeks in the same manner.

Custodio’s awards in the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines include second prize, Ginataan (Assorted Fruits in Coconut Milk) and best landscape, Rosario Barong-Barong (Rosario Shanty), both in 1953; second prize, After the Storm, 1954; and second prize, Pantalan (Wharf), 1955. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

DALENA, DANILO (Danilo Echavaria Dalena) aka Danny Dalena. b. Pakil, Laguna 4 Jan 1942. Painter, illustrator. He is the son of Diosdado Dalena and Loreto Echavaria. His daughters, born to artist Julie Lluch, are also artists: Sari, a filmmaker; Kiri, a transmedia artist; and Aba, a sculptor-painter and musician. From an early age he was fascinated by the comics, both foreign and local, which he collected avidly. In 1964, he graduated with a fine arts degree, major in advertising arts, at the University of Santo Tomas, where his mentors included Victorio Edades, Galo B. Ocampo, and Cenon Rivera.

Dalena made his mark in the early 1970s with his caustic political cartoons and illustrations for the Philippines FreePress and Asia-PhilippinesLeader, which raised the standards of editorial art in the country. He did a series of highly realistic toilet and graffiti drawings in 1972.

From 1974 to 1979, he produced his powerful Jai-Alai series of paintings, a culmination of the figure drawings rendered in epic perspective. In these paintings done during the bleak martial law years, the betting hall and the swarming masses in search of luck became a metaphor for the human condition, particularly for the Philippine society in crisis. In 1980, Dalena worked on his Alibangbang series. In these paintings, the setting is a popular beerhouse in Cubao, with its night habitues and a-go-go dancers. All the while, the artist continued filling his sketch pads with hundreds of character studies, figure drawings of the down-and-out prowling the streets, and the city’s beer joints.

From urban sleaze, Dalena returned to his hometown Pakil, where he has found new artistic inspiration in folk customs and lifestyle. What relates the Pakil series that he began in 1984 to the earlier works is the sense of milling crowds, of mingling bodies in a sea of movement during public festivities, especially the dance procession of the turumba for the Nuestra Señora de los Dolores, the komedya performance, and church and home scenes.

Among Dalena’s one-man shows were those at the Joy T. Dayrit Gallery in 1969, Solidaridad Galleries in 1972, Regent of Manila in 1978, and Alegria Gallery in 1981.

Dalena received the second prize for Rizal Monument, Luneta in the on-the-spot contest of the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1964. His awards from the Art Association of the Philippines are: first prize for Tres-Seis Dejado in 1974, and fourth prize for Alibangbang in 1979. The Mobil Art Awards gave him the grand prize for his Jai-Alai as Metaphor in 1980. He was named one of the Thirteen Artists by the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) in 1972. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1996, while the CCP honored him with Centennial Honors for the Arts in 1999.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

DALENA, KIRI (Gabriela Krista Lluch Dalena) b. Quezon City 2 Dec 1975. Multimedia artist, sculptor, and filmmaker. She is the daughter of painter Danilo Dalena and sculptor Julie Lluch, and sibling to filmmaker Sari Dalena and painter-sculptor Aba Lluch Dalena. She holds a bachelor of science in human ecology from the University of the Philippines (UP) in Los Baños.

Dalena’s early practice was associated with terra-cotta sculpture and documentary filmmaking. She subsequently explored installation and video. She was a member of the Southern Tagalog Exposure, an activist multimedia collective formed in 2001. She directed Alingawngaw ng mga Punglo (Echo of Bullets), 2003, and Red Saga, 2004, which won first place in the experimental category, Gawad CCP para sa Alternatibong Pelikula at Video.

Dalena made a series of life-size fired terra-cotta figures of women for her first solo exhibition, Found Figures, 2007. In 2008, she started incorporating found objects, texts, and images in a definitive shifting toward installations. The works Erased Slogans and Red Book of Slogans, 2008, consist of slogans digitally effaced from archival photographs of Philippine protest actions from the 1950s to the 1970s. She recompiled the expunged texts in a facsimile Mao-inspired little red book installed within a site-specific work evocative of the faculty and student takeover of the UP Diliman campus during martial law.

Dalena continues to explore the aspect of transformation inherent in the artistic process, fusing video with her installation projects. For the Sungdu-an 5 show at the National Museum in 2009, she collaborated with carvers from Pakil, Laguna, to translate her terra-cotta figures into wood sculptures. In the show The Present Disorder Is the Order of the Future, 2010, Dalena recast these wood sculptures in marble, juxtaposing them against slogans engraved on gray marble slates and video projections of scenery filmed in transit to sites where human rights workers and journalists had been slain. These elements also resurfaced in Monument for a Present Future at the Singapore Art Museum, 2013.

Dalena’s installations have centered on gathering material and visual testimonials of trauma and tragedy, particularly human rights violations and natural disasters. Time and Place of Incident, 2011, is a five-channel video installation that constructs a loose narrative around how Dalena documented both the graves of Philippine journalists slain over the years as well as the sites of these crimes. It was included in the survey exhibition The Philippine Contemporary: To Scale the Past and the Possible, 2013, at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. The works Washed Out, 2012, and Tungkung Langit (Toward the Sky), 2013, are based on video footage taken in Iligan City in the aftermath of typhoon Washi (Sendong) in Dec 2011. Tungkung Langit won a special mention in the Premier Pas category of the Visions du Reel Festival in Switzerland, 2014. She has also shown in group exhibitions in Germany, Singapore, Taiwan, and the USA, including Giving Form to the Impatience of Liberty, 2013, Württembergischer Kunstverein in Stuttgart, Germany, and at the Singapore Biennale, 2013. Dalena received the Ateneo Art Award in 2009 and the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists award in 2012.Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Chikiamko 2011; Dalena 2014; Ito 2010; Southern Tagalog Exposure 2014.

DAMAG, GASTON (Gaston Bistol Damag) b. Banaue, Ifugao 23 Mar 1964. Painter, sculptor, installation and performance artist. He is the son of Pablo Damag Sr and Inhaybong (Veronica) Bistol. He is married to Joëlle Rüttyn. He graduated from the University of the Philippines Diliman in 1984 with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts. He then proceeded to attend the Faculté de la Sorbonne in Paris where he took up civilisation Française, 1987-89; the Ecole National Supérieur d’Arts Plastique de Cergy Pontoise, 1987-90; and the Ecole national supérieur des Beaux-Arts de Paris where he earned his diplome national d’expression plastique (nationalhigherdiplomain visual expression), summa cum laude, 1993.

Damag is among a growing number of Filipino artists who have established transnational art practices that breach the traditional bounds of state and international art circuit impositions of identity clustering. He has taken his critical interest in the politics of display, the complicities of anthropology and historiography to produce works of conceptual rigor and sensate provocation. At the heart of his creative impulse lies a critique of the representation of non-Western ethnic cultures in Western cultural arenas, such as museums and spaces of the art market. This impulse is primarily driven by his experiences as an Ifugao jarred by the encounter with his cultural roots through displays in ethnographic museums. In these spaces, he would often see familiar objects from his culture taken out of their context and used in ways far removed from the lived experiences of the people that produced them. Damag’s artistic response to this is aggressive on both the physical and cognitives planes. For instance, in Modern Grid, 2010, he encloses the bulol, the Ifugao rice deity statue, in crisscrossing sheets of glass which appear to cage it, its form appearing as a strong silhouette against translucent layers. In Concilliabules des Idoles Dans un Musée (Conclave of Idols in the Museum), 1995/2010, he crafts several bulol from synthetic resin and enshrines them in metal scaffolding that appear to pierce or fuse them as structural elements. In evoking the recurring motif of the Cordilleran bulol, which he physically subjects to varying degrees of violation such as drilling, casting then melting, overpainting, chopping into pieces, and so on, Damag places the notion of construction and self-determination squarely in the hands of the subject, presumably himself, who weighs in on presentations and re-presentations of evolving culture. By placing these physical remains in museums and other institutional contexts of display, Damag consciously situates his critical gesture amidst the trafficking of ideas and investments of value.

The shaman’s knife becomes small components defining the form of a heart in Puso (Heart), 2013. Other notable works include Ifugao Red, 2012, a painting formed by betel extract spat on a canvas, and The Saliva of an Ifugao as an Artist, 2010, where Damag transforms a restroom into an installation by incorporating wooden pestles and betel-chewing ingredients. In most cases, such objects are appropriated as evidences of the simpler, more primitive societies making up one pole of historical evolutionary accounts of human development where modern, Western cultures lie at the pinnacle of progression. As such, he intends to wrest his culture from a faux pure and sacred state and instead assert its being dynamic, evolving, yet enduring.

Based in Paris, Damag has exhibited extensively in solo and group shows across Europe, Asia, and the United States. Among these are My Home Is My Castle, 2006, Dexia Banque Internationale, Luxembourg; Synthetic Reliquaries, 2010; White Spirit, 2012, Silverlens Galleries, Makati; Homage to the Culture of Rice, 2013, The Drawing Room, Singapore; and Miserable Intentions, 2005, with Manuel Ocampo, Galerie Bains Douches de la Plaine, Marseille, France. He also participated in Heterotopias, the Thessaloniki Biennale in Greece in 2007, and in the Jakarta Biennale of 2011.Written by Ryan Francis Reyes and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources:

Damag, n.d.; Drawing Room Gallery 2015; Galerie Zimmermann Kratochwill 2015; Silverlens Galleries 2015d.

DANDAN, VIRGINIA (Virgina Bonoan Dandan) aka Ginny. b. Laoag, Ilocos Norte 10 Sep 1941. Sculptor, teacher. Dandan received her early education at the Holy Spirit Academy, Laoag, and at the Immaculata Academy of Malolos, Bulacan. She received a bachelor’s degree in fine arts, with honors, from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1976 and a master’s degree in anthropology from the same school in 1989. She taught various courses on advanced studies in the fine arts at UP where she served as dean from 2001 to 2006. She was also chair of the United Nations Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Organizations Center for Human Rights, Geneva, Switzerland, 2011.

From 1976 to the 1980s, Dandan was actively involved with RayAlbano’s group of conceptual artists doing experimental works at the CulturalCenterofthe Philippines (CCP). Her works were thus focused on formal problems delineating the concerns of minimalism, installation, and conceptual art. One of her works consisted of two-inch by one-inch strips of wood painted black or white, joined at sharp angles, and which were constructed in modular format, offering a great number of installation possibilities. In Objects, 1980, at the Sining Kamalig, she exhibited shaped plywood pieces wedged into each other as these were installed on the floor vertically to heighten their plastic qualities in relation to the gallery space. In 1983, Dandan showed her paintings consisting of scenes employing impressionistic techniques that showed her refined handling of color. Dandan painted Batanes landscapes with the same finesse. She was named one of the Thirteen Artists of the CCP in 1978.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

DANS, ESMERALDO b. Paete, Laguna. Sculptor. He took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines. In 1974, Dans was one of the master carvers from Paete who created the dioramas depicting scenes in Philippine history at the Ayala Museum.

His art stands for the classic Malay physique. He imbues his subjects’ faces and hand clasps with expressions of idealized serenity. His Madonna and Child in ivory is an immaculate picture of tenderness. Whether in ivory or wood, he infuses life into his figures with a graceful sway of convincing rhythm. He meticulously carves even the finest nuance of weave, stitch, or wind breezing through drapery. Among his genre works are Mindanao Couple, 1981; Batang May Tirador at Kapoteng Nipa (Boy with Slingshot and Nipa Raincoat), 1981; and Lansones sa Palda (Lanzones on a Skirt), 1981.

Dans was a runner-up in the 1971 Shell National Students Art Competition for his Searching for Hope. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

DANS, JOSE (Josef Luciano Dans) b. Paete, Laguna 1805. d. 1888. Painter. His baptismal certificate shows that he was originally named Joseph Luciano de San Rafael. One theory says that he was a mestizo of Spanish, Chinese, and indio stock and that he adopted the family name Dans upon the promulgation of the decree by Gov-Gen Narciso Claveria ordering Philippine natives to assume new surnames. Another possible theory points to the Dans family coming from Belgium in the 1500s. Painter Araceli Dans, who is married to the great-great-grandson of Jose Dans, said that a certain Dans family from Belgium sent them a genealogical chart which shows a note of “Philippines–1500” (Fajardo 2005).

In the church of the Santiago Parish in Paete, Laguna, are found four larger-than-life murals—namely, Juicio Final (Last Judgment), ca 1720; San Cristobal (Saint Christopher), fresco on plaster, ca 1780; another San Cristobal, oil on panel, ca 1840; and El Cielo, El Paraiso, El Purgatorio y El Infierno (Heaven, Paradise, Purgatory, and Hell), ca 1850. Only the last two are attributed to Dans. His Cristobal was hung over the 1780 fresco in order to cover it. According to oral tradition, the fresco did not satisfy the church authorities as it violated iconographic conventions. In it, San Cristobal was depicted in 18th-century buccaneer’s costume, complete with a wedge-shaped blade.

Dans’s Cristobal was painted on 12 planks of wood joined together. According to legend, San Cristobal was a pagan giant who transported people on his shoulders across the lake. One day he carried an infant who became heavier and heavier as they reached the depths of the lake. When Cristobal asked the reason for this, the child revealed himself as Christ who was carrying the globe with him. This revelation caused the pagan’s conversion, and he assumed the name Cristobal or Christ’s bearer. The painting shows Dans’s proficiency as a realistic painter. Both Christ and San Cristobal are effectively modeled, their limbs well drafted. Dans also painted a vast lake in accurate linear perspective.

Dans’s more important work, El Cielo, El Paraiso, El Purgatorio y El Infierno, depicts the Catholic view of salvation, showing Adam and Eve at the center and the crucified Christ above them. On the same level with Christ are the seven sacraments, and above the saints is heaven presided over by God the Father, God the Holy Spirit, and the Virgin Mary. Below the sacraments are the souls in purgatory, and below them the torturers, monsters, and fires of hell. Dans’s church paintings have provided Philippine art history a visual anchor on how religious concepts were negotiated and understood in the context of a colonized society.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

Fajardo 2005.

DAROY, RODERICO (Roderico Jose Vallado Daroy) aka Dick Daroy. b. Manila 27 Jan 1954. d. Quezon City 26 Jan 2014. Painter, sculptor, and intermedia artist. He was the son of Bernardo Jaime Callanta Daroy and Ester Castro Vallado. He took up his degree in fine arts at the University of the Philippines Diliman (UP) from 1970 to 1974.

Daroy is known for creating collages and intermedia works that embrace a wide range of materials in the tradition of found objects, appropriating the overlooked and ordinary, and transforming them into unique and unfamiliar artistic creations. Some of these objects he had stumbled upon, retrieved, and salvaged, while others he had kept and collected over the years, such as damaged photographs, glass, metal, galvanized iron, beeswax, books, coasters, and LP sleeve covers. He made use of such diverse media to reflect on themes that revolve around the passage of time and how forces of nature and human action interact in the process. In his works, he reflects on notions of growth and decay, nostalgia and memory, transience and permanence, life and death. His artistic process also alludes to his incursions into the nature of spatio-temporal existence: how deliberate human action navigates around accidents and random occurrences. He subjects his chosen objects to the inevitable effects of wear and tear, allowing the stains of time and neglect, patina, and at times infestations to accrue on their surfaces before subjecting these to scraping, drawing, painting, and other processes. His last work before his death, the installation Untitled [Anus of the Sun], 2013, engaged with the space of the Museum of Contemporary Art and Design (MCAD). It was part of the exhibit Without a Murmur, curated by Joselina Cruz, which marked MCAD’s first all-Filipino group show, which also included At Maculangan, Lani Maestro, and Maria Taniguchi.

His solo exhibitions include Illuminated Pages, 1983, Hiraya Gallery; Palimpsest, 1985, De La Salle University Gallery; Viewing the Numinous, 1986, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Selected Works, 1996, Japan Cultural Center, Bangkok, Thailand; Still, 1997, Vargas Museum, UP Diliman; New Works, 2002, The Drawing Room, Makati; and And of Time, 2010. He participated in group shows such as the Kunsan International Show, 1985, at the Kunsan National Library in Korea; Salon de Tokyo International Exhibition, 1987, in Japan; 36 Ideas from Asia: Contemporary Southeast Asian Art, a traveling exhibition organized by the Singapore Art Museum, 2002-3; Stories of Dreams and Realities: Contemporary Art from the Philippines, 2011, in London; and the Hong Kong International Art Fair and Art Stage Singapore in 2012.

He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1980.Written by Ryan Francis Reyes

Sources:

Daroy 2010, n.d.; Drawing Room Gallery 2015.

DAVID, ANGELITO (Angelito de Leon David)b. Balanga, Bataan 28 Jul 1936. Painter, art conservator. His parents are Rafael Tuazon David and Generosa de Leon. He finished his early education at Balanga Elementary School and Arellano High School. He obtained his bachelor of fine arts degree at the University of Santo Tomas in 1957. In 1963, the Italian government awarded him with a two-year scholarship in painting at the Regge Accademia di Belle Arti in Rome. David became interested in art conservation at this juncture, and in 1967, he studied at the Instituto di Ristauro di Roma. He joined the team that worked on the rehabilitation of art objects damaged by the floods of Florence. From 1967 to 1969, he took on conservation work for the Corcoran Studio and later for Carolyn Horton, noted author on restoration. Upon David’s return to the Philippines, he was involved with the National Historical Commission and the Lopez Memorial Museum. He also taught at the Philippine Women’s University and the College of the Holy Spirit. He resides in the USA.

David staged his first one-person show at the Philippine ArtGallery in 1960. His works may be classified as belonging to the first generation of abstract expressionism in the Philippines. In Carroza (Processional Float), 1965, he energized the entire canvas with acrylic paint in a variety of gestures from brush sweeps to spatula daubs. Dynamic movement was evidently one of his concerns. Passaggio dal Cielo (Passage to Heaven) was painted in bright hues applied with forceful strokes. These hues have been laid out on top or beside each other to create the effect of an explosion resulting from the speed of an object such as a jetliner.

David received nine gold medals and several silver and bronze medals in art competitions in Italy. His awards from the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines include best in watercolor, Juliet, 1959; best in watercolor, Red Sails, and honorable mention in photography, Tug O’War, both in 1961. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

DAY-AG, ANSELMO b. Nueva Vizcaya 1936. d. 1986. Sculptor. Day-ag took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) from 1953 to 1957. Trained in the classical tradition, his early works were realistic. After graduation, he shifted to semiabstraction as he took on a job in a construction firm where he created mural reliefs and sculptures for edifices. Day-ag was a member of the League of Philippine Sculptors of which he was once secretary.

In 1954, then only a sophomore, Day-ag garnered first prize for Storm, a cement piece submitted to the UP Students Art Competition. In 1956, his Grief and Nag-iigib (Fetching Water) won honorable mention in the art contest sponsored by the UP Student Catholic Action. In that year, he also won second prize for Goose, made of stone, at the annual exhibition of the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines. In 1958, he garnered another second prize in the same contest for Redeemer, which was crafted in wood.

In 1960, Day-ag staged his first one-person exhibition at the Contemporary Art Gallery consisting of figures with grossly distorted facial features and limbs inspired by tribal sculpture of the Cordilleras. Most of the figures were made of his favorite medium, wood—specifically, kamagong from Mindoro; molave from Nueva Vizcaya, his home province; and also lauan and narra. Day-ag’s mural reliefs and garden sculptures were made of stone, cement, or a mixture of white marble sand and cement. His exploration of medium helped inspire new and more indigenous ways of visualizing and presenting Philippine art. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

DAYAO, RODOLFO (Rodolfo Fernando Dayao) b. Gapan, Nueva Ecija 28 Jan 1920. d. 18 Jul 1991. Illustrator, painter. His parents were Antonio Dayao and Adela Fernando. He studied at Tondo Elementary School and later at the University of the Philippines (UP) High School. He took up fine arts at UP in the 1930s while at the same time working as an artist at the La Vanguardia and Taliba. He became senior illustrator of the APWESCAPO Adjutant General Printing. He married Consolacion de Lara and their only child is named Lydia.

In 1947, he was staff artist of the New York Yankees. In 1953, he illustrated for 30 Years After which featured Filipino luminaries. He was chief artist of the Manila Chronicle from 1949 to 1972. He did the Bata Batuta series in this newspaper from 1970 to 1972. Bata Batuta was later transferred to Times Journal, running from 1978 to 1981. He taught at the FEATI University School of Fine Arts from 1965 to 1987.

Dayao received the following awards: special award (calendar) for Shell Pickers at Laguna Bay from the Art AssociationofthePhilippines (AAP) Watercolor Exhibition, 1953; honorable mention in conservative painting for Cumbancheros at the AAP 7th annual exhibition, 1954. He was grand awardee in all categories, including editorial layout and artworks, in a competition sponsored by the Art Directors Club of the Philippines. He also received a travel award from the Manila Chronicle which brought him to various Asian countries.

Although known for his illustrations and series of cartoons, Dayao was also a prolific painter. His main subjects were children, depicting them with an inner fullness, zest, self-assurance, and joy.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

DE GUIA, KAWAYAN (Kawayan Thor Kalayaan Muller de Guia) b. Baguio City 2 Oct 1979. Intermedia artist. He is the second of the three sons of artist and filmmaker Kidlat Tahimik (Eric de Guia) and artist-scholar Katrin Müller de Guia. Kawayan’s siblings, Kidlat and Kabunyan, are also intermedia artists. De Guia studied at the Philippine High School for the Arts in 1992-96.

Involving compelling commentaries on identity and the colonial past, de Guia’s works are entrenched in the Cordillera where he was born and raised. His affinity with place is reflected in his process of sourcing and refashioning found objects and establishing connections with the local community. Turning to painting, photography, assemblage, video, sculpture, installation, performance, and later on to public art practice, many of de Guia’s works employ pastiche and imaging techniques from popular culture, forming layered significations in his art. In the exhibition Katas na Pilipinas, God Knows Hudas Not Pay (Philippine Earnings, God Knows Who Does / Judas Not Pay), 2009, de Guia collaborated with the technician Rojer Berdun to revive junked jukeboxes. Recalling present-day appropriations of symbols of colonial legacy, the artist transformed the machines’ exteriors to make these appear like jeepneys. The lure of television and its repercussions are explored in de Guia’s works for the exhibition Ice Cold Happiness, 2009, held at Soka Art Center, Beijing. Harking on a similar theme albeit more rooted in the Philippine experience, his Linangaw (Fit for Flies) series rendered portraits of celebrities and TV personalities by collecting houseflies affixed unto a surface. An assemblage of trumpets made from 35 mm celluloid films depicting a horse about to gallop rounded out the aforementioned series in the exhibition A Lot of Sound and Fury Signifying Nothing, 2011.

De Guia’s artistic training is further honed by his exposure to a community of Baguio-based artists who have probed into prevailing conditions of the region. His series of intermedia work for Incubator, 2006, imagines rooms of artists who have influenced his practice—among them, Tommy Haffala, Rene Aquitania, Roberto Villanueva, Santiago Bose, and his father, Kidlat Tahimik. In 2011, de Guia co-organized the AX(iS) Art Project: Accident Waiting to Happen, an art festival held at Burnham Park, Baguio, which involved local and international artists. This was followed by To the End of the World, 2012, where artists and writers traveled together on a bus along Halsema Highway to reach the Mountain Province. The artists engaged with the local communities and together they created site-specific and ephemeral works. This cumulative and collaborative project grew, and became part of the Singapore Biennale in 2013, where de Guia was selected as one of its curators.

De Guia received the Ateneo Art Award in 2008 and 2011. As winner, he was granted artist residencies at Omi International Arts Center in Ghent, New York, 2009, and at La Trobe University Visual Arts Centre in Melbourne, Australia, 2012. He received the Nokia Art Award and the Thirteen Artists Award in 2009.Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

Source:

de Guia 2014.

DE GUZMAN, JAIME b. Liliw, Laguna 1942. Painter, potter. He studied at the University of Santo Tomas and the University of the Philippines, where he finished a degree in fine arts. In 1967, he held his first one-person show at the Solidaridad Gallery. While in Mexico to study mural painting under the masters, he became interested in and later shifted his attention to pottery. His wife, Ann, and his children are all engaged in pottery. He has lived with his family in Liliw, Laguna; Candelaria, Quezon; and Sagada, Mountain Province. He has dedicated himself to promoting the art of pottery in rural communities.

De Guzman won critical recognition in the 1970s with his large murals Gomburza and Metamorphosis. A historical mural, Gomburza shows the three martyred priests upon a cross which also serves as their garrote, an allusion to the martyrdom of Christ. Metamorphosis is a powerful, semiabstract composition in red, black, and white. These are considered to be his greatest contributions to Philippine painting and are in the collection of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

A recurring theme in the artist’s work is the quest for identity through a retracing of the past. Some of his paintings, particularly what he calls “historical allegories,” contain autobiographical elements that pose the question of his identity as an individual and as Filipino. In Indio Sangre Puro (Pure Indio Blood), de Guzman identifies the country’s heroic period as the 19th-century propaganda movement, which was the inspiration for his historical paintings. Many of his landscapes evoke the setting of Liliw at the foot of Mount Banahaw, known for its millenarian and Rizalist groups, and the source of de Guzman’s symbols. His other works are visionary landscapes leaning toward esotericism as these are done in his dramatic painterly style.

De Guzman received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1970. In Mar 2015, the CCP held a retrospective of de Guzman’s works. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

DE JESUS, ROMUALDO TEODORO(Romualdo Teodoro de los Reyes de Jesus) aka Lolong de Jesus. b. San Miguel, Manila 7 Feb 1848. d. 23 Dec 1921. Sculptor, wood-carver. He was the son of Eduvigio de Jesus, a wood and ivory carver, and Juana de los Reyes. He married Benedicta Vergara. He learned wood carving from his father who had a shop in their house in Santa Cruz, Manila. His paternal grandfather, Anastasio de Jesus, was also a wood-carver. Romualdo took over his father’s shop when the latter died in 1868. It was here that he made his acquaintance with JoseRizal, to whom he gave wood-carving lessons every week. He is said to have been the model for Pilosopo Tasio (Tasio the philosopher) in the novel NoliMe Tangere (Touch Me Not) and was later a rich source of information on Rizal’s early life.

De Jesus founded and became the first president of the Gremio de Escultores de Santa Cruz, a guild of sculptors and wood-carvers. He was honorary sculptor of the Ayuntamiento of Manila and was once gobernadorcillo (mayor) in Tondo. He also contributed to periodicals like La Oceania Española, El Comercio, El Mercantil, El Renacimiento, El Ideal, and La Vanguardia.

The works of de Jesus, principally figures of saints, are found in churches in different parts of the country. The Tercera Caida (Third Fall) used during the Lenten procession in Santa Cruz is attributed to him. He received a gold medal for his sculptures exhibited at the Exposicion Universal de Barcelona (Barcelona Universal Exposition) and a medal of civil merit from the Spanish government in recognition of his artistic works.Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

DE LA ROSA, FABIAN (Fabian Cueto de la Rosa) b. Paco, Manila 5 May 1869. d. Quiapo, Manila 14 Dec 1937. Painter. He is the second child of Marcos de la Rosa and Gregoria Cueto. He married Gorgonia Tolentino. SimonFlores y de la Rosa was his uncle while Fernando and PabloAmorsolo were his nephews. His first art lessons were from an aunt, Mariana de la Rosa, who taught him at age 10. When he was 22 years old, he painted La Perla de Lucban (Pearl of Lucban), considered to be his oldest existing work. He studied at Escuela Superior de Pintura, Grabado y Escultura in 1893, under Don Lorenzo Rocha. He later enrolled at the Escuela de Bellas Artes y Dibujo under Agustin Saez but dropped out after three years. He also received lessons from LorenzoGuerrero and MiguelZaragoza. In 1908, the Germinal Cigar Factory sent him to Europe as a scholar. The schools he attended included the Academie Julien in Paris and the Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid. Back in Manila, together with a number of artists, he became one of the first faculty members of the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts. He introduced and taught decorative painting at UP. During the period 1927-37, he became the director of the school. In 1928, he sailed to Europe for the second time with his wife. He painted in Paris for four months and then traveled to Munich, Geneva, Rome, and Madrid. In 1928, he presented a much-acclaimed exhibition of his paintings at Ateneo de Madrid.

He is reputed to have produced about 1,000 works in his lifetime. AurelioS. Alvero divides his works into three periods. In the first period, de la Rosa’s emphasis is academic, detailing figures but forgetting atmosphere. Works of this period include Planting Rice, which won the gold medal in the International Exposition of Saint Louis, Missouri, in 1904 and The Death of General Lawton, which won the bronze medal in the same exposition. The second period, which includes works he did in Europe, shows a transition from focusing on academic figures to greater attention to atmosphere. Examples of this period are ElKundiman, 1936, and Marikina Road, ca 1939. In his third period, de la Rosa emphasizes plays of colors in the manner of massing and spacing hues. Typical of this period is Fishermen’s Huts on Balut Island, Tondo, considered by Alvero as his best landscape. Other paintings of de la Rosa are Landscape with Dark Trees, 1927; La Pintora (Woman Painter), 1926; and La Bordadora (The Embroiderer), ca 1926. He also did a Riverview of Santa Ana, 1938.

De la Rosa posthumously received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1968. In 2006-7, the Fabian de la Rosa (1869-1938) Retrospective Exhibition was held at the UP Vargas Museum to honor his legacy. Written by J. B. Guysayko, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

de la Paz 2015a.

DE LA ROSA, IBARRA (Ibarra Yacap de la Rosa) b. Gapan, Nueva Ecija 24 Mar 1943. d. 1998. Painter. He was the son of Miguel de la Rosa and Corazon Yacap. Ibarra took up business administration and some courses in architecture, mostly from Mapua Institute of Technology. In 1969, he got a bachelor of fine arts degree from FEATI University, where he taught fine arts. De la Rosa’s citations were mostly centered on his teaching career in the field of fine arts, which he pursued since 1969. He was also a former faculty at the Philippine Women’s University.

He is best known for his highly colorful landscapes done in the impressionist style with a fauvist approach. His medium was mostly oil but also pen-and-ink and watercolor. His subject matter ranges from still lifes to genre, historical and tourist spots, rock formations, flora, and, most especially, landscapes. His meticulous and impressionistic brushstrokes endowed his works with a highly textured surface, further enriched with the use of a wide range of color combinations that makes him a colorist. He also did prints showing urban scenes.

De la Rosa is perhaps one of the most exhibited painters in the country, with more than 60 one-person shows since 1970 and more than 145 group shows since 1967.

He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of thePhilippines in 1972. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1982. Written by Rachel Mayo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

Kulay Diwa Gallery 2016.

DE LEON, FELIPE M., JR (Felipe Mendoza de Leon Jr) aka Jun de Leon. b. 5 Dec 1940. Composer, cultural administrator, educator. He is the son of pianist and teacher Iluminada Bonus Mendoza and National Artist for music Felipe Padilla de Leon. He is the great grandson of composer and conductor Ladislao Bonus. His siblings Bayani, Tagumpay, Luningning, Magdangal, and Marilag are also into music as composers or performers. His son Diwa de Leon is an award-winning composer while his daughter Dawani de Leon is a visual artist. He received his AB Humanities degree, cum laude, from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1969 and took graduate courses in music composition and theory at the UP College of Music from 1976 to 1978. He also took courses in musicology at Madras Music Academy in Madras, India, and Philippine studies at UP Diliman.

De Leon began teaching in UP Diliman in 1969. He served as chair of the Humanities Department (later called the Department of Art Studies) in the College of Arts and Letters from 1976 to 1982. He retired in 2005 but continued teaching as a professorial lecturer until 2013, marking more than 40 years of service to the university. De Leon has published numerous essays and journal articles, delivered papers and lectures on Philippine art and culture, aesthetics, and music, foregrounding an interdisciplinal approach to the study of art and culture, and promoting the importance of Philippine indigenous concepts, values, cultural forms, and practices in the development of Philippine society.

De Leon has written several musical works and has collaborated with various major playwrights and writers. He composed music for plays such as Abadeja: Ating Sinderela (Abadeja: Our Cinderella) by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, Yerma by Federico Garcia Lorca, Lysistrata by Aristophanes, and Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) directed by Tony Mabesa. He also wrote nationalistic songs including “Lumuha Ka Aking Bayan” (Cry My Country), lyrics by National Artist for Literature Amado V. Hernandez. For the centennial celebrations of Philippine Independence, he was commissioned to write “Awit ng Sentenaryo” (Centennial Song), with lyrics by National Artist Bienvenido Lumbera, and “Diwang Pilipino” (Filipino Spirit), which was the official hymn of the Philippine Republic in 1997. He has also served as musical director of several choirs including the Kasarinlan Philippine Music Ensemble.

De Leon has also served as the head of major cultural institutions in the Philippines. From 1999 to 2001, he was a commissioner of UNESCO in the Philippines and was chairman of the Committee on Culture of the same institution. During his term, he initiated several projects and activities that demonstrated to development planners and local government officials the links between culture and development. He was also the chairman of the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan from 1993 to 2007. He became the chairman of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2011, concurrently heading the Committee on Intangible Heritage, the National Committee on Music, and the Sub-Commission on the Arts. He received the National Research Council of the Philippines Achievement Award in 2008 and the NRCP Service in 2012. Written by Patricia Marion Y. Lopez

DE LEON, R. M. (Ramon Manuel Yoingco de Leon) b. Manila 29 Jan 1960. Painter, educator. He is the son of Eduardo de Leon and Emiliana Yoingco. He first studied industrial design at the University of Santo Tomas before shifting to the University of the Philippines, finishing fine arts in 1984. He became involved in building a children’s art workshop after graduation. He teaches at the De La Salle College of Saint Benilde’s School of Design.

De Leon’s paintings are characterized by vigorous strokes, passionate images, and sparkling colors, according to art critic AlejandroRoces. His early works have a powerful style that rises out of a “fiery force” within him, influenced by the art styles of German expressionism and abstract expressionism. His later works utilizes irony and appropriation in critiquing societal and aesthetic norms.

He held his first solo exhibition in 1984 at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). It was during his third exhibit at the Sining Kamalig Gallery that he gained the notice of noted artist RobertoChabet, who influenced him greatly during the early stage of his career. Since then, de Leon has been represented in annual shows of the CCP and other major group exhibitions both here and abroad. He has held shows at the Pinaglabanan Galleries. He took part in the Manila-Berlin Exchange Exhibit held at the Raab Gallery in West Berlin in 1988. He held the exhibits From a Distance Beyond 18 Inches, 2013, Art Informal; and Dust Drawings and Other Works, 2015, Archivo 1984 Gallery, Makati City.

He was a participant in the Third Biennial in Bangladesh sponsored by the United Nations and was the first Filipino artist to be granted a scholarship at the Vermont Studio Center. He was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1990. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Sources:

Art Informal 2016; Tejero 2015.

DE LOS SANTOS, JUAN Active early 17th century. Sculptor. He is the only Filipino sculptor prior to the 19th century whose activities are amply recorded. He was a native of San Pablo, Laguna, then an artistic center paralleling, if not antedating, the wood-carving town of Paete. In his unpublished manuscript Historia de la Provincia de Batangas (History of Batangas Province), 1790, Pedro Andres Castro y Amadeo, later known as Fr Agustin Maria de Castro of the Augustinian order, described de los Santos and his works as “a native of San Pablo de los Montes and chief sacristan of its church for forty years. This maestro made the main altarpiece of SanAgustin in Manila and many others. He was also a skillful jeweller and worked with his hands all the silver ornaments of San Agustin, which were excellent. All these works were done under the guidance of Fr Hernando Cabrera, son of Cordova and prior of the Augustinian Monastery.”

De los Santos executed the tabernacle of San Agustin Church, Intramuros, from a design by Father Cabrera. He is also credited by EsperanzaBunagGatbonton with crafting the ivory crucifix in the same church, which features a realistically agonizing Christ. His most accessible work is the retablo also found in the San Agustin Church. Executed in 1617, this retablo was placed above the main altar, but in 1622, it was transferred to the vestry hall, now the Museum Hall of the convent. This was because its Ionic-Corinthian style no longer conformed to renovations in the church, which were patterned after the then-fashionable baroque style.

If the naturalism of de los Santos’s ivory crucifix reflects late Renaissance sensibility, his retablo shows the symmetry of Renaissance architecture. One feature of this altar is the broken arch pediment, which also shows the influence of the mannerist style. De los Santos’s works are testaments to the influences of European sensibility and aesthetic on Filipino art. These also suggest how Filipino artists used and synthesized these influences to create distinct bodies of work. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

DE PIO, GIG (Gig Completo de Pio) b. Balamban, Cebu 2 Oct 1951. Painter. His parents are Ramon de Pio Sr and Loreta Completo. His sons Vincent and Simkin are also painters. De Pio participated in art shows in his high school days. In the 1970s, he became a member of the Weekenders Group, which consisted of painters encouraged by Rogelio and Flora Pantaleon of the Manila Art Frames office in Cebu City. When de Pio became its manager in 1972, he offered art lessons to young Cebuano artists. He later put up Gallery 90 in Cebu City. De Pio left for Manila on a Juan Ponce Enrile scholarship to study at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts. As an outstanding student, he received the JoseJoya scholarship.

In 1976, he participated in several group shows: Cycles and Sequences and Black and White, both at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) Small Gallery (also known as Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo), Portfolio at the CCP Main Gallery (also known as Bulwagang Juan Luna), the Baguio Summer Art Festival, and the Tuklas exhibit of the Center for the Advancement of Young Artists. DePio works in both abstract and figurative styles. His abstract art is based on the theory of entropy, which involves the process of moving from order to disorganization in the universe. His portraits in charcoal, pastel, and oil are much admired for their refinement. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

DE VERA, RUBEN b. Guagua, Pampanga 27 Dec 1942. Painter. His family migrated to Davao where he completed his grade school at the University of Mindanao, and high school and collegiate courses at Ateneo de Davao. In 1962-64, he took fine arts courses at the University of Santo Tomas under Galo B.Ocampo. At first, he did sculpture in wood and stone but shifted to painting. Aside from using oil and watercolor, he experimented with the use of lacquer acrylic (car paint) in his search for durability and brightness of color.

He had his first one-person show at the United States Information Service or USIS Center, Davao. This was followed by a 1986 two-person show at the Solidaridad Gallery in Ermita, Manila, and another at CM Gallery. His third one-person show was at the National Museum in 1969. In 1980, he held his fourth one-person show at the Heritage Center. He had a 20-year retrospective of his works at the Davao Museum and Gallery.

Many of his works are Davao landscapes and genre, particularly of the cultural communities of the South. He has also done a series of paintings on the Philippine eagle as a double symbol of US imperialism, on the one hand, and of the strength and beauty of unconquered indigenous groups, on the other hand. He is one of the first to employ photocopying as art medium and mode in the interest of popularizing powerful images of the people’s struggle. In the gap between his 1969 and his 1980 show, he devoted himself full time to the people’s cause. His exploration of alternative mediums encapsulates the realities of struggle and collective action informing art practices in the country.

De Vera won awards at the Shell National Students Art Competition: first prize for Psyche, 1964; first prize for Archetype, 1965; and second prize for Highway, 1965.Written by Alice G. Guillermo

DEFENSOR, EDWARD (Edward Doligosa Defensor) aka Ed Defensor. b. Mina, Iloilo 13 Mar 1945. Painter, sculptor, director, playwright. He is the son of Santiago Azucena Defensor and Lourdes Palma Doligosa. He graduated with a bachelor’s degree in English, major in comparative literature, at the University of the Philippines (UP) College Iloilo (CI) in 1971. He finished his master’s degree in art history at UP Diliman in 1991. His graduate thesis focused on the Ilonggo scenic designer Vicente deSanMiguel. He took courses in radio-TV production at the GMA Channel 7 Workshop in the early 1970s. In UP, he worked as a research assistant at West Visayas Studies Center in 1975; a lecturer of theater classes in the 1980s; and a full-time faculty member of the Division of Humanities in 1985 until his retirement in 2009. He founded the UP Visayas (UPV) Teatro Amakan in 1979 and was its artistic director until 2000. He was a member of the Art Association of the Philippines since the 1980s, the charter chairman of the Hubon Madiaas: The Panay Art Association in 1983, a charter member in 1986 and one of the board of directors of the Arts Council of Iloilo Foundation Inc from 1992 to 1996, and the charter chairman of the Visayas Islands Visual Artist Association in 1994.

As a painter, he conducted one-man shows all over the Visayas and in Manila, and has helped organize art exhibits. His painting, print, and sculpture exhibitions include Pahayag I (Show I), 1980; Pahayag II (Show II) and Ani (Harvest), 1981; Tapalan (Chopping Board), 1992; Dance Sculpture in Wood and Nails and Dancing for the Moon, 1998; Garden Sculptures, 1999; Panakayon sa Sudu 2 (Journey to Sudu 2), 2008; and Pasalamat (Gratitude), 2010. He also exhibited his mixed media paintings, titled Pahayag, at the Philippine Center in New York City in 2002.
