Defensor translated to English two Hiligaynon novels: Ramon Muzones’s Margosatubig and Magdalena Jalandoni’s Dalaga sa Tindahan (Lady at the Store).

His theater involvement began when he transferred to UPCI and enrolled in a theater directing class under Majella Palacios. He then became the president of the Theater Arts Club performing in plays such as Pink Carnation, Impromptu, and The Lady Is Not for Burning in 1970-71. His first directorial work was for a UPCI student club production, under Lourdes de Castro, titled Bungang-Hangin (Fruits of the Mind), 1977, a Visayan translation of Harvey Schmidt’s The Fantasticks. However, it was with Teatro Amakan that he fully exercised his capacity as theater director. For Teatro Amakan, he directed his Hiligaynon translation of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1979; Pabrika (Factory), 1980; Candelaria, 1981; Mga Santos nga Tao, 1982, his Hiligaynon translation of Tomas Remigio’s Mga Santong Tao (People as Saints); Ramona Reyes ng Forbes Park (Ramona Reyes of Forbes Park), 1982; Kanla-on, 1983; Dumut cag Huya (Vengeance and Shame), 1984; Ang Bastos (The Boor), 1985; and Role Call, 1986. His plays, which he also directed for Teatro Amakan, include the skit Titser ng Bayan (People’s Teacher), 1984; a Panay legend, Baloy!, 1988; and the dance dramas AngBabaylan (The Shaman), 1989, and Apik, 1991, for which he was also the music composer. His Ang Babaylan was toured in over 60 venues all over the country from 1989 to 1990 and was also performed in Kuala Lumpur and Penang, Malaysia, in 1990.

He was conferred the Most Outstanding Professional Jubilarian in the Arts and Letters award by the UPV Alumni Association in 2006; Distinguished Ilonggo in the Visual Arts award by the Province of Iloilo in 2008; Garbo sa Bisaya Award: Living Legend of Visayan Art by the Cebu City government in 2010; Luna Award for the Visual Arts by the Junior Chambers International Regatta of Iloilo City in 2013; and the Dungganon nga Dumangasanon Award in the field of the arts from the municipality of Dumangas in 2014.Written by Malou L. Maniquis, updated by Erick Dasig Aguilar

DEL CASAL, RAFAEL (Rafael Carvajal del Casal) b. Manila 15 Jun 1956. Painter, sculptor, stage designer. He is the son of Mauro del Casal and Norma Carvajal. He studied at the Lourdes Catholic School. He apprenticed under SalvadorBernal for stage design in 1975 and 1977-78. He has done several designs for stage plays in the University of the Philippines (UP) such as Tony Mabesa’s Toreng Garing (Ivory Tower), 1976, and Behn Cervantes’s PagsambangBayan (People’s Worship), 1977, and Tanghalang Pilipino’s restaging of Larawan (Portrait) at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino (also known as Little Theater) in 1992.

As a visual artist, del Casal is known for his detailed realistic style, excellent draftsmanship, and mastery of artistic expression in oil, watercolor, and pastel, as seen in his portraits, religious works, and historical oeuvres.

His portraits of artists and friends like Salvador Bernal and Alice Reyes—most in pastel, some in oil—were first exhibited in Portraits, 1982, at the Sining Kamalig at Regent Manila, and Portraits II, 1982, at the Viana Gallery. Soon commissions followed, and between 1983 and 2004 he completed portraits in oil of the chairs of major business corporations and institutions such as Enrique Zobel, Jaime Zobel de Ayala, John Gokongwei, Jesus Cabarrus Sr and Jr, Enrique Razon Sr and Jr, Robert Coyiuto, Mariano Que, Geronimo de los Reyes, and Amado Tetangco. For the United States Embassy in Manila, he did the oil portraits of American historical personages in the Philippines, like William Howard Taft, Najeeb Saleeby, Chick Parsons, and Clara Phillips, between the years 2004 and 2007. He painted the official portraits of the heads of major universities like UP presidents Francisco Nemenzo Jr and Emerlinda Roman in 2008 and University of Santo Tomas Dominican rectors Rolando de la Rosa, Tamerlane Lana, Ernesto Arceo, and Herminio Dagohoy from 1992 to 2014. From 1988 to 1994, the CCP commissioned him to paint portraits of outstanding Filipino artists: Francisco Baltazar, Nicanor Abelardo, Gerardo de Leon, Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Carlos V. Francisco, Lucio San Pedro, and Hernando Ocampo. In 2011, he mounted an exhibit featuring women personalities including Josephine Cojuangco, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, Hetty Que, and Kaye Tinga.

Del Casal is most associated, however, with his fine religious works. His first exhibit titled Santong Garing (Ivory Saints), 1979, was held at the Sining Kamalig at the Manila Mandarin. This was followed by The Sacred and the Profane, 1986, Finale Art File, with art collector Joey de Leon; and Ang Pagdalaw ng TatlongHari (The Visit of the Three Kings), 1990, CCP Museum Hallway. Between 1992 and 1998, he held six exhibits at the Finale Art File, showing various images of angels in male and female Filipino period costumes, playing traditional Philippine instruments. In 1999, he did a show focusing on male angels in Greek classical style at the Ayala Museum. In 2005, he returned to the same religious theme at the Finale Art File, this time featuring santos or images of saints under virinas or glass dome covers. For the Loyola House of Studies, he did the portraits of famous Jesuits, including Saint Ignatius of Loyola and Horacio de la Costa. He painted the official portrait of San Pedro Calungsod that was used for the canonization rites at Saint Peter’s Basilica in Rome in 2013. He designed the stained glass windows of the Benedictine Retreat House in Silang, Cavite, in 2010. His major contribution to religious art, however, is in the works he did for the completion, renovation, and decoration of the Cubao Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception under Bishop Honesto Ongtioco. Between 2000 and 2015, he redesigned the altar and sacristy, the side altars, the ceilings, nave, and the facade and sides of the cathedral. He also painted the portraits of the Four Evangelists for the ceiling above the transept and the portraits of the 12 apostles installed on the walls of the nave, and designed the nine stained glass windows depicting scenes from the life of the Virgin Mary. With various architects and engineers, he also designed the cathedral’s rectory, columbary, and bishop’s residence. He is also well known for his exquisite designs for priestly vestments and the costumes of important Marian images like the La Naval and the Virgin of Manaoag.

In celebration of the centennial of the Philippine Independence and Republic, he mounted an exhibit in 1998 depicting Philippine heroines like Gregoria de Jesus, Teresa Magbanua, Melchora Aquino, and Trinidad Tekson. In the same year, he did two more history-themed exhibits: one focusing on the characters of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) like Crisostomo Ibarra, Maria Clara, Elias, Sisa, Padre Damaso, Fray Salvi, and Doña Victorina; and the other called La Filipina, showcasing Filipino women in different period costumes. In 1999, he did a sequel exhibit to the Noli, this time featuring characters from Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion) like Simoun, Kabesang Tales, Basilio, Juli, and Isagani. In 2004, he did the portraits of 15 of the 20 Women of Malolos as well as the recreation of the scene where the 20 Women of Malolos presented their "letter" to Gov-Gen Valeriano Weyler on 12 Dec 1888. Historical too are the illustrations del Casal did for the book Fashionable Filipinas: An Evolution of the Filipino National Dress in Photographs 1860-1960, 2015, depicting silhouettes of period costumes, both European and Philippine.

He dabbles in clay figure making. He did a portrait of National Artist Salvador Bernal in clay, 1985, and designed the figures of children at play adorning the entrance gate of the Quezon City Park and Wildlife Museum, 1983. Written by Annaliza B. Villar and Nicanor G. Tiongson

DELACRUZ, FIL (Filemon Perez de la Cruz) b. Hagonoy, Bulacan 22 Nov 1950. Printmaker. He is the son of Edilberto de la Cruz and Carmen Perez. He married Ma. Luz Buenaflor with whom he has two children. As a student of fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas, he learned the basics of etching and woodcut under MarioParial. He studied an archaic Western technique, mezzotint, which results in rich, deep black shades and delicate modulations and nuances of tints, and often combined this method with etching and aquatint. In 1982, he held a one-person show at the Hiraya Gallery where he demonstrated the process of mezzotint. He and his family run Artists’ Gallery in Parañaque City.

De la Cruz’s most noted subjects are members of indigenous cultural communities, particularly the Manobo of Kalamansig, Sultan Kudarat, with whom he lived for three years. He supported their struggles against land grabbers and loggers who ravage ancestral lands. His art is rich in indigenous symbols, such as the lizard, the egg, and the skull, which convey tribal values. The black-and-white medium suits the themes of displacement and deprivation experienced by these groups. In Thanatopses, 1981, a Manobo woman in ritual finery mourns the passing of the trees. At the same time, works like TheWivesofDatuBog, 1982, bring out the sensuousness and ornamental wealth of Manobo culture.

De la Cruz received awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: grand prize, Thanatopses, 1981; grand prize, Transmogrification, 1982; first prize, Goddess of the South, 1983; finalist, Aftermath, 1986; and finalist, Prayer for Nimula, 1986. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural CenterofthePhilippines in 1992.Written by Alice G. Guillermo

DELOTAVO, ANTIPAS (Antipas Polines Delotavo) b. Iloilo City 18 Mar 1954. Painter. He is the son of AntipasDelotavo Sr and Danara Polines. He obtained his art education at the Philippine Women’s University and joined the Center for the Advancement of Young Artists and Kaisahan. He was also a member of the ConcernedArtistsofthePhilippines.

He held his first one-person show at Art Associates in 1977. Portraiture is his forte, but he chooses his subjects from the anonymous crowd in busy thoroughfares. In his portraits of workers, each face is focused separately, marked with the vulnerability of the oppressed by becoming hardy with age and experience borne of survival and struggle. With characteristic economy of means, he has recreated the entire environment: the sights, textures, and smells of the city. In Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan (Dagger in the Heart of Mang Juan), the sharp bladelike thrust of the Coca-Cola sign appears to stab the old man’s heart.

His solo shows in 1978 and 1979 at the Ma-Yi Gallery consisted of portraits in oil, again of men and women of the urban poor against a background of whitewashed walls with traces of graffiti in keeping with the theme of the Kalburo (Whitewash) series. Themes relating to the exploitation of women made its appearance in Delotavo’s body of work in 1979. In mid-1982, his show Mga Bayaning Di Kilala (Unknown Heroes) was the product of the artist’s sojourn in the haciendas of Central Luzon where he observed the life of sugar plantation workers. His 1983 show at the Hiraya Gallery dealt with the subject of urban construction workers and their alienation from the grand structures they build. His Struktura (Structure), 1990, showed construction workers building the edifices of the Marcos period.

Delotavo has had over 13 one-man shows and continues to exhibit works that strongly emphasize his views, specifically that of worker’s struggle, alienation, and plays for power. Among his exhibitions are Mallcontents, 2013, and Oplan Noplan, 2014, both shown at Art Informal, Greenhills. His exhibition Agos (Current), 2016, at the Vargas Museum, University of the Philippines Diliman, gave a critical reflection on the Basi Revolt through paintings and installation work. Among his group shows are Recolonization: VFA and the Next Hundred Years, 1999, with Maria Cruz, shown at the Hiraya Gallery, Manila; Feast of the Forest, 2007, and Samu’t-Sari: Art for Biodiversity (Diversity: Art for Biodiversity), 2008, both shown in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan; GRRROAN→>GRRREEEN, 2013, shown at Liongoren Gallery, Cubao, for the Philippine Art Fair; and Picture Life: A Contemporary Still Life Exhibition, 2014, shown at Tin-Aw Gallery.

Delotavo won the grand prize in the 1979 Art AssociationofthePhilippines Annual Art Competition for his watercolor Kapos (Lack). He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines in 1990, Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the city of Manila in 2005, and Garbo sa Bisaya by the VIVA ExCon in 2012. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro
Dibella, Giovanni (See Alberoni, Cesare.)

DIEGO, DEMETRIO b. 9 Apr 1909. d. 15 Sep 1988. Illustrator, painter. He took up courses in fine arts at the University of the Philippines, but he never finished because he had to work for a living. Thus from 1929 he was employed as illustrator in the Tribune and Taliba. Later he became chief artist of the Sunday Times Magazine. He served as president of the Society of Philippine Illustrators and Cartoonists in 1964-65.

Diego made an impression on his employers at the Tribune because of his advanced skills in drawing. His drafting style was robust, his tonal values refined and dramatic, thus apt for the illustration of short stories and serialized novels. Because of his vigorous lines (and bold brushwork in his paintings), VictorioEdades regarded him as a potential modernist, and he enlisted him as one of the Thirteen Moderns.

Diego’s early period is best represented by Capas, 1948, a work containing elements that in two years’ time would appear as traits of Neo-Realistic genre. Capas is a poignant recreation of the suffering of Filipino-American forces that surrendered to the Japanese in 1942. It is a close-up of multi-decked bamboo cots where the sick soldiers are lying consumed by disease and hunger. The predominantly brown color scheme suggests the bleak situation while rugged textures and the shallow space where all the bodies are huddled evoke the prevailing discomfort. As chief artist of the Sunday Times from the 1950s to the early 1970s, Diego hardly had time for painting. He painted again sometime in 1974, turning to genre in a style influenced by magazine illustration but using bright hues. His Carabao Rice series was his most successful, showing his characteristic vigorous drafting style.

Diego won third prize for Siesta during Harvest Time at the second National Art Contest sponsored by the Kapisanan ng Paglilingkod sa Bagong Pilipinas or Kalibapi in 19 Jun 1944. His Capas won second prize at the first annual ArtAssociationofthePhilippines competition in 1948.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

DIZON, VICENTE (Vicente Alvarez Dizon) b. Bacolor, Pampanga 5 Apr 1905. d. 19 Oct 1947. Painter. Dizon graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1928 and from Yale University in 1936. He won scholarships at the Federal School of Arts, Minneapolis, Minnesota, and at Yale University. In Yale, he specialized in mural decoration, general art education, and museum administration. Upon his return, he taught drawing and art appreciation at the National Teachers College, Mapua Institute of Technology, and UP. In 1934, he published Art Appreciation and Education, a pioneering book on the subject in the Philippines. He illustrated for dailies and magazines as well as books—notably, Pamana ng Lahi, published in 1940. He also composed musical pieces like “Bato-Bato” (Stone-Stone), 1934, and “The Fifth Air Force March,” 1945.

His work After the Day’s Toil was exhibited and won a prize by popular vote at the pavilion for International Business Machines at the Golden Gate International Exposition at San Francisco, 1939. His works are found in many private collections in Boston, New York, and the Philippines.

Before World War II, he painted 39 watercolor drawings of different Filipino dress silhouettes from precolonial to modern times. He used these illustrations to make the Americans understand the complex culture of Filipinos. During the Battle of Manila in 1945, he finished an album of war scenes in the Philippines.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

DOCTOR, EDGAR b. Calabanga, Camarines Sur 7 Jan 1941. Painter, sculptor. A son of a baker and a dressmaker, his early experience in art involves wood carving, toy making, and performing in puppet shows. He got a degree in fine arts, major in painting, from the University of Santo Tomas in 1965. He also studied ceramics at the National Institute of Science and Technology. He worked as a volunteer art instructor and a member of the technical staff of the National Historical Commission.

Doctor has held 10 one-person shows and participated in numerous group shows both in the country and abroad. He represented the Philippines in the International Exhibition of Original Drawings at the Moderna Galeria, Rejikal Yugoslavia, 1970; the International Art Exhibition in Juvesy Sund, France, 1971; the 4th Indian Triennale, New Delhi, India, 1978; the Festival de la Peinture, Cagnes-Sur-Mer, France, 1981; and the 7th Biennial of Fine Arts, Valparaiso, Chile, 1985. He was part of the Philippine delegation for the ASEAN Travelling Show and Cultural Tour and the Travelling Exhibition and Cultural Tour to the People’s Republic of China, both in 1981.

His works echo the distinct style developed by the modernists, adding his own touch through a balance of lightness and depth within the figures that he paints. Doctor won awards at the Shell National Students Art Competition: third prize, Grazing Carabaos, 1960, and first prize, Rizal Monument, 1964. He won several times at the Annual Art Competition of the ArtAssociationofthe Philippines: third prize, Into the World of My Own, 1965; second prize, The Clowns, 1967; grand prize, Economic Aggression, 1972; and third prize, Ala-Ala # 9 (Memory # 9), 1976. At the annual exhibition of the Society of Philippine Sculptors in 1971, his work Metropolis # 2 was named best entry.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, with notes from Zeny May D. Recidoro

Source:

Navate-Camacho 1998.

DOLORICON, NEIL (Leonilo Ortega Doloricon) b. Lanuza, Surigao del Sur 1957. Painter. He is the son of Tomas Doloricon and Genoveva Ortega. He is married to Angela Manoga and they have three children. He grew up in the cities of Butuan and Surigao in Mindanao. He graduated with a fine arts degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1979. He was an artist of The Manila Times, a national daily newspaper. He served as a professor at the UP College of Fine Arts, and dean from 1998 to 2001. He served as secretary-general of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines.

He started by painting still lifes, then went on to abstract painting. Doloricon found his calling in socially committed art during a period of social and political ferment in the country. At age 18, he became involved with a group of socialist realist painters called Kaisahan, to whom he owes the growth of his social awareness. His works show his deep involvement with people, particularly those from the laboring classes, whom he treats not as an amorphous mass but as interesting individuals. His paintings contribute to a new image and truer characterization of the Filipino. The focus of these characterizations are specific portrayals of the struggles and plight of the Filipino working and farming class. Woodcuts such as Hacienda, 2014, and Iron Dragonfly, 1989, present the viewer with exploitation of nature and of the agency and rights of farmers. In Forces of Production, 2014, and Kalbaryo ng Anak Pawis (Calvary of the Toiling Masses), 2010, the focus is on the plight of workers and the effects of systematized violence.

His solo exhibitions include Fundamental and Digital, Now Gallery, 2013, and Dispossessed, Art Portal, Davao, 2015. He has also held exhibitions abroad, particularly at the Philippine Center in New York City and Centro Cultural de la Raza, San Diego, California. Since 1981, he has joined group shows both in the country and abroad, such as Lupa: Struggle for Land, Vargas Museum, 2013. Doloricon has won several prizes in various art festivals, design and caricature competitions. He was an artist in residence at UP in 1989. He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990 and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 2013.Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

DOMINGO, DAMIAN (Damian Gabor Domingo) b. Tondo, Manila 12 Feb 1796. d. Manila 26 Jul 1834. Painter. According to his will of 1834, he was the son of Domingo Macario and Erminigilda Gabriela. His parents’ possession of two Christian saints’ names instead of a Christian name and a traditional Spanish or Filipino surname confirms that they were Chinese immigrants who converted to Christianity or that they were children of Chinese immigrants who could not claim any important Chinese surname. This fact dismisses earlier suppositions or claims that Domingo was descended from Spanish nobility. He married Lucia Casas with whom he had 10 children, two of whom died in infancy. Domingo established his reputation as an artist by painting lifelike miniatures on ivory. By 1821, he already had such a large following that he had to open his house to take on trainees. On 2 Dec 1823, the Sociedad Economica de Amigos de Pais formalized his workshop as the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura. His appointment as professor was confirmed on 13 Jun 1826. On 9 Apr 1829, he gave the first examinations in the said school.

Sometime in the mid-1820s, Domingo must have met Rafael Daniel Baboom, a Catholic Indian merchant from Madras, who traded in silk. Baboom engaged Damian to paint albums that depicted the fashions and occupations of the various citizens of the Philippines. Damian executed several of those albums. Before World War II, six of these were extant but one was destroyed by fire. Meanwhile the album at the Newberry Library is the only one that Domingo signed individually on all the constituting plates.

Only four easel paintings have been ascertained as being painted by him: the Nuestra Señora del Rosario dando el Santisimo Rosario al Santo Domingo y Santa Catalina (Our Lady of the Rosary Giving the Most Holy Rosary to Saint Dominic and Saint Catherine), ca 1815; La Sagrada Familia (The Holy Family), ca 1830; La Catedra de San Pedro (The Seat of Saint Peter), ca 1825; and LaInmaculadaConcepcion (The Immaculate Conception). The first three are in the possession of his descendants; the last is in the Xavier University Folklife Museum and Archives. All these pieces are done in fine miniaturismo technique. These Domingo paintings were achieved by using five Chinese sable brushes, some equipped with just one bristle. Domingo’s brushwork is even finer in the albums of costumes for which he used gouache or water-based tempera on pith paper. According to historian Carlos Quirino, the only existing portrait of Domingo was done by his son Jose, based on a self-portrait on ivory (Quirino 1961). Domingo’s paintings provided a better understanding and insight into the appearances, clothing, and occupations of the Filipinos of his time, enriching the study of Philippine history.Written by Luciano P. R. Santiago and Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

Quirino 1961.

DOMINGUEZ, BOY (Federico Sulapas Dominguez) aka BoyD. b. Tangkulan, Bukidnon 9 Jun 1953. His parents are Francisco Francisquete Dominguez and Emiliana Nojeda Sulapas. He is married to Maria Teresa Cheng. A self-taught artist, he began to draw during his elementary school days and started painting when he was in high school. In college, he was first an architecture student at the University of Mindanao and then a fine arts visual communication student at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. He briefly joined the Kabataan Makabayan from 1971 to 1972, but only began to immerse in the mass movement in 1980, eventually joining UGATLahi Artist Collective and the Concerned Artists of the Philippines in the 1990s.

His influences include Philippine indigenous folk arts, the arts of post-Impressionist European masters, the arts of the Latin American muralists, the arts of the Chinese Cultural Revolution, Cuban and Russian protest arts, Japanese and Aboriginal arts, and American Indian folk art. He also cites various local painters, artists, and cartoonists as major influences: in his younger years, Adlao, a movie sign painter, and Suazo, a graphic artist, both based in Davao in the 1960s; in later years, visual artists Neil Doloricon, Nune Alvarado, Fred Liongoren, Leon Pacunayen, and Jose Tence Ruiz.

Although already based in Quezon City, Dominguez values and draws deeply from his Mandaya lineage for his life and art. His works do not only represent or invoke Mandaya folk imagery but participate in the struggles of indigenous peoples by foregrounding their issues and efforts toward self-determination, recognition and protection of their ancestral lands, and preservation of their culture and environment. Distinct for their vividness of color, intricacy of detail, political themes, and folk-indigenous infusions, Dominguez’s works have been categorized as social realist, although the complex and finely detailed juxtapositions of images in his works have also led to their being described as naif surrealist. In their highly nuanced appropriations of indigenous narratives, his works take on a mythopoetic quality, tying together the worldview and history of indigenous peoples with the national and democratic struggles of the mass movement.

Among Dominguez’s most recognizable works are Gatilyo (Trigger), 2013, a digitally enhanced copy of his 1984 painting Militarisasyon (Militarization), which got lost during an exhibit in the early 1990s. It bears an image of the blood-soaked Philippine flag being wrung by iron hands bearing the seal of the Republic of the Philippines and the emblem of the United States of America, dripping into a red sea of people in revolt. His Balilig Ritual, 2013, depicts the Mandaya healing ritual, a recurring image in his works throughout his career as a painter. Indeed, many of his paintings depict characters and motifs from indigenous folk mythologies, such as the busaw (blood spirit), limokon (dove), balyan (healer), and the great bird Minokawa.

Dominguez has held solo exhibits, such as the two-part exhibit Wa Ya Kila, 1984-85, at the Intercon Hotel Gallery and Manila Peninsula, and Dayaw (Celebration), 2010, at the NCCA Gallery in Intramuros, Manila. He has also joined group exhibits across a number of museums, galleries, and universities all over Metro Manila—among them, Hardware, 2001-2; Tutok Perspektiba (Focus Perspective), 2006-7; Pahina’t Kuadro Alay para sa Manggagawa (Pages and Frames as Offering to Laborers), 2007; Tutok Kargado (Focus Loaded), 2008; Kapital (Capital), 2010; Placards, 2011; Against the Current, 2013; Kasama II (Companion II) and Pumapapel (Acting to Be Noticed), both in 2014; and PortrAYAL: Faces for Freedom, 2015. He has also exhibited his works internationally, such as in the Ethno ExpoTravelling Exhibit from 1995 to 1997 in Europe; Missie Zendings Kalender in the Netherlands, With or Without You in Australia, and Dream for My Planet in France, all in 2001.

In 2013, he was awarded the Nippon Foundation Asian Public Intellectual research and art grant, which took him around Thailand and Indonesia to immerse with indigenous peoples’ groups. Written by Louise Jashil R. Sonido

DULAY, LANG b. Lake Sebu, South Cotabato 3 Aug 1924. d. 30 Apr 2015. Textile weaver. Her father was Kambay Kinteg and her mother was Luan Kasing Sengid. Belonging to the Tboli people, Lang Dulay learned to weave tnalak cloth at age 12, when she first “dreamed” of a tnalak design. As a master weaver, Lang Dulay has been recognized for her role in preserving the traditional designs of the tnalak. Her textiles are valued because of the “fine even quality of the yarn, the close interweaving of the warp and weft, the precision in the forms and patterns, the chromatic integrity of the dye, and the consistency of the finish.” At the time of her death, eight of her grandchildren had learned to weave.

Tnalak weaving uses abaca fibers using the tie-dye process. The process begins with stripping the stem of the abaca plant to extract the fibers. The threads are then dried, then manually tied into bands strand per strand. These strands are then set on the “bed-tying” frame made of bamboo, on which strands are laid out to resist the dye chosen by the weaver. Using natural dyes from plants, the traditional colors of tnalak cloth are red, black, and the natural color of the abaca. Using a backstrap loom, the design of the tnalak emerges through the ikat process where the weft threads are woven through the warp threads, binding the cloth together. As the whole process needs a great deal of attention and concentration, Tboli weavers usually abide by behavioral taboos during this time. Accordingly, they abstain from sex and avoid illness by ceremoniously passing a single abaca thread all over the body before beginning to weave. Lang Dulay never washes the tnalak with soap and avoids using soap when she is dyeing the threads in order to maintain the pureness of the abaca.

Among the Tboli, tnalak weaving is traditionally done by women. Called “dream weavers,” these weavers have explained that they get their inspiration for their designs from their dreams. Lang Dulay has said that the spirit of Fu Dalu would come to her dreams and show her tnalak designs. In her lifetime, she executed over a hundred designs, including the bulinglangit (clouds), the bankiring (hair bangs), and the kabangi (butterfly), aside from designs consisting of stylized crocodiles, butterflies, flowers, mountains, and streams. Each tnalak cloth is uniquely designed. The last tnalak that Lang Dulay wove was acquired by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA). The cloth featured her spelled name “LANG DULAY” vertically woven into the lower part of the textile (Espejo 2015).

The value of the tnalak cloth has changed over time. Before the 1960s, the Tboli bartered tnalak for horses and the textile was considered precious enough as dowry in wedding rituals. The introduction of the cash economy has affected the designs of the tnalak as designs are now imposed by buyers. Despite the fact that the modern designs are priced higher and easier to weave, Lang persisted in weaving the traditional designs which are complex and took longer to finish.

Lang Dulay was awarded the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA in 1998. The award helped her train 46 weavers from the time of her conferment until her retirement in 2011.Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Maricris Jan Tobias and Rizzi Gorospe

Sources:

Espejo 2015; GAMABA Committee, n.d.; Tobias, n.d.

DUMLAO, ANTONIO (Antonio Gonzalez Dumlao) b. Intramuros, Manila 30 Apr 1912. d. 27 Aug 1983. Painter. His father was Melecio Dumlao. He was admitted at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts in 1923, but did not pursue his studies beyond that year. He began his career in the arts at the Antonio Garcia Engraving firm, then worked at the Jean Bisson Advertising Company from 1935 to 1940.

Dumlao’s paintings are of the conservative school of representationalism. Essentially a figurativist, his human figures are solidly modeled but softened by a masterful handling of light and shadow. From the late 1940s to the early 1950s, he underwent a Filipinist phase during which he created monumental Mary figures garbed in ethnic-inspired costumes. He also Filipinized the Virgin Mary in Ina ng Lahi (Mother of the Race), 1952.

Dumlao painted murals for the Bank of America, Malacañan Palace, Bank of Commerce, MSA-Philcusa, ManilaHotel, Far Eastern University, and the Philippine Airlines terminals in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Oakland, Honolulu, Hong Kong, and Manila.

Dumlao received a gold medal at the MetropolitanTheater Art Exhibition in 1934. He also won second prize for Benguet Lily in the Filipiniana category, and first honorable mention for The Defense of Tirad Pass at the National Art Competition sponsored by the University of Santo Tomas in 1941. At the Art AssociationofthePhilippines (AAP) fifth annual exhibition in 1952, he won third prize, overall category, for Ina ng Lahi; a special award, best female figure, for Sultana; and another special award, best landscape, for Balut Island. He won third prize in the conservative painting category for Urduja at the AAP annual exhibit in 1954.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

DY, CHRISTINA (Christina Cabañeros Dy) b. Manila 9 Mar 1976. Painter and performance artist. She is the daughter of Marcelino Jacela Dy and Helen Obeña Cabañeros. She took up bachelor of arts in interdisciplinary studies at Ateneo de Manila University. She graduated in 1998 and began work toward a master’s degree at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Dy’s work as an illustrator and performer taps into the pulse of simple things. Her subjects exist in nature along with the human body, as the artist has taken on hair, plant life, fabric, and water to explore and elevate concepts of depth, symmetry, and repetition. By using charcoal, Dy not only whittles down her medium as she nears completion; she progressively closes the gap between skin and surface, using her bare fingers to achieve gradients and literally drawing herself closer to her work. Dy has distinguished herself not only for her large-scale works on paper but also for pieces done in situ that merge illustration and performance, blurring the boundaries and valuation between process and product. This sensibility is also expressed in Dy’s other pursuits, most notably her role as the founder of Polecats, the pole acrobatics dance troupe organized in 2010.

In 1999, Dy had her first solo exhibit titled Apples in the Garden of Eden, a series of oil paintings shown in Bistro 110, Makati City. This was followed by her participation in Secret Diaries, 2000, her first group show, at Surrounded by Water, Mandaluyong, Metro Manila. A later work, Curtains Matching Carpet, 2007, is an ephemeral and participatory piece, through which the artist’s fascination with hair was translated into a large drawing of strands on the walls of the Silverlens Galleries in Makati. In 2008, she took part in Beyond Frame: Philippine Photomedia, curated by Gina Fairley at the University of Technology Sydney in Australia, where Dy once again combined illustration with performance in Running with Scissors, 2008.

It was in Sydney that an obsession with seascapes and flora began to take hold of Dy as she created Soaplands, 2009, shown at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The theme also propelled Dy to do Between the Sea and Sky, 2009, at Silverlens Galleries. The large-scale charcoal drawing of the Sydney Harbour that Dy rendered in Between Sea and Sky was then scaled up to 3.6 meters by 18 meters, and was created over the span of three weeks for the 2010 Busan Biennale in Busan, South Korea. Dy collaborated with photographers Juan Caguicla and Corinne de San Jose, illustrating over and around their photographs in To Cut a Long Story, 2006, at the Lumiere Gallery in Makati and A Very Short Flowering Season, 2011, at the Silverlens Galleries. She is also credited as a production designer, contributing work to full-length independent films such as Auraeus Solito’s Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Olivares), 2005, and Quark Henares’s Rakenrol (Rock ’n’ Roll), 2011.

Dy was shortlisted twice for the Ateneo Art Awards: for Curtains Matching Carpet in 2008 and Soaplands in 2009. She received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2009. Written by Alice Sarmiento

EDADES, VICTORIO (Victorio Edades Edades) b. Dagupan, Pangasinan 23 Dec 1895. d. 7 Mar 1985. National Artist for visual arts. He was the son of Hilario Edades and Cecilia Edades. He married Jean Garrott, an American who also later taught English and drama at the University of the Philippines. Their daughter Joan is also a painter. Edades received his early education in town schools. In 1919, he left for the United States where he studied architecture and fine arts at the University of Wisconsin in Seattle during the school year and worked in the salmon canneries of Alaska during summer. In 1922, the traveling exhibit of the Armory show opened his eyes and that of the American public to the artistic ferment in Europe led by Cezanne, Gauguin, Matisse, Picasso, Duchamp, the surrealists, and the Dadaists. While the exhibition drew outcry from the conservative public, it gave Edades the direction he was looking for. Deviating from the academic style, but retaining much of its qualities such as its somber palette, he did two key paintings in 1928: TheSketch (sometimes called The Artist and His Model) and TheBuilders.

When Edades returned to the Philippines in 1928, he embarked on a crusade to change the course of Philippine art, which was then dominated by painter FernandoAmorsolo and sculptor GuillermoTolentino. Barely a month after his return, Edades had a one-person show in December at the Philippine Columbian Club. It was met with shock and disdain by a public accustomed to Amorsolo’s rural idylls. Edades decided to shift strategy: it was through teaching that he would conduct his campaign. In 1930, Edades helped organize the University of Santo Tomas (UST) Department of Architecture, where he also served as its acting head. The inception of the Department of Architecture subsequently led to the fine arts program. And in 1935, he was appointed director of the university’s College of Architecture and Fine Arts, putting UST at the forefront of modern art. Among Edades’s students in UST were National Artist Ang Kiukok, Jerry Elizalde Navarro, Antonio Austria, Manuel Baldemor, Norma Belleza, Charito Bitanga, Danilo Dalena, Angelito Antonio, Jaime de Guzman, Veronica Lim, Ramon Orlina, Leon Pacunayen, Edgar Doctor, and Rhoda Recto.

The year 1934 provided him with a new opportunity to reach the public through art when he was commissioned by the architect JuanNakpil to do a mural titled Rising Philippines for the lobby of the Capitol Theater on Escolta St. For his assistant, Edades chose CarlosV.Francisco aka Botong Francisco, the illustrator for the Philippine Herald, who in turn brought GaloB.Ocampo. Together, they formed the first triumvirate in modern Philippine art. Their first collaboration was followed by other murals for the State Theater, and for the private residences of Vicente and Ernesto Rufino, owners of Capitol and State, and Juan Nakpil, through whom these murals were commissioned. They also did the mural for the ceiling of the house of President Manuel Quezon in Pasay.

In the 1930s, the famous press battle between the modernists and conservatives erupted. In an interview with A. B. Saulo for an article in the Monday Mail, Edades fired the first shot by bewailing the conservative orientation of art and its insistence on the bright aspects of life while excluding the dark side of reality as a valid artistic subject. In addition to Edades, those who spoke for the modernists included Salvador P. Lopez and JoseGarciaVilla; the conservatives had Ariston Estrada, IgnacioManlapaz, and Fermin Sanchez on their side. The debate was interrupted by World War II, but resumed in 1948, this time with Edades and Tolentino on opposite poles, debating the merits and demerits of modern art on the pages of The Sunday Times Magazine and later This Week magazine of the Manila Chronicle broadsheet.

In 1937, Edades, Ocampo, and DiosdadoLorenzo organized the Atelier of Modern Art, which led to the public foregrounding of a group of artists Edades perceived as emergent modernists and whom he christened the Thirteen Moderns. This gesture boosted the cause of modernism with new talents. The support system for modernism was further strengthened with the founding of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) in 1948 and the PhilippineArtGallery in 1951. The struggle between modernists and conservatives came to a head in the AAP annual exhibition in 1955, which was marked by the walkout of conservatives who charged that the modernists had unfairly won.

Modernism opened the way to new artistic idioms, as well as enlarged the subject of art to span the entire range of human experience. Edades not only introduced modernism to the Philippines but also gave it his guidance and related it to the issue of national identity. He envisioned an art in which the artist was to pursue his original vision, while discovering his identity as Filipino.

His iconic works The Sketch or The Artist and His Model and The Builders, both dated 1928, are examples of the distinct visual language of Philippine modernism. The Sketch presents the viewer with a painter and his work in progress, while another person oversees his work. It might seem to the viewer that the painter is working on a portrait of the woman, but upon close inspection on his sketchbook, it seems that he is rather working on a still life of fruits arranged on a table in front of them. For a rather ordinary and self-absorbed scene, The Sketch gives both viewers and students of art history plenty of questions with regard to form and content, and in this respect the work is sometimes treated as an allegory on painting, or of the painter’s process and philosophy on art. In The Builders, the canvas is filled with laborers, bodies contorted and twisted to emphasize work and movement. The warm, deep colors of this work also enhances a sense of difficulty and struggle, and the clamor of a busy construction site—one can feel the heat and strain upon the laborers, and the frenzy of work furthered by two figures trying to lift a heavy steel object. In various respects, The Builders represents the massive structural, economic, and cultural growth that was occurring in Philippine cities during the early part of the 20th century at the expense of the working class, until this growth was interrupted and ultimately stunted by the repercussions of the war.

Among other works of Edades in the pre-World War II period are Mother and Daughter, Japanese Girl, and The Wrestlers, all in 1927; Dr. Frederick Staarr, My Sweetheart, The Artist and the Model, The Picnic, and The Market, all in 1928; and Woman with Idol, undated. After the war, he did Joan, 1949; Modern Maria Clara, 1955; Two Young People, 1964; Esther, 1965; Stella, 1966; Preparing for the Picnic, 1968; Susan, 1971; Poinsettia Girl, Nude, Bringing in the Catch, and Demoiselles de Davao, all in 1976; and Purita, 1977.

Edades received the Pro Patria Award during the Rizal Centennial Celebration in 1961 and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1964. He was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts in 1976. The retrospective exhibit Edades: From Freedom to Fruition was held in 2011-12 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, with the publication of the book of the same title. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

EMBUSCADO, RESTY (Restituto Embuscado) b. Nueva Ecija 1945. Painter, printmaker, and theorist. He took up his art studies at the Philippine Women’s University. In 1967, he formulated the concepts of dissectionism, communalism, and compartmentalism. In 1975, his book The Aesthetic of Dissectionism was published.

From 1984 to 1985, he launched three exhibits side-by-side, each one expressing his aesthetic views on the concepts of dissectional art, communal art, and compartmental art. In 1985, his exhibition catalog Dissectionism in the Nuclear Age was listed in the Art in America 85-86 Annual Guide to Galleries, Museums, Artists. In 1989, Embuscado exhibited his works at Smokey Mountain, a landfill in Tondo, Manila. In 1992, Embuscado taught “communal art” in response to the garbage-dependent life of Smokey Mountain communities. He was particularly focused on teaching children. Embuscado’s work infuriated state authorities as he associated the poor’s decrepit existence with the garbage-like quality of Filipino life. He protested, exposed, and exhibited this inhumanity, both in his writing and art. This politically charged exhibition in the summer of 1992 was censored both by the government and the National Museum. In 2000, Embuscado published Compartmental Art wherein he characterized his “declarations” as communal human intercourse, and a dissectional beginning working toward unity amidst ethnic (cultural and artistic) diversity.

Embuscado’s works express his view of existence as a spiritual, rather than a material and physical, undertaking. The figures in his works, as with the face of Jesus in The True Christ, take on abstracted and fragmented forms. Each line and dot, expressed as jabs of ink or color, appear to stand on their own and yet share a connection or an affinity to others, as these are assembled on the canvas in order to form a coherent, albeit unnatural image. His style is elucidated further in many of his essays. In The Two Christs, Embuscado relates his dreams in which Christ appears. He writes: “the false Christ is dying but the True Christ is not.” He relates too of an “existence separate from nature,” and that the True Christ as a “dissectional man” is not a historical figure for “the history of the world belongs to the speculative matters … a composition of organic form.”

Movement-D, an ink work in the possession of the Ateneo Art Gallery, is composed of layers of geometrical lines and shapes, forming a complex and dynamic image. In Dissectionism in the Nuclear Age, he speaks of a “common center” that is dissected, fragmented and one that blurs the boundaries rather than clarifies distinct planes of existence showing the essence of things. Despite being highly theoretical, Embuscado manages to relate his worldview and philosophical pronouncements to the context of his time. Eschewing the existence of art for art’s sake, which he says draws upon a dead context, he attempts instead to speak to current conditions of political instability and poverty in relation to material conditions, as well as spiritual and intellectual concepts.

Embuscado officially represented the Philippines at the India Triennial in 1968 at Delhi, India; Sao Paulo Biennial with Napoleon Abueva and Cesar Legaspi, 1969; and the first Biennial of Contemporary Painting in Italy, 1969. He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1970. Written by Zeny May D. Recidoro

Source:

Dissectional Art, n.d.

ENRIQUEZ, RAFAEL (Rafael Villanueva Enriquez) b. Nueva Caceres (now Naga), Camarines Sur 1 Jul 1850. d. 5 May 1937. Painter. He is the son of Antonio Enriquez y Seguera and Ciriaca Villanueva, both immigrants from Spain. He studied at Ateneo Municipal and Academia de Dibujo y Pintura. He received his bachelor’s degree from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he also enrolled in law. At 18, he continued his law studies at the Universidad Central de Madrid in Spain. After getting his licenciado en derecho (law degree) in 1874, he enrolled in painting at the Real Academia de San Fernando. From 1879 to 1887, he lived in Paris where he did portrait painting. In 1887, he went to London where he finished a historical canvas, La Muerte de D. Simon de Anda (The Death of D. Simon de Anda), which won a medal at the Exposicion General de Filipinas (Philippine General Exposition) in Madrid, 1887. The painting was later acquired by the National Library, Manila. He returned to Manila in 1896, in time to witness the execution of JoseRizal.

Enriquez was one of the organizers of the Sociedad Internacional de Artistas, and it was partly due to his initiative that the society held an exposition of fine and industrial arts in Manila in 1908. He was the first director of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts and was its head for 17 years.

Enriquez’s works depict foreign themes, figures, and scenes, as in San Agustin (Saint Agustin); Una Jitana Tocando la Pandereta (A Gypsy Lady Playing the Tambourine), 1875; Una Dama de la Edad Media (A Middle-Aged Woman); Carmen de Granada (Carmen of Granada); Alhambra; La Lealtad Filipina (Philippine Loyalty); A Portrait of a Young English Woman, 1888; Jesus con Cruz a Cuestas (Christ Carrying the Cross), 1890; San Francisco de Asis (Saint Francis of Assisi); El Juicio de Dios (The Judgement of God); and El Paño de la Veronica (Veronica’s Veil). Two of his works, Un Patio Andaluz (Andalucian Yard) and Un Jitano Tocando la Guitarra (A Gypsy Playing the Guitar), are at the Jorge B. Vargas Museum while four of his works are at the UST Museum.Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

ERMITAÑO, TAD (Luis Thadeus Debuque Ermitaño) b. Manila 10 May 1964. Transmedia artist. He is the son of Luis Monreal Ermitaño and the late Rolina Divinagracia Debuque. Ermitaño earned a bachelor of science in philosophy from the University of the Philippines in 1991 and took further studies in biology in Japan.

His solo exhibition Passage, Pablo Gallery, The Fort, 2011, was the opening exhibition in the series of video-related projects lined up in the End Frame Video Art Project 3 organized by the curatorial collective Visual Pond. Passage was a site-specific work consisting of multiple video projections on the gallery’s walls and staircase. It was the explicit intention of the artist that the beholder’s body would experience heightened sensations of sight and sound as it progressed through the gallery’s two levels. The visitor’s spatio-temporal and sensory experience tied into the exhibition title as did the crossing over from the real to the fictional that Ermitaño pegged on journey genre staples Alice in Wonderland and Dr. Who. Ermitaño made use of video mapping to transform the staircase into a faux fluid surface and created a spatial marker upon an inner wall which housed cabinets to turn this section into a portal that a beholder could aspire to virtually cross through.

Ermitaño’s group exhibitions include Surrounded by Idiots, Surrounded by Water, 2000; Centrifugal Vision, Video Circle 2000; HKUST Exposition Hall, 2000; Interruption, Big Sky Mind, 2001; videoart.mov, Greenbelt Cinema 1, 2002; Katawan (Body), Satti Event in Gravity, Multimedia Art Asia Pacific, The Art Gallery, National Institute of Education, Singapore, 2004; Cinema Purgatorio, National Commission for Culture and the Arts, 2005, and Ogaki Biennale, Ogaki City, 2006; Dime a Dozen, Lopez Museum, 2007; ISEA2008 Main Juried Exhibition, National Museum, Singapore, 2008; We Said Our Piece, Cultural Center of the Philippines, 2009; Drifted Narratives, Hong Kong Arts Centre, Wanchai, 2009; From Here to Ear, Outer Space Gallery, 2010; Reverb, Lopez Museum, 2011; Modes of Impact, Ateneo Art Gallery, 2012; Listen to My Music, Vargas Gallery, University of the Philippines, 2013; The Philippine Contemporary, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, 2012-15; Sensorium, Ayala Museum, 2013; extra/ordinary, Black Box Gallery, Publika, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, 2013; Consumer vs The Power of Industry: Society Who Criticize Technology, Galeri Nasional, Jakarta, Indonesia, 2013; Reality Distortion Field, SABAW Media Art Kitchen, 2013, and Singapore Biennale 2013, Singapore Art Museum; Immaterial Frontiers, Ateneo Art Gallery and Nanyang Technological University, 2013; and Sensorium 360, Singapore Art Museum, 2014.

His inclination toward performative genres is also demonstrated in his collaborative projects with fellow transmedia artists such as Caliph8, Malek Lopez, and Tengal Drilon; work with theater and dance artists for Tanghalang Pilipino and Ballet Philippines; and video and film festivals such as the 2004 Singapore International Film Festival, the 2008 Sinekalye Video and Film Festival, and the 2009 Silent Film Festival. Ermitaño was awarded residencies at the National University of Singapore, 2008, and the Hong Kong Arts Centre, 2009. Written byEileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Source: Ermitaño 2011, n.d.

ESCORA, FRANCISCO (Francisco Hipolito Escora) aka Kiko Escora. b. Manila 21 Apr 1970. Painter. He is the son of Jose Escora and Leticia Hipolito and the brother of artist Fernan Escora. He is mostly self-taught but was able to take units in studio arts at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman.

A mixture of surrealism, hyperrealism, and graphic design characterizes Escora’s body of work. His earlier pieces were surrealist in orientation as these displayed a preference for portraying human figures with exaggerated anatomical features. Works in his solo exhibit Café Ennui, 2001, however, were more clearly about playing up the human body and its fleshiness. The oil paintings Piece of Meat as Woman and Piece of Meat as Man are made up of headless and armless bodies set upon a table ready for consuming. This show contrasts with another solo exhibit Synthetic Solitude, wherein Escora’s flat-looking, cartoonish, graphic design-inspired portrait paintings are much less fleshy but still amiable as human beings. Armed with the skills needed for hyperrealist rendering, Escora later became known for work that combined gritty imagery and pop art influences. An occasional club disc jockey, Escora is not only familiar with the members of this subculture made up of habitués of the night who have appeared as subjects of his portraits—he is also one of them.

Escora held his first solo exhibition, Paintings, 1996, at the Penguin Café Gallery. This was followed by Drawings, 1999, at The Drawing Room. He has also had solo exhibitions in Boston Gallery, Big+Small Art Co., Pinto Art Gallery, SM Megamall Art Center, Kish, and Alliance Française de Manille. Escora has also had solo shows in Utterly Art Exhibition Space and Taksu, Singapore, and at Ark Gallerie, Indonesia. In 2009, he undertook Mapping Asia, a solo exhibition which was a special project of the China International Gallery Exposition.

Escora has been part of local group exhibitions in the UP Vargas Museum, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), GSIS Museo ng Sining, Ayala Museum, Ateneo Art Gallery, Green Papaya Art Projects, Boston Gallery, and The Drawing Room. His works have been featured in exhibits and art fairs in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, India, United Arab Emirates, USA, Italy, France, and Switzerland. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2003.Written by Iris De Ocampo

ESPIRITU, OSCAR (Oscar Pindon Espiritu) b. 3 Feb 1895. d. 13 Jun 1960. Painter, teacher. He was the son of Manuel Espiritu, an acclaimed painter in the 19th century, and Anselma Pindon. When his parents died, Espiritu was raised by his uncle Anselmo, also an acclaimed painter and sculptor. He graduated from the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts in 1928 as a self-supporting student. His paintings graced the covers of Graphic and PhilippineMagazine in the 1930s. He taught art at the Instituto de Mujeres, and he founded the Academy of Fine Arts in his house in Sampaloc in 1937.

Espiritu is a painter of original subjects in the conservative tradition. Since technique and style are limited by the rules of academic painting, Espiritu sought to widen realistic expression by introducing new subjects. In 1940, he painted Old Woman Pounding Buyo. Although the theme was common, Espiritu innovated the rendering of the subject by painting a full figure seated in a room with a bamboo floor flooded with light. Espiritu also painted Madonna of the Lanzones, which showed the Virgin and the child holding a cluster of lanzones. He also did Christmas genre scenes which show a country road strategically lit by Christmas lanterns. Espiritu’s widening of realistic expression is a testament to artists being able to work within certain restraints.

Espiritu won first prize at the 1938 Bureau of Education-sponsored art exhibition for his Portrait of Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

ESQUILLO, ALFREDO JR (Alfredo Dorado Esquillo Jr) b. 16 Nov 1972. Visual artist. His parents are Alfredo Z. Esquillo Sr and Estrellita Dorado. Esquillo graduated in 1993 with a fine arts degree in painting from the University of Santo Tomas.

Esquillo’s art involves astute observations of Philippine culture and history, engaging themes of identity, veneration, survival, and the persistent performativity of the self, often realized through the ethos of salvation which Esquillo articulates as transformation. He gathers material from folklore, cult rituals, and historic archives, as he explores these themes in richly composed, meticulously rendered paintings, and ingeniously staged mixed media works which include assemblages, installations, videos, and performances. His works show the strong influence of both social realist painters and magic realists. Esquillo composes complex scenes of individuals or throngs of people in ritual settings: be it a crowded procession, an imagined assumption, or an apocalyptic scene. His paintings explore a multilayered geography of existence and faith. From Plaza Miranda in Quiapo, to domestic spaces, to visions of destruction and deliverance, Esquillo traverses both inner and outer landscapes: that which he calls loob (inner self), labas (the larger world or beyond self), and lalim (depth). Similar to his manifold interest in spirituality, existence, and being, he takes his brush to unconventional grounds—painting on rubber sheets (ethyl-acetate vinyl), canvas strips woven into ground resembling mats, and pineapple fiber.

Mamakinley, Esquillo’s contribution to the exhibition The American Effect: Global Perspectives on the United States 1990-2003 at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 2003, is a provocative work depicting a grim figure clad in Victorian attire cradling an infant. Cloaked in dark velvet cloth are eagle claws, the barrel of a gun, and a foreboding grimace, all hidden from the unwitting infant in the adult’s lap. This is the artist’s commentary on Philippine relations with the United States: from the deceptions of benevolent assimilation to strains of neocolonialism operating well beyond the Philippine declaration of national independence.

These reflections on Philippine history spill over to the artist’s observations of contemporary faith practices, which in several senses are hybrid and multifarious as seen in his joint exhibitions with artist Renato Habulan: Semblance / Presence, 2012, National University of Singapore Museum, and Loob, 2014, Jorge B. Vargas Museum, University of the Philippines Diliman, 2014. The works in these exhibitions focus on the leader of a local cult, Lauro, who believed himself an incarnation of Christ. Both Esquillo and Habulan chronicled Lauro’s life through photographs and videos, immersing themselves in the context of faith amid the din and clamor of city life. Esquillo specifically essays a piercing scrutiny of belief, through paintings, sculptures, and video. He depicts Lauro as a reincarnation of Christ reinterpreted in searing realism with respect to different aspects of salvation. In the context of Esquillo’s visual grammar, each and every form conveys a crucial balance between belief and skepticism.

Esquillo won the grand prizes for the Metrobank Painting Competition, 1993, and the Philip Morris ASEAN Art Awards, 1995. He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2003. Written by Tessa Maria Guazon

Sources:

Esquillo, n.d.; Finale Art File, n.d.; Fukuoka, n.d.; National Portrait Gallery, n.d.; Silverlens Galleries, n.d.
Estella, Ramon (See Film volume.)

FABIE, SEVERINO C. b. Agno, Pangasinan 4 Feb 1894. d. ca 1950. Painter, sculptor, teacher. Fabie received certificates in painting and sculpture in 1917. Throughout his stay in the University of the Philippines (UP), he received six medals and a number of honorable mentions in various classes. He was the only sculptor who avidly supported VictorioEdades’s campaign for modern art. He enrolled again at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) College of Architecture and Fine Arts when Edades organized these courses in that school. Fabie, therefore, obtained another degree of fine arts in UST. Fabie was immediately recruited to the UST faculty, serving as a professor till his death.

Fabie was active in both painting and sculpture. His paintings are executed in the academic tradition, solidly defined by strong but finely modulated lighting as in the work Man with a Newspaper, 1925, found at the UP Vargas Museum collection. Under the influence of Edades, he seems to have had adopted thick impasto. His paintings are also found at the Central Bank collection, the UST Museum Gallery, and the National Museum of the Philippines.

Fabie’s sculptures stand out for their daring stylization. Forsaking the classicism espoused by GuillermoTolentino, his sculptures were characterized by bold contours, stylized poses, and modernistic cold polish. In line with the modernistic movement spearheaded by Edades and the architect JuanNakpil, Fabie’s style is thus linked to the shift to art deco as it complemented the murals of the Edades Atelier and Nakpil’s theater lobbies. Only one of Fabie’s sculptures seems to be extant today—namely, the Lady with Mandolin, 1940, at the National Museum. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, with notes from Cecilia S. De La Paz

FAJARDO, BRENDA (Brenda Villanueva Fajardo) b. Manila 18 Feb 1940. Painter, stage designer, art educator, curator. She is the daughter of Valeriano F. Fajardo and LibertadVillanueva, a folk dance scholar. Her sister, MaryJoan, is a dancer and choreographer. She holds a degree in agriculture from the University of the Philippines (UP) in Los Baños, 1959, a master’s degree in art education from the University of Wisconsin, USA, 1967, and a doctoral degree in Philippine studies from UP Diliman in 1997. She has taught abroad, at the Wisconsin public schools of Madison and Stevens Point; and locally at Ateneo de Manila University and the College of the Holy Spirit. In 1976, she became a faculty member of the UP Department of Humanities (renamed Department of Art Studies in 1989), where she served as chairperson from 1985 to 1991. She also served as curator of the UP Jorge B. Vargas Museum from 1995 to 2001. Upon her retirement in 2005, UP honored her with the title Professor Emeritus.

She studied printmaking under Manuel Rodriguez Sr, which led to a body of artworks in the graphic arts embodying personal introspection on the themes of self-liberation. She is known for her Baraha ng Buhay Pilipino (Playing Cards of Filipino Life) aka Tarot Card series in the late 1980s, which appropriated the images of the babaylan (shaman), gaga (fool), salamangkero (magician), among others, to provide commentary on various thematic tableaux of her paintings. Art critic Alice Guillermo described Fajardo as the “High Priestess of Tarot,” explaining that the tarot as a device allowed the artist to “not only deal with the personal vicissitudes of an individual but also touches on the large movements of a country’s collective experience” (Guillermo 2001, 93). Fajardo found inspiration from Philippine history and myths, interpreting the colonial past in the light of contemporary issues of migration, human rights, political corruption, and women’s rights. Her series on Labaw Donggon in the mid-1990s featured the epic myths of Panay, exploring issues of history, ecology, women, and power. She also utilizes diaries or letters as handwritten narratives to frame the discourse of bayani or heroes/heroines in Philippine history, inscribed in the border of her paintings.

Fajardo had her first solo exhibition of paintings in 1974 at the Kalinangan ng Lahi Gallery in Quezon City. From 1981 to 1989, she has held several exhibitions at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Notable exhibitions are Baraha ng Buhay Pilipino (Playing Cards of Filipino Life), 1990, at the UP Visayas, and Buhay Pilipino (Filipino Life), 1994, her special exhibit for Galerie le Rond Point in Paris, which was premiered at the CCP. She also joined group shows held mostly at the CCP. In 2010, she had a solo exhibit, Divination: Brenda Fajardo Retells History, at the UP Vargas Museum. She was a participating artist in international exhibitions, such as those in Cuba and in Brisbane, Australia. Her works are part of the art collection in the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum, Museum of Contemporary Art in Tokyo, Queensland Art Gallery in Brisbane, Australia, and the Singapore Art Museum.

She has also worked in theater mostly for productions of the Philippine EducationalTheaterAssociation (PETA): as set and costume designer for May-I,May-I, 1979; Galileo Galilei, 1981; and Pilipinascirca1907, 1982. She acted in plays such as Mother Courage, 1985, and MgaAma,MgaAnak (Fathers and Sons), 1977. She directed Mapait sa Bao (Bitter Coco), 1980; June Bride, 1986; and Damas de Noche (Women of the Night), 1991. She has conducted theater workshops all over the country.

She was co-founder of the Philippine Art Educators Association, Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan or KASIBULAN, Baglan Art and Culture Initiatives for Community Development, and Dalubhasaan sa Sining at Kultura or DESK. Her involvement in outreach projects for the CCP, National Commission for Culture and the Arts, and National Research Council of the Philippines also focused on the development of a community of artists in the regions, advocating the value of local research and resources as a strategy of cultural empowerment.

She authored books, including Ang Inukit na Kaalamang Bayan ng Paete (The Carved History of Paete), 2005, and coauthored several textbook projects on art and the humanities, such as Asian Art and Culture, 2012.

Fajardo won awards in the Annual Graphics Art Competition of the Printmakers Association of the Philippines, 1968; honorable mention for Landscape, 1970; first prize for Feeling and Form Series 3-11 and third prize for Bukas Ngunit Tikom (Open But Close), both in 1975. For her contribution to Philippine visual arts, she was awarded the CCP Thirteen Artists in 1992, the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts in 1999, Gatpuno Antonio Villegas Award from the city of Manila in 2005, and the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for visual arts in 2012.Written by Malou M. Maniquis, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

Guillermo 2005.

FAROL, NOEL (Noel Elmido Farol) aka El Farol. b. Pasig, Rizal 22 Aug 1961. Painter, printmaker, mixed-media artist. He is the son of Marcelino Farol and Monica Elmido. He finished drafting technology in 1979 at the Technological University of the Philippines (TUP) and bachelor of fine arts in 1981 at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU). He took up graduate studies at the University of Santo Tomas and master of arts in art education at Shizuoka University in Japan in 1991. He serves as department head of the College of Fine Arts at TUP, assistant professor of fine arts at PWU, and lecturer at the De La Salle College of Saint Benilde School of Arts and Design.

Farol’s works were shown in the Young Art in Asia Now, an Asian traveling exhibition, in 1980; Skystrokes, Pinta Nueve Flying Painting Competition at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) in 1981; Kirotique at Sining Kamalig in 1983; Piglas (To Be Free), 1986, CCP; Banaag (Light), 1989, CCP; and A-Value group exhibit at Shizuoka Prefectural Museum of Art in Japan. His first one-person exhibit was held in Shizuoka, Japan, showing his use of different materials, such as wood, stone, glass, bark, fiberglass, and wood dust, as media in painting and sculpture. In 1991, he had another exhibit, Mga Larawan sa Papel, Mga Gasgas na Salamin (Pictures on Paper, Scratches on a Mirror), in Hiraya Gallery.

Among his award-winning works are the mixed-media print (diptych) Dreams Sent by God, 1982, best entry, ArtAssociationofthePhilippines(AAP) Annual Art Competition; the mixed media painting Beach Boy, 1986 Metrobank competition; Si Wonderboy, Isang Rebolusyonista, Bakasyonista (Wonderboy: Revolutionist, Vacationist), a print on silkscreen and embossment combined with glass etching, 1987 Philippine Association of Printmakers competition; and the mixed media print Christmas Surprise, grand prize, 1986 AAP art competition. Farol joined solo shows and curates exhibitions by young artists in ventures such as Dust, 2014, at the National Commission for Culture and the Arts Gallery.Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

FELEO, ROBERTO (Roberto Bulatao Feleo) aka Bob Feleo. b. Manila 9 Sep 1954. Painter, sculptor, art educator. He is the son of Rosendo N. Feleo and Purificacion Bulatao. He married Cecille Laxamana. He studied fine arts history in the University of the Philippines (UP) and in Philippine Women’s University and then became a fellow at the Virginia Center for Creative Art in Virginia, USA, 1988. Feleo was the chief designer of Comite de Festejos, an art and design workshop, and visiting teacher-artist at the Philippine High School for the Arts in Mount Makiling, Laguna, until 2007. He serves as a faculty member of the UP College of Fine Arts, honing the skills of the students since 1990. As a mentor, his focus on his students allows them to widen their creativity as he takes them under his wing.

Feleo’s subjects are sociohistorical commentary. His works—like the Tau-Tao series and Virinas series, figures made from sawdust as his signature medium—continue the line of commentary on society, adding elements from Philippine folklore and history. These figures of prominent personalities taken from different parts of history are encased in a bell-shaped glass and displayed like religious saints and icons. His works reflect an imagination, which is simple, naive, playful, wise, and elemental. In his art, he consciously uses ethnic images like the anitos and pintados (literally, “painted” or tattooed natives), folk icons like San Miguel, the crucified Christ and the Virgin Mary, and popular images like Darna.

He has held several one-person exhibits—among them, Sapin-Sapin ni Feleo (Feleo’s Layer upon Layer), Hiraya Gallery, 1985; Sapin-Sapin sa Kahoy at Salamin (Layer upon Layer on Wood and Glass), Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1987, and Fukuoka Art Museum, Japan, 1988; and Roberto Feleo, Centro Provincial de Artes Plasticas y Disefto, Havana, Cuba, 1989. He participated in group shows such as the 3rd Asia-Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art, 1999, Queensland Art Gallery, Brisbane, Australia; Bound, 2010, and Handumanan (Memories), 2012, both at the Jorge B. Vargas Museum, Quezon City; and Welcome to the Jungle: Contemporary Art in Southeast Asia from the Collection of Singapore Art Museum, 2013, Contemporary Art Museum, Kumamoto and Yokohama Museum of Art, Nishi-ku, Yokohama, Japan. He did all the illustrations of native gods and beliefs in The Soul Book of Francisco Demetrio, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, and Fernando Zialcita, 1991.

He won several awards including the 1984 grand prize of the first Metrobank Foundation painting competition for August 6 and the 1988 CCP Thirteen Artists Award.Written by Pauline Mangilog, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Katrina Yap

Source:

Feleo 2014; Snippets 2009c.

FER, ANA (Anna Policarpio Ferrazinni-Mangahas) b. Pasay City 13 Jul 1941. Painter. She is the daughter of Anselmo Ferrazinni and Consuelo Policarpio. She is married to Mahar Mangahas. Their daughter is the anthropologist Maria F. Mangahas. She studied at the Immaculate Conception College in Davao and Holy Ghost College in Manila. She took fine arts courses in life painting and drawing at the University of the Philippines (UP), 1964-65. From 1970 to 1972, she took a graduate course in Asian studies at the Asian Center, UP Diliman. In 1979, she held her first one-person exhibition of drawings, Emanation, at the Hyatt Regency. In 1980, she participated in the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines first annual art exhibition in Davao, where she was based for many years. In 1983, Fer, then project illustrator of the “Kudaman” project of the French anthropologist Nicole Revel-McDonald on the Tagbanwa of Palawan, held another exhibition, Palawan Highlands, at the Heritage Art Center. These works, influenced by Balinese figuration, showed the Tagbanwa while living out their rituals and daily activities, as well as navigating their mountain setting.

Fer participated in exhibitions by social realists at the Pinaglabanan Galleries and at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1987. She also participated as artist in the Pananaw Palawan (Palawan Views and Perspectives), 1999, an exhibition curated by Revel-McDonald at the CCP. She has done numerous illustrations, posters, and murals with sociopolitical and feminist themes, such as Triptiko ng Lupa: Indya at Illustrada, Diwata, Lupang Tigang (Triptych of the Land: Native Woman and Elite Woman, Muse, Barren Soil), 1999, exhibited at the CCP Bulwagang Carlos Francisco. In 2012, her work, Favali at ang Iba Pang Biktima (Favali and the Other Victims), 1987, was included in the exhibit Recollection 1081: A Clear and Present at the CCP, which commemorated the 40th anniversary of the declaration of martial law. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

FERNANDEZ, EDGAR (Edgar Talusan Fernandez) aka Egai Fernandez. b. Caloocan City 20 Jan 1955. Painter. He is the son of Eliodoro Fernandez and Ester Talusan. He is married to Nena Gajudo. Their children are Malaya, a resident artist at Sofitel, and Diwa, a freelance web designer. He studied fine arts at the Philippine Women’s University. He started painting in 1974 and first made his mark when he won the grand prize for his abstracts in the “Civilization” art competition sponsored by the Kenneth Clark television series of the same title. In 1976, he joined the Center for the Advancement of Young Artists and later became associated with Kaisahan, a group of politically oriented young artists who painted murals for rallies and symposia. He was also a founding member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines. Fernandez has led various organizations: as president of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), 1983; as president of the Christian Art Society of the Philippines, 1987; as president of the Agos Kulay Watercolor Group, 1999; and as head of the Visual Art Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), 2007-10. He is the vice president of the Filipino Visual Arts and Design Rights Organization; the secretary general of Intramuros Visual Artists, Philippines; and consultant curator of the NCCA.

He was an abstract painter and later became a leading social realist. He made paintings, reliefs, and three-dimensional works. His paintings include those of the mother-and-child which he has reinterpreted according to the conditions of struggle, wherein the absent father signifies his engagement in the arena of conflict. Bagong Umaga (New Morning), 1980, and Hanap ay Laya (Seeking Freedom), 1984, make use of color symbolism, while Martsa ng Bayan para sa Katotohanan, Katarungan at Kalayaan (National March for Truth, Justice and Freedom), 1984, and Pandora ng Karunungan (Pandora of Wisdom), 1983, take off from political events.

His works have been exhibited locally and internationally in Australia, China, Hong Kong, Iraq, Japan, New York, Paris, and Singapore. Some of his paintings were also chosen for several Philippine stamps in 1993, 2001, and 2003. While majority of his works are paintings, he has done three-dimensional work in wood carving, wood relief, and experimental works such as Kinupot, from the Filipino “kinuha” (picked up) and “sinupot” (bagged), 1978, in which a blanket smothers figures in struggle.

Fernandez was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990. His earlier awards were won in the University of Santo Tomas on-the-spot painting competitions, 1974-75; the painting contest with the theme civilization sponsored by Compro Philippines, 1976; the AAP competition, where he won third prize for Kinupot; the Sining: Alay sa Kabataan competition of the Makati North Rotary Club, 1979; Young Art in Asia (now Hong Kong Arts Centre) competition, 1980; the AAP 34th Annual Art Competition, 1981; the 2nd Art of Ecology competition where he won the grand prize, 1990; the Gallery Genesis competition, where he won one of the best in watercolor, 1996, and best in watercolor (Hall of Fame), 2009. He was awarded the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 2006.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Czarina Lopez.

Sources:

Charis: Boundary Crossing 2014; Erehwon Artworld Corporation 2014; GMA News Online 2013; Manila Bulletin 2012; Museum Foundation of the Philippines 2010; Stanze 2000; Takenaka and O’Grady 2014.

FERNANDEZ, HONRADO (Honrado Ramoso Fernandez) aka Hony Fernandez b. Cabanatuan City 14 Aug 1949. d. Laguna 26 Apr 2005. Painter, sculptor, architect. He was the son of Nicolas Fernandez and Angelina Ramoso. He married Josephine Evangelista with whom he had two children. He finished a bachelor’s degree in architecture at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1971, a master’s degree in engineering, architectural design, at the Tokyo Institute of Technology in 1975, and a doctor’s degree in the science of art and design at the Tsukuba University in 1988. His first one-person show of sculptures and paintings was at the Asian Institute of Tourism, Quezon City, in 1983; his subsequent shows were at the Art for Architecture Gallery at Tradewinds in 1989, and at the Ayala Museum in 1990. He served as director of the Coordinating Center for Visual Arts of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines, 1989-90. As a practicing architect, he was an executive trustee of the Center for Philippine Architecture under the United Architects of the Philippines. He was also dean of the UP College of Architecture from 1990 to 1999, and executive director of the Philippine High School for the Arts until 2005.

While the sculptures of his 1978-80 Gilho period focused on the supple human form, he later shifted to planometric sculpture in white, black, or colored metal strips folded and counterfolded in open compositions recalling origami. With these works, he began his Formal and Spatial Pattern series in painting, sculpture, and architecture through which he worked on various theories, principles, and methods involved in the organization of forms and spaces. In an open setting, Fernandez’s sculpture assumes the character of lines in oriental calligraphy interacting with the surrounding space. Also in regard of the figure-space theme is a series made of bands and wire mesh which are curved, twisted, or folded in order to bring out the values of plasticity and flexibility. Space interpenetrates into the figure and around it in these pieces. In later works, the metal planes are cut into basic figurative shapes, painted in various hues, and lightly treated with acid for textural interest.

The UP College of Architecture launched in 2006 the Honrado R. Fernandez Architectural Writing Competition held every two years to honor the memory of Fernandez. In 2007, the Jorge B. Vargas Museum in UP Diliman held an exhibition titled Form and Substance: The Works of Dean Honrado R. Fernandez.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S.
