De La Paz and Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Asia Research News 2014; Notes from the Editor Singkit 2005.

FIGUEROA, MELECIO (Melecio Magbanua Figueroa) b. Arevalo, Iloilo 29 May 1842. d. Manila 30 Jul 1903. Sculptor, engraver. He married Enriqueta Romero, a Madrileña. His father was Rufo Figueroa, who moved the family to Sorsogon after the untimely death of Melecio’s mother. His uncles Esteban and Andres earned some fame as artists for their sculptural works. Melecio studied in Manila’s Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, where he attracted attention for his intricate carvings, while repairing watches for a living. In 1871, he left for Spain as a scholar of Francisco Ahujas, a Spanish high official. He earned his diploma de honor (certificate of honor) at the School of Arts and Trades in Madrid.

From 1871 to 1875, he studied at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando, earning medals for engraving, modeling from nature, and pictorial anatomy. When his benefactor died, his circle of friends and skill at watch repair saw him through until he was able to secure a scholarship from the Spanish government. He was sent to Rome on a grant. He also received a scholarship in engraving from the Queen Regent of Spain. In 1892, he returned to the Philippines and became the first professor of the Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado. The following year, he was appointed engraver of the Manila mint. He was one of two artist delegates to the Malolos Congress, the other being MiguelZaragoza. In 1901, he taught art appreciation at the Liceo de Manila.

His best-known works are the designs he made for the obverse of the Philippine coins minted during the American regime: a thinly clad statuesque lady standing before an anvil with the Mayon Volcano in the background, and a young man sitting on an anvil gazing at the volcano.Written by Luciano P. R. Santiago

FLORES, JUAN C. (Juan Culala Flores) aka Apung Juan. b. Santa Ursula, Betis, Pampanga 24 Jun 1900. d. 9 Sep 1992. Sculptor and furniture maker. Juan’s father was a fisherman and as a young man, he assisted his father in this regard. He was, however, more attracted to the carving of the saints and paintings in the BetisChurch and engaged in honing his skills on his own. At age 16, he jumped aboard a passing barge going to Manila. In Manila, he apprenticed with MaximoVicente in the latter’s atelier on R. Hidalgo, Quiapo. Juan received nothing for the next few years but food and shelter in exchange for his labor. But he learned the crafts of carpentry and wood carving, furniture making, and sculpture, especially the making of santos (carved religious figures).

After four years, he became the shop’s foreman. Flores was so talented that his reputation grew among the other workshop owners. By 1918, he was working closely with established names like IsabeloTampinco and Graciano Nepomuceno. After six years in Manila, feeling he had enough training to be on his own, he went back to Pampanga. The commissions from Manila kept coming. He once made a bust of Pres Manuel Quezon and this led to other commissions, notably that of Gregorio Araneta, then secretary of justice and finance. It was through Araneta that Flores met Gregorio’s son, Luis, who put the sculptor’s expertise in woodcraft and firsthand knowledge of santos to some other use. In the late 1950s, Flores accompanied Luis all over the country in search of good santos and antiques for the latter’s collection. Wherever they went, Juan picked up apprentices: in Bicol, Marinduque, Leyte, Cebu, Surigao. Furniture makers in many parts of the country acknowledge a great debt of knowledge toFlores.

Flores’s art abided by the classical tradition, inspired by pictures of masterpieces of Western art. His training with Tampinco, however, taught him to incorporate ornamental motifs derived from local plants as well as locally evolved design patterns.

In 1971, he won first prize with his creation, a bust of the United States president Richard Nixon. The Pampanga government gave him many awards and citations for his contribution to his province’s economy and culture such as Panday Pira award in 1977 and Most Distinguished Sons of Pampanga in 1982. Written by Maita Subido, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

Tana 2004.

FLORES, KAREN (Karen Ocampo Flores) b. Caloocan City 30 Oct 1966. Painter, educator, curator, writer, organizer. Her father is Jamil (nee Jaime) Maidan Flores, a writer included in Asia’s who’s who and in anthologies, most notably by Jose Garcia Villa, while her mother is Norma Illorato Ocampo, daughter of the late Hernando R. Ocampo, National Artist for visual arts. She holds a bachelor of fine arts in painting obtained in 1987 from the University of the Philippine College of Fine Arts, and graduate units in master of arts in the fine arts and design at Philippine Women’s University (PWU).

Before her graduation, her first full-time job until 1989 was as a writer for Radio-Television Malacañang under the helm of television director Maria V. Montelibano. She also worked as editorial assistant to her father while he was managing director for Lifestyle Asia Magazine until 1991. Flores is also an educator, teaching multimedia and art students at De La Salle College of Saint Benilde, PWU, Asia-Pacific College, and Philippine High School for the Arts. Serving in various capacities as juror, discussant, and organizer in various projects and art events, Flores is also contributing writer, editor, and author whose works have been published here and abroad. In 1996, she published the The Chair King, a picture book for children, which she coauthored with fellow artist Mark Justiniani.

Working mainly in oil and canvas, Flores’s paintings visually probe into struggles within religion, history, and sexual politics, utilizing images drawn from Catholic icons, colonial paintings, and popular media. In her critique of heart and home, Flores combines the sublime, the absurd, and the carnivalesque as endeavors to create new icons about women. This strategy is apparent in such works as Kasal (Marriage), 1994; Uyayi kay Paraluman (Lullabye for Paraluman), 1999; A Line of History, 2006; and her contribution to Baraha ng Buhay (Tarot Cards of Life), 2008, a mural project directed by Brenda Fajardo, installed at the PETA building in Quezon City.

Flores’s artworks are inseparable from her work as organizer, advocate, curator, and educator. Since 2005, she has served as project director of TutoK, an initiative of visual artists for advocacy projects on issues such as human rights and freedom of expression. She is also co-founder of Salingpusa, 1985-92, and Sanggawa, 1994-98, collaborative groups that participated in major exhibitions here and abroad, and eventually left a number of significant works in museums in Japan, Singapore, and Australia. She represented the country as artist and member of Sanggawa at the Sydney Biennale in 2000. Since 2011, she has served as head of the copyright organization Filipino Visual Arts and Design Organization and is an officer of the Artists’ Welfare Projects Inc. She is also part of BAGLAN, an organization for art and culture initiatives for community development since 2006.

In 1995, she was artist in residence at the Artists Regional Exchange, Perth Institute of Contemporary Art, Western Australia. She served as the head of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) visual art unit from 2008 to 2011. She received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2000.Written by Flaudette May V. Datuin

FLORES, SIMON (Simon de la Rosa Flores) b. San Fernando de Dilao (now Paco), Manila 28 Oct 1839. d. 12 Mar 1904. Painter, decorator. Flores descended from a family of artisans originally from Balayan, Batangas. His uncle Pio de la Rosa taught Simon the rudiments of the arts when he was in his teens. Later, he enrolled at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, studying under Lorenzo Guerrero and LorenzoRocha. Painter Fabian de la Rosa was his nephew.

Flores first gained attention in 1871 when the colonial administration commissioned him to make a portrait of Amadeo I, which he presented to the province of Pampanga. During this time, he might already have made the acquaintance of Msgr Ignacio Tambungui who introduced him to the wealthy families of several towns of Pampanga for whom he executed many portraits and religious paintings. Flores married the monsignor’s sister, Simplicia.

Flores painted as many as 20 portraits, which include the two versions of the FamiliaQuiason, and the portraits titled Miguela Henson, Andrea Dayrit, Quintina Castor de Sadie, Severina Ocampo de Arroyo, Anastasia Sandiko Panlilio, and Lucila Panlilio. All these are known for the fine miniaturistic detailing of the embroideries of the piña dresses of the sitters, their elaborate jewelry, as well as the appurtenances in their homes. Among Simon’s religious paintings are El Bautismo de Cristo (The Baptism of Christ), SanRoque, Parabola de la Mujer Arrepentida (Parable of the Repentant Woman), LaInmaculadaConcepcion (The Immaculate Conception), and two versions of La Virgen Maria (The Virgin Mary), inspired by a painting of Carlo Dolci. He decorated the interiors of the churches of Bacolor, Betis, Mexico, and Santa Rita towns of Pampanga. He also did mortuary portraits. Only two of his genre paintings are known to be extant, Primeras Letras (First Letters) and Alimentando Pollos (Feeding the Chickens).

Flores was the first Filipino of native blood to garner a prize from an international exhibition. In 1876, he was awarded a silver medal at the Philadelphia Universal Exposition for his painting La Musica del Pueblo (The Music of the Town). In 1892, he won the highest honors for Despues de la Ultima Cena (After the Last Supper) and El Prendimiento (The Arrest) in the art contest to commemorate the tercentenary of San Juan de la Cruz. In 1895, he won a silver medal for La Expulsion (The Expulsion), his entry in the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition). Before his death, he was able to submit paintings for the Universal Exposition of Saint Louis, Missouri, USA, one of which was the portrait Andrew Carnegie.Written by Santiago A. Pilar
Francia, Hilario (See Literature volume.)

FRANCISCO, CARLOS V. (Carlos Villaluz Francisco) aka Botong. b. Angono, Rizal 4 Nov 1912. d. Angono, Rizal 31 Mar 1969. National Artist for visual arts. He was the son of Felipe Francisco and Maria Villaluz. He married Rosalina “Nene” Villamor of Angono in 1942 and they had three children. Their grandson Carlos III is also a painter. Francisco studied at Angono Elementary School, 1919-25; Rizal High School, Pasig, 1926-29; and University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, 1930-35. In 1934, he worked as layout artist and illustrator for the Philippines Herald and later as illustrator for the Manila Tribune. Later, with Victorio Edades and Fermin Sanchez, Francisco painted sets for the Manila Grand Opera House and the Clover Theater. He also became associated with a group of artists called the Thirteen Moderns in 1938. In that same year, he became one of the pioneer instructors of the newly established School of Architecture and Fine Arts, University of Santo Tomas, together with Galo Ocampo, Diosdado Lorenzo, and Vicente Manansala. He also worked in cinema with Manuel Conde as scriptwriter of Genghis Khan, Putol na Kampilan (Broken Sword), Tatlong Labuyo (Three Wild Roosters), and Sigfredo. He also designed costumes for Romeo at Julieta (Romeo and Juliet), as well as Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), Sigfredo, Siete Infantes de Lara (Seven Devils), Genghis Khan, and the Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan) series.

Francisco belonged to the first-generation modernists who, with Edades and Galo B. Ocampo, constituted the pioneering triumvirate that attempted to change the direction of Philippine art from the tenacious influence of the Amorsolo school to new and fresh idioms of visual expression. In the struggle for modern art, Francisco was one of the artists/protagonists in the center of the fray. His painting Kaingin (Swidden), 1945, which heralded modernism in its strong sense of design and rhythm, won for him the grand prize in the historic first national art exhibition of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) held at the National Museum in 1948. Francisco, along with Edades and Ocampo, were commissioned to do a number of murals for theater lobbies and private residences such as that of the architect Juan Nakpil. These murals featured stylized figures in flowing curvilinear lines: nymphs dancing or playing the flute, often against a background of tropical vegetation. Through these works, the artists contributed toward developing Filipino imagery, drawing inspiration from the customs and traditions of the people, as well as from the familiar environment. In the quest for a Filipino modernist idiom, Francisco, who chose to be based in his fishing village of Angono, observed Philippine folk aesthetics and researched Philippine history, customs, and traditions. He arrived at an idiom which was both Filipino and Asian in the fresh colors of the folk, the flowing curvilinear lines in rhythm creating decorative patterns, and the particular disposition of space that satisfies the Filipino penchant for covering the entire field. Filipino, too, was his sense of the communal life: the crowds of people in interaction as they engage in trade, enjoying themselves in fiestas or uniting in common struggle. His images of women were drawn from mythology such as Mariang Makiling, from history and legend such as Princesa Urduja, from customs of the past such as the maiden carried on a hammock across the mountains of Antipolo, and from contemporary folk such as the woman preparing fish for sinigang. Fisherfolk were among his favorite subjects since he lived in a fishing village. He showed his closeness to the folk in paintings like Camote-Eaters, his last and unfinished work.

Francisco’s first important mural was done for the 1953 International Fair held in Manila. On the theme of Five Hundred Years of Philippine History, its scope covered the legendary origin of the Filipino with the first man and woman Malakas at Maganda springing from the primal bamboo, up to the administration of then incumbent president Elpidio Quirino. The mural was finely executed in wood by the Paete wood-carvers. Foreign visitors to the fair were impressed by Francisco’s mural, which received full coverage in Newsweek, but local appreciation was apparently lukewarm since it was promptly dismantled and carelessly disposed of after the fair. Francisco’s major masterpiece is the mural for the Bulwagang Katipunan of the Manila City Hall, commissioned by Manila mayor Antonio Villegas during his administration. Filipino Struggles through History, 1964, chronicles the history of Manila from the first great rajahs of Tondo, the Spanish colonial period, Balagtas, Rizal, and the Revolution of 1896, the American colonial period, the Commonwealth, up to the Japanese occupation. It is the veritable history of the entire nation itself. In this work, Francisco often integrated several historical episodes, in smaller scale, under one period. The episode groups, however, are not static but flow into each other by means of various linking devices such as a winding river, flames branching out, or clouds coiling in spirals. The murals are marked by artistic vigor and inexhaustible inventiveness, a lively characterization of the numerous historical personages, unifying all through an admirable sense of design. Andres Bonifacio’s figure makes a visual impact as he is shown forging onward, leading the Katipunero with their long bamboo spears, rifles, and bolos. Among the many dynamic scenes is the encounter between Limahong and the Spanish soldiers in the thrust and counterthrust of weapons. A smaller mural is the Pageant of Commerce in four sections: two sides on the history of Philippine trade, from commercial relations with China and Arabia to the Manila-Acapulco galleon trade; a section on the development of modern industry in factories, travel, and communication; and the central one of a Filipino couple in native costume, the woman slipping a coin into a bamboo alkansiya (coin bank), with the spirit of commerce hovering above. He also did the murals Life and Miracles of Saint Dominic for the Santo Domingo Church, 1954, and the Stations of the Cross for Far Eastern University, 1956. He worked with Victoria Edades and Galo B. Ocampo on the mural Rising Philippines for the Capitol Theater and murals for the Golden Gate Exposition, the State Theater, and the houses of Pres Manuel Quezon, Ernesto Rufino, and Vicente Rufino.

In 1944, Francisco won three major prizes at the Botica Boie-sponsored Kapisanan ng Paglilingkod sa Bagong Pilipinas or Kalibapi painting contest: first prize for Angelus; second prize for Frugal Meal at the Farm; and third prize for Angono Fiesta. His Kaingin won first prize in the 1948 painting competition of the Art Association of the Philippines. He was awarded Most Outstanding Alumnus by the UP School of Fine Arts in 1959. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila, and the Republic Cultural Heritage Awards, both in 1964. He was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts in 1973. In 1989, the Cultural Center of the Philippines held an exhibit of his works titled Botong: Alay at Alaala (Botong: Offering and Remembrance). In celebration of his birth centenary, an exhibition of over 40 works titled Botong Francisco: A Nation Imagined opened in 2012 at the Ayala Museum. A short film by Peque Gallaga that featured the artist’s murals in public and private offices complemented this latter exhibition.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Ayala Museum, n.d.; Flores 2010b; Guerrero 1998; Reyes 2010.

FRANCISCO, VICENTE (Vicente Dionisio Francisco) b. Quiapo, Manila 18 Jun 1865. d. 28 Mar 1936. Sculptor. He was the son of Angel Francisco and Leonor Dionisio. Francisco apprenticed under the sculptor SoteroGarcia at age 14. He also took up private lessons in painting under LorenzoRocha.

Francisco gained public recognition for the first time when he won first prize for his entry in the competition commemorating the tercentenary of Santa Teresa de Avila. In 1884, he established a shop on Dulumbayan (presently Rizal Ave) where he made images of saints. In 1885, he was appointed Escultor de la Comandancia General de Marina (Sculptor of General Marine Command). On 1 Apr 1887, Francisco sailed for Spain to participate at the Exposicion General de Filipinas (Philippine General Exposition) in Madrid. There, he obtained a scholarship for four years at the Escuela Central de Artes y Oficios. Sailing back to Manila in 1891, he arrived in time to participate in the competition held to commemorate the tercentenary of San Juan de la Cruz.

During the American colonial period, Francisco was one of the founding faculty of the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts. Together with his students, he executed the sculptures gracing the entrances of the different colleges at the old UP campus in Padre Faura. Today, only two sculptures of Francisco seem to be in existence—namely, the bust of Doña Filomena Ortiz and the nymph adorning the fountain at the Adelaida Vargas Residence in Tagaytay.

Aside from winning first prize in the Santa Teresa de Avila art competition, Francisco also won for his works in clay and marble a bronze medal and a diploma at the Exposicion Universal de Barcelona (Barcelona Universal Exposition) in 1889. He also received an honorable mention at the Madrid Exposition of 1891. This was the same year he received first prize for his maquette of El Genio Coronado por las Bellas Artes (Genius Crowned by the Fine Arts), an allegorical piece. For the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in 1895, Francisco entered Ultimos momentos de los Numantinos (Last Hours of the Citizens of Numancia), a study in plaster and a mortuary bas-relief on marble. He received a silver medal for these latter pieces.Written by E. Arsenio Manuel and Santiago A. Pilar

GAJO, ELY b. Irosin, Sorsogon 1950. Painter. He graduated from the Philippine Women’s University College of Fine Arts. He belongs to the group of magic realists, with Stevesantos, GerViterbo, NestorLeynes, Efren Lopez, and Agustin Goy, who drew their inspiration from the American artist Andrew Wyeth.

Gajo works in a highly realist style, maintaining a casual and informal effect which he learned from impressionism to further bring out the semblance of life. His style involves a heightened sensitivity to tone, as well as to the reflections and shadows of bodies and objects, as seen in his paintings of children playing in the water. Here the bodies of the children are carefully modeled in light and dark, and the water sparkles with tiny points of light.

Gajo sometimes paints solitary figures seated as though in contemplation in a rice field. In these works, he brings out the gritty textures of the earth and the spiky rhythms of the rice stalks growing densely together. The natural light source is clearly defined, and the shadow cast by the single figure further enhances its solitariness—an uncommon condition in the countryside where a strong collective spirit marks seasonal activities.

Gajo’s first individual show, The Farm, was at the Hidalgo Gallery in 1971, followed by Pasakay at Sining Kamalig. He also exhibited at the Schwalbach Gallery in West Germany in 1979.

Gajo was given a certificate of merit for FortSantiago in the on-the-spot painting competition of the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1968. The following year, he won third prize for painting also in the Shell competition. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines in 1974.Written by Alice G. Guillermo

GALANG, MARCIANO aka Mars. b. Cabusao, Camarines Sur 1945. Multimedia artist. Galang studied fine arts at the University of the Philippines from 1962 to 1966, the first two years of his education made possible through the M. M. Castro Scholarship.

Galang’s work could be taken as typical of early Philippine modernist practice, given his broad experimentation with material and visual grammar. Ironically, this experimentation was critically received either as wholly committed to social commentary or purely self-indulgent. His early work was alternately associated with Art Brut and Arte Povera as was the case of his peers RobertoChabet, LeeAguinaldo, and RayAlbano, all of whom were involved in exploring processes and materials outside the usual norms of artistic practice at the time. Galang’s piece for the Paris Biennale consisted of three long wooden bars laid out on the floor. Another famous work consisted of a plain white canvas collaged with discarded shoes, among other objects, encrusted at the bottom of the frame.

Galang’s later body of work demonstrates a leaning toward abstraction and minimalism bordering on the conceptual. He continuously questioned the concept of painting and sculpture and this questioning would shift his process of work from producing surfaces and objects that were blotched, stained, punctured, roughened up with sand, to creating the slick geometric abstract paintings in his final years.

Under the auspices of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), Galang figured in at least three exhibitions with Virgilio Aviado and Benedicto Cabrera within two decades beginning 1965. National Artist BenCab would eventually publicly acknowledge Galang for encouraging him to explore painting, which was as yet outside Cabrera’s comfort zone of sketching and illustration. Galang had his first solo exhibition at the Gallery Indigo in 1967. Among the international exhibitions Galang was selected for were Tour of Contemporary Art of Asia, 1965, Manila-Tokyo-Hong Kong; the Philippine Contemporary Prints Show, 1967, Geneva; the First Indian Triennale, 1968; and the Seventh Paris Biennale, 1971.

Galang’s other group exhibitions include Nine Young Artists, 1963, Ateneo Art Gallery; Galang and Liongoren, 1965, AAP Gallery; Galang, Romero, Yongder, 1965, Luz Gallery; the new Luz Gallery inaugural Twenty Years of Philippine Art: 1946-1966, 1966; Twenty Artists, 1967, International Rice Research Institute, Los Baños; Sixteen Young Artists, 1967, AAP Gallery; Prints and Drawings, 1967, Indigo Gallery; Young Artists ’68 and ’69, Luz Gallery, 1968 and 1969 respectively; Embuscado and Galang and Words and Pictures, 1969, Joy Dayrit Print Gallery, a visual art exhibition done after poems by Filipino poets. Galang frequently exhibited at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the allied Museong Pansining ng Pilipinas or Contemporary Art Museum of the Philippines (CAMP) as he was part of Philippine Printmaking, 1969, CCP; Sculptures, 1970, CCP Main Gallery; the CCP Summer Exhibition 1970 and 1973; Objects, 1973, CCP Small Gallery; Collage, 1976, CCP Small Gallery; the CAMP inaugural exhibition Contemporary Art in the Philippines, 1976; Museum Artists 1979, CCP Main Gallery; A Decade of Developmental Art, 1979, CCP Main Gallery; Art in Private Spaces, 1988, CAMP; and Sikat: Two Decades of Philippine Art, 1969-1989 (Ray of the Sun / Famous: Two Decades of Philippine Art, 1969-1989), CCP Main Gallery.

Galang was given a certificate of merit for Cavite in the Shell National Students Art Competition, 1964. His Huymans Revisited won honorable mention in the AAP painting competition in 1967. He was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1970.Written by Rachel Mayo and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources:

askArt 2015; BenCab Museum 2015; CCP 1970; Heritage Art Center 2015b.

GALICANO, ROMULO (Romulo Emnace Galicano) b. Carcar, Cebu 4 Feb 1945. Painter. Brought up by his mother, Josefa Emnace Galicano, Romulo grew up as the personal student of his uncle, the Cebuano maestro MartinoAbellana. At age 13, he became part of his uncle’s household. The close relationship of maestro and apprentice made Galicano the direct and immediate heir to Abellana’s artistic heritage. His mastery of color and tone, figure drawing, composition, techniques, and materials came from lessons he learned from his early youth. His first drawing is dated 1959. In 1963, he showed evidence of precocity in portraiture, with JuanLuna as one of his early influences. In 1967, Galicano came to Manila to take up fine arts at the University of the East. Even if Galicano already had a solid training in figure drawing, Florencio Concepcion taught him abstract design. For a year, in 1968, he painted expressionist works, still lifes with spare elements; from 1969 to 1975 he had an impressionist period with Abellana’s influence predominating. This was also his Dimasalang period, where he worked with fellow artists EmilioAguilarCruz, Andres Cristobal Cruz, IbarradelaRosa, and Sofronio Y. Mendoza aka SYM, figurative painters who promoted on-the-spot painting. Since 1976, Galicano has done tonal paintings, mostly atmospheric scenes of the seacoasts of Cebu and Pangasinan. He painted domestic interiors, portraits, folk genre, and still lifes.

Galicano identifies himself as a post-realist as he merges representation and abstraction to produce works that cohesively evoke both the aesthetics of realism and modernism. Galicano believes that the strength of a figurative painting lies in its underlying abstract structure which often has a mathematical basis, thus pointing to classical affinities in his work. For him, a painting goes beyond recording reality because it has its own internal formal relationships. He is known for incorporating a vertical line as an integral part of the artwork, whether these are portraits and genre scenes, as a means of “reconciliation between opposite poles and the merging of the subjective and the objective” (romulogalicano.com).

From 1972 to 2011, Galicano held 19 solo exhibits in various galleries in Manila, San Juan, Quezon City, Makati, and Cebu. He has also participated in group exhibitions held in Manila and Cebu.

Galicano’s Kangkongan (Vegetable Vine Swamp) won third prize in the painting competition of the Art AssociationofthePhilippines in 1977. He also won third prize in the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards in 1994, and grand prize at the International Portrait Competition held in 2005 in Washington, USA. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Altro Mondo 2013; Carcar Families, n.d.; Galicano, n.d.; Raddatz 2015.

GALVEZ, MIGUEL (Miguel Geronimo Galvez)b. Paombong, Bulacan 27 Sep 1912. d. 7 Nov 1989. Painter. The son of Jacinto Galvez and Rosa Geronimo, Miguel peddled vinegar in jars during his teens. In his early 20s in 1932, he went to Manila to stay with his uncle TeodoroBuenaventura, painter and professor at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts. He stayed with him for four years, doing household chores; in return Galvez attended Buenaventura’s classes in UP, although he was not officially enrolled. Observing his talent, the UP professors encouraged him to take free lessons in their classes. An early work of his, Copy of Gericault’s Raft of Medusa, 1935, shows that Galvez learned all that was needed in academic classical techniques and pictorial skills. In 1948-49, he became art instructor at the Manila Wesleyan Colleges. During that term, he also opened a gallery in Mabini.

Galvez’s paintings may be classified into four periods. The first, from the 1930s to 1948, his classical period, produced mainly genres and landscapes, solidly conceived and structurally elegant compositions done in rigorous impasto. Banaba Tree, 1943, Barrio Scene, 1943, Mandaluyong, 1947, exemplify this period. His second period, from 1949 to 1952, encompassed his decorative phase. By decorative is meant his use of the classical skills toward the creation of landscapes, all correct in terms of technique and structure but no longer showing the vigor of his early period. From 1953 to 1965, he went into an experimental phase. Perhaps bored with representationalism, Galvez went into semiabstraction, experimenting with neorealist expressionism, the cubism of VicenteManansala. Newsboys, 1955, shows exaggeratedly elongated forms. His fourth period begins around 1967, when he returned to straight representationalism, the style he used until his demise.

Galvez had his first one-person show at the showroom of Hans Kasten and Associates in 1948. He was represented in the International Exhibition in Kuala Lumpur in 1953. He traveled with the Traveling World Tour-Exhibit sponsored by the De La Rama Steamship Company in 1955. He held eight solo exhibitions in his lifetime, the last being in 1989.

Galvez was honored as the country’s Outstanding Landscape Painter in 1950 by the San Miguel Corporation. He won second prize for Abandoned in the oil painting category at the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) competition in 1949. In 1953, his oil painting Dice was chosen by the AAP to join a selection of outstanding Filipino paintings to represent the country at the International Exhibition held in Kuala Lumpur. In 1956, Galvez also won second prize at the Philippine Tourist and Travel Association art competition for his painting Pista sa Nayon (Rural Fiesta).Written by Santiago A. Pilar

GAMAYO, MAGDALENA (Magdalena Galinato Gamayo) b. Pinili, Ilocos Norte 13 Aug 1924. Textile weaver. Her parents are Timotea Bigsot and Catalino Galinato. She is the widow of Crespin T. Gamayo. A weaver of the traditional cloth called inabel (Ilocano handwoven cloth), Gamayo learned her craft from her aunt when she was 16 years old. Gamayo grew up at a time when women learned to weave by copying the patterns and weaving process of elders. She taught herself the traditional patterns of binakol, inuritan (geometric design), kusikos (spiral forms similar to oranges), and sinan-sabong (flowers). She is able to recreate designs that she has seen elsewhere, a skill that is important in recreating designs that are in danger of disappearing from collective memory.

She received her first loom when she was 19 years old and this lasted her 30 years. The sturdy frame was made of sag’gat or hardwood, which her father obtained from the area they lived in at the time. The loom had three foot pedals with wide horizontal beams to support the warp and a longer lengthwise frame to keep the threads in place. The arrangement of the threads on the loom is the most important step in the weaving process requiring good eyesight. A mistake at this point could result in faulty design in the finished product. The shuttle is threaded through the warp and under the strands, while operating the foot pedals which raise or lower the corresponding column of fibers that enable the shuttle to pass through. The process requires dexterity with good coordination of the eyes, hands, and legs, and could be hard on the back muscles of the weaver.

Gamayo’s abel blankets are valued for their high thread count and its being woven uniformly, and for its intricate designs that use as much as five colors. Just prior to World War II, she used to spin her own cotton on which she applied beeswax. However after the war, she had to rely on commercial threads bought in the market. Gamayo prefers using linen, because it is malleable to the weaver’s touch. The best abel cloths are strong, lasting for generations. These gradually get softer from frequent handling, but still retain their form for a long time.

Gamayo has taught weaving to her cousin’s daughter-in-law and her sister-in-law, and also to other women in her community. In 2012, she was awarded the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA. She was featured as the “Grandmother of Abel Iloko” in the exhibit Abel Iloko, 2014, at the National Museum of the Philippines.Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Maricris Jan Tobias and Rizzi Gorospe

Sources:

GAMABA Committee, n.d.; Lazaro 2014; Tobias, n.d.

GAN, RODOLFO b. Manila 1949. Painter. He graduated bachelor of fine arts from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1970.

Gan’s work may be classified under the nonobjective school of painting associated with the minimalism of op art as initiated in the Philippines by ConstancioBernardo and pursued by Lee Aguinaldo. This hard-edge painting style is a stream of geometric abstraction that privileges fullness of color, economy of form, and symmetry of structure.

In Gan’s hands, however, hard-edge painting becomes total geometric construction as his picture edge is often part and parcel of the picture frame that spans the canvas. Sometimes, he would saw off a perfect right angle from a corner of his frame, and echo this shape at the center of his work. Reflective Symmetry, 1970, a lacquer painting on wood, in the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) collection, illustrates Gan’s predisposition for boxlike structure and immaculate surface, which he achieves with the use of patterns defined by masking tape and color applied with a spray gun.

In Love in an Empty Drawer, 1971, hard-edge delineations assimilate soft-edge forms in an efficiently calculated composition of soft tints of white, beige, blue, and gray. All in all, minimal hard-edge art as exemplified by the works of Gan, is reflective of an orderly, efficient, and structured mind, or an aspiration for this.

In the 1970s, Gan exhibited at the CCP and the Luz Gallery. He kept a low profile for over three decades, reemerging in 2014 with a comeback solo show at the Finale Art File. He describes this hiatus as a period for “time, space and quiet … a process of unlearning what one has learned” (Finale Art File 2014b).

He received major awards in painting from the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1969, and the UST competitions for various works in painting, sculpture, and advertising design. In 1971, he represented the Philippines in the 7th Paris Biennale and the ASEAN collection exhibited in Israel, Jakarta, and Hong Kong. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1972. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

BusinessWorld 2014; Finale Art File 2014b; Reyes 2014a.

GARCELLANO, LYRA (Lyra Teresa Abueg Garcellano) b. Quezon City 1 Dec 1972. Installation artist, painter. She is the daughter of writers Edel E. Garcellano and Rosario Abueg. She got a bachelor’s degree in fine arts, major in studio arts, from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 2000, and a bachelor of arts, interdisciplinary studies, from Ateneo de Manila University, 1994. She is a graduate student at UP working for a master’s degree in art studies, major in art theory and criticism.

Garcellano’s works revolve around the politics of identity and are anchored on issues of displacement, movement, history, memory and the everyday, to which she takes an anthropological approach. A Filipino Girl, 2001-11, challenges racial stereotypes by mimicking the visual template of colonial postcards distributed by American anthropologists in the 1900s. Since its first distribution at the Gwangju Biennale in South Korea in 2002, as part of Filipino artist Judy Sibayan’s performance for Scapular Gallery Nomad, the postcard has been distributed in exhibitions in Australia, Indonesia, New York, Singapore, and the Philippines. Free Land, 2002, is an installation, video and performance, held in Jogjakarta, Indonesia, during an artist-in-residency grant. The performance consisted of the artist giving away packets of earth, which she dug out of the yard of Cemeti Gallery and wrapped like Indonesian food takeouts, referencing deeply embedded social and economic problems in Indonesia and the Philippines. Short Stories, 2007, a collection of paintings, are peopled with figures hollowed out in solid white against a background of threatening skies and shadow-crammed landscapes that invite viewers to weave their own narratives onto the canvas. Her Taxonomy series (Yearbook, 2012; K-Pop, 2013) conjures images of the artist’s body as a form of landscape where notions of identity—given its homogenous quality and permutational capacity—are scrutinized.

Garcellano’s first solo exhibit was Free Land, 2002, at the Cemeti Gallery, Indonesia. Since then, she held solo exhibits almost annually, some of which were held abroad: Nessun Dorma (None Shall Sleep), 2009, Singapore; Portraits and Observations, 2010, New York; Indelible, 2011, Singapore; and Ballads, 2012, Malaysia. She participated in major international exhibitions here and abroad—among them, trauma, interrupted, 2007, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Biennale XIII, Indonesia, 2009; and Faith+The City, Thailand, Singapore, and Malaysia, 2001-2. She also contributed works to nationwide art events, including Sungduan 3 / NCR 3: Making the Local, held at the CCP in 2004. Garcellano is also the creator, writer, and illustrator of Atomo and Weboy, a newspaper comics strip serialized in the Philippine Daily Inquirer.

Garcellano was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 2006. She received grants from the Asian Cultural Council, 2010, and UNESCO Aschberg Bursaries for Artists, 2002, through which she served as artist in residence in One, Soho, New York and Cemeti Art Foundation, Jogjakarta, respectively. She also participated in several residencies in Seoul, Gwangju, New York, and Singapore. Written by Flaudette May V. Datuin

Source:

Garcellano, n.d.

GARCIA, ANTONIO (Antonio Llamas Garcia) b. Manila 16 May 1912. d. Madrid, Spain 30 Nov 1999. Painter, teacher. His father was AntonioGarcia Granda, famous engraver and professor of engraving at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts. He received his early education at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. He began his studies in painting at UP in 1926. In 1938, he left for Rome to study at the Regge Accademia di Belle Arti. Two years later, he became a scholar at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid. He was a professor of painting at the University of Santo Tomas for many years before he migrated to Spain.

Garcia belonged to the conservative school of painting, a result of his training in UP and at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes in Madrid under professors Eduardo Chicharro and Manuel Benedito y Vasquez-Diaz. In 1941, his Indays (Women) created a sensation in Madrid during his solo exhibition at the Circulo de Bellas Artes de Madrid. It projected Garcia as the Filipino Gauguin, his painting being a trio of nude women with their Malayan features emphasized. Due to its indigenized sensibility, the painting was also reproduced in Shin Seiki, the sleek cultural magazine of the Philippines during the Japanese occupation. In 1945, Garcia presented important paintings including the portrait of General Borbon at the National Exposition of Fine Arts in Madrid. In 1950, he showed his Madonna Filipina, an image of the Virgin in the Filipino patadyong (striped or checkered skirt).

Garcia exhibited his pieces during the Semana Filipina at the Sala de Exposiciones del Centro Iberoamericano de Cooperacion where he highlighted abstract, realist, and allegorical works in May 1979. Among his last major works is the mural of the Virgin Mary called Mia Madonna, at the Mia Madonna e Mia Salvessa (My Lady and My Savior) Church in Casapenna, Caserta, Italy, which was blessed by Pope John Paul II on 13 Nov 1990.

Garcia won the first prize in the open-poster competition for the 33rd International Eucharistic Congress celebrated in Manila in 1937. He was also awarded the Alfonso El Sabio medal by Generalissimo Franco in 1942.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Source:

Cariño 2014.

GARCIA, DANILO (Danilo Ordinario Garcia) b. Manila 7 Aug 1947. Painter. He is the son of Silvino Garcia and Loretta Ordinario. In 1964, he enrolled at the University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts, majoring in advertising. After a break, he continued his studies at the University of the East. He began as a realist painter but shifted to abstraction.

His first one-person show at the Sining Kamalig in 1976 was on the theme of mother-and-child. His second reflected the trend in pen-and-ink drawings that Vicente Manansala had begun and also featured cork reliefs. For his Sining Kamalig show in 1978, all the pieces were in cork. His shows at the Finale Art File and at the Luz Gallery in 1981 showed a shift in medium from cork to watercolor, pastel, and acrylic and from genre to the theme of space. He explored spatial concepts in the show Summer Haze followed by Shadow, Transparency. The paintings, of predominant brown hues with color accents, placed value on subtlety of hue and tone, creating soft fleeting movements with an op art effect. His seventh exhibit, New Horizons, at Gallery Genesis in 1989 extended the space theme to abstract works except for the horizon line which suggested waves in fine parallel ridges and for the lunar/solar symbol. In acrylic, the hues were tempered, in delicate modulations of tone, at times with the collage of a found organic object.

Garcia joined the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines Annual Art Competition with an entry in an original medium of his invention, cork cutouts glued on wood, which won a prize for unique medium. He was given a certificate of merit in the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1971 and had several mentions in competitions sponsored by B.F. Goodrich and the Philippine National Bank.Written by Alice G. Guillermo

GARCIA, EULOGIO (Eulogio Velarde Garcia) b. Quiapo, Manila 11 Mar 1871. d. 21 Feb 1936. Sculptor, painter. Eulogio was the second of three children of Sotero Garcia, also a sculptor, and Petrona Velarde. He finished his primary and secondary education at Ateneo de Manila. He learned wood carving from his father and painting from LorenzoGuerrero. When his father became gobernadorcillo (mayor), he took over his father’s shop on Calle Santa Rosa. Later, he established his own at the corner of Carriedo and Palma St. Garcia married twice. He had three children with his first wife, Rosalia Borja, and five with his second wife, Victoria Guevarra.

Among Garcia’s known works are the monument Thirteen Martyrs of Cavite; The Cry in San Juan del Monte; the statues of JoseRizal and Graciano LopezJaena in Silay, Negros Occidental; the monument of Gregorio del Pilar in Bulacan, Bulacan; the monument of Juan Kalimbas; the mausoleum of Teodora Alonso at the Cementerio del Norte; a bronze statue of Jose Rizal in Daet, Camarines Norte; and a wood carving presented by Sorsogon and Masbate to Atkinson Jones, the author of the Jones Law.

Garcia first achieved recognition at the art competition held to commemorate the tercentenary of San Juan de la Cruz, where he received diplomas of merit for a painting and two sculptures. At the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in 1895, he was granted an entire booth where he showed wood carvings of numerous saints. For this, he received a gold medal. His Rafael and Tobias was awarded a silver medal at the Exposicion Internacional de Bellas Artes (International Exposition of Fine Arts) held in Manila in 1908. In the same year, his wood carving St. Francis Xavier, won second prize in the contest sponsored by the Liga Antipornografica de San Francisco Javier.Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

GARCIA, NONA (Nona Medina Garcia) b. Quezon City 11 Jul 1978. Painter and installation artist. She is the daughter of Nestor Garcia and Nora Medina. A graduate of the Philippine High School for the Arts, Garcia started joining group exhibitions in 1999 and graduated with a degree in fine arts, major in painting, from the University of the Philippines in 2000.

Garcia’s practice is characterized by a mastery of realism, the employment of the photographic image, and a strong conceptual approach to art making. Born to doctor parents who owned a hospital in Marikina City, Garcia first started using X-rays as a material for her works in 1999. This exploration of media was recognized in her work See Saw, 2000, a diptych of a chainsaw wrapped in cloth, captured in two panels comprised of an oil-on-canvas painting and an X-ray film on lightbox. Simultaneously representing a singular object through two different imaging techniques, Garcia’s work emphasized how the visual is dialectically comprised of both surface and structure. She continued to explore the possibilities of the radiographic material in later shows, such as False Apparitions, 2012, where X-rays of icon statues of saints were desacralized in a sense even as the objects were also bathed in a halo.

Garcia’s paintings have been noted for their precise photorealistic quality, across great variations of scale and subject matter. In 2006, Garcia started producing a series of portraits showing sitters from behind and would later on explore the representation of abject spaces and desolate landscapes. In 2010, Garcia started exploring the use of photo assemblage, using techniques from decoupage or paper tole (creating 3D pictures from a number of flat prints) crafts. She would also engage in collaborative exhibitions with other contemporary Filipino artists such as MM Yu.

Garcia’s work was included in the Prague Biennale in the Czech Republic, 2009, and the 3rd Fukuoka Triennial at the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum in Japan, 2005. Apart from exhibiting locally, she had solo exhibitions in Singapore, 2012, and Berlin, 2015.

See Saw won the grand prize in the Philip Morris Group of Companies ASEAN Art Awards in Singapore and the juror’s choice distinction in the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards. Garcia was also a finalist in the Metrobank Young Painter’s Competition in 2000. Following these three successive distinctions, Garcia held public exhibitions of her works and received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2003 and the Ateneo Art Award in 2005. These were followed by her participation in several residency programs abroad: in Fukuoka and Kitakyushu, Japan, in 2003 and in Bangkok, Thailand, in 2004.Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Cobangbang 2010a; Garcia 2014; Kolesnikov-Jessop 2012; Reyes 2000.

GARCIA, SOTERO (Sotero Dionisio Garcia) b. Quiapo, Manila 12 Apr 1848. d. 10 Jun 1917. Sculptor, wood-carver. He married Petrona Velarde, they had three children, one of whom, Eulogio, became a sculptor. In the 1890s, he became teniente mayor (senior lieutenant) in the Quiapo Tribunal and, later, gobernadorcillo (mayor). At an early age, Garcia apprenticed himself in the shop of Jose Arevalo. Later, he set up an atelier of his own in his house on Santa Rosa (now Regidor) St. His work flourished from his friendship with Juan Sales, a famous contractor of religious works during his time. Many of the wood-carving orders for images of saints, altars, and carrozas (processional floats) were given by Sales to Garcia for execution.

The figures of the evangelists, San Pedro (Saint Peter) and San Pablo (Saint Paul), on the facade of the prewar ManilaCathedral and La Purisima Concepcion (The Immaculate Conception) in the same church were carved by Garcia. The last image was the first reproduction of a famous painting by Murillo in the Philippines, the coloring of which was done by FelipeRoxas. The images Maria Magdalena, La Veronica, San Juan (Saint John), and the Señor en el Huerto (The Lord in the Garden), housed in the Recollect Church, Manila, were considered his better works. His other works remain unknown as it was not the practice of wood-carvers and other artisans during the Spanish colonial period to sign their works.Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

GARCIA, TEOFILO (Teofilo Callos Garcia) b. San Quintin, Abra 27 Mar 1941. Hat maker. His parents are Francisco Garcia and Concepcion Callos. He is married to Dolores C. Garcia and they have five children. Garcia is a casque hat maker. In the Ilocos region, this headpiece is locally called kattokong nga tabungaw, an all weather headgear made of upu or gourd (Cucurbitaceae). He learned the craft from his grandfather when he was 15 years old. Primarily a farmer who cultivates rice and tobacco, Garcia plants gourd after the harvest season. He then transforms the yield into traditional tabungaw.

The process of creating the hat involves hollowing out the upper portion of the gourd, polishing and varnishing the outer surface to produce a bright orange sheen which also improves its durability. The inside part of the hat is matted with woven uway (rattan) while the brim is decorated with a puser (bamboo) weave. It usually takes Garcia at least seven days to finish one tabungaw, using hand tools that he personally developed. He is known to have innovated his own process of hat making by studying the properties of his raw materials—gourd, rattan, and bamboo—in terms of pliancy and resistance to decay. He has also developed different patterns and remains open to exploring new designs.

Limited by the availability of his materials, especially by the amount of the harvested gourds, Garcia is able to create 100 hats in a good year, which is then sold in Ilocos Norte and Ilocos Sur, as well as in agricultural fairs organized by the government. Aside from farmers who buy the tabungaw, the hats are also bought as gifts or as souvenirs. The gourd hat is sturdy and reputed to last three to four generations with proper care.

Garcia was awarded the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA in 2012. He has committed time to teach the process of hat making to students of San Quentin National High School in Abra.Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Maricris Jan Tobias and Rizzi Gorospe

Sources:

Cabigas 2015; GAMABA Committee, n.d.; Tobias, n.d.

GARCIA, WENCESLAO (Wenceslao Sicat Garcia) b. Bacolor, Pampanga 28 Sep 1915. d. 7 Mar 1979. Painter, teacher. He attended the Bacolor Elementary School and the Pampanga Trade School. He graduated from the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts in 1934. He taught at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) until his death. Garcia’s discipline, dedication, and systematic lessons earned for him a compliment from professor Mariano Madarang, first director of Philippine Women’s University, who referred to Garcia as the “greatest teacher of painting in UST.”

The superior painting procedures of Garcia is best evident in the Portrait of His Wife, 1938. Although affiliated with the conservative tradition, Garcia set forth the image of his wife in vigorous brushwork along the impressionist impasto technique. These strokes rendered the embellishment of the sitter’s Western dress while also capturing the elegant curve and sheen of the Baughman’s chair she is sitting on. Unlike his contemporaries in the American period, Garcia preferred to paint urban scenes to rural genre subjects. His approach to Jones Bridge, 1939, and Walls of Intramuros, 1939, are enlivened by a vigorous brushwork and rich palette that depart from the dark hues of the conservative tradition.

Garcia won honorable mention for Communal Cooperation at the second Kapisanan ng Paglilingkod sa Bagong Pilipinas or Kalibapi National Art Competition in 1944 and third prize for Peasant’s Daughter at the Art Association of the Philippines competition in 1951.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

GARIBAY, EMMANUEL (Emmanuel Robles Garibay) aka Manny Garibay. b. Kidapawan, North Cotabato 17 Nov 1962. His father, Limerio C. Garibay, was a Methodist pastor and his mother, Liliosa Robles, was a government employee at the City Engineer’s Office. The young Garibay spent most of his childhood in Davao City, where the family migrated. Garibay earned a bachelor of arts in sociology from the University of the Philippines (UP) Los Baños in 1984, then went on to get a bachelor of fine arts degree in UP Diliman, before taking a master of arts in divinity at the Union Theological Seminary in Cavite in 1995.

He is an expressionist-figurative painter of sociopolitical realities. He is considered part of the second generation of social realists in Philippine art, which include Elmer Borlongan, Karen Flores, Mark Justiniani, Joy Mallari, Ferdinand Montemayor, and Federico Sievert. He was a member of the young artist collective Salingpusa before he moved on to Sanggawa, two groups prominently associated with producing socially relevant collaborative murals in the late 1980s through 1990s.

Garibay’s pastels, acrylics, and oil paintings show the masa (common people) in scenes from everyday life. His aggressive brushwork and vivid color palette provide contrast to the somber themes he renders, such as in Sagrada Familia (Holy Family), 2002, where he fuses the sacred and banal by placing the Holy Family in a jeepney, literally communing and commuting via the iconic ordinary Filipino’s means of transit. Rush Hour, 2006, is painted on canvas of a jeepney interior, showing driver and passengers in a cramped space. Mendiola, 2010, references the street leading to Malacañan Palace, the seat of state power, where rallyists and demonstrators traditionally converge.

Garibay’s enduring attachment to the daily travails of the struggling Filipino proceed from his first solo exhibition Pasada (Driver’s Daily Grind), 1993, done at Liongoren Art Gallery. Since then, he has continued to turn out work in a signature style occasionally loosening up in terms of compositional density. Garibay has had countless exhibitions from local to international venues, and has been behind several artist initiatives such as TutoK, the Cavite-based collective Anting-Anting, and Bakawan. In 1994, he received both the Diwa ng Sining Award from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and the first prize in the painting category of the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Competition. In 2000, he won second place in the painting category of the II Bienal del Baloncestoen Bellas Artesin Madrid, Spain. In that same year, he received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award.Written by Kelly P. Ramos

Sources:

de la Paz 2015b, 2015c; Flores 2014; Garibay 2015; Guillermo 2015; Legaspi-Ramirez 2015; NCCA 2015b; OMSC 2015.

GASTON, RAMON (Emmanuel Ramon Paredes Gaston) aka Ray Gaston. b. Davao City 30 Dec 1948. Painter. He is the son of Emilio Gaston Jr and Luz Paredes. He graduated with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts in 1971 from the University of Santo Tomas. After graduation, he worked at the Ayala Museum for some time, then as a photographer in Mindanao in 1972. A year after, he left for New York to further his studies at the Art Students League. He later moved to study the Italian language at L’Universita de Perugia per gli Stanieri in Perugia, Italy, in 1973. He initially experienced difficulty with his art training in Europe but later earned recognition as a London-based artist. He became a lecturer at various colleges and organizations in the United Kingdom, while also teaching portrait painting from 1998 to 2004. He returned to the Philippines in 2010 and set up a studio at St. Clare Montessori Center, Caloocan City.

He held a one-person show at the Ateneo Art Gallery in the 1970s and left a number of paintings in its collection. These are examples of veristic surrealism because of their dreamlike juxtaposition of images from widely different contexts, as in the female nude resting on the inverted dome of a cathedral in Ginhutikan (Whispered To) on whose borders can be found several unaccountable scenes of an electrocution, a cup breaking, along with a peaceful domestic scene. Another painting, Allora, shows a beautiful and winged sci-fi Amazon with occult signs. Gaston’s figurative style is clear and precise of line, the colors luminous, and he is able to achieve rare effects with color and tone to suggest glowing, as in high heat. His subjects are arresting in their originality; they raise questions rather than answers.

In 1970, he won the first and third prizes for his works Nagapalangga (Loving) and Muyat Sigay, respectively, in the Shell National Students Art Competition. In 1987, he became a representative of the Philippines to the United Nations Educational Scientific Organization at Cagnes-Sur-Mer, France.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Gaston, n.d.; Guerrero 2012.

GATBONTON, LIBORIO (Liborio Talag Gatbonton) aka Gat. b. Macabebe, Pampanga 23 Jun 1914. d. Manila 5 May 1976. Cartoonist, painter. He was the son of Manuel Gatbonton and Potenciana Talag. He took correspondence courses in cartooning, then studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts, 1933-34. In 1935, he joined the Tribune–La Vanguardia–Taliba (TVT) Publications as staff artist of the Sunday Tribune. During the Japanese occupation, he illustrated for the Shin Seiki. When the Americans returned, he came out with a collection of caricatures of life under the Japanese rule in the book Jappy Days. In 1946, he became a staff artist and cartoonist of the Manila Chronicle. Gatbonton was the first Filipino to have a cartoon published in the New York Times.

Gatbonton rose to become art director and editorial cartoonist for the Manila Chronicle. During this period he published another book of cartoons, The Chronicle Off Parade. His style consisted of forceful, spontaneous drawings that captured his subjects in an abstract sweep, as opposed to the more detailed work of his predecessors like PedroConiconde and Procopio Borromeo.

Gatbonton won the following awards: third prize in conservative painting for Peasant’s Daughter at the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines(AAP) fourth annual exhibition, 1951; a special award, best portrait, for Surgeon at the AAP fifth annual exhibition, 1952; and first prize for World Celebrities in Caricature and second prize for Presidential Line at the AAP semiannual exhibits, 1953. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

GELVEZON-TEQUI, OFELIA (Ofelia Lucas Gelvezon Tequi) b. Guimbal, Iloilo 4 Jun 1942. Printmaker, painter. She is the daughter of retired Brig Gen Ramon Gelvezon and Milagros Lucas. She is married to Marc Tequi, and they live in Paris, France. She finished her bachelor of fine arts in 1964 at the University of the Philippines (UP), and two years later she earned a bachelor’s degree in English from the same university. In 1967, she earned a diploma in painting from the Regge Accademia di Belle Arti de Roma, Italy. In 1968, she took special studies in graphic arts at Pratt Institute on a Rockefeller grant. After a teaching stint at UP, she took up residence in Paris as housewife and mother of three. She then resumed her art activities and worked at the Atelier of Lodge and Caporaso and at the Atelier Brancoise Bricaut, La Taille Douce, in Paris.

She has done prints, collages, and paintings on silk. In printmaking, she has worked in several media: colored etching on zinc plates, engraving on copper, and collage with handmade paper. In Paris, she also learned the technique of viscosity printing, which enables several colors to be registered simultaneously. Her first prints displaced classical imagery by subsuming it in a pop context. Her next series juggled images from the Apocalypse within a pinball machine game with its range of options, conveying a subtle warning on the nuclear threat, as in Commentary on the Apocalypse, 1970. Using the format of the Quattrocento predella, she also combined images from the Apocalypse with salient figures from the political scene in allusion to Philippine contemporary issues as in Predella, 1984.

She has had more than 40 solo shows since 1970 in the Philippines, France, and the United States, including Prints and Collages, Luz Gallery, 1980; The Graphic Works of Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1985; Painting and Prints, Galerie Telford, Paris, 1990; Paintings, Luz Gallery, 1995; Paintings and Prints, Philippine Center, New York, 1998; Still Life Paintings, Ayala Museum, 1999; Prints and Collages, The Drawing Room, 2001; Prints, Hiraya Gallery, 2004; Paintings, Pinto Art Gallery, 2005; Perigord Still Life, Alliance Total Gallery, Alliance Française de Manila, 2008; Peintures, Salle du Chateau du Limeul, Dordogne, 2009; Vessels, an exhibition of stoneware pottery, Ben Cab Museum, 2011; Pots and Gourds, Galerie Hans Brumann, 2011; and Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi: Paintings and Prints, Bulwagan ng Dangal, UP Diliman, 2012.

Gelvezon-Tequi’s awards include first prize at the Printmakers Association of the Philippines Competition in 1969; a gold medal for the print Retablo at the 35th Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition; Mariang Maya Achievement Award in Graphic Arts from the Sigma Delta Sorority Alumnae Association, Manila, in 1983; Quatrieme Mention, XVIII Salon Ile de France in 1985; the Distinguished Alumni Award for Culture and Arts from UP on its 100th anniversary in 1998; the Michiko Takamatsu Prize in 2002 and the Lucien and Suzanne Jonas Prize in 2003, both from the Salon des Artistes Français, Espace Auteuil, Paris. She was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CCP in 1972.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Gelvezon-Tequi, n.d.; Pineda 2012; Villariba 2008.

GO, FIDEL (Fidel Antiporda Go) b. ca 1940. Potter. The son of Ongkai Go, Fidel is a direct descendant of Chinese merchants who brought burnay pottery to the Philippines early in the 20th century. He is both artisan and owner of one of the remaining burnay kilns in Vigan, Ilocos Sur. Burnay pottery refers to the red-clay earthenware pots turned off a potter’s wheel and fired at very high temperatures, thus making it more durable than terra-cotta. The kilns are enormous, some of them half as long as a city block. The pottery methods used are identical to those in the pottery craft of Fookien in southern China. The pots come in three forms: tapayan or banga, round water jars found in rural homes; the bagoongan, ovate fermenting jars used in Ilocano-speaking regions; and the asinan, small ovate jars for storing salt.

Of the five burnay kilns still active in Vigan, four are no longer in the hands of their original owners and are run as strictly commercial ventures. Go is the only burnayan owner involved in the creative process, which he learned from his father. Dedicated to preserving this unique tradition of Vigan, he operates his own family kiln, working alongside another potter in turning out the claypots with his own hands. Go inherited from his father the old burnayan which was built in 1935. While maintaining the traditional forms, methods, and materials, he has explored new forms and directions in the potter’s art. Although no one in his family has shown the same enthusiasm for this traditional folk art, he shares his skills and talents with the community to ensure the survival and growth of burnay pottery.

In 1990, Go was named Manlilikha ng Bayan, one of the first folk artists to receive the award, for “continuing with conviction the ancient and traditional craft of high-fired Burnayan pottery within his community.” Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

Ballesteros and Corsino 2012.

GOY, AGUSTIN (Agustin Ong Goy) b. Binondo, Manila 3 May 1935. Painter. He is the son of Antonio Goy (Goy Sit San) and Ong Bian Bian. He graduated with a degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas in 1956.

Goy started painting first in oil and watercolor, particularly in the company of VicenteManansala who lived near his place in San Francisco del Monte in the 1960s. They often went on expeditions to paint landscapes together. In the early 1970s, he studied the techniques of Andrew Wyeth and this led him to hyperrealistic painting. He staged his first one-person show at the Hidalgo Gallery in 1972 and has had nine solo exhibitions, including shows at the Finale and West Gallery at SM Megamall in Nov 1992. Shortly after, Goy took a hiatus from the exhibition circuit to devote his time to mastering his craft without the influence of trends in artistic styles. Goy resurfaced for ManilArt 2013 where he exhibited 23 of his works spanning four decades of artistry, from 1971 to 2013.

His most remembered works include King Fisher, 1975, which features rich red marshy humus and patches of puddles captured in bluish grey that provide variety to the almost monochromatic color scheme, and Pahinga (Rest), 1977, which shows a cow nestled in the foreground amidst grass in a sprawling meadow. In the background is a cart full of worn objects evoking distance. Generally, his paintings are meticulously detailed and exude a rich optimistic feeling in contrast to the desolation of the American farms recorded by Wyeth.

In 1957, Goy won first prize in the Bureau of Travel and Trade Industry painting contest.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

GREEN PAPAYA ART PROJECTS or GP is a project space for realizing exhibitions and productions that represent new perspectives on contemporary realities. Initially committed to making space for promising artists based in the region, it has been run as a gallery, performance space, classroom, and residency space for collaborations and exchanges among artists engaged in alternative media.

Co-founded by artists Norberto Roldan, Donna Miranda, Manny Chaves, and curator Bobi Valenzuela, GP opened in 2000 on Maginhawa St in Teacher’s Village, Quezon City. Its inaugural exhibition was The Umbrella Country, a group show named after a semiautobiographical novel by Bino Realuyo. The exhibition featured works from Nunelucio Alvarado, Santiago Bose, Charlie Co, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, and Brenda Fajardo, all of whom were already established names in social realism at that juncture.

Positioned as a noncommercial, artist-run platform, GP later aimed to create an environment for experimentation, research, and representation, setting off a momentum from which artists could mobilize and organize themselves and take active roles in cultural production. A turning point in GP’s programming took place when it was selected by University of the Philippines fine arts professor Gerardo Tan as venue for a group show titled Two for the Road, curated by Roberto Chabet, featuring the works of the graduating class studio majors of 2000. Some of the emergent curators that have since been able to establish platforms for themselves after incubating projects at GP include Lian Ladia and Merv Espina. They belong to a new generation of artist organizers who no longer work in a purely exhibition-centric curatorial mode as they have initiated projects online, and through pirate radio, with some of these projects taking a more-research-based or discursive mode as opposed to an art production/object-making approach.

In 2002, Green Papaya was, along with Big Sky Mind, listed by the Japan Foundation in their directory of independent spaces. Green Papaya relocated to T. Gener St in Quezon City in Aug 2008 and elected a board of directors from within the arts community, all of whom share a belief in the role of alternative and artist-run spaces in keeping the creation and consumption of art dynamic and relevant. GP was invited to London’s Tate Modern Gallery for No Soul for Sale Festival of Independents in 2010. GP was appointed in 2012 as the Philippine partner organization to smARTpower, which is part of the US State Department’s cultural diplomacy program administered by the Bronx Museum of Arts in New York.Written by Alice Sarmiento

Sources:

Papayapost, n.d.; Roldan 2014.

GUERRERO, KATYA (Katya Carratala Guerrero) b. Makati 1 Nov 1970. Multimedia artist. She is the daughter of fashion designer Helena Carratala and photographer Xavier “Wahoo” Roces Guerrero. Guerrero’s partner is painter and photographer At Maculangan with whom she has a daughter. Guerrero began her art studies by taking a course on film at Film in the Cities, Minnesota, 1991, and went on to anthropology and philosophy at the New School for Social Research, New York, 1989. She earned her bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts, 1998. Guerrero is among a generation of artists who studied with Roberto Chabet and who then pursued not only an individual creative practice but also embarked on art initiatives that included curation, continuing education, documentation, and the enabling of the circulation of work of fellow artists.

Guerrero’s body of work straddles diverse media though she is more largely associated with video and installation. While Guerrero’s fairly early work would most logically be construed as conceptual image-making with particular emphases on time, action, and possibly the thwarting of intent, she does acknowledge a strong desire to keep publicly engaged to some degree. This can be seen in several unrealized proposals for public art projects and in her work Outpost, 1998, a collaborative installation she intended as a symbolic occupation of a site tied to both past and present. In it, she coaxed visitors to take on a space at the old Leandro Locsin-built Ayala Museum for the one-night event called Post, curated by artist colleague Jet Melencio. Later on in her practice, Guerrero applied this principle by opening up artist-activated sites to residencies, exhibitions, workshop-seminars, curated slideshows which collectively pose a parallel learning space for visual artists to meet each other, including those in transmedia fields such as music and dance.

Her solo exhibitions include Mind/Matter, College of Fine Arts Dirty Room, 1994; The Revolving Door, Finale Art File, and Natural Disasters, College of Fine Arts Dirty Room, 1995; Leaving Utopia, College of Fine Arts Dirty Room, 1996; Old and New, De La Salle University Art Gallery, 1999; and State of Color, MO Space, 2012. Her group exhibitions include Ikot Stops: Installations in UP Waiting Sheds, UP Diliman, 1993; High (F) Risk Group, Penguin Café, and Hit or Miss, UP Diliman, 1994; The Book as Object, Centro Wifredo Lam, Havana, 1995; Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Pin the Tail, Foot and Line, Connect the Dots, all at UP Diliman, 1995; Painting by Numbers, Cultural Center of the Philippines, and Measure and Metaphor, SM Megamall Art Center, 1995; Dangerous Metaphors, SM Megamall Art Center, 1996; To Barbara and Owen, Picture Show, New Territory, all three at the UP Faculty Center, 1996; Residence Project 11, Makati, Ground Zero, SM Megamall Art Center, The Miter Box, The Plumbing Trap, God, and Other Matters, West Gallery, and Conversation Piece, Ayala Museum, all four in 1998; Double Wall, The Dog Show, and The Lighting Show and Other Incidents, all at Surrounded by Water, 2000; Yokohama Biennale and Spin Cycle, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 2001; Gwangju Biennale, XS XL, Sculpture Square, Singapore, and Its All Over, Surrounded by Water, 2002; Globo!, Philippine Center, New York, 2003; SENI: Art and the Contemporary, Singapore Art Museum, 2004; The Light Show, 2010-11; Mixed Emotions, in collaboration with At Maculangan, Apt 1B, 2011; Complete and Unabridged Part 2 (CHABET: 50 YEARS) and Intermediate Geography, Osage, Kwun Tong, Hong Kong, 2011; Topophilia, Finale Art File, 2012; Picture Imperfect, MO Space, 2013; Coming People, Stedelijk Museum voor Actuele Kunst, Ghent, 2014; and What Does It All Matter, as Long as the Wounds Fit the Arrows?, CCP, 2014.

Guerrero’s inclination to work with other artists has also manifested in collaborative painting with Vicente Butron, Gerardo Tan, and Bernardo Pacquing, 1998, and in variably collaborative performances such as Lift with Nina Hayuma Habulan and Dwight Rodrigazo at the UP Lagoon, 2002; Rambol-Survival Series 1, 2001, Red Green Yellow Series, Katya’s Love Interest, and Cooking with Al Cruz and Silvia Garde, 2000; Untitled with Manny Migriño, 1999; Outpost, 1998, and Cups with Diokno Pasilan and Alan Rivera, 1993. Guerrero is behind several artist-initiated ventures such as the Photography Art Center, 2002; Big Sky Mind, 2003; Pioneer Studios, 2008; and Artbooks.ph, 2014. As an organizer-arts administrator, Guerrero has also figured in curatorial roles as in her teaming up with Nilo Ilarde on Constancio Bernardo: 1913-2013, Ayala Museum, 2014; The Light Show, Manila Contemporary, 2010; Cinema Purgatoryo, NCCA Gallery, Intramuros, 2005; SENI Art and the Contemporary, Singapore Art Museum, 2004; Its All Over, Surrounded by Water, 2002; and What the Hell Is Lomo?, Photography Art Center, 2002. As production designer, her film work includes Toy Chest, 1992; Katakata, 1998; Memories of a Forgotten War, 2001; Sa Ilalim ng Cogon (Under the Cogon), 2005; and Altar, 2007. Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

GUERRERO, LORENZO (Lorenzo Leogardo Guerrero) b. Ermita, Manila 4 Nov 1835. d. 8 Apr 1904. Painter. His parents were Leon Jorge Guerrero and Clara Leogardo. He married Clemencia Ramirez, one of his artistically gifted students. They had nine children, two of whom, Fernando Ma. Guerrero and Manuel Guerrero, were writers.

Guerrero studied at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura under the Spanish art teachers Cortina and Valdes, and later Saez. In 1858, he offered his services as assistant to indio (Christianized native) students at the Academia located on Cabildo St, Intramuros. Aside from teaching painting in the homes of prominent Manila families, he also gave lessons in drawing at the Colegio de Santa Isabel, La Concordia, and Instituto de Mujeres. Among his pupils were Juan Arellano and JuanLuna whom he advised to pursue studies abroad as the academia had nothing more to teach them. Later he also taught Juan Arellano.

As an art teacher, Guerrero’s influence was considerable. His house was the scene of many tertulias (social gatherings), which welcomed such scholarly and artistic personalities as FabiandelaRosa, Vicente Rivera y Mir, and Toribio Antillon. Epifanio de los Santos y Cristobal described him as “a most appreciative critic of the literary and musical arts.” Aside from painting, he also wrote verses and lyrics for songs.

Working in the transition period from the religious to the secular, he did paintings on religious subjects, as well as landscapes and genre. Among his religious works are Santa Filomena (Saint Filomena), San Juan Bautista (Saint John the Baptist), and Nuestra Señora de Guia (Our Lady of Guidance) for the Ermita Church. Other religious paintings are Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother), Santa Veronica de Julianus (Saint Veronica of Giuliani), San Felix de Cantalicio (Saint Felix of Cantalicio), and La Transverberacion de Santa Teresa de Jesus (The Transfixion of Saint Therese of Jesus), which won the gold medal in the tercentenary celebration of Santa Teresa de Avila in 1882.

His secular works include those depicting the elements and known today as The Fire, The Flood, The Storm; those showing local scenes like Taking Water, Cockfighting, Chinese Vendor of Tsin-Tsao, River’s Bend, and Scene at a Brook (the last three were exhibited at the Saint Louis Exposition of 1904); and the landscapes like Landscape, Chorillo de Mariquina (Waterwell in Marikina), and Mariquina Landscape. Of his genre, Vistiendo la Novia (Dressing the Bride) is considered most outstanding. Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

GUILLERMO, ALICE (Alice Vitalis Guerrero-Guillermo) b. Quiapo, Manila 6 Jan 1938. d. Quezon City 29 Jul 2018. Essayist, art critic, art historian, art educator. She was the daughter of Pastor Aquino Guerrero and Teodorica Vitalis. She was married to poet and essayist Gelacio Guillermo; they have two children, one of whom, Ramon or Bomen, is a writer. She finished bachelor of arts and bachelor of science degrees in education, magna cum laude, in 1957 at the College of the Holy Ghost. She then went to the University of the Philippines (UP) where she completed the course requirements leading to a master’s degree. Awarded a scholarship by the French government, she studied at the Universite d’Aix-Marseille in France where she obtained the Certificat d’Etudes Littéraires Generales, the Certificat de Seminaire d’Etudes Superieures, avec mention Assez Bien, with a study of the French nouveau roman, “La Modification par Michel Butor: Thèmes et Structures” and the Diplome de Langue et Lettres Françaises, also Assez Bien, in 1967. She received her doctor of philosophy degree in Philippine studies from UP in 1995. She was a member of the Cultural Research Association of the Philippines and the Concerned Artists of the Philippines. She was professor at the UP Department of Art Studies, 1976-2003, and was subsequently appointed as professor emeritus after her retirement. She served as chair of the department from 1991 to 1994.

She has written numerous reviews and articles for magazines like Archipelago, Observer, Who, We Forum, Business Day, and New Progressive Review. She has written the following books: Mobil Art Awards, 1981; Social Realism in the Philippines, 1987; Blanco: The Blanco Family of Artists, 1987; Images of Change, 1988; The Covert Presence, 1989; Alfredo Carmelo: His Life and Art, 1990; The National Museum Visual Arts Collection and Cebu: A Heritage of Art, 1991; Color in Philippine Life, 1993; Image to Meaning: Essays in Philippine Art, 2001; Protest: Revolutionary Art in the Philippines, 1970-1990, 2001; and Inscapes: the Art of Agnes Arellano, 2008. She is a senior author of the book Philippine Sculpture: From Anito to Assemblage, 1990, and author of an essay for the book Anita Magsaysay-Ho.
