She also participated in the Cultural Center of the Philippines ’ (CCP) Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art) monograph and video series project as essayist-scriptwriter for Sining Biswal: An Essay and Documentary on Philippine Visual Arts, 1989, and Sining Biswal IV: An Essay and Documentary on the American Colonial and Contemporary Traditions in Philippine Visual Arts, 1993. She is co-author of the textbooks Art: Perception and Appreciation, 1976, Ang Sining sa Kasaysayang Filipino (Art in Philippine History), 1991, and Art and Society, 1997. With Imelda Cajipe-Endaya and Santiago A. Pilar, she edited the Visual Arts volume of the CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art in 1994.

She received a Japan Foundation fellowship grant in Tokyo in 1991, a UP Diamond Jubilee Assistant Professorial Chair in 1988, and was a UP Creative Writing Center national fellow for the essay in 1987-88. Her essay “Ang Kaisipang Pilipino Batay sa Sining Biswal” (Filipino Psychology in the Visual Arts) won second prize in the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1979. She won the Art Criticism Award from the Art Association of the Philippines in 1976. In 1999, she was honored by the CCP with the Centennial Honor for the Arts in Art Criticism. In 2014, the Metrobank Art and Design Excellence or MADE competition in writing art criticism was called the Alice Guillermo Art Criticism Award. Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

GUTIERREZ, ROMEO (Romeo Espenilla Gutierrez) b. Tacloban, Leyte 9 Apr 1945. Painter. He is the son of Jose Gutierrez and Purita Espenilla. Romeo married Franceta Aguilar with whom he has three sons. Romeo spent his early years in Baguio City, his father being a Philippine Military Academy graduate. He finished elementary school at Pacdal Elementary School in Baguio City and high school at Jose Rizal College and the Polytechnic Institute (now Central Colleges of the Philippines). He obtained his bachelor of fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1968. He studied art education courses at the University of the East until 1971.

Gutierrez achieved recognition for his carefully deliberated upon compositions that attempted to reconcile abstraction and figuration in an essentially Philippine sensibility. He developed the tendency of breaking down forms along cubistic concepts but through transparent layers of color. By the mid-1970s to the early 1980s, he had evolved tightly knit compositions transforming genre themes into stylized overlapping layers of planes with grainy texture enhanced by embossment. This grainy feel and his undulating lines and monochromatic hues were recognized as his personal innovations.

Gutierrez held his first one-person show at CM Arts Gallery, Timog Ave, Quezon City, in 1969. He exhibited in London and other European cities in 1982, and at the 7th International Biennial of Art in Valparaiso, Chile. In Jul 2014, Gutierrez held his 30th solo exhibit titled Figurative Abstraction at the Art Asia Gallery in SM Megamall.

He received his earliest recognition in 1965 when he won second prize at the UST annual competition. He won a certificate of merit in the Shell National Students Art Competition for Everyday, 1966, and third prize for Indication. He won first prize at the national painting competition sponsored by the Art AssociationofthePhilippines (AAP) and the Philippine Bible Society on the “Interpretation of a Passage from the Bible,” Job’s Agony, 1971. He won honorable mentions and second best entry, AAP graphic competition, 1974; honorable mention for Ang Buhay (Life), Philippine Association of Printmakers Graphic Arts competition; finalist and third best entry, AAP Painting competition, 1975.

In 1987 and 1991, Gutierrez made it as finalist at the third and fifth International Graphic Arts Biennial, both held in Taipei.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Inquirer.net 2014c.

HABULAN, RENATO (Renato Rentoria Habulan) b. Tondo, Manila 30 Mar 1953. Painter. He is the eldest son of Juan Habulan and Alicia Rentoria. He is married to Sylvia Zarsadias with whom he has four children. Through a scholarship, Habulan was able to enter the University of the East School of Fine Arts in 1970-76, during which time he took special tutorship in portraiture under Virginia Jacinto, 1972-76, and a glass blowing course at the National Science and Development Board, 1975. In 1977, Habulan was sponsored by two institutions to travel around Luzon and for a month lived with the Mangyan of Oriental Mindoro. These experiences soon found their way into Habulan’s canvases as he infused ethnic imagery into his painting of social themes. In 1979, Habulan held his first one-person show, Sa Lupa ng Katahimikan (In the Land of Peace). Since then, Habulan has steadily held one-person shows and participated in more than 25 group shows. He was one of the major members of Kaisahan, a group of socially committed artists during the period of the Marcos dictatorship. His art has also brought him to other countries like Japan, South Korea, Thailand, India, Singapore, and Canada, either as a delegate or as a commissioned artist to do murals. He is also a member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines.

Applying realistic figurism, Habulan’s art seeks to portray the contrast between the rich and the poor by painting landlords and tenants, the ilustrados (educated native) as represented by Maria Claras in their fineries, the poor and deprived as typified by Sisa, and the ragged and bent sacada (seasonal cane worker). Habulan later shifted his themes from class struggle to the role of religion and tradition, still in the light of social justice. Habulan is also known for his long-standing collaboration with fellow artist Alfredo Esquillo since the 1990s, where they both have employed their realist inclinations in depicting the Black Nazarene devotions in Quiapo, Manila. Such collaborative efforts took fruit in their joint exhibits at the National University of Singapore Museum in 2012 and at the Vargas Museum in 2014, where their work consisted of multimedia art forms, including film and sculpture.

He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990 and is an active teacher of several generations of emergent artists.Written by Rachel Mayo, updated by Rina Corpuz

Sources:

Guazon 2014; Vargas Museum 2014.

HAFALLA, TOMMY (Bartolome Dulay Hafalla) b. Baguio City 15 May 1957. Photographer and cinematographer. He is the son of Sabas C. Hafalla and Josefina B. Dulay. He attended John Hay Elementary School, and Baguio City High School, 1974. He studied aircraft engineering at FEATI University, 1978, and took film workshops at the University of the Philippines Film Center, 1984.

Known for documenting the scenes and people of the Cordilleras and their ways of life, Hafalla captures arresting photographs showing communities of individuals in both everyday and ritual contexts. He was cinematographer of the documentary Bontoc Eulogy, 1995, directed by Marlon Fuentes and Bridget Yearian. Among his noted exhibits are Images of Ifugao at Hiraya Gallery, 1986, and Images of the Cordillera at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1988-89, and at the Malacañan Museum, 1990.

His photographs capture not only his subjects’ physical appearance but also their spiritual character. His monochromatic and high-contrast photographs of residents of the Cordilleras bear quiet depth. He portrays these individuals amidst their possessions and homes, subtly implying the connectedness of these people to their places of living from which meanings of the objects and practices around them emanate. These photographs do not easily lend themselves to touristic purposes as they are more intent in capturing the aura of the environment and its people, and the history that is contained within and around these sites. Hafalla’s photographs also create a dialogue between the old and the present Cordilleras not only through juxtaposition and use of youth as subject matter but also by presenting individuals who continue to practice and carry out traditional rituals and customs amidst a changing landscape and ways of living. Hafalla believes that items, as well as symbols and rituals, may help young Cordillerans connect to their ancestors. His photographs can also be seen as a testament to the culture of Cordillerans who persevere despite changes occurring within and around their communities.

Hafalla received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1992. His work Cliff Hanger: Death Rite won the Documentary Award from the Humanity Photo Awards in Dazo City, China, 2006, and in Guangzhou, China, 2009. The same film was also accorded the Performance Award in Beijing, China, 2013.Written by Zeny May D. Recidoro

Sources:

Cabreza 2011; Hafalla, n.d.; IMDb, n.d.; Philippine Photography 2009.

HARNISH, HARRY (Harry Whitfield Harnish) b. 16 May 1869. d. San Francisco County, California 4 Jun 1960. Photographer. Not much is known of the life of H. W. Harnish. Accounts tell us that he was a Private of Company D, 14th US Infantry, and served in the American campaign against Muslims in 1898. His last known rank according to records of the United States Department of Veterans Affairs was warrant officer. He served in both the Spanish-American War, 1898, and the First World War, 1914-18. Current available information maintains that after being discharged (the exact date for this is not known), he and his wife Josephine Peas Barnes ran a photograph gallery in Zamboanga, known as the Mrs. H. W. Harnish Gallery. The works of Harnish are known through a photographic collection at the University of the Philippines Library consisting of more than 500 glass negatives, slide plates, film negatives, and prints taken between 1898 and 1907. It is uncertain whether these photographs were taken while he was in active service or were shot as commissioned work or as a hobby, or whether some of the photographs were taken by Mrs Harnish herself, after whom the gallery was, in fact, named.

The photographs were rendered in either black-and-white or were colored by hand. They were taken with what could have been a Penny Picture camera. They consisted of peoples, scenery, and structures from different parts of the Philippines. These “Filipino and Moro” views, accompanied by more than the usual short caption, were sold as postcards in the United States and Europe. Some shots were taken inside the studio, while others were shot against natural settings. Harnish took individual and group portraits of American soldiers and civilians stationed in Zamboanga, as well as portraits of local Filipino families. A variety of ethnolinguistic groups, such as the Ifugao and Itneg of the north, and the Bagobo, Subanon, and Maranao of the south, were likewise represented. Scenic images included seascapes with ships, coastal and riverine views, and everyday activities. Structures included images of residences, religious buildings, military barracks, hospitals, and civic infrastructure, such as bridges, streets, and roads. Except for the colored plates, the photographs were generally “unmediated,” although in the case of portraits, the sitters were often “posed.”

These photographs may be interpreted in a variety of ways, and some have read the images to have been framed from an orientalist perspective or, more specifically, the American colonial administration’s “civilizing” agenda. It is highly possible that as a foreigner, Harnish’s perception of the Philippines was from a vantage point of difference, surfacing, whether wittingly or unwittingly, his biases against other races and ethnicities. At the same time, the photographs may be seen as evidence of aspects of life in a period in the Philippines’ past which are now difficult to access. Written by Marilyn R. Canta

Source:

NCCA 2004.

HECHANOVA, LAMBERTO (Lamberto R. Hechanova Jr) b. Kabankalan, Negros Occidental 29 Mar 1939. d. 31 Aug 2014. Painter, printmaker, sculptor. He studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas and graphic arts and printmaking at Philippine Women’s University. He was active in painting and printmaking, doing abstract works, before he shifted to sculpture.

In a series of highly innovative sculptures, Hechanova introduced the use of aluminum and transparent plexiglass combined with wood. His works thus show the influence of the constructivists who used chrome and plexiglass to achieve virtual volume in sculpture and bring out its spatial dimension. The elements of his work are basically structures made from large transparent cubes and rectangular blocks. The artist employs a highly original approach to his materials. In his art, geometric formality and impersonal technological aspect is mocked by a central assemblage of painted metal parts, randomly twisted and warped. This creates a striking contrast between order and chaos, controlling reason and arbitrary impulse, altogether creating the impression of a streamlined structure with an unpredictable, irrational core. He also did large sculptures in wood, such as the wheel-like Mandala which consists of irregular spokes revolving around a center. Again, it continues a persistent concern for contrasting formal structure with unpredictable elements, regular form with irregular details, reason with creative intuition.

His first one-person show was at the Northern Motors Showroom in 1966. He participated in the Sixth Paris Biennale in 1969. He later held another show at the Agra Gallery in Washington, DC, where he took up residence.

Hechanova received awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: second prize, Algae, 1966; first prize, Perspectus #7, 1967; honorable mention, Sculpture, 1967; third prize, Political Epilogue, 1967; and major award, Allegory in Aluminum, 1968. He won awards in the 1966 Shell National Students Art Competition: fourth prize for Variety No. 1, certificate of merit for Creation, and certificate of merit for The Final Agony. In 1969, he represented the Philippines at the 6th Paris Biennale Art Expo in France with a series of Transfiguration sculptures. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines in 1970.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

HERMISANTO (Herminigildo Abarca Santos)b. Isabela 20 Feb 1951. Visual artist. His parents are Eduardo Santos and Clara Abarca. Hermisanto studied at the College of Fine Arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) in the 1970s and is counted among early Filipino practitioners of environmental and site-specific art. Hermisanto was one of several artists included in the Los Baños Site Works, 1981, perhaps the first outdoor installation and site-specific art exhibition organized in Luzon. Participating artists were advised to use materials found on site. Hermisanto’s piece had three 15-foot pieces of thick vines tied to trees opposite each other. Floating above ground, they traced three strong lines across the clear skies. Birds later on perched on them. Artist Junyee, writing about the piece in the same year, described it as a pleasant alternative to the electrical wires that marred the view of the skies. Hermisanto’s vines may very well have alluded to electric wiring, subtly posing the organic against the synthetic, the crafted against the manufactured.

His installations are often large-scale, open-frame structures incorporating materials from nature like bamboo and vine. This preference for natural materials can be discerned not only in his site-specific works but in his mixed media pieces as well. The artist has used rice husks and grains, for instance, to make abstract forms on a two-dimensional ground. Spheres, horizontal and vertical spans in solid colors combine the natural and the synthetically abstract, yet even in these formal gestures a sentiment for the cycles and patterns found in nature is discerned. These mixed media works make up the bulk of his solo exhibitions, which include Booth #15, 2014, for the Sikat Pinoy art fair at Megamall, and the double segments for Dalawang Daan (Two Routes), 2014, at a Lipa medical center and the Executive House at the UP Campus. Hermisanto’s Palayan ni Hermisanto (Hermisanto’s Ricefield) was shown at the Avellana Gallery in 2011.

Hermisanto collaborated many times with artist Junyee on site-specific projects in 1992 and 1993. Their series featuring bamboo works was called Putok sa Buho (a local expression meaning “coming out of nowhere”; buho is similar to bamboo). This was shown at the Alliance Française de Manille and the Sining Makiling Gallery at UP Los Baños. Hermisanto’s preference for the pliant bamboo is evident in Ode to Mother Nature, 2003, done for the first Bagasbas Beach Eco Arts Festival in Camarines Sur. In this work, bamboo poles were lashed with rattan as pieces of wood and coconut tree husks dangled at various heights from the tips of the poles, making the structure appear like a fish trap when seen from underneath. In 2013, Hermisanto helped Junyee realize the latter’s proposal for PLOT at the UP Diliman Sculpture Garden. It was a network of cans tied to each other to make their tingling sound resonate when pulled from certain nodes. This inclination toward a participative and performative element in site work also informed Hermisanto’s frequent collaborations with other artists, such as his teaming up with Jean Marie Syjuco in her seminal Mano-Mano performances in the 1990s as well as his individual work in the Philippine International Performance Art Festival. Hermisanto has consistently mounted solo and group exhibitions since the 1980s. His works were included in numerous group exhibitions such as Broadstrokes II, 2011, at the Corredor at the UP College of Fine Arts, and Sampu’t Isang Daliri (Ten Plus One Finger), 2014, at Gallery Astra. Hermisanto’s works have also been included in group exhibitions abroad: Singapore in 1995, Thailand in 1993 and 1992, and Italy in 1992. Written by Tessa Maria Guazon

Sources:

ArtsHub 2013; ASEF Culture 360 2015; Espina 2014; Galleria Duemila 2003a.
Hernando, Cesar (See Film volume.)

HERRERA, RODOLFO aka Rody. b. Manila 16 Jan 1925. d. 30 Jul 2009. Illustrator, painter. He first put his artistic talent to use by doing portraits of American soldiers after the Battle of Manila in 1945. In 1947, he won a Don Ramon Roces scholarship through a competition. This enabled him to attend the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts. Honing his skills in anatomy was part of his training as illustrator. When he completed the year, he was employed by the Ramon Roces Publications as illustrator. He stayed with Liwayway for 15 years, from 1948 to 1964, as cover artist and illustrator.

Herrera is one of the few who mastered the art of history painting. In 1964, he resigned to be on his own as a full-time painter. Having trained at the UP School of Fine Arts, he considered FernandoAmorsolo as his dominant influence. From the maestro, he derived the sense of history, tradition, and national identity. From the beginning, he had always considered himself an impressionist, working in a painterly idiom while remaining in the academic tradition. In 1976, he put up an art school in Greenhills, San Juan, where he does individualized teaching. Herrera was the founder of the National Society of Filipino Artists and became its president in 1993.

Herrera won awards from the Art Association ofthe Philippines: second prize, Adamyo, 1951; special award, After the Rain, 1951; honorable mention, Siga (Bonfire), 1953; second prize, Rosary, 1953; and best Philippine genre, Sunday Menu, 1954. Herrera also distinguished himself in history painting in the Rizal Centennial Painting Competition in the 1960s. Six of his entries were awardees—among them, Jose Rizal, Andres Bonifacio, Miguel Malvar, Gabriela Silang, Emilio Aguinaldo, and Apolinario Mabini. His painting Huling Paalam (Last Farewell) won the grand prize. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

HILARIO, RIEL (Ronald Jaramillo Hilario) b. Vigan 9 Sep 1976. Painter, sculptor, writer, curator. He is the son of Hermenegildo Hilario and Juliet Jaramillo. He was a visual arts major at the Philippine High School for the Arts from 1990 to 1994 and studied painting andart history at the College of Fine Arts of the University of the Philippines Diliman from 1994 to 2000. He is the curator of Pinto Art Museum. From 2005 to 2008, Hilario taught art at the Philippine High School for the Arts. He has also participated in conferences here and abroad, including the Multifaceted Curator, held in Jakarta and Bandung, Indonesia, 2006. From 2004 to 2007, he served as secretary of the National Committee on Art Galleries of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Prior to this, he was project officer of the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards, Ayala Museum, 1997-2001, and Sambayan (National Art Festival) 1998. He also co-founded Art Informal in 2004.

Hilario’s strongest works demonstrate his inclination toward the mining of the meaning-making potential and bricolage possibilities in the whimsical assembling of craft elements, specifically of those harking to the making of santos (religious images). Coming from a family of santo makers, Hilario draws from the rich iconography of religious wood carving as well as a childhood interest in astronomy, dreams, and the paranormal. These sources lend his works a magical and dreamlike quality. In the installation he collaborated on with Joel Ajero, It Was a Paradisical State: The Body Was Allowed to Be a Body, 2012, four-legged animals with human heads gaze impassively at the viewer, challenging us to draw out its secrets. In Flight of the Astral Body, 2011, a maiden with night sky wings rides on the artist’s “trademark” aniwaas, a birdlike creature with a human face. While perched atop the bearded head of saint are exquisite corpses, playful yet austere in their introspective air.

He held his first solo exhibit Kristuhan in 1996 at Hiraya Gallery, Manila. Since then, he has held several exhibits in Manila, Vigan, and abroad, including Possible Full Body Apparitions(in collaboration with Janine Go Dimaranan), 2013, The Drawing Room, Gillman Barracks, Singapore; Miracle Machines,2013, Bliss on Bliss Projects,New York; and And He Walked and Spoke at His Birth,2012, Eglise Saint-Merri, Paris, France. His group exhibitions include Sungdu-an 3: National Traveling Exhibition, 2004, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Anyo: Annual Invitational Sculpture Exhibition, 2008, Art Informal, Mandaluyong City; ArtHK 11,2011 Hong KongInternational Art Fair; India Art Summit, 2011, Delhi, India; and the Ateneo Art Awards 10th Year Anniversary Exhibition, 2013.

His awards include an Elizabeth McCormack andJerome Aron Fellowship, 2012; an Asian Cultural Councilgrant, 2012; and an Alliance Française de Manille PhilippineArtist Residency Programgrant, 2012. Also in 2012, Hilario received the Award of Excellence during the Philippine Art Awards, the Ateneo Art Award, and the CCP Thirteen Artists Award.Written by Sofia G. Guillermo

Source:

Hilario, n.d.

ICARANGAL, GERMAN M. b. Balian, Pangil, Laguna 20 May 1914. d. 1984. Painter, illustrator. After his elementary and high school education in Laguna, Icarangal enrolled at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts where he finished his bachelor’s degree in 1933. In 1938, he also finished his degree in architecture at the University of Santo Tomas. To help support his studies, Icarangal worked as illustrator for the magazines Liwayway and the PhilippineGraphic. After earning his degree in architecture, he also taught subjects in the same field. During World War II, he served as a guerrilla officer. He migrated to the United States soon after the war, but he constantly visited the Philippines, residing for long periods to enable him to show his works in several group exhibits and to join various national art competitions.

Trained in the classical tradition, Icarangal belonged to the classical realistic school during the first period of his career. His deftness in the representational style understandably served him well in his career as illustrator for fiction in Liwayway and Graphic. His second period began after visits to the Philippine Art Gallery, which led to experiments in the semiabstract style. His geometrization of the human form and his rendering of shapes through layers of colors indeed show the influence of VicenteManansala’s transparent cubism. Icarangal’s paintings, however, are different from Manansala’s in his preference of dark and somber hues and heavy shading that might have been derived from his experience as illustrator. He also executed figural wood sculptures in which his shapes were also articulated geometrically while his textures were rough to evoke the brawns of the Filipino peon.

Icarangal continued to participate in Philippine shows until 1960 when he joined an art publishing company in the United States. His paintings were reproduced in the Encyclopedia of the Philippines by ZoiloM.Galang, and he is represented in the National Museum Collection.

Stylization along abstract simplification but still inspiring reverence characterized his Madonna in Wood, which won an honorable mention at the ArtAssociation ofthePhilippines (AAP) Sculpture competition in 1951. In the same year, Icarangal won first prize at the AAP watercolor exhibition for Rice Pounding. He won second prize for Sculpture in 1952 and third prize also for Sculpture in 1953.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

IGARTA, VENANCIO (Venancio Claris Igarta) b. Sinait, Ilocos Sur 18 May 1912. d. New York, New York 1 Jun 2000. Painter. Venancio’s parents were Victorio Igarta and Monica Claris. As a child, Venancio was so interested in art that he walked on foot to Badoc, Ilocos Norte, a town adjacent to his own to the north, in order to see a 19th-century oleograph of the Spoliarium by Juan Luna in the aforementioned town, Luna’s birthplace. At 18, he left the Philippines to seek a better life. For four years, he shifted from one farm to another, north to south in California. Later he moved to New York and landed a menial job in an exclusive psychiatric sanitarium. While waiting for errands, he watched the nurse paint flowers on food trays. Called to perform a chore, the nurse left her painting and Igarta automatically took over her work. When she returned, she was so impressed with what he did such that she encouraged him to take formal lessons. Igarta first attended classes at the National Academy of Design, New York, under Charles Curran and Leon Kroll, then in 1938 at the Art Students League of New York under William Palmer. In that year, he first earned praise from a critic named Emily Genaver who wrote in the World Telegram: “One could learn a lot about color by looking at Igarta’s paintings.”

He was the first Filipino to exhibit a painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City. The piece was Northern Philippines, which was hung beside works of Rufino Tamayo, Willem de Kooning, Henry Moore, and Ben Shahn. Northern Philippines became the cover of the May 1942 issue of Fortune Magazine. It showed how Igarta was trying to create a style that expressed the temperament of his country. This he evoked by using earth colors, slanting up his perspective, and depicting images recalling his old Sinait, Ilocos Norte, such as a woman balancing a jar on her head, carabaos, and nipa huts. Banana Bloom, 1946, illustrates the same tendency; this time the canvas is filled up with a close-up of the banana flower, the lines of its petals dominating space such that the subject itself becomes an abstract composition. The key of the composition Bamboo, 1947, lies in the rendering of the visual image in close-up, until the lines of bamboo tubes, the nodes, and young branches become mere abstract compositional elements. All these works prefigure the neorealism that was yet to be inaugurated in 1950. In 1949, Igarta was “discovered” and claimed by his Filipino compatriots in New York. His painting Harvest Scene, reproduced in the Art of the Philippines 1521-1958, is characterized by a surrealistic feeling sensed in the treatment of small figures in a wide space enriched by grain-fine dabs of paint presaging the works of PrudencioLamarrosa, another Ilocano.

In 1991, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila hosted Ang Pagbabalik ni Igarta (Lopez 2014), showing the artist’s neo-expressionist portraits and interpretations of scenes from Biag ni Lam-Ang (Life of Lam-Ang). Igarta exhibited at the Pennsylvania Academy of Arts; Des Moines Art Center, Iowa; Dayton Art Institute, Ohio; and Artisans Gallery, New York City. On the day of his death, Igarta had another show with other Asian American artists titled Milieu Part III, scheduled to open at the Asian American Arts Centre. Igarta was included in the World Biography, 1948. In 1991, a coffee-table book of Igarta’s works was released by Celia Zenaida Aborro and Shehbaz Saframo. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Arcellana 2000; Artasiaamerica, n.d.; Lopez 2014; SAAM, n.d.

IGLESIAS-RODRIGUEZ, MARIA (Maria de la Rama Iglesias-Rodriguez) b. Iloilo 5 Feb 1900. d. 2 Sep 1957. Painter. She is the daughter of Nicolas Iglesias and Ernesta de la Rama, prestigious embroiderer of genre scenes on piña. She married Francisco Jinete Rodriguez, a hacendero from Negros Occidental. Maria’s sister was Monserrat Iglesias, a prominent soprano before World War II. During her early years, her family transferred to Manila. She took her elementary and secondary education at the Santa Isabel College and Philippine Normal School. She began her studies at the University of the Philippines (UP), first studying music. She obtained her certificate in painting in 1927. During her UP years, she consistently bagged the medals of the annual competitions, and in the yearly exhibitions sponsored by the UP President’s Committee on Culture, she always merited the praise of critics. She also figured in art exhibitions held at the Ayuntamiento de Manila, for which reason she was the only woman represented in the collection of the National Museum (then called National Gallery of Arts) prior to World War II, with her Portrait of Emilio Jacinto.

Maria Iglesias is the Philippines’ most highly acclaimed woman painter during the American colonial period. In 1928, Maria Paz Mendoza-Guanzon’s The Development and Progress of the Filipino Women included a picture of Maria Iglesias surrounded by seven large canvases that showed her undoubtable skills as portraitist and landscape painter. In style, these paintings resembled those of FabiandelaRosa. Of these pieces, none seems to have survived the war. Also in 1936, an American art critic reviewing the UP annual exhibition wrote: “Miss Maria Iglesias had among her exhibited pieces 2 first-rate landscapes.” Her extant paintings are found in the UP Vargas Museum, the National Museum, and her daughter’s collection. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

ILARDE, NILO (Nilo Arrastia Ilarde) b. Manila, 23 Jul 1960. Installation and multimedia artist, curator. He is the son of the broadcaster Edgar U. Ilarde and Sylvia Arrastia. His brother Rico is a filmmaker. Ilarde earned his degree in fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts in 1982.

Ilarde’s work, ranging from installation to collage, is influenced by both conceptual and minimalist art practice and by his collaborations with Roberto Chabet since the 1980s. His installations are produced using a broad range of found objects such as a smashed up Volkswagen Beetle to artists’ tools and materials. Shows such as Painting as Something and as the Opposite of Something, 2010, at the Finale Art File reconstitute everyday materials as abject monuments to modernity. In The Triumph of Painting, for instance, Ilarde appropriates a used boxing ring canvas sourced from the Elorde Boxing Gym. This was framed and suspended as if it were a painting within the gallery space. Other installation works explored the process of collecting things like pencil stubs, erasers, and used paint tubes. His collage series, starting in 1999, made use of objects found in artists’ studios—discarded pencils, measuring implements, sketches, cutouts, and even hardened paint pigment transformed into sculptural material.

He likewise utilizes the exhibition space itself as part of the work, deliberately altering it physically, reconfiguring it away from being merely an area of containment to a site in which space itself is imagined as meaning-making material and a way to surface various processes of artistic production. Since 2001, Ilarde’s work increasingly explored the concepts of erasure, excavation, and void in relation to the exhibition space. In the show White Cube, 2001, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), he extracted layers of paint from the actual gallery walls and displayed the result as a literal white cube, remaking both time and space in a single form. Variations of the excised cube appear in later installations in 2004 and 2009, when Ilarde distilled this into single resin cubes in further acts of excavation and erasure, transforming remnants of walls into material objects placed on display.

Ilarde held his first one-man exhibition at the Ayala Museum in 1987, and has subsequently staged at least 17 one-man exhibits since then. From 1983 onward, he participated in various group exhibitions in Hong Kong, Manila, and Singapore. These include Market Forces – Erasure: From Conceptualism to Abstraction, 2014, at Osage Hong Kong and at the City University of Hong Kong; No Talking Points, 2012, TAKSU Singapore; and Complete and Unabridged, Part I, 2011, La Salle Institute of Contemporary Arts, Singapore.

Ilarde served as the exhibition director of the Pinaglabanan Galleries from 1984 to 1985. He has curated numerous exhibitions of Philippine contemporary art in the Philippines and in Singapore beginning 1980. These include shows at the CCP, UP College of Fine Arts, Jorge B. Vargas Museum, Mag:net Galleries, West Gallery, Finale Art File, Mo_Space, and SM Megamall Art Center. Ilarde was selected for the 1980 Young Arts in Asia Now exhibition at the Hong Kong Art Center. He also received the top award in the painting category of the 1981 Art Association of the Philippines competition. Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Ilarde 2013; Ito 2014c.

IMAO, ABDULMARI (Abdulmari Asia Imao) b. Jolo, Sulu 14 Jan 1936. d. Manila 16 Dec 2014. Sculptor, photographer. National Artist for visual arts. His parents were Jamasali Allih and Asia Imao. Raised by a maternal uncle, Captain Abdurahim Imao, he finished his elementary at the Jolo Central School (now Muhammad Tulawie Central Elementary School) and secondary education at the Sulu Trade School (now Hadji Butu School of Arts and Trade). He married Grace de leon of Santo Tomas, pampanga, who died in 2012. They had four sons: Abdulmari Jr, Josemari, Juan Sajid, and Alkarim—all visual artists. He earned a bachelor of fine arts from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1959 and a master of fine arts from the University of Kansas in 1962.

As a sculptor and painter, he drew his inspiration from the Tausug and Maranao artistic traditions of southern Philippines, particularly design motifs from okir (traditional Tausug and Maranao sculpture) wood carving, which he reinterprets in a contemporary idiom. His art evolved by employing four distinct but interrelated themes: Islamic calligraphy; the sarimanok, a mythical bird with a fish in its beak; the sari-mosque, a design combining the sarimanok and the form of the mosque; and the sari-okir. He executed these themes through different sculptural processes, mainly metal casting, welding, embossing or repousse, as well as painting. He made use of different mediums, mainly brass and bronze, in sculpture. Imao combines okir and Arabic calligraphy to create sculptural variations in the name of Allah. Imao’s art has a highly developed technological basis in his moulds of dolomite or white carbide stone, ignited or fossilized coal, or raw marble dust, technologies that have been widely adapted in the Southeast Asian region.

His first solo exhibit in 1960 was held at the Contemporary Art gallery in Mabini. He took graduate studies at the University of Kansas, 1960; Rhode island school of Design, 1962, where he studied brass casting, creative sculpture, and ceramics; and at Columbia University, 1962-63. His sculpture The South Pacific Trail was displayed for two years at the New York Museum of Modern Art. His major works during this period include The Muslim Warrior, Animal Monument, Muslim Prayer, Woman by the River, The Birds, Sultan Family, and Water Buffalo. His other works include Industry Brass Mural for the Philippine National Bank; Mural relief on Filmmaking for the Manila City Hall; Industrial Mural for the Central Bank of the Philippines; Sulu Warriors, Statues of Panglima Unaid (a local hero of Silangkan, Sulu), and Captain Abdurahim Imao for the Sulu Provincial Capitol; the Pres Elpidio Quirino monument, Manila; Amai Pakpak: Hero of Marawi, Lanao del Sur; Vicente alvarez: Katipunero general, Zamboanga City; Datu Oto, Hero of rajah Buayan, General santos City; Tawi-tawi Freedom Monument; Aman dangat: Hero of batanes; Sultan Kudarat’s Battle at tantawan, Cotobato, Philippine International Convention Center; Antonio Pigafetta Monument, Fort san Pedro; Allah Islamic Calligraphy, UP Vargas Museum; Angel of peace, manila memorial Park; Sculptures and Calligraphy, Muslim maharlika Village; Water Buffalo, Ateneo Art Gallery; Creative Fishes, Purita Kalaw-Ledesma collection; stained glass of a minaret, sarimanok, and kris, Sulu Provincial capitol, Jolo; and sarimanok paintings, Central Bank of the Philippines.

His received awards from the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP): third prize for Muslim Prayer and a bronze medal in the Southeast asia tenth Annual Art Exhibition; third prize, Animals Memorial, 1960; third prize, Moslem Prayer, 1962; and gold medal for sculpture, 1980. One of his early works, Inah Iban anak (Mother and Child), a tribute to his mother, won the top prize in a 1956 sculpture competition. In 1971, he represented the country in the Seventh Paris Art Biennale. He received the Ten Outstanding Young men of the Philippines Award, 1968; the Araw ng Maynila Award for sculpture from the city of Manila, 1985; an honorary doctor of humanities, Western Mindanao State University, 1985; Order of the raja baginda for Most Outstanding Contribution to Philippine Art, 1987; Most Outstanding Professional Alumni Award for Fine Arts, UP, 1986; and the gawad CCP para sa Sining, 1990. In 2005, he received the Presidential Medal of Merit from the Office of the President, Malacañan Palace. He was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts in 2006.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Sakili 2006; Sharief 2007.

IMAO, TOYM (Abdulmari de Leon Imao Jr) b. 1968. Sculptor and painter. He is the oldest son of National Artist Abdulmari Asia Imao and Grace de Leon. He finished bachelor of science in architecture at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 1992 and a master of fine arts in sculpture at Rineheart School of Sculpture, Maryland Institute College of Art, Baltimore, Maryland, USA in 2012. From 2010 to 2012, he enjoyed a Fulbright scholarship, the William M. Philips ,54 Memorial Scholarship, and the Rineheart School of Sculpture Scholarship, the last two from Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore. He lectured at the College of Fine Arts, UP Diliman, in 2008-10 and in 2016.

He has held more than 10 solo exhibitions, among them, Head of State, UP Diliman, Quezon City in 2013; Last, Lost, Lust for Four Episodes (Voltes V), UP Diliman, 2014; Coping with a Couple’s Copious Conjugal Cupboard of Curios, Cops, Cuffs, and Corpses (Mazinger Z), UP Diliman, 2015; Desaparecidos: Memorializing Absence, Remembering the Disappeared, UP Diliman; AlterNOTION + AlterNATION: Alternative Imagi(ni)ng of History, Bulwagang Carlos V. Francisco, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Abdulmari Asia Imao’s Visual Journey, Museo Pambata, Manila, all in 2015. He participated in group exhibitions from 2010 to 2016 in various galleries in the Philippines, such as the CCP, Ayala Museum, Galerie Joaquin, UP Bulwagan ng Dangal, Galerie Nicolas, Galeria Roces; and in Baltimore, Maryland, USA such as Fox Gallery 3, Pinkard Gallery, The Creative Alliance Gallery, and Decker Gallery.

As a public art sculptor, he has designed and built busts and monuments honoring heroes like Francisco Dagohoy, Jose Rizal, Andres and Procopio Bonifacio, Apolinario Mabini, Gregorio Aglipay, Francisco Macabulos, and Teodoro Alonzo; Catholic saints like St. Therese of the Child Jesus, St. Lasalle, Lorenzo Ruiz, and Pedro Calungsod; and prominent Filipinos like Ramon Magsaysay, Corazon C. Aquino, Hilario Davide Jr, and Diosdado and Eva Macapagal, James Reuter, and Leandro V. Locsin.

His awards include Grand Prize, First National Letras y Figuras Painting Competition, Instituto Cervantes and the Spanish Embassy, Manila, 1994; Most Outstanding Capampangan Award in the field of sculpture, provincial government of Pampanga, 2003; Gawad Parangal para sa Sining, sa Larangan ng Kultura, Quezon City, 2010; Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan (Sculpture) City of Manila, 2012; Best Production Design, New Breed Category for K’na, the Dreamweaver, Cinemalaya 10, 2014; and Best Set Design for Tanghalang Pilipino’s Mabining Mandirigma, Philstage Gawad Buhay Award, Manila, 2016.Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson

INGLE, LYDIA (Lydia Rivera Ingle) b. Manila 11 Oct 1934. Painter, pianist, writer. She is the daughter of Pablo Rivera and Lourdes Consunji. She married George Ingle in England and had three children. After her graduation from college in Silliman University in 1953, Ingle went to Madrid in 1954, and then to France to take up informal studies in drawing and painting at the Academie Julien. The following year, she went to Regent Street Polytechnic in London. Her stay in England marked a milestone in her piano career when she passed the final performance examinations given by the Associated Board of Royal Schools of Music in 1975. She worked as an employee of the Philippine Embassy in London, 1957-67. She returned to Davao in 1975 where she continued her dual career as a pianist and painter, and later took on environmentalism as a vocation.

Ingle’s paintings of women and children are done with much tenderness and delicacy. Linear in style, the figures are individualized like portraits, while beyond the sensitive particularity of the women is a penetrating insight into the small, continually shifting gestures and postures of a relational body language that tells of elusive inner moods and attitudes.

Ingle’s literary talents have not been neglected. She wrote a novel on the local landed class, as well as a prize-winning biography, Edades: Kites and Visions, 1980, of the pioneer modernist VictorioEdades, who had settled in Davao. Her biographical work on Edades eventually became the basis of the script of a documentary drama about the artist, released in 2004.

Ingle participated in a group show of women artists in Mar 1993 at the Liongoren Gallery. In Sep 2000, Ingle participated in another exhibit, Seven Women: Windows of Davao, at the Gallery M of the Barcelo Royal Mandaya Hotel in Davao, with the aim of celebrating womanhood and nature in 58 works by seven Davao-based women artists. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

de Ungria 2000; Tejero 2004.

ISIDRO, RAUL (Raul Gomez Isidro) b. Calbayog City, Samar 2 Mar 1943. Painter. He went to Calbayog Elementary School, Samar, 1950-56, and finished high school at Christ the King College in 1960. He is married to Annabella Isidro, and their daughter Tricia has studied fashion and interior design. Isidro studied fine arts, majoring in advertising, at the University of Santo Tomas (UST), 1961-65. He also took up postgraduate studies in advanced painting at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) College of Fine Arts in 1968. He was a faculty member of the PWU College of Fine Arts, 1969-75, and served as its director, 1975-77. He also taught at the fine arts department of the College of Holy Spirit, 1972. In 1985-87, he was the art director of Studio Five Designs Inc in California. In 1983, he was the president of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) as well as the president of the Philippine Association of Printmakers in 2000 and 2001, and organized its Traveling Print Workshop and Exhibition in 2001-3. In 2009, he organized and was a co-chairman of the Light Railway Transport National Art Competition.

Isidro was fascinated with abstract forms from the start of his career. His Seinegung (Affection), 1966, which appeared in Philippiniche Malerei, Germany, showed concern for meaningful organization through forms emphasizing the plasticity of the oil medium. In the early 1970s, Isidro returned to figuration in works using acrylic on metal etching. But his shapes led him to realize the potential of bold lines for calligraphic abstract expression. In the mid-1970s, his works turned pure abstract with bold but impersonal gestures of the brush conveying dynamic mental and emotional configurations. This stage is represented by his Festival series in the exhibition Insights into Philippine Contemporary Art. In this series, Isidro’s calligraphic gestures were made sleek because he coated his surfaces with thick polishes of lacquer.

He had his first solo exhibition, Lunar Series, in 1969 at the Solidaridad Galleries, followed by other solo exhibitions at the Luz Gallery, 1972, 1973, 1974, 1980, 1995, 1996; Gallery A, San Francisco, 1990, 1991; I.S. Gallery, Fremont, California, 1992; Pacheco Gallery, 1994, 1996; Gallery 139, Alabang, 1995, 1997; Crucible Gallery, 1996; Negros Museum, Bacolod, 1997; A Collection of Monoprints, West Gallery, 2003; Windows, Ricco Renzo Galleries, 2004; Impressions, Yellow Door Gallery, 2006, 2007; Mother Earth 40 Years Retrospective Exhibit, Cultural Center of the Philippines, 2008; Andorra, Galerie Anna, 2011; Impressions II, Artist Space, Ayala Museum, 2011, 2012; and Raul Isidro: Abstract Landscapes, Ayala Museum, 2013.

Isidro’s many awards include second prize, UST Painting Competition in 1963, 1965, and 1967; second prize, 17th Shell National Students Art Competition for Way In and a certificate of merit for Genesis of Man, 1967; second top awards, First SPS National Sculpture Competition, 1968; first prize, First National Sculpture Competition, Luneta Park, 1969; first honorable mention, AAP Annual Art Competition for Lunar Orbit, 1969; and first prize, PAP annual exhibition and competition, 1972. He was a Ten Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines awardee for fine arts in 1979. In 1981, he received the Australian Government Cultural Grant Award and gave lectures on Philippine contemporary art in five major Australian universities. Other awards include Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila, 1998; Outstanding Thomasian Alumni Award, 2006; and Outstanding Samareño Award, 2011.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Ayala Museum 2013b; D’Bayan 2009a; Isidro, n.d.

IZON, ESMERALDO (Esmeraldo Zulueta Izon) aka E.Z. Izon. b. Samal, Bataan 8 May 1911. d. mid-1990s. Cartoonist, photographer, painter. He was the son of Gregorio Izon and Isabela Zulueta.

Izon’s mother passed away when he was nine years old. After that, he and his family migrated to Manila (Izon 1993). In college, he took fine arts at the University of the Philippines and started working in the Philippines Free Press when he was 22 years old. Together with Jose Pereira, Izon did the prewar editorial cartoons of the Free Press. When Pereira left the Philippines Free Press in 1938, Izon took over Pereira’s box on page one of the periodical until it was shut down during the Japanese occupation in 1942. Izon joined the “underground” movement during the occupation and became captain of President Quezon’s Own Guerrillas (PQOG), doing the illustrations for the guerrilla news magazine The Liberator (Izon 1993). He also worked for the US Office of War Information, creating the illustrations for the leaflets dropped in Hiroshima and Nagasaki before the fateful bombing of these two places (Izon 1993). He resumed his job as editorial cartoonist of the Philippines Free Press when the periodical reopened in 1946. In 1972, censorship under martial law closed down the critical Philippines Free Press. When the periodical resumed its publication in 1986 after the fall of the Marcos regime, Izon rejoined the periodical, doing the page-one editorial until his demise in the mid-1990s.

Aside from creating editorial cartoons, Izon served as a photographer and did some of the photo shoots for the cover of the Philippines Free Press (Izon 1993). He also painted portraits and landscapes and held art showsin several venues locally and in other countries. He held art shows at the Gallery Amerisia in Washington, DC, and the Galerias Internationales in Dover Delaware in 1978 (Izon 1993). He also exhibited his paintings at theManila Peninsula in 1982 and at the Hidden Treasure Gallery in 1983 (Izon 1993).

Izon’s illustrious career spanned the prewar and postwar periods. His works accompanied the most stinging and controversial editorials of the Philippines Free Press, the magazine described as “the most uncompromising proponent of adversarial journalism in the country” (Maranan 2007). Izon’s visual satires were as acerbic as the written editorial they accompanied. Pointed as they were, his cartoons also had a poetic quality capable of strong symbolism and metaphor. Izon’s style displayed a range of characteristics drawing from somber realism to hyperbolic humor. Like the works of his predecessor Jose Pereira, Izon’s cartoons had a narrative, almost filmic quality. Unlike Pereira’s playing up of his famous cross-hatching technique, Izon’s works highlighted tonal gradation through smudging and shadowing.Written by Helen Yu-Rivera

Sources:

Izon 1993; Maranan 2007.

JAMIR, NAP II (Napoleon Covarrubias Jamir Jr) b. Manila 27 May 1952. Photographer and filmmaker. He is the son of the photographer Napoleon Jamir Sr and Milagros Covarrubias. His father had the distinction of holding the first solo photography exhibition at the Philippine Art Gallery in 1952. Jamir II is a senior lecturer at the University of the Philippines (UP) Film Institute, the Department of Visual Communication of the UP College of Fine Arts (CFA), and the Asia Pacific Film Institute. He finished his undergraduate degree in communication arts in 1971 at Ateneo de Manila University, where he later taught basic cinematography from 2007 to 2009.

His sustained interest in street photography beginning 1978 enabled his participation as Philippine representative to the 1981 ASEAN Traveling Exhibition of Paintings/Photography and the Valparaiso Biennale of Prints.

By the 1980s, Jamir, along with fellow photographer Neal Oshima, put together Shadow Visual Design Group Inc, which, among other similar engagements, has earned him multiple awards from critics and from within the commercial industry. Credits include work on TV for National Artist Eddie Romero’s series Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1992, and as director of photography for Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995; Rizal sa Dapitan (Rizal in Dapitan), 1997; Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros (The Blossoming of Maximo Oliveros), 2005; Twilight Dancers, 2006; Boses (Voice), 2008; Maximus & Minimus, 2009; Long Live Philippine Cinema, 2009; Lauriana, 2013; Hustisya (Justice), 2014; El Brujo (The Wizard), unreleased; and Himala Ngayon (Miracle Today), 2012, a documentary on the 30th anniversary of National Artist Ishmael Bernal’s film classic Himala (Miracle), 1982.

Jamir’s solo exhibitions include those at Shop 6, 1974, Sining Kamalig; Printings, 1975, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Small Gallery; Eccentric Exposures, 1979, CCP Hallway; Paris Shots, 1979, Penguin Café Gallery; Jazz Portraits, 2005, Ayala Museum and Mag:net Gallery Katipunan; Torso, 2006, Lumiere Gallery; and sNAPshots Series 01 Sydney, 2010, new Penguin Café Gallery.

Among Jamir’s group exhibitions are the Inaugural Show, 1973, Sanctuary Gallery; Buklatan (Unfolding), 1973, CCP Small Gallery (now also known as Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo); Group Show, 1974, Sining Kamalig; Otherwise Photography, 1974, CCP Small Gallery; Shop 6, 1974, Sining Kamalig; Thirteen Artists exhibition, 1974, CCP Main Gallery (now also known as Bulwagang Juan Luna); Recent Developments in Printmaking, 1975, CCP Small Gallery; Five Artists, 1975, Luz Gallery; Shop 6 at the CCP, 1975, CCP Main Gallery; Inaugural Exhibition, 1976, Contemporary Art Museum of the Philippines; the CCP Annuals from 1976 to 1978; Nine Photographers, 1978, CCP Main Gallery; Word Works, 1979, CCP Small Gallery; Work No. 4 at The Farm, 1980, San Francisco, CA; CCP Annuals, 1980-81, CCP Main Gallery; Works on Paper Inaugural Exhibition, 1980, Third Level Gallery, SM Cubao; Otherwise Photography II, 1981, CCP Main Gallery; Moving Pictures: Two Man Show Butch Perez / Nap Jamir, 1982, Cx2 Gallery of Photography; The Decisive Movement, 1982, Alliance Française Gallery; SUGBA Group Show, 2005, SM Art Center, Cebu City; 5 Masters Group Show, 2005, One Workshop Gallery; SUGBA Group Show, 2006, Treebu Showroom and Tirol Museum, Boracay; group show featuring UP CFA teachers–CCP Thirteen Artists awardees, 2008, CCP Bulwagang Juan Luna; SUGBA Group Show, 2008, Herald Suites Gallery; Group Show, 2013, UP Visayas; and Spatial Halo-Halo (Spatial Hodge-Podge), 2013, UP CFA Corredor Gallery.

Jamir received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1974. Among many other film-related awards, he received the Gawad Urian for Best Cinematography for his work on Ang Pagdadalaga ni Maximo Oliveros in 2006 and the Young Critics Circle citation for Best Achievement in Cinematography and Visual Design for Lauriana in 2014.Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

JARQUE, EUGENE (Eugene Quieng Jarque) b. 13 Oct 1974. He is the son of Sergio Dioquino Jarque and Salvacion Tañon Quieng. He earned his bachelor’s degree in fine arts, major in advertising, in 1995 from the Technological University of the Philippines, where he also began teaching in 1999.

Jarque’s first solo exhibition, Unparalled, 2001, was held at the Avellana Art Gallery. Here he first demonstrated a resolute inclination toward a constructivist strain of abstraction that can be seen in his body of works. Jarque has consistently shown carefully built-up, textured surfaces borne of impasto painting, wood, metal, and glue. Jarque’s work suggests an ambivalent attitude toward structure where the deftly composed topmost surface still retains an unfinished or gruff texture, perhaps to serve as foil to the cold minimalist feel of his pieces. His later works suggest a readiness to move away from the flat and planar through excursions into the more definitively sculptural.

Unparalled was followed by solo exhibitions mostly at the Avellana Gallery, such as Inside Out, 2005; Surface Tension, 2006; Blocks, 2009; No Moving Parts, 2010; Assymetry, 2011; Scratch Build, and Monotonic, Blanc Gallery, 2012; Disassemble, 2013; and Fill, 2014, Finale Art File. Among his group exhibitions are Square Roots, 1997, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Distinctions, 1998, Negros Museum; Pangunahing Udyok III (First Impulse 3), 2001, Surrounded by Water Gallery; Pangunahing Udyok: Ikaapat na Yugto (First Impulse: Fourth Segment), Baguio Botanical Garden Gallery, 2002; Arte Orientale, Casa de Cantabria, Madrid, Spain, 2002; Zero-in Constructs, A/P Analog Playground, 2005, Ateneo Art Gallery; WAHANA, 2005, Jorge B. Vargas Museum; Room 307-Inkling Gutfeel and Hunch, 2008, National Art Gallery, National Museum of the Philippines; Art Beijing, 2008, National Agricultural Exhibition Center (New Hall), Beijing, China; Everything Is Temporary, 2009, Blanc Compound; TutokSONA (Watch SONA), 2009, Manila Contemporary; Shoebox Dioramas 2, 2009, West Gallery; Implode, 2010, CCP; Collage Drop Outs, 2011, Finale Art File; Incidental Pleasures, 2012, Mo Space; and Into the Woods, 2013, Manila Contemporary.

Jarque won second place, watercolor category, in the Metrobank Foundation’s Young Painters Annual in 2000. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2006. Written by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

JAVIER, GERALDINE (Geraldine Guillen Javier) b. Manila 2 Apr 1970. Painter and intermedia artist. She is the daughter of Edilberto A. Javier and Aurora T. Guillen. She received her bachelor of science degree in nursing from the University of the Philippines (UP) Manila in 1991. She then took up painting at UP Diliman where she received her bachelor’s degree in fine arts in 1997. She was part of the collective Surrounded by Water between 1999 and 2003.

Geraldine Javier’s early works are paintings that tend to be photorealistic. Often replete with decorative elements, she creates implied textures that balance the sleek paint surface of her canvases. Her paintings for Butterfly’s Tongue, 2009, West Gallery, feature banal subject matter, ranging from children at play, appropriations of romantic works and religious imagery, as well as floral motifs, either embedding insects or integrating embroidered figures, or both, on canvas.

Javier’s exhibition Always Wild, Still Wild, 2011, at Finale Art File demonstrates one of her forays into installation. Javier recreates an orchard based on personal memory, recalling a place of “childhood wonder.” Here, she evoked a nostalgic setting where the artist’s figure can be found embroidered on a handmade hammock, against the backdrop of a tree mural with fibrous nests, and framed animal figures adorned with tatting lace. The pressed leaves that lend a sensual quality to her works can also be found in her prints depicting the changing seasons as well as inventive configurations of insects and skeletons. A poetic reflection on evolution and natural history, she produced these in line with her residency at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute, which culminated in the exhibition Playing God in an Art Lab, 2012.

The artist’s solo exhibitions from 2011 to 2013 reveal a more active engagement with installation. Javier’s alter ego, Madame A, is conjured in her later exhibitions as an important part of the narrative. Referencing sacred spaces such as museums and chapels, Javier sets up environments to showcase her penchant for painting, working with minutiae, collecting, encasing, preserving, and exhibiting. These exhibitions include Curiosities, 2013, UP Vargas Museum; Chapel of Many Saints and Sinners, 2012, Equator Art Projects Gallery, Singapore; and Museum of Many Things, 2011, Valentine Willie Fine Art, Singapore. In 2013, Javier’s solo exhibitions include Stuck in Reverse at Arndt Gallery, Berlin, Germany, and Beyond the Veil at Arario Gallery, South Korea. She has participated in numerous group exhibitions such as Asia Looking South, 2011, Arndt Gallery; Prague Biennale, 2009, Prague, Czech Republic; and Beacons of Archipelago, 2010, Arario Gallery.

Javier received the Thirteen Artists Award in 2003 and the Ateneo Art Award in 2004.Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

Source:

Javier 2014.

JOCANO, OJENG (Ojeng Catli Jocano) b. Manila 12 Jan 1958. Printmaker. He is the son of Rodolfo Jocano and Aleli Catli. He married Ana Gallego. Studying fine arts at the University of the Philippines, he worked closely with his printmaking teacher Virgilio Aviado. He has since gone full time into printmaking, and has been active in graphic arts workshops of the Philippine Association of Printmakers in the late 1980s and the Mariposa Workshop.

Jocano keenly developed etching and aquatint techniques in his prints, which are characterized by fine intricate lines, gentle rhythmic movement, low tonal contrast, great variety of texture, and well-balanced design. In terms of subject matter, he has preferences for dreamlike images, pursuing the path of the surreal and the occult in Aviado’s earlier style. He treats erotic themes in a subtle, magical way, recomposing human internal organs with botanical forms. Thus a man with an ambivalent kidney-shaped body may grow a scrotum and phallus in his chest, or ginger-like roots would sprout female breasts as in his etching Raw Plant, 1978. Atlas, 1978, also an etching and aquatint work, is drawn like a zoologically dissected human specimen juggling his own internal organs in the air. The artist also loves to create X-rayed images, combining these with circular forms that appear like magnified cells seen through a microscope.

Jocano has won at least three major awards for his graphic works in the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition, the highest of which was the grand prize in 1979, which included a scholarship grant for three months at the International Yoshida Hanga Academy in Japan. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya

JOCSON, CRISPULO (Crispulo Papa Jocson) b. Manila 9 Jun 1850. d. 1927. Wood-carver, sculptor. He was the son of Remigio Jocson and Marta Papa. He married Marcela de la Cruz, with whom he had four children. His sister Victoria married Isabelo Tampinco who was commissioned to carve the interiors of the SanIgnacio Church,Intramuros. For the San Ignacio Church, Jocson carved the image of the La Inmaculada Concepcion (The Immaculate Conception). With Manuel Flores, he also carved the SanIgnacioChurchpulpit, following the design of Agustin Saez. These were all destroyed when American planes bombed Manila in 1945.

Some of his surviving sculptures are the Crucifix, which he carved with Fernando Jocson; a life-size crucifix in the SanAgustinChurch, Intramuros; a Cristo Rey (Christ the King), table-size, in wood; a La Sagrada Familia (Holy Family); and a Cristo de las Misericordias (Christ of Mercy).

Unlike other wood-carvers and contemporaries, Jocson sometimes chiseled out his name or initials on the bottom or back of his works. Jocson remained faithful to the traditions of 19th-century sculpture until his death.Written by Santiago A. Pilar and E. Arsenio Manuel

article_title: Jorge B. Vargas Museum and Filipiniana Research Center
text:
JORGE B. VARGAS MUSEUM ANDFILIPINIANA RESEARCH CENTER. The museum is located at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in Quezon City. It was named after the politician and collector-philanthropist Jorge B. Vargas. Vargas, 1890-1980, donated his art, library, personal archives, numismatic and philatelic collections to his alma mater on 1 Mar 1978. Prior to the transfer of the collection to the university, Vargas had housed these objects in Kawilihan, his family compound located in Mandaluyong City. The museum officially opened on 22 Feb 1987 with President Corazon C. Aquino as guest of honor.

The Vargas art collection covers turning points in Philippine art and sociopolitical history, providing a survey of works from the late 19th-century Spanish colonial period, the American and Japanese occupations, the post-World War II years, until the end of the 1960s. There are over 500 artworks documented in the museum catalogue, majority of which are paintings, drawings, or prints, along with 21 pieces of sculpture. Artists represented in the collection include Simon Flores, Lorenzo Guerrero, Juan Luna, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, Fabian de la Rosa, Graciano Nepomuceno, Guillermo Tolentino, Fernando Amorsolo, and his contemporaries from the UP School of Fine Arts including Jorge Pineda, Irineo Miranda, Teodoro Buenaventura; modernists including Victorio Edades, Federico Alcuaz, Juan Arellano, Cesar Legaspi, Diosdado Lorenzo, Vicente Manansala, H.R. Ocampo, Nena Saguil, and Fernando Zobel. The museum has also gained recognition for having the most number of works by Fernando Amorsolo in a public collection. Within the museum premises is the Vargas Archives, made up of documents, books, and other objects related to Vargas and his family (Vargasiana); Manuel L. Quezon (Quezoniana); Jose Rizal (Rizaliana); Sports; Law; as well as Philippine periodicals and serials circulated during the Commonwealth period and the Japanese occupation. In 2011, the significance of the Quezon Papers was inscribed in the UNESCO Memory of the World, citing the Vargas Museum as one of the custodians of this documentary heritage. In recent years, the Vargas Archives were activated in line with the museum’s contemporary art program.

The exhibition and education programs of the museum are constantly being developed to accommodate publics within the university and beyond. Previously operating under the UP College of Fine Arts, museum programming was turned over to the UP College of Arts and Letters in 1995. Since then, Vargas Museum has been headed by a faculty-curator appointed by the dean of the college. Past and present curators include Aurora Roxas-Lim, 1989-94; Ma. Victoria Herrera, 1994-95 and 2008-9; Regalado Trota Jose, 1995; Brenda Fajardo, 1995-2001; Ana Ma. Theresa Labrador, 2001-8; and Patrick Flores, beginning 2009.

The museum holds a permanent exhibition of the Vargas Collection in its second floor gallery. Other galleries are devoted to temporary exhibitions of contemporary art and other interdisciplinary projects. For the museum’s contemporary art initiatives, the Vargas Museum was named Museum of Contemporary Art of the Month by ZKM Center for Art and Media Karlsruhe, Germany, in Feb 2011.Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

JOYA, JOSE (Jose Tanig Joya) b. Manila 3 Jun 1931. d. Manila 11 May 1995. Painter. National Artist for the visual arts. He was the son of Jose Joya Sr and Asuncion Tanig. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1953 with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts and was the first magna cum laude of the UP College of Fine Arts. In 1954-55, the Instituto de Cultura Hispanica of the Spanish government awarded him a painting grant to Madrid. A year later, he finished his master’s degree in painting under a Fulbright-Smith-Mundt grant. He also received a grant from the John D. Rockefeller III Fund and Ford Foundation to paint in New York from 1967 to 1969. He was dean of the UP College of Fine Arts, 1970-78. Joya had initially wanted to become an architect, but the mathematics and science subjects discouraged him. At UP, he was exposed to the paintings of Fernando Amorsolo. Among his other early influences were Vicente Manansala and Anita Magsaysay-Ho. His first works were mostly representational. During the late 1950s, he gradually shifted to abstract painting and became one of the leading proponents of abstract expressionism. Joya has also done paintings in ceramics, as well as sketches in pentel.

He held many one-person shows here and abroad starting in 1954 at the Philippine Art Gallery. He represented the Philippines with Napoleon Abueva in the 1964 Venice Biennial. In 1981, a retrospective of his works was held at the Museum of Philippine Art. In 2011, another retrospective titled Joya: Balik-Tanaw (Joya: A Retrospective) was held at the National Museum. Showing 73 art pieces, it also marked the artist’s 80th birth anniversary and the launch of the Joya Festival 2011. In 2012, the UP College of Fine Arts presented the exhibition Jose Joya: Scholar, Artist and Mentor, which focused on the life of the National Artist at UP as Joya’s academic career spanned 39 years, 1957-95, during which he was a great influence on students and faculty. In 2013, on the 10th anniversary of Joya as National Artist, an exhibition titled Joya: A Modern Native was held at the Rockwell Tent. It showed two large murals, Lanterns of Enlightenment and Mariveles, along with a number of travel sketches drawn on the spot using pencil, charcoal, or pastel on drawing paper from the artist’s numerous overseas trips.

Among the positions he held were president of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), 1962-65, and chairperson of two Philippine delegations to China, 1961 and 1972. He served as chairperson of the National Committee on Visual Arts of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. He won several awards and distinctions from the AAP: first prize, Cathedral, 1958; second prize, Space Transfiguration, 1959; third prize, City Entering the Edge of Sundown, 1951; third prize, House of Life, 1960; purchase award, Church Silver, 1960; second prize, Cathedral, 1962; and honorable mention, Yellow Harvest, 1962. He won first prize for Gossips in the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1952 and was finalist for An Abstraction of Strength and Refinement in the Mobil Foundation competition, 1980. He received the Ten Outstanding Young Men award for painting and the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, both in 1961; the ASEAN Cultural Award, 1970; and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the city of Manila, 1971. In 1987, the French government bestowed on him the Order of Chevalier des Arts et Lettres. From the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), he received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 1991 and the Centennial Honors for the Arts in 1999. He was conferred the title National Artist for visual arts in 2003. Written by R. Chu, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Bolido 2011; Filipino Heritage, n.d.; Geringer Art, n.d.; Guillermo 2003a; Heritage Art Center 2012; Rondina 2013; UP CFA 2012.

JUBAN, SALVADOR (Salvador Tolentino Juban)b. Angono, Rizal 16 Nov 1941. Painter. He is the son of Simplicio Juban and Maximina Tolentino. He married Celestina Reyes with whom he has four children. He was an art scholar at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1969-73 and for a time, became an assistant to CarlosV.Francisco. He became Francisco’s longest-serving artist-assistant and protégé. He also paints the same subjects as Botong, such as fiestas featuring the Virgin, and other folk genre, especially of the fishing town of Angono. Compared to the maestro, Juban makes use of bolder lines and a more spontaneous approach. He also assisted Vicente Manansala in his murals for the Philippine Heart Center for Asia and the United Coconut Planters Bank. Unlike Botong who never left his homeland, Juban traveled around Asia to learn about the art of his counterparts. He joined several group exhibitions since 1973 and had one-person shows in different art galleries here and abroad. He has done murals for the different public and private institutions: Pag-asa (Hope), National Orthopedic Hospital; Anazibu and Batangan, historical murals for Batulao’s Clubhouse in Nasugbu, Batangas; History of Meralco, Lopez Building; and Nymphs, Colonnade Building, Makati.

He was president of the Angono Artists Association, 1985; vice president for operations, Carlos V. Francisco Foundation, and director of the Lakeshore Artists Foundation, 1992. He was also the vice president of the ArtAssociation ofthePhilippines in 1992.

Juban won several awards in painting: from the Shell National Students Art Competition, second prize, Landscape, 1969, and honorable mention, Lumang Simbahan (Old Church), 1971; from the YMCA Art Competition, honorable mention, 1971. He has also received several awards from art competitions in UST from 1970 to 1971. In 2012, in celebration of Botong Francisco’s 100th birth anniversary, the Yuchengco Museum held an exhibit titled Remembering the Great Master: Works by Salvador Juban, Botong’s Apprentice, which featured Juban’s paintings, murals, sketches, and studies. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Circuit Mag 2013; Yuchengco Museum 2012.

JUNYEE (Luis Enano Yee Jr) b. 12 Feb 1942. Installation artist. He is the son of Luis Yee Sr and Eliza Enano. He is married to Marites Gatchalian. He graduated with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1976.

Junyee’s sizeable body of work definitely established the trend in indigenous materials. He lives in the forested slopes of Makiling and creates an art integral to a life in nature. His work assembles, binds, or weaves together into various shapes organic materials such as dried pods, twisted roots, banana pulp, coconut shells, twigs, and coconut fiber. He makes mobiles of strong and supple vines formed into rustic garlands. He playfully sets loose upon a field, real or simulated as in a gallery, a swarm of assorted insects and bugs made from pods, seeds, and twigs that crawl all over the ground and climb walls and ceilings as in his Wood Things, 1981. Exhibited in a gallery or in an urban context, his installations are thus a reclaiming of space for nature. Spaces and Objects, 1986, is one such scatterwork released upon a grassy field as an assortment of stones, twigs, spikes, and bark, thereby situating the objects in a real space. His use of indigenous materials is clearly linked with ecological concerns, as the title of his 1988 exhibit, Extinct Future, conveys.

His other solo exhibitions include the bamboo installation Kapit Bisig, Clark Pampanga Expo, 1998; Rain and Silence, Brix Gallery, 1998; Recent Works: Junyee at Duemila, Galleria Duemila, 2000; Installation, Government Service Insurance System Museo ng Sining, 2000; Angud: A Forest Once, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) front lawn, 2007; Siete Pintados, Galleria Duemila, 2008; Pintado Tres by Junyee, Sining Makiling Art Gallery, UP Los Baños, 2010; and Dark Matter, Galleria Duemila, 2012.

From the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), Junyee received special award in 1968; grand prize for In the Woods, 1974; second prize in sculpture for Taglagas, Tagsibol (Fall, Spring), 1977; gold medal for Two Doors, 1980; and grand prize in sculpture for Bagong Binhi (New Seedling), 1986. From the Shell National Students Art Competition, he got certificates of merit for Condemned No 2, 1967, and The Last Mile of Ho Chi Minh, 1969. He was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1980. In 1997, he received the Brotherhood of the Plebeian Award for Art Excellence from UP and won second prize for sculpture at the AAP National Open Art Competition. In 1998, he won first prize for mixed media, Diwa ng Sining Biennale Award, National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), and was awarded a grant under the First CCP Installation Competition for the Philippine centennial celebration. In 2007, he won an NCCA competition for a monument project to be built for the Holocaust Memorial Park, Rishon LeZion, Israel. For this, he designed a geometric sculpture titled Open Doors, which commemorates Pres Manuel L. Quezon’s providing refuge for 1,200 Jews fleeing Nazi Europe. Junyee received the UP Distinguished Alumnus Award for Culture and Arts in 2013. In the same year, he was also awarded the Gawad Alab ng Sining Award as Most Outstanding Alumnus of the UP College of Fine Arts. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Cinco 2013; Contreras 2009; Lamentillo 2011; Philstar.com 2013c; Snippets 2012b; UP Los Baños 2013.

JUSTINIANI, MARK (Mark Orozco Justiniani) b. Bacolod, Negros Occidental 25 Apr 1966. Painter. He is the son of Jose Justiniani and Adelina Orozco. He was a student at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts from 1982 to 1990, major in painting.

His paintings are of social themes and personal relationships. At times, they satirize social pretensions in an expressionist style making use of distortion that borders on caricature. When he joined the Salingpusa group, his art was stimulated by the encouragement of his fellow artists. He resided with the group for a time in the Antipolo estate opened to them through the hospitality of Dr Joven Cuanang, then went to Bacolod, spent several years in the USA, before returning to Manila in the 2000s.

Justiniani’s solo exhibitions include Sanktuaryo (Sanctuary), Boston Gallery, 1999; Daong (Anchor), Starbucks 6750; Transit, Red Dot Gallery, and 2002, Galleria Duemila, 2002; Mga Dialogo (Dialogues), Boston Gallery, 2003; Varying Constants, Art Verite, 2006; Sa Silongalingan, Nineveh Art Space, 2007; Catapult, Substation Gallery, Singapore, and Pamati (Listen), Sitio Remedios, 2008; Malikmata (Mirage), SLab, 2010; Damgohanon (Dream), Capitano Gallery, and Phantom Limb, Finale Art Gallery, 2011.

Justiniani won the award of excellence for Gahasang Biswal (Visual Rape), 1989, and Asong Puti at ang Gutom (White Dog and the Hungry), 1990, at the Shell National Students Art Competition. He won the first prize for Last Trip in the Metrobank Foundation annual competition, 1990. In 1991, he placed second at the University of Santo Tomas Annual on-the-spot painting contest. In 1994, he received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists award. In 1997, he received the Most Outstanding Victorianon in the Arts (Malihaw Award) in Victorias, Negros Occidental. He was awarded for his Philippine Centennial Mural Project at Malacañan Palace, Office of the President of the Philippines, as a member of Sanggawa. He received the Jurors Choice Award, Philip Morris Group of Companies, at the Philippine Art Awards in Manila and was also the Philippine representative to the ASEAN Art Awards in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in 1999. He received the Award for Continuing Excellence in the Arts from the Metrobank Foundation in Manila in 2004. He was given the Solidarity Award by the Pilipino Workers’ Center in Los Angeles, California.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Source:

Justiniani, n.d.

KALAW-LEDESMA, PURITA (Purita Villanueva Kalaw-Ledesma) b. Manila 2 Feb 1914. d. Makati City 29 Apr 2005. Essayist, art collector, art scholar. She is the daughter of essayist Teodoro M. Kalaw and Pura Villanueva. She is the sister of essayist Maria Kalaw-Katigbak. She married Rafael Ledesma with whom she has four daughters. She was born to a hacendero clan whose ancestors have been part of the historical moments of the country. She had her elementary education at Assumption Convent in Iloilo. At age 12, she entered the Philippine Women’s College in Manila, where she was elected the class president in Grade 7 and became active in the Student Council. In her junior year in high school, she enrolled at the Escuela de Bellas Artes—later known as the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts—and had lessons there thrice a week with contemporaries such as Anita Magsaysay-Ho and others (Laya 1994). Kalaw-Ledesma first wanted to be a painter and took up fine arts at UP, but upon the prodding of her mother switched to education afterward. During her time at the university, she was a corps sponsor of the ROTC and the Lakambini of the Nucleo Solteril, a society of professionals. She was also part of the Kahirup Club, organized by the prominent families from Iloilo, Negros, and Cebu (Laya 1994).

Despite her various activities, her love for the arts did not diminish, and in 1947 she founded the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) and became its first president. The art association began as an organization of the graduates of the UP School of Fine Arts. As more artists who were not from UP joined the meetings, the group became an open association. The AAP held shows annually, showcasing the paintings of the modernists, such as Anita Magsaysay-Ho and Vicente Manansala, and the “conservatives” such as Simon Saulog and Cesar Lopez.
