The annual show also included paintings of less established artists side by side with the professionals. Then less experienced painters like Sanso got their first taste of recognition from these shows. A proponent of modern art, Kalaw-Ledesma and other artists were aware of the “stagnation” of Philippine art during the 1950s and tried to bridge the gap between Philippine art and its counterpart overseas.

She wrote Philippine Art Gallery: The Big Little Room, 1987, and coauthored with Amadis Ma. Guerrero the books The Struggle for Philippine Art, 1974, and Edades: National Artist, 1979. In 1994, her autobiography And Life Goes On was written by Jaime Laya. She received a special citation in the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the city of Manila in 1973, and the Gawad para sa Sining (special award) from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1991. In 2014, the Ateneo Art Gallery and the Kalaw-Ledesma Foundation Inc created an award in art criticism in her honor, the Ateneo Art Awards–Purita Kalaw-Ledesma Prize for Art Criticism.Written by R. Chu, updated by Ariel Pinzon

Sources:

Laya 1994; Ocampo 2005.

KASIBULAN / KABABAIHANSA SINING AT BAGONG SIBOL NAKAMALAYANThis is a feminist art organization founded by five visual artists who were active in the nationalist democratic movement during the anti-Marcos dictatorship revolt—Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Anna Fer, Ida Bugayong, and Julie Lluch. They started organizing in 1987 after three of them participated in a consultation conference for women in the Philippine Development Plan, upon invitation by Remedios Rikken, head of the National Commission on the Role of Filipino Women. They collectively painted a mural on women’s work that toured with the Cry of Asia theater. They researched and did surveys leading them to conclude that images of Filipino women in the arts did not fairly represent women’s views and strengths, that careers of women artists were generally protracted vis-à-vis those of their male counterparts, and that traditional art organizations depended heavily on female labor for the larger benefit of male members.

In 1989, KASIBULAN was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Among its mission and goals are: “1. to effect an understanding of the collective consciousness of Filipino women from which ... transformation can begin by giving a sense of empowerment rooted on the Babaylan tradition; 2. to project expressions of Filipino women artists ... grounded on culture and history; 3. to recognize and empower women as a vital force that opposes destructiveness ... ; 4. to recreate symbolisms, imagery, values and beliefs of women’s personal and collective transformation; 5. to protect and develop crafts that are the traditional domain of women—indigenous and folk; 6. to work for economic and social betterment of women ... ; 7. to network with women artists regionally, nationally and internationally; 8. to do research, studies and documentation on women artists and their work; and 9. to promote cultural dialogue among women.”

Open to female artists in the visual, literary, and performing arts, as well as historians, educators, and cultural workers, it holds artists’ talks, creative workshops, and discussions on women’s issues. It has created an impact in the development of feminist consciousness through exhibitions such as Ang Babaylan (The Shaman), 1989, University of the Philippines (UP) Faculty Center; Sinaunang Habi / Makabagong Habi (Traditional Weaving / Modern Weaving), 1990, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Ang Babae (The Women), 1991, CCP; Sibol ng Kamalayan (The Growth of Consciousness), 1992, Nayong Pilipino; Inang Kalikasan (Mother Nature), 1993, Rizal Park; Filipina: Migranteng Manggagawa (Filipino Women: Migrant Worker), 1993, CCP; Tahi-Tagning Talambuhay: Isang Pagpupugay sa Sining ng Kasibulan (Patchwork of Biographies: A Salute to the Art of Kasibulan), 1997, UP Vargas Museum; Tradisyon, Ebolusyon, Rebolusyon (Tradition, Evolution, Revolution), 1998, National Commission for Culture and Arts; Alimpuyo (Whirl), 2000, CCP; balaybay@kasibulan.net, 2004, CCP; PasyonNasyon (Passion of the Country), 2009, CCP; Malakas at Maganda (The Strong and the Beautiful), 2013, St. Scholastica’s College Museum; and Hilom: End Violence Against Women (Healing: End Violence Against Women), 2014, Glorietta/Zonta Makati. The exhibit Tahi-Tagning Talambuhay in 2015 was given the 13th Natividad Galang Fajardo honor of recognition by the Ateneo Library of Women’s Writings or ALIWW.

KASIBULAN works collectively. Cajipe-Endaya was founding president, succeeded by Baidy Mendoza, Lia Torralba, Edda Amonoy, Sandra Torrijos, Alma Quinto, Brenda Fajardo, and Vivian Nocum Limpin. Among its members are Paz Abad Santos who offered up her studio as office and meeting place for KASIBULAN over a decade. Other members are prominent feminists from the academe, such as Fe B. Mangahas, Grace Javier Alfonso, and Thelma B. Kintanar. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya
Kidlat Tahimik (See FILM volume.)

LACORTE, IRMA (Erma Eugenia Lacorte Capucion) b. Tacloban, Leyte, 11 Sep 1965. Painter, installation artist, educator. She is the daughter of Nestor Capucion and Maria Flores Lacorte. She finished her degree in fine arts, major in advertising, at the University of Santo Tomas in 1986 and her master of fine arts,major in studio arts, at the University of the Philippines Diliman in 2012.

Lacorte isinvolved in lesbian advocacy and often represents this through herart. Her works touch on the issues of lesbian identity politics by inserting and asserting lesbian representations and voices in Philippine art and arthistory. Her five-panelpainting Optometry, 2000, is an appropriation of the Snellen chart, an ophthalmological device used intesting the visual acuity of a person. Lacortereplaced the standard letters of the Snellen chart with letters thatspelled out the word LESBIAN. Eachletter on the panelis used to start a lesbianstatement that challengesrepresentations and positions on issues surrounding lesbian identity politics. As a gendered work, Optometry compels the audience to constantly test vision as means to see lesbian identities and representations.Walang Kokontra(No Opposition), 2002, is Lacorte’spretendlesbian wedding. This performance done at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) interrogated the performance of weddings both as ritual of affective intimacies and relationships of lesbians, as well asinstitutional legal practice of heteronormative social affirmation.

Lacorte is a member of KASIBULAN or Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan, a visual artsand cultural organization with gender advocacy as one of its primary organizing principles. Lacorte is also afounding member of the lesbian art organization Lesbianaramaandthe psychosocial help group Womyn Supporting Womyn. She exhibited at the Saint Paul’s Gallery, Columbia University, New York, in 1999, and atthe Vermont Studio Center, Vermont, USA, in 2003. She has also done solo and group exhibitions at The Drawing Room, 2002 and 2012; Galleria Duemila, 2009 and 2010; Art Informal, 2008; CCP, 2000, 2002, 2004, and 2005; Surrounded by Water, 2002; and the Institute of Women’s Studies, 2001, among many others. Lacorte has received several art grants and scholarships including the Freeman Fellowship Grant and the Asian Cultural Council fellowship.Written by Clod Marlan Krister Yambao

LAIDAN, RASID b. 1940. Brass caster. He is considered the finest brass artist in Tugaya, a community by the Lanao lakeside in Lanao del Sur, Mindanao, the only place in the Philippines that has continued the art of traditional brass casting. One of the oldest methods of technology, the lost wax process of brass casting involves making a prototype of the final product in beeswax and encasing it in a clay mold. When the clay-and-wax form is heated, the wax model melts away, leaving its imprint on the clay mold. Molten brass poured into the hollow clay mold fills the shape of the “lost” wax. The clay mold is then broken to reveal the brassware in all its glory. Although this tedious craft process can be found in other areas in the country, the Tugaya brass casters are distinguished by the excellence of their work, as shown in their elaborate Maranao okir (traditional Tausug and Maranao sculpture) designs and their ability to produce massive pieces.

Laidan learned the craft in his youth when brass casting was a common skill practiced in practically every household in Tugaya. One of the few practitioners of the art left in the village, he specializes in designing intricate motifs on the surface of all brass pieces done by him and his two partners.

He was conferred the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA in 1990 for “continuing with artistry the ancient process of Maranao brass casting using traditional materials and methods.”Written by Rosalinda Galang

LAMARROZA, PRUDENCIO (Prudencio Leal Lamarroza) b. Tagudin, Ilocos Sur 24 Jul 1945. Painter. He is the youngest of five children of Eugenio Lamarroza and Iladia Leal, the youngest of five children. He took fine arts courses in both the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1963, and the Philippine Women’s University in 1965.

Lamarroza won critical attention in the 1960s with his experimental abstracts of wide-ranging techniques. His first one-person show in 1969 consisted of works in mixedmedia, including brass sheets, molding paste, solidified polyester, and canvas. His second one-person show in 1971 was the highly innovative Frame series consisting of the frame in acrylic and molding paste enclosing an empty space. Marked by vigorous invention, Lamarroza’s Population Explosion made use of small figures of children’s heads done in modeling paste composed in a grid with a surrealist effect. This was followed by the Laoag (Light) series, which was his own version of op art in serial abstract motifs still in a grid pattern. Here he exhibited a fine control of tones to create the optical perception of light emanating from the painting.

In 1976, Lamarroza began his long Amburayan Queen series. This draws upon his childhood in Barrio Ambalayag between the Amburayan and Chico Rivers. Complementing the central image of the regal yet ever changing Amburayan Queen are the mountain-river landscapes which introduce the ecology theme, the artist lamenting the death of the river due to mining. His landscapes developed a surrealist quality that stemmed from his rich technical resources, proffering realist passages and then deconstructing them by showing the work as the artist’s autonomous domain into which abstract or geometric elements may be introduced at will.

In 2010, Lamarroza had a homecoming exhibition, The Colors of Amor Lamarroza, at the Beata Angelico Gallery, his first in UST, as part of Artistang Tomasino Ako (I Am a Tomasian Artist), a series of art exhibitions throughout the year in preparation for his alma mater’s quadricentennial celebration. Previously, Lamarroza had exhibited his works at the National Museum, Ayala Museum, and the Metropolitan Gallery, and had touring shows in Washington, Seattle, Los Angeles, Honolulu, Hong Kong, Kuala Lumpur, and Jakarta under the auspices of the RP-US Development Council of Art.

Lamarroza won the international competition with a well-disseminated work featuring grids with symbolic motifs in mixed media. He won awards in the Shell National Students Art Competition: third prize for Blue Girl and the Butterfly, 1965, and second prize for Maya, 1966. From the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines, he won second prize for Manila ’70, 1971, and honorable mention for Landscape Machine, 1974. He received the Sadiri Ti Tagudin Award in 1978. He won second prize for Amburayan Vision in the Mobil Art Awards in 1982. In 1983, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Cruz 2010; Lamarroza, n.d.; Pinoyarte.com, n.d.a; Venturina-Bulanadi 2013.

LANGENEGGER, ROBERT (Robert Argueza Langenegger) b. Saint Gallen, Switzerland 22 Feb 1983. Painter and installation artist. He is the son of Walter Langenegger and Daisy Argueza. Langenegger studied fine arts at the University of the Philippines from 2004 to 2005 and was among the first batch of fine arts students of Kalayaan College in 2003.

Langenegger’s first exhibit was a group show called Under Construction, 2003, curated by Roberto Chabet at the artist-run space Big Sky Mind. For the exhibit, artists created works revolving around the idea of the city and the environs of Cubao in Quezon City. Langenegger’s piece for the show was an installation comprised of found objects such as animal skull, bones, clothes, dried leaves, grass, and rice. This was quickly followed by successive group exhibitions in 2005 and 2006 in Manila and New York, paving the way for his first solo exhibition, Can You See My Balls?, 2006.

Langenegger has often been cited for his work in painting, which merges pictorial realism with carnivalesque and pastiched elements of contemporary reality. Going beyond displays of irreverence and the grotesque, his works function as phantasmagoric fables. His works often appropriate images both Biblical and art historical and incorporate these with observations of local realities around the Philippine archipelago. Despite their eclectic subject matter, Langenegger’s works have, over the years, returned to a notion of absurdity underlying the sublime, the beautiful, and the picturesque. The artist also employs humorous puns and wordplay to further complement his works.

Langenegger has also infused new media and installation as intrinsic elements to his painting. In 2011, he transferred images on light boxes and utilized video, clay, and oil on canvas for the work The Sun Is Warm and Life Is Easy in Quezon City and the Men as Women, and the Women as Children, 2012, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Thirteen Artists awardee show.

His work has been included in exhibits held in Australia, Austria, Hong Kong, Germany, Malaysia, and the USA, including group exhibitions of Philippine art held at the Goliath Visual Space, New York, 2005; XII Filipino Contemporary Artists, 2008, Singapore; How’s My Painting?, 2009, MOP Projects Sydney; the Bastards of Misrepresentation, 2010, Freies Museum, Berlin; and VOLTA 6, 2014, Basel, Switzerland. Langenegger also completed artist residency programs at the Talmart Gallery in Paris in 2009 and at the Galerie Zimmermann Krachtochwill in Austria in 2011.

Langenegger received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2012.Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Asia Art Archive 2003a, 2003c; Bastards of Misrepresentation 2010; Cobangbang 2010b; Ito 2014a; Langenegger 2013.

LAO LIANBEN (Lao Tan Lianben) b. Manila 21 Apr 1948. Painter. His parents are Mariano Lao and Martina Tan. He married Lilia Cruz with whom he has three children. Lao finished fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the East in 1972.

Lao Lianben’s works in wood, although largely two-dimensional rather than three-dimensional, blur the distinction between painting and sculpture. He is a minimalist in color, using either black or white. He is also a minimalist in the sense that his works show the influence of Zen aesthetics, which gives importance to the role of insight and creative intuition. His early works in black wood with relief elements showed an abstract and geometric orientation. In his white works he used techniques such as scratching, incising, and charring in combination with the use of found objects to convey meaning.

Lao Lianben was one of the first artists who used indigenous materials in assemblage in the 1970s. For instance, he superimposed twigs and small branches on carved and etched wooden panels. There is often a play of contrasts between free organic shapes and the geometric order of the panel design in his works. At times they subtly dwell on the ecological theme, as when the found object, a twig, is slightly charred by fire, signifying the destruction of the forests. The found object, plucked from the bosom of nature, takes on an aura of magic and ritual.

He held his first one-person show at the Solidaridad Galleries in 1973. Since then, he has done many solo and group shows in the Philippines and abroad.

Lao Lianben won awards in the Shell National Students Art Competition: first prize, Dead Birth, 1968; graphic arts, Bird Machine, 1969; fourth prize, Traces of Memory, 1970; and second prize, Pray No. 2, 1970. His works also won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: honorable mention, Tryst, 1976; and second prize, Om, 1977. He won in the 1983 Mobil Art Awards for Earth. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1976.Written by Alice G. Guillermo

LAUDICO, YOLANDA (Yolanda Perez Johnson) b. Santa Rosa, Laguna 13 Jun 1947. Conceptual artist. She is the daughter of Gregorio Perez and Norma Litonjua. She studied painting and sculpture at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts, graduating in 1972. She was one of the original members of Shop 6, an informal group of artists led by her former professor at UP, Roberto Chabet, in the 1970s. She also worked as part of the curatorial staff of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the Museum of Philippine Art in the 1970s.

Johnson mounted her first solo exhibition Photograms at the CCP in 1972. She exhibited regularly in this decade, becoming known for her material and process-based works that challenged modernist notions of permanence and purity. Among her works from this period are a toothpaste-covered pedestal, a wall lined with motor oil-stained papers, a suspended fishing net onto which she attached pieces of twigs, canopies of tissue paper, a collection of borders of Foto-Me portraits, and a grid of cut banana leaves.

By the 1980s, Johnson shifted her attention to crafts and design, exhibiting only occasionally with Chabet and his other former students at Sining Kamalig, Pinaglabanan Galleries, and West Gallery. She founded her company SouMak in 1997, where she continues to work with local artisans to create furniture, textiles, and home products using natural indigenous materials such as kamagong, molave, abaca, buntal, nito, and ramie. She is the publisher of Bistro Filipino. Her monograph, the first on painter-educator Constancio Bernardo, was launched in conjunction with Bernardo’s centennial retrospective at Ayala Museum in 2013. Johnson received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1974.Written by Ringo Bunoan

LAYUG, WILFREDO (Wilfredo Tadeo Layug) aka Willy Layug. b. Betis, Pampanga 5 Dec 1959. Sculptor, painter. He is the son of Alfonso Layug and Rita Tadeo. He studied architecture and fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas. Growing up in a family of artists in a community known for wood carving, Layug began training in sculpture when he was eight years old. Among his mentors were Juan Castro and Pedro Datu. In pursuit of improving his skills, he researched in various parts of Europe and in 2007 trained as an apprentice under Jose Antonio Navarro Arteaga in Seville, Spain. He is the owner of Betis Galleria in Pampanga, a workshop of ecclesiastical artists working with and under Layug’s guidance.

Layug produces religious images, church altars, tabernacles, as well as retablo (altar screen with niches for saints images) and carroza (processional float) for major churches and private collectors in the Philippines and abroad. Aiming to digress from traditional local sculpture, Layug translates into his works what he has learned by way of his Spanish training and research on European religious art. The scale, anatomical details, vesture drapery, and chromatic palette of his images echo the realism of high European church art rather than Spanish colonial Philippine church art tradition. He achieves such realism by transforming materials using age-old finishing techniques he learned in Spain. His process starts with the making of a clay model before carving the wood, as learned from Arteaga. His finishing process involves a tedious seven-way treatment including dorado (gilding) and estofado (creation of brocade-effect). In keeping with this technique, the wood is gilded with gold or silver leaf and then painted over with different patterns.

His first major project, the restoration of the Fort Santiago gate in Intramuros, came in 1981 while he was still finishing his bachelor’s degree. After training in Spain and establishing Betis Galleria, Layug was commissioned by local and national church and state officials. His most notable works include a retablo made in honor of San Lorenzo Ruiz and San Pedro Calungsod, which he donated to the Pontifico Collegio Filippino in Rome, on the occasion of the canonization of Pedro Calungsod in 2012. Layug also made the image of Our Lady of Palo for the Leyte Mass and the Crucified Christ for Luneta Mass of Pope Francis during the latter’s Pontifical visit to the Philippines in 2015.

Layug sees his pursuit of a career as an ecclesiastical artist as a way of giving back to the Roman Catholic faith while also supporting the advocacy to revive and sustain the art and industry of wood carving in Betis. To reach a wider audience, he collaborated with Armando Lao and Brillante Mendoza in the film Dukit (Carved in Wood), 2013, which pays tribute to the wood-carving industry of Betis. Layug received the Presidential Medal of Merit for Ecclesiastical Art in 2009 and the Juan D. Nepomuceno Award for Arts and Culture from Holy Angel University in 2013. Written by Dino Carlo Santos

Sources:

Banal 2014; Business Mirror 2013; GMA Network 2015; NCCA 2013.

LEAÑO, ANTONIO (Antonio Catral Leaño) aka Tony Leaño. b. Cagayan 19 Sep 1963. Painter and installation artist. He is the son of Ramon Villegas Leaño and Petra Teaño Catral. He is married to Maria Cielo Dominique Macapagal Salgado.

Leaño began working on his bachelor of fine arts degree in painting at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, in 1982. Although he did not finish his art studies, his stay in the university proved to be pivotal in his artistic career as this is how he met contemporaries Mark Justiniani, Marcel Antonio, the younger Elmer Borlongan, and teacher Roberto Chabet to whom Leaño attributes the development of his curiosity and penchant for exploring methods and materials.

Together with Justiniani, Borlongon, and Karen Flores, Leaño founded the artist collective Salingpusa, a group established in Antipolo under the auspices of their main patron—the geriatrician-collector Dr Joven Cuanang. Borne from the struggles of artists who were then at incipient stages of their individual careers, the camaraderie, friendship, and artistic collaborations of Salingpusa’s artists resulted in various projects ranging from group exhibitions to the collaborative painting of murals. One such collaborative mural is the massive Karnabal (Carnival), 1992, now housed in Cuanang’s Pinto Art Museum. This expansive art space served at various points as Leaño’s home, garden, and creative laboratory for years. As de facto museum architect and landscape artist, Leaño continues to work on this still ongoing project which officially opened to the public in 2010.

Leaño started out as a painter turning out both figurative and abstract pieces combining traditional pigment and industrial materials. He later displayed a heightened interest in space and keen attention to locale and topography as seen in the inherent site-specificity of his installations and the way he considers how built architecture can be made to negotiate with the intrinsic territorial qualities of the spaces within Pinto Museum. Among his exhibitions are Drawings, 1997, with Reggie Yuson, Gallery 139, and Alay 12 (Offering 12), 2009, Boston Gallery, while solo exhibitions include Quiescence, 2002, and Anthropometrics, 2009, Sitio Remedios. His 1988 work U-Turn, strikingly made up of decapitated bodies and horses whirling amidst an apocalyptic scene, won him the first prize at the Metrobank Foundation National Painting Competition. A mural titled Supremo, 1993, depicting animals preying on a human brain, was acquired by Fukuoka Art Museum, Japan.

When he was selected as one the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists in 1994, he created an intricate and multilayered installation for the exhibition called Diptych: ICU, consisting of elements like soil, tree trunks, dextrose bags, seeds, coco fiber, plastic, and aluminum. Conceptualized around the time that mall culture was still emergent, he included blown up stills of mall interiors he discretely shot while roaming one of the giant commercial edifices in Metro Manila.

Another notable installation is Intelligent Man Rethinkin, a work he did in Fukuoka, Japan, where he facilitated a multisensory experience by constructing an enclosed space of four panels of plexiglass, within which one could hear the sound of trickling water in the background. Terra-cotta soil mounds with twigs wedged into them were strategically situated around the outside walls’ surface. Tin cans he collected around the area dotted the wall of mounds, but these were visually overpowered by the decomposing organic materials.

Leaño’s other international engagements include participation in the Osaka Triennale with The Last Full Show, 1993, and a residency at the Fourth Australia and Regions Artists’ Exchange: Torque in 1995 during which he was also a visiting artist at the Australian National University School of Art.Written by Thea C. Garing

Source:

Enriquez 2012.

LEBAJO, RAUL (Raul J. Lebajo) b. Tacloban, Leyte 11 Sep 1941. Painter. His son Nikulas is also a painter. He took up art studies at the University of the East, 1966-67, and the Philippine Women’s University, 1967-68.

Lebajo was a product of the ferment in Philippine art in the late 1960s, which was absorbed in the exploration of abstraction. Consistently inclined toward surrealism, he infused his works with images that evoke the realm of dreams or the bizarre. Park #17, 1971, for instance, is a composition of found objects mounted on wood. The materials consist mainly of painted metal impressed with groupings of circular bottle caps or button-like coin-sized objects with a small hole at the center. The squarish shape of the work suggests a bird’s-eye view of a park. A secondary square within the painting, one side of which extends into a straight-edged wing, evokes a cold sensation. Inside the square could be seen eyelike objects arranged in a series. In Crowd I, 1979, Lebajo used the plasticity of the oil medium to create a sleek bubbly surface that is bizarre, but the orange and blue paints tone down the eerie feeling and make the piece attractive. In Imaginary Landscape, 1979, he fused the cold shapes of hard-edged abstraction with a surrealistic treatment of space, such that the painting acquired a depth with the shapes suggesting a mysterious dimension of reality. Lebajo created surrealistically themed works while employing a realist technique in the late 1980s. This brought him both material success and favorable criticism from galleries and collectors here and abroad.

He staged his first solo exhibition at the Solidaridad Galleries followed by another at the Luz Gallery in 1971. Lebajo has been doing individual exhibitions since 1969, mostly in Metro Manila. His other exhibitions are The Mind’s Eye, 1990, Chicago Cultural Center, West Gallery, and Mindscape, 1987, Le Plaza Hotel, Basel, Switzerland. Since 1974, he has participated in group exhibitions in West Germany, 1977; Hong Kong, 1980; Chicago, USA, 1991; Paris and Malaysia, 1998; and Bangkok, Thailand, 2001 and 2005.

Lebajo won several awards at the Shell National Students Art Competition: second place, on-the-spot painting for Chinese Garden, 1967; first place for Twice Born, certificates of merit for Pathways to Ajanta and Fort Santiago, and second place for 4 Squares to 2 Circles, all in 1968. In 1989, he received a grant from the Illinois Art Council and National Endowment for the Arts. In 1998, he represented the Philippines in Art in the World, Beaux Art, Paris.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Galleria Duemila 2013; Ito 2013b.

LEE, ILEANA (Ileana Chua Lee) b. Sarabia, Negros Occidental 15 Sep 1952. Printmaker. She is the daughter of Joaquin Lee and Ana Chua. She earned her fine arts degree, major in editorial design, at the University of the Philippines (UP). She earned her master’s degree in fine arts at Ohio University in 1986. She was actively involved in the UP Chamber Film Group and the Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP), and worked as a part-time art instructor at the Don Bosco School in Tondo, Manila.

Lee has participated in group exhibitions since 1973, including graphic arts exhibitions of the PAP at the Sining Kamalig and the CulturalCenterofthe Philippines (CCP), and the First CCP Annual Exhibition of Recent Philippine Painting and Sculptures in 1976. Among her other exhibitions at the CCP were Thirteen Artists, 1976; The Third CCP Annual for the Visual Arts, 1978; A Decade of Developmental Art, 1979; Recent Exhibitions in Printmaking, 1979; Woodworks, 1979; Sikat: Two Decades of Philippine Art: 1969-89 (Famous/Shine: Two Decades of Philippine Art: 1969-89); and Transmissions: UP Artists and the Thirteen Artists Awards, 2008. She was also part of the Museum of Philippine Art exhibition Museum Artists, 1979. Lee participated in the CCP tribute to Roberto Chabet titled What Does It All Matter, as Long as the Wounds Fit the Arrows?, 2014. In Jun 2009, Lee’s work likewise was shown as part of the opening exhibit of Bulwagan ng Dangal, the heritage museum of the University of the Philippines, titled Pag-asa ng Bayan (Hope of the Nation).

In 1974, she was the grand prize winner at the PAP 6th Graphic Arts Competition, in addition to winning first prize in the experimental category. She was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CCP in 1976.Written by Rosalinda Galang, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Asia Art Archive, n.d.a; Dipasupil 2009; Philstar.com 2014a.

LEE, ROMEO (Romeo Federizon Lee) aka Lee. b. Naga, Camarines Sur 2 Jan. Painter. He is the son of Christopher Lee and Fortunata Federizon. Creativity was abundant in the family of six children, with Lee’s brothers carving their own mark in their respective fields. Roque Lee or “Roxlee” is a filmmaker recognized as a pioneer in independent film animation, who, together with his brother Mon, created Cesar Asar, a popular comic strip that ran in Manila Bulletin from 1980 to 2000. Ruben, on the other hand, was the cinematographer for Lav Diaz’s Batang West Side (West Side Avenue). Another member of the clan, Mon’s son Topel Lee, ventured into independent and eventually mainstream filmmaking primarily associated with Regal Films.

Before his formal tertiary education, Romeo Lee did a brief stint in vocational school where his teachers frequently asked him to draw machine parts directly on the blackboard. This, coupled with his relentless attachment to anything that allowed him to sketch at a young age, developed his acuity in drawing instinctively without guidance and formal studies. In 1984, Lee entered the College of Fine Arts of the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman and received his bachelor of fine arts in advertising (now visual communications) in 1990.

In the UP College of Fine Arts, he met art contemporaries Soler Santos, Nilo Ilarde, and his frequent conspirator, collaborator, and often enabler, Manuel Ocampo. Their friendships revolved around art and punk music, among other things. Even running paved the way for gathering together in the Fine Arts Running Team or FART, an informal group that emerged in jest. Asserting his varied interests apart from visual art, Lee pursued other campus collaborations. A member of the UP Mountaineers, he headlined and emceed the infamous “Elvis” concerts for years until its last run in 2006. He was also involved in Auraeus Solito’s Manhid (Numb), a musical based on Salman Rushdie’s novel Midnight’s Children and X-Men comics. In this production, Lee performed with another UP Diliman icon, the Eraserheads, and members of the UP Tropa Experimental Theater Company. Lee’s lingering presence in the university led to his emergence as a punk icon, his reputation as master of stage mayhem, and appellation as the “Wild Thing,” which extended beyond his undergraduate days.

As a visual artist, Lee’s roughshod aesthetic sense and pack-rat sensibility may be regarded as influential upon a succeeding generation of artists of a variably punk inclination including Manuel Ocampo, Louie Cordero, and Robert Langenegger. Lee was already active in several group exhibitions prior to his first one-man show Oil-Lee at West Gallery, 1990. His subsequent exhibitions illustrated his wit with playful puns he inscribed as show and work titles, all of which have been crafted eponymously. As a free agent, untethered to a particular gallery, Lee continues to create works for various museums, galleries, and alternative spaces in Manila. He has also shown internationally in countries such as Australia, Hong Kong, Germany, Singapore, and the USA.

Lee’s paintings are reflective of his endearingly eccentric and electric persona, with canvases filled with oil renderings of cheeky, humorous, and sinister visages. Aside from paintings, he has also done photography and installation work for exhibitions such as the photo assemblage-installation Leestory, 1999, as well as the parodying of publicity machinery in the “multi-media extravaganza” (Caruncho 2003, 2) two-man reunion show with Ocampo titled Lee Almighty, 2003. In the latter show hosted by Mag:net Gallery, the duo played with various platforms to carry out a provocative commentary on media chatter and the machinery that perpetuates it. In the solo exhibition ArtinformaLEE, 2014, Lee continued to assert that the tangible work on show is not the bottom line as art reverts back to the penchant for theatrics and everyday performance. Lee has also been part of other notable group exhibitions by the project cum artist collective Bastards of Misrepresentation, in multisite exhibitions in Berlin with Doing Time in Filipino Time, 2010, and Bastards of Misrepresentation: New York Edition, 2012.Written by Thea C. Garing

LEGASPI, CESAR (Cesar Francisco Torrente Legaspi) b. Tondo, Manila 2 Apr 1917. d. Manila 7 Apr 1994. National Artist for visual arts. He was the son of Manuel S. Legaspi Sr and Rosario Torrente. He was married to Vitaliana Kalugdan. They have five children, one of whom, Celeste, is one of the pioneers and founders of the Organisasyon ng Pilipinong Mang-aawit. He finished his elementary grades at Washington Elementary School, Sampaloc, Manila, in 1929, then went to Arellano High School. In 1931, he entered the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts and after a semester, switched to commercial art under Irineo Miranda, graduating in 1936. In the same year, he worked as a staff artist of the advertising department of Elizalde & Co. Inc. Legaspi pursued art studies abroad as a scholar at the Cultura Hispanica in Madrid, 1953-54. He subsequently entered the Academie Ranson in Paris. In 1968 and 1969, he was the Philippine representative to the Sao Paulo Biennial for graphic art and for painting, respectively.

Legaspi espoused the cause of modern art from its early years and nurtured it to full maturity with his fellow pioneering modernists Carlos V. Francisco, Galo B. Ocampo, Hernando R. Ocampo, and Vicente Manansala. Up to his death, he was the most active surviving member of the Thirteen Moderns. While his work shows the influence of cubism, the rigorous approach of cubism’s intellectual phase in Legaspi’s works gave way to the more harmonious aspect of cubism’s synthetic phase. There is a facetting of figures into larger planes, which overlap and cut through space in transparent curvilinear rhythms and which achieve a richly textured orchestration of hues and tones. Except for his earlier monochromatic canvases, Legaspi’s paintings fully release the expressive potential of color, creating a sensuous chromatic ambience with a variety of subjects from dancers and flower gardens, to dynamic street scenes. His early paintings, from the period immediately before and after World War II, reflect his personal reaction to the national trauma. Man and Woman (also titled Beggars), 1945, is rendered in an expressionist idiom involving distortion. It shows a couple in rags amidst the skeletons of buildings which are broken like surrealist sculpture. Another important work, Gadgets, 1947, done in two versions, reflects the increasing importance of machines in the postwar industrialization period, as well as what the artist perceived was the insidious threat of humans metamorphosing into machines.

Legaspi spent many years as magazine illustrator and artistic director in advertising agencies, while he took time in between his work to do paintings. In 1963, he held a one-person show at the Luz Gallery. This marked the beginning of an active phase with major pieces, such as Chiaroscuro, in which rocks and stone quarries become his central image and symbol, and in which structure is the predominant concern. Spatial depth is suggested by the darker tonalities of the recesses in the granite rock that half conceals organic forms, like curling fetuses, embedded within. In these and subsequent works, Legaspi strove toward an artistic language based on the integrity of shapes and figures that would convey an entire range of values, from strength to sensitivity, power to grace, dynamism to lyricism. In 1968, Legaspi finally left advertising to devote his time to painting.

His subsequent works significantly modified the cubist idiom by his use of rhythmic curvilinear lines and planes contrary to the angularity of the original style. From 1974 onward, his paintings became more chromatic, sometimes even effulgent with color, with layers of transparent passages creating prismatic effects. His figures dynamically cut through space in gestural movements. Light enhances color and form or dematerializes and dissolves human form into airy transparencies, creating resonances in space. The human figure, in its well-articulated muscular and structural frame, increasingly becomes an eloquent vehicle for expression, while a play of contrasts ensues between organic form and geometric structure, transparency and solidity, the flexible and the inexorable, tensions that generate the vitality of Legaspi’s art. In 1976, Legaspi did a number of multilayered paintings on wood panel to give actual depth and shadows to the illusion of spatial movement. He also produced a large diptych with a crucified torso spanning the two panels; graffiti of the times are scattered over the wall-like background.

Through the 1970s and 1980s, Legaspi worked on paintings that dealt with universal human experience, as seen in The Survivor. At this time, large heroic canvases, done in his dynamic style, convey the surging, straining movements of human beings in aspiration, struggle, and triumph. Aside from being dramatic metaphors of the human condition, these are also visual correlatives of inner moods. The artist’s “biota” imagery explored organic and visceral movements beneath the surface where human beings are one with nature, woven of the same tissue as the trees. The images of struggle and nightmare transpose onto the imagery of art the emotional tensions of the everyday that seek resolution in dreams.

In 1978, Forty Years of Legaspi: A Retrospective Exhibition was held at the Museum of Philippine Art. Ten years later, he held three simultaneous exhibits: A Retrospective Show, 1978-88, National Museum; a drawing exhibit, Finale Art File; and Pamana (Heritage), an oil painting exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, which featured his Jeepney series in which the dynamism of the imagery brought together the spatial and temporal dimensions, dream and reality, the past and the present. In 1990, he held his Retrospective of Drawings, 1945-90 at the Luz Gallery.

Legaspi won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: fourth prize, Sick Child, 1948; first prize, Gadgets II, 1949; fourth prize, Planters, 1949; and third prize, Ritual, 1951. He won first prize for Stairway to Heaven in the Manila Club Art Exhibition, 1949. His Symphony won an honorable mention award in the Manila Grand Opera House Exhibition in 1950. His other awards include the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award, city of Manila, 1972; Professional Award for Painting, UP Alumni Association, 1978; Gawad CCP para sa Sining, Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1990; and Tanglaw ng Lahi Award, Ateneo de Manila University, 1990. He was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts in 1990. The book Legaspi: The Making of a National Artist by Alfredo Roces was published by Crucible Workshop in 1993, a year before Legaspi passed. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources:

Guillermo 1998b; Rizal Library, n.d.; Roces 1993.

LEGASPI, JOSE aka Jojo Legaspi. b. Manila 1959. Painter, sculptor, and performance artist. Initially planning a medical career, he was first trained in the sciences, earning degrees in zoology and biology from the University of Santo Tomas. He shifted to the arts when he took graduate units at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, in 1985. He was an artist in residence at Art in General, New York, in 2001.

He is known for his provocative imagery often described as gruesome and disturbing. His oeuvre draws inspiration from across a range of sources, from the stark conditions of Philippine society to its rich visual culture. From Catholic iconography, he appropriates the grisly details of Christ’s crucifixion and the martyrdom of saints. The everyday realities of violence, poverty, and corruption that are turned into spectacles in popular films, for instance, also find their way into his drawings and sculptures. Adding more layers to his corpus of works is his investigation of the human psyche, memory, sexuality, and the body, as exemplified in the Phlegm series from 2000 to 2002. The way he renders these subjects plays a key role in achieving the character of his art. Noted for meticulous treatment of details, the figuration comes off as shockingly truthful and real. His background in the sciences proves to be instrumental, allowing him to be detached from his images of violence and horror and to approach them in a clinical manner that lends them a more haunting effect. In his pastel drawings of people, for example, the minimalist appearance, muted colors, and linear clarity command attention from viewers, forcing them to confront the troubling imagery presented. At times, his drawings in pencil or charcoal resemble childlike scribbling, evoking a nightmarish character. All told, Legaspi’s art is notable for its daring stance in exploring themes and images that would otherwise be regarded as taboo, unsightly, or discomfiting yet operating deeply in Filipino life. His works are ultimately reflective of the workings of Philippine society, especially its harsher facets, and lead us to confront the realities often swept under the rug by those with delicate “sensibility” and conservative values.

Legaspi has exhibited widely in solo and group shows both locally and internationally. Among his solo exhibitions are Plantigraphs, 1980, Cultural Center of the Philippines; Diary of a Dead Man, 1990, Art Lab, Manila; Nightmare Obsession, 1999, Hong Kong Arts Centre; Aberrations in Monochrome, 2000, Hiraya Gallery, Manila; Phlegm, 2001, Art in General, New York; and Catholic, 2008, SOKA Contemporary Space, Taipei. He has participated in the Asia-Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art, 2002, Queensland; the Istanbul Biennale, 2003; and the Singapore Biennale, 2006. Selected group shows include Under Construction, 2002, Japan Foundation Forum, Tokyo; 15 Tracks: Contemporary Southeast Asian Art, 2002, Singapore Art Museum and Fukuoka Art Museum in Japan; and 36 Ideas from Contemporary Southeast Asian Art, an exhibition that toured Austria, Italy, and Germany from 2002 to 2003.Written by Ryan Francis Reyes.

Sources:

Asia-Pacific Triennial 2014; Kulay Diwa Gallery 2014; Verso Manila 2009.

LEONARDO, GERARDO (Leo Gerardo Cua Leonardo) aka Gerry Leonardo. b. Davao City 6 Nov 1965. Sculptor, photographer, installation artist, art educator. He is the son of Cesar Leonardo and Lorna Cua. He is married to Athenie Jill Sahagun. He was a visual arts major in the Philippine High School for the Arts in Makiling, where he graduated in 1982 and received the most outstanding visual arts student award. He earned his bachelor of fine arts, major in sculpture, in the University of the Philippines (UP), where he received the Outstanding Student Artist Award from the UP President’s Committee on Culture and the Arts in 1986 and graduated cum laude in 1987. In 1992, he received the Monbusho Scholarship for Master Program in Sculpture. He graduated with a master of fine arts in sculpture and received the outstanding sculpture award at the Kyoto Seika University in 1994. He also holds a research certificate in Japanese Ceramic Aesthetics and History from the Kyoto Seika University and a certificate in Japanese culture and language studies from the Osaka University of Foreign Studies. In 2011, he received a grant from the Asian Cultural Council, which enabled his residency at Headlands Center for the Arts, California, and PointB, New York. Leonardo considers himself to be primarily an art educator, serving as a faculty member of the Philippine High School for the Arts since 1994.

Leonardo’s work is a fusion of organic forms, mythological stories, traditional art elements, and his own experiences as a teacher. He is known to use wire and fiberglass materials but also incorporates other materials, including found objects. His art demonstrates his fascination with the organic forms and movements that are abundant in his environment, and manifests in his use of shapes from nature, space, light, translucency, and wind-inspired kinetic elements. He takes much of his inspiration from images and his experiences in Mount Makiling, where he first resided as a student of the Philippine High School for the Arts. In the urban environment of Manila, he first began to use wires to “draw” figures. His first solo exhibition done as a UP student in 1986, Studies in Wire, was a result of this. Studying in Japan allowed him to learn additional techniques in sculpture and to incorporate aspects of Japanese culture in his work.

References to other places he has lived in can also be found in his work, such as elements from traditional art forms in Mindanao, where he spent his childhood. His family’s trips during his youth to the beaches of Davao developed his interest in boats that resulted in works like the Balanghai, 1997, displayed at Fort Bonifacio Global City. Inspired by the large boat used by early Malay settlers in the Philippines, the three sails of the Balanghai kinetic sculpture represent the country’s three major island groups: Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao. The sails respond individually to shifts in wind but may also respond in unison, billowing or moving forward, when a strong wind comes along. The motif was used again for the Cinemalaya trophy beginning in 2005.

Among his significant commissioned artworks are the 42-foot outdoor bamboo installation Sibol: Earth Day at CCP, 2006, at Liwasang Kalikasan, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Complex, meant to be a bouquet of flowers for Mother Earth; a large-scale sound sculpture Bamboo Boat, a 400-piece sound sculpture that wails with the amihan or February wind, installed at the CCP front lawn for Pasinaya 2008; La Salle Animo Sculpture, 2014, at the Henry Sy Building in De La Salle University; and Elsa, 2014, a sculpture of actress Nora Aunor in her role in the film Himala (Miracle) at the sand dunes of Paoay, Ilocos Norte. The last is one of the series he did in fiberglass with light, typified by his work in the Yankee Doodle exhibit, 2003, at the CCP.

Leonardo has had solo exhibitions in the Faculty Center Gallery of UP Diliman, CCP, GSIS Museum, and Galleria Duemila. He has also had solo exhibitions in Suzuki Gallery in Kyoto and Point Bin Brooklyn, New York. His group exhibitions include those at the CCP, Pinaglabanan Galleries, GSIS Museum, Pinto Art Gallery, Tala Gallery, UP Vargas Museum, Corredor Gallery, Kyoto Seika University Gallery, Kyoto Cultural Center, Kyoto International Community Center, and Kyoto Museum of Art.

Leonardo has won several awards from the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Competition, including juror’s choice in sculpture in 1995, first prize in Sculpture in 1996, and third prize in sculpture, 2000. He was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 2000. Written by Iris De Ocampo

LEYNES, NESTOR (Nestor Garcia Leynes) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 26 Feb 1922. d. Quezon City 18 Mar 2016. Painter. His parents are Ricardo Leynes and Enriqueta Garcia. Leynes studied at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts. Among his teachers were FernandoAmorsolo, IrineoMiranda, Macario Peralta, Toribio Herrera, PabloAmorsolo, and VicenteAlvarezDizon. PabloAmorsolo advised him to master drawing first, after which all the rest would follow. He was on his fourth year when World War II broke out in 1941. During the war, he supported himself by carving bakya or wooden slippers and painting them. After the war, he first worked in a sign shop and did oil portraits. For seven years, Leynes was an illustrator and cover artist for the RamonRocesPublications where Vicente Manansala also worked. While Leynes then recognized only the style of Fernando Amorsolo, Manansala slowly changed his attitude and opened his eyes to modernism.

As a painter, Leynes first experimented in different styles, such as abstraction, expressionism, and cubism. It was in 1976 that he discovered the realist style of the American painter Andrew Wyeth. He joined a number of artists to form the group of Magic Realists, including Ger Viterbo, Jaime Roque, and Joselito Barcelona aka Jeb. In 1977, they joined a group show with other artists titled Macrovision at the Impressions Gallery. One of the pieces that Leynes exhibited there was the painting titled Bigas (Rice), 1974. Because of the warm reception to the painting, Leynes realized that he had finally discovered his personal style.

Leynes’s Balara Hills won an honorable mention in the painting contest of the Art Association ofthePhilippines in 1951. In 2002, a retrospective titled At 80: The Nestor G. Leynes, Magic Realist Retrospective was held at the RCBC Plaza, Makati. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Leynes, n.d.; Phillippine Daily Inquirer 2002b.
Liceo Artistico Literario (See Literature volume.)

LIM, TITA (Tita Velasco Lim) aka Tata Lim. b. Manila 1 Jun 1954. Photographer. She is the daughter of Lim Cha and Agrifina Velasco. Tita Lim initially started her studies in political science, then shifted to fine arts. She was in residence at the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP), for only two years in 1975-77 before the call to join the local family business pressured her to finally discontinue her studies. In 1987, she decided to go to the United States, where she pursued her bachelor in fine arts, major in photography. She completed her degree in 1990 at the Academy of Art College, San Francisco, after which she returned to the Philippines.

In the 1990s, Lim had four solo exhibitions: Perception and Other Realities, 1991; Altered Images, 1992; Recent Photographs, 1993; and Women, 1996. The works in these exhibitions consisted of a range of “painted photographs” and photo collages—images produced by methods other than that of a straight print. Lim would scratch, bleach, burn, or paint her negatives, sandwich positives, manipulate the camera while shooting, or “tamper” with paper during and after printing. She talked of these experiments with considerable relish, admitting to the surprising effects which some of these mediations created. To a considerable extent, this creative vocabulary has become a sort of trademark for her. While some may find Lim’s photographic mediations intriguing, the imagery could be quite puzzling. In fact, many of Lim’s works are replete with her own personal symbolisms but she is intrigued by what other people may read into them.

In between these solo exhibitions, Lim also participated in several group shows of Art Manila, a conglomerate of galleries. As an artist affiliated with the Hiraya group, she was represented in the shows in 1991-92 and 1994. Art Manila’s 1994 catalogue had Lim’s work, Bambina in Wonderland, on the cover. After this spurt of creative energy in the 1990s, Lim’s art production slowed down somewhat, as she embarked on graduate studies, teaching, and giving photography workshops. Nevertheless, she still managed to contribute works to group exhibitions which included WOWB: Who Owns Women’s Bodies?, 2000-01; Titamarialmairma: Conversations with 19th Century Artists, 2002; balaybay@kasibulan.net, 2004; and Four Faces of Woman Dance-Exhibit, 2006. Many of these works have a decided slant toward women and gender issues, subjects close to Lim’s heart, though expressed in her quietly provocative visual language. As a Filipino-Chinese, Lim’s photographs have also led her to explore issues of mixed heritage and identity.

As an artist-photographer, Lim has generally stayed clear of commercial photography. She prefers to exhibit in small, alternative spaces, and maintains her fascinating relationship with photography through a continued exploration of the new technologies it has to offer. Apart from her creative practice, Lim has also involved herself in cultural work through Baglan Art and Culture Initiatives for Community Development.Written by Marilyn R. Canta

Sources:

Aguilar-Cariño 1994; Canta 2001; Corpus 2004; Datuin 2002b; Pineda 1999.

LIM HIGGINS, SALVACION (Salvacion Diaz Lim-Higgins) aka Slim Salvacion. b. Legazpi, Albay 28 Jan 1920. d. San Francisco, California 15 Sep 1990. Fashion designer. Slim first developed her fashion design practice through the encouragement of her family. Her father, Don Luis Samson Lim Katiam, ran a textile and clothing business, and some of the jusi she used in her ternos (three-piece matching ensemble) was even handwoven and handspun by her mother, Margarita Navera Diaz. In 1959, Slim married Hubert Lewis Higgins, with whom she had two children, Mark and Sandra, who would later run the design school she opened with her sister Purificacion. Slim obtained her bachelor’s degree in fine arts in 1944, major in painting, from theUniversity of Santo Tomas in Manila, where she took classes under National Artist Carlos “Botong” Francisco. To enhance her design practice, she would pursue further studies in fashion design at the Traphagen School of Design in New York, returning to Manila in 1952. Between courses in advanced pattern making at Traphagen, her tireless search for inspiration would lead her to attend over 27 couture shows in Paris, France.

In 1947, she opened her atelier in Malate with her sister Purificacion and her friend Consuelo Barberan. They became known for sculptural pieces through her cleverly drafted patterns and draping techniques. The shop eventually moved to Taft Ave. Slim and Purificacion established the Slim Fashion & Arts School in 1960, basing their curriculum on their extensive professional experience. “Slims,” as it is popularly known, has since produced designers and entrepreneurs such as couturier Joe Salazar and clothing and shoe designer Cesar Gaupo. At the New York World’s Fair in 1964, Slim costumed theBayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, creating a black-and-white version of theMaria Clara, which was admired by photographer and fashion designer Sir Cecile Beaton.

Slim received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Filipino Designer’s Group in 1987. Her last collection was presented at the 1990Manila Fashion Designers Awardswhere she was also posthumously inducted into the Hall of Fame. Slim received the Achievement Award at the 1997 Filipino Fashion Achievement Awards. From Nov 2009 to May 2010, a retrospective exhibition of Slim’s body of work was held at the National Museum of the Philippines. In May 2014, two ternos designed by Slim were acquired by the Victoria and Albert Museumin London: a white cotton silk piqué with an asymmetrical balloon skirt and bow, adorned with raffia leaves and flowers, a piece created for First Lady Leonila Garcia in 1957; and a dove gray French silk satin gown modeled by 1956 Miss Philippines, Edith Nakpil Rabat, which appeared on the cover of SLIM: Salvacion Lim Higgins: Philippine Haute Couture, 1947-90, 2009, edited by her son Mark Higgins. Another creation, an appliquéd, pink jusi-pleated gown presented by First Lady Leonila Garcia to United States First Lady Mamie Eisenhower is stored at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.Written by Alice Sarmiento

Sources:

Enriquez 2014; Maranan 2010.

LIM-YUYITUNG, VERONICA aka Veronica Lim-Yu. b. Aparri, Cagayan 13 Jan 1935. Painter. She is the daughter of Mariano Lim and Ho Chien. She married Rizal Yuyitung. She finished her bachelor of fine arts degree at the University of Santo Tomas in 1957.

Her works center on the mother-and-child theme and draw inspiration from children and the games and activities of childhood. Her paintings convey the closeness and warmth of mother and child, emphasizing the feminine role of nurturing the young. Thus, in her paintings she brings out the qualities of tenderness, solicitude, and maternal care. To convey these values, she uses soft lines and light warm, pastel hues for the mother and child, capturing the textures of delicate rosy skin. In outdoor setting, the sunlight is tempered and nature, including the trees, has an overall protective quality over the growing children. The warm and happy atmosphere of her paintings implies that women find fulfillment in motherhood, which has a positive self-enhancing value rather than a negative one impeding self-realization. This does not go against feminist groups who have rediscovered the positive role of nurturance for women, not only of their immediate families but of society as a whole. Veronica Lim-Yu has also derived valuable inspiration from the ordeals of her highly political family of publishers in their exile during the Marcos years.

Her first solo show was at the PhilippineArtGallery in 1962. She has participated in numerous local and foreign group exhibitions.

Lim-Yu won awards in the Shell National Students Art Competition: second prize, Self-Study, 1955; second prize, Portrait of a Woman, 1956; and third prize, Mother and Child, 1956.Written by Alice G. Guillermo

LIMCACO-DANS, ARACELI (Araceli Fernandez Limcaco-Dans) aka Cheloy Dans. b. Manila 9 Dec 1929. Painter, teacher. She is the daughter of Eleuterio Limcaco and Regine Fernandez. She graduated with a bachelor of fine arts degree in painting from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1950. She married engineer Jose P. Dans of Paete, Laguna, with whom she has 10 children. After earning her college degree, she founded the fine arts department of the Philippine Women’s University in 1950, where she taught and administered for 13 years. In 1963, she reorganized the art program of the Ateneo Grade School, eventually heading the art department until 1972. She pioneered the teaching of art through television as studio teacher in the Ateneo Educational Television from 1964 to 1968 after which she founded, together with BrendaFajardo, the Philippine Art Educator’s Association (PAEA).

PAEA launched programs of training and seminars to introduce creative approaches to teaching art at preschool, primary, and secondary levels for public and private schools in 13 regions of the Philippines. She was also a professorial lecturer at the education department of the Ateneo de Manila University Graduate School.

Trained by conservative masters FernandoAmorsolo and GuillermoTolentino, Limcaco-Dans was first known for her portraits. Her works, often shown in exhibitions with fellow Guhit group artists, are still lifes in watercolor called the Calado series. The series features highly realistic renderings of embroidery on translucent fabric such as jusi and piña, the embroidered pieces alternatively combined with flowers, baskets, boxes, and other objects to create meaningful juxtapositions.

Limcaco-Dans has held over 160 exhibits in the Philippines. In 2013, Limcaco-Dans held a benefit exhibit at the United Centre, Admiralty of the Philippine Consulate in Hong Kong, titled Backyard Blooms. She was awarded the Cultural Center of the Philippines Centennial Honors for the Arts for painting and art education, and the UP Alumni Association Award for Lifetime Achievement, among other citations and awards in national art competitions. In 2010, a coffee-table book titled Araceli Limcaco Dans: A Celebration of the Life and Works of a Filipina Artist was published by Abiva Publishing House. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

ClickTheCity 2010; Miller 2013; Orendain 2014; Philstar.com 2013a.

LIONGOREN, ALFREDO (Alfredo Aritcheta Liongoren) b. Hiba-iyo, Guihulngan, Negros Oriental 15 Jan 1944. Painter and performance artist. He is the son of Vicente Liongoren and Fernanda Aritcheta. He married Norma Crisologo with whom he has two children who are also artists: Erik who is a photographer, and Hannah whose practice is in illustration and design. Liongoren graduated with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP). He received three major scholarships in college, including the JoseJoya Sr Memorial Foundation and the PuritaKalaw-Ledesma scholarships. He and his wife run the Liongoren Gallery.

In the mid-1960s, at age 22 and still in school, Liongoren’s work already showed experimentation with materials like burlap, rope, sand, and glue. These he incorporated into his oil paintings, most of which were done in black, white, and grey. During this period, Liongoren and his classmates began to combine abstraction and figurative forms in their paintings. Liongoren’s work generated much attention and won many awards. But the pressure soon drove Liongoren to withdraw from the art scene for five years. He reemerged in 1971 with his new works still combining abstraction and figuration, but now with strong religious undertones, brighter colors, and more details. From the mid-1970s until the present, Liongoren has been painting what he terms as abstract landscapes, which explore the medium of paint: oil, acrylic, and watercolor.

Liongoren’s exhibitions include Twenty Years of Philippine Art, Luz Gallery, 1966; Sixteen Young Artists, Northern Motors Showroom, 1967; Twenty Artists, IRRI, 1967; Thirteen Artists, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1972; First CCP Annual of Paintings and Sculptures, 1976; Museum Artists, Museum of Philippine Art, 1979; The Nature of Influences: CAMP Annual, 1987; Sikat: Two Decades of Philippine Art: 1969-89 (Famous/Shine: Two Decades of Philippine Art: 1969-89), CCP, 1989; Fifty Years of Philippine Abstract Painting (1949-91), CCP, 1991; Bayan ni Nanding versus the Post Modern World (Nanding’s Town versus the Post Modern World), Manila Contemporary, 2009; and Art after 40: New Concepts, Sining Kamalig, 2008. One of the most important international exhibitions he participated in was the Philippine Contemporary Art Show, 1975-84, in Japan, the United States, and Europe. Liongoren’s performative work was part of We Said Our Piece, the CCP’s 40th anniversary exhibition program, 2009, and the Project Bakawan Festival (Mangrove Project Festival), Hardin ng mga Diwata, UP, 2015. His protest action in a performance using ashes during public mobilizations against Malacañan’s intervention in the 2009 National Artist Awards selection process continues to be one of the most poignant images of artist’s resistance to the manipulation of validation channels.

Liongoren held a major comeback exhibition in 2011 at the Gallery Jose in Marikina City, where he showcased 30 watercolor paintings that delivered an apocalyptic message about the dangers of environmental degradation. In 2014, he teamed up with his firstborn son, Erik, in a fund-raising exhibit titled Balesin on My Mind, the proceeds of which went to rehabilitation efforts for areas ravaged by the 2013 typhoon Yolanda.

Liongoren received the British Council Scholarship to the United Kingdom in 1979. He won awards from the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines: purchase award, April Gray, 1964; first prize, Pagdidili-dili (Musings), 1971; and major award, Mangbubungkal (Tillers), 1972. He also won awards at the Shell National Students Art Competition: honorable mention, Moonbath, 1963; certificate of merit, A Token for Veronica, 1964; third prize, Rizal’s Monument, Luneta, 1964; honorable mention, Crown of Thorns, 1964; honorable mention, Paru-parong Bukid (Country Butterfly), 1964; honorable mention, The ManilaCathedral, 1965; second prize, Manila Bay (From the Manila Yacht Club), 1966; and second prize on the theme Mindanao region, 1970. He was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1972. Written by Rachel Mayo, updated by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez and Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Inquirer.net 2014a; Liongoren Gallery, n.d.; Lippi 2014; Mayo 2011a.

LLERENA, EUGENIO (Eugenio Valencia Llerena)b. San Miguel, Manila 6 Sep 1860. d. 17 Jan 1924. Sculptor, wood-carver. He was the son of Juan Llerena and Juana Valencia. He married Concepcion de Leon. He started carving in his father’s shop, taking it over when the latter died.

Most of Llerena’s wood carvings were done for churches and religious devotees. He designed and made the altars of the churches of Angeles, Pampanga; Concepcion, Tarlac; Liliw, Laguna; and La Consolacion College and Hospicio de San Jose in Manila. Religious images he sculpted were kept in the homes of rich patrons.

He received prizes at the competition in honor of Pope Pius X in Manila, the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) held in Manila in 1895; the Universal Exposition at Saint Louis, Missouri, USA, in 1904; and the Primera Exposicion de Bellas Artes y Artes Industriales (First Exposition of Fine Arts and Industrial Arts) in Manila in 1908.Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

LLUCH, JULIE (Julie Moneja Lluch) b. Iligan City 5 Mar 1946. Sculptor. She was earlier known as JulieLluch Dalena during the time of her marriage to DaniloDalena. She is the daughter of Pacificador Lluch and Concepcion Moneja. Her artist-daughters are the filmmaker Sari, transmedia artist Kiri, and sculptor-painter and musician Aba. Lluch finished a bachelor of arts degree in philosophy at the University of Santo Tomas in 1967. She was active in the women’s desk of the ConcernedArtistsofthePhilippines, and she co-founded KASIBULAN or Kababaihan ng Sining at Bagong Sibol ng Kalayaan.

Lluch excels in the sculptural medium of painted terra-cotta. Her first works consisted of variations of cactus forms, hearts, and buttocks which made witty comment on the relationship of the sexes. She proceeded to do portrait-busts in actual size, among the first being those of NickJoaquin and JoseGarciaVilla. Philippine Gothic II, 1985, is a tableau in half figures of Julie and Danilo Dalena, and their dog. The male figure is an image of the Filipino macho, the female figure that of the harassed and long-suffering wife, who is, however, just about ready to shed her illusions of domestic bliss and rebel against conventional male-female roles. A wry note is provided by the black male dog, scratching itself with sheer animal pleasure. SiPicassoatAko (Picasso and I), 1985, shows Julie as housewife in extreme distress over the burnt fish on the frying pan. She is surrounded by Picasso-inspired figures: a spiky cubist dog; a harlequin doubling as her child; and her cactus sculptures, some broken into pieces.

Lluch has since then proceeded to do more sculptures with feminist themes, such as the woman contemplating herself before a mirror and becoming aware of her distinct identity, as well as mythico-symbolic figures, such as the woman shouting from within a burning house, the mermaid swimming against the strong currents, and veiled Mindanaoan women in various postures of prayer. Lluch has also done numerous half-figure portraits of men and women in a style that faithfully captures not only the subject’s physical attributes but, more importantly, their witty and lively characters.

Lluch won third prize for Portrait in the sculpture competition of the Art Association ofthe Philippines in 1979. She was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) in 1990. In 1997, Lluch won the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for sculpture from the city of Manila. In 2008, a retrospective on Lluch’s work, Yuta: Earthworks by Julie Lluch was held at the CCP. The retrospective showcased her life and work, and coincided with the launching of the book bearing the same exhibit title on the artist’s work consisting of previously published articles, reviews, and interviews.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Asia Art Archive, n.d.c; Miclat 2012.

LOPEZ, CRISPIN (Crispin Villafuerte Lopez) b. Bulacan 26 Oct 1903. d. 14 Aug 1985. Painter. He is the son of Emiliano Lopez and Sotera Villafuerte. Emiliano was himself a painter, having painted the Execution of Dr. Jose Rizal for General Gregorio del Pilar Elementary School in Bulacan, Bulacan. Crispin’s greatest influence, however, was Eugenio Lopez, his grandfather, a portraitist of principalia (elite) families of Bulacan province. After graduation from the Far Eastern University High School, Crispin spent several years as a retoucher and painter for various photographers’ studios. He gained recognition for his talents when he won first prize in the Rizal Portrait Contest sponsored by Malacañanin 1937.

Lopez is remembered for the vivid realism of his works. Having achieved his techniques independent of the FernandoAmorsolo school, his paintings can be distinguished by their fine tonal contrast that approaches that of photography. This penchant may be observed in Study of an Aeta, 1944, in which a tribesman holding a spear is shown standing under glaring sunlight. Almost the entire surface of the man’s body is rendered in bright tones strongly contrasting with the deep shadows in his cheekbones, neck, and ribs. Lopez’s portrait, President Manuel Quezon, 1949, is also remarkable for photographic vividness and candidness.

Lopez received honorable mention for The Fisherman at the Manila Club Exhibition sponsored by the Art AssociationofthePhilippines in 1949, and second prize for El Maestro (The Master), 1951. Written by Santiago A.Pilar

LORENZO, DIOSDADO (Diosdado Magno Lorenzo) b. San Isidro, Nueva Ecija 25 May 1906. d. 12 Aug 1984. Painter. He was the son of Emilio Lorenzo and Bonifacia Magno. Lorenzo finished his bachelor of fine arts with honors from the University of the Philippines (UP). He also attended the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid, Spain, and the Regge Accademia di Belle Arti in Rome, Italy. Although trained in the academic tradition, he was one of the pioneering modernists after VictorioEdades. His first one-person show was at the Philippine Columbian in 1935. He taught at the University of Santo Tomas before World War II, and afterward headed its Department of Fine Arts for 26 years.

As one of the Thirteen Moderns, Lorenzo developed his own distinct artistic personality. Unlike the Neo-Realists VicenteManansala and CesarLegaspi who went into the new subject matter of postwar urban life, Lorenzo did not depart from the Amorsolo countryside. He continued to paint nipa huts in rural landscapes. The difference, however, lay in the style. Influenced by impressionism, he painted in a vigorous and spontaneous painterly style, the brushstrokes with traces of pigment lending actual texture. He worked in fresh colors—greens, oranges, and yellow—and their violent complementaries. Characteristic of his paintings was the use of violet shadows in lush tropical landscapes, with alternating sunlight and shade brought out not by academic modeling with graduated tones but by the juxtaposition of warm and cool hues.

His distinctions include the Diwa ng Lahi and the Republic Cultural Heritage awards. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1969. His painting Japanese Inhumanity won fifth prize in the painting competition of the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines in 1948.

Publications on the life and works of Lorenzo includes Diosdado Lorenzo, 1978, by Leonidas Benesa, and Diosdado Magno Lorenzo: Art Rebel to Legend, 2009, by Alice Guillermo. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

LOYOLA, RACQUEL DE (Racquel Dequina de Loyola) aka Kleng de Loyola. b. Manila 18 Feb 1980. Performance artist. She is the daughter of painter Gine Villaflor de Loyola and Teresita Alinsog Dequina. She is married to visual artist Mideo Cruz. De Loyola was a voice major at the College of Music, University of the Philippines Extension Program, in 1996. She studied fine arts, major in painting, at the Philippine Women’s University (PWU), 1998-2001. She also studied the Gamelan Karawitan at the Institut Seni Indonesia in Yogyakarta, Indonesia, as a Darmasiwa scholar, 2002-3.

De Loyola’s performance pieces have explored a wide range of themes over the years, from gender to human rights, from migration to colonization, from identity to globalization. In Subsisting Sustenance, 2006, she dons the form of multiple-breasted Bagobo goddess Mebuyan, fusing song and movement as her custom-made “breasts” are emptied of red paint and ripped open. In Blemish, 2009, she stains piles of white laundry with red, beating fabric with a stick while an audio recording calling out hundreds of names of slain Philippine activists plays in the background. This work would later be part of the exhibition The Triumph of Philippine Art, 2013, at the University of Southern California Fisher Museum of Art, Los Angeles. Another piece presented in Manila, France, and Germany, Satisfaction, appropriates the beat, costume, and posture associated with fashion runways in a parody of consumerism in an increasingly globalized economy.

De Loyola’s art practice began in earnest in 1999. After graduating from PWU, de Loyola participated in Philippine performance art festivals such as the 2002 Philippine International Performance Art Festival and Tupada action art events in 2003. This was followed by successive invitations to perform locally and abroad. Her performance pieces have been presented in events and exhibitions throughout Canada, China, France, Germany, Indonesia, Japan, Myanmar, Serbia, Thailand, and the USA. These events include the Laokoon International Festival, 2004, Germany; Live Art Biennale, 2007, Canada; ASIATOPIA World of Performance Art, 2008 and 2005, Thailand; Open Art International Performance Art Festival, 2009, Beijing; and the 4th Beyond Pressure Festival of Performance Art, 2011, Yangon/Mandalay.

In 2012, de Loyola went to New York for six months as a recipient of the Asian Cultural Council artist residency grant. She performed in venues such as Grace Exhibition Space, Panoply Performance Laboratory, Bliss Project Studio, and Black Box Theater, John Jay College. She collaborated with Mideo Cruz on several performance projects while in America. These included Fulcrum, 2013, at the Grace Exhibition Space, New York, and I Heart America, America Heart Me, 2013, at the Perform China Town Festival in Los Angeles, California. She is a member of the neworldisorder and KASIBULAN. In 2014, she co-founded Bangan Project Space in Gapan, Nueva Ecija. De Loyola received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2009.Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Beyond Pressure 2014; Cruz 2009; de Loyola 2014; Lopez 2011; Satisfaction, n.d.; Sustenance, n.d.

LOZANO, JOSE HONORATO b. Manila ca 1821. d. ca 1885. Painter. His father was the watchman of Malacañan Palace. As a child, he used the palace watchtower’s telescope to observe the life at Manila Bay and its environs. These impressions of childhood would surface in several of his watercolor paintings and in his letras y figuras (letters and figures).

Lozano is described by Rafael Diaz Arenas in Memorias Istoricas (Historical Memories), 1850, as a “landscape painter … a watercolorist without rival in the country.” He also painted the capture of Balanguigui in several episodes which were displayed in the fiestas of Santa Cruz. Of these episodes, the Martirio de Fray Pascual Ibañez (Martyrdom of Fr Pascual Ibañez) is preserved in an engraving by Carlos Borromeo in 1851.

Lozano was also the foremost practitioner of the letras y figuras, a visual art form that enjoyed patronage in the 19th century. In this genre, human figures, buildings, plants, and animals were painted and arranged to form the contours of letters spelling out the names of individuals. The capital letters of the name were cleverly formed by trimmed foliage to provide support for the human figure in various activities. The skill of the artist was seen in how naturally he could integrate the figure to form part of the letter. With each letter only a few inches high, the art of the miniaturist came into play in the finely delineated figures of great variety and the exquisite details of their costumes. The other letters of the name, often on two or three levels, were situated in a lighter background of landscapes. In Francisco Garcia Ortiz, “Francisco” is set against a view of Manila Bay with merchant ships at anchor; “Garcia” is set against scenes of the Pasig River with the PuentedeEspaña (now Jones Bridge) on the left, and “Ortiz” is set against a view of Intramuros, including the ManilaCathedral. Apart from their artistic value, they are a good visual documentation of Manila in the late Spanish period. Other letras y figuras by Lozano are BalvinoMauricio, Francisco de Yriarte, Views of Manila, and Jose Feced y Temprado. Twenty pieces of this genre, not all done by Lozano, are known to date. Jaime Laya published a book on Lozano’s work titled Letras y Figuras, 2001. In 2002, Jose Maria A. Cariño published a larger work, Jose Honorato Lozano: Filipinas 1847, with essays by different art scholars.Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

LUNA, JUAN (Juan Novicio Luna) b. Badoc, Ilocos Norte 24 Oct 1857. d. Hong Kong 7 Dec 1899. Painter. His parents were Joaquin Luna de San Pedro y Posada and Laureana Novicio y Ancheta. He had four equally famous brothers: Manuel, b. 1855, a violin virtuoso; Jose, b. 1861, a physician; Joaquin Damaso, b. 1864, governor, congressman, and senator; and Antonio, b. 1866, writer and general of the Philippine Revolutionary Army. On 7 Dec 1886, Juan married Paz Pardo de Tavera y Gorricho aka Chiching, with whom he had two children, AndresLunadeSanPedro, who became a famous architect, and Maria de la Paz who died young.
