The Lunas transferred to Manila in 1861, enabling Juan to finish his high school at Ateneo de Manila. In 1869, he enrolled at the Escuela Nautica, where after five years of theoretical courses and practical sailing to Asian ports like Hong Kong, Amoy, Singapore, Colombo, and Batavia, he obtained the certificate of piloto de altos mares tercer clase (pilot of the high seas third class). While in port for six months, he took up landscape painting at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura. Eventually, he received private lessons from LorenzoGuerrero, who, perceiving his potentials, urged his parents to send him to Spain for further studies. In 1877, Juan executed Barrio al Lado del Rio (Village by the River) and Vista de un Barrio con Kapok (Barrio Scene with Kapok Trees). Toward the end of that year, he sailed for Spain.

Luna enrolled at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid. There he obtained accesit (outstanding) in color composition and antique studies but did not stay long. Instead he apprenticed himself with Alejo Vera, a professor of the said school, whom he accompanied to Italy in 1879 when the latter went to fulfill commissions there. Upon arriving there, Luna visited the ruins of Pompeii and Naples and made some 40 studies of excavated classical sites and objects, now in the collection of the National Museum of the Philippines. At this time he finished his miniature Autoretrato a Edad 22 (Self-Portrait at 22) on charcoal, and Dafnis y Chloe (Daphnis and Chloe). The latter would soon win for him a silver palette from the Centro Artistico-Literario de Manila. When Vera went back to Spain, Luna remained behind, staying with the Benlliure brothers, with whom he was to develop a loyal friendship. He stayed in Rome until spring, 1884, finishing there such pieces as La Bella Feliz y la Esclava Ciega (The Happy Beauty and the Blind Slave), La Muerte de Cleopatra (The Death of Cleopatra), and the portrait of PedroPaterno. Cleopatra won for him a silver medal at the Madrid Art Exposition of 1881. For this achievement, the Ayuntamiento de Manila granted him a four-year scholarship upon the recommendation of Francisco de Paula Rodoreda. In 1883, he started painting the Spoliarium, which won for him a gold medal at the Madrid Art Exposition the following year. A colossal multifigure scene depicting dead gladiators being mourned by their relatives at the basement of the Roman Colosseum, the Spoliarium was identified by JoseRizal as an allusion to the exploitation of the Philippines by Spain.

Luna transferred to Paris in Oct 1884 but he shuttled back and forth to Madrid as his works, particularly portraits, were now in demand. His presence was also needed by fellow Filipinos who were pushing for reforms in the Philippine colony from the Madrid government. In 1885, he executed ElPacto deSangre (Blood Compact) and Miguel Lopez de Legaspi, pieces sent to Manila in return for his aforementioned scholarship. He also started La Batalla de Lepanto (The Battle of Lepanto), commissioned by the Spanish Senate upon the influence of King Alfonso XII to be hung beside La Rendicion de Granada (The Surrender of Granada) by 1878 grand prize winner Francisco Pradilla Ortiz. By this gesture, the king hoped to compensate Luna who was not given the grand prize for Spoliarium. Although public sentiment felt he deserved the award, it was withheld from him by a biased jury. In 1886, Luna’s Damas Romanas (Roman Ladies) won a diploma of honor at the Munich Salon, and in 1887 his Mestiza en su Tocador (Mestiza Lady at Her Dresser) won a similar award at the Exposicion General de las Islas Filipinas (General Exposition of the Philippine Islands). In November of the same year, the Queen Regent Maria Cristina unveiled both Luna’s and Pradilla’s paintings at the Madrid Senate where both are still hanging. From 1884 to 1890, Luna also executed city scenes like En el Palco (At the Theater Box), 1884; [Street Flower Vendors], 1885, which captured part of the funeral cortege of Victor Hugo; many views of villages and beaches in Normandy; and several portraits of himself, his wife, and children.

Nurtured in the academic classical canons then prevalent all over the Western world, Luna followed the conventional steps in attaining professional success, such as obtaining prizes with colossal Graeco-Roman canvases in the grand Classico-Romantic manner at the prestigious art salons of Europe. By 26 May 1889, however, in his letter to Javier Gomez de la Serna, he avowed his disillusionment with the historical canvas thus: “all historical painting is false starting with the very concept, and those who think that correct drawing, good composition, brilliant coloring and a lot of adornment are enough to make it valid are mistaken.” This statement, however, does not signify Luna’s break with the academic tradition nor his sympathy with impressionism, as many critics earlier presumed, but rather his leaning toward the more progressive faction of the Salon—“the dissident [one]” that he described on 5 May 1890 to Rizal. Luna first signaled this involvement with Le Chifonier (The Ragpicker), showing an old man in tattered clothes carrying a basket of rags, which he showed at the Champs-de-Mars in 1889. By 1891, he was reading Le Socialisme Contemporain (Contemporary Socialism) by E. de Lavelaye and through this concern, he attained the highest honors he was ever to achieve—namely, his acceptance as member of the Societe Nationale des Beaux-Arts. This entitled him to exhibit as many as 10 pictures at the Champs-de-Mars without going through the jury. He gained this acceptance through the merits of Les Ignores (also known as Heroes Anonimos or Los Desherados in Spanish and Poor Man’s Burial in English), which he showed at the Champs-de-Mars in that year.

In 1892, Luna finished Parisian Life and Peuple et Rois (People and Kings), which he intended to send to the Chicago Universal Exposition of that year. However a tragedy aborted his plans. On 22 Sep 1892, he shot his wife and mother-in-law. Acquitted by the French court on 3 Feb 1893, Luna left Paris for Madrid with his son Luling. On 12 Jul, he moved to Portugalete, Bilbao, where he executed two worker themes, La Colada (The Strainer) and Interior de los Talleres del Acero Robert (Interior of the Robert Steel Foundry). In May 1894, after an odyssey of 17 years, Juan returned to Manila with his son and his brother Antonio. In the summer of 1896, he went to Japan with his student GastonO’Farrel. Juan did as many as 20 paintings in Japan. In Aug 1896, he was arrested together with his brothers by the Spanish constabulary for complicity in the Katipunan rebellion. Cleared eventually, he left for Spain to work for the pardon of his brother Antonio. During his homecoming period, he painted many portraits such as Gobernador General Ramon Blanco, LaBulaqueña, those of his parents, brothers, sisters-in-law, and nieces. He painted landscapes like Taal Volcano, Marikina, etc, and genre scenes like Tampuhan (Lover’s Quarrel). Back in Spain, he received news of the overthrow of the Spanish rule in the Philippines. Upon the establishment of the Philippine Republic, he was appointed diplomatic agent of the Hong Kong Junta and later a member of the diplomatic missions to Paris and the United States to work for the recognition of the new government in those countries. Luna died in Hong Kong on his way back to the Philippines.

Publications on the life and works of Luna include Luna, 1975, by Aguilar Cruz; Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter, 1980, by Santiago Pilar; Juan Luna Drawings: The Paris Period, 1998, written by Jun Terra based on the collection of Dr Eleuterio M. Pascual. Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo were the subjects of an exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum in 1989 called Oro Plata (Gold Silver), exploring the life, art, and legacy of these two artists in Philippine art and the nation’s history. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

LUZ, ARTURO (Arturo Rogerio Dimayuga Luz)b. Manila 29 Nov 1926. National Artist for visual arts. He is the son of Valeriano K. Luz and Rosario Dimayuga, an interior designer of Lipa, Batangas. He is married to Teresita Ojeda. They have four children. He finished a three-year certificate course in art at the California College of Arts and Crafts in 1949. Later, he continued his studies at the Brooklyn Museum in New York, and at the Academie de la Grande Chaumiere in Paris. After coming back to the Philippines, he became president of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) in 1952. Among the other positions he held were executive director, Design Center of the Philippines, 1973-87; director, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, 1976-86; and director, Museum of Philippine Art, 1977-85. Together with his wife, he ran the Luz Gallery since 1960.

Luz’s early works bear the influence of Rufino Tamayo, a Mexican expressionist painter. This is evident in his geometrized and elongated treatment of figures, as in Candle Vendors, 1952, and Street Musicians, 1951. In his works between 1957 and 1964, such as his Carnival series and Cyclist series, Paul Klee’s influence becomes more evident. In his more linear paintings, he has been compared to American painter Frank Stella. He also did explorations into burlap collage, its expressive qualities dependent on texture, tonal play, color contrasts, and composition. Between 1966 and 1970, he did large-scale sculptures in various media: marble, wood, and metal. Some of his huge abstract sculptures may be found in the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), the Philippine International Convention Center, and the Philippine Plaza Hotel. He did the floor design for the Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice at the University of the Philippines Diliman.

Luz represented the Philippines in various exhibitions abroad, including the Arte de America y España in Europe, 1963; Sao Paolo Biennale, 1974; the Tokyo International Print Biennale, 1974; and the eighth British International Print Biennale, 1984. In 1995, a retrospective of his works was held at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. Other exhibitions include Arturo Luz, SM Art Center via Crucible Gallery, 2008; Performance, an exhibit of paintings and sculptures with only one subject, performers, SM Art Center, 2009; Monumental: New Works by Arturo Luz, Ayala Museum and Greenbelt Park, 2009, a public art exhibit with new paintings in yellow, red, orange, and blue and large-scale abstract sculptures in the park; Renewal, Total Gallery, Alliance Française de Manille, 2011; Desert Plants, Crucible Gallery, 2012; Arturo Luz, Manila Contemporary and Crucible Gallery, 2013, which showed recent paintings and vintage photographs; Arturo Luz: Sculptures in Metal and Wood, Finale Art File, 2013.

Luz won first prize in the Asian Art Competition held in Saigon, 1963. He won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: honorable mention, Gray Day, 1951; first prize, Ang Bagong Taon (New Year), 1952; best genre, Piko (Hopscotch), 1952; first prize, Procession, 1955; first prize, Venezia No III, 1958; first prize, Forms of Amusement, 1959; first prize, City, 1951; honorable mention, Dayforms, 1960; and first prize, Yellow Quintet, 1963. He received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award for Painting, 1966; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for painting, 1980; the Order of Chevalier des Arts et Lettres from the French government, 1978, from which he was promoted to “officiel” in 1987; and the Gawad CCP para sa Sining, 1989. Luz received the Diwa ng Lahi award from the city of manila in 1993. He was named national artist for visual arts in 1997. Celebrating his 80th birthday in 2006, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and CCP organized a series of events titled In Light of Luz, consisting of several museum exhibits on Luz and his influence on various artists.Written by R. Chu, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Alvina 1998; Hildawa 2006; Philstar.com 2013b; Reyes 1999, 2009, 2011.

MACABUHAY, FLORENTINO (Florentino Gavia Macabuhay) b. Lumban, Laguna 8 Feb 1908. d. 4 Nov 1977. Illustrator. He was the son of Manuel Macabuhay and Escolastica Gavia. He married Consolacion Pascual with whom he had nine children. He finished elementary and high school at the Quiapo Parochial school. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1931. His drawings appeared in Lipang Kalabaw, La Semana, among others. He also played the violin, which he learned under Maestro Incade.

Macabuhay was essentially an illustrator whose work stood out for the vigor of his strokes and the movement of his subjects. Siesta, 1949, demonstrates his versatility in the watercolor medium. The head of the sleeping child is rendered hazily by bold washes to indicate his deep slumber. This contrasts with the solidly rendered toy drum he is clutching shown in the foreground. Macabuhay won third prize for Siesta in the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines art competition in 1949. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

MADARANG, MARIANO (Mariano Naboye Madarang) b. Kiangan, Mountain Province 11 Jan 1937. d. 2008. Painter, teacher. His parents were Vicente Madarang and Cristina Naboye. He took up his early education at Santa Catalina College, Manila, and his secondary education at the University of the East High School. He earned bachelor’s degree in fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1958. He furthered his studies by doing research and taking up art conservation at the Art Center, New York; Academia de Bellas Artes, Mexico; and the Smithsonian Institute, Washington, DC. He was professor and director of the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) from 1959 to 1977. Madarang co-founded and co-organized JT Dayrit Print Gallery, Hidalgo Gallery, Sining Kamalig, Raya Gallery, Avans Gallery, Rafaelita Gallery, Sampaloc Art Center, Manila Garden Art Gallery, Legaspi Art Center, and Greenhills Art Center. He served as director of the PWU Department of Fine Arts, for many years. Madarang also engaged in restoration and conservation work for private collectors and institutions.

Trained in the UST in the 1950s, Madarang was influenced by the geometrization of form through transparent layers of color taught by VicenteManansala. In 1969, he created semi-surrealistic compositions through detailed drawing and brushwork in pen-and-ink. In the mid-1970s, he experimented by merging representation with expressionistic gestures using a brush. He painted realistic genre scenes highlighted by layers of color applied in straight bands that evoke the rhythm of linear patterns created by the contours of the Banaue rice terraces.

Madarang won first prize in painting at the Marian Year Art Contest of 1958. He won second prize for Night Vendors in the nonrepresentational category of the Shell National Students Art Competition of 1957. He was awarded the PWU Professorial Chair in 1967. He received a John D. Rockefeller III grant for international tour and study in 1968-69. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

askArt, n.d.; Skinner 2011.

MADRIÑAN, MARIANO (Mariano Baldemor Madriñan) b. Paete, Laguna 26 Sep 1858. d. Paete, Laguna 7 Jan 1939. Wood-carver. The son of Luciano Madriñan and Tomasina Baldemor, Mariano grew up in Paete, a town already known for its wood carving industry. He learned to carve wood at an early age, but desiring to improve his talents, he took further training under BonifacioArevalo.

Mariano received acclaim during the Spanish period for his Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother) carved out of batikuling wood, which he sent to the Amsterdam Universal Exposition of 1883. This won critical acclaim; and King Alfonso XII, hearing about it, sent him a plaque of recognition. For the rest of his life, Madriñan did realistically detailed religious carvings.Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

MAESTRO, LANI b. Quezon City 1957. Installation artist. She finished her bachelor of fine arts in 1977 from the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. She moved to Canada in 1982 and studied at the Banff Centre in Alberta, and later pursued her master of fine arts at the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

Her major works in the 1980s deal with the theme of political violence. In these works, she pays tribute to the victims whose lives were lost due to their political beliefs, even as the artist herself confronts her own fear, having witnessed such circumstances. She evokes the harrowing experiences of killings, torture, and disappearances through the use of texts and by juxtaposing disturbing images of mutilated bodies and body parts with a range of objects, such as flowers, leaves, candles, bedsheets, frames, and windows. Included in this series are Poem without a Country, 1986; Suspended Voices, 1987; and The Heart Is Stronger Than the Hand, 1989. The Dark Depths, 1986, an installation consisting of electrical cables, broken glass, and black tar paper with written comments on torture victims, bagged the Biennale Prize in the second Havana Biennale.

Another thread running through Maestro’s works is the interrogation of the idea of space, how it is occupied and how it affects people. Inspired by philosophic traditions, this inquiry has opened her creative exploration to a multitude of concepts associated with the notion of space, such as emptiness, silence, absence, a sense of belonging, inclusion, and the home. Notable in this trajectory is the large-scale installation Je Suis Toi (I Am You), 2006, at the 11th-century Romanesque church of Saint Nicolas in Caen, France, where she creates an environment by filling the church with benches constructed from scraps of wood.

The art of Lani Maestro represents a transnational consciousness informed by her life as a migrant Filipino artist living in Canada and later France, and working across the globe. Her art practice resonates with a sensibility that took root in the Philippines and is inflected by her constant mobility in the international art scene while still keeping ties with her roots. This movement across space has allowed her to produce works that communicate universal human experiences localized in different contexts.

She has been active internationally, exhibiting in numerous venues, and has represented both the Philippines and Canada in biennales and triennales worldwide. Among these are the Canadian Biennial of Contemporary Art, 1989; the fifth International Istanbul Biennale, 1997; the third Asia-Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art, 1999, Brisbane; the Shanghai Biennial, 2000; Busan Biennial, 2004; and the Sharaj Biennial, 2008. Some of her solo shows are Perspectives, 1993, in Toronto; Cradle, 1996, in Buffalo and New York; To Dream Sleep, 1998, in Paris; Quiet Rooms, 2001, in Montreal; and Her Rain, 2011, in Winnipeg and Vancouver.

She received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1978 and the Hnatyshyn Foundation Visual Arts Award in 2012. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya and Ryan Franics Reyes

Sources:

Hnatyshyn Foundation 2014; Je Suis Toi 2006.

MAGSAYSAY-HO, ANITA (Anita Corpus Magsaysay-Ho) b. Manila 25 May 1914. d. 5 May 2012. Painter. She is the daughter of Ambrosio Magsaysay and Amalia Corpus. She is married to Robert Ho. She studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts under Fabian de la Rosa, Vicente Rivera y Mir, and Fernando and Pablo Amorsolo. She also studied at the School of Design under Victorio Edades and Enrique Ruiz. From there, she proceeded to the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Michigan. While in the United States, she affiliated with the Art Students League in New York where she took courses in oil painting, graphics, and figure sketching.

During the early 1940s, Magsaysay-Ho’s works showed the influence of Amorsolo in choice of subject and in treatment of light and color. However, her works had very modernist tendencies, such as the use of expressive distortion and concern for design and rhythm. The Philippine Art Gallery (PAG) did much to situate Magsaysay-Ho’s art in the modernist movement of the 1950s. The original Neo-Realists expanded to the PAG group, which included Lydia Arguilla, Nena Saguil, and Magsaysay-Ho as its women artists. In her paintings of the PAG period, which had as subjects women harvesting fruits, gathering sheaves of grain, or selling fish in the market in their baro’t saya and bandanna, Magsaysay-Ho emphasized movement and bustling interaction by means of bold, vigorous brushstrokes, and strong tonal contrasts of light and dark. In the 1960s, she opened up her compositional space and allowed a more leisurely disposition of her women figures which became clearly articulated and separate, the better to bring out the relationship of their movements and serial rhythms. In these later works, the lines tended to soften with a more consistent modeling, the light and dark tones creating a more harmonious and mellifluous effect hinting choreographic grace. The style developed into paintings with movement and greater interaction among the figures. Her work of the 1970s showed the artist exploring a new style influenced by Chinese calligraphy, and a secondary quasi-writer atmosphere. While her subjects were still the same native women, she randomly spattered her canvases with delicately controlled ink blots, which suggested rock formations, vegetation, or waves in the sea. Her concern had evidently become purely formal: balancing the interest and variety of the human gestures and movements with the dynamic and assertive power of the ink blots. A distinct period in the mid-to-late 1980s may be called her Green Period after its predominant coloration. The predominant green is the hue of leaves, fruit, and vegetables; the women figures themselves share this quality symbolically as they themselves become like plants and fruit in nature. By this time, the physical type of her sisterhood is clearly defined through the oval face with high cheekbones, narrow eyes, and brows softly curving up to the temples. In the late 1980s, Magsaysay-Ho began to paint large half-figures. She filled the pictorial field entirely with female figures surrounded by baskets, fruits, or tame birds hopping around them. In place of spontaneity and lightness, which characterized her earlier period, her figures and forms acquired a solidarity of mass rendered in a highly refined manner. Her colors became very Asian, using stark contrasts such as burnt sienna and yellow greens.

In 2001, she had an exhibit at the Crucible Gallery, and one of her works featured an interaction of three artists: herself, Mauro Malang Santos, and BenCab. She published her memoir, Anita Magsaysay-Ho: An Artist’s Memoirs in 2000. Artist-critic Alfredo Roces wrote her biography, In Praise of Women, 2005. Magsaysay-Ho’s works are in the collection of the Ateneo Art Gallery, the Lopez Memorial Museum and Library, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and the Yuchengco Museum.

Magsaysay-Ho won second prize for Five Senses in the 1950 Manila Grand Opera House Exhibition. She won second prize for Fish Vendors in the second watercolor exhibition of Graphic Arts, 1952. She won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: first prize, The Cooks, 1952; second prize, Fruit Vendors, 1953; third prize, Mending the Nets, 1959; first prize, Two Women, 1960; and second prize, Trio, 1962. Magsaysay-Ho received the Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi from Ateneo de Manila University in 2000.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Geringer Art 2013b; Javellana 2009; Magsaysay-Ho 2000; Mananquil 2012; Ner 2012; Robillos and Madarang 2012; Roces 2005.

MAGTIBAY, WILLIAM (William Benavidez Magtibay) aka Willie Magtibay. b. Paco, Manila 17 Apr 1954. Painter, illustrator, multimedia artist. He is the youngest of nine children of Martin Magtibay and Maria Benavidez. He is married to Bernadette Lagasca. His mother was a modista (dressmaker) who painted in textile in the 1950s. He earned his bachelor’s degree in political science at the Baguio Colleges Foundation, then went on to take architectural drafting in the same school. He took units in anthropology and enrolled in painting and drawing workshops at the University of the Philippines, then pursued further art lessons at the Oomoto School of Traditional Japanese Art and at the Royal Art Academy in London, England. He also explored printmaking, handmade-paper making, book art, installation and performance art, and woodworking.

While still in school, Willie was a volunteer art teacher for the Christian Children’s Fund in the Good Shepherd Sister’s Convent at Baguio City. He found early employment as illustrator for the local publication The Northern Edition, hand drawing the covers of this magazine and providing illustrations to the stories about the people and the culture of the Cordilleras. From 1981 to 1983 he was in the art department of Brent International School in Baguio City, performing various duties such as artist in residence, academic head for art studies, and art coordinator. He taught art at the Yokohama International School in Japan in 1983-85 and at the Manila Waldorf School in Quezon City in 2007-9. In 1986, he was a photographer for the Cordillera News Agency. In 1987, Magtibay was part of the group of artists who founded the Baguio Arts Guild. He participated in many shows with this group from 1987 to 1991.

Magtibay’s art is shaped by a common thread of fellow artists of his generation like Santi Bose, Ben Cabrera, Pandy Aviado, and Joey Ayala. They strived to go against the grain of classical Western artistic practices and search for the Filipino in art. Willie did this through an exploration of found objects and the use of indigenous materials. He delved into Philippine cultural traditions to make use of native symbolisms as elements in his art. An example is his mixed media work The Portrait of a Mumbaki. A geometrically designed Itneg blanket is the base of this mixed-media assemblage where beads and a miniature rice god amulet are included as elements in the work.

In the spirit of the true mixed media artist, Magtibay is exploring spirituality and symbolism through a new medium: digital art. His works show skill in color and composition. He juxtaposes old pen-and-ink illustrations and photographs with found images from the Internet. He turns some of these into assemblages with wood, digital art printouts, and other objects. Just as he started doing art by going to the mountains and drawing what he saw of Cordillera culture with the only goal of “drawing like Durer,” so he is tackling this medium of the Internet for the sake of doing the best art he can—without the end-goal of exhibits, without sponsors or collectors, without an audience except the ones in his online artists’ group.

He had his first solo exhibition, Cycle of Life, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1991. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1992 and represented the Philippines in the 4th Havana Biennale in Cuba on the same year. He went to the South East Asia Art Conference in Jakarta, Indonesia, as a Philippine representative in 1993 and at the Artists’ Regional Exchange ARX 4 residency program in Perth, Australia, from 22 Feb to 29 Mar 1994, where he was named Outstanding Asian Artist in the Perth Institute of Contemporary Art and the Northern Territory Gallery in Darwin.Written by Kelly P. Ramos

Sources:

Bennett 1992; Javelosa 1990, n.d.a, n.d.b; Magtibay 2014, n.d.

MALACAÑAN PALACE COLLECTIONS Malacañan Palace retains aspects of the Philippines’ colonial, democratic, and authoritarian history. The term “Malacañang” emerged when journalists in the 1950s heard and spelled it as such and the populist president Ramon Magsaysay adopted it during his term. Today, its stewards use the term Malacañang when referring to the executive seat of power, offices, and complex, and Malacañan when referring to the palace. To describe the palace’s use of space and its collections of art and furnishings is to reflect on each administration’s notion of its role in the state. No one list covers these collections, but written and oral memoirs, archival photographs, and documents help fill the lacunae.

The Spanish gave the name Malacañan to the idyllic district by the Pasig where in 1654 the government purchased a country estate for use by the governors-general and captains-general. After the 1863 earthquake destroyed the Palacio del Gobernador in Intramuros, Malacañan became their principal residence up to 1898. After a series of natural disasters and over two centuries of neglect, reconstruction work began in 1883. Photographs from that period show a settled grandeur and dignity: high-ceilinged Victorian-Edwardian halls, formal dining and salon furniture in local hardwood and rattan solihiya (woven wicker/rattan), gilded mirrors, and iron and glass chandeliers. Balconies looking onto the Pasig had wicker furniture interspersed with potted and hanging plants. A carved 1877 couch bearing Spanish arms remains one of the oldest pieces in the palace today.

The Royal Order of 29 Jun 1845 mandated that portraits of all captains-general and governors-general be displayed in the palace (Montero y Vidal 1895, in Quezon et al. 2005, 47). Juan Luna’s portrait of Fernando Primo de Rivera, 1880-83, and Félix Resurrección Hidalgo’s commissioned painting of Gomez Perez de Dasmariñas, 1590-93, survived and are now in the National Museum. Fernando Amorsolo continued the tradition, and his portraits of Francis Burton Harrison, 1913-21, and Frank Murphy, 1913-21, the latter the 11th and last American governor-general, are likewise in the museum. Amorsolo’s later portraits of Philippine presidents are on display in Malacañan’s Reception Hall, as is Luna’s magnificent Pacto de Sangre (Blood Compact), 1886, which is at the end of the hall, at the top of the main staircase where Governor-General Harrison had installed it.

The prewar Commonwealth period under Manuel L. Quezon and Sergio Osmeña (1935-42) saw Malacañan swiftly fill with people, politics, and parties. Crates from Quezon’s 1937 European tour included three massive Czechoslovakian crystal chandeliers for the Reception Hall. Also for this room were a carved barrel vault and panels by Isabelo Tampinco and a magnificent table built by prisoners who were later pardoned in gratitude for their fine craftsmanship. These renovations symbolized Quezon’s authority and triumph over enormous resistance to independence. In stark contrast was the subdued takeover by Jose P. Laurel, president of the Second Republic under the Japanese, 1942-45. Mrs Laurel refused to move into what she considered the Quezon residence. Executive Secretary Jorge B. Vargas notably expanded the collection then by commissioning Amorsolo to paint Muslim Vinta, undated, and by purchasing Miguel AranquiznaZaragoza’s The Violinist, undated, and Luna’s Una Bulaqueña, 1895, the latter work since given over to the National Museum.

With reparation funds poured into public works, the Third Republic under Manuel Roxas, 1946-48, saw few additions to the palace. It was under Elpidio Quirino, 1948-53, that Malacañan underwent its first postwar refurbishment. In Castilian Filipino style, his administration replaced the Victorian upholstery and wallpaper, stored tapestries, and purchased new drapery, beds, a piano, a harp, an Aubusson carpet, and Louis XVI-style furniture. For the Council of State Room, Tampinco carved another table. Ramon Magsaysay, 1953-57, man of the masses, brought in people rather than furnishings to Malacañan. Over 80,000 people took up his invitation to visit in one day. On the other hand, Carlos P. Garcia, 1957-61, returned Malacañan to its previous formality. Living simply, the billiard and chess room was his modest legacy. In tandem with Diosdado Macapagal’s anti-corruption new era years, 1961-65, Mrs Macapagal denounced what a staff member described as outright thievery: “Servants had been helping themselves to the silver, china, and had stripped the residence of everything movable.… Every evening they left for home carrying cases and even crates of goods belonging to the Palace” (Quezon et al. 2005, 245). The First Lady also brought in from the Luneta (today Rizal Park) and the 1950s Manila World’s Fair Francesco Riccardo Monti’s Four Freedoms and adorned Heroes Hall with busts commissioned from Guillermo Tolentino of national heroes Rajah Lakandula, Gabriel Silang, Jose Rizal, Marcelo del Pilar, Andres Bonifacio, Apolinario Mabini, Emilio Aguinaldo, Manuel Quezon, and Jose Abad Santos.

Ferdinand E. Marcos, 1965-86, ordered the complete demolition of Malacañan complex in 1979 (Lico 2003, 40). Much of the furniture and architectural embellishments of previous administrations would disappear, like the Tampinco panels and the Commonwealth-era stained glass doors and sky light. Heavily fortified, Malacañan Palace doubled in floor space from 5,653 sq m in 1965 to 11,510 sq m in 1978. Under martial law, 1972-86, state-sanctioned art and state-funded architecture combined to produce a site governed by indigenized and cosmopolitan aesthetics. An iconic symbol of this period was the renovated Ceremonial (now Rizal) Hall—rendered bulletproof and missile-proof—featuring two gilded thrones under an embroidered presidential seal and enormous Rococo-style wooden chandeliers carved by artisans from Betis, Pampanga.

Corazon C. Aquino, 1986-92, consciously rejected all links with the previous regime, choosing instead to live in the Arlegui Mansion and work in the Premier Guesthouse. A two-volume photo inventory of Palace contents that Mrs Marcos commissioned for its 1979 re-inauguration helped the Cory administration conduct their own inventory of the Palace collections. Much of the furniture listed in storage—formal chairs, tapestries, drapes, side tables, urns—had vanished.

Succeeding administrations Fidel V. Ramos, 1992-98, Joseph Ejercito Estrada, 1998-2001, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, 2001-10, and Benigno S. Aquino III, 2010-16 would each have their own policy regarding their residency in the Malacañan. A major renovation was conducted during the Estrada administration, installing the largest of the three Czech chandeliers that Quezon purchased in 1937 in the lobby. Designer Chito Antonio added to this repurposed furniture, gilded mirrors, and Italian antiques from the nearby Goldberg Mansion and to the palace, the wall-papered interiors, bleached wood paneling, and stuffed modern couches, introducing the luxurious comfort of a boutique hotel. Renamed Bonifacio Hall, this space today houses official meeting rooms, state guest suites, and office space for senior officials. Malacañan, after nearly three decades of transformation from “regal residence to the residence of a periodically-changing, democratically-selected chief executive,” is considered a symbol of the legitimacy and authority of the president of the Philippines (Quezon et al. 2005, 305). Written by Purissima Benitez-Johannot

Sources:

Lico 2003; Montero y Vidal 1998; Quezon et al. 2005.

MALANG (Mauro Malang Santos) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 20 Jan 1928. d. 10 Jun 2017. Painter. He was the son of Dan Santos and Juliana Malang. He married Mary San Pedro. They have four children, two of whom are painters—Steve Santos and Soler Santos. At the age of 10, he studied drawing under Teodoro Buenaventura. When he was 19, he decided to stop schooling and join the staff of the Manila Chronicle art department under noted cartoonist Liborio (Gat) Gatbonton.

In the 1950s, This Week magazine had a column called Legal Info that explained the Philippine legal system, and it was complemented by Malang’s humorous sketches. In 1956, he also drew for a pictorial feature called “That’s the Law” for the same magazine. Malang made some cartoons and illustration strips from 1947 to 1967 including Labuyo (Chili), a serial published in Sinagtala, 1947. He also established Bituin Komiks. Malang created the daily comic strip Kosme the Cop, which first appeared in This Week. This was a weekly cartoon that showed “the exploits of a high strung policeman as he patrolled his beat.” Later, Kosme retired as a cop and became known as Kosme the Cop (Retired), which was about “the henpecked husband who gets into all kinds of scrapes.” Kosme moved to the Chronicle, the first Filipino cartoon character in a daily English strip. Malang also launched Chain Gang Charlie, “the convict who has a thousand and one uses for his ball and chain” and Beelzebub, “the devil whose tail is an indispensable accessory” for Pageant Magazine. His other characters include Bentot and Osboy. In 1955, Malang, with Liborio Gatbonton, Larry Alcala, Hugo Yonzon, and Elmer Abustan, opened Bughouse, the country’s first cartoon gallery but it closed down after a year despite positive public feedback. Gat and Malang also launched a comic book also named Bughouse.

His editorial cartoons for the Weekly Graphic reflected his visual commentaries on the social ills of Philippine society—government corruption, crime, unemployment, police abuse, and incompetent politicians. A series that came out in the Weekly Graphic is called Malang’s Menagerie, one big picture, a montage of “sight-gags” or uncaptioned jokes that Malang called “village-scapes” that were set in a barrio or in the city, a graduation event, New Year’s Eve, a neighborhood—in a tableau of scenes that tells an amusing story. Journalist Armando Malay suggested that Malang adopt a single moniker, and use his mother’s surname to sign his cartoons.

In the late 1960s, he decided to become a full-time painter, after a two-decade career as a cartoonist and editorial artist. Among his works is Barrio Fiesta, an oil on canvas commissioned in 1958 by the Ayala Corporation for the FGU-Insular Life Building. His first one-man show at the Philippine Art Gallery (PAG) was sold out, followed by many more successful solo exhibitions. He is acknowledged as a master colorist, and he has received acclaim for his Barung-Barong (shanty) series, floral abstractions, scarred landscapes, and his signature women vendors. He is a senior member and former head of the Saturday Group of artists. In 1966, together with other prominent painters, Malang launched the project “Art for the Masses,” which allowed art, through reasonably priced prints, to be made available to a wider audience. In 1972, Malang studied at the Otis Art Institute under a special grant. Two books have been published on his work, Malang: Paintings and Drawings, 1981, and Malang’s Women: Thirty Years of Art, 1992.

Malang’s solo exhibitions include Malang’s Women II, 1984; In the Beginning, 1991; Women: 30 Years of Art, 1992; Malang at Genesis 6750, 1993; Malang Gouache and Prints, 1993; Drawing, 1994; Women Vendors, 1995; Landscape, 1995; Women, 1996; Malang: One, 1997; Malang: 50’s to the 90’s Retrospective, Metropolitan Museum, 1997; A New Phase for Malang, 1998; Malang Celebrating Seventy, 1998; Colored Drawings, 1999; Small Works, 1999; Recent Works, 1999; April Show, 2000; and Malang Celebrates the 21st Century, 2000. In Mar 2007, he had an exhibit titled The Forgotten Malang, which showcased a wealth of comic strips, cartoon characters, and drawings. Another exhibit in 2009, Malang Drawings, was a collection of some 100 drawings in pen-and-ink, watercolor, gouache, acrylic, charcoal, and crayon shown in celebration of the artist’s 81st birthday.

In 1957, Malang was included in the list of “Twelve Artists in the Philippines—Who’s Who” put together by Lyd Arguilla, founder of the PAG. The following year, he received the Award for Editorial Design from the Art Directors Guild of the Philippines. He consistently won in the competitions held by the Society of Philippine Illustrators and Cartoonists, which named him Artist of the Year in 1964. Malang won awards in the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competitions: second prize, Street Fight, 1951; third prize, Traffic, 1953; honorable mention, The Yellow Sky, 1959; second prize, Quarter Moon; and an honorable mention for Gate to Intramuros, 1963. He was a Ten Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines awardee in 1963. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the city of Manila in 1981. In 1994, he received from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining for visual arts.Written by R. Chu, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Artinasia.com 2013; de Guzman 2008; Gatbonton 2002; Komiklopedia 2008; Santos 2013; Tejero 2009.

MALANTIC, ANTONIO (Antonio Feliciano Pascual Malantic) b. Bulacan, Bulacan 13 Jun 1821. d. Tondo, Manila ca 1886. Painter. He was the son of AntonioMalantic el mayor (the elder) and Maria Pascual. This information was based on the discovery at the Archdiocesan Archives of Manila of Malantic’s application for marriage license in order to marry his third cousin Josefa Nicandro. The artist was in his early 20s when the Academia de Dibujo resumed operation in 1845 and he might have studied there. Prior to the arrival of Agustin Saez, the teachers of the school were Enrique Nieto y Zamora, Ventura del Arco, Luis Perez Domine, Nicolas Enrile, Jose Bosch, and Manuel de la Cortina, from whom Malantic could have learned his techniques.

Malantic was a miniaturist—that is, he achieved realistic representation by rendering every particular aspect of an object fastidiously with every brushwork finely applied and concealed. This is evident in his portraits where all details of dress such as delicate embroidery designs, as well as appurtenances attesting to the prestige of his sitters, have been limned meticulously. One of the most refined portraitists in the 19th century, Malantic is only known today from four signed works—namely, the portraits Don Narcisco Padilla y su nieto Felix (Don Narciso and His Grandson Felix), 1859; Soledad Francia and InocenciaFrancia, 1870; and La Divina Pastora (The Divine Shepherdess), 1855, the last being a religious painting. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

MANALAD, AMADEO (Amadeo Yabot Manalad) b. Bautista, Pangasinan 25 Nov 1911; d. Quezon City 17 Sep 1984. Painter, muralist, illustrator. He is the third child of Sotero Manalad and Alejandra Yabot. He studied fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1930-32 and was a contemporary of Carlos V. Francisco and Vicente S. Manansala. He then worked as an illustrator for The Herald, and partnered with his brother Wagas Manalad as production manager at the Philippine Advertising Company, where he would work on and off from 1935 until his resignation in 1967. Starting in 1947, he was also employed as chief illustrator at the Ramon Roces Publications. He also worked briefly for Advertising Associates as chief artist. He became a co-founder of the Bulacan-based Lakan Sining group of artists in 1975.

Although educated in the then prevailing conservative style at UP, Manalad nonetheless utilized a modern style in composing and rendering his subjects, which were primarily focused on historical and mythological scenes culled from Philippine literary texts. Manalad was a key member of a Filipino muralist movement that started in the late 1930s. He was an assistant for mural projects under Victorio Edades and Enrique Ruiz. The demand for murals from the private sector peaked in 1945-46 and for government-commissioned murals during the martial law period in 1974-76. Manalad’s murals exhibit a propensity for flowing compositional elements that relate strongly to Carlos Francisco’s works, while also hewing to blocklike renditions of human subjects reminiscent of Vicente Manansala’s murals. His first major mural was Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao, 1945 (now destroyed), at the US Army Snack Bar No. 11 near Ayala Bridge in Manila, for which he had as assistants Manuel Certeza and Vicente Manansala. This was followed by Mother Earth, 1945 (also destroyed), for the US Army Officer’s Club at San Francisco del Monte, Quezon City. In 1946, Manalad did murals for the staircase and second floor lobby of the Life Theater in Quiapo. In 1974, he was commissioned by First Lady Imelda Marcos to do a mural called Philippine Arts and Culture, and another on the First Lady’s social and cultural projects (both now lost). In 1976, he was chosen by Bulacan governor Ignacio Santiago to paint a mural for the provincial capitol building, The History of Bulacan, completed with the assistance of many noted Bulakenyo artists.

Manalad illustrated the history of the Philippines in charcoal and ink for The Philippine Saga, 1947, written by Jaime de Veyra and H. Otley Beyer. His last major opportunity to image history came when he was asked to illustrate the various scenes of Ferdinand Marcos’s Tadhana books from 1978 to 1979. Thirty-eight out of a total of 102 scenes from his Tadhana series made up his first and only solo exhibition on 7-14 Oct 1980 at the Galerie Bleue in Rustan’s Makati. These works were subsequently purchased by Mrs Marcos and housed at the Santo Niño Shrine in Tacloban. Another series of historical tipos del pais (country scenes) drawings were done in 1979 to decorate the Coconut Palace, and is now in the care of the Government Service Insurance System Museum.Written by Reuben R. Cañete.

Sources:

Cañete 2006; Guerrero 2003.

MANALO, NEIL (Neil Arriola Manalo) b. Antipolo, Rizal 20 Feb 1965. Painter. He is the son of Marcial Manalo Sr and Manuela Arriola. In his fifth grade of primary education, he attended the workshop of well-known artist-teacher FernandoSena at the Antipolo Municipal High School. He later took up advertising at Far Eastern University where he graduated in 1990. He joined the Salingpusa group of young artists when he was in first year college and benefited much from the encouragement of the group. He worked for two years as a designer at the Modern Paper Products company where the hands-on experience in working with design strengthened the basis of his art. Through the joint activities of Salingpusa, many of its members, including Manalo, were able to gain critical notice and support.

Manalo became known for his social commentary works on the moral influences of societal forces on children and simple folk. However, he took a long pause from exhibitions and competitions to reassess his work, only returning to the scene in 2007 with a solo exhibit titled Dumadaan (Passing By) at Art Informal in San Juan City. In 2014, he had another solo exhibition at the Pinto Art Museum in Antipolo City titled Koordinasyon (Coordination).

Manalo won first prize in the International Marian Year art competition in 1988. In the same year, he won second prize in the Metrobank Foundation competition, watercolor category, for the work titled Ang Buklod ng Taas Baba’t Takip Butas na Luma’t Bagong Mali’t Tama (Unity of High and Low Stopgap of the Old and New Right and Wrong). Here the image was sectioned into several levels containing numerous figures showing the traditional social hierarchy, as well as the contradictions of Philippine society. He won awards in the watercolor category from Metrobank for Art, second prize, 1989, and Opera, Korokoro’t Kurokuro (Opera, Choruses and Opinions), 1990. Manalo was conferred the Thirteen Artists Award by the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2000. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Guzman 2007; Pinto Art Museum, n.d.

MANALO, NOEL b. Manila 20 Jun 1939. Painter. Manalo took up courses in fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas. While practicing his art, he also served as director of an advertising agency.

Manalo was one of the earliest Filipino artists influenced by pop art, perhaps because of his experience in the advertising industry. He expressed this in his appropriation of pictorial devices and techniques earlier exclusive to advertisement design in his paintings. Art critic Alfredo Roces in his commentary on the artist’s solo exhibition in 1967 described his style thus: “Manalo, who earns his bread in an advertising agency, utilized the color pages of magazines as a starting point for his paintings and collages. The artist paints patterns over the surface or puts an overlay of tracing paper (an advertising technique) and makes ink drawings on the surface. The overall effect is a transformation of the colored magazine page into background and surfaces for Manalo’s flat motifs. The muted effect of a tracing overlay creates a sense of depth or fantasy.” In the 1970s, Manalo became identified with the avant-garde of local contemporary art for his hard-edged shapes and evenly painted acrylic surfaces.

He held his first one-person exhibition at the Philippine Art Gallery in 1963 and has held other shows since then.

Manalo won first prize in painting, modern art category, for his Original Sin at the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1960. The following year, he won second prize for Exhibit A in the same category in the same contest. In 1963, his O Blushing Moon, Now You See It, Now You Don’t was adjudged the best relief at the 2nd Graphic Arts Competition sponsored by the Art Association of the Philippines. Manalo was chosen to represent the Philippines in the First India Triennale in New Delhi, 1968, and in the fourth Sao Paulo Biennale, 1969. He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1970.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

MANANSALA, VICENTE (Vicente Silva Manansala) b. Macabebe, Pampanga 22 Jan 1910. d. 22 Aug 1981. National Artist for visual arts. He is the son of Perfecto Q. Manansala and Engracia Silva. He finished his elementary grades at Intramuros Elementary School (now Araullo), Manila; and first year at the Manila South High School. He married Hermenegilda (Hilda) Diaz, with whom he had one child; their granddaughter, Ronna Manansala, is an artist. As a newsboy and bootblack in Intramuros, he expressed his early creativity designing kites and making charcoal sketches. At 15, he studied under turn-of-the-century painter Ramon Peralta while doing signboards for a painting shop. He entered the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts in 1926, and graduated in 1930. In 1927, he was awarded medalla or first prize for Coloring from Life. He worked as a sign painter at the Manila Advertising Company in Calle Meisic, from 1931 to 1932; and as an illustrator for the Philippine Herald in 1932. He was chief layout artist for Photonews and Saturday Evening News magazine during the 1930s. He undertook further studies and training at the Ecole de Beaux Arts in Banff and Montreal, Canada, 1949, under a UNESCO Art Fellowship, and in the USA and in France at the Ecole des Beaux Arts of the University of Paris, 1950, where Manansala had a brief stint under Ferdinand Leger.

As a member of the Thirteen Moderns and the Neo-realists, Manansala was at the forefront of the modernist movement in the country. With the issues of national culture and identity in focus after World War II, his works became, as did those of the other early modernists, reflective of the social environment and expressive of the native sensibility. He held his first one-person show at the Manila Hotel in 1951. Manansala consistently worked in the figurative mode, with the exception of a few abstract works. Shunning Amorsolo’ s rural idylls, he developed a new imagery based on the postwar urban experience. The city of Manila, through the vision of the artist, assumed a strong folk character. He painted an innovative mother and child, Madonna of the Slums, 1950, which reflected the poverty in postwar Manila. Besides the mother-and-child, his subjects included jeepneys, barong-barong (shanties), cockfighters, families gathering for a modest meal, and Quiapo women vendors of various goods. His women vendors sit veiled and hunched over their wares, their brown impassive faces like the archaic bulol, block-like with broad planes, their large bare feet projecting from the hem of their saya (long skirt). He did still lifes of native fruits, vegetables, and dried fish in the setting of a native kitchen with its folk utensils, palayok (clay pot), kawali (frying pan), and almires (mortar) against capiz windows. The cubist aspect of Manansala’s work rests largely on the geometric facetting of forms and in the shifting and overlapping of planes. But his facets and planes are broader than in original cubism as they bring out larger rhythms. Here and there, he incorporates linear decorative patterns, as in the ironwork curlicues of gates and windows. In his work, he developed the style of transparent cubism, which was generally shared by his fellow Neo-Realists Cesar Legaspi and Romeo Tabuena. Unlike analytical cubism, which arbitrarily fragments and dissects the figure into complex abstract compositions with only clues of the subject remaining, Manansala stayed close to the figure which he simplified to its basic geometric shape. He went through a black-and-white phase of crucifixions and Madonna-and-child paintings, but, on the whole, he used color in all its folk vibrancy, sensuous appeal, and evocative power. In composition, his works often feature lines of perspective with receding, although shallow space; but recession in depth is simultaneously defined by lines and planes that create spatial ambiguities. His still lifes have a tapestry-like quality. The various objects from the domestic context are not fragmented but left integral, occupying the entire visual field, with bright elements on a dark, ambiguous space and at times showing the influence of 17th-century paintings of Dutch interiors with their checkerboard motifs. As a whole, Manansala reinterpreted or indigenized cubism as he drew his themes from the familiar Filipino environment. Manansala’s vision of the city and his sensibility to his subjects would influence numerous artists who took up his folk themes within an urban context.

Among those who show his influence are Mauro Malang Santos, with his own version of folk romanticism in paintings that convey the fragile, makeshift character of the 1950s, and others from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where Manansala taught for a time. These include artists such as Antonio Austria, Angelito Antonio, and Mario Parial. Like him, they drew their inspiration from the folk, their occupations, and pleasures. He also influenced Manuel Baldemor, whose roots are in Paete, Laguna, as well as some Laguna lakeshore artists. Manansala’s art exemplified a solution to the problems of the 1950s in terms of the use of modern Western idioms and their local transformation, and in terms of the subject matter and content of art reflective of a people’s identity.

Manansala won first prize for Barong-Barong No. 1 (Shanties No. 1) in the 1950 Manila Grand Opera House Exhibition of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP). His awards from the AAP also include third prize for Banaklaot (Fishermen) and honorable mention for I Believe in God, 1948; second prize, Kahig (Scratch), 1953; second prize, Fish Vendors, 1955; third prize, Best Served, Well-Gained, 1955; second prize and also best in show, Give Us This Day, 1962. In 1940, he won first prize for Pounding Rice at the UST National Art Exhibition, Filipiniana Division, and in 1949, the Best Poster of the Philippine Republic, USIS Poster Contest, and second prize for the Philippine National Red Cross design. He received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1963. He also received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1970. He was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts in 1982. In 2012, the Museum of Kapampangan Arts, Holy Angel University, Angeles City in Pampanga inaugurated its Manansala Gallery, which holds the artist’s pencil and watercolor works, the Parisian Boudoir series, the UP Stations of the Cross studies, and other memorabilia, including the artist’s National Artist medallion. In 2014, on Manansala’s 104th birthday, a tribute titled Si Manansala at ang Masaganang Ani (Manansala and a Prosperous Harvest) was held at the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) in Los Baños where two of his murals were originally hanging in the IRRI dining area before going on loan to the National Museum.Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Ayala Museum 2010; Barbiera 2014; Nazareno 2005; Paras 1980, 1998; Reyes 2012; Rizal Library, n.d.

MARAMAG, BEN b. 3 Oct 1945. Painter. He took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines. His art was shaped when pure abstraction was gaining ground in the country as exemplified in the works of FernandoZobel de Ayala who explored problems of depth on the canvas through fine tonal gradations. Maramag explored similar problems on canvases, usually square-shaped with evenly laid colors.

Curator RayAlbano in a critique on the artist summed up Maramag’s achievement thus: “Maramag was the leading master of the spray gun, having had the authority and experience to play around with it. He managed to complicate his surface by masking, using masking tape, shaping his surface, taking chances. His language was complete with nuances of expression and illusion possible for such a look.” This mode of work is demonstrated in Maramag’s Untitled, 1978, in acrylic which was part of Insights into Philippine Contemporary Art sent to Washington, DC, in 1978. He created the illusion of endless space on the center of the canvas’s surface from which straight-edged bands of color seemed to emanate and fold up on each other. In 1980, he delved further into concerns with illusory space in Title A, in acrylic, a shaped surface, his entry in Five Directions at the Museum of Philippine Art. Here two opposite corners of his painting were curved instead of straight, a device that heightened the illusion of projection of the triangles meeting at the center of the painting. Maramag staged his first one-person show at the Indigo Gallery in 1967, followed by five others at the Luz Gallery and at the CulturalCenterofthe Philippines (CCP). He belonged to the first group of Thirteen Artists chosen for their outstanding achievement by the CCP in 1970. In Sep 2012, his works along with those of select Thirteen Artists awardees, were exhibited at the CCP. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Source:

CCP Visual Arts 2012.

MARCELO, ILDEFONSO (Ildefenso Cruz Marcelo) b. Bulacan 23 Jan 1941. Sculptor. He is the son of Severino Marcelo and Inez Cruz. He married Lilia Enverga. Marcelo finished bachelor of fine arts, major in sculpture, at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1962, then took graduate studies at the University of Hawaii and Pratt Institute, New York. He was an East-West scholar to the United States, 1964-65. He held his first exhibit in open air at the UP campus during his graduation. In 1964, he exhibited at the Seattle World Fair and the New York World Fair. It was much later, in 1980, that he held his second one-person show, followed by a series of shows in different galleries.

Marcelo spent the 1960s as Rizal Park designer and sculptor. He did the large ebony carabaos flanking the steps to the Quirino Grandstand. The medium associated with him is adobe stone, as seen in his figures of Captivity, Contemplation, and Challenge on the UP Diliman campus. The medium of sharply hewn bedrock is used to advantage in his large-scale works expressive of massive strength, permanence, and solidity. Because of its hardness and gritty texture, adobe lends itself best to the artist’s simple and broad treatment of the human figure, not concerned with detail but composed in terms of the integral whole. The figures, whether turned inward to themselves or bent backward into a tense arch, are generally cubistic with flat surfaces meeting at sharp angles.

Marcelo has worked with smaller figures with stylized features and linear patterns.

Adobe resists polish, and the severe blocklike orientation of the figures give his sculpture a “primitive” quality echoing the native likha (icon). Marcelo received awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: second prize, Man and Crocodile, 1960; first prize, Superstructure, 1961; first prize, Captivity, 1962; and second prize, Offering, 1963. He received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1961. In 2009, the works of Marcelo, along with several UP alumni, were featured in the opening exhibition of the UP Bulwagan ng Dangal University Heritage Museum. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Source:

Dipasupil 2009.

MARCELO, NONOY (Severino Santos Marcelo) b. Malabon, Metro Manila 22 Jan 1942. d. Manila 22 Oct 2002. Cartoonist. He is the son of David Marcelo and Rita Santos. He published his first comic book titled Likmuan ng mga Pighati sa Paligid-ligid (Seat of Sorrows All Around) when he was nine. He followed this strong leaning toward the arts when he became editor–art director–artist for the high school paper at St. James Academy of Malabon. In college, he graduated with a bachelor’s degree in English from Far Eastern University (FEU) while writing and drawing for the school organ Advocate. Later he finished a course in advanced animation in the School of Visual Arts of New York City, USA, in 1970. He also became staff artist for the Evergreen Review and art director of McGregor & Warner in Washington, DC, 1970.

Marcelo’s sketches reflect a very personal view of the world, “harsh, alienating but very funny” (Bondoc 1985). As one Hong Kong art critic said: “Just as some people review films, others review politics, Marcelo reviews life. His Filipino intelligence and sensitivity give him an understanding of people and situations, and he’s got the courage to stab with his pen anything pretentious, stupid, or just downright funny” (Bondoc 1985). His most popular works are the comic strips Plain Folks (Daily Mirror), Tisoy (Manila Times) and Ikabod (Bulletin Today). Tisoy was made into a movie twice. In 1969, it was directed by Lauro Pacheco, with Jimmy Morato in the tile role. In 1977, it was helmed by Ishmael Bernal, with Christopher de Leon in the title role.

Marcelo also went into film animation. In 1974, he did a seven-minute cartoon clip for Maryo J. de los Reyes’s disco film Annie Batungbakal, which starred Nora Aunor. In 1978, his 48-minute pilot episode of Tadhana (Destiny), a history series, was aired on RPN 9. In 1979, he did a one-hour feature film titled Biag ni Lam-ang (Life of Lam-ang), which highlighted the adventures of the Ilocano epic hero.

Marcelo is a multi-awarded artist. He received the Artist of the Year award from FEU in 1960. He won first prize for the most humorous cartoon from the Society of Philippine Illustrators and Cartoonists in 1963 and 1970, and in the doodle and caricature contests of the Manila Overseas Press Club in 1963.Written by Pauline Mangilog

MARTE, MAGDALENA b. ca 1920. Piña weaver. She belongs to one of the weaving families in Kalibo, Aklan, who actively promoted the tradition of piña fabric weaving. Woven from the tough leaf fibers of the wild red pineapple plant, piña is the finest, most delicate fabric in the world and is produced mainly in the town of Kalibo, Aklan. The whole process—from extracting the piña fiber to the preparation of the threads or stretching on the loom to the interknitting which produces the cloth—requires precision, delicacy, and painstaking care. Until recent periods, piña weavers could be found in almost every household in the island of Panay.

Marte and her niece Zosima de la Cruz have taken the lead in reviving this tradition. Their household in Kalibo had four looms, and became the center of a weavers’ training program sponsored by a government agency. Marte and her nieces are the only ones known to practice the traditional weaving method called pili or sinuksok. This consists of embellishing the piña fabric with tiny, delicate designs through a floating weft technique done after the cloth weaving.

Marte received the Manlilikha ng Bayan Award in 1990 from the Cultural Center of the Philippines for “actively supporting and sustaining the traditional weaving of piña, the most unique and delicate fabric of the Philippines.”Written by Rosalinda Galang

MARTINEZ, FELIX (Felix Lorenzo Martinez) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 23 Feb 1859. d. ca 1917. Painter. He came from a family of artisans. He finished high school at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1877, where he obtained sobresaliente (outstanding) in art under Fr Antonio Sabater. After this achievement, he was asked to render some plates for the deluxe edition of Father Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas (Plants of the Philippines). In 1878, one of his drawings was featured in the newspaper La Ilustracion del Oriente. In 1882, he won a silver medal for his entry in the contest commemorating the 300th anniversary of Santa Teresa de Avila. From this time, Martinez became one of the most prestigious painters of Manila. Six of his landscapes were sent to Madrid in 1884; a year later, he held a solo exhibition at the Tienda de Catalanes. He served as illustrator for magazines like La Ilustracion Filipina. He was also renowned for his portraits of several governor-generals, and of members of the Paterno, Tuason, Tambunting, and Escudero families. He also helped decorate the San SebastianChurch and the SanIgnacioChurch in the 1890s.

Most of Martinez’s works known today are genre pieces like The Pasig River (Central Bank Collection) and Panguingueras (Luis Ma. Araneta Collection). These pieces show him to be a costumbrista whose treatment of local custom themes is imbued with incisive realism. Thus, he avoided idealization, emphasizing instead the peculiar features of his sitters.

In 1904, FelixMartinez obtained a bronze medal for his overall collaboration at the Saint Louis Universal Exposition, another bronze medal for Portrait of an Old Woman, and an honorable mention each for Holy Water Fountain and for Manila Bay in the same exposition. Not all old paintings signed “Martinez” were done by Felix. He usually signed his works with “Fx Martinez.” Those simply signed “Martinez” are usually done by RamonL.Martinez. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

MARTINEZ, LUCIO P. b. Manila 1947. Printmaker. He graduated with a degree in fine arts at the Philippine Women’s University in 1966. After this, he worked closely with Manuel RodriguezSr at the latter’s contemporary graphic art workshop, exploring every newfangled approach to print techniques with colleagues Manuel Jr aka BoyRodriguez, MarcelinoRodriguez, and VirgilioAviado.

Martinez’s best medium is woodcut, which he uses with a keen sense of dynamism that is powerful in its simplicity. He depicts portraits from storybooks as though from an innocent, eager child’s point of view. Not concerned with individualized character, he is rather engrossed with bringing out a comical fantasy of playful figures in quasi-naive renditions in black supplemented by two other flat colors. A charming, primitivistic design results from an intimate knowledge of wood grain and skillful handling of the carver’s chisel. Most notable of his woodcut prints are Moses and the Flaming Tree, Queen Elizabeth, Adam and Eve, Statue of Liberty, and The Juggler, all done in 1969-70, and founded on a “single image” approach to space.

Among the group exhibitions he participated in were the First Indian Triennale of Art in New Delhi in 1968, the Fifth International Exhibition of Colored Graphic Prints in Switzerland in 1970, the Sepia Print Show in New York in 1973, the Kutingting at the Cultural Center of thePhilippines Main Gallery in 1975, and The Art of Fine Print: A View of 25 Years at the Museum of Philippine Art in 1980. He held solo exhibitions at the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines (AAP) gallery in 1965 and the Luz Gallery in 1969.

He won the first and grand prize for his Contemplation in the painting category of the AAP Annual Art Competition in 1966, and best lithograph for his Playtime in 1967. His Visions of Rapture also won second and the grand prize in the Philippine Association of Printmaker’s annual competition of 1968. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya

MARTINEZ, RAMON (Ramon Lazaro Martinez) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 8 Nov 1869. d. ca 1950. Sculptor, painter. Son of Francisco Martinez and Alejandra Lazaro, Ramon was educated in private schools. He finished his artistic training at the Escuela de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado in 1898. Later to specialize in sculpture, he also excelled in painting such that his Coming from the Market won a bronze medal at the Universal Exposition held in Saint Louis, Missouri, in 1904. His Rustic Idyll, painted in 1903, was in the National Museum prior to World War II.

Martinez did several important public sculpture commissions—namely, the Grito de Balintawak (Cry of Balintawak), 1911, originally situated at the Clover Leaf Bridge, Caloocan City, going to North Expressway. This sculpture showing a brawny figure of AndresBonifacio holding up his bolo and the Katipunan banner is now situated in front of the Vinzons Hall, University of the Philippines Diliman Campus. To Martinez is attributed the two allegorical group sculptures that once graced the two entrances of the Jones Bridge. These figural groups now flank the main door of the Court of Appeals Hall along Maria Orosa St. Martinez also provided the ornamental sculpturing of the Legislative Building prior to World War II. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

MASFERRE, EDUARDO (Eduardo Pins Masferre) b. Sagada, Mountain Province 18 Apr 1909. d. Sagada, Mountain Province 24 Jun 1995. Photographer. He was the son of Jaime Masferre and Mercedes Pins, a Kankana-ey. He married Nena Bansiong Ogues. His father was a soldier in the Spanish colonial army, who settled in Sagada after the Spanish ceded the islands to the United States in 1898 (Newton and O’Hehir 2014). Masferre spent most of his childhood in the mountains of Sagada. As a child, he studied in Spain, and later at the St. Mary’s Mission School before going to Baguio to continue his education at the Mountain Province High School, 1926-28. He began teaching at St. Mary’s in 1931 before learning and practicing photography in 1934, setting up his own studio in Bontoc. He earned money through photographing people who came to Bontoc from more remote regions, and who took trips around Sagada. It was then that he began to document the Cordillera and its people, a project he continued for two decades.

He was inspired by the shots of Dean C. Worcester in photography magazines such as National Geographic and American picture magazines like the Picture Post. When his mother died in 1935, Masferre realized the weakening of the traditions of the Filipinos who lived in the mountains in the North because of the modernization of the metropolitan centers in the lowlands (Newton and O’Hehir 2014). In 1951, his studio made only a modest profit, so he decided to stop working full-time and focus on farming oranges. His son Jaime took over his studio (Newton and O’Hehir 2014).

Although a practitioner of photography since the 1930s, Masferre’s skill in the art was not fully appreciated until late in his career, when he started showing his works to the public in the 1980s. Masferre’s 1,000 or so photographs have been exhibited in and out of the Philippines: in Manila, 1982, 1983, 1988; Copenhagen, Denmark, 1984; and Tokyo, Japan, 1986. Among his most moving works are the portraits Lakay Kabayo (Old Horse), 1950, and Woman Wearing Beads of Bistakaw Seeds, 1956. His photographs (in the form of print and postcards) have traveled the globe with tourists who visit Bontocor Sagada. His work was compiled into a book titled E. Masferre: People of the Cordillera, 1988, published by Mobil Corporation and distributed to schools, museums, and libraries in the Philippines. His work was recognized in the 1980s as an effort to rediscover Philippine culture before the Spanish colonization. In 1989, he exhibited in Les Recontres Internationals de la Photographie in Arles, France, one of the world’s most prestigious photographic exhibitions. In 1990, the Smithsonian Institution bought 120 of his original prints. They were exhibited for six months in the main rotunda of the American National Museum of Natural History, and traveled to Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, and Connecticut (de Villa 1995). In 2000, 33 of his prints were exhibited in the National Gallery of Australia (Newton and O’Hehir 2014).

Masferre is regarded as a pioneer in Philippine photography. “The power and clarity of Masferre’s photographs, the greatness of his work, lies in his feeling for and knowledge of his subject matter … the rice terraces, the planting, the weavers and potters at work, and the strong faces that meet one’s gaze with great integrity—Masferre preserved all of these in timeless images that transcend ethnography and imbue documentary with deeper meaning” (Masferre 1988).Written by Pauline Mangilog, updated by Ariel Pinzon and Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

de Villa 1995; Masferre 1988; Newton and O’Hehir 2014; Tibaldo 2015; Your One Voice 2012.

MAYO, MANOLITO (Manolito Tolentino Mayo) b. Lipa, Batangas 1954. d. Manila 1983. Painter, printmaker. He took his secondary education at the De La Salle Lipa City. He graduated from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1975. As a student, he won many awards and distinctions. One of his two sons, Michelangelo Mayo (b. 1971), exhibited with him in 1979. He taught at the Philippine Women’s University School of Fine Arts and was president of the Philippine Association of Printmakers.

Mayo intertwined his narratives of the bizarre with decorative devices such as spontaneous blotches of texture, rhythmic arrangement of texts and shapes, frame within a frame, and cropping. Adept at line drawing, he stylized his human figures into robust but graceful forms. In 1976, he produced a body of work in experimental intaglio. An example is Abakada (Syllabary), a posterlike etching with the main figure of a shaman in ethnic woven skirt and the headgear-mask of a wild boar, combined with enlarged texts and numbers and anatomical drawings of two horses. In his 1980 series of prints, he delved deeper into the subject of human fear of the unknown. He enlarged familiar objects into monstrous proportions while contracting human and animal forms to a much reduced scale.

He held several one-person shows, including Prints, 1976, at the Art Associates Gallery; Mga Recycle at Iba Pa (Recycled Things and Others), 1977, at Sining Kamalig; and Koladsining (Collage Art), 1978, at the Rear Room Gallery.

Mayo won awards from the Art AssociationofthePhilippines: first runner-up, 1976; first prize in Graphic Arts, 1976; and honorable mention, 10 Balls, 1977. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya

MEDALLA, DAVID (David Cortez Medalla) b. Singalong, Manila 23 Mar 1938. Artist, poet, art community organizer. He is the eldest of four children of parents David Medalla Sr and Juanita Angkay Cortez who migrated from Cebu to Manila. In 1949, he moved from the Ermita Catholic School to the Philippine Normal School Training Department where he finished elementary at age 11, receiving his only academic diploma. Medalla was a voracious reader and basically an autodidact, attending high schools in the University of the Philippines (UP) system via Manila and Diliman, and St. Mary’s in Sagada, Mountain Province. In 1954, UP President Vidal Tan allowed the 16-year-old Medalla, already a published poet at that time, admission to the College of Liberal Arts without a high school diploma. Not long after, his professors recommended that Medalla receive a grant from the George Jonas Foundation to attend Camp Rising Sun, an international summer camp for gifted writers in Rhinebeck, New York. In the autumn of 1954, American poet Mark van Doren enabled Medalla’s admission into Columbia University to attend classes in philosophy, modern drama, classical literature, Greek drama, as well as workshops in poetry and music. Medalla spent much of this time meeting poets and painters in Greenwich Village, including New York-based Filipino poet Jose Garcia Villa and Filipino painter Alfonso Ossorio, a close friend of Jackson Pollock. It was at this juncture that Medalla began to seriously draw and paint.

Medalla works out of Bracknell, England. His success comes as a result of over 50 years of working around, but rarely within, the established systems of European, American, and Philippine museums, art journals, and commercial galleries. He was at the forefront of the science, technology, and art wave of the 1960s (he co-founded Signals London and Signals News Bulletin), the tumultuous political movements of the 1970s (he founded Artists for Democracy and Exploding Galaxy), the anti-materialistic wave of the 1980s (he roamed Europe giving proto-art performances), and the postmodern triumph of the 1990s when anything was possible (he founded the all-inclusive London Biennale). His Kinetic and Participation Art works—particularly Cloud Canyons (aka Bubble Machines) and A Stitch in Time—pointed to alternative uses of the environment, materials, and spectators as these innovations challenged traditional understanding of art.

Medalla’s works have been exhibited in important international art fairs and exhibitions such as Live in Your Head: When Attitudes Become Form, 1969, Bern, Switzerland; Pioneers of Participation Art, 1970, Oxford, England; and Documenta 5, 1972, Kassel, Germany. After the publication of Guy Brett’s Exploding Galaxies, 1995, demand for his works took off in other major cities. These include Flux Attitudes, 1996, New Museum, New York; L’inform, 1996-97, Centre Pompidou; Live/Life: British Art Today, 1996-97, Musee de la Ville de Paris and Centro Cultural do Belem, Lisbon; Out of Actions: Between Performance and the Object, 1949-79, 1998, Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles; 2nd Johannesburg Biennale with the theme Trade Routes: History and Geography, 1998; A Fruitful Incoherence: Dialogues with Artists on Internationalism, 1998, Institute of International Visual Arts, London; Live in Your Head: Concept and Experiment in Britain 1965-75, 2000, Whitechapel Gallery, London; Force Fields: Phases of the Kinetic, 2000, Hayward Gallery London and Museu d’Art Contemporani de Barcelona; Century City, 2001, Tate Modern, London; Pulse Art, Healing and Transformation, 2003, Institute of Contemporary Art (ICA) London; Happiness: A Survival for Art and Life, 2003, Mori Art Museum, Tokyo; Art and the 60s: This Was Tomorrow, 2004, Tate Modern, London; Changing States: Contemporary Art and Ideas in an Era of Globalisation, 2004, Institute of International Visual Arts, London; Anywhere in the World – David Medalla, 2005, ICA London; Filipiniana, 2006, El Cuartel de Conde Duque, Madrid; Metropolis Rise: New Art from London, 2006, Temporary Contemporary, London; Performa: Chosen Word, 2007, Second Biennial of New Visual Art Performance; Deformes Festival of Performance Art, 2007, Chile; Documenting Live, 2008; 16th Biennale of Sydney: Revolutions – Forms That Turn, 2008; Death of the Audience, 2009, Wiener Secession, Vienna; This Could Happen to You: Ikon in the 1970s, 2010, Ikon Gallery Birmingham; Overflow, 2011, More Space Gallery, Las Vegas; and Migrations, 2012, Tate Britain, London.

Art critic Guy Brett, Artscribe contributor Brandon Taylor, Happenings historian Frank Popper, and Third Text founder-editor Rasheed Araeen have asserted that Medalla’s propositions were some of the most elegant and insightful strategies in British art.
