These longtime supporters and others have doubtless weighed in on Medalla’s subsequent presence in catalogs and biennales intent on reevaluating contemporary art history. Not surprisingly, it is among polyliterate audiences on the global stage that Medalla’s works and ideas receive warm circulation and appeal. Written by Purissima Benitez-Johannot, with notes from Rachel Mayo

Sources:

Araeen 1979; Benitez-Johannot 2012a; Brett 1995; Popper 1975.

MENDOZA, BAIDY (Maria Thybaida Rico Mendoza) b. Lingayen, Pangasinan. Sculptor. She is daughter to Maximo Viray Mendoza, a dental surgeon, and Eugenia Sison Rico, a teacher. She finished her secondary education at St. Joseph’s College and her bachelor of philosophy at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in Manila. As a child, Mendoza’s earliest experience in art was doll making, using fabric as a soft sculpture to create dolls in national dress. As a student, she studied drawing under GaloB.Ocampo and watercolor painting under ArturoLuz.

Soon after college, Mendoza traveled widely. She took special studies in art and culture at the Grailville College in Loveland, Ohio, where she also did sculpture in clay and paper. Later she traveled to Europe, taking postgraduate studies in Vogelenzang, Netherlands. Then she came back to Asia to live and work for almost three years in Indonesia as a teacher of Western culture. There she studied Bahasa, the art of batik making, the wayang, and gamelan. She then moved to Malaysia and Singapore, where she held workshops for youth and women. In Singapore, she was in charge of the Philippine participation in the United Nations Festival and the Mabuhay Merdeka Orang Choklat Summit celebrating the Maphilindo.

In the late 1960s, Mendoza returned to the Philippines disappointed at not finding any clay art in the galleries. Thus she decided to focus on this. Going back to her parents’ hometown in Labrador, Pangasinan, she explored its mountains and riverbeds to find an abundance of red clay and natural silica for use in her art. Soon she completed 100 clay art pieces and opened her studio in Cubao to an appreciative audience. This was followed by her first solo exhibition held at the Manila Hilton Art Center, on the theme Two Birds of Happiness, interpreting forms of IbongAdarna (Adarna Bird) and the sarimanok (a mythical bird with a fish in its beak) in terra-cotta. Soon she exhibited with stoneware artists Jaime and Anne De Guzman, receiving positive reviews from critic AlfredoRoces. She participated in the Concurso Internacionale della Ceramica d’Arte Contemporare in Italy, and the Adelaide Art Festival in Australia, where she exhibited at the Lombard Art Gallery.

Mendoza has dedicated her life and career to teaching clay sculpture, not only in her own studio, but in various provincial workshops under the auspices of the Design Center Philippines and the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines. With the support of the Ceramic Council of the Philippines, she organized the Potters Guild with the aim of cultivating appreciation and use of clay as medium for art.

Mendoza continues to work and exhibit free forms of terra-cotta with her group called Luad (earth), which includes CharitoBitanga and Lia Tayag, and with the women artists of KASIBULAN or Kababaihan ng Sining at Bagong Sibol ng Kalayaan.

She also affiliated with the Christian Art Society of the Philippines and the Society of Philippine Sculptors. In Sep 2014, Mendoza, participated in the Department of Trade and Industry’s National Art Fair. With the help of KASIBULAN, they launched her book titled Labrador, which contains a rich narrative of the artist’s ancestry and place.Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Ghettomanila 2014; Mendoza 2009; Tobias-Papa, n.d.

MENDOZA, GODOFREDO (Godofredo Ilanan Mendoza) b. Cebu City, Cebu 14 Dec 1948. Painter. He is the son of Teofilo Mendoza Sr and Clemencia Ilanan. He is the third of the three Mendoza artist-brothers, the other two being Sofronio aka SYM and Teofilo. He excels in landscape painting, especially in watercolor. He studied for a few semesters at the University of the East College of Fine Arts. The public took notice of his art when, as a relatively unknown, he won the grand prize in the 29th Annual Art Competition of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP). His entry, a watercolor rendering of barong-barong (shanty), won over the abstract works and numerous genre and landscapes because of its technical excellence and fresh treatment of a familiar subject.

He has used monochrome to advantage, using clear but subdued browns, greens, or blues in a wide range of tones to create an art of restraint and quiet reflection. At the same time, the subtle tonal modulations add a subdued emotional mood that hints at the pain and yearning that course through the dark esteros (estuaries) and the sagging structures of the poor. In the welter of details that make up the perverse baroque of the slums, the unifying devices of monochromatic hue and linear rhythm put the diversity of elements under control. A theme that has recently emerged in his work is the contrast between the rot and slime of poverty and the healthy organic growth of trees and vegetation. From images of the urban slums, he has shifted to the rural landscape, particularly images of the native house completely integrated with its setting of lush tropical greenery. His paintings of houses capture the folk air, with hanging plants and masetera (flowerpots) all in a row. Much of his recent work is in oil on canvas.

Mendoza won the grand prize for Bahay I-Composition (House I-Composition) in the AAP competition in 1976. Written by Alice G. Guillermo

MENDOZA, JOSE (Jose Malat Mendoza) b. 1941. Sculptor. A toymaker’s son, Mendoza went on to take fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas, which enabled him to take on color separator duties in a publishing house. His sculpting practice, however, has roots in his serving as apprentice to National Artist Napoleon Abueva at the suggestion of Mendoza’s former professor, Ildefonso Marcelo. Mendoza eventually went on to finish studies in bronze casting under Prof Elden C. Tefft at the University of Kansas in 1969, after which he assisted his teacher in teaching the sculptural technique. He was at one time a member of the Board of Directors of the Society of Philippine Sculptors.

Mendoza worked with Marcelo on the carabao and tamaraw sculptures guarding Rizal Park. Mendoza’s own major achievements in sculpture are his bronze cast of the fiery, expressionist monuments of Gabriela Silang, Pio del Pilar, and Sultan Kudarat, all popular landmarks in the Makati business district. Although he is most adept at realistic rendition, he has also explored abstraction and stylized representation in various large-scale media. He also designed and executed the sculptural relief map of the Philippines and the sculptural children’s playground at the Rizal Park. Since 2001, Mendoza, has been aggressively exhibiting nonfigurative modernist work in annual solo exhibitions at the Crucible Gallery.

Mendoza won awards from the Art Associationofthe Philippines: first prize, Bisig (Arm), which he did together with Francisco Cruz and NapoleonAbueva, 1968; second prize, Kasaysayan ng Isang Lungsod (History of a City), 1971; first prize, Population Control: Economic Determination of City’s Growth, 1971; grand award, Taon-Katauhan (Year-Humankind), 1973; first prize, Baguis (Line), 1974; first prize, Pagpapanatili ng Buhay (Maintaining Life), 1976; and grand prize, Banyuhay (Metamorphosis), 1979. Mendoza was conferred the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for painting by the city of Manila in Jun 2008. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources:

Lopez 2008; Lustre 2001.

MENDOZA, PELAGIA (Pelagia Gotianquin Mendoza-Zamora) b. Pateros, Rizal 9 Jun 1867. d. 12 Mar 1939. Painter and sculptor. She was the second child in a family of five children born to Venancio Mendoza and Evarista Gotianquin. She married Crispulo Zamora, 1871-1922, on 10 Jun 1892 (Manuel 1955, 488). They had seven children and 16 grandchildren. Zamora was a silversmith and a classmate of Pelagia at the Escuela de Dibujo y Pintura. The couple established an engraving business, Crispulo Zamora and Sons Inc, in Quiapo, Manila.

Pelagia is the first known woman sculptor in the Philippines. She studied modeling under Manuel Flores (Zaragoza 1982, 374). She was the first female student to be accepted at the Escuela de Dibujo y Pintura. Mendoza was 22 years old when Lorenzo Rocha, director of the Escuela, accepted her. According to Alejandro Capitulo in his biography of Pelagia titled Women in History: Doña Pelagia Mendoza, she completed a course in painting in 1892 and another course in sculpture in 1898.

Pelagia won first prize in sculpture for a wax bust of Christopher Columbus at the Columbus Quadricentennial Art Contest held on 12 Oct 1892. Pelagia had not yet completed her course on sculpture when she won the contest. Upon winning the competition, she landed on the front page of La Ilustracion Filipina on 21 Oct 1892. It is safe to say that Pelagia’s winning the competition marks the very first time a woman artist broke into and entered this public domain of art. Pelagia’s bust of Columbus also reaped honors internationally. Pelagia also won the second prize at the Chicago Universal Exposition, 1892, for her bust of Columbus at the Quadricentennial celebrations of the explorer. This honor makes Pelagia the very first woman artist in the Philippines to have earned international recognition.

In the same year, Pelagia also won a diploma of honor for work done for the art contest celebrating the tercentenary of San Juan de la Cruz. Pelagia’s achievements as a sculptor also led to her being recognized with the Cruz de Merito Civil (Cross of Merit) by Governor-General Despujol. Pelagia was also acknowledged for her skill in painting.

When Crispulo Zamora died in 1922, it was Pelagia who took over the engraving business. Probably, the business and her many chores as wife and mother took her more and more away from her art. None of Pelagia’s works survive today, having been presumably destroyed during World War II. Despite the loss of her works, Pelagia Mendoza’s contribution to the visual arts is significant, particularly for women in the visual arts of the 19th century. She demonstrated that women could excel in the male-dominated fields of painting, sculpture, and business. Pelagia died after two months of illness at the age of 72. She was buried at the Manila North Cemetery. Written by Eloisa May P. Hernandez

Sources:

Capitulo 1951; Manuel 1955b, 1970; Pilar 1975, 1994; Sta. Maria and Pilar 1998; Torres 1975, 1981; Zaragosa 1982.

MENDOZA, SOFRONIO (Sofronio Ylanan Mendoza) aka SYM. b. Putat Bagong Bayan, Cebu City 11 Mar 1936. He is the eldest son of Teofilo Mendoza and Clemencia Ylanan. He is married to Elena Villanueva, with whom he has six children. SYM studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas, 1963-65, and the University of the East, 1965-68. He also took private lessons with Martino Abellana at Carcar. In 1968, SYM became the co-founder of the Dimasalang Group of artists along with Emilio Aguilar Cruz, Andres Cristobal Cruz, Elias Laxa, Romulo Galicano, Jaime de Guzman, and Ibarra de la Rosa. SYM headed the Dimasalang II group, consisting of Godofredo Mendoza, Vicente Larosa, Ernesto Villanueva, and Carlos Cadid, in 1974, and the Dimasalang III group of Filipino-Canadians based in Vancouver, British Columbia, in 2004. He is also a member of the Federation of Canadian Artists.

SYM’s earliest works harked to an academic realist style of portraiture that was engendered by his first artistic mentor Abellana. Upon moving to Manila in 1962, SYM took up an impressionist palette similar to his contemporaries’ works in Mabini, but also learned modern abstract composition from mentors like Florencio Concepcion. His works from 1968 to 1994 utilized impressionistic and academic realist techniques focusing on heritage scenes, urban landscapes, and wharf scenes. Since 1995 he has employed futurist and Cubist techniques for his nudes, landscapes, and, in particular, still lifes as a means of combining his interest in modernist styles with his subject matter.

His first solo exhibition, SYM, was held at the National Library in 1969. He has since held numerous solo and group exhibitions in Manila, Canada (where he migrated in 1981), and the USA. SYM won first prize at the Shell National Students Art Competition in 1967 and a special award at the Philippine National Bank 60th Anniversary Art Competition. He received the Golden Heart Award from the Philippine Centennial Movement, British Columbia Chapter, in 1998; the Transforming Art Award from Simon Fraser University in 2004; and the Garbo sa Sugbo Award from the Cebu City government in 2010. Written by Reuben R. Cañete

Sources:

NCCA 2010; Roces and Gillis 2010.

MERCADO, CONRADO (Conrado Camacho Mercado) b. Bulacan 20 Oct 1945. Sculptor. Born to Conrado Sr, a civil engineer, and Concepcion Camacho, a former schoolteacher, Mercado is the youngest of three sons. After graduating with a fine arts degree from the University of Santo Tomas, he worked as art director for a local advertising firm until he decided to pursue a full-time career in art.

In the 1970s, Mercado did a series of sculptures consisting of aluminum doors with small and barred arched windows from which a Christlike figure seemed to look out. In the context of the times, they seemed to be making a subtle comment on the lack of freedom in the martial law period.

His recent works with figures trapped within an open-cage structure of metal rods repeat, although in a different form, the theme of enclosing, if not imprisonment. For his more recent sculpture, he no longer uses solid metal planes but instead uses structural rods which he creates by welding, bending, and twisting into single figures and open-cage constructions. These bring out linear design rather than volumetric form in sculpture defined by lines interacting within a circumscribed space. Generally, there is the impression of figures, human or animal, such as horses and giraffes, entrapped in a web or struggling in barred enclosures. In the open-cage constructions, the numerous thin rods that form both figures and their setting and that come into different angles of interactive relationship create a wiry tension, as well as lively three-dimensional play between the sculptural medium and inner and outer space.

Mercado has exhibited his works in solo and group shows both locally and internationally. He is acknowledged for founding the Philippine Association of Figure Artists in 1988. He helped revive the Society of Philippine Sculptors, for which he served as president from 1993 to 1998. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Source:

Mercado, n.d.

MIRANDA, IRINEO b. San Fernando, Pampanga 15 Dec 1896. d. 21 Mar 1964. Painter, illustrator. He finished a fine arts degree in painting at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1916. He worked at the Bureau of Printing, 1915, as assistant illustrator; at the Pacific Commercial Company, 1917, doing labels and advertisements; and at the Brown and Roosedel Advertising Company, 1920-21. In 1918, he was appointed to the faculty of the UP School of Fine Arts and taught decorative painting, cartooning, and commercial design until his retirement in 1916. He illustrated for Liwayway and El Debate and did the first cover of Graphic magazine.

Considered dean of Philippine illustrators then, Miranda learned his techniques from FernandoAmorsolo. He produced a considerable body of works both as a painter in oil and watercolor and as illustrator. His most popular work today as a painter is Maguindanao Princess, actually the portrait of Sen Santanina Rasul. This shows the artist as a superb representationalist, masterfully employing light and shadow to dramatize the dignity and beauty of the sitter, at the same time suggesting the details of her costume in impressionistic sweeps reminiscent of Amorsolo. Miranda used the same approach in his illustrations; characterization and local color were always established, but all these appear impressionistic or concisely captured due to his mastery of technique. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

MODESTO, FERNANDO aka Mode. b. Quezon City 22 May 1953. Painter, printmaker. He married Eleanor San Jose with whom he has two children. Modesto graduated with a bachelor of fine arts degree from the University of Santo Tomas. His solo exhibitions, staged in the Philippines and abroad, include Xerox Prints, Shop Six Kamalig, 1974; Bananas, Shop Six, 1975; Erotic and Non-Erotic Drawings, CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP) Main Gallery (now also known as Bulwagang Juan Luna), 1975; Trumpo-Trumpo Drawings (Top-Top Drawings), Rear Room Gallery, 1975; Private Drawings: 1973-1974, Arkari Galleries, Tokyo, 1976; Works on Paper Bags, CCP Museum Hallway, 1979; Drawings: 1972-1976, Gallery R-16, Stockholm, Sweden; The Sensuous Eye, CCP, 1987; The Mystical Planet of Modest, Hiraya Gallery, 2006; and Manipulation of History, Ayala Museum, 2007. Modesto lived for several years in Indonesia and participated in Contemporary Art of the Non-Aligned Countries, 1995, Gallery National, Jakarta; and the CP Biennial, 2003, Jakarta. Among his other international exhibitions are ARX ’87, Australia; Philippine Printmakers, Royal Festival Hall, London, England; Contemporary Asian Art, Fukuoka Museum, Japan; Kunsan International Modern Art Exhibition, Republic of Korea; VII Biennal International del Arte de Valparaiso, Chile; and the Third Asian Art Show, Fukuoka Museum, Japan. In 2014, Modesto had an exhibit titled Anonymous at the West Gallery, which featured both old and new paintings and collages, most of which were created after he had a mild stroke in 2010.

In the 1987 Sensuous Eye exhibition catalogue, Modesto’s work is described as “surrealistic renderings of genitalia armed with wit and humor, his works at once titillated and embarrassed the bourgeoisie.” Art critic Cid Reyes, on the other hand, asserts that “his one abiding quality has been irreverence, but irreverence laced with zaniness and hilarity.”

Modesto won first prize from the ArtAssociationofthe Philippines for his print Galaxy Three in 1980. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CCP in 1974. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources:

Kulay Diwa Gallery, n.d.a; Modesto 2015; Philstar.com 2014c.

MONON, SALINTA b. Bansalan, Davao del Sur 12 Dec 1920. d. 4 Jun 2009. Textile weaver. Her father was Datu Bansalan Barra. Her husband was Agton Monon with whom she had six children. Belonging to the Tagabawa Bagobo indigenous community, Monon learned the process of inabal weaving tradition from her mother starting at the age of 12. Together with her younger sister, Monon created handwoven tube skirts that are traditionally worn by the Bagobo. Due to her excellent weaving skills, her husband paid her parents a higher bride price. Later on when her husband died, she managed their farm and took care of her six children. Her income from weaving supplemented the family income.

Using the ikat weaving process, Monon began with the stripping of the abaca plant to get at the fiber strands. These were then dried and tied by hand for the dye resist process. The dyed strands were then tied to a bamboo frame, at which point the design could be defined. Monon did her weaving from home, isolating herself during this process to ensure concentration on her work. She held a solid reputation for the quality of her textiles along with the intricate designs that she created, which could be traced back to at least a hundred years (Tacio 2009). She is said to have favored the binuwaya (crocodile), one of the hardest designs to make in the Bagobo repertoire. Monon’s work in the collection of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts exemplifies the exemplar of binuwaya designs with hexagons encasing the crocodile motif at the center, x’s forming rhombuses on one side, and the binaglay or stripe motif (Respicio 2003, 61).

Until the 1950s, the tradition was still flourishing as wild abaca was still abundant in the area. Later on, the Bagobo weavers had to plant their own abaca fields to supply the demand for their own fabric weaving. In recent years, traditional Bagobo dress was only worn on special occasions, rather than in everyday life. Before the advent of cheap machine-made fabrics sold in the market, the common types of Bagobo tube skirts were called the sinukla and bandira. In comparison, Monon’s traditional Bagobo woven cloth, measuring 3.5 m x 42 cm in length, took three to four months to finish, at a rate of one abaca tube skirt per month. Monon taught the younger women in her community the value of diligence, perseverance, and discipline as necessary attitudes of a good weaver.

To honor her commitment to preserving the Bagobo textile weaving tradition, Monon was awarded the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA in 1998. Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Maricris Jan Tobias and Rizzi Gorospe

Sources:

GAMABA Committee, n.d.; Respicio 2003; Tacio 2009; Tobias, n.d.

MONTELIBANO, MANNY (Mariano Gemora Montelibano III) b. Bacolod City 6 Dec 1971. Multimedia installation artist and filmmaker. He is the son of Emilio A. Montelibano Sr and Marietta Gemora. His brother Emilio “Junjun” Montelibano Jr is also a painter and filmmaker. Manny Montelibano graduated as an economics major in the University of St. La Salle in Bacolod City and received training from the Negros Summer Workshops led by Peque Gallaga.

As an installation artist, he often works with video and sound. Montelibano’s installation work tackles the psychology of current social, political, economic, and religious structures. While heavily dependent on technology, Montelibano also questions how images and sounds that circulate through mass media have been enabled by these technologies which privilege speed and spread of transmission. The artist draws upon media techniques to deliver commentary by manipulating the videos and sounds via repetitions, pauses, effects, zooming, and unexpected juxtapositions. In this way, he drastically changes the presentation of political and popular culture video and sound materials often presented as “reality” to viewers.

Montelibano began exhibiting in 2002 at the 7th Visayan Visual Arts Exhibit and Conference (VIVA EXCON) and 17th MINDWORKS (performance art festival) held in the University of the Philippines Visayas, Cebu City. He has since worked with Peque Gallaga, Charlie Co, Dennis Ascalon, and Paul Pfeiffer. An early installation work was Po Asa, shown in Gallery Orange, Bacolod City, in 2008. The following year, he had a solo exhibition in Galleria Duemila called Escabeche: Filipino Sweet and Sour. He has had two shows at NOVA Gallery in Makati, Greater Than or Equal to Infinity, 2010, and Sorry for the Inconvenience, 2011. The latter was also part of Visual Pond’s End Frame Video Art Project 3 series. His contribution to the project KM1: What Remains, What Disappears in 2012 was Pinoy Fortress, a site-specific installation that involved multichannel video and sculptures installed in Intramuros. His work Ma’am Said, 2006, was part of the Ateneo Art Gallery’s inaugural collection of video art, launched in 2012.

Montelibano has exhibited in the National Museum of the Filipino People, Cultural Center of the Philippines, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, Ayala Museum, Fort Santiago-Intramuros, Negros Museum, Museo Iloilo, Visayas Islands Visual Arts Exhibit and Conference, Museo Negrense de La Salle, Vargas Museum, Ateneo Art Gallery, Galleria Duemila, Picasso Boutique Hotel, NOVA Gallery, Singapore Art Museum, and Seoul Citizen Hall. He has also participated in exhibitions in Korea, Hong Kong, Spain, Germany, New Zealand, Canada, and France.

Montelibano is active in promoting artistic activities in his hometown Bacolod City. He was part of the mass communication faculty of the University of St. La Salle and continues to be involved in the institution’s Culture and Arts program as a committee member and artistic director for the Production Support Group. He is affiliated with Black Artists in Asia Association Inc, Gallery Orange, Crossing Negros Cultural Foundation Inc, Bacollywood Organization Inc, and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) Committee on Visual Arts. He is founder of Bacollywood: The Visayan Film Festival supported by the NCCA and Produksyon Tramontina Inc, a Negros-based collective that produces original works on film, stage, as well as in music and the visual arts. Montelibano received recognition in filmmaking as director for the 3rd Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival entry Ligaw Liham (Lost Letters). He has also done work in theater. Written by Iris S. De Ocampo

MONTEMAYOR, FERDINAND (Ferdinand Balaguer Montemayor) aka Ferdie Montemayor. b. Tarlac 7 Dec 1965. Painter. Montemayor is the son of Jose Gaspar Montemayor and Resurrección Guamos Balaguer. He earned a bachelor of fine arts degree, major in painting, from the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, in 1990. He is a member of the painting collective Grupong Salingpusa.

Painting primarily in expressionistic styles, Montemayor is known for early works done in the 1990s of town and cityscapes and their attendant notions of sense of place and belonging under religious, national, and global rubrics, as well as the instabilities or changes brought about by forces such as urban migration and discourses of development. Another thematic that appears later on in Montemayor’s work during the early 2000s is that of competitive sports or games. These deal with the drives to compete, strive, and emerge victorious, as well as the attendant energies and tensions born of these struggles.

Montemayor mounted his eponymous first solo exhibition in 1993 at West Gallery in Mandaluyong. In 1994, he mounted the shows Bayan (Country) and Bahay (House) in Boston Gallery and West Gallery, respectively, and followed these with a triple-venue show titled Bayang Magiliw (Beloved Country), 1995, hosted by West, Finale, and Liongoren galleries, which were all based in Megamall in Mandaluyong. Among his other exhibitions in the 1990s were Bayanbayanan (Playing at Being a Country), 1996, West Gallery, and Sa May Bayan (In the Country), 1998, Finale Art Gallery. Montemayor has mounted numerous solo exhibitions such as One Day, Isang Bayan (One Day, A Country), 2001, West Gallery; Lupa (Land), 2002, West Gallery; Messages, 2003; Drawings, 2004, Big & Small Art Co.; and Banwa (Homeland), 2005, Boston Gallery. In 2007, Montemayor mounted Bagong Araw (New Day) at Boston Gallery. His 23rd solo exhibition titled Race, 2013, Boston Gallery, marked over 25 years of his practice. In 2014, Montemayor’s Game was exhibited at Pinto Art Museum in Antipolo.

After graduating from UP, Montemayor received an honorable mention in the Metrobank Foundation National Painting Competition in 1991, winning the grand prize in the same competition in 1992. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1994 and the award for Most Outstanding Visual Artist of Antipolo in 1995. In 2004, Montemayor received the Metrobank Foundation’s Award for Continuing Excellence and Services. Written by Antares Bartolome

Source:

Montemayor, n.d.a, n.d.b.

MONTI, FRANCESCO (Francesco Riccardo Clementi Monti) b. Cremona, Italy 6 Sep 1888. d. San Juan, Metro Manila 11 Aug 1958. Sculptor and teacher. He was the son of Alessandro Monti and Angela Clementi. He came from a family of sculptors known primarily for funerary and architectural works. In 1905, he completed a four-year program at the School of Design of the Academy of Fine Arts in Brera, Milan, where he gained strong classical training and studied ancient statuaries and works by Renaissance masters. His personal style shows strong influences from Art Nouveau and later Art Deco, which were current in Europe then. Monti worked with the traditional materials and techniques of carved marble and cast bronze. His commissioned works were mostly funerary sculptures for the rising middle class and monuments commemorating World War I heroes in Cremona and neighboring cities in Northern Italy.

Monti left Cremona in 1929 after his short-lived victory in a monument project was taken away from him. He traveled to San Remo, then to Nice, and then to New York. It was there that he met Filipino architect Juan Arellano who was sent to the United States to study theater design under Thomas Lamb. By Oct 1930, Monti had already reached Manila and had begun his many collaborations with Juan Arellano, who was then principal architect at the Bureau of Pubic Works. Their collaborations include the Metropolitan Theater, 1931; the Tayabas Capitol, 1935; the Negros Municipal Plaza; and the former Iloilo City Hall, 1936. At this time, Monti’s work shifted in terms of material from primarily being of marble and bronze to using more concrete cast as this was locally accessible. His style also leaned toward the more simplified Art Deco, which complemented the buildings that Arellano had designed.

Monti settled in Manila and, in 1930, was joined by his wife Antonia Giovanna Adrianna Chiappa and two of three daughters, Liliana and Sandra. Their eldest daughter Angiola was left to the care of relatives. Between 1932-33, Monti worked with Guillermo Tolentino on the execution of the latter’s winning entry for the Bonifacio Monument. They were also assisted by Anastacio Caedo and Conrado de Leon, who later founded the House of Precast. Monti made his last visit to Italy with Tolentino in 1933 for the final casting of the Bonifacio monument figures.

Between 1935 and 1937, he also accepted commissions in Hong Kong for the Hong Kong Shanghai Bank and the Repulse Bay Hotel. In 1938, he collaborated with architect Pablo Antonio for the Preventorium, now known as the White Cross Children’s Home in San Juan. They worked together on the sculptural elements consisting of concrete cast figures of playing children.

Monti also produced portraits of prominent personalities, among them President Manuel Quezon and his wife Aurora, President Manuel Roxas, Eulogio “Amang” Rodriguez, and Cardinal Rufino Santos.

Monti and his family lived in the interment camp at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) during the war. After World War II, Monti’s projects were mostly for private clients including schools and churches. He produced sculptures, such as Pieta and Virgin Mary with Angels, both in 1947, for two Manila chapels of the former Funeraria Paz Building, 1947, designed by architect Otillo Arellano. He made a second cast of the Pieta for another church project, Our Lady of Sorrows, 1948, designed by architect Arsenio Topacio. In 1949, he completed four large-scale concrete bas-relief panels for the lobby of the Far Eastern University Administrative Building designed by architect Pablo Antonio. These panels depict scenes in Philippine history.

He accepted a teaching post at the UST College of Architecture and Fine Arts and was the first to teach courses on sculpture. His students include J. Elizalde Navarro, Virginia Ty-Navarro, Leonardo Hidalgo, Leon Pacunayen, and Ting Ping Lay. From 1949 to 1953, he executed 15 large-scale concrete cast figures at the top of the UST Main Building depicting the three virtues of faith, hope, and charity, as well as Western philosophers, writers, and thinkers. Later projects include the Santo Domingo Church, Quezon City, 1954, with architect Jose Zaragoza; Sta. Maria Church, Iloilo City, 1957; the Espiritu Santo Church and Parochial School, Tayuman, 1957; and Don Bosco Institute, Mandaluyong, 1957.

Monti’s most ambitious project was the 1953 Philippine International Fair, which he took on in collaboration with architect Otillo Arellano. For this they executed several large-scale concrete cast free-standing figures including Filipinas and the Four Freedoms; five multi-figure tableaux as allegorical representations of local industries, music, and the arts. Of these, only the Filipinas has remained intact while the Four Freedoms was broken in pieces.

He was conferred the Papal Order of Saint Gregory the Great on 17 Aug 1958. Written by Ma. Victoria T. Herrera

MORENO, PITOY (Jose Reyes Moreno) b. Gagalangin, Tondo, Manila 25 Feb 1930. Fashion designer. He is the son of Feliciana Barrientos Reyes and Jose Brodett Moreno. Poet and playwright Virginia Moreno is his sister. He studied fine arts at theUniversity of the Philippines (UP), where he earned his bachelor’s degree in 1951. He is the founding president of thePhilippine Couture Association—the very first association of fashion designers inManila.

Moreno is credited with reviving interest in the Maria Clara using the traditional gown as inspiration. Moreno’s gowns may be considered emblematic of the 1950s and 1960s fashion. In stark contrast to the stiffness of his silhouettes, Moreno created intricate beading, fringe, appliqués, or embroideries, generously placed across the chest, hip, and along the train, to accentuate the curves of the high-society women he handpicked as his models and muses such as Pearlie Arcache, Bambi Harper, Joji Felix Velarde, Maita Gomez, and Tony Parsons. Moreno has dressed up prominent names in both local and international politics and entertainment, such as American First Ladies Betty Ford and Pat Nixon on their visits to the Philippines, Queens Sirikit of Thailand, Margaretta of Bulgaria, Sophia of Greece, Princesses Margaret of Britain, and Suga of Japan. He also designed the gown that Hollywood legend Rita Moreno wore when she won the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress for West Side Story in 1962. However, Moreno was not limited to custom creations for upper-class clientele. He was also commissioned to design costumes for the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company.

His work has been exhibited at the World’s Fairs inSeattle, Washington,andNew York City, as well as photographed for international publications such asVogue, Harper’s Bazaar,Holiday, andLe Figaro. He published two books,Kasalan (Wedding), 1990, written by Dudu Ulepwith photography by Ricardo Baldovino, and Philippine Costume, 1995, produced and edited by Marian Pastor Roces, photographs by Ricardo Baldovino.

In 2004, the Cultural Center of the Philippines paid tribute to Moreno with a fund-raiser for young artiststitled Ginintuang Moreno or Golden Years of the Art and Life of Pitoy Moreno. In 2006, Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo chose him to parade his designs at the ASEAN Summit Gala dinner for the ASEAN heads of state. He received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 2008. In the same year the University of the Philippines Alumni Association gave Moreno a Lifetime Achievement Award. Written by Alice A. Sarmiento

Sources: Chiong 2010; Francisco 2011; Gomez 2012; Logarta 2004.

MUÑOZ, MICHAEL J.M. (Michael Mogan Muñoz) b. Cainta, Rizal 1 Jun 1973. Intermedia artist and exhibition designer. His parents are Isabelo Umando Muñoz and Clarita Mogan. He studied painting at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1993. He was part of the erstwhile collective and artist-run space Surrounded by Water.

Michael Muñoz is recognized for his paintings and installations that incorporate religious imagery and texts from the Roman Catholic tradition. Muñoz’s exposition of the canon is exemplified by his use of Latin excerpts and titles for his works; the appropriation of iconic images by Renaissance and Baroque painters; and his thorough research on biblical narratives and official releases from the church. He combines figurative painting with the materials and methods of carpentry and weaving, as well as machine-fabricated glass and lights, digital etchings on wood, and found objects. Framed as contemporary art, his works are votive and philosophical expressions exploring theology and the origins of the church. Ichthus (Jesus Christ God Son Savior / Fish), 2009, is a text-based plasterwork pieced together by dovetail joint. The sturdy construction alludes to the foundation of the Church. Casting a silhouette of the Greek characters from the light box, the work evokes the confluence of Western and Eastern traditions.

Muñoz’s works attempt to circumvent religious controversies such as those that deal with intolerance and the predominance of materialist philosophy, and social rifts resulting from the collision of scientific and sacred truths. Contemporary in form, his approach to these long-held issues is often didactic. His work titled Caput Adami (Adam’s Head), 2010, is a longitudinal installation of plaster skulls foregrounding a backlit cross. By introducing a religious symbol in an archaeological display, the work juxtaposes Darwin’s theory of evolution with the story of creation as revealed by biblical texts. The aforementioned examples seem to convey a stark departure from his early works that explored secular themes—particularly, socialist propaganda in images, as well as subject matter drawn from social realism. Regardless of form, the artist’s body of works intimates his inclination to probe the work of ideological structures in shaping consciousness and constructing histories.

The artist’s works for the exhibition Cognitio Cristo (To Know Christ), 2014, depict the four apostles Mark, Matthew, Luke, and John who chronicled Christ’s revelation through the gospel accounts. Following classical religious iconography, Muñoz poses the seamlessly cut out image of the animal symbolizing the evangelist as negative counterpoint to each of the sleek portraits. Preceding this inquiry on evangelization is Provincia Philippinensis (Philippine Province), 2012, an exhibition consisting of six assemblages that recasts the process of conversion from the perspective of religious orders that evangelized the Philippines. The aforementioned exhibits proceed from a series of exhibitions begun in 2010 that would lead to a sustained reflection on Christianity; among these are Deus Historiae (God of History), 2010; Christiadum (Saga of Christ), 2011; and Aetas Martyrum (Age of Martyrs), 2012.

Among the exhibition design projects Muñoz undertook were those done for the Museo ng Kalinangang Pilipino in 2003 and Manila Contemporary in 2008. In 2005, he co-founded with Mitzi Icasiano the Manlilikha Artisans’ Support Network, an organization that promotes indigenous traditions through research and exhibition projects. Muñoz was conferred the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2012. Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

Sources: Granumsinapis 2015; Muñoz, n.d.

MUTUC, EDUARDO (Eduardo Tubig Mutuc) b. Apalit, Pampanga 12 Oct 1949. Silversmith. His parents are Jose Mutuc and Natividad Tubig. He is married to Leticia A. Mutuc and they have five children. His son Eduardo Jr also learned the process of pukpuk (hand hammering).

Initially a farmer, Mutuc was 29 years old when he became a wood-carving apprentice to Carlos Quiros who made furniture in Pampanga (Pangilinan 2015). His initial motive was to supplement his income from tilling the land to feed his family. After six years of making furniture, a colleague taught him the process of silver plating, which was often used to emulate gold and silver leaf in the decoration of saints and religious screens found in colonial churches. The objects produced through this process serve primarily as ornaments for ecclesiastical purposes.

For Mutuc, the process of metalwork called pukpuk or pinukpuk (to hammer) begins with a detailed drawing of the design which is then transferred unto a block of wood by chiseling. After covering the wood with a metal sheet, the artist carefully hammers the surface of the metal using a mallet and an old rubber slipper to transpose the design in wood. The metal sheet is then dipped in molten silver, then worked over through additional hammering and polishing.

Mutuc has been commissioned to create retablos, mirrors, candelabras, altars for churches, and karosa (religious floats). One of his first works is a tabernacle for the parish in Fairview, Quezon City, commissioned by Mons Fidelis Limcauco. While he bases his designs on traditional religious art from the Spanish colonial period, Mutuc also infuses his own design ideas into his projects. To avoid unnecessary cost overruns that come with revisions, the artist considers the size of the project. Some of his works have measured up to 40 ft, featuring fine and detailed craftsmanship. For example, Mutuc is known to use different molds for cherubs to give each figure a unique character. He is also fond of using the design motif commonly called callado, which depicts intertwined leaves and flowers embossed on silver-plated yellow brass (Pangilinan 2015).

Mutuc was awarded the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA in 2004. Mutuc’s residence and workshop is located in Apalit, Pampanga, a province subjected to flooding from the nearby Apalit River, resulting in damages to his woodblocks. He teaches youngsters in the neighborhood the process of silversmithing. Written by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Maricris Jan Tobias and Rizzi Gorospe

Sources: GAMABA Committee, n.d.; Pangilinan 2015; Tobias, n.d.

NAGKAKAISANG PROGRESIBONG ARTISTA AT ARKITEKTO (NPAA) An art organization officially founded in 1971, NPAA was initially made up of artists and architects who were members of the national democratic youth group Kabataang Makabayan. The organization was amalgamating from as early as 1969, as students from across various universities were motivated to political action by the writings of the Communist Party of the Philippines chairman Jose Maria Sison. Art and architecture students and professionals from various universities like the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, Far Eastern University, FEATI University, Ateneo de Manila University, University of the East, and University of Santo Tomas, came together to push for social realist and protest art. Although the group’s members were already participating in the student movement prior to the establishment of NPAA, its creation allowed them to focus on the role of art and culture in society and the revolution.

NPAA’s works included social realist paintings, murals, newspaper publications, and editorial cartoons depicting the mass struggle against imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism. NPAA also created placards, murals, and other materials used in demonstrations and protests. The students of the UP College of Fine Arts published the newspaper Spoliarium, which circulated mainly within the UP Diliman campus. As part of the Konsehong Tagapag-ugnay ng Rebolusyunaryong Sining or KONTRES, the group participated in the exhibit Sining ng Bayan (People’s Art), converting Plaza Miranda to a people’s art gallery. They also worked with theater groups, like Samahang Demokratikong Kabataan (SDK) and Gintong Silahis, in the staging of performances during rallies in Plaza Miranda.

The original NPAA headquarters was located in Kamuning Road, Quezon City. It was raided and subsequently vacated after the declaration of martial law in 1972. Despite their cameras and other equipment being confiscated, the group continued to operate and protest against the Marcos dictatorship. They endured the persecution, garnering even more members, until at least 1975.

During a speech delivered at the UP Sunken Garden by then defense minister Juan Ponce Enrile, the Reserve Officers’ Training Corps Green Beret Company conducted a sitting strike while NPAA unrolled a large manila paper mural down from the library rooftop depicting the struggle of the masses against the dictatorship.

A problem with leadership eventually led to the disbanding of the organization. However, some members continued their work in the underground and regional circles. NPAA is one of the earliest, if not the first, social realist art group in the Philippines. It served as a precursor to similar groups such as Lingkod Sining and Kaisahan. Written byKelly P. Ramos

Sources: Flores 2013; Guillermo 2001b; Palaganas 2015.

article_title: National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) (See ARCHITECTURE volume.)
text: National Commission for Culture and the Arts (See architecture volume.)

NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE PHILIPPINESThe National Museum was founded in Manila in 1901 during the American colonial period and was formerly called the Insular Museum of Ethnology, National History and Commerce. Now located near the Intramuros complex, the National Museum is mandated to preserve, conserve,and protect the country’s material heritage, movable and immovable cultural properties, and engage in research dissemination and museum education programs pertinent to its collections. It also administers the different museum system offices around the country.

The neoclassical buildings (restored after World War II) that now house the National Museum collections were part ofthe American architect Daniel Burnham ’s urban plan for Manila, encompassing the fields of fine arts, archaeology, ethnography, and biology. The building complex includes the National Art Gallery, which houses the Philippine Fine Arts collection (formerly the Senate Building); the Museum of the Filipino People (formerly Finance Building), which displays the diversity of the Philippine ethnological material culture; the Planetarium, which is thescience and technology museum of the country; and the Museum of Natural History (the retrofitted Agriculture, later Department of Tourism Building), which will house the natural science collection. As a whole, the National Museum collections stand as tangible evidence of the depth and wealth of the material culture of the Philippines.

The National Art Gallery is located in thehistoric building that housed the Philippine Senate and the House of Representatives and the 1934 Constitutional Convention. Highlights of the permanent exhibit at Hall of Masters include 19th-century paintings such as Juan Luna ’s Spoliarium , 1884, and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo’s El Asesinato del Gobernador Fernando Bustamante y su Hijo (The Assassination of Governor Fernando Bustamante and Son), late 19th century. Both are painted in the academic style and signify the political conditions during the late Spanish colonial period. Other works in the gallery consist of representative works of artists from the Spanish colonial period, the American occupation, and post-World War II period. These artists include Fabian de la Rosa, Fernando Amorsolo, Jorge Pineda, and Irineo Miranda, who painted in styles ranging from the academic, romantic, to impressionist. Early modernist works consist of pieces from the likes of Victorio Edades, Diosdado Lorenzo, Vicente Manansala, Carlos V. Francisco, Hernando R. Ocampo, Cesar Legaspi, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, Ang Kiukok, Jose Joya, Fernando Zobel, and Mauro Malang Santos. The museum’s sculpture collection consists of several 17th-19th century carved religious objects, reliefs, polychromes, and an altarpiece from the Church of San Nicolas de Tolentino in Dimiao, Bohol. The sculptures of Guillermo Tolentino, Isabelo Tampinco, Graciano Nepomuceno, and Jose Rizal are also part of the sculpture collection.

The Museum of the Filipino People exhibits the archaeological and ethnographic collection of the National Museum in the former Finance Building. The narrative of this collection traces the lineage of the country’s prehistorical and precolonial provenance through recovered artifacts, documentation of former and extant practices, and selected pieces from the museum archives. The archaeological collections include the Manunggul jar,890-710 BC,a late Neolithic period jar used in burial rituals signifying an ancient worldview of the afterlife; the Tabon cave skullcap, 14500 BC, considered one of the country’s earliest human remains excavated in Palawan; and representative text in the ancient system of writing called the baybayin script. The artifactsrecovered from the San Diego galleon that sank in 1600 near Fortune Island, Batangas, makes up a major part of the permanent exhibition. The ethnographic collection highlights the different cultural practices of Filipino people groups based on the character of the country’s geography and social relationships articulated through diverse economic systems, lifeways, religious worldviews, language, and everyday material culture. These include examples of culturally significant objects from Northern and Southern Philippines in the form of textiles, carvings, metalcraft, and examples of traditional houses. Written by Clod Krister Marlan V. Yambao and Cecilia S. De La Paz

Sources

National Museum of the Philippines.2015. Official Website of the National Museum of the Philippines. Accessed 12 Dec. www.nationalmuseum.gov. ph/.

Villalon, Augusto. 2013. “DOT Building to Be Transformed into Museum of Natural History.” Inquirer.net, 21 Jan. http://lifestyle. inquirer.net/86273/dot-building-to-be-transformed-into- museum-of-natural-history.

NAVARRO, J. ELIZALDE (Jeremias Elizalde Navarro) b. San Jose, Antique 22 May 1924. d. 10 Jun 1999. Painter, sculptor, National Artist. He was the son of Emiliano Navarro and Paz Elizalde. He married artist Virginia Ty. He graduated with a bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1951, and pursued advanced studies at the Art Students League in New York, USA, in 1953. He also did special studies in story and commercial illustrations. A versatile artist, being both painter and sculptor, he taught art at UST and at Randwick University in Sydney, Australia. He held his first one-person show at the PhilippineArtGallery in 1954. He represented the Philippines at the Sao Paulo Biennial, Brazil, in 1969 and 1971.

As a sculptor, Navarro introduced masks in contemporary Philippine design by carving a series in hardwoods. His masks call to mind archaic deities. They merge the human with the animal, transcending gender definitions and going beyond the familiar gamut of human emotions to the alien and strange. In his linear sculpture using rods and pipes, he emphasized the interaction of figure and space. Echo features two rows of upright rods ending in open circles; the idea of the echo arising from the serial repetition of the circles suggests open mouths or channels of sound.

Navarro was among the first contemporary artists who did assemblages of found objects and metal parts in a variety of forms to create freestanding works. As a painter, he has done abstract and figurative works in oil and watercolor. His abstracts spontaneously combine geometric elements in strong, vivid hues. He did a series of figurative works drawing inspiration from Balinese art and culture.

Navarro was also a prolific writer particularly in his later years when he turned to poetry and art criticism. Serving as art editor of UST’s Varsitarian from 1949 to 1951, and producing criticism for broadsheets, his alma mater UST sought to honor this aspect of his work by establishing the annual JEN National Workshop in Criticism on the Arts and Humanities beginning in 2008.

Navarro won first prize in the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines for Baguio in the second watercolor exhibition in 1952. He was conferred the National Artist Award of the Philippines for visual arts in 1999. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez and Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources: Altro Mondo, n.d.; Emanila 1999.

NAVARRO, OSCAR (Oscar Capulong Navarro) b. Ermita, Manila 24 Aug 1921. d. 22 Dec 1973. Painter. He was the son of Feliciano Navarro and Hipolita Capulong. He belonged to the batch of students at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts whose studies were interrupted by the outbreak of World War II. Most of his classmates perished in the Bataan Death March. After the war, in 1948, he established his shop in Ermita. Navarro was the most disciplined and most acclaimed disciple of the classical tradition. Unlike most of the affiliates of the Amorsolo school who opened art galleries in the Mabini area, he consistently produced works of high quality, even in the small landscapes he sold to tourists and middle-class consumers in his shop.

Navarro’s skills as a realist in the old academic tradition are evident in Semaphore, Intramuros, 1939, which exhibits masterly drawing and full modulation of colors. Although he naturally took up subjects similar to Amorsolo’s, he consciously strove to evolve a coloring unique to his works. Greens and browns appear often in his landscapes; he eschewed Amorsolo’s yellow, orange, and pink tones. He deliberately avoided painting the proverbial brilliant tropical sunlight and strove for his own identity in art. He also excelled in aerial perspective. His canvases depicting scenes in the medical profession show his mastery of complex compositions.

Navarro received numerous prizes in various art contests and exhibitions. In the conservative painting category of the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines annual exhibition, he won honorable mention for Two Forces, 1951; first prize for Early Risers, 1954; and first prize for Sidewalk Vendors, 1955. Trader’s Boat garnered the Calendar Prize and a third prize in 1951; San Juan River, best prize, 1959. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

NAVARROZA, WAWI (Cherry Mae Cinco Navarroza) b. Manila 4 Aug 1979. Photographer, multidisciplinary artist, and curator. She is the daughter of Efren Navarroza and Edita Cinco. Her grandfather, Cristituto Roa Navarroza Sr, was a professional photographer. She graduated with a bachelor’s degree in communication arts in 2002 from De La Salle University, where she was mentored by Dr Judy Freya Sibayan. She pursued continuing education at the International Center of Photography in New York, with support from the Asian Cultural Council and was given a scholarship in the Instituto Europeo di Design, Madrid, where she completed the program European Master of Fine Art Photography (Master Fotografia de Autor). She came under the tutelage of Antoine d’Agata through a scholarship from the Angkor Photography Festival in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Navarroza also does installation art, and works as a commercial photographer, doing editorial work and commercial commissions. She is the singer of the post-punk band The Late Isabel.

The range of images in her photographs includes fictional scenes, installations, fabricated still lifes, landscapes, and self-portraits. The substance of her earlier work included personal poetry, such as in Polysaccharide: The Dollhouse Drama, 2005, and Saturnine: A Collection of Portraits, Creatures, Glass, and Shadow, 2007, and mythologies of personalities such as in her self-portraits as Frida Kahlo in 100 Años Entre Nosotros / 100 Years Between Us, 2008, which was commissioned by the Instituto Cervantes de Manila. Navarroza’s initially highly dramatic, stylized, and wistfully introspective tenor appears to have shifted to more concentrated examinations of a broader state of affairs, recently in relation to questions of power and the environment. One particular example is her series on the nature of landscapes, the photographic medium, visual culture, and contemporary society. This is demonstrated in Ultramar, her portfolio project at Instituto Europeo di Design, Madrid. She exhibited Ultramar Part 1 Falling into Place Gathered Throng in 2012 and continued the series with Ultramar Part 2: Hunt and Gather, Terraria, 2013. The latter consisted of photographs of terraria made from material collected through a public call made out to Metro Manila residents to participate in foraging around the metropolis for a project dubbed Project Terraria. Both Ultramar exhibitions were done in Silverlens Galleries, an art space that also represents Navarroza.

Navarroza has participated in the following international exhibitions: Verso Manila: Contemporary Art from the Philippines, 2009, in Turin, Italy; the annual touring exhibition CUT: New Photography from SouthEast Asia organized by VWFA Kuala Lumpur, 2010; ASEAN-Korea “Emerging Wave” Asian Contemporary Photography Exhibition, 2010, in Seoul, Korea; the Asian Art Biennale, 2011, in Taichung, Taiwan; and the 2012 Tokyo Month of Photography presented by the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Photography. Her work has also been shown in the National Museum of the Philippines; Metropolitan Museum of Manila; Mongolian National Modern Art Gallery; Hangaram Museum, Korea; and Fries Museum of Contemporary Art, Netherlands. Photography festivals in which her pieces have appeared include the Angkor Photography Festival in Cambodia, Noorderlicht Photography Festival in the Netherlands, and Photo Ireland in Ireland.

Navarroza received the Ateneo Art Award for Polysaccharide: The Dollhouse Drama, 2005, and Saturnine: A Collection of Portraits, Creatures, Glass, and Shadow, 2007; Prix de la Photographie Paris, 2009; Portfolio Preis, Germany, 2010; International Photography Awards, 2010; Lumi Photographic Art Awards, Helsinki, 2011; and the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Awards, 2012. Written byIris S. De Ocampo

NEO-ANGONO ARTISTS COLLECTIVE Established by a core group of cultural workers hailing from different fields in 2004, Neo-Angono is composed of visual artists, writers, musicians, theater workers, filmmakers, critics, and researchers. Conceived as both a movement and an organization, Neo-Angono aims to produce art that invigorates and responds to contemporary Angono experience, sensibility, and consciousness. A nonprofit, artist-centered entity that is committed to experimentation and collaboration, it also seeks to keenly respond to the many forms of creative expression that emerge from and develop within the community.

Neo-Angono recognizes the significance of research and education in the arts, and has periodically given free seminars and workshops on the visual arts, including painting, sculpture, glass etching, and silkscreen printing as well as poetry, theater, and music to young people. One of the major activities of the group is its eponymous annual public art festival, during which poetry readings, concerts, film screenings, and works of performance and installation art are offered up for the participation and enjoyment of people, locals and tourists alike. The installation and performance pieces tend to revolve around significant social issues, such as human-rights violations and extrajudicial killings, or questions of history and nation.

In 2007, the National Press Club (NPC) commissioned Neo-Angono to produce a mural on press freedom. NPC later drew the artists’ and public ire for altering what the collective had submitted without permission, allegedly because of pressure from the Presidential Security Group (PSG). Members of the PSG had dropped by the NPC office a day before the painting was to be formally unveiled—a ceremony to which President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo had been invited—and had supposedly objected to “leftist marks” in the work, which contained a number of references to controversies under the Arroyo administration, including the disappearance of activist Jonas Burgos and the NBN-ZTE scandal. The NPC had then apparently tried to get the Neo-Angono to change the mural, but, as the members of the collective were not available, hired an unnamed artist to make the necessary revisions. This act was widely condemned as violative of the right to freedom of expression and the law on intellectual property.

Neo-Angono is headed by Ian Lomongo. Previous officers and board directors include the collective’s pioneers: Ramon “Chitoy” Zapata, Wire Rommel Tuazon, Carlos “Totong” Francisco II, Kyo Zapanta, Cherryl M. Villaflores, Keiye Miranda-Tuazon, Richard Gappi, Lomongo, Arturo Sanchez, Philip Anorico, Allan Alcantara, Peter Natividad, Isidro Santos, Neliza de Leon, and Rem Vocalan. The advisers of the group are artists Nemesio Miranda Jr, Jose Tence Ruiz, Mideo Cruz, and Iggy Rodriguez, art critic Alice Guillermo, and poet-musician Jesus Manuel “Jess” Santiago.

Most of the members of the collective live and work in Angono, Rizal, which has produced two National Artists—namely, Carlos “Botong” Francisco (visual arts) and Lucio San Pedro (music). This is primarily the reason Angono has been called the art capital of the Philippines. Written byJaime Oscar Salazar

Sources: Burgonio 2007; Neo-Angono 2007, n.d.a, n.d.b.

NEPOMUCENO, GRACIANO b. Trozo, Binondo 18 Dec 1881. d. 30 Dec 1974. Sculptor, painter. He apprenticed under Ciriaco Arevalo and EugenioLlerena, famous sculptors at the turn of the century. He also studied painting under MiguelZaragoza at Liceo Filipino.

He was commissioned to do relief decorations for the ceiling of Malacañan Palace and for the facade of the MetropolitanTheater. He also did a number of religious sculptures, among them the figure of San Francisco in the Quiapo Church and the figures of the fallen Christ and the Roman soldiers in the Tercera Caida of the Potencianos in Biñan, Laguna. One of Nepomuceno’s famous works is Jose Rizal, a bust done in bronze relief. He also did realistic polychrome figures of peasant types, such as a woman holding a clay pot and a gray-haired man proudly holding a rooster, their stances natural and the details of their costume meticulously depicted. Animal subjects also fascinated Nepomuceno. One of his secular sculptures portrays a man grappling with and subduing a crocodile, a genre work recalling 19th-century accounts of hunters fighting crocodiles teeming in the swamps, as in Paul de la Gironiere’s adventures. Another piece shows a female nude fighting a snake which has curled around her leg. Another genre work is that of a boy playing sipa (traditional game that requires kicking and balancing the rattan ball on his ankle). Nepomuceno also created tableau-reliefs, which were transpositions of paintings into relief, as in his relief carving of JuanLuna’s Spoliarium and of Leonardo da Vinci’s Last Supper. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

NEPOMUCENO, MARCELO b. Santa Cruz, Manila 4 Sep 1871. d. 7 Sep 1922. Sculptor. Both his father Pedro Nepomuceno and his grandfather were wood-carvers. He married Faustina Mijares with whom he had 10 children. He was a member of the Centro de Escultores, Manila. His subjects were influenced by his reading of such books as Joseph Feuhrich’s Triunfo de la Religion de Jesucristo (Triumph of the Religion of Christ), 1865, and Felix Torres Amat’s Spanish translation of the Vulgate, La Sagrada Familia (The Holy Family), 1883-84, both of which had copious engravings.

Nepomuceno carved figures of saints, which were the order of the times. However, his Espiritu y Material (Spirit and Matter), a sculptural piece that depicted a priest embracing a nude girl, drew protests from the religious orders of Manila. During the American regime, his other work, 13 de Agosto (August 13), was presented to the Saint Louis Exposition in 1904 but was again rejected. The figure of a Filipino woman brandishing a bolo against a lion and an eagle was too reminiscent of the two struggles of the Filipino people for freedom. Nepomuceno also designed and constructed floats such as the El Ultimo Adios (The Last Farewell), which won a silver medal in 1906, and the El Triunfo del Patriotism Sobre la Muerte (The Triumph of Patriotism over Death), which won a gold medal in 1907. Written byE. Arsenio Manuel

NEW, LEEROY (Jan Leeroy Chua New) aka Leeroy. b. General Santos City 2 Feb 1986. Sculptor, multimedia artist, and designer. He is the son of Carmel Chua and Ang Luan New Jr. He studied at the Philippine High School for the Arts in Mount Makiling, Laguna, in 1999-2003 and finished his bachelor of fine arts in studio arts, major in sculpture, at the University of the Philippines in 2007. Trained in three-dimensional work, New fabricates visual and tactile elements and enables representation through the introduction and appropriation of different fictional characters fleshed out from mythologies, science fiction, popular culture, and local worldviews. His manipulation of materials creates installations and built environments that employ an experiential sense of playful strangeness and conjured imaginations and fantasies.

Balete, 2009, exhibited at the Ateneo Art Gallery, is a visual reinterpretation of the balete or banyan tree of Philippine mythology. It is an interactive installation that was crawling, hanging, and towering biomorphically in its monumental scale on the exterior of the building structure of the gallery. Balete used materials like orange flexible conduits coiled together, with the surface of each tube tied and locked with white cable ties. The white cable ties were tediously installed all throughout the installation, creating an impression of unwelcoming prickly fur that was rough and itchy when touched. The work was spatially parasitic as the art was reliant on and disruptive of existing structural elements on-site.

New’s Chimera series is a science fiction version of the ancient mythological hybrid monster. It consists of round fiber-reinforced plastic shaped into an odd spaceship-like alien insect with many legs and one large eye. New created the eye and body of the chimera through the traditional technique of metalwork called pukpok (beat), a manual process of beating metal sheets to create designs and ornamentation. Chimera imposingly greeted visitors of the 4th Fukuoka Asian Art Triennale, 2009, as it was installed at the exhibit entrance area.

According to New, he projects his infantile creative imagination upon his works. These impulses shape the playful, incomprehensible creatures and adventurous spatial environments which are site-specific and engaging to publics activated through the artist’s different modes of reinventing and reshaping of form. New has also served as set designer for productions done at Casa San Miguel, Zambales, and works by Sipat Lawin Ensemble and Dulaang UP.

New was awarded the Ateneo Art Award in 2009 and the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2012. Written byClod Marlan Krister Yambao

NUYDA, JUSTINIANO (Justiniano Suntay Nuyda) aka Tiny. b. Albay 29 Sep 1944. Painter. He is the son of Herinel Nuyda, a writer, and Evelyn Suntay, an Olympic swimmer. He finished with a degree of bachelor of fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas in 1965. He received two study grants to France in 1971 and 1974. Nuyda is also a recognized lepidopterist and is presently chairperson of the Insect Society of the Philippines.

Nuyda staged his first one-person show in 1965 at the Manila YMCA Exhibition Hall. Then already involved in the study of butterflies, his paintings were inspired by the design patterns in the wings of the said insect. Blown up into abstraction, these were called Mindscapes by the artist. Nuyda’s art is essentially surrealistic in sensibility, and most of his shows and paintings were titled Search. Held at the Solidaridad Galleries in 1967, the Search series depict light-defined geometric shapes floating in space or solidly anchored, or surrounded or veiled by mists of colors. Sometimes the geometric shapes meet or interlock to form walls or to open to corridors with glowing effects of light suggesting depth.

Nuyda won two awards from the Art AssociationofthePhilippines: second honorable mention, Search 39, 1967, and second prize, Search, 1969. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines in 1972. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

OCAMPO, GALO B. b. Santa Rita, Pampanga 16 Oct 1913. d. Virginia, USA 12 Sep 1985. Painter. He studied at the University of the Philippines and holds the distinction of being the only Filipino to study heraldry abroad and to hold membership in the International Institute of Genealogy and Heraldry in Madrid. During World War II, he did intelligence work for the guerrilla movement and became a captain. As his cover, he did stage backdrops for the Associated Artists group headed by FernandoPoeSr. In the 1960s, during the administration of President Diosdado Macapagal, Ocampo served as curator of the Presidential Museum of Malacañan and, subsequently, as director of the National Museum and technical adviser on heraldry in the president’s office. During this time he also taught art at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) and at the Far Eastern University, where he became head of the Department of Fine Arts in 1971.

Ocampo staged the revolt against academic conservatism in the 1930s together with Victorio Edades and CarlosV.Francisco. The triumvirate launched a crusade to stimulate artistic development along modernist lines. In 1934, they created murals—early works in interaction—for the lobbies of the Capitol and State Theaters, which expressed their new artistic credo and the rising nationalist consciousness at the height of the Commonwealth era.

Ocampo soon developed his own artistic personality. A key painting of the period was his BrownMadonna, 1938, which indigenized the image of the Virgin Mary. Moro Dancer and Igorot Dance were celebrations of indigenous culture in lively colors and designs. These paintings are characterized by a modernist sense of design, linear rhythms, and fresh colors.

In the 1950s Ocampo’s art was haunted with images of the war he had just lived through. The flagellant theme, fully brought out in Ecce Homo (Behold the Man), arises from harrowing experiences of the war. Christ, crowned with thorns and hooded with the flagellant’s veil, stands with arms bound together, while in the skies, warplanes zoom, trailing smoke or releasing a fleet of parachutists. In Shades of Things to Come, 1955, a flagellant lies prostrate, his arms forming a cross on the ground, while shadows of airplanes are reflected on the sand. These paintings in brown tones convey the feeling of the modern wasteland, littered with the debris of war.

The flagellant theme would undergo a significant stylistic change in the mid-1950s with the large painting Christ in Flagellant. Here the entire space is filled up with figures, including that of a hooded Christ on the cross. The receding space in previous works is now replaced by a vigorous design sectioned as in stained glass.

The artist was sent to Rome in 1956 by the archbishop of Manila to train for the work of designing stained glass for the ManilaCathedral. For the cathedral he did the seals of different archbishops of Manila and various images and attributes of the Virgin Mary in the country. He also did the designs for the stained-glass windows of SantoDomingoChurch in Quezon City, and the sarimanok (a mythical bird with a fish in its beak) for the Philamlife Building.

It was only in 1973, at the age of 59 and after his years in government service, that Ocampo held his first one-person show at Galerie Bleue. For this exhibit he produced a new series titled Anthropographic Designs, in which he paid tribute to the Tabon man. His fieldwork with Robert Fox in Palawan inspired him with images of the early Filipino: Adam and Eve growing from the ancient stalagmites and reflecting the ever-changing hues of the mysterious caves.

His 1982 retrospective at the Museum of Philippine Art brought out all his themes, although the “flagellants” had shifted from their original somber mood to a more positive tone—the hooded figure of Ecce Homo now sits on a space missile in a lunar landscape. He expanded the ethnic theme to include the Ati-Atihan where masked figures cavort in gaudy revelry. In 2013, the exhibit Mysteries and Colors: Galo Ocampo was held at the UST Museum to celebrate his birth centenary.

Ocampo won awards from the Art AssociationofthePhilippines: second prize, Pounding Rice, 1951; honorable mention Igorot Dance, 1951; special award, Weary Traveller, 1951; and the first Rotary Golden Anniversary Award, Bayanihan, 1955. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1964. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

OCAMPO, HERNANDO (Hernando Ruiz Ocampo) aka H.R. Ocampo. b. Santa Cruz, Manila 28 Apr 1911. d. Caloocan City 28 Dec 1978. National Artist for visual arts. He was the son of Emilio Ocampo and Delfina Ruiz. He married Irene Illovato in 1932, but she died in 1945. His second wife was Cresenda Valenzuela. Painter Karen Ocampo Flores is his granddaughter. In 1931, he started working at the Philippine Education Company. In 1935, he worked as executive secretary of the National Paper Mills Inc. After the war, he worked in the script department of Palaris Feler and FernandoPoe Productions.

He began as a writer in English. He was one of the organizers of the Veronicans, a young writers’ group that included FranciscoArcellana, Estrella Alfon, N.V.M. Gonzalez, Manuel Viray, and Angel G. de Jesus, among others. His house at Maypajo, Caloocan, served as a frequent venue for their meetings. As a Tagalog fictionist, he is known for his prizewinning Bakya (Wooden Slippers) and Rice and Bullets, both showing a consciousness of the proletariat. During the Japanese occupation, Ocampo turned to writing in Tagalog and wrote plays for the stage, becoming the chief scriptwriter and assistant director of the Associated Artists. The Japanese also appointed him censor for the stage and for the Taliba newspaper, at the same time that he had an intelligence assignment as second lieutenant in Straughn’s Guerrillas.

He also became editor of the Manila Sunday Chronicle Magazine. He was producer-director of the FilipinoPlayers Guild, which specialized in radio programs, 1950-53. He became executive director and senior vice president of Philprom, 1958-68.

Together with CarlosV.Francisco, GaloB.Ocampo, and other modern artists, he was a member of the Thirteen Moderns founded in 1938. With VicenteManansala and CesarLegaspi, he formed the triumvirate of Neo-Realists. He was also a leading member of the Saturday group of artists which met regularly at the Taza de Oro.

Ocampo identified the several stages in the development of his art: 1929-34, Amorsolo period; 1934-45, proletarian period; 1945-63, transitional period; 1963-68, mutants period; and 1968-78, visual melody period. Since FernandoAmorsolo was the dominant artistic influence in the 1930s, most artists who began painting before the war, including Ocampo, emulated Amorsolo, although unsuccessfully, as Ocampo did not take formal studies in the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts where the maestro was based, preferring to pursue art on his own.

Ocampo’s proletarian period reflected the debate in the 1930s between “proletarian art” and “art for art’s sake,” which was also an issue in the United States at the time. It was during this period that World War II broke out, resulting in widespread dislocation, hunger, and misery. Under such conditions, his paintings showed the stark realities of the time, such as the painting of an emaciated man staring at an empty plate with high-rise buildings in the background to imply the wide class gap of the period. Another was the painting titled Calvary, 1948, which showed the triple crucifixion of Christ flanked by two thieves against the background of factories spewing smoke. In the same period, his triptych Tatlong Larawan (Three Pictures) also developed the religious theme. These paintings, while still largely figurative, were not in a realist style but were rather expressionist in their distortion and their use of garish colors.

His transitional period, 1945-63, was a period of intense creativity in painting. His works from this period became more stylized and showed an increasing tendency to abstraction in their primary concern for design, color, and texture. Some of his more complex and highly textured paintings, such as Fiesta, are of this period. It was also during this time that the PhilippineArtGallery (PAG) opened its doors to modernist painters and Ocampo, Legaspi, and Manansala made the PAG their second home.

Most of his paintings of the 1960s belong to his mutants period. He derived inspiration from The Beginning of the End, a science-fiction fantasy film on the mutants and strange forms spewed forth by nuclear explosions. The painting Dancing Mutants, for instance, shows fingerlike shapes with a nervous, quivering quality. Toward the end of the 1960s, he developed into the visual melody period in which he brought back tonalities into his abstract designs of organic shapes, creating a richer form of abstraction. An example of this style is Genesis, 1969, which was executed into a tapestry for the main theater of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Its central motif is a bright flame which casts oscillating shadows and reflections on the surrounding design of red and yellow elements. Ocampo himself said that the work represented “the full flowering” of his visual melody period. It also represented the final maturation of the abstract style of the artist in painting the search for the Filipino spirit.

His got awards from the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines: sixth prize, Nude with Candle and Flower, 1948; first prize, Arabesque, 1950; second prize, Man and Carabao, 1950; first prize and special award, Ancestors, 1951; honorable mention, Intramuros, 1951; third prize, Fifty-Three E, 1954; honorable mention, Fifty-Four A, 1955; second prize and purchase prize, Nativity, 1958; and first prize, Circe, 1969. He won third prize for Angel’s Kiss in the 1949 Manila Club art exhibition. He also received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award, 1969, and the Diwa ng Lahi Award, 1976, both from the city of Manila. In 1979, he was awarded the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. The book H.R. Ocampo: The Artist as Filipino written by Angel de Jesus was published by the Heritage Art Center, also in 1979. In 1991, he was proclaimed National Artist for visual arts. In 2013, Ayala Museum exhibited Ocampo’s 51 artworks coming from various collections for the show The Real H.R. Ocampo Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source: Tanchanco 2013.

OCAMPO, YUANMOR’O (Juanito Marquez Ocampo) b. Santa Ana, Manila 24 Jun 1957. Multimedia and performance artist. He is the son of Candido Ocampo and Loreta Marquez. He finished his elementary education at Don Bosco Technical Institute in 1970, his high school at St. Paul’s Seminary in 1974. He took up fine arts at the University of the Philippines. From 1984 to 1986, he studied mask making at the Art Institute of Indonesia in Yogyakarta, becoming the first Filipino artist to be granted a scholarship from the Dharmasiswa Republik Indonesia. Ocampo taught art at De La Salle University, 1977-79, and at the Ateneo de Manila, 1988-89. In 1999, Ocampo with gallerist Jamima Pajati, established the Philippine International Performance Art Festival. Ocampo was executive director of Lingap Sining, an association of Filipino artists, and was also an executive council member of the Visual Arts Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

Although his early works were canvas oriented, Ocampo became absorbed in multimedia and installation works that sought to recreate the precolonial roots of Philippine art found in textiles, animistic ritual offerings and practices.

In 1992, Ocampo mounted Sutra (Fiber Works) at the Pasilyo VictorioEdades, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), a transmedia activity-exhibition giving evidence of the typical wit, philosophical depth, and inexhaustible inventiveness of the artist.
