The fiber used in this show was raw silk as expelled by the silkworm, presented in black-painted multi-celled boxes.

He staged Mongo-Mongo in Jakarta in 1985 and Dunia Satua Jazz (The Jazzy World of Animals) in the same city in 1986. Among his other performances in Manila are I’m Sure Glad That This Rubber Tree Is Not the Withering Rubber Tree, Selamatan (Thanksgiving), HoNoCoRoKo (Javanese Alphabet), Kuda-Mangsa (Fighting Horse), and Kuda-Kuda (Horsemen). In his later works, Ocampo explores the theme of Filipino cultural identity, marked with collaborative and participatory processes. For example, Diaspora, 2005, was a participatory piece that delved into the displacement felt by Filipino migrant workers. In 2010, Ocampo received the Dodjie Dy Award for Culture and the Arts as the “Most Outstanding Visual Artist in Isabela” where he is based as a cultural organizer. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources: Angel 2013; Hu, n.d.

O’FARRELL, GASTON (Patricio Gaston Blocquel O’Farrell) b. Paris, France 7 Sep 1879. d. 12 Jun 1942. Painter. The son of Jose O’Farrell and Marie Blocquel, he is often mistaken for a Frenchman or Irish because of his family name. His mother was a Frenchwoman and he was born in Paris. But Chinese and Filipino blood also ran in his veins because his father was a Chinese mestizo. The first O’Farrell, John Christopher, was the captain of a British merchant ship trading in Manila in the 18th century. In 1805, John married Catalina Tuason, granddaughter of Son Tua, the ancestor of the landed Tuason families of Manila. Catalina and John had a grandson, Mariano. Mariano in turn married Eugenia de Ocampo, and this couple sent their son Jose to study in Paris, where he met Marie.

Gaston took up his early education at the Colegio de la Inmaculada Concepcion and at the Colegio de San Jose de Calasanz, both in Manila. At age eight, he began his art lessons at the Escuela de Artes y Oficios in Intramuros, then studied privately under FelixMartinez. When JuanLuna came back to Manila in 1894, Gaston took further studies from him. The two developed a special liking for each other, for both could paint and practice their French together. In May 1896, the two visited Japan. During this sojourn, both executed many views of the Komagatake and Kamakura regions. It is believed that the Japan trip was made primarily to deliver a message to Jose Ramos, an activist who settled in Japan, soliciting arms for the Katipunan movement. The Katipunan was discovered upon Luna’s return from Japan followed by his arrest and imprisonment along with his brother. While Luna was away in Spain working for the pardon of his brother Antonio, Gaston studied at Ateneo de Manila where he obtained a Perito Mercantil equivalent to business management.

Gaston painted many artistically significant paintings of which several have survived. His self-portrait at age 16 and his Interior del Estudio de Juan Luna (Interior of Juan Luna’s Studio), 1895, show the maturity of his talent at an early age. At the Saint Louis Universal Exposition of 1904, his Portrait of Juan Luna received a bronze medal. At the exhibition sponsored by the Sociedad Internacional de Artistas de Manila in 1908, he received a gold medal for Portrait of Señorita X. He also received a bronze medal at the Panama-Pacific Exposition in 1915 for Umagang Tahimik (Peaceful Morning). One of his extant historical canvases is the Betrayal of the Katipunan, which shows Teodoro Patiño at the confessional. The priest was posed by the Uruguayan consul, Mr Delfino, while Patiño was posed by Gaston’s faithful messenger. Written by Santiago A. Pilar

OLAVIDES, KARLO (Karlo Bodiongan Olavides) b. Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental 19 Nov 1977. Visual and sound artist. He is the son of Ireneo L. Olavides and Nena Bodiongan. Olavides began teaching illustration and aesthetic theory courses in 2012 at the College of Saint Benilde’s School of Design and Art, under the school’s design foundations department. He is also a musician and plays the guitar, performing and recording first with Elemento in 1999, then with Pastilan Dong! in 2013. He graduated from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts, where he received his bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, in 2000. Upon graduating, he was employed by Tower Records, Philippines, where he worked both on and off the shop floor, designing graphics and handling all aspects of its retail merchandising activities, until its closure in late 2006. In 2007, he began selling used books and records from his own shop, Timbooktu on Katipunan Ave, where his literary, musical, and pop cultural interests further crystallized.

The closing of Timbooktu coincided with the beginnings of his practice as a full-time visual artist. His first solo exhibition was X & M, Green Papaya Art Projects, 2007. This was followed shortly after by Futuramanila, 2008, a group show with 22 other contemporary Filipino artists at the Osage galleries in both Singapore and Hong Kong where Olavides’s large-scale collage Agos (Flow), 2007, was exhibited.

Olavides’s professional experiences in a hybrid corporate entity like Tower Records and as an independent retailer are evident in recurring themes in his work. As an artist, he makes use of multiple forms of print and audiovisual media through various modes of collage, sampling audio, video, and print materials; recontextualizing the homogenous agenda of global media outlets to make them fit contemporary Filipino realities. His tendency to bombard his audience through musical and visual experiments captures the tensions between the monotony and subjectivity of modern life, where cultural expression is conscripted into furthering movement along the various channels of neoliberal capitalism. By framing the static and noise of everyday existence, placing these in quadrants or cutting these into verse, Olavides attempts to make sense of a widely accepted deluge of sameness, laying bare this imposed standardization, and opening it to critique and conceptualization. Olavides is a visual artist whose works present a critical view of contemporary pop culture even as it betrays a fixation with its media and materials.

Olavides’s short film Pagbangon sa Katapusan (Rise at the End, 2012) was shown at the 11th Sharjah Biennale in 2013. He was selected as one of the CCP Thirteen Artists for 2012 and was among the Metro Manila winners of the Philippine Art Awards in 2014. Written byAlice Sarmiento

OLAZO, JONATHAN (Jonathan Tria Olazo) b. Manila 25 Dec 1969. Painter, printmaker, and curator. He is the son of painter and printmaker Romulo Olazo and Patricia Tria. He is married to Lyn Yusi. He received his bachelor’s degree in fine arts, major in painting, from the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts, 1992. He serves as an instructor at the UP College of Fine Arts while pursuing a master’s degree in fine arts.

Olazo grew up in a home that doubled as a printmaking studio called 101 Workshop. It was in this space that artists like his father, Roberto Chabet, Fernando Modesto, Illeana Lee, and Nonon Padilla would pull prints, with the young Olazo as spectator, even occasional salingpusa (hanger-on/kibitzer). Despite his having spent his formative years around artists and the daily making of art, it was only in his junior year in high school at Jose Abad Memorial School that his interest was undeniably piqued. It was about the same time when his father taught printmaking at the same school. It was the senior Olazo who encouraged his son to enter the Art Association of the Philippines annual print competition in which his work bagged the third prize in 1986. The young Olazo would go on to catch the critical attention of both artists and critics, and join his father on trips to the Thomas Jefferson Library where he saw documentaries on American abstract expressionist painters like Willem de Kooning and Franz Kline. It was within a minimalist strain of abstraction that Olazo found an eventual fit, albeit with a lot of leeway for experimentation and personal nuance. Chabet’s influence came in the form of exposure to modern tendencies as well as a shared keenness toward taking on different media, methods of manipulating materials, and playing with form. Olazo’s art practice eventually broadened in scope to include paintings, prints, and installations.

As seen in a particular generation of Chabet’s students, Olazo’s paintings are characteristically highly textured and come with impastoed surfaces. The tactile and graphic nature of his works alludes to a highly gestured process that subtly brings imagery to the fore. However, the enabling of form makes up only a fraction of his motivations. For Olazo, the artistic process is intimated with his spirituality, ideologies, and an engaged and constant dialogue with his own and other artists’ bodies of work. His exhibition Hotel Painter, 2013, questions and challenges the place of abstraction beyond the auspices of a limiting decorative bent.

Olazo continues to do solo and group exhibitions in various galleries, museums, and art spaces in Manila. He has also shown in Malaysia, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, and New York. In 1987, he participated in the 8th Biennial Internacional de Arte Valparaiso, in Valparaiso, Chile, and in the 3rd International Biennial Print Exhibit at the Taipei Fine Arts Museum.

He received the grand prize for his work in the Philippine Association of Printmakers Open Graphic Arts Competition in 1987. He received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 1994. Written byThea C. Garing

OLAZO, ROMULO (Romulo Gamez Olazo)b. Calatagan, Batangas 21 Jul 1934. d. 18 Aug 2015. Printmaker, painter. He was the son of Vivencio Olazo and Simeona Gamez. Olazo was married to Patricia Tria with whom he had three children; son Jonathan is also a visual artist. He studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas.

Olazo is associated primarily with his Diaphanous series consisting of paintings, some as large as 213.4 x 457.2 cm, which are produced through an original collograph technique that the artist developed himself. As paintings, they are made of exceedingly fine transparent screens composited as overlapping layers that create patterns of relative transparency and density. In these works, which are often in classic black-and-white, color is usually restrained to cool monochrome blues and greens, and occasional yellows. With this particular technique, he is able to achieve light ethereal effects or luminous passages that emanate from the thin films that filter the light from the surface, evoking increasing depths. The artist approaches color as objective phenomenon, although he does not exclude nor negate the subjective dimension, for such a subtle art may easily be expressive of highly nuanced states of feeling. In his explorations, Olazo has often modified the layering technique by crumpling and folding the delicate diaphanous tissues, by heightening tonal play in thin, sharp facets, and by superimposing brisk gestural strokes to stimulate the surface. The artist has a figurative side that produces elegant nudes and tonal watercolor landscapes.

His first solo show was held at the Luz Gallery. In 1974, he held his solo show at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). In 2008, Olazo’s solo exhibition AZOOL consisting of the artist’s variably tinged blueworks was awarded the Museum Director’s Choice of the Year and shown at the Artist Space, Ayala Museum. In 2009, Ayala Museum with Paseo Gallery organized Romulo Olazo: A 40-Year Retrospective. In 2012, Olazo’s 40th solo exhibition, Diaphanous by the Sea, was shown in Mactan City, Cebu. Another solo exhibition, Romulo Olazo: Black and White Redux, was held at Paseo Gallery, SM Megamall Art Center, Mandaluyong City, 2013.

Early in his career as a young artist, from 1963 to 1968, he won several awards in the annual art competitions of the Philippine Advertising Counselors, a local advertising company in Manila. In 1969, he participated for the first time in a national show, the 22nd art exhibition of the Art Association of the Philippines. In 1971, he won first prize for Sepia II, 2nd Ed, and third prize for Shame, both collagraphs in the mixed media category of the annual competition of the Philippine Association of Printmakers. He won again in 1972 the second and the third prizes in the mixed media category of the same competition. This was the same year he was named one of the CCP Thirteen Artists awardees. In Jul 1976, he won special mention at the Philippine National Bank’s 60th Anniversary Art Competition with his work Diaphanous 52. In 1979, his entry Permutation No. 2-A Book won honorable mention at the 11th International Biennial Exhibition of Prints in Tokyo. In 1980, his Transparencies and Permutations was a finalist in the Mobil Art Awards, and he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila. In 1981, Olazo was selected as one of the Five Outstanding Living Artists recognized under the Mobil Art Awards for Philippine Art, along with Cesar Legaspi, Ang Kiukok, Arturo Luz, and Napoleon Abueva. In 2013, Paseo Gallery published the book Romulo Olazo. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Source: Olazo 2013.

OLIVERIA, JAYSON (Jayson Cordero Oliveria) b. Manila 18 Jul 1973. Multimedia artist. He is the son of Danilo Oliveria and Elizabeth Cordero. His formal art education consists of painting units earned at the Philippine Women’s University and the University of the Philippines Diliman College of Fine Arts, 1992.

Oliveria’s body of work is made up of oil paintings, mixed media collages, sculpture, and installations. Culling texts and images both from the virtual and the tangible, Oliveria takes what is seemingly an overwhelming pile of material and repurposes these for imaginatively new configurations. The bits and pieces that make up the elements of his work come from the everyday, from books, magazines, even the dizzying goldmine that is the world wide web. His approach does not come from an intrinsically value-laden nor ideologically driven academic bent. Rather, he reframes the images and uses them to create visual puns and provocative annotations that sting nonetheless. His image-making is sometimes jarring, while others are judiciously composed. This ability to travel back and forth between the categorical and the liminal underlies Oliveria’s unpredictability, counterposed to a palpably committed temperament and a sense of awareness especially about the conditions and contexts influencing the enterprise of art and how the artist figures in the art world.

Oliveria has shown extensively through solo and group exhibitions in a variety of art spaces in Manila from galleries and museums to artist-run and alternative spaces. He frequently exhibited at the now-defunct Mag:net Galleries and was part of the artists’ collective that ran Surrounded by Water. In his exhibition Truth Adjustment, 2008, Mag:net Gallery, Katipunan, a series of paintings were posed as a conversation ongoing amidst a procession of tombstone plaster casts. About 50 casts coax viewers to recognize their obsession with the superfluous rhetoric that often circumvents discursive channels of meaning and significance. Also in 2008, Oliveria was one of the artists selected by Green Papaya Art Projects to participate in No Soul for Sale, a festival cum exhibition of independent art spaces and collectives from all over the world brought together as an eclectic mix of practices, projects, and programming. Set in the Turbine Hall of the Tate Modern, London, the exhibition component of the Philippine delegation was later restaged at Taksu, Singapore, as part of Philippine Art Trek IV 2010 under the title Serial Killers: From Tate Modern to TAKSU Singapore.

Oliveria is one of the artists making up the loose group Bastards of Misrepresentation, a project/collective that showed Doing Time in Filipino Time, 2010, Freies Museum, Berlin, followed by the multisited exhibition Bastards of Misrepresentation: New York Edition, 2012. Oliveria has also shown in Jakarta, Hong Kong, Beijing, Sydney, Tasmania, and Graz.

He was a part of the first batch of artists in residence under the Big Sky Mind Artists Projects Foundation in Cubao, 2003-04. This was followed by a three-week artist residency in Tetra Art Space in Fukuoka, Japan. The program was facilitated by curator Mizuki Endo. In 2012, he conducted his residency at Galerie Zimmermann Kratochwill, Graz, Austria. Oliveria was one of the three winners of the inaugural Ateneo Art Awards in 2004 for his exhibition Instinct vs. Learning, Mag:net Gallery. He received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2006. Written byThea C. Garing

OLMEDO, ONIB (Luis Velozeo Olmedo) b. 1937 d. 8 Sep 1996. Painter. He was the son of Luis Olmedo and Lourdes Velozeo. He was married to Bienvenida Rodriguez with whom he had two children. He graduated from the Mapua Institute of Technology in 1959. His first one-person show was at the Solidaridad Galleries in 1971.

Olmedo painted in the figurative expressionist style. While most of his works consist of faces of people, these are not portraits in the sense of physical likeness but are rather haunting soul portraits of humans warped and distorted by anguish and suffering, victims of social injustice as well as of their own tortured psyches. As such, they do not necessarily convey a palpable physical presence but are more like wraiths and orphans from a gray limbo. While many of the faces are universalized, without clues or props to suggest a specific context of class or occupation, there are also a large number that are evidently society’s victims, such as the sakada (seasonal cane workers), the bar girls of Mabini, and the hungry poor. His gallery of “portraits” date back to the artist’s Singkong Suka (Five Centavo Worth of Vinegar) in the 1960s with its inhabitants of the run-down corner store and cheap joints. He described his art as “imploding” into an inner universe where bodies glow from within like phosphorescent creatures in unfamiliar waters, at the same time that on a social plane they convey the sense of dehumanization and alienation.

He was gold medalist in the 1979 Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition and his Faces of Torment was one of the five finalists in the 1980 Mobil Art Awards. In 1979, he was the Philippine representative to the international competition of painters in Cagnes-sur-Mer, France, and in 1988 to the international competition of painters in Baghdad, Iraq. He received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1991. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines in 1992. Written byAlice G. Guillermo

ORLINA, RAMON (Ramon Gahol Orlina) b. Manila 27 Jan 1944. Sculptor, architect. He was born to Capt Vicente Orlina and Paulina Gahol. He is married to Lay Ann Lee with whom he has three children. He obtained a degree in architecture from the University of Santo Tomas in 1965, after which he put up the architectural firm Ramon G. Orlina and Associates. He was the president of the Society of Philippine Sculptors, 1986-88; Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), 1992-99; Philippine National Committee of the International Association of Art, UNESCO, 1992-99; and director of the Artists’ Association of the Philippines Foundation Inc, 1998-2016.

For his 1975 first one-person show, Reflections, Orlina chose glass as his medium. In 1976, he developed sculptural form using glass when the Republic Glass Corporation in Pasig, Rizal, gave him access to the cullets or slabs of residual glass for use as his raw material. Orlina developed an appropriate technology to transform these into sculpture. One of his first major works was Arcanum XIX Paradise Regained for the lobby of the Silahis International Hotel. Measuring 1.8 x 3.2 x 0.6 m, this showed an optimum use of the medium, its multifaceted green transparent blocks capturing the light like cut emeralds. This work opened the way for him to study studio glass technology in Czechoslovakia, Paris, and New York. Orlina’s work consists of glass murals and table sculptures sited within an architectural setting. While achieving harmony and integrity of form, he creates a lively interplay between transparent and translucent areas, polished, matte, and frosted surfaces, or prismatic areas and smooth planes in a dialogue between long graceful movements and straight angular definitions. One of his important local achievements is the glass altar and overall sculptural architectural design of the Greenbelt Chapel in Makati. He has done a number of public glass sculptures in several Asian countries such as Fertile Crescent in Singapore.

Among his other solo exhibitions are Preview of a Touch of Glass and A Touch of Glass, Hong Kong, 1993; Orlina in Davao, Genluna Gallery, 1995; Ramon Orlina Sculptures, Seattle, 1996; Salamin ng Kalayaan (Mirror of Freedom), George Sison Gallery, 1998; Glass in Silver, ArtSpace Glorietta, 2000; Glasscapes, Genluna Gallery, 2001; Translucent Life, Gallery Nine, 2002; Quintessence: 30th Year in Sculpture, Ayala Museum, 2006; Abstract Emeralds, Galerie Joaquin, 2007; Luminosity: The Colors of Orlina, SMU Art Gallery, Singapore, 2008; and Highlights, Art Verite Gallery, 2009.

In 1982, he won the best entry in the 35th AAP Annual Art Competition and a gold medal in the 1983 AAP photography competition. In 1985, he won the second place in the National Memorial of the Philippines Competition together with Eduardo Castrillo.

In 1993, he received the ASEAN Awards for visual arts in Brunei. In the following year, he was conferred by the ASEAN Business Forum in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with the third ASEAN Achievement Award for visual arts. He received the Dangal ng Batangas Award on the 415th Batangas Foundation Day and the “Mr. F Prize” of the Toyamura International Sculpture Biennale ’99 in Hokkaido, Japan. Orlina’s winning piece was a white optical glass sculpture called Silvery Moon. He won the first prize, sculpture category, of the II International Biennial of Basketball in the Fine Arts in Madrid with his winning work titled Basketball Mi Mundo (My World Basketball). The work introduced tubular stainless steel in his practice. In 2004, he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for sculpture from the city of Manila and was given the Outstanding Filipino Award in 2006. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Source: Orlina, n.d.

ORTIZ, RENAN (Renan Urmeneta Ortiz) b. Manila 19 Jun 1977. Visual artist and art educator. He is the son of Ranulfo Ortiz Jr and Erlinda Urmeneta of Calbayog, Samar. He studied political science at the University of the Philippines (UP) Manila, 1994-99, and fine arts, majoring in painting, at UP Diliman College of Fine Arts, 2001-5.

Ortiz expresses his activism and social advocacy through works that span various media. His installations incorporate video and audio technology to reflect on issues related to globalization and human rights. Ode to Empire, 2012, is a sound collage made from archival video and film clips, showing the rise of the United States of America as a world military superpower. Murmur, 2012, engages the phenomenon of desaparecidos—activists who have disappeared against their will due to actions by the state—by inviting viewers to listen to a poem through earphones suspended from a low ceiling. Other installations explore the use of intermedia, such as television sets and video clips, to produce commentary on the state of mass media, land reform, and poverty. Ortiz is also regularly commissioned to produce illustrations, poster designs, comics, political cartoons, and drawings for advocacy campaigns of people’s organizations. This practice is reflected in his exhibitions through works such as the mural Palabas-Papasok (Outgoing-Incoming), 2011.

Ortiz held his first solo exhibition, Sandosenang Sarap or The Lies and Farce of Iñigo Ramus and the Rivet Thieves, 2007, at the West Gallery in Quezon City. This was followed by versereverse, 2011, at the Republikha Art Gallery in Quezon City. He started joining group exhibitions in 2003, including Mga Pahina’t Kwadro Alay sa Manggagawa (Pages and Frames Dedicated to Workers), 2007, Liongoren Gallery; Seeing You, Seeing Me: Contemporary Portraits, 2009, Manila Contemporary; and About Face, 2011, Lopez Memorial Museum. He has also participated in group exhibitions in South Korea, Singapore, the USA, and Japan, including Censorship_2013 Move On Asia, Alternative Space Loop, Seoul, Korea; Triumph of Philippine Art, 2013, Montclair State University George Segal Gallery, New Jersey; and Media/Art Kitchen-Reality Distortion Field, 2014, Aomori Contemporary Art Center, Japan.

An art educator, Ortiz started teaching art appreciation and media education subjects at the Ateneo de Manila High School in 2006. Since 2008, Ortiz has taught art and visual communication at the Philippine Science High School in Quezon City. He also served as a member of the Executive Council for the National Commission for Culture and the Arts Committee on Visual Arts, 2010-13. He is a member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines and the Philippine Association of Printmakers. Ortiz received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2012. Written byLisa Ito-Tapang

Sources: Hirano 2013; Jose 2013; Ortiz 2014a, 2014b; Republikha 2014.

OTEYZA, VICTOR (Victor Sta Maria Oteyza)b. Manila 27 Jul 1913. d. United States 1979. Painter. He was the son of Mauricio Oteyza, a Filipino concert violinist in the United States and Dolores Sta Maria. He was a cousin of filmmaker Eric de Guia aka KidlatTahimik. He married Leonila Madrid and had a daughter. One of the pioneers in the Neo-Realist style, Oteyza turned to art in the mid-1930s. He finished a bachelor of science degree in engineering at the University of the Philippines and a masteral degree in physics at the Far Eastern University. Oteyza began to paint as influenced by artist friends with whom he associated with while working as engineer and head of radio and TV production for J. Walter Thompson-Manila. By 1949 he was encouraged to take up painting when his works won in several art competitions. The critic MagtanggolAsa wrote that as early as 1947, Hernando R. Ocampo and VictorOteyza were already experimenting on non-objectivism.

Oteyza is acclaimed today for his Plastic Engineering series of paintings, which he might have begun as early as 1947. The title evidently refers to Oteyza’s exploration of plastic space on canvas, filling it up with pencil-thin shapes placed in different directions and interacting with each other such that they began to suggest planes or spaces of color floating in the resulting three-dimensional space. Plastic Engineering # 13 and Untitled, both reproduced in Art in the Philippines, 1958, are outstanding examples of this particular exploration of Oteyza.

In 1965, he held a one-person show at the Galerie Bleue, showing pure abstract forms suggestive of light feathery objects and cracking surfaces. This was followed by shows at Sining Kamalig and Luz Gallery. In 1969, he migrated to the United States.

Oteyza was awarded fifth prize by the Art AssociationofthePhilippines for his Perfect State in 1949, and his work Study was cited in the First Exhibition of Non-objective Art staged at the PhilippineArtGallery. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

PABLO, SEVERINO (Severino Flavier Pablo) ca 1800-70. Painter. He married a woman named Leocadia, with whom he had a daughter, Isabel Pablo, who later married the painter Isidro Arceo. Known as Capitan Viring, Pablo lived in San Fernando de Dilao (now Paco), Manila. Among all the known painters of mature skills by the 1850s, Pablo was the most likely to have belonged to the first batch of enrollees at the Academia de Dibujo under DamianDomingo.

Pablo’s earliest signed and dated work, 1836, is the portrait Don Paterno Molo y Agustin, 1786-1835, which the painter might have started while the sitter was still alive or which he might have painted from a miniature, after the subject’s demise. This work has been adjudged as “stiff,” a term associated with “primitive” or folk portraiture, probably because it was the early work of a formally schooled painter who was still young and self-conscious. Pablo’s other known works are Don Maximo Paterno y Yamson, signed and dated, 1852, Obispo Pedro Agurto, OSA, signed and dated, 1859 (Augustinian Parish Convent Library, Cebu City); and Obispo Juan Jose Aragones, OSA (Archbishop’s Palace, Vigan, Ilocos Sur), signed but not dated. All these portraits are remarkable for the vivid depiction of the features of the sitters and the meticulous rendition of the embroidery of their garments, which show Pablo’s training as a miniaturist. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

PACQUING, BERNARDO (Bernardo Agonoy Pacquing) aka Bernie Pacquing. b. Tarlac 27 Apr 1967. Painter. He is the son of Oscar Pacquing and Marilou Agonoy. He studied editorial design at the University of the Philippines Diliman College of Fine Arts, 1984-89.

Pacquing is distinguished for his deft painterly handling of planar surfaces rendered abstractedly in their invoking of urban spaces under construction, or evincing the weathering of time and physical elements. His tightly composed pieces often consisting of scratched and/or unevenly applied pigment register as subtly raw human traces of intervention upon ground subjected to a seeming loss of control or desired spontaneity. Pacquing’s inclination toward abstract expressionism of a decidedly minimalist strain sets him apart from earlier and later generations of abstract painters given to dramatic flair and chromatic flourish. In the course of his artistic career, Pacquing’s works have ranged from the playfully enigmatic to a somewhat dark minimalism, both of which resist easy interpretation. Seemingly more random than graffiti, his works suggest a disjunction of the everyday. In his multilayered images of positive and negative spaces, backgrounds and foregrounds, half-revelations and palimpsests, meanings rife with contradiction and irony may be gathered. Yet for all their apparent opacity, his abstract works draw reference from objects as disparate as termite hills as in Earth Mounds, 2010, and internal combustion engines of Recent Works, 2011, with the latter described as both “a praise and a lamentation for the gifts of the Industrial Revolution.” In both instances, the main theme explored is human intervention in the world, presented with disconcerting effect.

He held his first exhibit, Chasms-Saltando-Coalesce, at the West Gallery in 1993. His solo exhibitions include Premise Trumps Plot, 2013, West Gallery; Potato Motion, 2011, Finale Art File; Things We Miss While Waiting, 2009, West Gallery; Making Truth Forgettable, 2008, Finale Art File; Shape Memory, 2007, Mag:net Gallery; and Dripping Weight, 2006, Finale Art File. In 2000, his exhibition Drawings was held at Vermont Studio Center, USA. Pacquing has shown in several group exhibits—notably, Bernardo Pacquing / Max Balatbat, 2014, Silverlens, Manila, 2014; Art Fair Philippines, 2013, West Gallery, Manila; Abstraction Is Homeless, 2012, Manila Contemporary; Complete and Unabridged Part 1, 2011, Institute of Contemporary Arts, Singapore; La Salle College of the Arts, 2011; I Miss the 20th Century, 2011, Manila Contemporary; Earth Mounds, 2010, Finale Art File; Alcazaren-Pacquing, 2009, Finale Art File; Etudes for More Than Two Hands, 2008, Mo_Space, Manila; and 16th Asian International Art Exhibition, 2001, Guandong Museum of Art, China.

In 1992 and 1999, Pacquing won the Grand Prize at the Art Association of the Philippines Open Art Competition in Painting, nonrepresentational category. He received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2000. That same year, he won a Freeman Foundation Fellowship grant from Vermont Studio Center, USA.

Written bySofia G. Guillermo

PACUNAYEN, LEON b. Nueva Ecija 19 Apr 1934. Painter. A graduate of the University of Santo Tomas (UST) College of Architecture and Fine Arts in 1957, he took advanced studies in painting, restoration, etching, and ceramics from 1960 to 1968 at various Italian schools—the Regge Accademia di Belle Arti, Istituto Ornamentale di San Giacomo, and Scuola Libera del Nudo. He has taught at the UST College of Architecture and Fine Arts.

Since his first show at the PhilippineArtGallery in 1959, he has held a score of solo exhibitions in Rome and other parts of Italy, in California, and the Philippines, mostly at the Luz Gallery. He participated in group exhibitions all over Italy; Philippine-Italian Art Exhibitions in Manila; shows of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), Contemporary Artist Club, Philippine Art Gallery, and Museum of Philippine Art; and international exhibitions, including the First Southeast Asian Art Competition, 1957; Chicago International Fair, 1958; First International Art Exhibition, Legione Azzura, Rome, 1962; and Troisieme and Quatrieme Biennales in Paris, France. In 2014, Pacunayen held a solo show titled Buhay Ciudad (City Life) at the Finale Art File booth, Manila Art Fair.

Most of Pacunayen’s awards were won in art competitions in Italy from 1962 to 1968. Earlier, he won first prize at the AAP-Philippine Tourist and Travel Association National Art Competition in 1959, and second prize at the AAP Excursion Art Competition in 1960. In 2014, the Philippine Embassy in Rome presented Pacunayen (along with fellow Filipino artists) an award in recognition of his contribution in promoting Filipino art and culture outside the Philippines through his works (Aguilar 2014) Updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources: Aguilar 2014; Philstar 2014d.
(See Theater volume.)

PALATIC, KAHHIMNGAN b. Banaue, Ifugao 1912. Ikat weaver. She successfully revived the ikat-weaving craft of the Cordilleras in her home village of Amganad, Banaue, Ifugao. Ikat, a dye-resist process applied upon threads before weaving the fabric on the loom, is found in the tnalak of the Tboli of South Cotabato in Mindanao. It had long vanished in the Cordilleras before anthropologist Harold Conklin found Palatic in the 1960s. With his encouragement, she resurrected the ancient ikat process, even locating the source of the organic dyes used in dyeing the threads. With the assistance of her niece Kittayan, she taught the long forgotten craft to the women in the village.

Twenty years later, Amganad became a thriving community of ikat weavers, with more than 70 members registered in the Amganad Weavers Cooperative. Kahhimngan Palatic no longer works on her loom, but the art she revitalized continues to be spun into life in the best works of the weavers of Amganad.

Palatic was honored with a Manlilikha ng Bayan award in 1990 for “the single-handed revival and community revitalization of Ifugao ikat-weaving art in the Cordilleras.”Written by Rosalinda Galang

Paras-Perez, Rodolfo aka Rod Paras-Perez. b. Manila 7 Apr 1934. d. Pasig City 30 Mar 2011. Printmaker, critic. He was the son of Atilano Perez and Anicia Paras. He graduated with a fine arts degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1957, earned a master’s degree in art history in 1962 from the University of Minnesota, USA, and a master’s degree in art criticism and a doctor of philosophy in art history, 1971, from Harvard University, USA. He received several scholarships, among them the Smith Mundt-Fulbright and the Rockefeller, and was one of the few Filipinos awarded a Harvard Traveling Fellowship. He was elected to international bodies such as the Accademia delle Arti del Disegno of the Collegio dei Professori at Florence and the Association Internationale des Critiques des Arts in Paris. He taught at the UP College of Arts and Letters and the College of Fine Arts, and was the chancellor of the ASEAN Institute of Art, which he also founded.

Paras-Perez is an award-winning graphic artist who held shows both here and abroad since his first one-person show at the Luz Gallery in 1962. He participated in the Bienal de Sao Paulo, 1965, and international exhibitions of graphic arts in Yugoslavia, Geneva, Krakow, and Florence. Among his notable works are two woodcuts: TheKiss, 1962, and Sun Moon Poles, 1964. He also did original prints to illustrate FloranteatLaura. His works indirectly influenced those of other graphic artists, like LucioMartinez, EfrenZaragoza, Rodolfo Samonte, and MarioParial.

Paras-Perez’s scholarly studies and books on Philippine artists include Castañeda, 1971; Irineo L. Miranda, 1972; GaloB.Ocampo and Romeo Tabuena, 1973; Sanso: Art Quest between Two Worlds and Tolentino, 1976; Manansala and Visions and Voices, 1980; FernandoZobel and Manansala Nudes, 1990. He did an important study on the French sculptor Rodin, published in the International Art Quarterly in 1967; a documentary called BeyondArt, 1974, on EduardoCastrillo’s sculpture; and numerous articles for various magazines and publications.

Paras-Perez’s won awards from the ArtAssociationofthe Philippines: first prize, The Kiss, 1962; second prize, Rite, 1962; first prize, Ethereal Glow, 1963; and third prize, Homage to the Cholmondelay Sisters, 1969. He was awarded a gold medal at the II Internazional della Grafica in 1969, and he received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award from the city of Manila in 1972. The Lopez Museum and Library and the Ateneo Art Gallery honored him posthumously with the exhibitions Context: Rod Paras-Perez and Illuminating Rod Paras-Perez in 2014. Written byAlice G. Guillermo and R. Chu, updated by Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez and Roberto Daniel Devela

Source:

Inquirer.net 2011a.

PARDO, JOSE (Jose Sabado Pardo) b. Bayambang, Pangasinan 18 Apr 1916. d. 2002. Painter, architect. He was the son of Enrique Pardo and Remedios Sabado. He married Gertrudes Lim with whom he had five children. He finished his elementary and high school studies at San Alberto College in Dagupan, Pangasinan. He studied architecture at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) where he also took up painting. He impressed Victorio Edades, then director of the UST School of Architecture and Fine Arts, with the bold stylization of forms. Edades then enlisted him to the core of the modernist movements, making Pardo one of the Thirteen Moderns.

Pardo specialized in urban planning as an architect. He finished a master’s degree in environmental planning at the University of the Philippines and also a one-term scholarship grant at the Massachussets Institute of Technology. Despite continuing to pursue his architectural practice, he did not put down his paintbrushes through his later years. He staged his last solo exhibition at the Manila Midtown Hotel in 1990.

Pardo’s paintings are characterized by bold wavy outlines that capture the essence of his subjects while at the same time rendering them in stylized movement. His early period, exemplified by Muslim Woman Combing Her Hair, 1943, demonstrates his energetic contours. In this piece, the undulating long hair of the woman acts as counterpoint to the curve of her body. The concise depiction of the shapes, on the other hand, suggests the elemental way of life of the subject. Fellow artist GaloOcampo in an essay in the Philippine Review, 1944, referred to this piece as “Long Hair” and praised its “planar composition and intense color scheme that make it stand out in spite of its small size.” In Pulubi (Beggar), 1952, Pardo set forth the image of a beggar with sharply drawn lines with color applied to mimic flat watercolor to approximate abstract form. In Corazon de Maria (plant called Heart of Mary), Pardo suggested a grouping of plants through his characteristically bold outline that evoked heart-shaped leaves. Pardo again picked up these plants as subject in 1989, using their leaves as a stepping-stone to a meaningful and organic abstract image. Even as he continued painting, he also later went on to do metal sculpture.

Pardo won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: third prize for Water Bearer, 1951; third prize for Pulubi, 1952; and second prize in photography for Stairway Pattern, 1953. In Apr 2003, a year after his passing, the Ateneo Art Gallery held an exhibit in memory of Pardo titled Jose S. Pardo: In Line with Modernism.Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Artbooks.ph 2012; Asia Art Archive 2003b.

PARIAL, MARIO (Mario Torres Parial) b. Gapan, Nueva Ecija 13 Aug 1944. d. 22 Dec 2013. Painter, graphic artist, sculptor. He was the son of Fidel Parial and Aurora Torres. He married Carina Claro with whom he has two children. His son Mikel is a painter and graphic artist. Parial graduated with a bachelor of fine arts from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1969. He taught printmaking and painting at the UST College of Fine Arts, 1969-83.

In prints, Parial’s subjects were of folk genre, which was the forte of his mentors Vicente Manansala, CarlosV.Francisco, and Antonio Austria. Many of his rubbercuts portrayed mother-and-child, calesa (horse-drawn rig) drivers, and mythical subjects, but marked by a lively decorative appeal and an unusual approach to the figure, with an emphasis on two-dimensional design. In painting, he developed a strong folk quality. His 1979 Moriones series is characterized by vigorous design and vivid hues. His works also have a strong sense of organic life, in which plants have spiky rhythmic shapes and intense colors. He has developed his own figurative style that brings out the expressiveness of figures, at the same time that there is a unity of the human subjects, such as female nudes, with the whole of organic life. He has pursued folk and mythological interests in his art, in which the woman figure is central whether as mother, temptress, Eve in a native paradise, or even the Virgin Mary in all her splendor.

His first one-person show was in 1965. Since then until his death in 2013, he accomplished 28 solo and 160 group exhibitions in the Philippines and abroad. In his later works, he explored the fusion of photography and painting, or painted photography, in an exhibit titled The Peripatetic Process of Parial’s Painted Photographs at the Kaida Art Gallery in Quezon City in 2009, and at the Francesca Gallery in SM Megamall in 2012. In 2015, the retrospective exhibit Mario V.A. Parial: Beyond Reality was held at the Bulwagan ng Dangal Heritage Museum of the University of the Philippines Diliman.

Parial won first prize for Flight in the Sun in the 1966 competition of the Art Association of the Philippines. He also won a prize in the 1967 Philippine Airlines art competition. His won awards in the Shell National Students Art Competition: honorable mention, The Fire Is Over, 1965; first prize, The World Has Many Faces, 1966; certificate of merit, Once upon a Construction, 1966; certificate of merit, Night Flight, 1966; and certificate of merit, Hour After Hour, 1967. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in l972. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

Sources:

Tariman 2012; Venturina-Bulanadi 2014.

PASILAN, DIOKNO (Diokno Olladas Pasilan) b. Negros Occidental 17 Aug 1963. Visual and performance artist. His parents are Rudolfo Pasilan and Marita Olladas. His younger brother Neil is also a visual artist. Pasilan has a diploma in fine arts from the Western Australia School of Art, Design, and Media.

Diokno Pasilan may be described as a pilgrim between ports, his art finely honed by his interest in locale and its relations to a wider world. Prior to settling in Perth, Australia, in 1998, he traveled the Philippine archipelago with the famed folk band Asin, designing stage backdrops for performances. Prior to migrating, he was also involved with another iconic band, Pinikpikan. Plying routes across the Asia Pacific, Pasilan mounted solo exhibitions in Perth, Manila, and Singapore. Diasporic travel and local lifeways were abiding themes in these exhibitions.

Pasilan navigates his way across various territories through the vehicle of art. This was most pronounced in Ganta, 2013, an exhibition at the University of the Philippines Jorge B. Vargas Museum. He utilized the gantangan, a wooden cube equivalent to celemin, a unit of measure widely used for grains, as metaphor and tool. Through photographs, prints, sculpture, installation, sound, and performance, his works traced the way of life of Palawan’s senior residents. His primary materials were given to weathering and effacing: rust, sand, wax, and coffee stains. His methods of making art and manner of assembling and presenting them place the themes of fortitude, resilience, presence, and loss in relief. While vast in scope and varied in form, Pasilan’s assembly of objects explore these themes eloquently. Most notable of his pieces were wall-bound back-lit portraits of senior residents framed inside wooden gantangan, connected to each other by a network of gnarled electric wires intimating the form of an aged tree rooted to earth.

For SV Locomote, a solo exhibit at The Drawing Room Gallery, Gillman Barracks, Singapore, Pasilan collects objects from his home in Ballarat, Victoria, and interweaves them with memories of growing up in Visayas Island. Central to his recollections is the boatbuilding tradition, an enterprise his family practiced during his growing-up years in Negros Occidental through their eventual move to Bacolod City. The artist plots landings on shores to voyages across seas, from his travels with the folk band Asin, to his interactions with communities in Palawan, his relocation to Australia, and his recurring visits to Manila. These acts of passage consolidate Pasilan’s diverse body of work. Moving across mediums and making art of varied forms coupled with a nuanced understanding of passage, belonging, and wandering consistently inform Pasilan’s art.

Pasilan has done solo exhibitions since 2003 in the Philippines, Australia, and Singapore. Among these were Ballarat ID, 2013, Slot Gallery, Sydney, Australia, and ID, 2011, Kurb Gallery, Perth, Western Australia. Pasilan’s pieces have also been included in group exhibitions in Hong Kong, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, Singapore, and Italy. He has participated widely in performance workshops in Australia. Ganta, his 2013 show at the UP Vargas Museum, included a performance piece and sound recording. Pasilan’s performance pieces have also been staged at the Bagasbas International Eco-Arts Festival in 2003 and 2010.Written byTessa Maria Guazon

Sources:

Asia Art Archive 2014a; Cultural Precinct 2014; Drawing Room Gallery 2014a; Snippets 2011a.

PASTOR-ROCES, MARIAN (Maria Loreto Limjoco Pastor-Roces) b. Batangas City 10 Dec 1953. Essayist, curator. She is the daughter of Juan A. Pastor Jr and Aurora Limjoco. She is married to lighting designer Cesar Roberto (Bobby) Roces with whom she has two children. A communication arts graduate from St. Theresa’s College, she has worked with the Technology and Resource Center, the National Library, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), where she was founding director of the Museo ng Kalinangang Filipino (Museum of Philippine Culture). She has also taught at the University of the Philippines (UP) and De La Salle University. She pursued a doctor’s degree in cultural research at the University of Western Sydney in Australia.

Her curatorial work include the following exhibits: Contemporary Philippine Art, 1977, the inaugural exhibition of the Museum of Philippine Art; The Olaging: An Exhibition on the Manuvu Epic, at the CCP. As part of the centennial celebration of Philippine independence, she co-curated with the Smithsonian Institution in 1998 the Festival of Philippine Folklore at the National Mall, Washington, DC. Pastor-Roces’s advocacies as curator concern Philippine folk culture and asserting the validity and agency of the ethnolinguistic groups of people and the marginalized sectors in society, who have no record of their history. This is exemplified by her work for the The Negros Museum, 1996, in Bacolod City and the Museo Puntong Batangan in Batangas City, 2006. She also curated Lumina Pandit, 2011, as part of the 400th anniversary of the University of Santo Tomas (UST). The exhibit featured rare books from the UST collection, including the 17th-century documents featuring the baybayin script. Pastor Roces was also the principal curator of the EDSA Boysen Knox Out public art project in 2012. In 2014, she curated the UP Manila’s MuseumofaHistoryofIdeas on the intellectual history of the university.

Pastor-Roces was managing editor of the CCP’s Philippine Art Supplement and was editorial board member of San Juan, an art magazine of Pinaglabanan Galleries. She has published essays on Philippine art and culture for publications here and abroad such as Kaleidoscope in Hong Kong; Philippine Airlines’ Mabuhay; Heritage; Artlink and Art and Text in Adelaide, Australia; Midwest in Auckland, New Zealand; World Book International, a children’s encyclopedia published in London; Art and Asia Pacific in Sydney, Australia; and monographs published by the CCP and other institutions. She authored the book Sinaunang Habi: Philippine Ancestral Weave, 1992, published by Nikki Coseteng, and contributed essays to Disrupted Borders and Shift: Critical Strategies, both 1993.

She founded TAO Management in 1992, which develops projects in the culture field, and Planetary Inc, which produces TV programs. She was editor for Bayani, a magazine for executives published by the Evelio B. Javier Foundation and was a consultant for cultural policy at the office of Sen Leticia Ramos-Shahani, for whom she produced and wrote for the TV program The Shahani Perspective.

She has received grants for research and writing from the Institute of Southeast Asian Studies and the United Board, a New York-based foundation, and undertaken research visits to museums and Universities in the United States, United Kingdom, and the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. She has been speaker in international conferences in Southeast Asia, Guam, New Zealand, Australia, the United States, and Barcelona, Spain. In 1993, under a Critical Theory Residency at Griffith University in Brisbane, Queensland, Australia, she gave a series of lectures at this university, including the Institute of Cultural Policy Studies. Pastor-Roces also served as member of the Committee on Social and Human Sciences, UNESCO National Commission. She received a writing fellowship from the Center for Intellectual Performance at the University of California, Los Angeles, USA, in 1999; an Asian Leaders Fellowship from Japan Foundation in 2003; and a research fellowship from the Australian National University in 2004.Written byE. R. Galang, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz and Zeny May D. Recidoro

Sources:

Batangas City, n.d.; Montalvan 2015; Negros Museum, n.d.; UP OVPAA 2014.

PASTRANA, GARY-ROSS b. 1977. Installation artist-curator. He earned a bachelor of fine arts degree, major in painting, from the College of Fine Arts, University of the Philippines Diliman, and won the Gawad Dominador Castañeda for Best Thesis, 2000.

Pastrana has established a reputation for turning out consistently understated work that takes everyday objects to speak evocatively about a broad range of ideas. In Collapsible Stream, for instance, he took a discarded fisherman’s boat, chopped it into pieces and then sent the pieces by mail from Kyoto, Japan, where he was doing an artist’s residency, to Busan, South Korea, where he exhibited as one of the artists in the Busan Biennale, 2008. This indexical reference to the trafficking of objects and ideas is something that logically proceeds from his interest in the cognitive summoning of meaning in another work, First Attempt at Social Sculpture or Breaking the Fourth Wall, 2011, which consisted of a cake that guests were tauntingly invited to partake of, except that they first had to deal with the jagged glass shards that were foisted on its surface. Pastrana also undertook 99%, 2014, in one of the last exhibitions at Silverlens, Gillman Barracks, Singapore. In this work, Pastrana counts on an elaborate narrative that can be taken as a contemporary tale of the life of things—in this case, a car destined for the trash heap but instead sold off with 99 percent of the proceeds used to purchase the corresponding amount of gold, which was tiny. This was then shown at the gallery as part of a video installation screening the narrative transformation. This obtuse but often poetic upending of the skew of fates, of the impoverished and disempowered 99 percent vis-à-vis the power elite 1 percent, is typical of how Pastrana’s work delivers several substrata of stories which beholders are drawn to confront.

Among Pastrana’s other solo exhibitions are Sustaining Symmetry, 2000, Big Sky Mind; Echolalia, 2002, Finale Art Gallery; Detour/Set/Fraction, Green Papaya Art Projects, 2003; Actuality/Virtuality, 2003, IAF Shop, Fukuoka City; Stray Bullets, 2004, Finale Art Gallery; New Collages, 2008, 20 Square; Indivisibilis, 2009, SLab; and Vivo Fragmenta, 2011, Bangkok University Gallery. He has participated in various international group exhibitions in Thailand, Italy, Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, Japan, Switzerland, and various venues in the United States of America.

Apart from starting up the now-defunct artist-run space Future Prospects at the former Marikina Shoe Exchange turned Cubao Ex, and programming the short-lived Theo Gallery in Makati, Pastrana continues to be active as both practicing artist and curator-organizer. He collaborates with other artists through partnerships such as Project Joint with Stanley Ruiz, and the design initiative Broke with Jeremy Guiab. Among the exhibitions he either curated or co-curated are On the Radar: Six New Symptoms, 2011, Silverlens; Complete and Unabridged II, Osage Art Foundation, 2011; Ley Hunting 1 and 2, 2012 and 2013, Silverlens; The Midnight Marriage, 2013, Silverlens; Fundacion Broke, 2013, Art Informal; Relikt, 2013, The Shadow Factory and Space and Two Points, 2014, all at Silverlens Gillman Barracks.

Pastrana has been awarded residencies at Bangkok University Gallery, 2004 and 2010, and by Japan Foundation under the Jenesys Program, 2008. He received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2006. Written byEileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Source:

Pastrana, n.d.

PATERNO, ADELAIDA (Adelaida Ignacio Paterno) aka Adela Paterno. b. 24 Oct 1880. d. 2 Nov 1962. Adelaida Paterno was the youngest child of Don Maximo Molo Agustin Paterno and Teodora Devera Ignacio, his third wife. Adelaida’s siblings were also artists led by her older half-sister Paz, considered one of the most prolific women visual artists in the 19th century. Paz painted Bodegon (Still Life) and Frutas y Canasta (Fruits and Basket), the earliest known existing painting by a woman visual artist in the Philippines. Another sister, Dolores Paterno, composed La Flor de Manila aka Sampaguita. Pedro Alejandro Paterno, her brother, wrote the novel Ninay, 1885, the first novel in Spanish written by a Filipino, as well as the libretto of Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance). Another sister, Trinidad, made embroidery using human hair, as exemplified by Escena Rural con Aguador (Rural Scene with Water Carrier), ca 1890s. Concepcion (Concha) Paterno was one of the women who joined the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in Manila, in which she exhibited a landscape done in embroidery. Adelaida’s older sisters must have taught her to embroider using hair.

The catalogue of the 1895 Exposicion Regional de Filipinas in Manila reveals that Adelaida submitted an embroidered landscape for the exposition. However, the whereabouts and status of this embroidered work are not known. In 1896, Adelaida painted Escena del Rio Pasig (Pasig River Scene). In 1897, when Adelaida was 17, she produced three embroideries using human hair on Chinese silk: [Country Scene], [Rural Scene with Child], and Vista de Mariquina (View of Marikina). These three works portray women of the working class from the viewpoint of an ilustrado (educated native) woman. Adelaida’s use of human hair to depict a scene and figures is admirable, considering that she had no training in anatomy. While the influence of her older sister Paz can be discerned in her landscape genre painting, particularly in regard to the combination of themes, her embroidery work using hair is unique to Adelaida. The three works are in the Central Bank collection.

Adelaida was inclined not only toward painting and embroidery but also toward music. According to Manuel (1970, 117), she studied music under Victorino Carrion and even appeared in ensayos musicales (musical rehearsals).

Like her older sister Paz, Adelaida never married. Adelaida died at the age of 82. She was then the last survivor among the Paterno siblings. Written byEloisa May P. Hernandez

Source:

Manuel 1970.

PATERNO, PAZ (Paz Santa Ignacio Paterno) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 1 Nov 1867. d. 25 Aug 1914. Paz was the ninth of Don Maximo Molo Agustin Polo Paterno’s children, the eighth with his second wife Carmina Devera Ignacio. Paz’s siblings were also inclined toward the arts. Paz’s youngest half-sister, Adelaida Paterno, was known for hair embroidery. Dolores Paterno is known as the composer of La Flor de Manila (Flower of Manila). Her brother Pedro Alejandro Paterno wrote the libretto of Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), the first opera staged in the country, in 1902. Another sister, Trinidad, also made embroidery using human hair as seen in her work titled Rural Scene with Water Carrier, ca 1890s. Concepcion (Concha) Paterno joined the 1895 Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in Manila, where she exhibited a paisaje (landscape) done in embroidery.

Because the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura was still not open to women at that time, Paz studied painting and drawing with private tutors who happened to be the three leading painters of the time: Lorenzo Guerrero, Felix Martinez, and Teodoro Buenaventura. Critic Emmanuel Torres credits Guerrero specifically for Paz’s deftness in her bodegones or still lifes of fruits (Torres 1980, 60).

At age 17, Paz painted Bodegon (Still Life) and Frutas y Canasta (Fruits and Basket). These two pieces are the earliest known existing painting by a woman visual artist in the Philippines. In 1885, she painted Frutas y Flores (Fruits and Flowers), Escena del Rio con Banca (River Scene with Banca), and Escena del Rio con Barcos de Vapor (River Scene with Steamboat). Another work, [Still Life with Bird], is undated, but scholars assert this may also have been painted around the same period. As in her first work, Bodegon, Paz also combined landscape and still life in this painting. Paz’s works, however, were not limited to landscapes and still life. She also painted [Portrait of a Woman], which is now in a private collection. Paz appears to have been the most prolific of the women visual artists in the 19th century. In the span of two years, she produced seven works, all in oil and canvas. Paz exhibited works in the 1895 Exposicion Regional de Filipinas in Manila. Among these were a paisaje, four bodegones, and another paisaje titled Orillas del Pasig (Banks of the Pasig).

Paz suffered from tuberculosis and lived in Santa Ana, Herran, to recuperate. According to other relatives, she probably painted her paisajes from this family home but must have been forced to stop painting because of her illness. She died unmarried at the age of 47. Written by Eloisa May P. Hernandez

Source:

Torres 1981.

Paulino and Hetty Que

COLLECTION Recognized for its immensity and relevance to Philippine art history, this private art collection was formed through the vision and efforts of Paulino Que. His first acquisition was a collage by Jose Joya, a purchase that he made in the 1970s. The trove has grown increasingly since then, reaching over a thousand in number in the form of paintings of landscapes, portraits, letras y figuras (letters and figures), and tipos del pais (country genre); sculptures of santos (icon saints) of all types; ivory; furniture; and salakot. The artworks illustrate turning points in the history of Philippine art from the 18th century to the present—the periodical and stylistic shifts from religious and secular painting in the late 18th and 19th centuries, to the academic and conservative tradition, the emergence of modernism, and on to the contemporary. Rare and iconic works by notable artists form a significant part of the collection. There are early pieces, works that define artistic achievements or mark important biographical moments in the artist’s life. Likewise, there are works that signal the artist’s transition from one medium and technique to another, or impart new explorations in subject matter and content.

The following are among the most significant in the collection: the self-portrait of Damian Domingo, 19th century; La Virgen Maria (The Virgin Mary), a religious image in oil and wood by Simon Flores, late 19th century; the two versions of En el Paco (In Paco) by Juan Luna, 1880 and 1884; and Waves at Sunset by Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, 1890. Fabian de la Rosa, one of the first faculty members of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts, is represented in the collection through the genre painting Kundiman (Filipino Love Song), 1932, as well as through a rare portrait of his nephew, the young Fernando Amorsolo, 1903. Works by Amorsolo include Portrait of Morgan Sweet at Age 10, 1929, and Planting Rice, 1924. Distinct works by modernists include Chief Galo, 1907, an early work by the architect painter Juan Arellano; Self-Portrait, 1927, by Victorio Edades, a work the artist did when he was a new graduate; Planting Rice, 1948, a large-scale painting by Galo Ocampo; Maria Makiling, 1947, a lyrical interpretation of folklore by Carlos V. Francisco; Veronica, 1957, by Vicente Manansala; Sacramental, 1956, by Hernando Ocampo; Nativity, 1950, by Cesar Legaspi; and Street Musicians, 1952, by Arturo Luz. Later artists of modernist sensibilities are well represented in the collection—among them, Fernando Zobel, Jose Joya, Lee Aguinaldo, Federico Alcuaz, Ang Kiukok, Jeremias Elizalde Navarro, and Benedicto Cabrera. There are also exemplary works by Filipino artists who lived abroad such as Venancio Igarta, the pioneer of printmaking Manuel Rodriguez Sr, Mexico-based Romeo Tabuena, Paris-based Nena Saguil, and long-term United Kingdom resident David Medalla, whose painting Progress in Cery Vision figures prominently in the collection. These examples are by no means definitive of the breadth of the collection as it continues to expand to accommodate contemporary art. The exhibition Revealing Signs of the Present: Philippine Paintings 2000-2012, held at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila in 2013, presented a selection of contemporary art from the Paulino and Hetty Que collection.

The provenance of the works in Que’s collection gives insight to the transfer and circulation of objects from one collector to another. A number of works have been acquired from reputable artists, critics, and fellow collectors who previously owned them. Among them are Luis Araneta, Arturo de Santos, Federico Alcuaz, E. Aguilar Cruz, the Bautista-Nakpil family, Roberto Villanueva, Mariano Corpuz, Arturo Luz, Jess Ayco, and Purita Kalaw-Ledesma. In 2013, the exhibition The Real H.R. Ocampo held at the Ayala Museum featured the collector’s 51 Ocampo paintings which Que collected over a period of 30 years. Que’s recurring presence in key museum exhibitions also reveals the power dynamics in the local art world whose institutions rarely have their own acquisition budgets. Other recent thematic exhibitions that presented selections from the Paulino and Hetty Que collection are Figuring the Times: Philippine Paintings 1996-2009, 2009; Meaning to Be Modern: Philippine Paintings from 1907-1959, 2010; Imagining Identity: 100 Filipino Self Portraits, 2012, all held at Finale Art File.Written byLouise Anne D. Marcelino

Sources:

Reyes 2013; Villegas 2004b.

PERALTA, RAMON (Ramon Resurreccion Peralta) b. Namacpacan (now Luna), La Union 31 Aug 1877. d. Manila 1 Oct 1940. Scenographic painter. Peralta pursued his secondary education at the Instituto Burgos, then finished his bachelor of arts at the Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado where he received medals in the yearly competitions. He taught at the Centro de Artistas before he joined the faculty of the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1918.

Upon the death of ToribioAntillon, Peralta became the leading scenographic painter. In recognition of this achievement, UP placed him in charge of the annual celebration of UP Day, National Heroes Day, and the tableaux-vivants at the UP Padre Faura Campus. He was also the main decorator of the stage of the Grand Manila Carnival held yearly before World War II. To further enhance his talent in scenographic art, UP sent him to Europe for further studies. He traveled to Barcelona, Madrid, and Paris where he observed various theaters and stage houses. Upon his return, he did the mural Alma Mater, which adorned the President’s Office at the Administration Building at UP Padre Faura.

One of Peralta’s three paintings on the same locale, Tirad Pass, now at the UP Diliman Library, shows a panoramic reed and grass landscape of which the narrow and steep passage courageously guarded by Gen Gregorio del Pilar to his death is depicted small in relation to the sky-dominated setting. General del Pilar mounted on horseback is understandably also depicted small. This approach to the subject is certainly reflective of Peralta’s training as scenographic artist. In traditional stage backdrops, the characters were always small in relation to the painted panoramic settings. Other works by Peralta also give evidence of his scenographic approach to painting. His colors were pastel and his shadows sharply contrasted with highlighted forms.

His awards include a bronze medal for Study of a Head at the Saint Louis Universal Exposition of 1904 and another bronze medal for Estudio de Cabeza (Study of Head), perhaps the same as the former, at the Exhibition-Competition sponsored by the Sociedad Internacional de Artistas de Manila in 1908. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

PEREIRA, JOSE V. (Jose Valdezco Pereira) b. Ilagan, Isabela 14 May 1901. d. 1954. Painter. He was the son of Eduardo Pereira and Faustina Valdezco. Portraitist RafaeldelCasal is a grandnephew. He finished high school at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran, then took up painting at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts, 1923-25. While still a student, he worked at the Pacific Commercial Company designing labels and advertisements. In 1924, he joined the staff of the Philippines Free Press, eventually becoming its chief artist. He left the magazine in 1938 due to tuberculosis. He was replaced by Esmeraldo Z. Izon.

As editorial artist of Free Press, Pereira produced a weekly cartoon dwelling on the issue or event discussed in the editorial. Since the main theme during this period was the campaign for Philippine independence, the artist focused on the weaknesses or follies of local politicians. His style was derived from painting, with lines achieving or evoking character and tonal contrasts reminiscent of bold washes, injecting a dramatic atmosphere into the scene. Pereira resumed his painting in 1938, creating his Batis (Stream) series, which portrayed rural lasses bathing or washing clothes, reminiscent of the works of FernandoAmorsolo. The maidens are depicted sensuously, their bodies tightly wrapped with blue-and white-striped sarongs. He adopted the bright highlights of Amorsolo, but his coloring was sweeter, with a penchant for orange tints mixed with pink. Written bySantiago A. Pilar
(See PARAS-Perez, Rodolfo)

PETTYJOHN, JON/PETTYJOHN, TESSY (Jon Lorenzo Pettyjohn/Tessy San Juan Pettyjohn) b. Okinawa, Japan 4 Oct 1950/b. Manila 29 Jun 1948. Potters. Jon is the son of H. C. Pettyjohn and Isabel Lorenzo. A studio potter of Filipino-American descent, Jon studied ceramic arts and worked as pottery apprentice in Barcelona, Spain. He has had his own workshop since the mid-1970s. His work concentrates on functional, one-of-a-kind limited edition stoneware and porcelain in the Asian tradition. He occasionally does sculptural and experimental work, including murals. He has had many one-person shows and has joined group shows starting at the Design Center Philippines in the late 1970s. He exhibited at the Luz Gallery, Hiraya Gallery, CulturalCenterofthePhilippines, Sining Kamalig, and Vargas Museum. He has also participated in exhibits in Southeast Asia and the United States. Jon is the co-founder of the Pettyjohn-Mendoza Pottery School and president of the Association of Philippine Potters Inc or Putik, and stands at the forefront of the movement for the recognition of ceramics in the Philippines as art.

Tessy is the daughter of Francisco and Remedios San Juan. She studied fine arts, major in painting and ceramic arts, at the University of the Philippines. She did further studies in ceramics under Manuel Ramirez at the New School for Social Research in New York City. She has worked with husband Jon in their workshop studio in Laguna since the late 1970s. She had numerous one-person shows and has joined group shows in Manila.

Together, Jon and Tessy have done extensive research on the use of indigenous raw materials, specifically doing exhibits with local materials for handmade porcelain. Their workshop was one of or probably the first to produce glazes like celadon, tenmoku, and Chun in the country. They continue to do research on the use of interesting materials like wood and sugarcane, ash and volcanic stones for high-temperature glazes. The Pettyjohns occasionally do collaborative work, but for the most part maintain their own styles.

In addition to their research and experimentation, the Pettyjohns also periodically teach and conduct seminars, and have mentored second- and third-generation potters, including their daughter Hannah who has also gone into painting and installation. Most recently, the Pettyjohns held an exhibit in Aug 2015 at the Silverlens Galleries titled Touch Me, Touch Me Not, where the couple showcased clay pieces that evoke their current ambivalence about their practice and functionality. Written byAnnaliza B. Villar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources: Mendoza 2014; Miclat 2013; Tejada 2015.

PHILIPPINE ART EDUCATORS

ASSOCIATION(PAEA) Initiated in 1968 by Araceli Dans and Brenda Fajardo, two art educators then teaching at the primary and secondary levels of Ateneo de Manila, PAEA was launched with the preliminary motive of updating and studying the teaching method of art teachers. Patterning their plan after the National Art Education Association of the USA, they organized art teachers from 15 private schools in Manila to share, discuss, and assess the situation of art teaching in the metropolis. Finding out that most art teaching was still based on ideas published in American magazines, they decided to focus their efforts on developing Filipino consciousness. They enlisted resource persons to help develop content and new methods of propagating art practice and art appreciation to Filipino children and the general public. Then National Museum director Gemma Cruz, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) visual arts director Roberto Chabet, and Design Center of the Philippines director Oscar Mapua Jr assisted them in their planning and strategy. It became PAEA’s mission to professionalize the teaching of art, and to keep the teachers creative. In 1970-71, Six to Sixteen was organized as the annual children’s art exhibition at the Main Gallery (now also known as Bulwagang Juan Luna) of the CCP, becoming the model for exhibitions of a wide variety of imaginative, stimulating, and colorful visual expressions by children and youth. Annual thematic conferences with art-making workshops became a well-kept tradition that consistently deepened the members’ Filipino sensibility, and expanded their creative, innovative capabilities. Exposure and field trips to indigenous cultural communities were also organized. Tam-awan Village in Baguio City became a regular venue for its Artsploration / art immersion projects in regard to Cordillera arts and culture.

The vision, mission, and goals of the organization are as follows: to make art and culture accessible for the development and advancement of Filipinos as creative individuals and responsible members of the society; to nurture creativity, promote culture, and strengthen Filipino identity, to educate through the arts by training art educators based in institutions and communities, and to develop linkages with individuals, organizations, and communities for the promotion, appreciation, and respect for the diverse cultures in the Philippines. PAEA exerts much effort in strengthening knowledge and appreciation of the various forms of living traditions of the Philippines, and making these relevant and sustainable. A sample of the organization’s rich trove of creative learning is the 2013 workshop module Buffet Drawing, wherein participants had workshops in comic book production, painting, printmaking, indigenous Philippine performing and literary arts, and “Claymation.” In 2015, the theme for its annual conference was Sining Pangkabuhayan (Art for Livelihood), and in line with this it held Katutubo (Indigenous), a portrait exhibit by teachers/members consisting of paintings, crafts, and sculptures focusing on indigenous peoples. Through its adopted pedagogical framework, Discipline-Based Art Education, images, sounds, and stories become a vehicle for social change. As PAEA adheres to making arts beneficial for total human fulfillment, it has served as effective proselytizer of its Arts Integration Program, wherein the arts—drama, dance, and music—are used in teaching math and literacy.

While PAEA’s membership was first drawn from the academic private sector, it has since expanded to include public school teachers, administrators, teachers practicing informal education, cultural workers in the communities, club moderators, counselors, student leaders, and individual artists who desire to work for PAEA’s goals. Its list of presidents includes Brenda Fajardo, Cota Yabut, Teresita Dichupa, Clarissa Perez, Pearl Kapunan Ortega, Alice Alafriz Panares, Zenaida Xavier, Blesilda Reynoso, Rosel Valenzuela, Edda Amonoy, Alma Quinto, Jane Ebarle, and Orlando Abon. Its officers are accomplished in their careers as teachers, authors, consultants, and evaluators of government art education curricula, trainers and resource speakers in educational institutions.

PAEA had 675 registered individual members from various schools nationwide. Institutional members include St. Mary’s Academy of Pasay City; Claret School of Quezon City; De La Salle University (DLSU) in Dasmariñas, Cavite; DLSU–Saint Benilde College in Manila; Mapua Institute of Technology; Philippine Normal University in Northern Luzon; Marist School of Marikina; Letran College of Manila; and Ateneo de Manila. PAEA draws its financial sustainability from modest membership contributions and project participation fees, donations and institutional support, such as those from Metrobank Foundation, National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA), Government Service Insurance System Museum of Art, Faber-Castell, WriteTech, Rex Book Store, Phoenix Publishing House, and Coca-Cola Foundation.

With the support of NCCA, PAEA has set up a scholarship program for 60 art educators nationwide who are now leaders in their educational community. It also supports the goals of the Department of Education’s K-12 Art Education Program through its promotion of arts and culture among teachers through its holistic approaches to Transformative Culture-Based Education. It has partnered with the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority to include and enrich the arts and culture aspects of its national certificate accreditation program. Some of its members are now holders of National Certificate (NC) such as NCII Illustration, NCIII Events Management, and NCII Tourism and Promotions. PAEA now has regional coordinators and training centers nationwide such as in Batanes through Yaru Gallery; Philippine Normal University in the North Luzon campus in Bulacan; Tam-awan Village in Baguio City; Bangaan Elementary School in Sagada, Mountain Province; and Balay Mindanao in Cagayan de Oro City and Iligan City. Written byImelda Cajipe-Endaya

PHILIPPINE ART GALLERY (PAG) Begun on 30 May 1950 by a group of women writers as part of their promotions and advertising outfit, it evolved into one of the foremost art centers in the country, supplying the first modern art collectors such as PuritaKalaw-Ledesma and LeandroLocsin. Its founders were Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla, writer and widow of fictionist ManuelArguilla, Flora Lansang, TrinidadTarrosaSubido, Consuelo Abaya, and EstrellaAlfon. They set up Promotions Inc along Azcarraga (now C. M. Recto) St in front of the Aranque market, then added a commercial art gallery after three months. At that time, public awareness of art was increasing through the efforts of the Art Association of the Philippines and the ongoing debates between the conservatives and the modernists. RomeoTabuena was the first artist to be presented on PAG’s “Feature Wall,” followed by HernandoR.Ocampo, ArturoLuz, and Arguilla herself. Later on, artists were invited to participate in group exhibits.

When the outfit moved to the Malate area (near the corner of Taft Ave and Herran St) after six months, Promotions Inc gave way to the PAG. It became a busy art center with lecture forums and classes in art, music appreciation, flower arrangement, and languages such as Tagalog, Spanish, and French, and attracted not only artists but also professors, poets, fictionists, students, and other cultural personalities. The gallery printed Christmas cards designed by artists like Nena Saguil, Vicente Manansala, Arturo Luz, Anita Magsaysay-Ho, CenonRivera, and Romeo Tabuena.

After a year PAG transferred to a building owned by CarmenGuerrero-Nakpil along Taft Ave, facing the Philippine General Hospital. There it celebrated its first anniversary with a big, monthlong exhibition of paintings, photographs, and architectural designs. The following year it organized a Philippine exhibit in the United States.

The PAG was kept alive, through many financial difficulties, largely by Arguilla, even though she was out of the country for long periods. It set up several branches in Cubao, including the one on Saint Williams St, which featured a studio-theater-gallery, but none of them prospered. Only the branch in Arquiza was maintained till the late 1960s. When Arguilla died on 20 Dec 1969, the PAG died with her. Years later its belongings, which had been stored at the house on Saint Williams St, were bought by Mario Alcantara and went into the Heritage Art Center.

A book called The Biggest Little Room, 1987, by Purita Kalaw-Ledesma has documented the development of the PAG. Written byAlice G. Guillermo

article_title: Philippine Women's University School of Fine Arts and Design
text:
