PHILIPPINE WOMEN’S UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF FINE ARTS AND DESIGN(PWU SFAD) The School of Fine Arts and Design of the Philippine Women’s University was first established in 1952 as the Philippine School of Music and Fine Arts under Director Felicing Tirona. The first fine arts students were Patty Biroceni, Anterra Mar, Lilia Trinidad, Elenita Sayoc, Fe Severino, and Rosario Bitanga. SFAD was separated from the music program, and renamed the Institute of Fine Arts and Design (IFAD) in 1957. The first studio artist to become IFAD director was Araceli Limcaco-Dans. Two major programs were emphasized in its formative years in the 1960s: painting and graphic arts. With the establishment of the Center for Visual Printmaking under Manuel Rodriguez Sr in the 1960s, IFAD became a notable venue for printmakers in the Philippines. The Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP) was born in the institutional space offered by IFAD. Among the notable faculty and administrators that were associated with IFAD were Mariano Madarang, Raul Isidro, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, Julian Cea Nepal, Alfonso Miaga, Ludivina Abes, J. Elizalde Navarro, Virgilio Aviado, Purificacion Torres, Lualhati Trias, Julia Calixto, Lorna Alvarez-Salutal, Ibarra de la Rosa, Benjie Cabrera, Noel El Farrol, and Roberto Feleo.

In 1998, the master of arts in fine arts and design program was instituted under Dean Rosario Bitanga. In 2006, IFAD was renamed the School of Fine Arts and Design. Since 2011, the SFAD has been led by Dean Josephine Turalba. In 2013, the SFAD Gallery was inaugurated under Curator Noel Cuizon. SFAD offers a bachelor’s degree in fine arts, major in industrial design, painting, and visual communication; a bachelor of science degree in interior design, and a master of arts degree in fine arts and design. The pedagogy emphasizes a globally competitive contemporary art and design curriculum that also gives importance to issues in Philippine art history.

SFAD has graduated a notable list of fine arts alumni since the 1960s. Five of its alumni have received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Awards: Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Roberto Feleo, Antipas Delotavo, Noel Cuizon, and Raquel de Loyola. Other notable alumni of the PWU SFAD are Justino “Tiny” Nuyda, Rafael Cusi, Rossano Capili, Prudencio Lamarrosa, Eghai Roxas, Vincent Ramos, Hermes Alegre, Alfredo Juan Aquilian, Lotsu Manes, and Ged Merino. Written byReuben Ramas Cañete

Sources:

Pueblo 2014; PWU SFAD 2013.

PILAPIL, IMPY (Imelda Manalaysay Pilapil) b. Cavite City 19 Sep 1949. Sculptor. She is the daughter of Serafin Pilapil and Francisca Manalaysay. Pilapil’s artistic background is diverse. She spent a year training in painting and printmaking at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1968. This was followed by a scholarship in cinematic studies at the Academia Italiana in Rome, then a workshop at the Pratt Graphic Institute in New York, 1977-78, where she specialized in lithography.

A versatile artist, Pilapil has done prints, particularly serigraphy, as well as sculpture in glass and mixed media. Serigraphy, combined with etching or lithography, is her printmaking forte. Her earlier prints were geometric, marked by rigorous discipline and with a measured approach to color and tonality. The imagery of her prints later developed into a dialogue between free and intensely colored biomorphic shapes, as in the Dreamer’s Zone series in the early 1980s. She has also done paper art, in which colored paper is folded or pleated to create geometric designs producing a relief effect, and has explored indigenous materials such as gauzelike coconut fiber. In 1983, Pilapil shifted to the medium of glass, as in her work installed at the Philippine Commercial and International Bank. Since then, she has done works using large irregularly shaped planes of glass, at times combined and contrasted in texture with rocks and metals. Often she etches the glass with linear patterns allusive of sun and moon, water and clouds that together compose an aerial landscape of floating colored form.

Pilapil’s selected solo exhibitions in the Philippines and abroad include Paper Sculptures, 1975; Collage and Prints, 1976; Prints, 1985; Paper, Glass and Metal, 1986; Mix-Media, 1989; Sculptures in Glass and Stone, 1990; Art and Ecology, 1992; Reflections in Water, 1993; Reflections of the Spiritual, 1994; Art of Glass and Stone, 1994; Seed, 1995; Glass and Stone: Boracay Series, 1997; Find Your Truth, 1998; Glass and Stone, 2000; Benevolent Force, 2002; Earth Empowered, 2006; Spiral of Life, 2006; Interactive: The 12 Senses, 2008; and Aquabella, 2011. In 1990, she was one of the artists in 10 Philippine Artists in Museo Civica Contamporanea, Italy.

Pilapil won third prize in the Graphic Art Competition in Rome, 1971. In 1974, she received citations from the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) as outstanding artist, and as prizewinner at the annual competition of the Philippine Association of Printmakers. She was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1976. In 1987, she received the AAP grand prize, Sculptor of the Year. She was the Philippine Representative to the Seoul Olympics festival in 1988. In 1993, she received the Vidal Sassoon Visual Arts Award for Sculpture, and in 1997 she was the selected sculptor for the ASEAN Plaza Landmark in the CCP Complex. In 1998, she was also the sculptor commissioned to do the Heroes Memorial Landmark in Fort Bonifacio. She received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan from the city of Manila in 2000 and the Outstanding Citizen Award of Cavite. She was selected as one of the 100 Outstanding Women of the Philippines in 2002 and in 2004. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Gutierrez 2009; Philstar.com, n.d.; Pilapil, n.d.

PILAR, SANTIAGO A. (Santiago Albano Pilar) aka Jack Pilar. b. Bacarra, Ilocos Norte 15 Oct 1946. Essayist, art historian, art educator. He is the son of Elias Pilar, who served as municipal judge of Bacarra from 1955 until his retirement in 1975, and Jesusa Albano. He finished high school at Vigan Minor Seminary where he was influenced by Fr Juan Foronda, Ilocano historiographer, and at the Convento de San Agustin, Intramuros, where he received guidance in the classics under Fr Isacio Rodriguez. He obtained a bachelor of arts degree in art history from the University of the Philippines (UP). Pilar taught advanced courses in art history and connoisseurship in both the undergraduate and graduate programs at the UP College of Fine Arts. He retired from teaching at UP in 2011. He served as a consultant for exhibition projects of the Ayala Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Manila, and Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

Several of his poems appeared in the Philippines Free Press. After graduation, he began writing essays aimed at reconstructing the history of Philippine painting, particularly during the Spanish and American period. He wrote an essay on Philippine silent movies which was anthologized in Readings in Philippine Cinema, edited by Rafael Ma. Guerrero. His essays on forgotten 19th-century painters, like Jose Lozano, Justiniano Asuncion, Vicente Villaseñor, Juan Arceo, among others, mostly published in Archipelago, unearthed new data and led to the revaluation of the achievements of these painters. Some of his researches were also published in Orientations, Zone D, and Metro Manila Commission Publication. His Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter, 1978, an evaluative biography, is a significant contribution to the study of Luna. In 1985, he delivered the inaugural lecture at the First Philippine Art History Conference held at the Casa Manila, Intramuros. In 1986, he was one of five art critics chosen to write the essays in A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces. He is also the author of The Philippine Classic Heritage, 1981; Unang Pambansang Eksibisyon sa Paggunita kina Juan Luna at Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo (First National Exhibition in Commemoration of Juan Luna and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo), 1988; and Inspired Calm: The Sober Realism of Domingo Celis, 1992. His Pamana: The Jorge B. Vargas Art Collection, 1992, includes a lively discussion of 60 masterpieces in the UP Jorge B. Vargas Museum. He was one of three editors of the Visual Arts volume of theCCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, published in 1994. He also wrote the section on Philippine painting for the multivolume Dictionary of Art published by Grove Press, London. He contributed to the seminal publication Discovering Philippine Art in Spain, 1998. His book The Life and Art of Isabelo Tampinco was launched, alongside a documentary, at the National Museum on 22 Aug 2014.

Pilar received the Ten Outstanding Young Men award for art history in 1980. In 1992, he became the first recipient of the Purita Kalaw-Ledesma Professorial Chair for Art History and Criticism and was holder of the Ignacio Villamor Professorial Chair for Art. He also won theAraw ng Maynila’s Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan, tagapag-alaga ng sining (patron of the arts), in 1996.Written by Ino Manalo, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Therese de Silva

Sources :

Bartolome 2014; Torre 1978; Wikipilipinas 2014.

PINAGLABANAN GALLERIES Pinaglabanan was run by artist Agnes Arellano and Michael Adams from 1984 to 1989. Built on the ruins of the former Arellano family residence in San Juan, which burned down in 1981, the gallery complex was a memorial to the members of the family who died in the fire: Arellano’s father architect Otilio Arellano, mother Liwayway Almario, and sister Cita.

Roberto Chabet, Arellano’s mentor at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (UP CFA), and Nilo Ilarde, also a former student of Chabet at UP CFA, set the direction of Pinaglabanan as a space for paintings, sculpture, installations, and other experimental works. They curated the first season of exhibitions, which formally opened on 9 Nov 1984 featuring works by Antonio Austria, Danny Dalena, Jaime de Guzman, and Tito Sanchez. Succeeding shows included solo presentations by Pardo de Leon, Julie Lluch, Fernando Modesto, and Popo San Pascual. Chabet and Ilarde also organized three survey shows that presented recent works in figuration, abstraction, and mixed media by a number of young and emerging artists including Ray Albano, Bert Antonio, Huge Bartolome, Joe Bautista, Dick Daroy, R.M. de Leon, Yoli Laudico, Ileana Lee, Judy Sibayan, Gerardo Tan, and Nestor Vinluan.

After the first season of exhibitions, Pinaglabanan invited other guest curators such as Bobi Valenzuela. The galleries began showing more social realist works that reflected the political atmosphere of the times, such as the solo shows by Pacita Abad and Jose Tence Ruiz in 1986, and the group exhibition SR: Mga Bagong Likha (Social Realism: New Works) in 1987. They hosted exhibitions of artists from other parts of the Philippines, such the Baguio Arts Guild, Bicol Arts Guild, artists from Sagada, and the Philippine High School for the Arts in Los Baños, Laguna, as well as the works of Filipino expatriate artists Duddley Diaz and David Medalla who were both based in Europe. The gallery also showed works by writers and poets in the two-part Chromatext exhibitions in 1985 and 1986.

Pinaglabanan played an active role in introducing Philippine art to an international audience. The gallery organized several exchanges between Filipino and foreign artists and curators, such as the exhibition Ex-change Manila-Berlin in 1988, which brought together paintings, sculpture, installations, and films by Filipino artists Marcel Antonio, Agnes Arellano, Edson Armenta, R.M. de Leon, Peque Gallaga, Dan Raralio, Raymond Red, Raul Rodriguez, and German artists Luciano Castelli, Knut Hoffmeister, and Birgit Hoffmeister.

Pinaglabanan closed after five seasons of exhibitions. Chabet curated two more group shows: Five Girls: Chaos and Alarm and Sunsets and Other Vanishing Acts, before mounting his own solo exhibition Cargo and Decoy, which essentially brought the gallery’s fate full circle as it closed in 1989. Written byR. S. Bunoan

PINEDA, JORGE b. Santa Cruz, Manila 26 Jul 1879. d. Santa Cruz, Manila 12 Sep 1946. Illustrator, painter. He was the son of Ines Pineda. He studied at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura before the outbreak of the Philippine-American War and later enrolled at Buenaventura’s School of Drawing. In 1904, he won awards at the Universal Exposition in Saint Louis, Missouri, USA: bronze for Campesina (Farm Girl), showing a solidly drawn head of a rural lass, and honorable mention for Las Buyeras (Betel-Nut Vendors). In 1895, he began working as a lithographer in the Carmelo and Bauermann printing firm.

Pineda was also considered the leading illustrator of his time. He was an active contributor to political publications such as The Independent and Lipang Kalabaw, a satirical magazine, where he sometimes used the pen name Makahiya. He did the lithograph version of the composite portrait of 13 heroes, Filipinos Ilustres (Illustrious Filipinos), based on the 1911 drawing by GuillermoTolentino. He is credited as the creator of Juan de la Cruz, the symbol of the ordinary Filipino. He also drew cover illustrations for Renacimiento Filipino as well as ads, and designed sweepstakes tickets, postage stamps, and the prewar 20-peso bill showing the Mayon Volcano. He did illustrations for many books such as Bajo los Cocoteros (Under the Coconut Trees) by ClaroM.Recto.

As a painter, Pineda was peer to FernandoAmorsolo but less prolific, being an occasional painter. He explored subjects outside those of the Amorsolo school. He painted the neat and quiet streets of the city in the 1920s. Among his most charming genre scenes are those depicting Filipino games like siklot and sungka (bantumi). Bantilon, 1943, depicts a young couple playing the siklot on the floor, while Chongka, 1943, shows an old couple playing sungka by the window. Characteristic of these works is the interplay between the shadowy indoors and bright outdoors, as well as the psychological interest in people absorbed in their activity. Pineda used rugged brushstrokes that help suggest the simplicity of domestic settings. Written bySantiago A. Pilar and Alice G. Guillermo

THE PURITA KALAW-LEDESMACOLLECTIONThe Kalaw-Ledesma collection consists of a thousand paintings, sculptural pieces, drawings, prints, mixed media work, pottery, and religious figures from the Spanish colonial period. Assembled by the founding president of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP), Purita Kalaw-Ledesma, the collection is critically illustrative of both the formal and thematic concerns of the work of early and post-World War II Filipino modernists such as Victorio Edades, Carlos Francisco, Galo Ocampo, and the other Thirteen Moderns whom Edades posed as the emergent voices of a new Filipino aesthetic challenging classicist and romanticist sensibilities.

Artists whose works also form part of the collection include Fernando Amorsolo, Fabian de la Rosa, and Irineo Miranda who were Kalaw-Ledesma’s former teachers at the then School of Fine Arts at the University of the Philippines. Alongside these are pieces by her fellow artists and modernist advocates. The collection also includes works from those who did not necessarily match Kalaw-Ledesma’s predilection for a new aesthetics that was more experimental and socially oriented. Finding herself amidst a circle of artists and intellectuals working in a landscape bereft of institutional and private support, Kalaw-Ledesma straddled multiple positions in the emergent art world. Alternately artist, collector, documentor, and impresario, her own personal art practice took a backseat to the rigors of organizing and chronicling of a broad stream of art practices including but not solely of the modernists’. Key pieces in the collection dating prior to World War II onward affirm her place in a nascent art world where artists navigated the tensions between notions of identity and internationalism, while distilling tendencies from impressionism to cubism. As in most early collections, the acquisition logic is driven more by kinship and professional affinities than traditional regard for art historical junctures and a coherent register of aesthetic values.

Birthed in the logic of gifts and tokens of gratitude from struggling artists hoping to trigger their momentum for an exhibition, or to plump up a kitty for further studies, the Kalaw-Ledesma trove, along with other small pockets of assembled art, would stand as the primary source for early modernist history through the 1970s and 1980s. Presumably, it would also be the core reference for Kalaw-Ledesma when she later set out to write art history in books such as The Struggle for Philippine Art and The Big Little Room, under the auspices of the ASEAN Institute of Art headed by Dr Rod Paras-Perez.

The collection represents pivotal moments in modernist art production in many respects. While it boasts of some of the most iconic pieces from the oeuvre of early modernists, it also contains a significant number of pieces done by artists at possibly their least unguarded or most playful moments at work when they might have been resolving points of influence, exploring unfamiliar material, or merely trying on new ideas for size. The collection includes works that have gained circulation through Philippine art history books and didactic materials for the humanities. Among these are H.R. Ocampo’s Man and Carabao, 1949; Cesar Legaspi’s Diggers, 1951; Napoleon Abueva’s Rice Planters, ca 1952; Benedicto Cabrera’s 1970s etchings of Filipino migrants; Vicente Manansala’s Banaklaot, 1948; Lyd Arguilla’s Camia Flowers, 1950; Onib Olmedo’s tempera Singkong-Suka series; and Abdulmari Imao’s three-dimensional bronze rendering of the AAP logo. Nonetheless, the assembly of work also encompasses more idiosyncratic pieces such as Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi’s untitled 1982 oil on cloth with Latin spiritual references; Chabet’s minimalist watercolor Ocho, 1963; Luz’s pieta-like Brown Man, ca 1950s; Abueva’s undated Totem Pole; and Edades’s study done in collaboration with Anita Magsaysay-Ho and Consuelo Lee for a mural commissioned for the Quezon Institute.

Once intended as a bequest to the Museum of Philippine Art, the collection has reverted to Kalaw-Ledesma’s surviving family who have honored her desire to broaden Philippine art’s public by loaning these works to institutions for exhibition and by opening up access to Kalaw-Ledesma’s archive of materials from her travels and seminal years as presiding leader of the longest-running art organization in the countryWritten byEileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Source:

Kalaw-Ledesma Foundation and Ayala Foundation 2010

PURUGANAN, RICARTE (Ricarte Madamba Puruganan) b. Dingras, Ilocos Norte 20 Nov 1912. d. 1998. Painter. The son of Honorio Puruganan and Victoria Madamba, he married Victorina Soles with whom he had nine children. He graduated from the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1936. In 1940, he entered the University of Santo Tomas (UST) on a scholarship and earned his bachelor of arts degree after one year. While studying at UST, he joined the fine arts faculty.

Puruganan’s early works like Coming Storm, 1935, and Bullfight, 1942, show his penchant for dynamic composition and movement. This is complemented by his bold strokes and heavy application of paint. Identified by National Artist Victorio Edades as one of the Thirteen Moderns, Puruganan in the 1960s evolved a style that sought to synthesize indigenous Filipino designs with contemporary themes.

Puruganan won first prize for Coming Storm at the National Landscape Competition at Philippine Vistas, 1935; first prize for Safety Breeze, 1937, at the third annual exhibition of the UP President’s Committee on Culture; second prize for Inauguration of the Commonwealth at the UP Los Baños National Historical Painting Contest, 1937; first honorable mention for El Ultimo Galeon (The Last Galleon) in the historical category, and the same prize for Doubting Peter in the religious category at UST’s national art competition, 1941. In 1943, during the Japanese period, he garnered first and second prizes for Bullfight at the first National Art Competition, and first prize for One December Morning, 1943, at the literary and art contest held during the celebration of the Foundation Day of Manila. In 1944, he participated in the 2nd National Art Contest, but his two works, Mass Burial of Heroes at Capas and Railroad Scene, were reportedly disqualified for their anti-Japanese sentiments (Kulay Diwa Gallery, n.d.c). He also won the following prizes at the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines–Manila Club Exhibition of 1949: first prize for Neighbors, third prize for Suburban, and honorable mention for Father and Son, all in the watercolor category.

In 2012, the UST Museum held an exhibit on Puruganan and fellow modernist Botong Francisco titled Botong and Puruganan: A Double Centennial Tribute, while in 2014, the Ilocos Norte government, in cooperation with the collector-director of Pinto Art Museum Dr Joven Cuanang, presented an exhibition titled Ricarte Puruganan: The Filipino as Modernist at the Paseo de Paoay, Ilocos Norte.Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Adriano 2015; Dioquino 2012; Inquirer.net 2014b; Kulay Diwa Gallery, n.d.c.

QUERUBIN, NELFA (Nelfa Amante Querubin-Tompkins) b. Concepcion, Iloilo 24 Aug 1941. Potter, printmaker. She is the daughter of Melchiades Querubin and Natividad Amante. She lives in Colorado with her husband, Michael Tompkins. She studied at the Iloilo School of Arts and Trade and the Philippine Women’s University. She was an illustrator at age 14, and was largely self-taught in painting. In Manila, while working as architectural draftsman from 1965 to 1973 in a government agency, she was active in printmaking workshops of the Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP), working closely with Manuel Rodriguez Sr and Brenda Fajardo. She explored various techniques in the graphic arts including etching and aquatint, collagraphs, and linocut, doing a variety of themes in abstract expressionist style.

Although she garnered numerous awards in printmaking, it is in ceramic art that she has excelled most, after working closely with Leonardo Villaroman. In 1973, she decided to work full time as potter, moving back to her Iloilo hometown where she built her own house, workshop, and kiln. There she gathered local clay as material and waste wood as fuel, sharing her talent in the art with friends and kin. To Querubin, firing is the most important technical factor in pottery, such that she developed her own “fire show” technique in kilns she builds herself. She developed formulas of glazes based on arches she gathers from her fireboxes. Often, she applies this thickly on the bisque pieces by pouring, dipping, or brushing, sometimes leaving portions unglazed. Querubin started making black pottery in 1976. The mixture of clay she uses for this is a coarse mass with plenty of iron content. With techniques of slip- coating, rigid burnishing, the right time of drying, and smothering in pulverized cow dung, she produces handsome black pottery.

She moved to Colorado in 1985 where she found influence and inspiration from her new environment. The natural landscape and the changing seasons are echoed in her works of varying texture and color, much like a cross-section of the Earth’s interior.

She held major retrospective exhibitions and projects from the early 2000s, some of which are Forms & Textures and Patterned & Inscribed, both at the UP Vargas Museum, and Terrain in the Ayala Museum in 2013. In 2012, she launched her book titled Peace and Joy in My Real World, which documents her spiritual journey. The book was illustrated by her paintings. In 2015, the book Nelfa Querubin: A Passion for Clay, authored by Patrick Flores and Imelda Endaya, was launched at Galleria Duemila with an accompanying exhibit of her works.

She was awarded first prize etching by the PAP in 1970 for her Power Beyond Human Power. She also won first prize for mixed media in 1969 and first prize for intaglio in 1971, both from the PAP Annual Competition. In 1980, she received a Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines. She also received various awards at art festivals abroad such as a first prize in Ceramics from the Castle Rock Art Festival in Colorado. Written byImelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Love Belle Calimoso

Sources:

Galleria Duemila 2003b; Hounds In Heaven 2013; Mayo 2013; Querubin-Tompkins 2012.

QUINTO, ALMA (Alma Bongolan Quinto) b. Urdaneta, Pangasinan 3 Aug 1961. Visual artist and art educator. She is the daughter of Jose Bernardino Quinto, a musician who used to play in a local orchestra, and Lolita Galliguez Bongolan. Quinto finished a bachelor’s degree in Philippine studies in 1983 and took graduate units in art studies and undergraduate units in the fine arts program at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1998. She also earned art education specialization and preschool education units in 1992 and a teaching certificate in 1988 at the Philippine Normal University. Quinto has served as president of Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan or KASIBULAN and the Philippine Art Educators Association, both nongovernment organizations advocating the empowerment of women and art education in the Philippines.

Quinto is best known for her contributions to the field of art and healing, having worked since 1980 with traumatized children and communities, including survivors of sexual abuse, domestic violence, and disasters, and those living under conflict situations, extreme poverty, mental illness, and other forms of disabilities. With soft sculpture, textile, and needlework as her primary media, she has facilitated arts for healing workshops with girl survivors of abuse for more than a decade, 1995-2008, under the CRIBS Foundation in Marikina City. During the same period, she facilitated visual arts workshops for children and adults at Art in the Park, Quezon Memorial Circle. The insights and experiences she gained from these projects form the foundation and wellspring of the collaborative nature of her art projects. Among these is the House of Comfort Art Project, a work in progress which she started in 2006, aiming to build a collapsible, modular, easy-to-install quilt house made out of grids of dreams from various communities including those from the Philippines, Japan, Korea, and the Middle East. Her appropriation of textile and needlework as primary medium and technique also link her work to art processes associated with women’s art in the Philippines and Asia.

Art empowerment and healing similarly form the main threads of her major works like Ayayam, shown at the 2nd Yokohama Triennale, 2005; Soft Dreams and Bed Stories, shown at the 8th Havana Biennial, 2003, at her solo show at the University of Santo Tomas Museum of Arts and Sciences, and at Henie Onstad Kunstsenter, Norway, 2004; the House of Comfort Art Project, shown in solo exhibitions at the University of the Philippines Galeria 1, 2007, and the Osaka Prefectural Women’s Center, 2008; the Nothing to Declare exhibition at Yuchengco Museum in Makati, 2011; the Women-in-Between: Asian Women Artists 1984-2012 traveling exhibition in Fukuoka Asian Art Museum, Okinawa Prefectural and Art Museum, Tochigi Prefectural Museum, and Mie Prefectural Museum in Japan, 2012-13, and as a solo show titled weDREAMforCHANGE held at the Museum of Three Cultures, Cagayan de Oro City, 2012; and Floating Wombs for the Earth Manual Project shown at the Design and Creative Center Kobe, 2013, and at the Sining Makiling Gallery, UP Los Baños, 2014. Every time these and other works are shown, Quinto conducts workshops, either aiming to train trainers or to facilitate healing of traumatized survivors.

Quinto’s writings have been published in several national and international publications. She also served as speaker and lecturer in various events locally and internationally. Quinto’s art practice is anchored on the notion of creative intervention to human and social traumas. Transcending the traditional role of artist as individual creator, Quinto contributes to the aspect of Philippine art practice in which the artist becomes the facilitator and interlocutor of collaborative works, with the goal of empowering communities in the Philippines. Written byFlaudette May V.Datuin

RAGODON, RODOLFO (Rodolfo Yboa Ragodon) b. Manila 28 Jul 1929. d. Quezon City 28 Apr 2001. Painter. He was the son of Teosilo Ragodon and Eliza Yboa. He married Theodorsia Inez Beltran with whom he has five children. He graduated from the University of the Philippines with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts in 1952. He held one-person shows at the Philippine ArtGallery in 1962 and the Luz Gallery in 1970. In 1967, UNESCO gave him a travel grant to Europe and Mexico. He taught Asian History at the Lyceum of the Philippines, and worked as artist in the Sunday Times Magazine. He became director of the Ayala Museum during its founding phase.

His distinctive paintings of old Spanish churches inthePhilippines in the 1960s became the hallmark of his artistic career, as he rendered these in elegant, realistic style. This came to be later emulated by younger artists interested in the subject of nostalgia and antiquities.

Church of Daraga, 1966, is an oil painting on wood done in fine linearity and delicate washes of blue, ocher, and black set against an immaculately plain white background. This depiction of a traditional subject through a single-image approach to space was an innovation in painting at the time Ragodon developed this. It was a device akin to literal representation associated with American pop and magic realism of the 1960s. Church in Lana, 1971, was another work done in convincing photo-realistic manner set against a blank background as this further exemplified this new tendency.

An accomplished landscape painter, Ragodon also utilized ink, tempera, and watercolor. Sometimes, he combined Chinese calligraphic techniques with his unique personal skill in capturing photographic likeness, such as in his Spanish Landscapes series of 1967. His Norte España (Northern Spain), 1967, consists of delineated and contrasting horizontals and vertical planes, with light and shade, textural richness of earthenware rooftops, and plastered walls amidst an architectural landscape finely crafted in brown ink wash.

Ragodon received the Ten Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines award for art in 1964. Written byImelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Sources:

Heritage Art Center 2011c; Inquirer.net 2013a; Philippine Trivia, n.d.; Pinoyarte.com, n.d.b.

RAMBOYONG, ANTONIO (Antonio Ramboyong Corporal) b. Iriga, Camarines Sur 27 Sep 1946. Painter. Antonio’s parents are Elias Corporal and Adelaida Ramboyong. He obtained his elementary education from La Consolacion Academy and St. Anthony Academy. He also finished high school in the latter. He took up preparatory engineering at the University of Santo Tomas in 1963, then studied fine arts at the University of the East from 1966 to 1970. He staged his first three one-person shows at the Solidaridad Gallery in 1971, 1972, and 1974. He opened his 10th solo exhibition at the Manila Garden Hotel.

Ramboyong is identified with the pure abstract movement of the early 1970s. But his works gained particular recognition for his use of acrylic or oil on aluminum sheet, as influenced mainly by the same finish on the anting-anting (amulet). On the metal sheet, Ramboyong would raise geometric shapes like circles, triangles or fusions of forms from the surface by incising and hammering. He enriched these designs by adding color. The contemporariness of his works lie in the impersonal rigidness of the arrangement of the shapes, and the cold feel of the aluminum sheet. In Sixteen Squares, 1971, for example, the artist arranged 16 squares which in turn are set in a circle at the center of the painting’s square surface. In the 1980s, Ramboyong rejected his own early rigid format, filling up his aluminum surface with wide sweeps of lines uniformly repeated to evoke palm leaves as in Diptych: Twin Growth, 1987.

Ramboyong won prizes at the Shell National Students Art Competition: fifth prize for painting for his work Field Machines at Rest in 1967; and first honorable mention for Beat, certificate of merit for Diptych: Forms in Space, and second prize for on-the-spot painting in 1968. Another work, City, won second prize in the annual exhibition sponsored by the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines in 1980. In 1976, he also won first prize for his painting Labuyo sa Umaga (Rooster in the Morning) at the art contest sponsored by the Philippine National Bank during its 60th Anniversary. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

RAMIREZ, CLARO (Claro Alberto Jarme Ramirez Jr) aka Chitz Ramirez. b. Pasay City 23 Apr 1965. Multimedia artist and curator. He is the son of Claro Augusto Ramirez and Angelita Jarme. He is married to Eileen Legaspi, an art scholar, curator, and critic. Ramirez began his formal art studies at the University of Santo Tomas where he earned a certificate in commercial arts in 1985. He then went on to finish a studio arts degree, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1991. He apprenticed under Cesar Legaspi, and was informally mentored by conceptual artist Roberto Chabet Rodriguez and curator Bobi Valenzuela.

Ramirezexplores and investigatesthe use of space as integral in theprocess and production of his art.This led him toproduce multimedia installations employing elements from traditional painting and sculpture to new media.His interest in space and the participative aspect of installation arthas led to the making of site-specific pieces that demonstrate how meaning might be created through engagements between artworks and visitors, and the artists themselves. This is demonstrated in his work titled eachmineallmine done for the 2000 CCP Thirteen Artists exhibition. The titling of the piece was deliberately handed over to fellow artist Yason Banal, and the installation involved asking other artist-colleaguesto contribute elements to make up the collaborative work whose spatial armature consisted of cardboard packing tubes installed as faux wall-piercing and as viewing surfaces rigged with a peephole and lit by motion sensors activated by those entering and moving through the exhibit space. The artist explains that the work metaphorically evokestheidea of a playful“chasing after art.” Ramirez isknown for working with multimedia,industrial-mechanical materials, found sound and video, and electronics in his installations.

His solo exhibitions in the Philippines include Wanted: Tubero (Wanted: Plumber), 2011; No Pay per View, 2009; No Rhyme Nor Reason, 2005; Hang Up, 2004; Deepenetration, 2002; Tampulan (Target), 2000; Bagay? Bagay (Object? Object), 1998; Recent Work, 1997; and Palliative, 1996. He has also shown his work internationally in a solo exhibition titled Dayo (Outsider), Vermont, USA, 1997, and in group exhibitions such as the Jakarta Biennale, 2011; the Changwon Asian Art Festival, South Korea, 2008; Asian Comments, Copenhagen, Denmark, 2002; City Transformers, Gdansk, Poland, 2002; Bangladesh Biennale, Dhaka, Bangladesh, 2001; and the Second Fax Art Biennale, Reykjavik, Iceland, 1998.

Ramirez was artistic director for exhibitions and new media projects for the Lopez Museum. He art directed exhibitions for Japan Foundation, Goethe Institut, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines between 2005 and 2012. He served as curator for the Philippines in international projects like Singapore Art Biennale, 2013; Video Art Exchange, 2012, Tromso, Norway; Nothing to Declare, 2011, Makati, Metro Manila; and Riverscapes in Flux, a project that traveled across Cambodia, Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines in 2011-12. He is also the artistic director of the independent platform Back to Square 1/Juan.

Ramirez was awarded residency grants at Centrul de Cultura Geoge Enescu, Tescani, Romania, 2006; D. Fleiss East West Artists, Bacau Romania, 2006; and the Vermont Studio Center, 1999 and 1996. He received the Juror’s Choice award, painting category, at the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Competition in 1995 and the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2000. Written byClod Marlan Krister Yambao

RARALIO, DAN (Dan Agatep Raralio) b. Manila 16 Jan 1961. Sculptor. He is the son of Vicente Raralio Sr and Teresa Agatep. His wife Edna is a sculptor. He was educated at the University of the Philippines (UP) on the primary, secondary, and tertiary levels. He graduated with a bachelor of fine arts degree from UP in 1983. He taught sculpture at the UP College of Fine Arts from 1990 to 1995. Showing prodigious talent early on, he staged his first one-person show at the UP Elementary School at age 13.

Essentially a modernist sculptor, he does not reject the classical tradition as a source of his imagery. He appropriates motifs and forms from Graeco-Roman sculpture with a pop sensibility, projecting their sleek classical quality to embody the alienation of the contemporary world. Raralio is a minimalist, capitalizing on the raw crude qualities of the medium he fancies to play up its hidden aesthetic potential.

Raralio was chosen to represent the Philippines in the show Marble and Sound held in Serbia, Yugoslavia, 1990. His solo exhibitions include those at the Art Student League Gallery, New York, 1991, 1994, and 1999; and the West Gallery, 1992, 1993, 1995, 1997, 2000, and 2001. In 2009, his exhibition Fish Out of Water: Dan Raralio New Works was held at Paseo Gallery, Mandaluyong.

Raralio’s Faceless Surface got an honorable mention from the Metrobank Foundation in 1986. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1988. In 1997, he received an Award of Excellence at the Third Oita Asian Sculpture Exhibition Open Competition in Japan. In 1995, he received the award for Most Promising Design at the Manila FAME KATHA Awards. In 2001, he won second prize in the Asian artist fellowship sculpture category in the Annual Art Competition of the Art Association of the Philippines. In 2003-4, he received the Freeman Foundation Asian Artist Fellowship given by the Vermont Studio Center, USA. In 2004, he was awarded the Metrobank Foundation Prize for Achievement in Sculpture with his pieces mostly composed of synthetic marble and metal. In 2004, he was awarded the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for sculpture by the city of Manila. In 2009, he was awarded the Metrobank Foundation Award for Continuing Excellence and Service. He was one of the 10 winners for Metro manila in the 2009-10 Philippine Art Awards with his winning work Brain Drain. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Galleria Duemila 2013a; Malaya 2009; Snippets from the Manila Art Scene 2009a.
Ravelo, Mars (See LITERATURE volume.)

REAMILLO, ALWIN (Alwin Viros Reamillo) aka Arnulfo Tikbang. b. Manila 25 Nov 1964. Installation, performance, mixed media artist. He is the son of retired government employee Marietta Macalalag Viros and Decimo Zabala Reamillo, who was a piano maker previously with Javincello & Company Inc. Reamillo was married to Australian artist Juliet Rea. Reamillo majored in painting at the University of the Philippines Diliman College of Fine Arts, 1981-85. He began his art practice as a visual arts teacher at the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) in Mount Makiling, Los Baños, Laguna, a school for gifted students in the arts. As state scholars, these students majored in the various fields of art. Reamillo himself majored in the visual arts at PHSA, 1977-81. He earned units under the master of arts in visual arts program of the Western Australia School of Visual Arts, Western Australia Academy of Performing Arts, Edith Cowan University, Perth.

Reamillo’s performative process involves play, improvisation, and a collaborative pedagogical method he terms creative bayanihan, a Filipino term that refers to the traditional community networking and support system. This practice draws inspiration from the German artist Joseph Beuys’s concept of social sculpture. Beuys was motivated by a utopian belief in the power of art to instigate change. Reamillo’s collaborative projects take place in mobile and community workshops that mobilize a range of mediums that intersect in many interesting ways: mixed media painting, sculpture, installation, shadow puppetry, video, and performance.

Shuttling between the Philippines and Australia, where he migrated in 1995, his art pieces and collaborations explore ideas about memory, mobility, and cross-cultural dialogue/exchange, colonization, migration, and globalization. These themes and processes created a number of participatory “social sculptures” in the form of “vehicles/vessels/crafts,” exemplified by the Thuringowa Helicopter Project, 2007-10, held and shown in several venues such as The Substation, Melbourne, and Stokes Hill Wharf / Festival of Darwin; Making It New: Focus on Contemporary Australian Art, 2009, Museum of Contemporary Art, Sydney; and plAAy / Contemporary Asian Artist Residency Programme, Blackburn Museum and Art Gallery, United Kingdom. Another major project involves the reconstruction of the grand piano from the now-defunct piano factory that his father co-founded, restaged as Mang Emo + Mag-himo Grand Piano Project, at the Galleria Duemila, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), and the Fremantle Arts Centre, Western Australia, 2007.

A number of Reamillo’s performances have also been driven by his inclination toward evoking participation with earlier work consisting of collaborations with artists such as Rene Aquitania and Jean Marie Syjuco. Reamillo’s performance pieces have been part of such key performance art festivals as Asiatopia, Thailand; The Future of Imagination, Singapore; and the Philippine International Performance Art Festival. Reamillo has shown extensively in national and international exhibitions, collaboration projects, and artists residencies in Japan, Australia, Hong Kong, Italy, Cuba, Mexico, Germany, Singapore, and New Zealand. He pursued a long-standing collaboration with Juliet Rea beginning 1993 through an artistic partnership dubbed Reamillo and Juliet. Reamillo received the Western Australia Mid-Career Fellowship in 2009; the Freeman Foundation for Asian Artist Fellowship, Vermont Studio Center, USA in 1996; and the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1994. Written byFlaudette May V. Datuin

REDONDO, NESTOR b. Candon, Ilocos Sur 5 Apr 1928. d. Los Angeles, California 30 Sep 1995. Cartoonist, writer. He took up architecture at the Mapua Institute of Technology. He was exposed to the medium at an early age when his father used to bring him imported funnies. He deftly imbibed the techniques of his favorite American illustrators and in no time shifted from a mere komiks reader to komiks illustrator. This transition was relatively easy as his involvement in the art heightened. Soon he was illustrating a serial, Palos (Eel), penned by his brother Virgilio. This was so successful that it ran for 14 years. It was followed by other stories of Virgilio which Nestor illustrated, among them, Diwani and Gagamba (Spider). He also did the artwork for most of PabloS.Gomez’s opuses: Gilda, Bangkusay, Dayukdok (Addicted).

Redondo’s popularity peaked when he was commissioned to illustrate MarsRavelo’s Darna. He had by then developed an illustrative style which so appealed to readers that a whole generation of komiks artists tried to emulate it.

In 1963, together with Tony Caravana, Alfredo Alcala, JimFernandez, Amado Castillo, and his brother Virgilio, he founded CRAF Publications. He also put up ARES Publications Inc, which became the training home for would-be komiks illustrators. Redondo’s publishing ventures waned, however, during the turbulent late 1960s and 1970s.

In 1972, through US-based Filipino komiks illustrator Tony Zuñiga, Redondo’s works got international exposure. Redondo initially illustrated several episodes of Edgar Burrough’s Tarzan. Later he took over the artwork for The Swamp Thing, a popular American series.

Refusing to migrate to the United States, he put up his own studio in his Valenzuela home, and continued to accept commissions from US publishing firms like the National Periodical Publications, the Pendulum Press, and the Dykeman Studio.

In 1975, he became one of the founding members of Lakan Sining ng Bulacan, an organization of Bulacan painters headed by Tomas Bernardo. He started painting at about this time and was commissioned by the Mass Media Production Center to do the covers of pocketbooks. He also founded the Association of National Illustrators with AngelCacnio, Noly Panaligan, Romy Mananquil, and Domy Gutierrez.

Redondo participated in art exhibits in the Philippines and the United States, and conducted lectures abroad. He received international recognition as an illustrator, and in 1979 was bestowed the prestigious Inkpot Award by the San Diego (California) Comics Convention. Before this, he also received the Valenzuela Kalikasan Award for his outstanding contribution to the advancement of arts and culture as a komiks illustrator. Written byC. Roxas and J. Arevalo, updated by Robert Daniel Devela

Sources: Lambiek Comiklopedia 2012;

RESURRECCION HIDALGO, FELIX (Felix Padilla Resurreccion Hidalgo) b. Binondo, Manila 21 Feb 1855. d. Sarrea, Spain 13 Mar 1913. Painter. He was the third of seven children of Eduardo Resurreccion Hidalgo, landed proprietor and lawyer, and Maria Barbara Padilla, entrepreneur. He studied in the University of Santo Tomas where his artistry was encouraged by Father Sabater. He studied law, which he never finished, received a bachiller en filosofia (bachelor of philosophy) in Mar 1871. He was simultaneously enrolled at the Escuela de Dibujo y Pintura under Spanish painter Agustin Saez. In 1876, he previewed his La Banca (The Native Boat), Vendadora de Lanzones (Lanzones Vendor), and other paintings at the TeatroCircodeBilibid before they were sent to the Philadelphia Universal Exposition of that year. In 1878, he painted the poignant and well-crafted LosMendigos (The Beggars).

In 1877, Resurreccion Hidalgo was awarded second place in the contest for best cover design for the deluxe edition of Fr Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas (Plants of the Philippines). In 1879, he left for Spain as a pensionado in fine arts of the Ayuntamiento of Manila. He attended the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando de Madrid whose courses he described in a letter to JoseRizal as obsolete and boring. During this period he exhibited La Siesta (Nap in the Afternoon), 1881, a piece favorably reviewed in La Ilustracion Española y Americana in that year.

In 1879, he went to Rome, still as a pensionado, where he finished a portrait, Senador Romano (Roman Senator), and others. In 1883, he toured Spain rejoining his patron and close friend Francisco de Yriarte in Galicia. There, he pitched a tent to study nature more closely. He then moved to Paris for further studies with the partial support of de Yriarte.

His Las Virgenes Cristianas Expuestas al Populacho (Christian Virgins Exposed to the Populace) was awarded the ninth silver medal at the 1884 Exposicion General de Bellas Artes (General Exposition of Fine Arts) in Madrid. This showed a group of boorish looking males mocking seminaked female slaves, one of whom is seated in the foreground, with head bowed in misery. In the same exposition Luna’s Spoliarium was awarded the first gold medal.

In the Exposicion General de las Islas Filipinas (General Exposition of the Philippine Islands) in Madrid in 1887, Resurreccion Hidalgo presented La Barca de Aqueronte (The Boat of Charon), 1887, and Laguna Estigia (The River Styx), 1887, for which he received a gold medal. La Barca was again shown at the Exposition Universelle de Paris (Universal Exposition in Paris) and was awarded a silver medal by an international jury. In 1891, it was accorded a diploma de honor (diploma of honor) at the Exposicion General de Bellas Artes (General Exposition of Fine Arts) of Barcelona. A year later, this painting also received a gold medal in the Exposicion Internacional de Bellas Artes (International Exposition of Fine Arts) in Madrid during the commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the discovery of America. It was finally bought for 7,500 pesetas by the Spanish government and ordered hung in the principal saloon of the Museo-Biblioteca de Ultramar, passing afterward to the Museo Nacional de Pinturas de Madrid after the archipelago became a territory of the United States.

He also exhibited Adios al Sol (Farewell to the Sun), 1892, at the Exposicion Internacional de Bellas Artes in Madrid in that year. In 1893, he sent El Crepusculo (The Dawn) to the Universal Exposition of Chicago. He showed both again at the Exposicion Artistica de Bilbao (Art Exposition in Bilbao) in Aug 1894. In the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in Manila in Jan 1895, Resurreccion Hidalgo was represented by paintings done in the grand romantic manner. In April of the same year he exhibited Oedipus y Antigone (Oedipus and Antigone), El Violinista (The Violinist), Cabeza Napolitana (Head of a Neapolitan), Cabeza del Viejo (Head of an old Man), Un Religioso (A Religious), and others at the Salon at Champs Elysees, Paris.

Among the canvases he executed for the Spanish colonial government in return for his study grant are Governor Luis Perez Dasmariñas and His Dominican Advisor, Guerreros Filipinos Velando la Tumba de su Jefe (Filipino Warriors Guarding the Tomb of Their Chief), 1890, and The Defeat of Limahong, 1892. The second showed a tribal setting, and the first and third were historical paintings of large dimensions. His Greek Philosopher at Work, 1889, La Enferma (The Invalid), 1900, and Per Pacem et Libertatem (Through Peace and Liberty), 1904, all life-size pieces, used to hang in the National Museum then called National Gallery of Art in Manila. A major and controversial mural is the El Asesinato del Gobernador Fernando Bustamante y su Hijo (The Assassination of Governor Fernando Bustamante and Son) aka La Iglesia Contra el Estado (Church versus State), which shows friars murdering the governor. This painting has since been declared a National Cultural Treasure in 1974, and belongs to the art collection of the National Museum of the Philippines.

Resurreccion Hidalgo received a gold medal for his overall participation at the Universal Exposition in Saint Louis, Missouri, in 1904. His El Violinista was individually accorded a gold medal. In 1912, he visited his relatives in Manila for six months, after which he hurried back to Paris. His mother, who had not seen him for 30 years, wanted him to be with her in her last days, but he had to leave.

The following year, Resurreccion Hidalgo died at Sarrea, near Barcelona, where he went to recuperate from failing health. His remains were brought to Manila, where it now lies entombed in the Hidalgo family mausoleum at the Cementerio del Norte.

The works of Resurreccion Hidalgo have been exhibited at the Lopez Museum and Metropolitan Museum in Manila, specifically the exhibit Oro Plata (Gold Silver), 1989, which gave importance to the historical and artistic contributions of Luna and Resurreccion Hidalgo. Publications on the life and works of Resurreccion Hidalgo includes Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo & The Generation of 1872 by Alfredo Roces, published in 1998 by the Eugenio Lopez Foundation. Written bySantiago A. Pilar and E. Arsenio Manuel, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz

REYES, CID (Cesar Victor Pangilinan Reyes) b. Pasig City 28 Jul 1946. Painter, creative director, art critic. He is the son of Augusto Raymundo Reyes and Humilde Pangilinan. He is married to Mary Ann Beldie, with whom he has four children. Reyes finished a bachelor of arts, major in sociology, at De La Salle University, Manila, in 1966. He earned a painting and studio arts degree at the Accademia di Belle Arti in Rome, 1973-74, as a scholar of the Italian government, and art history at the City Lit Institute in London, 1975-78. Reyes worked as creative director and advertising executive at Commerce Advertising, 1967; Hontiveros Advertising, 1968-69; and Ace Compton/Saatchi, 1970-2011. He manages the El Cid Advertising Agency. He served as president of the Art Critics Association of the Philippines in 1990.

As a visual artist, Reyes has mounted over 12 solo art exhibitions since 1969. His artworks adhere to an abstract modernist aesthetic, which began as hard-edged abstractions in the 1970s and developed into highly amorphous shapes done using airbrush techniques in 2011. Throughout his art career, he has focused on a bright palette composed of primary color combinations (red, yellow, and blue) contrasted with white.

As a writer and art critic, Reyes wrote a column titled “Gallery Hopping,” 1995-2005, for the national daily Today. He is a contributor of the Philippine Daily Inquirer. He also had a column titled “The Bigger Picture” at Adobo Magazine, 2005-13. As author and editor of books on Philippine art and culture, Reyes’s bibliography includes Malang: Paintings and Drawings, 1981; Conversations on Philippine Art, 1989; Arturo Luz, 1999; Herencia: The BPI Art Collection, 2005; Philippines, 2007; J. Elizalde Navarro, 2008; Abueva, 2010; and MADE of Gold, 2013. He also coauthored books such as Art Philippines, 1992, and Ben Cab, 2002. Reyes popularized a mode of writing art history directed at ordinary readers through the use of the interview format that dissects an artist’s style, concepts, and beliefs about identity and aesthetics. As creative director, Reyes was also responsible for many recognizable slogans and concepts for Philippine advertising campaigns from the 1980s. These include the “laba dami, labango” (lots of laundry, smells good) tag, as well as the “huwag maging dayuhan sa sariling bayan” (don’t be a stranger in your own country) tag.

Reyes received the Art Criticism Award from the Art Association of the Philippines in 1979; Art Critic of the Year Award from Art Quarterly Manila in 2001, 2002, and 2003; and the Lifetime Achievement Award in Creativity from the Creative Guild in 2007. He is also a regular juror for the Metrobank Art Competitions, the now-defunct Government Service and Insurance System Art Contest, the Petron Art Contest, and the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian and Reuben Ramas Cañete

Sources:

Cid Reyes Travel & Tours 2014; Reyes 2014b.

REYES, FRANCISCO (Francisco Reyes Reyes)b. Mandaluyong, Rizal 4 Oct 1910. d. Mandaluyong 1990. Cartoonist, painter. He was the son of Petronilo Magdaleno Reyes and Hilariona Reyes. Reyes’s mother came from a family of painters and church cantores (singers). He took up his early education in his town, secondary schooling at Manila East High School (now Mapa), and fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP). He entered UP in 1928, graduating in 1932. While studying, he obtained two medals in the Drawing from Life I and II classes taught by Pablo and FernandoAmorsolo, respectively, and another medal in illustration and commercial design.

Although mainly known for serialized comic stories, the artist also produced oil canvases. His portraits and landscapes in the 1930s showed influences of FabiandelaRosa and Fernando Amorsolo. During this period many of his paintings and editorial illustrations appeared in Graphic and Liwayway. In 1984, after his retirement from magazine and comic illustration, he resumed painting genre and nude pieces with fine realism and a penchant for bright hues.

Reyes is mainly remembered for Kulafu, an adventure serialized in comics magazines starting in 1933. For Kulafu, Reyes collaborated with another Reyes, Pedrito, who wrote the stories. In 1935, after Pedrito took on another job, Francisco became both narrator and illustrator of the series. This serial lasted for eight years until the outbreak of the war. Francisco also illustrated Teodoro Virrey’s Kilabot (Dread) for Silahis Comics; Talahib (Cogon Grass), 1946; Kilabot, 1947; Buhawi (Tornado), 1947; and Mahiwagang Sinulid (Mysterious Thread), 1949, which is based on a local folktale. He also illustrated ClodualdodelMundo’s Jose Safari, 1947; Ogganda, 1964; Dagog, 1967; and Sphinx, 1969.Written by Santiago A. Pilar

RICIO, NIK (Nicanor Castillo Ricio Jr) b. Santiago, Isabela 25 Nov 1946. d. 9 Jan 2014. Graphic designer, painter. He was the son of Nicanor Ricio Sr and Julia Castillo. He graduated in 1967 from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts. In the same year he finished school, Ricio soon started working as a visualizer for advertising and eventually moved up and became art director. His stint in New York soon earned him enough expertise in the field of graphic design. After 10 years in the business, he established his own design company in 1977—the Nik Ricio Studio, which handles specialized services in graphic design, photography, and production design.

Nik is known for his work in the field of graphic design for print media, specifically book designing. Some of the more noteworthy coffee-table books designed by Ricio are The Culinary Culture of the Philippines, 1976; The Streets of Manila, 1977; PhilippineDance, 1978; Turn of the Century, 1978; Dances of the Emerald Isles, 1980; Fiesta, 1980; History of the Burgis, 1987; Blanco: A Family of Artists, 1987; Filipino Hospitality, 1990; and Soul Book, 1991. His major work of book design is the 10-volume Kasaysayan: The Story of the Filipino People, 1998.

Ricio mainly painted commissioned works. His style generally geared toward art nouveau, mostly flora and fauna, which have attracted a number of private and institutional commissions. He used both three-dimensional media as well as computer graphics in designing brochures, pamphlets, handbills, posters, and restaurant menus.

Ricio won awards at the Shell National Students Art Competition: certificate of merit, Sungka (Bantumi), 1964; certificate of merit, Bad Faith, 1964; first prize, The Manila Cathedral, 1965; first prize, Threefold Path, 1966; certificate of merit, Community Cleanliness, 1966; certificate of merit, Lifeline, 1967; and fifth prize, Chinese Garden, 1967. Written byRachel Mayo

RIVERA, ALAN (Alan Alfon Rivera) b. Cebu 17 Sep 1941. d. 13 May 2015. Multimedia and installation artist. He was the son of fictionist Estrella Alfon and retired army major Bernardino Rivera. Rivera took courses in advertising art while pursuing a degree in architecture at the University of Santo Tomas (UST). While in UST, he studied under Roberto Chabet who introduced him to installation and conceptual art. Dropping out of school in 1967, Rivera went into photography, book illustration, set and props design for film, film production, acting, graphic art, advertising, and writing. His first employment was at the Design Center of the Philippines, 1975-76, as writer and liaison officer. This was followed by jobs in advertising and graphic design until 1991 when he decided to be a full-time painter and a freelance graphic designer. He aligned himself with groups like the Starving Artists and joined group shows such as Artists in Revolt and Manning the Barricades.

Ever the experimenter, Rivera’s earlier painting explored the medium of paint and collage. The first painting he sold was an abstract nude consisting of crumpled newsprint pressed together on a wet canvas. Alan was later attracted to Zen philosophy and its minimalism. His later works relied heavily on the use of indigenous materials, such as twine and rocks, often seen suspended from the ceiling. An artist’s residency in Australia in 1992 enabled him to explore the nuances of form, using found objects which resonated with deep spiritual themes. At the later part of his life, he began a series of self-portraits chronicling the downward spiral of his health.

Rivera’s roster of solo and group exhibits include Sikat: Twenty Years of Philippine Art (Shine/Famous: Twenty Years of Philippine Art), 1989, Bulwagang Juan Luna (also known as Main Gallery) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Solstice: My Life in the Resistance (Save the Planet), 1991, Sining Kamalig compound; Art Lab, 1991, Art Lab Gallery; Art in Progress, 1991, Kanlungan ng Sining Gallery; Kilusang Katutubong Sining (Indigenous Art Movement), 1992, Alliance Française Gallerie; 101 Monks Contemplating the Gospel According to Zen, 1992, Alliance Française Gallerie; Biyaheng Timog Patungong Kanluran (Journey to the South Going West), 1992, a two-man exhibit with Alwin Reamillo at the Australian Center Gallery in Makati; 14 Nautical Miles, 1992; Makabago, Alternatibo at Katutubong Sining (Modern, Alternative and Indigenous Art), 1993, West Gallery; Migrante (Migrant), 1993, CCP Main Gallery; Art Manila ’93 AIDS Group Show, 1993, Philam Life Building; Tugmaan: The Ties That Bind (Matching: The Ties That Bind), 1994; Storytellers and Small Works Show, both held 1995 in the USA; Virtual Landscapes in the Spirit of Zen, 1997 and 2003, Ayala Museum; Artopus ’98: Hilaga ug Sur, 1998, Ayala Tower 1 Lobby; All in the Spirit of Zen: A Place of Worship, 1998, Museo de Iloilo; Fast Forward to 2000 and Labintatlo: 13 Artists Survey Exhibition, CCP, 1998.

The CCP honored him with the Thirteen Artists Award in 1972. In 1992, he was awarded an artist residency by the Northern Territory Contemporary Art Space in Darwin, Australia, resulting in a solo exhibition, The Church of Crucified Forms, and a group show for ARX 3 ’92 (Australia and Regions Exchange 3), an art project held in Perth with the participation of other artists from Southeast Asia, New Zealand, New Caledonia, and Australia. Rivera received the Asian Cultural Council grant in 1994 in New York City. In 2000, he won second place in the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition for his collage work Lao Tzu’s Tao: The Ching No. 33. Written byRachel Mayo and Maria Virginia Ramona Alfon

RIVERA, CENON (Cenon Mangahas Rivera)b. Hagonoy, Bulacan 16 Apr 1922. d. 25 Nov 1998. Painter. He was the son of Pedro Rivera and Placida Mangahas. He married Ma. Teresa Tech. He graduated from Araullo High School and enrolled for a liberal arts course at the University of the Philippines (UP), while taking up some subjects at the School of Fine Arts. While at the UP, VicenteAlvarezDizon influenced him to go into art education. Thus after the war, Rivera entered the University of Santo Tomas (UST), where he finished his bachelor of science degree in art education in 1948. In 1956, he joined the faculty of the UST College of Architecture and Fine Arts, where he was conferred the title Professor Emeritus three years after his retirement in 1994.

In 1962, Rivera received a scholarship from the Italian government to study at the Regge Accademia di Belle Arti. He stayed in Rome for three years, during which he studied stained glass techniques in European cities and trained in mosaic at the official studio of the Vatican. Upon his return, he succeeded VictorioEdades as director of the UST Department of Fine Arts upon the latter’s retirement.

Rivera’s earliest style was influenced by the academic realism of his UP professors, but in 1951 he abandoned realism for semiabstraction. His Wooden Shacks, 1951, shows his attempt at analytic cubism. An early affiliate of the PhilippineArtGallery, Rivera exhibited in many group shows and held his one-person show at this gallery in 1956. His works from 1951 to 1957 are considered his best, characterized by a tightness of composition and sober or muted colors. He evolved a distinct style, blending semiabstract figuration with stained glass and mosaic techniques.

Rivera’s Pond Watchman won an honorable mention in the painting competition of the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines in 1955. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela

Source:

Artes delas Filipinas, n.d.

RIVERA, VICENTE (Vicente Mir Rivera) aka Vicente Rivera y Mir. b. Santa Cruz, Manila 19 Jul 1872. d. 29 May 1954. Painter, illustrator, art educator. He was the son of Cirilo Rivera and Cristina Mir. He finished his studies at the Escuela de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado in 1898. Subsequently, he became an illustrator for the Spanish-language publications El Pajarde Verde, Le Semana, La Peña, La Pavera, El Cosmopolitan, El Cinife, El Comercio, Diario de Manila, La Voz, Española, and La Ilustracion Filipina. With Balbino F. Alpaso and Francisco Muriel, he co-founded the Escuela y Talleres de Escultura on Calle Cervantes in Manila in 1903. This was a private school where students were tutored in art. He was among the co-founding faculty of the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts in 1908.

Rivera was known for his masterful rendering of religious scenes utilizing a classical academic approach. Among his works are Supplication, also known as Woman Devotee and Child, 1939, in which academic strictures of composition using a stable pyramidal form is observed in the rendition of the female supplicant kneeling before a crucifix. The devotee’s expression is both tender and restrained, adhering to the classical aesthetic of balance, order, and harmony. Another painting, now lost, Apparition of the Lady of Lourdes to Bernadette Soubirous, which hung at the Lourdes Church in Intramuros was praised by Fabian de la Rosa in an article written for La Vanguardia. Before World War II, the Dominican Order commissioned Rivera to paint the Dominican martyrs of China, and these images may be found in the University of Santo Tomas Museum. Other extant Rivera paintings include Girl from Cainta, Rizal Province, and Sacred Heart of Jesus, now found at the Jorge B. Vargas Collection.

In 1895, Rivera garnered a Silver medal for two head studies at the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in Manila. He subsequently won a silver medal at the 1904 Saint Louis Universal Exposition for Fisherman at Bangkusay, and a gold medal for Sueño Dorado (Golden Dream) in the art competition sponsored by the Asociacion Internacional de Artistas de Manila in 1908. Written byReuben Ramas Cañete

Sources:

Pilar 1992a; Stangl 2000.

ROCES, ALFREDO (Alfredo Reyes Roces) aka Ding Roces. b. Santa Cruz, Manila 29 Apr 1923. Painter, writer. He is the ninth son of Rafael Roces and Inocencia Reyes. Journalist, civil libertarian, and World War II martyr Rafael Roces Jr aka Liling was his brother as is National Artist for literature Alejandro. Alfredo married Irene Pineda with whom he has three daughters. Belonging to the prominent Roces clan of publishers and educators, he obtained his fine arts degree from the University of Notre Dame in Indiana, USA. He took further studies at the Art Students League of New York, USA, under the famed German expatriate artist Goerge Grosz. Since then, he has held numerous one-man shows, including those in the National Library; the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines, where he had two shows—the first, a 20-year retrospective of drawings, and the second where he made use of pottery as relief works post-EDSA Revolt—and another at the Philippine Consulate in Sydney, Australia. A versatile artist, he has branched out into pottery, photography, and book design in Sydney, Australia, where he is based.

Roces also wrote many articles on art for various international magazines and a daily column, Light and Shadow, which ran in the Manila Times for more than 10 years. He served as editor in chief of the 10-volume encyclopedia Filipino Heritage, 1977, published by the Hamlyn Group of Sydney, Australia. He wrote the pioneering book on National Artist FernandoAmorsolo, Amorsolo 1975; a historical survey, The Filipino Nude, 1977; and a book on JuvenalSanso, called Sanso, 1977. With the American historian Alfred McCoy, he put out the first book on Philippine cartoons of the American period, Philippine Cartoons 1900-1945, 1985. This was followed by a second one covering the Marcos regime, titled Medals and Shoes, 1991, which was co-written with his wife. He has also written Legaspi: The Making of a National Artist, 1993, and Phyllis Zaballero, 2013. For 12 years until retirement, he served as editor of Geo, Australia’s Geographical Magazine in Sydney. In 2009, Roces collaborated with Aboriginal artist Kevin Duncan to do The Sari Manok & the Rainbow Serpent: 5Lands Walk, an earthwork exhibit commissioned by the Gosford City Council, which showcased Filipino and Australian aboriginal cultures.

Among his many distinctions and awards are Ten Outstanding Young Men Award, 1961; Journalist of the Year Award, 1971, from the Citizens Council for Mass Media; honorable mention for the work Holy Water Foundation in the ArtAssociationofthePhilippines (AAP) competition, 1961; grand prize in painting for Kundiman at the 25th AAP annual exhibition, 1972; Artist of the Year Award from the AAP, 1974; and the ManilaCriticsCircle National Book Award, 1993, for Legaspi. In 2014, Roces was honored with the Pamana ng Pilipino Award of the Presidential Awards, a biennial award created in 1991 for “Filipinos overseas who have exemplified the talent and industry of Filipinos, and have brought the country honor and recognition through excellence and distinction in the pursuit of their work or profession.” Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Roberto Daniel Devela?Sources: Filipin-Oz 2014; Lippi 2013; Roces-Santos 2015.

ROCHA, LORENZO (Lorenzo de Icaza Rocha) b. Manila 11 Aug 1837. d. Manila 20 Oct 1898. Painter. Lorenzo’s parents were Antonio Rocha y Tuason, a Spanish-Chinese mestizo businessman, and Guadalupe de Icaza, a Philippine-born Spaniard. In 1871, he married Maria Rosario Ruiz Delgado, with whom he had five children.

He was one of the first enrollees at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura when it reopened in 1850. For a time, Lorenzo left the school, enrolled at the Escuela Nautica and obtained a naval degree. Then in 1855, he returned to his art studies. He was hailed as “most outstanding student” and made assistant director. In that year, the Junta de Comercio, the school’s sponsor, organized a contest for the best painting by a Spaniard and an indio (Christianized native). Rocha won the award together with his indio classmate and namesake LorenzoGuerrero; he, for his portrait of Isabel II, the reigning queen, and Guerrero, for his portrait of Ferdinand Magellan. Each won 150 pesos and the honor to have their works displayed permanently at the Junta de Comercio’s session hall. In 1857, Rocha won in the open competition for the directorship of the Academia, which was vacated by Nicolas Valdes. But in 1858, Agustin Saez arrived from Spain to fill in the job. Rocha in turn received a four-year scholarship grant to study at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in Madrid. His work pleased his teachers such that they recommended him to the Royal Palace. The Infante Don Francisco had him appointed Painter to the Royal Chamber of Her Majesty. During this stint, the Marquesa de Montijo asked him to paint two portraits of her daughter, the duchess of Alba, one for herself, and another for her other daughter, Empress Marie Eugenie of France. In 1867, he entered El Ensueño de Don Ramiro en la Batalla de Clavijo (The Dream of Don Ramiro in the Battle of Clavijo) at the Madrid Salon, which won him an honorable mention. He came back to Manila in Sep 1867, eventually setting up home in Intramuros. While still in Madrid, he actively sought the directorship of the Academia held by Agustin Saez. In the end, Saez and Rocha were made professors of equal rank in the school.

In 1880, Rocha introduced an art course at the Escuela Normal de Maestros. In 1889, the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura was transformed into the Escuela de Dibujo, Pintura y Grabado with the Escuela de Artes y Oficios incorporated with it, and Saez and Rocha jointly supervising. In 1891, Saez died, leaving Rocha as sole director of the school. In 1893, the school became the Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado and was directed by Rocha till his death in 1898.

Only one work by Rocha seems to have survived, a life-size Yndia Filipina, now hanging at the Museo de Bellas Artes in Cordoba, Spain. Only his highly detailed portrait of Josefa Angeles was documented photographically before World War II but this did not survive the war. Written byLuciano P. R. Santiago

ROCHA, RENATO (Renato Autor Rocha) b. Uson, Masbate 8 Mar 1937. d. 24 Aug 2001. Sculptor Renato was the son of Ramon Rocha, who made business out of his boats, and Consuelo Autor, who was a housewife. Rocha took up bachelor of fine arts majoring in sculpture at the University of the Philippines (UP) from 1959 to 1963. He also studied commercial design under the Scranton International Correspondence School. He apprenticed under Napoleon Abueva for several years and under Anastacio Caedo for a year. He was a major sculptor exclusively working on wood and was the master of this medium along with his mentor Abueva.

Rocha created forms, mainly abstracted from the objective world and with elegant polished surfaces. Although most of his works may be considered semiabstract sculptural interpretations of genre scenes, he also created significant images that are purely his own, as in Butterfly Fish, 1979, on molave wood, shown in the exhibit Museum Artists at the Cultural Center of the Philippines in that year. Here, Rocha captured the undulating movement of a fish with masses and voids carved out of a wood block. His major works include The Cry of Pugad Lawin, 1971, at the Himlayang Pilipino Memorial Park; Struggle of Man for Higher Knowledge, 1974, and Mariang Makiling, 1989, both located at UP Los Baños; and Guitarist and Reclining Figures, 1977, both found at the Malacañan Guest House (De La Paz 2013).

His first solo exhibit was Renato A. Rocha: Recent Wood Sculpture, 1978, held at the Manila Peninsula Hotel. This was followed by Rocha’s Wood Sculpture, 1981, at the Rear Room Gallery, Manila Garden Hotel (De La Paz 2013). He participated in two international group exhibitions: the Seattle World’s Fair, 1962, and the New York World’s Fair, 1964. He staged his first solo exhibition in 1978 at the Manila Peninsula Hotel lobby and his second at the Manila Garden Hotel three years later. He had a total of nine group exhibitions and a sculpture exhibition with Abueva, Castrillo, and Marcelo in UP Los Baños.

Rocha won several awards from the UP Student Catholic Action art competitions, including second prize and honorable mention in 1960, first prize in sculpture in 1961, first and second prizes in 1962, and first prize in 1963. In 1961, Rocha won the second and third prizes at the Shell National Students Art Competition for Shell Twist and Playmates, respectively. He also got awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: second prize, Man and Woman, 1962; first prize, semiannual exhibition, Embrace, 1963; first prize, annual exhibition, Family, 1963; first prize, 17th semiannual competition, 1964; and grand prize, 18th annual competition, Expulsion in Paradise, 1965. In 1980, Rocha received the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for sculpture from the city of Manila. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya and Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source: de la Paz 2013a.

RODRIGUEZ, IGGY (Raoul Ignacio Mallillin Rodriguez) b. Zamboanga City 27 Jul 1974. Multimedia artist. He is the son of Pedro Miel Rodriguez and Blandina Soledad Paredes Mallillin. He studied fine arts, major in advertising, at the University of Santo Tomas College of Architecture and Fine Arts.

From 1999 to 2009, Rodriguez was among the artists who collectively produced effigies and large-scale murals for UGATLahi, a collective of artists and activists. In 2004, he also started producing paintings, plywood cutouts, sintra board assemblages, and installation work. A collaborative piece with UGATLahi, Symphony of Destruction, 2009, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), represented the imposing figure of an orchestra conductor as symbol of imperial dominance. Over the years, he also produced a series of ballpoint pen drawings, Mga Kwento mula sa Ibaba (Stories from Below), eventually translating these into works of acrylic on paper.

Responding to the work of Filipino social realists in the 1970s to the 1980s, the work of Rodriguez is characterized by figurative expressionism. His paintings, drawings, and installations employ both distortion and symbolism to portray complex social realities in the Philippines, which may not be easily represented through more naturalistic means. His subjects range from images of the downtrodden masses to representations of exploitative classes. His representations of poverty, injustice, and corruption are often interspersed with references to religious icons and related imagery.

Rodriguez held his first one-man exhibition Kimi/Imik (Silenced/Spoken), 2009, at the Blanc Compound, and later exhibited his works in Dis/This Location, 2012, at the Gwangju Art Fair, South Korea, and Vista, 2011, at the 1961 Gallery in Cambodia. His sixth solo show, Hangganan (Limit), 2013, was held at Manila Contemporary.

Rodriguez began showing in group exhibitions in the Philippines in 1996. He also participated in group exhibitions in China, England, Malaysia, and Singapore, including Drawing a Distance: Drawings from Three Cities, 2012, at the House of Matahati, and Art Triangle, 2010, at the National Art Gallery in Kuala Lumpur; Rubix Rukus, 2009, at the National University of Singapore Museum; and Asian Art Showcase, 2008, at the Novas Contemporary Urban Centre in Liverpool.

Along with UGATLahi, Rodriguez completed artist residencies at Big Sky Mind, 2004-5, and the Sambalikhaan Artist Village, 2005-10. He also completed residencies in Malaysia and Singapore. Rodriguez served as a member of the Visual Arts Committee of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2005-7 and was a core group member of the Tutok Karapatan artist initiative. Since 2010, he has been serving as the National Capital Region coordinator for Makabayan, a political coalition of progressive party-list organizations.

Rodriguez won the grand prize in the pen-and-ink drawing category of the 2001 Art Association of the Philippines annual competition, as well as an honorable mention for the same category in 2003. In 2009, he received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award. Written byLisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Kulay Diwa Gallery, n.d.b; Lopez 2009; Rodriguez 2009, 2012a, 2012b, 2014a, 2014b; Santiago 2009.

RODRIGUEZ, MANUEL JR (Manuel Panis Rodriguez Jr) aka Boy Rodriguez. b. Manila 1942. d. 21 Jul 2014. Painter, printmaker. He was the son of pioneering printmaker Manuel Rodriguez Sr and Natividad Panis. He was married to Melanie Tiongson. His brother Marcelino is a painter and printmaker. He had an early exposure to art and art making. He had a bachelor’s degree in fine arts from the University of Santo Tomas, and, under a scholarship grant, studied graphic arts at the Pratt Institute in New York from 1969 to 1974.
