Rodriguez founded and managed Sepia Print Gallery in New York in 1969 along with his brother Marcelino and other Filipino printmakers such as Amberto Hechanova, Nonoy Marcelo, and Lucio Martinez.

The art of Manuel Rodriguez Jr shows his intense engagement with a variety of materials, textures, and techniques while challenging customary art practice. In search of alternative concepts and inspirations other than those deriving from the West, he found these in Philippine indigenous art, as in the expressions of the cultural communities.

He studied native weaving and ceramics in Manila, which heavily influenced his treatment of his art. In his tapestries inspired by indigenous weaves, Rodriguez conveys the value of developing an appreciative understanding of the material through direct tactile experience of the work. A principal concern of his has been the merging of art and craft, such as turning fiber into art. Despite the fact that he has had long sojourns in the United States, the artist explores themes of indigenous culture and the tropical environment. In his dye-resist paintings on cloth, he dwells on the expatriate theme in an original way. In Not in New York, he created a counter-image of the American asphalt jungle in the imagery of lush vegetation and tropical gardens.

His first one-person show was at the Contemporary Arts Gallery in 1961, and he had at least 14 others here and abroad. He participated in at least 41 group shows in painting in the Philippines and abroad and 18 exhibitions on printmaking in the United States from 1961 to 1985. He represented the Philippines in Brazil at the 9th Sao Paulo Biennale in 1967, in New Mexico at the New Mexico Triennale in 1971, and in Japan at the Tokyo Biennale in 1974.

Rodriguez received awards from the Art Association of the Philippines art competitions: honorable mention, Mayag, 1960; third prize, Cigarette Vendors, 1961; honorable mention, Carnaval, 1962; bronze medal, Picnic in Summer, 1963; purchase award, Ocean Effie, 1964; purchase award, Homeward, 1964; second prize, Devil’s Playground, 1966; honorable mention, painting category, 1967; and first prize, Devil’s Domain, 1967. He won awards in the Shell National Students Art Competition: third prize, Girl with an Apple, 1954; first prize, Mother and Child, 1957; first prize, Limpia Bota (Shoeshine Boy), 1959; second prize, Fish Vendor, 1962; third prize, Isdang Matitinik (Bony Fish), 1963; certificate of merit, Crown, 1964; first prize, Diary of Genghis Khan, 1965; and certificate of merit, Exit to Heaven, 1965. He won the grand prize at the 1972 Pratt Annual Print Show. His Bandera Española (a plant of yellow and red flowers) won first prize in the Mobil Art Awards in 1982. He received the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1970 and the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award of Manila in 1980. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source:

Heritage Art Center 2011b; Rodriguez-Diaz 2015.

RODRIGUEZ, MANUEL SR (Manuel Timario Rodriguez Sr) aka Mang Maning. b. Cebu City 1 Jan 1912. d. Florida, USA 6 May 2017. Printmaker, painter. He was the son of Severino Rodriguez and Antonina Timario. He married Natividad Panis. His sons Manuel Jr and Marcelino are painters and printmakers. Rodriguez’s early environment was conducive to his artistic development since his father was an engraver and goldsmith who did gold and silver ornaments for churches, designed liturgical vestments, and fashioned jewelry. He finished his elementary education in Argao, Cebu, and his high school at Southern Institute (now University of Southern Philippines Foundation). In 1935, he left Cebu for Manila and enrolled at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts, where he studied until 1939. His classmates included fellow Cebuanos Martino Abellana and Julian Jumalon. As early as the 2nd Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Watercolor Exhibition, 1952, when the debate between the conservatives and the modernists was at its height, Rodriguez had cast his lot with the modernists, with himself winning the first prize in the modern category and Abellana the first prize in the conservative category. In the historic 1955 AAP Annual Art Competition marked by the walkout of the conservatives, Rodriguez also won a major prize for his painting Liberty Walls, along with Galo B. Ocampo and Vicente Manansala. Even before Rodriguez devoted himself to printmaking, he had already attained recognition as a painter.

Rodriguez’s skill in serigraphy served him in good stead in the lean years of the war that broke out on the eve of his graduation from arts school. After the war, in 1948, he introduced serigraphy or silkscreen to the local art scene when he opened a small gallery to serve as outlet for the works of his students who learned from his workshop. In 1958, he received a grant from the Pratt Institute in New York where he studied lithography and etching. In 1961, he worked as trainee in the print department of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, after which he trained under the pioneer British printmaker William Stanley Hayter of Atelier 17 in Paris.

Upon his return to the Philippines in 1962, Rodriguez reorganized his Contemporary Art Gallery at 1416 A. Mabini St into a graphic art workshop and gallery. He also taught at the University of Santo Tomas and Philippine Women’s University where he established the graphic arts department and proved to be an exemplary teacher who took the popularization of printmaking as his personal vision. Not long after, Philippine printmaking began to flourish mainly through the zeal of Rodriguez and with the organizers of the Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP) like Maring Llamado, Adiel Arevalo, Ivi Avellana-Cosio, Virgilio Aviado, Petite Calaguas, Nelfa Querubin, Brenda Fajardo, Jo Escudero, Orlando Castillo, and Rodriguez’s own children: Manuel Rodriguez Jr aka Boy Rodriguez, Marcelino, Rey, and Marietta. For popularizing printmaking as contemporary art medium, a medium that was previously thought of as lowbrow and inferior to painting, Rodriguez is called the “Father of Filipino Printmaking.”

The production of his gallery-workshop was varied and prolific, marked by the enthusiasm of his students for new techniques and processes. From serigraphy, it branched out into lithography, woodcut, etching, aquatint, mezzotint, and drypoint prints. Spurred by the success of the Contemporary Graphic Arts Workshop in San Andres, Rodriguez put up a studio in New York where he now resides, the Pioneer Print Center at 1170 Broadway. His students and the PAP continued his crusade for printmaking and were joined by others.

From Dec 1982 to Jan 1983, Rodriguez held a big show of recent works at the Museum of Philippine Art. Reflecting his long and rich experience in printmaking, the exhibit gathered his “sculptural prints” in one gallery and his paintings in another. His sculptural prints are striking for their lively colors and textural contrasts and sculptural features: foldouts and projecting forms that involved the processes of cutting the paper, folding it out to form a protruding circular shape, and inserting within papers of different colors. These produced the effect of rosettes in relief, which, in the entire composition, can be bursting suns and flowering stars—bright focal points in landscapes of fantasy, marked by childlike whimsicality and grace. His texture art shows the artist’s involvement in texture which, for him, is the physical experience of life itself. With the use of a microscopic lens, he takes photographs of wood grains or cracks in the floor and develops these into symbolic shapes of an experience or a memory. One single print may combine a wide variety of techniques and processes which Rodriguez has at his fingertips. While he emphasizes the importance of developing technical skills in processes, he also believes that art can be created from ordinary materials through ingenuity and creative exploration. Rodriguez creates a rich artistic universe through an extensive vocabulary of processes that exceed the traditional graphic art methods.

His output as printmaker includes Traveller, 1961; Calesa (Horse-Drawn Carriage), 1965; Garden of Allah, 1969; Entourage, 1970; Penitent, 1971; Limbo and Sabong (Cockfight), 1972.

Rodriguez’s Jai-alai won an honorable mention in the 1949 Manila Club Art Exhibition. He received awards from the AAP: third prize, Washing by the Creek, 1949; honorable mention, Fragment, 1950; honorable mention, Two Girls, 1951; first prize, Lalaki’t Babae (Boy and Girl), 1952; first prize, Tatlong Hari (Three Kings), 1953; second prize, A Girl, A Flower, 1954; Rotary Golden Anniversary Award and second prize, Liberty Walls, 1955; honorable mention, Quarry, 1959; best entry, Traveller, 1962; and honorable mention, Fertility Rite, 1963. He received the Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1967. When he first returned to Cebu in 1997, he also received two awards: the Provincial Capitol’s Garbo sa Sugbu Award and the Rajah Humabon Lifetime Achievement Award.

Beatrice Harding wrote a book on Rodriguez and his art, titled Survival through Art, 1974. In 2009, the Lenore RS Lim Foundation for the Arts also published a book of the same nature, Manuel Rodriguez, Sr: Into the Threshold, written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Eva Florentino, Virgilio Aviado, and Clint White. When he was 98, he came back to Cebu to visit exhibits, converse with artists and students, and witness the launching of his book. As a celebration of his centennial year, Rodriguez launched his coffee-table book, which features his life and art, at the Philippine Center in San Francisco in Aug 2012. There he was awarded by the consul general a certificate of appreciation for his artistry and for generously sharing it to the San Francisco community. Four months later, the Cebu Artists Inc held Homage: An Exhibit of Prints in Honor of Manuel Rodriguez Sr. in SM City Cebu as a tribute to Rodriguez, who served as an inspiration for many Cebuano artists. The exhibit, which displayed various prints by native artists of Cebu, also aimed to present printing as a living art form and the Cebuano masters as artists who knew how to break away from traditional artistic forms and adapt to different media.

At the age of 100, Rodriguez still conducted workshops in the Philippines and abroad. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Paredes 2012; PhilippinesSanFrancisco.org 2012; Tagala, 2012; Taguchi 2012.

RODRIGUEZ, MARCELINO (Marcelino Panis Rodriguez) b. Manila 1946. Printmaker, painter. He is the son of Manuel Rodriguez Sr and Natividad Panis, the brother of painter Manuel Rodriguez Jr aka Boy. He studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas. Like his father and brother, Marcelino also studied at the Pratt Institute in New York under a four-year scholarship program. Working closely with his father and older brother Manuel Jr, he became a devoted and innovative printmaker like them. He helped his father manage the Contemporary Graphic Arts Workshop in Manila, and later assisted his brother in organizing the Sepia Gallery and Workshop in Manhattan, New York, in 1973.

Marcelino experimented on a variety of graphic techniques although he was most partial to etching and aquatint. Endless Night, 1974, is an aquatint work in deep black made up of a grid arrangement of random shapes and forms. Man and Woman, 1974, another intaglio in varying shades of gray, makes use of the same strategy of textural pattern repetition. His Untitled No. II, 1974, a photoserigraph, is a simple, playful composition of flat, colorful linear doodles. Most of his works are decorative abstract patterns that adhere to an art for art’s sake approach to presence as end in itself. Some of his works, such as Fruit Basket and Pitcher and Fruits, incorporate recognizable but flat figures in the foreground that hide a tapestry of abstract figures and shapes in the background. Technical virtuosity and self-confident boldness akin to American pop art characterize his artistry.

He had many solo exhibits in the Philippines and in New York, the first being at the Luz Gallery in Manila in 1969. He also joined group exhibitions such as the First Indian Triennale, 1968, in New Delhi; Kutingting (Little Things), 1973, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Main Gallery; and The Art of Fine Print: A View of 25 Years, 1980, at the Museum of Philippine Art. He also participated in the Pratt Graphic Arts Center Traveling Exhibit in New York.

He won first prize in the Art Association of the Philippines annual Graphic Arts Competition, 1966; third prize in the 17th Shell National Students Art Competition, 1967; grand prize in the Philippine Association of Printmakers Annual Competition and Exhibition, 1969; and grand prize at the Pratt Graphic Annual Competition. He was voted as one of the “Outstanding Young Men of America” in 1981. Written byImelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Heritage Art Center 2015a; Rodriguez 2015.

ROLDAN, NORBERTO (Norberto Santiago Roldan) aka Peewee Roldan. b. Roxas City 6 Jun 1953. Painter, multimedia artist. He took up philosophy at the St. Pius X Seminary and fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas, where he won first place in the annual advertising design competition in 1976. He also took graduate courses in art studies from the University of the Philippines. It was in Bacolod City, where he taught, that he became actively involved in artist’s groups and activities, and held his first exhibitions. In 1987, he worked as art director in a Sydney advertising company and graphic designer at the Australian Center of Photography. He, together with other Bacolod-based artists like Charlie Co, Nunelucio Alvarado, Dennis Ascalon, and Lilibeth Lao, formed the Black Artists of Asia (BAA) in 1986. In 1990 and 1992, he initiated and coordinated the BAA-organized Visayas Island Visual Arts Exhibition and Conference. Along with fellow artist Donna Miranda, he founded the Green Papaya Art Projects in 2000, an alternative artist-run space located in Quezon City.

In his early works, Roldan combines contemporary and traditional images and techniques in using indigenous materials and found objects to make social statements. He is a longtime avid collector, and his collections consisting of different everyday objects and paraphernalia often find their way into his installations. Newspaper clippings, bottle caps, crocheted doilies, patadyong fabric, scapulars, reeds, vintage toys, figurines, lipstick holders, amulets, beer crates, and grasses are assemblaged in flat, rhythmic, decorative manner. Roldan believes that ordinary items hold meaning such that they are witnesses to the histories of the people who own them.

In his later works, Roldan created diptychs that feature a photo-realistic image from the past on one side and a textual passage—also derived from history—on the other. This juxtaposition of texts that occurred within different historical events questions the truthfulness of history, and in the process also creates a new interpretation with a strong social statement. In his work F-16, 2012, a 6 x 12 ft oil-and-acrylic canvas diptych that represented him at the No Country exhibition in Guggenheim Museum, Roldan painted on the left half an American fighter jet flying over the lands of Afghanistan as a response to the 9/11 attacks. On the other half is an excerpt from a published interview with William McKinley, the American president who led America’s “benevolent assimilation” of the Philippines. The excerpt states America’s justification of its imperialistic actions, such as that the Philippines is “unfit for self-government.” Bringing the image and text together—which represent historical events that happened a century apart—interrogates the truth that man only repeats his mistakes through the course of history. F-16, along with another diptych of his titled First Lady, 2012, is now part of the Guggenheim Museum permanent collection.

Since 1983, when he exhibited with Alvarado and Co at the University of Negros Occidental-Recoletos in Bacolod City, Roldan has had one-person shows and joined group exhibitions both in the Philippines and abroad. His early solo exhibitions, starting with Mixed Media, 1984, at the La Consolacion College in Bacolod City, have been held mostly in Bacolod galleries. His Manila shows include Dagway sa Inaway (Images of War), 1987, at the Hiraya Gallery and Negative Collections Et Al., 1985, at the Art Association of the Philippines Gallery. Later on, he held more solo shows in Manila art galleries, such as in Hiraya Gallery, 1994 and 1999; Green Papaya, 2001 and 2005; Alliance Française, 2004; Mag:net Gallery, 2007; MO Space, 2008; Pablo Fort, 2009; and Now Gallery, 2011 and 2012. International solo exhibitions were also held abroad such as at the Charles Darwin University Gallery in Darwin, Australia, 2003; Taksu, Kuala Lumpur, 2009; Taksu, Singapore, 2009, 2011, and 2012; and the Vulcan Artbox in Waterford, Ireland, 2012. He also participated in a number of art exhibitions abroad such as the Philippine Exhibition Series: Imaging of the Continuing Struggle, 1989, Sydney, Australia; New Art in Southeast Asia, 1992, Japan; ASEAN Travelling Exhibition, 1991, and Handmade Paperworks, 1992, Philippine Center in New York, USA; Identities versus Globalisation, 2004 and 2005, Bangkok, Thailand; Flippin’ Out: Manila to Williamsburg, 2005, New York, USA; No Soul for Sale, 2010, London, United Kingdom; Negotiating Home History and Nation: Two Decades of Contemporary Art in Southeast Asia 1991-2011, 2011, Singapore; and No Country: Contemporary Art for South and Southeast Asia, 2013 and 2014, Guggenheim Museum, New York, USA.

His works can be found abroad at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York, Singapore Art Museum, Deutsche Bank, Fukuoka Asian Art Museum, US State Department, and Artour Holdings Singapore, and locally at the Ateneo Art Gallery, San Miguel Corporation, Carlos O. Cojuangco Foundation, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, BenCab Museum, and in many private collections all over the world. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

APT Global 2015; Arndt 2015; Bunoan 2010; Cariño 2013; Guggenheim Museum 2015a, 2015b; Spot.ph 2013; Zulueta 2013.

ROXAS, FELIPE (Felipe Arroyo Roxas) b. Paco, Manila 1840. d. Paris 13 Apr 1899. Painter. He is the son of Antonio Roxas and Lucina Arroyo. He married Raymunda Chuidian. He was the brother of architect Felix Roxas. An alumnus of the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, he taught such subjects as linear drawing, drafting, and design at the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. In 1884, up to the time he migrated to Paris, he taught at the University of Santo Tomas (UST). Among his students were Jose Ma. Asuncion, whom he advised to refine his studies in Europe. Only a few paintings by Roxas have survived—namely, Casa Indigena en Baliuag (Native House in Baliuag), Puente de Paete (Paete Bridge), Iglesia de Antipolo (Antipolo Church), 1889, and Despues de la Mercado (After Market Hours), all in the Pagrel Collection. In 1889, he left for Paris with his wife and children. His descendants still live there.

Roxas is regarded as a painter of buildings because of the three extant paintings and reproductions of numerous paintings now lost. This may have been the influence of his stepbrother, the architect Felix Roxas, who built the gothic Santo Domingo Church destroyed during World War II. Felix might have asked Felipe to draft the plans, facades, and interiors of the buildings he constructed. Thus, Felipe’s paintings of architecture are firmly drawn, solidly defined, and enriched with a lot of architectural ornamental details. Casa Indigena en Baliuag shows a lower middle-class house of the period with a steep roof of nipa, bamboo stairs outside the main structure, and window shutters also of bamboo. In the background is a rich upper-class house with stone walls, capiz windows, and tiled roof. These works were exhibited at the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in 1895. Written byRegalado Trota Jose

RUIZ, JOSE TENCE (Jose Tence Ruiz) aka Bogie Ruiz. b. 27 Jan 1956. Painter, multimedia artist, curator. He is the son of Felipe Ruiz and Victoria Tence. He is married to Rosario Tañedo and they have two children, the eldest Amihan is a theater actress. He graduated with a fine arts degree, cum laude, from the University of Santo Tomas in 1979 and subsequently taught anatomy there to art students. He was a member of Kaisahan, a group of socially committed artists, as well as of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines.

Ruiz began with a series of austere still lifes. From this, he proceeded to assemblages of shirts sewn from canvas and impregnated with synthetic resin to convey a sense of expressive form. In 1978, he began his Bus and Jeepney painting series marked by bright colors and unusual angles of vision. This developed into the three-dimensional work Jeepney, Tagilira’t Tapalodo (Jeepney, Side and Hood), which shows the side of the vehicle with a row of passengers’ heads done in resin with a wire framework. A comment on colonial mentality, Kikong Baterya (Kiko the Battery), another three-dimensional work, shows a standing figure stiff and proud in his boxed facade outfitted in American coat and tie but revealing rugged bare feet where the facade ends. The assemblage Erding Erdrayb at ang Kanyang Palasyong Agaw-Tanaw (Driver Erding and His Now-You-See-It-Now-You-Don’t Palace) brings together all the talismans of the folk survivalist psyche. The figure itself is basically constituted from an upright pay telephone bolstered with a radio-cum-cassette player. His work Tinolang Tinalo si Hari Manok at Iba Pang Martir ng La Loma (Tinola Dish That Defeated King Rooster and Other Martyrs of La Loma) continues the theme of folk psychology as manifested in cockfighting. The Katay (Butcher) painting series consists of large expressionist works, the central image of which is the carcass, the decaying beast, symbol of the system that breeds prostitution and criminality. In Mga Nagnininong kay Neneng (Neneng’s Sponsors), an a-go-go dancer emerges from the flanks of the beast to entertain her imperialist masters.

Ruiz’s solo exhibitions include Bukod Tanging Pag-ibig (Special Love), 2009, Silverlens Galleries, Makati; Wag Ma-inlab sa Tao sa TV (Don’t Be In-Love with a Person on TV), 2009, Kaida Gallery, Quezon City; Speculation: Only the Old Die Young, 2010, and Sagala de Ligalig, 2012, both at Art Informal, Mandaluyong; and Barangay Humigit Kumulang (Village More or Less), 2013, Artist Space, Ayala Museum, Makati City. Among his group exhibitions are Blur, 2007, Lopez Museum; Trianggulo, 2007, SM Megamall Art Space; Art at the Lobby: Deutsch Bank Philippines / CSI (Chimoy Is Imbisibol), 2013, Deutsch Bank Philippines Makati; and Lupa, 2013, Jorge B. Vargas Museum, Quezon City. His works have also been shown in such international venues as the Second Asia-Pacific Triennale, 1996; the 7th Havana Biennial, 2000; Telah Terbit (Out Now) Southeast Asian Contemporary Art Practices during the 1960s to 1980s, 2006; The Artists Village: 20 Years On, 2008, Singapore Art Museum; and Intersecting Histories: Contemporary Turns in Southeast Asian Art, 2012, ADM Gallery, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore. In 2015, Ruiz was one of the artists that comprised the Philippine Pavillion exhibit at the 56th Venice Biennale, Tie a String around the World.

As an artist-curator, Ruiz’s projects include MMY, the National Capital Region leg of Sungdu-an 2: National Visual Art Exhibition, 1999, Museo ng Maynila; Analog/Playground, 2006, Ateneo Art Gallery; and Tutok:Nexus, 2007, Ateneo de Manila University Loyola House of Studies. From 1999 to 2002, Ruiz published, designed and edited the independent publication Transit: A Quarterly of Art Discussion.

Ruiz has repeatedly received awards from the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competitions: gold medals for sculpture in 1980 and 1997, another gold for digital art in 2001, and an honorable mention for sculpture in 2005. Ruiz received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 1988. In 1990, he won the award for Illustration of the Year in the Singapore Press Holdings Annual Print Competition. In 2003, the city of Manila awarded him the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for new media. He was also finalist in the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards, 2005. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Source:

Ruiz 2013.

RUIZ, RONALDO (Ronaldo Quiocho Ruiz) b. Navotas 22 May 1971. Painter, performance artist. He studied fine arts at the University of the East (UE) and while there became a founding member of the student organization Buklod Sining in 1989. He is the artistic director of Tupada Action and Media Art.

Ruiz is a performance artist and painter who has also done installation work. While still a student, he often had the indigenous Filipino native as subject. Ruiz was born of meager means and as he became an active member of the leftist student organization League of Filipino Students during his UE years, social problems and issues would also feature in his work. The color red was the dominant color in the rallies he contributed to as a street muralist at that time and it was a color often found dominant in his work.

Ruiz worked for two years in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, as a graphic artist, and this experience provided him with firsthand experience of life as an overseas Filipino worker (OFW) who had to deal with the idea of being a human commodity while struggling in a foreign land. The paintings he did that received recognition soon after this overseas stint were Bagahe, Juror’s Choice, 1996 Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition; Sexportation, Juror’s Choice, 1997 AAP Annual Art Competition; Human Smuggling, Juror’s Choice (Top 5), 1997 Philip Morris Group of Companies Philippine Art Awards; and Reshuffled Identity, Best Entry, 1998 AAP Centennial Regional Art Competition. Ruiz, however, would later go beyond the OFW plight to explore more widely themes of human oppression and pain, such as in The Master, which won Juror’s Choice (Top 5) in the Philip Morris Group of Companies Philippine Art Awards in 2000. Eventually, his works would be influenced by his fascination with technology and advocacy for environmental awareness. Beginning with the solo exhibition High Risk, 2002, technology became the principal inspiration for his paintings, many of which are expressed in abstract forms.

He discovered performance art by accident while he was a fine arts student. He performed the atang (offering) ritual from Northern Luzon during one UE Foundation Day and did not know this constituted performance art, until the college dean spoke to him about it the next day. Ruiz continued to do performance art alongside painting; and as it had been in his early work, these performances featured themes related to his roots, social issues, the life of OFWs, and human pain. An association with fellow Filipino performance artists led to the series of performance events held mainly in public spaces called Tupada Action and Media Art in 2002. The visual composition of his performances is influenced by his training as a painter. Avoiding being too theatrical, he consciously integrates elements of spontaneity and interactivity in his performance art.

Locally, he has held solo exhibitions in Boston Gallery, Ayala Museum, The British Council, West Gallery, Red Dot Gallery, Renaissance Gallery, Big and Small Art Co., SM Megamall Art Center, Galerie Astra, Whitebox Studio, and The Drawing Room. He has also participated in international exchanges in Japan, ZSenne Art Lab in Belgium, Gonggan 415 in South Korea, and New Zero Art Space in Myanmar. He participated in group exhibitions and visual and performance art events in Australia, Bahrain, Belgium, Canada, China, Denmark, Dubai, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Israel, Japan, Macau, Myanmar, Poland, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, United Kingdom, and Yugoslavia. He was artist in residence at Artspace, Sydney, Australia, in 1999 and Artesan Gallery + Studio, Singapore in 2009.

Ruiz received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2003. Among his other awards are the 2006 Achievement Award of the UE Diamond Jubilee, the 2009 Metrobank Foundation Award for Continuing Excellence and Service, and the grand prize in the 2011 Kunst Filipino and Kunst Gallery Professional Category Painting Competition. Written byIris de Ocampo

Sources:

Cañete 2005; Legaspi-Ramirez 2012.

SABADO, JOHN FRANK (John Frank Barreras Sabado) b. Mankayan, Benguet 22 May 1969. Visual artist. He is the son of Juan Pabros Sabado and Mildred Barreras. Sabado is a Cordilleran artist whose large-scale and intricate pen-and-inks on canvas or handmade paper depict the indigenous people’s struggle against environmental abuse. He is based in Baguio City as a Tam-awan village artist.

Sabado grew up amidst both the abundance of nature and the expropriation of its resources. He was born and raised in the mining town of Mankayan, a once thickly forested muni­cipality tucked in the northern corner of Benguet. His Ilocano parents worked for the logging concessions of Lepanto Consolidated Mining Company, but the declaration of a total log ban in the mid-1980s resulted in their unemployment and the family’s migration to Baguio City.

He began exhibiting with the Baguio Arts Guild in the early 1990s. Together with Ged Alangui, Leonardo Aguinaldo, and Jordan Mag-osan, he is part of the second generation of artists from Baguio who gained prominence in the late 1990s for works showing mastery of artistic techniques coupled with strong sociopolitical messages regarding ecology, clashes between indigenous Cordillera cultural values against the onset of modernity, and depictions of the spirit world, juxtaposed with urban and rural life.

The bulol (a carved figure of ancestor-spirits) in a gas mask frequently populates Sabado’s dreamscapes of mountain ranges, blocky urban stru­ctures, forests, tree stumps, and a backdrop of intricate patterns remi­niscent of Cordilleran­ traditional weaving. This can be seen in works such as Soaring Spirits, 2011, the series Ifugao Warrior, 2011, Bontoc Warrior, 2012, and Kalinga Woman, 2011, all exhibited in Vanguards of the Earth, 2012, in The Drawing Room, Makati. Other major exhibitions include the solo shows Eco-Warriors, 2010, BenCab Museum Benguet, and Northern Postcards, 2014, The Drawing Room, Singapore, and the group shows The 3rd Asia Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art, 1999, Brisbane Australia, and The 2nd Fukuoka Asian Art Triennial, 2002, Fukuoka Japan.

Sabado’s notable accomplishments include receiving the Thirteen Artists Award­ from the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 2000, being cited as Jur­or’s Choice in the Philip Mor­ris Philippine Art Awar­ds (PAA), 2001, and being twice declared a finalist in the PAA, in 2000 and 2003.Written byKelly P. Ramos

Sources:

Fairley 2014; Flores 2008a; Perez 2010.

SAGUIL, NENA (Simplicia Laconico Saguil) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 1914. d. Paris, France 17 Feb 1994. Painter. She was the youngest girl among nine children of Dr Epifanio Saguil and Remedios Laconico, a relative of the 19th-century painter Juan Luna. Saguil graduated from the School of Fine Arts in the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1933. She received a medal of excellence from UP in 1949. She was the first woman to win an award at the Art Association of the Philippines art competition in 1949. She is recognized as the only woman invited to exhibit at the First Exhibition of Non-objective Art in Tagala curated by Magtanggul Asa at the Philippine Art Gallery (PAG) in 1953. Her first one-person show was held at the PAG in 1950. Four years later, she went to the United States on a Walter Damrash scholarship. She received a French government scholarship in 1954 and studied abstract art at the Ecole d’Art Americain, Palais de Fountainbleau. In 1955-56, she was a scholar of the Institute of Spanish Culture in Madrid and at the Academie de la Grand Chaumier in Paris. Since then, she resided in Paris but did not give up her Filipino citizenship. She frequently visited Manila in the 1970s-1980s.

Saguil is best known for her quasi-abstract paintings in which the predominant figure is the circle in its infinite variations. However, her early paintings of the late 1940s were representational portraits and genre that emphasized the rotundity of the subject. In the early 1950s, she did a series of genre works on wood panels depicting peasants and stevedores rendered in a distinctly rhythmic style. In Paris in 1955, the artist had a brief cubist phase playing on the relationship of geometric shapes. In her most experimental period, Saguil rubbed coffee grains into her paintings for texture. In 1967, she did several shaped canvases with circular holes or relief elements. Some watercolors of the mid-1960s were turbulent microcosms, with sweeping movements and dramatic light-and-dark effects. Her art of the 1960s also possessed an organic vitality in the imagery of cells proliferating and forming tissues bound together by nets of fine nerves. The first half of the 1970s saw her work entering a new phase of harmony and serenity depicted in landscapes without gravity, where circles rise and float in a blue and rose ether, deploying circular forms that are also bubbles, spheres, orbs, globes, worlds, suns and moons, and the artist’s magical mandalas.

Saguil’s works have been exhibited in prestigious galleries in The Hague, Munich, Zurich, Madrid, London, Stockholm, Istanbul, and New York. A number of the artist’s works are in the permanent collections of the Centre National d’Art Contemporain, the Fondation Nationale des Arts Graphiques et Plastiques, and the Musee d’Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris. In the Philippines, her works are in the collections of the Lopez Memorial Museum and the National Museum.

Saguil won several awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: eighth place for Faith, 1949; honorable mention for Mother and Child, 1951; and honorable mention for The Animal, 1954. Saguil received recognition from the Salon International de Juvisy, Paris-Sud, 1964; the Musee de la Lumiere, Tours, France, 1967; and the Second Annual Italian Graphic Art Show, Ancona, Italy, 1968. She received the Gawad Tanglaw ng Lahi from Ateneo de Manila University in 2004. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Source:

ALIWW 2009.

SALAZAR, JOE (Jose Salazar) b. Lemery, Batangas25 Dec 1944. d. 14 Feb 2004. Fashion designer. He was the son of Isabel and Juanito Salazar. Salazar studied architecture at Mapua Institute of Technology in the 1970s before he dropped out to work as an apprentice for couturier Ben Farrales, and later pursue further studies under Salvacion Lim-Higgins. An early breakthrough came when he was introduced by movie columnist Ethel Ramos to actress Nora Aunor.

Salazar is known for creating silhouettes that drape the body of the wearer, appropriating the features and fabrics of the traditional Filipino dress. In 1974, Salazar gained fame for designing an iconic albeit controversial translucent hoop terno with a set of hot pants underneath, for Miss Israel at the Miss Universe Pageant held in Manila. Salazar subsequently won the Ramon Valera Award for Fashion in 1975 with a softly draped and beaded blue chiffon gown as his entry.

He is best known for his contributions to the wardrobe of former First Lady, Imelda Marcos, who became a loyal patron of Salazar in the early 1980s. With Marcos, Salazar was able to freely begin experimenting with unconventional materials such as horsehair or peacock feathers. Unlike many of his contemporaries, Salazar typically kept few records of his work and did not document his process, preferring to approach fashion design instinctively to ensure the uniqueness of each piece.

Throughout his career, Salazar was the first choice for formal and bridal wear among many of the Philippines’ most popular figures in entertainment and politics. He made the inaugural gown of former First Lady Maria Luisa Ejercito in 1998, and dressed numerous high-profile brides, including Charlene Gonzales-Muhlach, Irene Marcos-Araneta, Jackie Ejercito-Lopez, and Angela Montenegro-Arroyo.

A final retrospective of Salazar’s iconic ternos was held in Nov 2003 at the ABS-CBN ELJ Communication Center, while another tribute exhibition was held at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila in 2003. Written by Alice A. Sarmiento

Sources:

Alano 2002; Mananquil 2002; San Juan 2004; Villanueva-Ong 2009; Zulueta 2004.

SALUBAYBA, DON (Don Maralit Salubayba)b. Davao 11 Sep 1978. d. 12 Mar 2014. Painter, puppeteer, illustrator, animator. He was the son of Carlito Salubayba and Flocerpida Maralit. He was married to Jennifer “OJ” Togan.

Salubayba was a member of the Avellana-Brocka Batch of the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) where he graduated in 1995. Later, he earned a bachelor of fine arts in studio arts from the College of Fine Arts in the University of the Philippines (UP) in 2000. Salubayba was a founding member of the Anino Shadowplay Collective and the Tutok Artist Collective. He was a teacher at Laguna’s Beacon Academy, visiting faculty of the PHSA and the Philippine Women’s University where he spearheaded the Center for Visual Printmaking in 2013.

Salubayba’s works use personal narratives to launch into the broad scope of allegory. His multimedia practice tackles the hazy relationships between personal and collective memory, rereadings of history and institutional thought, as well as resonances and tensions of the folkloric past in a present flattened by modernity.

His paintings and installations are heavily influenced by his multimedia work as a shadow puppeteer insofar as crafting narratives and characters, the layering of light and images, sensitivity to space, and the use of alternative materials all play a large part in his creative vocabulary.

Salubayba held his first solo exhibition, Figured Realities, 2002, in Boston Gallery in San Juan. In the same year, he mounted a second solo exhibition at Kulay Diwa Galleries titled Portraits. Salubayba’s other one-man exhibitions include Echoes of the Sea, 2003, in Casa San Miguel, Zambales, and Imaje-Nación, 2006, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). These were followed by a prolific period in which Salubayba held at least two solo exhibitions in the Philippines and abroad every year from 2008 to 2011. Among these are Images from My Floating Third World, 2008, The Drawing Room Gallery; The Peculiarity of a Familial Atmosphere, 2009, Valentine Willie Fine Arts Gallery, Singapore; The Muddled Matter of the Multi-tasking Monsters, 2010, Orange Gallery, Bacolod; Lamat (Fracture/Crack), 2010, Tin-aw Gallery; and Excess Baggage, 2011, Taipei’s Project Fulfilled Gallery. Salubayba mounted The Union of the Forgotten and the Unknown, 2012, at the Kuandu Biennale in Taipei. His last exhibition was Sala sa Init, Sala sa Lamig (Hot or Cold, You Lose), 2013, at the UP Vargas Museum.

Salubayba also took part in group exhibitions like Retro-Active, 2005, CCP; Pali-Palaruan (wordplay on “airport” and “playground”), 2008, Museo Pambata’s Zero-In Project; State of Education of the Nation (TUTOK SOeNa), 2010, with the TUTOK Collective at the Manila Contemporary; and Looking for Juan, 2012, UP Vargas Museum. He also participated in group exhibitions abroad such as Flippin’ Out, 2005, Goliath Visual Space in Brooklyn, New York; Art for Humanity, 2007, Kirkcudbright International Arts Festival, Scotland; Paper Labyrinth, 2012, Treasure Hill Artist Village, Taipei; and Maelstrom, 2012, Valentine Willie Galleries, Singapore. Salubayba partook of several residencies in Fukuoka, San Francisco, New York, Taipei, Hanoi, Vermont, Williamsburgh, and Zambales.

Apart from his career as a painter and illustrator, Salubayba also worked in stage and production design. He worked as visual director for Uyayi ng Dalampasigan (Lullaby of the Shore), 2003, at Casa San Miguel, and as stage designer for Apples in the Dessert, 2009, at the CCP, and Dulaang UP’s Umuulan Umaaraw (It Rains, It Shines), 2011.

Salubayba was awarded the Dominador Castañeda Award for Best Thesis for his undergraduate work at the University of the Philippines in 2000. He received the 2006 Special Jury Prize and Voice Award in the Singapore Short Film Festival for his work A Not So Giant Story. In 2007, he received honorable mention in the CCP Gawad Awards for Animation for Row Our Boat. Salubayba received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2009. Written by Antares Bartolome

Source:

Salubayba 2015, n.d.

SALVATUS, MARK (Mark Nañez Salvatus) aka Boy Agimat. b. Manila 22 Jan 1980. Visual artist. He is the son of Ramsel Salvatus and Annie Nañez. He is married to the Japanese curator Mayumi Hirano. Salvatus graduated with honors from the University of Santo Tomas with a degree in advertising arts. He is co-founder of the urban street collective Pilipinas Street Plan and co-director of 98B Collaboratory, two Manila-based artist collectives that focus on multidisciplinary collaborations.

Salvatus’s art comes from a committed interest in process, the resultant work often comprised of trails across places. A central feature of these sites is art, varied in modes of making and form. Paths across journeys, junctions, and intersections, stops whereby conversations unfold: all three make up Salvatus’s imagination of the city’s complex terrain. The artist walks, breathes, and lives the city with a trained eye, a sharp wit, a relentless curiosity, and an itinerary that proposes contemporary art as compass. The artist scrutinizes the highly aestheticized everyday expressions within urban settings and translates the short-lived gaieties that permeate daily urban life. Yet we are made to realize that this is only one face of the city: where there is great abundance, there is harrowing loss; where there is staggering wealth, there exists crippling poverty. Increasingly, cities all over the world share these inequalities.

Salvatus however, delivers an emancipatory gesture, a degree of hope in the promise offered by the city. This is a theme expressed in conversations facilitated through his art, like the workshops conducted with inmates of a Quezon province jail for his project Secret Garden, 2011, or the array of filmed lip-synching acts for his Territories exhibition, 2012. He documents dreams, dual expressions of desperation and hope in an installation piece of a revolving model of a gated community. In these projects, Salvatus forages, pilfers, and becomes both stranger to and dweller of the city. His projects are informed by a wide spectrum of contradictions that define urban life. While all-embracing, cities can also alienate. It is home to many as they transit through many other places like it. This itinerancy, this moving about is at once exhilarating and baffling. To a significant degree, his practice also charts itinerant travels, from his childhood in Lucban, Quezon province, through university training in the heart of old Manila, and of late, his many travels across the globe for artist residencies.

Salvatus has shown in group exhibitions including biennales in Singapore, Yokohama, Guangzhou, Jakarta, Gwangju, and Melbourne. His artist residencies include Bamboo Curtain Studio residency grant, Taipei; OMI International Artist Project Grant, New York; and another residency at La Trobe University’s Visual Art Centre in conjunction with his receiving the Ateneo Art Award in 2010. Salvatus received both the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the Schoeni Sovereign Art Prize in Hong Kong in 2012.Written byTessa Maria Guazon

Sources:

1335Mabini 2014; 98B 2014; Asiart Archive 2010; Drawing Room Gallery 2014b; Salvatus 2014; Scribd 2014; Sovereign Art Foundation 2012; Visual Pond 2010.

SALVOSA, JONAH (Jonahmar Aguilar Salvosa) b. Calabanga, Camarines Sur 29 Mar 1953. Painter. He is the son of Consortia Aguilar and Amaro Salvosa. He had an early exposure to art because his father, a public school teacher, studied at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts under Fernando Amorsolo. He enrolled at the UP College of Fine Arts and enthusiastically experimented and explored new concepts and techniques. Before graduation, Salvosa did a mural about Mindanao culture measuring 1-1/2 x 12 m for the Mindanao Hotel in Cagayan de Oro. Around 1970-71, he did the Baricada (Barricade) series in acrylic, abstracts in aggressive colors. In 1972, Salvosa became drawn to oriental philosophy, particularly to Zen. He is currently the president of Agos Kulay Maynila.

He traveled to Europe in 1976 after winning the Parks and Wildlife On-the-Spot Painting contest sponsored by the Quezon City Jayceerettes. During his tour, he had the opportunity to see the original works of the Italian masters whose masterpieces inspired him to go back to classicism. At the same time, he developed a stronger interest in Philippine festivals and rituals in their folk aesthetic aspect. Inspired by the Ati-Atihan, he tried to combine the local and the Western in paintings of folk subjects marked by classical influence. In 1978, he went to Japan where he stayed for four months. This stay deepened his earlier fascination with Zen aesthetics. His desire was to find a common ground for Asian and European culture. The following year, he revisited Europe as a prize for his winning the painting competition conducted by Circulo Romano and Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) on the subject of Lorenzo Ruiz, the first Filipino saint.

Back home in 1980, the Asian influence resulted in the series under the title My Name Is Mu. However, his other side brought up in Western influence also demanded expression. In 1981, he held the exhibit Ode to Beauty, which bore allusions to the work of Botticelli, Michelangelo, and da Vinci. This consisted mainly women images, ethereal and idealized. In 1985, still in the quest for meaning in the things around him, he came up with the exhibit titled Piping Saksi (Mute Witness). Here he focused on subjects that had no voice but were witness to an event or were a part of a social situation or context. From 1986 to 1987, Salvosa went home to Camarines Norte in the Bicol region and became involved in ecological concerns. His advocacy in protecting the environment reflects in many of his works, as seen in his paintings of diwata (deities), whom he considers the life forces of nature, and babaylan (shamans) who take their herbs from the forests. His most recent project is a series of 100 paintings of breastfeeding mothers, a vast collection of Madonna and child, which he considers his muse for his art. The Madonna paintings are rendered in many different ways: some mothers are idealized and universal, while others are more specific and humble Filipina portraits.

Salvosa held 25 one-man exhibits in the Philippines since his first show, Orchidism, in Metro Gallery, Makati in 1976. He had three solos in the USA, the most recent being an art exhibit dedicated to the survivors of the super typhoon Yolanda at the Hamilton Galleries in California, USA, in 2014. Since 1972, Salvosa has also participated in a total of 60 group shows in the Philippines and eight international shows in countries such as Egypt, France, China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, USA, and Thailand.

He received numerous recognition and awards from art competitions since 1961. His works in both the on-the-spot painting and watercolor contests were runners-up in the 1971 Shell National Students Art Competition. On the same year, he also won second prize at the YMCA Annual Art Competition. His Saan Ka Pupunta Juan? (Where Are You Going, Juan?) was the best entry in the 1982 Art Association of the Philippines Art Competition. Other awards he received from AAP include Emerging Artist Award, 1975; first prize, First Filipino Saint Art Competition, 1978; and best entry for his work Pamana (Legacy), Annual Art Competition, lithograph printmaking category, 1995. He was also the Top 5 watercolorist at the 19th Kulay sa Tubig Annual Watercolor Competition in 2002. In 2007, he received recognition as one of the outstanding alumni for the arts in UP. He was awarded the main prize at the Freedom to Create Prize in London, United Kingdom, 2009. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source:

Salvosa, n.d.

SAMBOLANI, MALUY LASA b. ca 1930. Mat weaver. She belongs to a Sama household reputed to have the most accomplished mat weavers on the small island of Laminusa off the coast of Siasi in Sulu. In a country that has an extensive mat-weaving tradition, Laminusa stands out for the excellence and intricacy of its handwoven mats, done with consummate skill by Sama women. Laminusa mats are made from the pandanus plant which grows abundantly in the place and the other islands of Tawi-Tawi. They are distinguished by exceptional pliability, luminosity, and fineness, and from a distance can even be mistaken for woven cloth. The mats feature complex geometric patterns in various color combinations, with plain colored mat serving as base. The tradition of mat weaving in the area has been on the decline due to the entry of more lucrative and easier sources of livelihood. But Maluy Lasa Sambolani and her two unmarried sisters have continued to produce their outstanding mat tapestries. They exert a powerful force to save this tradition endangered by modernity.

Sambolani was named Manlilikha ng Bayan in 1990 by the Cultural Center of the Philippines for “producing the finest mats in the unique tradition of the Sama tribe of Laminusa Island.” Written byRosalinda Galang

SAMONTE, RODOLFO aka Rod Samonte. b. Manila 29 Feb 1941. Printmaker. He finished art studies at the University of Santo Tomas. He held his first one-person show in 1969. Aside from important local group shows, he participated in Expo ’70 at Osaka, Japan; the 1973 Sao Paulo Biennale in Brazil; and the fifth International Triennial of Colored Prints in Switzerland, 1970. He traveled to Japan, the United States, South America, and Europe, holding exhibits abroad while studying various printmaking techniques. Samonte developed into a printmaker from various influences: Manuel Rodriguez Sr’s workshops, Rod Paras-Perez’s woodcuts, and Arturo Luz’s abstractions.

He has consistently done abstract works since 1970. A series called Colorscapes consisted of compositions of pure color and form, marked by precise linear modulation. While abstract, they were allusive of land and sky. From color woodcuts he proceeded to relief serigraphy, in which he molded his own paper through the technique of applying layer upon layer of transparent color on the surface. He showed an innovative handling of shapes and color in his prints, at the same time that he was one of the first to develop handmade paper for prints and paper sculpture. At one point, he did cast paper relief prints in which he rejected color, replacing it with tones and cast shadows. Following his international orientation, Samonte eventually opted to migrate to the United States in 1979. In the United States, he learned to do computer graphics when he worked for a number of advertising agencies. In 1998, he quit work and became a full-time artist. In 2003, he started experimenting with digital art. He presently resides in Burbank, California.

His solo exhibitions include Spheres of Time, a series of large-scale digital paintings on canvas shown at the Arts & Books Gallery, Los Angeles, 2003, and an exhibit in the Philippines titled New Work: Large-Scale Digital Paintings, 2011, Galerie One Workshop.

Samonte was cited by the Art Association of the Philippines in 1966 for his woodcut Love Garden and the serigraph Benguet, which won first and second prizes, respectively. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1974. • Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources: Samonte, n.d.a, n.d.b.

SAMSON, JAYPEE (John Paul Sienes Samson) b. Antipolo City 24 Feb 1985. Painter. His parents are Reynaldo Samson and Juliana Sienes. His siblings Jerson, Julio, and Reynaldo are also painters. He graduated with a fine arts degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 2007. Samson is a member of Sangviaje Art Collective. Its other members are fellow Antipolo-based artists John Paul Antido, Edrick Daniel, Dennis Fortoza, Guerrero Habulan, and Joven Mansit.

Samson’s early foray into altering perspective is exemplified in his figurative painting titled Mas Masaya Kung Nandito Ka (It’s More Fun If You Are Here), a winning entry in the 2005 Government Service Insurance System painting competition. The said painting features a brood of 11 individuals posed outside their home. Akin to a family portrait addressed to a missed breadwinning member, it is a poignant reflection on the increasing wave of migrant Filipino workers in search of greener pastures. Employing the technique of foreshortening, Samson elongates the torso of his figures and distorts their limbs to challenge the viewer’s sense of proportion in an otherwise realistic painting. His later works are further explorations on styles of figuration, often emulating the lens of a fish-eye camera, as can be seen in his suite of paintings for Iskul Bukol (Truants), 2008, and Diretso (Straight), 2013. Taking a cue from works done as his undergraduate thesis, he appropriates the law of frontality commonly observed in Egyptian paintings. Samson combines this technique with cubism, harnessing the multiple viewpoints it offers to present viewers with unlikely vantage points from which to deal with depth and space in two-dimensional art. Thematically, his works draw from everyday settings, with people mired in poverty and lacking in access to basic needs such as quality education.

His solo exhibitions include Diretso, 2013, Boston Gallery, Cubao; Isports Kalye (Street Sports), 2011, Boston Gallery; Eleksyon Hang-ober (Election Hang-over), 2010, Boston Gallery; Iskul Bukol, Utterly Art, Singapore; Eskulelat (School Loser), 2008, Boston Gallery; Tanghaling Tapat (High Noon), 2007, Boston Gallery; and Karaniwang Tao (Ordinary Person), 2006, Boston Gallery. He participated in group exhibitions such as Distrongka (Disassemble), 2013, Pinto Art Museum; Maelstrom: The Monumental in Philippine Art, 2012, Valentine Willie Fine Arts, Singapore; Basta: Samson Brothers Group Exhibition (That’s It: Samson Brothers Group Exhibition), 2011, Nineveh Art Space, Laguna; Crossover Contemporary Art from the Philippines, 2010, Copenhagen, Denmark; Putaje (Viand), 2008, Art Informal, San Juan; Bodabil (Vaudeville), 2008, Richard Koh Fine Art, Kuala Lumpur; The Samsons, 2007, Kaida Gallery, Kamuning; May Time Art Festival, 2005, Pinto Art Museum; and Winning Entries NCCA: Diwa ng Sining (Winning Entries NCCA: The Soul of Art), 2000, Art Center, SM Megamall, Mandaluyong City.

Samson was awarded best entry in the drawing category of the 56th Art Association of the Philippines Annual Competition in 2003. The following year, he received a Linggo ng Parangal award from the UP Diliman Office of the Chancellor; grand prizes in the 18th Visual Art National Competition of the PLDT-DPC Telephone Directory Cover and the Metrobank Art and Design Excellence in the oil-based medium on canvas category. Samson received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2009. Written by Louise Anne D. Marcelino

article_title: San Miguel, Vicente de (See THEATER volume.)
text: San Miguel, Vicente de (See Theater volume.)

SANGGAWA Active from 1994 to 2000, this artists collective is composed of Elmer Borlongan, Karen Flores, Mark Justiniani, Joy Mallari, and Federico Sievert. They all studied at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in the 1980s, except for Sievert who studied at the University of Santo Tomas. They were previously members of the group Salingpusa. They formed Sanggawa in Dec 1994 to create works that departed from Salingpusa’s interactive paintings of contemporary Filipino life. Sanggawa sought not just to combine their individual styles into one canvas but also to create a totally collaborative work, thus the name Sanggawa (One Work).

The group is known for their large-scale oil paintings that comment on various topical issues such as politics, religion, cultural displacement, and other Philippine social realities. They are recognized for “breathing new life on the Philippine mural tradition” (Toh 2009), which is traced back to the works of Carlos V. Francisco, who, together with Victor Edades and Galo Ocampo, pursued mural painting in the mid-1930s and later on formed “The Triumvirate” of Philippine modern art.

Among their noted works are Second Coming, 1994; House of Sin, 1995; Marlboro Man, 1995; Palo-Sebo (Oily Pole Contest), 1995; Into the Out, 1995; La Flor del Mundo (Flower of the World), 1996; Okamura sa ’Yo na ’To (This Is for You, Okamura), 1997; Engaging Echoes, 1998; and Epilogo (Epilogue), 1998, a mural commissioned by the Metropolitan Museum of Manila for Alab ng Puso (Flaming Heart), an exhibition commemorating 100 years of Philippine independence.

Sanggawa regularly exhibited at Pinto, Boston, and Hiraya galleries. The group also participated in several significant international exhibitions in the 1990s, including Traditions/Tensions: Contemporary Art in Asia, 1996, Asia Society, New York, USA; 2nd Asia Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art, 1996, Brisbane, Australia; Memories of Overdevelopment: Philippine Diaspora in Contemporary Art, 1996, University of California, Irvine, USA; Glimpses into the Future: Art in Southeast Asia, 1997, Hiroshima City Museum of Contemporary Art, Japan; and At Home and Abroad: 20 Contemporary Filipino Artists, 1999, Asian Art Museum, San Francisco and Houston Contemporary Art Museum, Texas, USA, 1999. The group disbanded in 2000 after participating in the 12th Sydney Biennial in Sydney, Australia, to focus on their individual careers. Written byRingo S. Bunoan

Source: Toh 2009.

SANSO, JUVENAL (Juvenal Gerrit Sanso) b. Reus, Catalonia, Spain 23 Nov 1929. Painter. He was born to Jose Sanso and Ramona Gerrit who set up a wrought-iron business, Arte Español, after they moved to Manila in 1933. Sanso was not interested in the family business and instead took up informal painting lessons under Alejandro Celis. Encouraged by Celis, he attended classes at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts as a special student, 1948-51. His professors included Fernando Amorsolo, Dominador Castañeda, Irineo Miranda, and Guillermo Tolentino. When he was 21, he left for Rome and studied at the Academia di Belle Arti, the Academia della Madaglia, and the Circolo Artistico. He was in Paris in 1953-61, studying at the L’Ecole Nationale des Beaux Arts.

Through the years, Sanso developed a unique style of his own, often labelled “poetic surrealism.” His best-known works are depictions of nature, which include rock forms, flora, seacoasts and riverbanks, bushes, lichen, and fish traps. Through his etchings and drawings of fish traps known locally as baklad, he did for the Parañaque fishing village San Dionisio what Carlos V. Francisco did for Angono, and what Benedicto Cabrera did for Bambang.

He held his first one-man show in Paris, and in 1957 he held his first local exhibition at the Philippine Art Gallery. In 1964, his work Lueurs was chosen as Print of the Year by the Cleveland Museum of Art. In 1964, he held a major solo show at the Cleveland Museum of Art as well as one-man shows at the Philadelphia Print Club and New York’s Weyhe Gallery. His local solo exhibitions include Sanso at the Podium and Bravo Sanso!, both at Galerie Joaquin, 2006; Summer, Galerie Raphael, and Black Bouquet, Ayala Museum, 2007; Parallel Inspirations and Dawnscapes, Galerie Joaquin, 2008; The Importance of Being Juvenal, Galerie Stephanie, 2009; Premier Sanso, Mandarin Oriental Suites, and Pioneer of Expressionism, SM Art Center, 2009; Sanso Moderno, Galerie Joaquin, 2011; Breton Houses, Powerplant Mall, and Sanso Classic, Galerie Stephanie, 2012; and Fundamental Sanso, The Gallery, 2013.

In 1966, Sanso had a 20-year retrospective show at the Makati Commercial Center. In 1974, a 25-year retrospective of his works was held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. In 1976, he held yet another retrospective of some 1,000 works and released a portfolio of 10 lithographs on Philippine subjects, in commemoration of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings in Manila. In 1989, he held six simultaneous exhibits at the Metropolitan Museum, Lopez Museum, Ayala Museum, Centro Cultural de España, Alliance Française, and Finale Art File. In 2009, celebrating his 80th birthday, he held a series of shows in Galerie Stephanie, Mandarin Oriental Suites, Gateway Mall, and SM Megamall Art Center. Still another of his birthday exhibitions was a 2012 showing of new works titled Paintings of a New Day at the SM Megamall Art Center.

Sanso’s pieces have been widely exhibited abroad. Several of his works are in the collections of the following institutions and museums: New York Metropolitan Museum, Museum of Modern Art, New York, Chicago Art Institute, Baltimore Museum, Smithsonian Institute, San Francisco Museum, Yale University, Princeton University, and Rhode Island School of Design, USA; Museo de Arte Contemporaneo in Madrid, Spain; and the Musee d’Art Moderne in Paris, France. Although he was a longtime resident of Paris, Sanso regularly visited and exhibited in the Philippines. Two books, Sanso: Art Quest between Two Words, 1976, and Sanso, 1976, were written on the artist by Rodolfo Paras-Perez and Alfredo Roces, respectively.

In 1950, Sanso’s work Incubus won first prize in the watercolor category of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP). The following year, he won first prize in the AAP oil category with his work Sorcerer, and honorable mention for Bombay. In the same year, 1951, he won third place in the Shell Art Competition. His work Tia Bianang (Aunt Bianang) also won third prize in the Shell National Students Art Competition, 1951. Sanso was awarded the Presidential Medal of Merit by President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. Former Spanish king Juan Carlos awarded him the Distinguished Cross of Isabela in Jan 2007. In Feb 2008, the Chevalier de l’Ordre des Arts et des Lettres was conferred on Sanso by the Ministry of Culture and Communications of France. He served as an artist in residence in 2008-9 for the Art Interaction program of the Shell National Students Art Competition. After 50 years of living in Paris, he established permanent residence in Manila in 2008. Written byR. Chu, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources: Joaquin 2012; Sanso, n.d.

SANTIAGO, LUCIANO P. R. (Luciano Perez-Rivera Santiago) b. Pasig. Art historian. His parents are Atty Apolonio V. Santiago and Dolores O. Perez-Rivera. He finished his early schooling at Pasig Catholic College, high school at San Beda College, and a medical degree at the University of the Philippines. Santiago’s commitment as a doctor has never gotten in the way of his artistic and writing inclinations. Trained in adult and child psychiatry at Sheppard and Erroch Pratt Hospital in Baltimore, Maryland, he won the Wendell Muncie Prizes for 1970 and 1976 for writing in psychiatry. He is the only non-American and only two-time recipient of the award.

Santiago’s research on the various aspects of the 19th century has produced books like The Hidden Light: The First Filipino Priests, 1987, and The World of Damian Domingo, 1990, with Nick Joaquin. He furthered his research on the artists of the Spanish colonial period with his books Fabian de la Rosa and His Times, 2007, and The Life, Art, and Times of Damian Domingo, 2010. His research gives a detailed setting of the late Spanish period to the transition to the American period. Other works include Stars of Peace: The Talangpaz Sisters, 2001; Laying the Foundations: Kapampangan Pioneers in the Philippine Churches 1592-2001, 2002; and To Love and to Suffer: The Development of the Religious Congregations for Women in the Philippines, 2005.

He has contributed articles on Filipino artists to the Filipinas Journal of Science and Culture and Philippine Quarterly of Culture and Society. His love for history and the arts has brought him prestigious awards and prizes such as the Premio Manuel Bernabe (Primer Premio) in History from the Centro Cultural de la Embajada de España in 1987; finalist, Best Book for The Hidden Light, Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1988; the Catholic Author Award from the Asian Catholic Publishers and the National Book Award for art from the Manila Critics Circle for The World of Damian Domingo, both in 1990. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Katrina Yap

Source: Santiago 2007b, 2010.

SANTOS, PABLO BAENS aka Adi Baens Santos. b. Manila 26 May 1943. Painter, photographer. He is the son of Amado Santos and Emilia Baens. He graduated with a bachelor’s degree in fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP). He first worked as an artist in an advertising company. Then, before the declaration of martial law in 1972, he worked as layout artist, illustrator, and photographer for the Manila Times. This experience exposed him to the harsh social realities of the time. Later during the Marcos regime, he worked as an artist-writer for anti-martial law underground publications such as Taliba ng Bayan and Liberation, and joined the protest art movement for which he created popular forms of art such as murals and posters with protest messages.

Santos debuted as a painter in a three-person show at the Sining Kamalig in 1975. By then, he had become one of the founding members of the Kaisahan group of artists—the first formal group of nationalist, protest artists in the Philippines—who developed as social realists and laid down the principles of committed art in the country. Social realism in the Philippines was partly influenced by the 1920 Mexican muralists movement of David Siqueiros, Diego Rivera, and Jose Orozco. The Kaisahan group sought to resist Western influence in Philippine art by veering away from painting only the romantic and beautiful and, instead, exposing the ugly and oppressive reality that the Marcos regime kept hiding. Santos believed that many artists of his time refused to be political in their art, so the group conducted lectures, workshops, and discussions about nationalist art, hoping to inspire in them a more realistic and nationalistic attitude toward art. Santos’s social and political beliefs showed in his choice of subjects: street urchins, mother-and-child of the slums, and workers. Most of his early works made use of the current symbols of political struggle: clenched fists, red banners, and a hand muzzling the mouth. In 1979, Santos did some of his strongest works on the theme of social conflict, such as Panginoong Maylupa (Landlord), 1974, and Komprador (Comprador), 1979. From 1982, Santos concentrated on images of mass mobilization, in a painterly style of sweeping fervor and energy. Some works, such as Sagot sa Eleksyon (Answer to Election), 1981, and Boykot (Boycott), 1981, related to specific issues. Later works dealt with the theme of militarization and of homage to the martyrs. The feminist theme also appeared in Bagong Pinay (Modern Filipina), 1984.

Several years after the turbulent Marcos period, he still actively paints current pressing social issues. He pays tribute to the disappeared and the victims of political killings in Oplan Tumba, an 8 x 36 ft mural that he first unveiled in 2007 in a one-man show in UP Los Baños. It features several dead bodies splayed on the floor in many parts of the painting, while those alive are left suffering. Feminist theme also emerges in his 2008 painting Kalinga sa Kalikasan (Attention to Nature), a work that pays homage to mothers. Surrounding the nude mother and child is text painted in different colors, which says: Babae dakila ka! Dahil dibdib mo ang nagpasuso, bisig mo ang nag-aruga sa mga dinadakila. (Woman you are great! Because it is your breasts which breast-fed, and your arms which cared for the heroes). Labor and Monkey Business or Labor Monkey, 2010, is a satirical work that mocks those who bathe in power and luxury (the “monkeys” in their office suits) while the faceless and unrelenting laborers work in dangerous situations. As a social realist, Santos sees his art not only as a mirror of reality but also as an agent of change. His works show the development of his art coinciding with the development of his perception of Philippine reality.

Santos has participated in six one-man shows and about 80 group exhibitions. Aside from Kaisahan, he was also a member of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines, Alternative Horizons Media Cooperative, Art Association of the Philippines, and Printmakers Association of the Philippines, and a charter member of Agos Kulay Manila and Balintawak. His won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: honorable mention, photography, for Binondo, 1967; and first prize, photography, for Mga Adorno ng Binondo (Binondo Decor), 1974. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 1990. For three consecutive years from 2003 through 2005, he was one of the top five watercolorists at the Annual Invitational Watercolor Competition sponsored by “Kulay sa Tubig” (Genesis Gallery), until in 2007 he received the Hall of Fame Award as Top Watercolorist. Two years later, he became the Best of the Hall of Famers in the same watercolor competition. In 2006, he received an Award of Excellence in Creative Arts at the UP Beta Sigma Fraternity Diamond Jubilee. He has been a judge himself in several art competitions in the country.

His works can be found at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, Philippine National Museum, Ateneo Art Gallery, De La Salle Art Museum, Singapore National Museum, and Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Art Stage Singapore 2015; ArtSlant 2015; D’Bayan 2009b; Kolesnikov-Jessop 2006; Lago 2012; Santos, n.d.; United States Embassy in the Philippines 2015.

SANTOS, SOLER (Soler San Pedro Santos) b. Manila 17 Mar 1960. Painter, photographer. He is the son of painter Mauro Malang Santos aka Malang and Mary San Pedro, and a brother to Steve Santos aka Stevesantos, also a painter. He married artist Monalisa Reyes with whom he has three children, also artists. He took courses in fine arts at the University of the Philippines in 1978-81.

Santos started as a magic realist, moved to semiabstraction, and now experiments with pure abstract imagery. His subject matter, however, has remained the same. He usually explores ecological themes, filling his canvas with nature forms like leaves, twigs, stems, and roots. His earlier works show close-up views of nature in decay, with earth browns, ochers, rust, and moss greens as the predominant hues. Since the late 1980s, his forms have achieved “buoyant simplicity” and his colors have become tropical and vibrant, such as in Foliage, 2014, where he achieved balance by contrasting the rigid and brightly colored geometric overlays with the pale and organic sheet of twigs underneath.

However, he has not only limited himself to using natural forms as his subject, but he also turned to abandoned houses and shabby physical structures as subject for his work. Santos combined his now two favorite subject matter in his Derelict series, which consists of photographs of houses, roofs, and walls over which he painted dried twigs and leaves. In these works, however, he refrained from using vibrant colors and returned to his early scheme of subdued browns, greens, and rust, so that his painted photographs appear to depict forgotten and haunting places of the past.

He has held over 40 one-person shows since 1981, in such venues as the Luz Gallery, Pinaglabanan Gallery, Finale Art File, Museo de Iloilo, Lopez Museum, and Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). He has represented the Philippines in exhibitions abroad like the Seoul Contemporary Show, National Museum of Modern Art, Korea; 2nd and 14th Asian Art Show, Fukuoka Art Museum, Japan; the 1st ASEAN Youth Painting Exhibition and Workshop, Thailand; Young Art in Asia Now, Hong Kong Art Centre; an art exhibit in China; the 7th International Asian Show, Indonesia; and the 11th International Biennial Print and Drawing Exhibition, National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts. He has joined more than 50 group exhibitions. In 1989, he and his wife Mona founded West Gallery. The Santos family showcased their individual works in Gathered Narratives, 2014, an exhibit that portrayed them not only as a family sharing the same creative blood but also as individual artists with their own distinct styles.

Santos was one of the Thirteen Artists awardees of the CCP in 1992. He was a finalist at the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Competition in 1981, first prize winner at the ASEAN Youth On-the-Spot Painting in 1983, finalist at the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards in 1994, and finalist at the Philippine Art Awards multiple times from 1994 to 2005. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Santos 2014; Silverlens Galleries 2015a, 2015b, 2015c.

SANTOS, STEVE (Steve San Pedro Santos)aka Stevesantos. b. Manila 22 Dec 1951. Painter. He is the son of painter Mauro Malang Santos aka Malang and Mary San Pedro, and a brother to painter Soler Santos. He married Elizabeth Diaz with whom he has two children. At a very young age, Santos was exposed to art because of his father and his friends, who were also renowned artists, such as his godfather Larry Alcala, Vicente Manansala, Hugo Yonzon, and Ang Kiukok. A graduate of the University of the Philippines, he worked at various times as artist for West Design Studio and as art director for Wingtips, the Philippine Airlines inflight magazine, and Editorial Associates. After working freelance for a number of years, he joined Lifestyle Magazine as art director and the Philippine Information Agency as consultant. Santos has held exhibitions, both solo and group, since 1973.

A noted magic realist, Santos paints in vivid colors mostly still lifes and landscapes. Though he dabbled first in portraiture, he prefers landscapes, as this genre allows him to easily manipulate his colors, composition, and forms. His early paintings showed resemblances to his father’s works, but the latter challenged his son to find his own niche. He tried his hand on a number of artistic styles such as cubism, expressionism, and surrealism, until he found his true voice in magic realism. It was the American artist Andrew Wyeth, known for his painting Christina’s World, who would then cast a major influence on Santos. Santos’s panoramic landscapes are monochromatic and done mostly in bands and sweeps of color. While most of his landscapes are rural, he also painted cityscapes, such as Urban Houses, which were showcased in his one-man exhibit New Landscapes, 2008, at the West Gallery in SM Megamall.

His first one-person show was at the Luz Gallery in 1975, which was made possible by his teacher Roberto Chabet. A group show with Agustin Goy and Manuel Baldemor reputedly pioneered the trend in magic realism. He participated in the Cultural Center of the Philippines Annual Visual Art shows from 1976 to 1980; Philippine Contemporary Art, Philtrade, 1979; Five Directions, Museum of Philippine Art (MOPA), 1980; ASEAN Exhibition of Paintings, Manila Metropolitan Museum, 1981; Kulturasya (Culture of Asia), Philtrade, 1983; Peace, MOPA, 1986; and group exhibitions in various art galleries such as the Luz Gallery, Alegria Gallery, Greenhills Art Center, Galerie Dominique, Galerie Bleue, and Finale Art File.

Santos won several awards for his watercolors: honorable mention at the 21st Shell Annual Watercolor Contest; first prize at the 28th Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Competition; honorable mention at the 30th AAP; and second prize at the 31st AAP. He also received awards in creativity from the Philippine Women’s University in 1966 and 1968; a special award in photography, 1970; and second prize at the B.F. Goodrich Painting Contest, 1972. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Co 2008; Jorge 2006; Santos 2008.

SAPRID, SOLOMON (Solomon Arevalo Saprid) aka Mang Sol. b. Imus, Cavite 13 Mar 1917. d. 23 Sep 2003. Sculptor. He was the son of Felix Saprid and Felicidad Arevalo. He married Consuelo Rivera with whom he had six children. He held a master of arts degree in education from Ohio State University, USA. He tried his hand at sculpture upon Vicente Manansala’s encouragement.

Saprid has done sculptures in wood and adobe but most of his works are in bronze. He has taken full advantage of the properties of metal through a technique he developed from welding together and shaping pieces of metal scrap. He has worked around a variety of themes which include the crucifixion, flagellants, mother-and-child, Daphne, puppeteers, the legendary hero Bernardo Carpio, amihan (northeast monsoon) and habagat (southwest monsoon), and genre figures of peasants and other working folk. He is most famous, however, for his series on the tikbalang, the half-human half-horse creature of Philippine mythology. One of his major works is the Taming of the Tikbalang at the Makati Commercial Center. His figures are the opposite of the classical form: they convey untrammeled freedom in their quest for human expression.

Saprid was already more than 50 years old when he had his first one-person show at the Solidaridad Gallery in 1969. Other shows were Seven by Seven, 1968, at the Solidaridad Galleries, and Triangulo (Triangle), 1977, at the Hyatt Regency. He was the representative of the Philippines at the Indian Triennale in 1971 and the Australian Biennial in 1973. He had a major show in 1990 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) with Onib Olmedo and Ang Kiukok called Three Figurative Expressionists. Posthumous group shows include Iskultura (Sculpture), 2009, at the De La Salle University (DLSU) Museum in Manila; Suddenly Turning Visible: The Collection at the Center, 2009, at the CCP; and the 7th Annual Sculpture Review, 2011, held at the Art Center in SM Megamall. Some of his sculptures are in the collection of the National Museum of the Philippines, CCP, and DLSU Museum. His works are also found in Hong Kong, Thailand, Australia, Germany, and the USA.

He won awards in the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competitions: first prize, Amihan Series II, 1977, and second prize, Eternal Triangle, 1979. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Robillos 2011; Snippets 2009b, 2009d; .

SAULOG, SIMON B. b. Malag, Imus, Cavite 28 Oct 1916. d. 1995. Painter. His father was Juan Saulog, a farmer. He studied in Malag Primary School and Imus Elementary School.
