He was admitted to the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1931 where he garnered eight medals of excellence in the annual school competitions. Some of his mentors were Filipino masters such as Fernando Amorsolo and Fabian de la Rosa. Despite having trained in a university, Saulog believed that one could become a brilliant artist without formal education. He then formed an informal school in his hometown consisting of art enthusiasts and hobbyists whom he adopted and mentored. This group was later called Malayang Sining.

Saulog’s works were exhibited in the Traveling Art Exhibit sponsored by the De La Rama Steamship Company in 1955. His murals used to hang at the Army and Navy Club, Far Eastern University, Manila Polo Club, and the headquarters of the United States Army and Navy. Some of his sketches can be found at the Makati Medical Center, his mural Our Malayan Heritage at Far Eastern University, and many in private collections.

Saulog was famous for anecdote painting, a type of genre painting revolving around a theme or narrative which he romanticized through the dramatic pose of his human subjects. Offspring, 1952, is a romanticized Filipino Madonna showing a mother embracing a baby. Love and Labor, 1970, shows a peasant couple, their vigorous bodies highlighted by bold contrast of light and shadow. His Madonna of the Sampaguita, 1955, exemplifies a trend of Filipinizing images of the Blessed Virgin. In fact, most of his Madonnas are seen wearing traditional Filipina costumes. His models were often his female neighbors or relatives who had babies. Because of this fascination with the Filipino Madonna and child, which many critics consider as the theme he was most adept in, Saulog has been known as the “master of the Filipino Madonna.”

To stay away from the controversies surrounding the battle between the modernists and the conservatives, Saulog moved away from the Manila art circle and established his own art shop in Imus. Inevitably, his works, done in the style of the Conservative School, had suffered the effects of the somewhat derogatory term “Calendar Artists” coined by the modernists.

Saulog won an honorable mention for Unselfish Love at the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) – Boy’s Town Carnival Exhibition in 1949. His other awards in the AAP include second prize in watercolor for Quack Doctor, 1949; honorable mention in conservative painting for Parting Kiss, 1951; second prize in the overall category for Offspring, 1952; and Purchase Prize for Madonna of the Sampaguita, 1958. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source: Aguinaldo 2011.

SAWABI, DARHATA b. Parang, Sulu 1957. d. 12 Mar 2005. Textile weaver. Sawabi was a Tausug textile weaver of the traditional cloth tapestry called pis syabit. These are handwoven square-shaped cloths which are usually worn as head covering by the Tausug of Jolo but may also be used as ornament to traditional dress, bag decorations, and accessories.

Sawabi’s life in Sulu was marked by economic difficulties, particularly by the effects of the armed conflict in Mindanao. Her family’s earnings from subsistence farming were not enough to feed her family. With no other training apart from doing household work, her talent for weaving became a means to help her family as she would earn 2,000 pesos for each pis syabit, measuring 39 x 40 in, she could produce. In the 1970s, her family had to seek refuge in the forest to flee their village because of the armed conflict. Time and again, she had to abandon her loom even with works in progress because she could not bring these into the forest as they fled. Each time, Sawabi had to start anew when they had to relocate their residence. She even sold pis syabit to warring groups when they would pass through her village.

The process in weaving a pis syabit is considered to be difficult and expensive. It takes three days just to prepare the warp, consisting of stringing black and red threads across a banana and bamboo frame to form the base of the tapestry. Each cloth, featuring intricate designs with bold contrasting colors, takes three months to weave. Her pis syabit is valued because of the evenness of her weave. More importantly, her work was recognized as staying true to Tausug traditional designs, thus enabling these designs to be preserved for future generations to do proper study on them. Before she died in 2005, Sawabi was able to share her weaving process and knowledge to other women in her community.

Sawabi was awarded the Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or GAMABA in 2004. Written byCecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Maricris Jan Tobias

Sources: GAMABA Committee, n.d.; Tobias, n.d.

SENA, FERNANDO (Fernando Belen Sena) b. Tondo, Manila 30 Mar 1948. Painter. He is the son of Arturo Sena and Faustina Belen. He is married to Nancy Canauay and they have two children. In 1968, he earned a fine arts degree from the University of the East (UE) School of Music and Arts where he majored in painting as a scholar of the Children’s Museum and Library Inc (CMLI). He established the Kabataang Tondo Art Group in 1975 and the Art Discovery Learning Foundation Inc (ADLFI) in 2001, the latter of which he is president. He is associated with the Saturday Group, a loose collective of artists who meet every Saturday to hold art-making sessions and discussions.

Sena is noted for his adeptness in the traditional media of pastel, watercolor, and oil in rendering portraits, still lifes, and other figurative paintings, and is particularly known for his technique of using a palette knife to make cubist-pointillist oils. He draws inspiration from the years that he spent growing up in Tondo, Manila, where he resided until 1987.

Sena has been dubbed the “Father of Philippine Art Workshops,” as he has been conducting art workshops since graduating from college in 1972. He began doing so for free to help underprivileged youths in Nueva Ecija and Cavite. Done under the auspices of the CMLI, the workshops are Sena’s way of giving back to the institution that sponsored his education. As the popularity of his workshops grew, CMLI encouraged him to strike out on his own, and he started accepting paid students and giving lessons at different venues, including Miriam College and the Vargas Museum of the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman. Sena continues to hold free workshops for disadvantaged young people, public school teachers, prisoners, and the chronically ill through ADLFI, which is composed of artists and art enthusiasts. The organization holds contests, exhibitions, and other activities for members and nonmembers, and also helps send young talents to art school, usually the UP Diliman College of Fine Arts.

Sena, who has been a faculty member of both his alma mater UE and UP, held his first solo show in 1973 at the Little Gallery in Tesoro Building, Makati, and has since mounted several other individual exhibitions, as well as participated in group exhibitions, in various venues in Metro Manila. He has received numerous awards, including Ten Outstanding Manilans from the city of Manila, 1979; Young Achievers Awards, arts and culture sector, from the Alyansang Kabataan, National Youth and Young Professionals Council, 1987; distinguished alumni from UE, 1989; outstanding alumni from the UE College of Fine Arts, 1994; and Gawad Parangal from the local government of Quezon City in 2011. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, Alice G. Guillermo, and Jaime Oscar M. Salazar

Sources: ADLFI 2009; Ayala Museum 2006; Barawid, Garcia, and Yu 2014; Santos 2008; Silangan 2011.

SENSON, JUAN aka Tandang Juancho. b. Angono, Rizal 1864. d. 1924. Painter. Nothing is known of Senson’s artistic education. Folks of Angono surmise he might have learned his art from an artistically inclined Jesuit, this order having been in charge of the town in the Spanish period. Life in Angono was mainly dominated by two religious celebrations—namely, the Lenten season and the feast of the Pope San Clemente, its patron saint. Accordingly, Senson painted many scenes of the Passion of Christ. He was also a sculptor and he created the props—that is, the soldiers’ helmets—for the village’s Lenten play or sinakulo. Some of his paintings are not inside museums or in private collections, but are secured in metal poles and carried around as part of the Lenten processions, blurring the distinction between “fine art” and “folk art.”

The earliest dated work of Senson is one now known as [At the Foot of the Cross], 1894, and his last dated work is [Christ before Pilate], 1917, both pieces being still in Angono. His activities, however, were not confined solely to his town, having submitted Vista Parcial del Pueblo de Angono y la Laguna de Bay (Partial View of Angono and Laguna Bay) to the Regional Exposicion de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition), which opened in Manila on 23 Jan 1895. The painting is now part of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas art collection. [The Stations of the Cross] and [The Crucifixion] by Senson were evidently inspired by engravings from a pasyon from which the folks read about Christ’s sufferings. His drafting skill in these pieces were accurate, having been aided by the prints. Since his sources were in black-and-white, it fell on him to provide the colors, and because he fashioned his pigments from local pigments and dyes, they were mainly pastel shaded. To protect his works, Senson used a local varnish that gives his paintings a yellow-brownish appearance to this day.

The National Artist Carlos V. Francisco acknowledged Senson as his earliest influence. As a child, Francisco watched him grind his own paints from raw minerals and plants. Botong also kept track of this master’s works. Senson’s presence gave him a strong sense of artistic tradition—meaning, the presence of local artistic roots; hence, he did not need to look for stylistic sources, particularly those from outside the Philippines. Written by Ino Manalo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Manalo 2015; Traveler on Foot 2012.

SERNA, SERAFIN (Serafin Olandes Serna) b. Raxabago, Tondo 14 Nov 1919. d. 9 Mar 1979. Painter. The youngest of four siblings, he was the son of Pablo Serna and Gracia Olandes. He married Bellaflor Laureano, a businesswoman. His father removed “de la” from the family name. He attended Rizal Elementary School and Torres High School. He took up drawing and painting under Teodoro Buenaventura before entering the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts where he was a senior when World War II broke out. He worked for the Philippines Herald as a layout artist and contributing photographer, during which he took photographs and painted portraits of a young Imelda Marcos (Imelda Romualdez at that time). His friendship with her carried on until he became a regular portrait painter of the Marcos family. Because he lived in New York for a time at the house of Jorge Araneta’s father, he painted portraits of important people such as government officials and ambassadors, most of whom were friends of Araneta. He also gave lectures on art to mostly American students and people from the embassy. There, he also had his own art studio where he received guests, such as art critics, and sold his paintings.

Serna belonged to the “conservative” or traditional school of representational art. His figurative work is exemplified by Igorot Woman, 1941, and Marketing in Baguio, 1941. Both show his solidly formed shapes and the bold brushwork that complement his subject matter, the rugged life of the mountain peoples in Baguio. In 1947, Serna painted a portrait of Teodoro Buenaventura, Mi Maestro (My Teacher), using dramatic contrast of light and shadow that highlighted the old man’s infirmity. Serna’s landscapes were also characterized by rough impasto. His colors were yellow and yellow-green mixed with large amounts of white. This tonality could be observed in his landscapes of the 1970s.

Serna won honorable mention for Baguio Market at the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Boy’s Town Carnival Exhibition in 1949 and honorable mention in conservative painting for Madaling Araw (Dawn), 1951. He had a successful one-man show in New York in 1957. In 1964, the Philippine government commissioned him to decorate the Philippine Pavilion at the New York World Fair with murals and brass sculptures, for which he won international acclaim. He also won an award from Shell for a portrait he did of Rizal as an ophthalmologist. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source: de la Paz 2013b.

SHOP 6 This is the no-nonsense name adopted by an informal group of artists led by conceptualist Roberto Chabet in the 1970s. After his brief tenure as founding museum director of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) from 1967 to 1970, Chabet envisioned an “alternative to the alternative” and began organizing exhibitions with other artists amidst the political tensions that marked the country during the martial law years.

Together with Joe Bautista, Rodolfo Gan, Yoli Laudico (now Perez-Johnson), Fernando Modesto, and Boy Perez, they opened their first exhibition titled Basta Hindi Ganon ’Yon (It Just Isn’t So) at K-Lahi Gallery and Café in Fiesta Carnival in Cubao on 19 Apr 1974. Featuring works made out of found objects and other everyday common materials such as Chabet’s suspended bamboo pole, Laudico’s twigs and motor oil–stained papers, and Bautista’s refrigerator with moldy Gerber bottles containing various objects including photographs of Ferdinand Marcos, the exhibition was seen as offensive by the gallery owners and was taken down by the artists a day after the opening. Word quickly spread about the censored one-day exhibition and the artists were soon offered a temporary rent-free space in Sining Kamalig, a shopping arcade in Pasay. The artists adopted the name Shop 6 after the six artists in the K-Lahi exhibition as well as the stall number of the single-room store space given to them in Kamalig.

Shop 6 opened the space for “mixed media works, constructions, situations, environments, and other exploratory projects” that countered the traditional paintings shown in commercial galleries. They launched their initial 14-week exhibition program with a two-part inaugural that showed works by the original six artists along with Danny Dalena, Joy Dayrit, Nap Jamir, Red Mansueto, Berna Perez, Alan Rivera, Eva Toledo, and Nestor Vinluan, followed by their solo exhibitions that opened every Friday and only lasted through the weekend. While some critics dismissed their works as “gimmicks,” others acknowledged them as “results of hard work perhaps, harder thinking” (Marks 1974).

Shop 6 exponentially grew as other artists and many of Chabet’s students from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (UP CFA) also joined their exhibitions such as 101 Objects, a sprawling exhibition that included a cut-up and reassembled tree, a blind man from Quiapo, and a yellow Volkswagen with leftover cake, half-empty milk bottles, and a ticking metronome. After Kamalig, Shop 6 held guerrilla exhibitions in homes, parks, and secretly installed their works in other artists’ shows. They also had an exhibition at the CCP Main Gallery (now also known as Bulwagang Juan Luna) in 1975 and participated in the Contemporary Art Museum of the Philippines inaugural in 1977.

By the 1980s, the artists behind Shop 6 started to concentrate on their own practices or moved on to other careers. However the issues they raised then—what constitutes art and its values—remain as critical and contentious today. Primarily known through oral accounts shared among artists, Shop 6 was a precursor to succeeding artist-run spaces in Manila, many of which were founded by Chabet’s students from the UP CFA. Written byRingo S. Bunoan

Source: Marks 1974.

SIAUINCO, MARIANO (Mariano Guzman Siauinco) b. Manila 9 Apr 1870. d. 20 Aug 1942. Wood-carver. His father Florentino Siauinco was owner of a textile store on the Escolta; his mother was Regina Guzman. Siauinco and his wife Margarita Candelaria had seven children, none of whom attempted to learn his art; Siauinco discouraged them as wood carving was an unprofitable occupation. Of the children, Pilar married composer and musician Antonio J. Molina, Jose was a photoengraver, and Alejandro, a piano tuner.

Siauinco learned wood carving from such master craftsmen as Manuel Flores and Domingo Teotico who both had shops in Quiapo. When Teotico died, Siauinco worked with Maximo Vicente before establishing his own shop in 1910.

He excelled in carving religious figures, such as the San Jose, several Mater Dolorosa (Sorrowful Mother), Virgen de la Paz (Virgin of Peace), and Corazon de Jesus (Heart of Jesus). A notable work was his life-size bust of Francisco Balagtas, carved out of batikuling wood probably in 1904 or earlier. This piece was executed under the supervision of Romualdo de Jesus who had known Balagtas in Tondo. For some reason, de Jesus did not carve it himself. When finished, the sculpture was readily approved by the poet’s children and other relatives as a faithful portrait of Balagtas. Since no likeness exists of Balagtas from his lifetime, Siauinco’s work has since been used as one source for portraying him. Another bust of Balagtas was made in 1915 by an unknown artist, the model being Victor Baltazar, a son who was said to have looked more like the poet than anyone else. Written byE. Arsenio Manuel

SIBAYAN, JUDY FREYA (Judy Freya Quines Sibayan) b. Baguio City 5 Jun 1953. Conceptual and performance artist, art educator, and curator. Her parents are Bonifacio Sibayan and Isabel Quines. She received her bachelor of fine arts from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1976; her master of fine arts from the Otis Art Institute of Parsons School of Design, Los Angeles, in 1984; and her doctorate degree in fine arts from the De La Salle University (DLSU) in 2010. Sibayan was assistant professor at DLSU from 1989 to 2010 and associate professor from 2010 to 2013.

The core of Sibayan’s work is the institutional and materialist critique of art. Her initiation and exposure to art institutions began early. While still a college student in 1974, she was invited by Professor Roberto Chabet to participate in the group exhibition Untitled Painting No. 1 and Other Paintings held at the Small Gallery of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Sibayan held her first solo exhibition Investigating a Museum at the CCP Main Gallery upon the invitation of its director, the artist-curator Ray Albano. It was premised on the idea that the exhibition space is a value-imbuing device that names the objects inside it as art. In the same year, her performance Lemon Cake, which took place at a parking lot near the alternative space Shop 6, was discussed by Albano in the contemporary art publication MARKS. Crucial to her artistic formation, these works marked her long involvement with the CCP: as a curatorial assistant from 1976 to 1977, as an exhibiting and performance artist supported by the CCP until 1985, as an artist performing in Ules, Bungon ti Agdawat (Ules, Shroud for Those Who Plead) in protest of the transition government in 1986, as director of the Contemporary Art Museum of the Philippines, and as head of the Coordinating Center for the Visual Arts from 1987 to 1989.

The artist’s first major work after a seven-year hiatus from the art world was Scapular Gallery Nomad (SGN), conceived in line with her reflection about being circumscribed in the Center for more than a decade. Through this work, Sibayan called attention to the difficulty of acting upon her conflicted roles as an artist expected to be responsive to the larger art community, on the one hand, and as an administrator of the foremost state-sponsored Contemporary Art Museum titled to privilege a limited few, on the other. Testing the limits of her autonomy and disengagement from the Center, SGN is a performance-based work that veers away from the institution by making her body the site of the exhibition. As owner and curator, Sibayan wore an enlarged scapular (1997-2002) with pouches that contained the works of artists whom she invites to exhibit. By literally diminishing the scale of the work and attaching SGN to her body, Sibayan brought SGN into the spaces of institutions just by her walking into them. She adds that SGN afforded her “a rhizomatic process of producing art (its circulation and reception).” The process and the use of minimal resources are echoed in succeeding projects—among them, The Museum of Mental Objects, begun in 2002. This performance rejects physical manifestations altogether as a commentary against the commodification of art. Here, Sibayan becomes the museum itself, the very site of memory, as she recites the artworks whispered to her by artists.

Sibayan has exhibited and performed in numerous local and international institutions. She is the co-founder and co-publisher of the independent online journal Ctrl+P Journal of Contemporary Art. Her curatorial projects include xsXL Expanding Art, 2002, at the Sculpture Square, Singapore, and 600 Images/60 Artists/6 Curators/6 Cities, 2005. Sibayan received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1976. She was also conferred the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan sa Bagong Pamamaraan award by the city of Manila in 2006. Written byLouise Anne D. Marcelino

Source: Sibayan 2007, 2014.

SIEVERT, FEDERICO (Federico Fua Sievert) b. Tacloban City 21 Mar 1961. Painter. He is the son of Salvador Sievert and Victorina Fua. He married Grace de Jesus. He graduated with the degree of bachelor of fine arts from the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1983. He was active with the Concerned Artists of the Philippines.

Sievert is a second-generation social realist. He has done powerful paintings, mostly of a symbolic character, dealing with sociopolitical issues, and of a strongly nationalist and anti-imperialist persuasion. Aside from doing paintings, he has also worked in popular forms, such as posters, comics, and illustrations and has contributed much of his energies to progressive art organizations.

He held a solo exhibit at the De La Salle University Gallery in 1988 and at the Boston Gallery in Quezon City in 1997 and 2002. He has joined group exhibits such as Buklod Sining at the German Cultural Center in 1983, the Piglas Exhibit at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Main Gallery in 1986, the Philippine Contemporary Arts exhibit at the Puffin Room Gallery in New York in 1999, and several group exhibitions at the Boston Gallery in Quezon City from 1997 until 2002.

He won a number of awards for painting: gold medal in the 35th Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition for Aliping Walang Malay (Innocent Slave) in 1982; third prize in the AAP-Metro Manila Symphony Foundation on-the-spot painting competition to mark the 200th Concert at the Park in 1983; and first prize in the UST College of Architecture and Fine Arts on-the-spot painting competition on the theme “What the World Should Be” in 1982. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Artprice 2015; Sievert, n.d.

SISON, YASMIN (Yasmin Belamide Sison-Ching) b. Silang, Cavite 21 Feb 1972. Painter, intermedia artist, educator. She is the daughter of Modesto Sison and Eileen Belamide. She is married to artist Mariano Ching with whom she has a son, Haraya, who has already exhibited work alongside his parents. Sison graduated with a bachelor’s degree in humanities cum laude at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1992. She received a certification for professional education the following year from the same university, where she later took up MA units in art education. In 1997, she received a bachelor of fine arts in painting from UP Diliman. Sison taught art in the following institutions: Cavite Institute, Silang, 2002-6, Ayala Museum, 1999-2006, and St. Scholastica’s College, 1998-2001.

Sison is known for her hyperrealist imaging, particularly in her works depicting children. In 2007, her suite of paintings titled Gingerbread Girls reinterpreted stories told to her as a child. The theme recurs in later works, like the paintings in the exhibition Into the Woods, 2009, whose narrative elements oscillate between genre and fantasy. Here, children garbed in their best dresses are set against the deep forest, wearing animal masks as if assuming a new identity while embarking on the process of discovery or survival. Her adroit handling of portraits is again exemplified in Underneath the Sky, 2011, as it harked back to her earlier series on children. In these, Sison introduced images of microbes to describe the breadth of children’s imagination and disposition, their sporadic yet contagious and challenging quality configured in diptychs paired with crocheted forms encased in glass. Sison’s solo exhibitions include Playing House, 2013, Finale Art File, Makati City; The Domestic Life of Pictures, 2012, Silverlens Galleries, Makati City; and Storybook Collages, 2012, West Gallery, Quezon City.

Sison is a deft observer of media and popular culture. Through her paintings, she is also recognized for the way she appropriates images from fashion magazines, capturing details of the background yet obscuring elements of the face and body to emphasize projected personas and fictive memories. Sison and former bandmate and fellow artist Lena Cobangbang formed the duo Alice and Lucinda, a “fluid mask persona” which they took on beginning 1999. Apart from their respective practices, their critical collaboration enabled them to produce a “lo-fi,” process-based body of works including zines, photographs, videos, performances, and installations. The paired performances of these two artists culminated in contemporary archive exhibitions on Alice and Lucinda in Vargas Museum and Mo Space, Taguig, in 2012.

Always keen on exploring collaboration and other alternative practices, Sison is identified with the collective-cum-artist-run space Surrounded by Water, working as one of several artist-volunteers from 1999 to 2002. In the exhibition Scribble Stage, 2011, she involved her son Haraya in creating collages and photographs, reverting to the idea of play and dissipating the boundaries of her simultaneous performance as mother, artist, teacher, and woman.

Sison has participated in numerous group exhibitions in the Philippines and abroad. These include Art Stage Singapore, 2013, and the Prague Biennale, 2009. Sison received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2006. Written byLouise Anne D. Marcelino

SORIANO, ARO (Lazaro Salamat Soriano) aka Aro. b. Manila 6 Feb 1943. Painter, sculptor. He is the son of Lazaro Soriano and Salud Salamat. His interest in the arts probably started when he was a child actor. He developed as an artist during his 11-year sojourn in Europe, mainly Paris, 1970-81, during which he took on odd jobs and gained a wide variety of experiences. There he did constructivist paintings, then proceeded to figurative works portraying forms such as animals. Since settling in the Philippines for good, he has drawn artistic inspiration from folk traditions and has committed himself to community development projects with the goal of rediscovering, reviving, and propagating traditional folk arts. He has worked in figurative pottery in a pot-making community and participated in the painting of public murals with community themes, as in Obando, Bulacan, as part of the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ (CCP) outreach program. He also painted clay sculptures depicting the Angono higantes (giants).

From 1985 to 1986 Soriano did a series of paintings in which he interpreted folk songs in oil on canvas. In rendering their imagery, he did not only go by the narrative but brought out their entire social and cultural dimension. True to the spirit of his subject, he developed a colorful style reflecting the folk sensibility free from academic canons. In a subsequent series, he rediscovered riddles and proverbs and interpreted them visually. These paintings on folk songs, riddles, and adages are some of the liveliest genre works in Philippine art, filled with humorous characterizations and situations, and insights into the psychology of the Filipino. His most famous work is Jak en Poy (Sticks and Stones), 1987. In this colorful modern masterpiece, figures who appear like caricatures—a combination of prominent people in politics and ordinary citizens—crowd at the foreground from the middle up to the lower half of the painting, forming a tension that builds and points to the central figure, who is Corazon Aquino. Here she is depicted like Venus, but stoic and apathetic to the chaos surrounding her, gazing at an area outside the picture. The man in white barong on her right is said to be Juan Ponce Enrile, and behind her are Cardinal Sin and Fidel Ramos. The title of the painting borrows from the timeless children’s game and alludes to the hand gestures used by opposing parties in the EDSA Revolt. This classic painting portrays the circus-like grandeur and childlike madness that often surrounds political events in Philippine history.

He was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1992. He participated at the First Asia Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art at the Queensland Art Gallery in Australia in 1993. His works were also included in the exhibit Edades: From Freedom to Fruition, 2011, at the Bulwagang Juan Luna (also known as the Main Gallery) of the CCP, as one of the artists who continued the style of modern art. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Kasilag 2015; Lerma 2005c; Literature, Culture, and Society of Singapore 2000a; Mayo 2011b; Plantingrice.com 2015.

SORIANO, MANUEL (Manuel Magarro Soriano) b. Manila 29 Mar 1934. d. 1996. Printmaker. He was the son of Santiago Soriano and Felicisima Magarro. He married Virginia Soriano. He earned a bachelor of fine arts degree from the University of Santo Tomas. He headed the creative arts visual communications group of the Design Center until 1981, and was for a time art director of the Philippine Advertising Counselors Inc, and member of the Art Directors Club of the Philippines. Although he also does etching, collagraphs, and serigraphy, Soriano is best known for his woodcut prints. He assembles several blocks of wood-carved images to create genre images of Philippine folk ways and country life in large-scale visual narrative. The Trial of Longinus, 1972, a vertical composition of a Morion mask repeated as leitmotif for a design in rhythmic repetition is an example. Barrio Fiesta, 1973, on the other hand, shows a nocturnal procession in a town plaza interpreted as an interplay of positive and negative images. Arches, saints in carroza (processional float), a hero’s statue, an orderly crowd and festival buntings, are composed in a serial pattern. Patched Home by the Railroad Track, 1975, is a grid composition of the life of rural people who are beginning to be exposed to urban life in dwellings beside the railroad.

Soriano worked closely with Romulo Olazo and Rodolfo Samonte in printmaking workshops and exhibition of the Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP). In 1972, he won first prize in the PAP graphic arts competition. In 1973, he received the grand prize award in the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition for his Barrio Fiesta. He was a Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists awardee in 1974, and a first prize winner in the AAP-UNESCO art competition for print in 1980. Written by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya

SOTTO, JACINTO (Jacinto Laguda Sotto) aka Jack Sotto. b. 29 May 1954. Painter. He is the son of Plaridel Sotto and Aida Lopez Laguda and is the brother of the late film critic and historian Agustin Sotto. He studied fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines Diliman. Sotto was creative director at McCann Erickson from 1981 to 1999.

Sotto’s abstract paintings play with sight, not through optical illusions but through color and pattern. In paintings such as the Trance series, 2005 and 2007, and Painting Noir 2, 2006, Sotto employed a tricolor scheme arranged in circular strokes that, at a cursory glance, appear as a solid plane. Yet, upon closer inspection, these strokes bear minute differences, each one being a unique expression of the artist’s thoughts and intuitions, but all together forming the whole picture that constitutes the artwork. Using the same color palette but with differing patterns, Kzspygv, 2008, is built up through linear strokes while Rhythm of Days, 2004, maintains the circular motif. Set apart from his conventional style, Water or Dream, 2009, employs different tones of blue while Fugitive Pieces, 2009, is composed of irregularly organized strokes framing those contained within the grid. These works and many more bear an inner light, through their deep and vibrant colors that invigorate the viewer. Sotto believes that “the art object (painting, sculpture, print, video, performance, etc) is like a prism. The light is the artist’s ideas and emotions that go into the object. What comes out is usually a multi-faceted view from the point of the audience. The engagement with the artwork is a dialogue” (Sotto 2014).

His first solo exhibition, Paintings, 1977, was held in Sining Kamalig. This was followed by New Paintings, 1981, also at Sining Kamalig; Blue Solitude, 2002, Finale Art Gallery; Signs and Wonders, 2004, Finale Art Gallery; New Works, 2006, Mag:net; and Kzspgyv, 2008, Mag:net. Sotto has participated in group exhibitions at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Main Gallery (also known as the Bulwagang Juan Luna) for Portfolio and Black and White, 1976, On Color, 1977, Thirteen Artists, 1978, Ten Years After: A Thirteen Artists Reunion, 1989; and at the Manila Contemporary for Patterns, 2009. Sotto received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1978. Written by Zeny May D. Recidoro

Source:

Sotto 2014.

STA. ANA, KATTI (Katti Pasco Sta. Ana) b. Quezon City 12 May 1970. Multimedia artist, illustrator, sculptor, art educator. She is the daughter of Froilan Mendoza Sta. Ana and Oliva Pasco. She is married to artist and terra-cotta sculptor Roberto Paredes Acosta. She received her bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman College of Fine Arts in 1991. She went on to finish a master of arts (MA) degree in urban and regional planning, 2006, at UP and a second MA in community arts, 2010, from the Maryland Institute College of Art, USA as a Fulbright scholar. Sta. Ana has been teaching at the Department of Studio Arts, UP College of Fine Arts, since 2010. She has also taught at the fine arts programs of UP Baguio, 2004-8, and Ateneo de Manila University, 2008-9. In 2012, she founded the studio-workshop Clay Art Garden in Marikina.

Sta. Ana’s body of works ranges from painting, photography, illustration, mixed media to assemblage, installation, and stonework sculpture. She started illustrating children’s books in 1996, creating visuals for Don’t Take a Bath on Friday, Ang Prinsesang Ayaw Matulog (The Princess Who Doesn’t Want to Sleep), Mga Alagad ng Mahiwagang Sirkulo (Disciples of the Magic Circle), and Sa Ilalim ng Dagat (Under the Sea). She is the author and illustrator of the book Bully Big Pig. She also drew covers and illustrations for publications of nongovernment organizations. Sta. Ana served as the president of Ilustrador ng Kabataan or I.N.K. from 1997 to 1999 and coordinated the traveling exhibit Art Esteem, 1999. She is still a member of I.N.K.

Her works in mixed media and assemblage explore social, feminist, and environmental advocacies. Moving to Baguio in 2004 as an art teacher, Sta. Ana started producing photographs that captured scenes of the Cordillera region’s indigenous and rural population amidst rising urbanization. In 2009, she traveled to the United States on a graduate scholarship and served as artist in residence and a community arts teacher at Baltimore Clayworks. Based in Manila since 2010, Sta. Ana has created more installation-based works that incorporate found objects, stoneware, and organic materials such as dried leaves, soil, and plant seeds. Her sixth solo exhibition, Vanishing, 2012, Mag:net Gallery, Quezon City, featured glazed and painted stoneware sculptures of plants and other natural forms.

Sta. Ana started joining group exhibitions in 1987 and held her first solo exhibition Larawan: Walang Bayad (Pictures: Free of Charge), 1996, at West Gallery in Mandaluyong City. She was among the featured artists in the exhibition Who Owns Women’s Bodies as it traveled across the Philippines and Thailand, 2000-03. She represented the country in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Cultural Week, 2002, in Angkor Wat, Cambodia. Sta. Ana received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2000. Written byLisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Ito 2012; MICA, n.d.; Pagyakap, n.d.; Sta. Ana 2014.

STA. MARIA, FELICE (Felicidad Garcia Prudente-Sta. Maria) b. San Francisco, California, USA 7 May 1950. Essayist, Philippine culinary historian, cultural heritage advocate. She is the daughter of Nemesio Encarnacion Prudente and Ruth Yulo Garcia. She is married to lawyer Andres B. Sta. Maria.

She received her elementary education at 32nd Street Elementary School in Los Angeles, California, USA, and Jose Rizal College, Mandaluyong, Rizal, Philippines, and her secondary education at the University of the Philippines (UP) Preparatory School. She finished her bachelor of arts degree, major in speech and drama, minor in anthropology, at UP Diliman in 1971. In New York, USA, she took special courses in magazine publishing at the New School for Social Research, a seminar on magazine management at Folio, and courses in photography at the International Center of Photography and New York University. She received grants from the Australian and French governments, and UNESCO to observe cultural management.

She is a trustee of the National Museum of the Philippines and Museo ng Kaalamang Katutubo, as well as a member of the Board of Advisers for Ayala Museum.

She served as president of the board, and then vice chairman for cultural development of the Metropolitan Museum of Manila from 1986 to 1995, during which experiments in museum education for civics education were conducted. She was also commissioner of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) representing the subcommission for cultural heritage in 1992-95, and commissioner of UNESCO National Commission of the Philippines in 1992-2011, for which she chaired its Committee for Social and Human Sciences in 1999-2011 with an emphasis on linking social and human sciences with the humanities in civics education. She has served on the board of judges of the Doreen Gamboa Fernandez Food Writing Award, the first nationwide culinary essay contest, since its inception in 2002.

Sta. Maria’s numerous essays on cultural history and culinary heritage have appeared in books like The Culinary Culture of the Philippines, 1976; the Filipino Heritage series and Turn of the Century, 1978; Comfort Food, 2004; Slow Food, 2005; In Good Hands: The Metrobank Story, 2010; Quezon City: The Rise of Asia’s City of the Future, 2010; Savor the Word, 2012; in her daily column (alternating with Corazon Alvina) titled “Halupi: Spirits of Reminiscence,” 1986-89, in The Manila Times as well as her weekly column “Pahiyas” for the Philippine Star, 1989-96, and “The Joyful Cook” for the Philippine Daily Inquirer, 2002-3; and in popular and specialized publications like Archipelago, Arts of Asia (Hong Kong), Mabuhay magazine of the Philippine Airlines, the Central Bank’s Barilla, The Barnacle of the Manila Yacht Club, Bulletin Today, Contempo, For Children, The Journal of History of the Philippine National Historical Society, Metro Magazine, Mr. & Ms., Panorama, Petron Art Folio, Philippine Tatler, Perro Verde, Philippines-Spain: A 300 Year Gastronomic Journey (Madrid Fusion Manila, 2015), Selected Papers of the Annual Manila Studies Conference, Spices, Times Journal, Veritas, Viewfinder of the Camera Club of the Philippines, and Woman’s Home Companion.

Her published books include Fountain of Gold: The Club Filipino Story and Household Heirlooms and Antiques, 1983; Halupi: Essays in Philippine Culture, 1989, a compilation of her and Alvina’s columns in The Manila Times; In Excelsis: The Vision and Mission of Jose Rizal, Philippine National Hero, 1996; Visions of the Possible: Legacies of Philippine Freedom, 1998; A Cultural Worker’s First Manual, 2001; The Governor General’s Kitchen: Philippine Culinary Vignettes and Recipes, 1521-1935, 2006; The Foods of Jose Rizal, 2012; Ayala Foundation at 50, 2012; and Coconut Champion: Franklin Baker Company of the Philippines, 2016.

Sta. Maria also wrote books for children such as Ang Panganay (The First Born), 1998, which won the Ceres Alabado Award for Outstanding Literature for Children; Naging Manlililok si Wigan (Wigan Becomes a Sculptor), 2009; Naging Pintor si Tominaman sa Rogong (Tominaman sa Rogong Becomes a Painter), 2009; and What Children Should Know about Philippine Food, 2016, all published by Adarna House.

Sta. Maria has also delivered lectures on Philippine culture to academic and nonacademic audiences. Her photographs have appeared in books such as Metro Manila in Color, 1978, Spanish Legacy in the Philippines, 1981, Household Heirlooms and Antiques, 1983, The Filipinos, 1987, and Our Philippines: Intimate Images, 2015; in magazines like Mabuhay and Panorama; and in exhibitions both here and abroad.

Her honors include several Philippine National Book Awards and World Gourmand Cook Book Awards (food history category); a knighthood in the Grand Order of Arts and Letters bestowed by the Republic of France, 1990; Mariang Maya Award from Sigma Delta Phi Alumnae Association for culture and history writing; Outstanding Professional Award in the field of arts and letters from the UP Alumni Association, 1999; Dangal ng Haraya lifetime achievement award from NCCA for cultural management, 2001; SEA Write Award for distinguished ASEAN writers, 2001; and Emilio Aguinaldo Award from the Province of Cavite for cultural advocacy writing, 2007. Written byRosalinda Galang, updated by Cecilia S. De La Paz, with notes from Love Belle Calimoso

Sources:

Adarna House 2014; Inquirer.net 2012a; NCCA, n.d.a;

Sta. Maria, n.d.

SUAREZ, FRANCISCO Active 1716-60. Engraver. One of several eminent Filipino engravers on copper in the 18th century, he practiced his profession ahead of Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay by 15 years. This implies that he was much older than the latter. Suarez’s earliest work is the San Rafael Arcangel (Saint Rafael the Archangel), which appeared in Beneficios y Favores Singulares (Special Benefits and Favors), 1716, a sermon in praise of the saint preached by Fr Pablo Clain. In 1729, he engraved the image of Santo Domingo de la Penitencia (Penitence of Saint Dominic) that illustrated Breve Resumen (Short Summary), a biography of Pope Benedict XIII by Jose Manuel Medrano. In 1734, Suarez collaborated with de la Cruz Bagay in the project of Gov-Gen Fernando Valdes Tamon to print the map of the Philippines charted by the Jesuit cartographer Fr Pedro Murillo Velarde. In 1737, Suarez did his most elaborate work, the title page of La Razon en las Medidas (The System of Measurements), the book written by Jose Nuno de Villavicencio in defense of the measuring standards used by the Manila merchants in the galleon trade. The book also contained three other engravings bearing the signature of a Luis Suarez, most likely Francisco’s relative.

The elegant illustration drawn by Suarez for the title page of La Razon el las Medidas auspiciously suited the theme of the book that defended the probity of the business dealings of Manila merchants. Suarez designed a three-storied triumphal arch in the center or archway on which was printed the bibliographical details of the work. The first story of the pediment features a pair of niches, with the muse of Arithmetic on the left, and that of Geometry on the right. Above each of the muses are a conch, on top of which, on the second story, is a cherub in relief. The arch is topped by a pediment decorated with trumpeting angels. Suarez’s ornamental sources were eclectic, mostly renaissance and baroque. The artist’s fine stippling and hatching points to his metier as engraver.

In 1738, Francisco engraved a portrait of Philip V, enclosed in an oval frame and adorned with a crown at the center. The portrait was drawn over the view of an ocean in which could be seen a two-masted war vessel. The view is flanked by two Corinthian columns topped by a crown. The left column is wrapped by a ribbonlike band on which the word “plus” (further) could be read; the right one is similarly decorated with the word “ultra” (beyond), visible on the ribbon. This engraving came out in the book Cursus Juris Canonici (A Course in Canon Law) that came out in 1743. In 1749, Francisco engraved the image of San Nicolas de Tolentino (Saint Nicholas of Tolentino) that adorned Sermones Varios (Various Sermons), a book of sermons preached by Fr Joseph de la Concepcion. In 1760, Suarez again collaborated with de la Cruz Bagay in illustrating Gaspar Aquino de Belen’s Manga Panalanging Pagtatagobilin sa Caloluoa nang Tauong Naghihingalo (Prayers for Commending the Soul of the Dying). This is Suarez’s last known project, perhaps his last, after 44 years of distinguished productivity. It may be surmised from the presence in the pasyon of a print by Luis de la Cruz that the latter had to come in for the former in the middle of the project. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

SUBANG, GAMALIEL (Gamaliel Ignacio Subang) b. Cebu City 7 Jul 1939. Painter. His parents are Jovencio Subang and Manuela Ignacio. Subang married Felixberta Paragsa from Bantayan Island, Cebu. His love for art is inherited by two of his sons, Albryant and Rammilito, who are also artists in their own right. He belongs to the closely knit group of Cebuano artists, which includes the Mendoza brothers. He is a self-taught artist, not having gone through a fine arts course. After a boyhood of selling newspapers, he worked in a sign shop where he was assigned to do portraits. He avers that he was never under the tutelage of Martino Abellana, the Cebuano maestro, but the elder artist’s influence is seen in Subang’s impressionist freshness of color and painterly approach. Though Subang has taken off from the impressionists, he has developed his own original interpretation of impressionism in what he calls “radiation and refraction,” components of his theory of “scientific realism,” in which forces of nature such as air and light combine with its objects (trees, rocks, mountains) to produce a realistic portrait of environment. In many of his works, the tropical heat emits a strong orange light that sets its mark on the people and objects of the environment. His theory is that light as it strikes objects or passes through them creates effects of refraction that very subtly changes depending on the angles and shift of the point of view, thus introducing movement and avoiding the static. Light as heat and warmth assumes a radiating energy that he uses dramatically or modulates softly. In his personal vision, landscapes are made of living forces of nature that interact and harmonize.

Many of his works are landscapes and paintings of ordinary people at work, such as Copra Workers, 1989, which features a bare-chested man caught in the act of splitting open a coconut, bathed in golden light. His paintings feature radiant colors and painterly brushstrokes. Despite facing various ailments, he maintains an optimistic view of life, living in his rented apartment that also functions as a gallery. Having pursued poetry, singing, stage acting, and painting, Subang has made the most of his talents. To him, painting is a “source of joy,” and art is an “honest and personal” endeavor, a reflection of the artist’s emotions and outlook in life. According to a personal anecdote, during a funeral for his best friend’s sibling, he dozed off and woke up early the next day witnessing a beautiful landscape before him, which became his source of inspiration. For the next 21 days, he woke up at the same hour to paint.

Subang held his first one-person show at the ABC Galleries in 1976 and has joined several group shows, including one where he exhibited with his sons, Subang Sun and Sons, 1994, at the Manila Pavillion and Liongoren Gallery. His succeeding solo exhibitions include one held at the Liongoren Art Gallery in 1984; The Suns of Subang, 1995, Gallery “Y”; and Master of Line and Color, 2001, ABC Galleries. He also gave a lecture on art at the USIS Lincoln Memorial as part of a monthly series of lectures on art by Cebuano artists and conducted art workshops in Monami Art Gallery. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Gamaliel Subang, n.d.; Subido 2007.

SUCGANG, TELESFORO (Telesforo Alayon Sucgang) b. Banga, Capiz (now Aklan) 5 Jan 1855. d. 16 Dec 1916. Painter, sculptor. Born to Eusebio Sucgang and Matea Alayon, he married Manuela Mateo of Madrid with whom he had 12 children. Sucgang showed interest in painting, carving, and music as a young boy. He studied at the Colegio de San Jose in Manila, later transferring to Colegio de San Juan de Letran, where he earned his bachelor’s degree. He continued his art studies at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura while working as an apprentice in the atelier of sculptor Juan Flameño. In 1884, Sucgang went to Madrid to study art. Upon his return from Europe in 1893, he taught modeling and engraving at the Escuela de Artes y Oficios in Iloilo. He contributed articles to the Manila paper El Comercio, to the periodicals El Porvenir de Visayas, El Panay, and El Ilonguillo published in Iloilo, and to La Revolucion published in Jaro. During the second stage of the Philippine Revolution, he served as commandant under Gen Martin Delgado. Sucgang helped to establish several academic institutions: the Instituto de Visayas in Jaro, Iloilo, in 1900; Instituto de Aklan in Kalibo; Instituto de Capiz, ca 1905; another in Capiz in 1907; and the Colegio de Minerva in Manila in 1912.

He also composed musical pieces, but none were published. He played the ucarina, guitar, violin, bandurria, and piano.

One of his paintings done in Madrid is Un Indio Modelo (A Native Model), 1886, which depicts a seminude brown-skinned male, presumably a Filipino, posed inside a studio and gazing at the viewer. While the painting may be seen as an anatomical study, it may also be considered the continuity of the tipos del pais (country scenes) style of painting, employing academic principles of painting. Other paintings done in Madrid were El Desembarco de Magallanes (The Landing of Magellan), sometimes called The First Mass in the Philippines, 1888, and La Ilegada de Legaspi y Urdaneta (The Arrival of Legaspi and Urdaneta). Aside from genre and still-life paintings, he also did portraits, including one of his friend Jose Rizal in 1891 and several other portraits of famous people, such as King Alfonso XIII and Victor Balaguer. He was also often commissioned by wealthy people to paint their ceilings and walls. Most of his sculptures are religious in character like Sagrada Familia (Holy Family), La Purisima Concepcion (The Immaculate Conception), and El Despojamiento de la Sagrada Tunica (The Disrobing of the Sacred Tunic). Written byE. Arsenio Manuel, updated by Jhoanne Kristine Vinuya and Cecilia S. De La Paz

Sources:

Fontanilla 2015; Ocampo 2015a, 2015b.

SURROUNDED BY WATER (SBW) is a seminal artist-run collective and art space formed in Mar 1998 by Wire Tuazon and schoolmates from the College of Fine Arts at the University of the Philippines Diliman. The following artists have been part of the collective: Mike Adrao, Victor Balanon, Argie Bandoy, Jonathan Ching, Mariano Ching, Lena Cobangbang, Louie Cordero, Christina Dy, Lyra Garcellano, Nona Garcia, Geraldine Javier, Keiye Miranda, Mike Muñoz, Jayson Oliviera, Gary Ross Pastrana, Lakay Ranjo, Eric Roca, Amiel Roldan, Erik Sausa, Yasmin Sison, Kreskin Sugay, Ferdz Valencia, and Alvin Villaruel.

SBW began as an experimental platform that provided an opportunity for young, emerging artists to exhibit works and to exchange ideas with their peers in an informal and alternative setting. Funded and organized by artists, its exhibition program was lenient and organic. Initially unable to access the institutional support of museums or galleries, the space functioned as an incubator of ideas and practices, enabling beginning artists to experiment with various media and pursue activities not normally embraced by mainstream channels of validation. In its early stages, artists were also initiated into organizing, programming, and curating by and for themselves.

The inaugural location of SBW was on Manila East Road Hi-Way, Angono, Rizal. The lack of funding prompted the space to close down in Jun 2000. In the same year, SBW moved to The Pied Piper Place, Mandaluyong City, when a former bakeshop was offered to the collective free of rent for a limited time. Its every room was appropriated as an exhibition venue, including the kitchen and stock room. From Oct 1999 to Jun 2001, SBW’s exhibition program supported the works of the collective as well as similar group initiatives like Anino Shadowplay and UGATLahi. Senior practitioners and curators were invited to organize exhibitions there as well, such as Roberto Chabet who curated the shows Handheld at SBW Angono; Panic Attack at SBW EDSA; and Surrounded, an off-site exhibition of SBW artists’ works at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Bulwagang Juan Luna (also known as the Main Gallery) in 2001. The regional exchange exhibitions curated by Bobi Valenzuela signaled an attempt to dialogue with artists practicing beyond Manila. SBW hosted the exhibition of artists from Mindanao in 2003; while in 2001, Iligan City and Cebu hosted SBW for their exhibitions Portalet and Portable Landscapes. The same period reflected a track record of support for the development of intermedia, as in the SBW Annual Sound Art Festivals and through performances by the Cavite-based experimental band Elemento, headed by Lirio Salvador. Dog Show, 2007, an annual invitational group exhibition of SBW has been held in independent spaces like Green Papaya even after the SBW space closed down.

In 2001, SBW held its second Fanzine Convention, an indication of support for lo-fi culture through zine production. SBW also organized talks in its EDSA space by contemporary artists active in the field such as Alfredo Juan and Isabel Aquilizan, Elmer Borlongan, Noel Cuizon, Alfredo Esquillo Jr, Jojo Legaspi, Alwin Reamillo, and Jose Tence Ruiz. Other SBW activities include film screenings, fora, poetry readings, and festival-pegged community-based projects. Although selling art was not SBW’s priority, it maintained a stockroom for consignment of selected works. In 2002, SBW moved to 18th Ave, Cubao, in a space adjacent to the artist-run Big Sky Mind. The inaugural exhibition in Cubao, paradoxically titled Mainstream was also curated by Roberto Chabet. Moreover, SBW had an exchange project with the Singapore-based space Plastique Kinetic Worms in the same year.

Due to persistent logistical challenges, the collective decided to close down the space in 2004. Artists who had been actively involved in SBW recognize its influence in their respective careers, harking to days of “shared idealism” and recalling its role in supporting their creative endeavors during their budding years amid minimal resources. Retrospective exhibitions of the SBW collective include In the Ocean without a Boat or a Paddle, 2009, Blanc Compound, Mandaluyong, and Surrounded by Water, Over the Water, 2013, Equator Art Projects, Singapore. Written byLouise Anne D. Marcelino

Source: Garcellano 2014.

SYJUCO, CESARE (Cesare Limcaco Syjuco) aka Cesare A.X. Syjuco. b. Manila 20 Aug 1953. Multimedia artist, poet, critic. The son of Augusto Syjuco and Aurora Limcaco, Cesare grew up in Australia and the United States where he obtained his formative education. He married artist Jean Marie Ricafort with whom he has five children. Returning to Manila, he enrolled at De La Salle University for courses in literature. Inclined to the arts since childhood, he was earlier recognized for poetry and fiction. In 1973, he turned to the visual arts, becoming both an art critic and an artist. Syjuco’s first solo exhibition was held at the Gallery of the Hyatt Regency Manila in Dec 1976, followed by another in the same venue in Mar 1977 and the Art Associates Showroom, Makati, in Aug 1977. His 1982 work that won in the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition appears to be an old Buddhist silk painting from a distance at first glance but is actually a multimedia collage in the pop art vein, with the faces of Andy Warhol and Marilyn Monroe among the images in the design.

Nourished in the Western artistic concepts and attitudes of the 1970s, Syjuco is a versatile artist along the conceptual and pop styles. His Tanka series is pegged on representationalism and other traditional traits of painting as a two-dimensional representation. His found objects and multimedia assemblages bring forth the bizarre to lay down metaphysical questions or simply to give tongue-in-cheek commentary on the erratic nature of human culture and society.

In 1992, Syjuco disappeared from the art scene. He came back in 2004 with Flashes of Genius, a major exhibit mounted at the Bulwagang Juan Luna (also known as the Main Gallery) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The works featured his Literary Hybrids—installations that combined poetry and visual art. Since then until 2011, he has had 12 solo exhibitions showcasing these hybrids and his spoken word performances. Syjuco formed the Electric Underground Collective in 2006, an organization of artists coming from different artistic fields. He also organized numerous events that showcased multimedia art performances, sound art, experimental film, and spoken word poetry. In 2008, he organized a mobile art project called New Art Lab Road Tour, where he brought spoken poetry events and multimedia exhibits to different places such as schools, galleries, and museums. A year later, he launched his YouTube videos that featured his spoken word performances from 2005 to 2008. In addition, he released A Sudden Rush of Genius, a package consisting of a CD album, a book, and a video set of his spoken poetry performances from 1981 to 2008. In 2010, A Sudden Rush of Genius was one in five finalists for best book design in the National Book Awards. He officially launched the album in 2011, accompanying it with a spoken word performance.

Syjuco’s awards include the Purita Kalaw-Ledesma Award for Art Criticism, 1980; grand prize, Tanka: Be Wary of Green, Be Most Wary of Memory, 1982 AAP competition; third prize for the collection The Chameleon in the poetry category, English division, of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards in 1983; Ten Outstanding Young Men of the Philippines for art and culture advancement, 1991; the CCP Thirteen Artists award, 1992; the Gerry Roxas Foundation Presidential Award for Outstanding Achievement in the Arts; the UNESCO Gold Medal for Photography and Design; the Catholic Mass Media Award for Outstanding Communicator; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan Award for new media in 2007; and the Lasallian Lifetime Achievement Award, 2007. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source: Syjuco, n.d.

SYJUCO, JEAN MARIE (Jean Marie Borja Ricafort-Syjuco) b. Manila 26 Jun 1952. Mixed media artist, performance artist. Daughter of Amado Ricafort and Pilar Borja, Jean Marie married multimedia artist and poet Cesare Syjuco with whom she has five children, three of whom—Michelline, Maxine, and Trix—are also artists in their own right. She graduated in 1975 from the University of the Philippines (UP) with a bachelor of science degree in industrial engineering, and is self-taught in the visual arts.

In Manila’s contemporary art scene, she is the most visible practitioner and orchestrator of performance art. Syjuco’s earliest attempts at performance, in her own words, were “very Western-style, sleight-of-hand technical feats of pre-conceived abrakadabra,” referring to the mostly brief conceptual “happenings” that she used to synchronize as supplement to her exhibition, such as in her Sleeper: New Works in Transmedia, 1985. In 1988, she launched the Mano+Mano series of works based on an ancient ritual of healing, which marked her conversion to socially committed and nationalistic performance. In its first episode called Isang Daan at Isang Dangkal (One Hundred and One Handspan), she explored the overseas Filipino domestic helper’s plight. This was followed by Oksidyin (Oxygen), 1988, on the theme of ecology, an elaborate collaboration of multimedia art for video. Porkilo (Per Kilo), 1989, was on the issue of mail-order bride, first performed at the Performance Space Gallery in Sydney, Australia, and reworked several times. Patawad, Diyos-Bundok (Forgive Us, God of the Mountain), 1991, focused on the Mount Pinatubo themes. Puting Uwak (White Crow), performed in 1992 at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino (also known as the Little Theater) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), was on the theme of violence and redemption from despair. The Bangkok Project, 1993, was a performance collage of past Mano+Mano episodes.

Since 1988, Syjuco’s performances have been lengthy quasi-surreal multimedia extravaganzas built around a social narrative: woman-victim degenerates into a hysterical madwoman who does violence to herself by shearing her own hair or bathing herself with a pail full of flour, dirt, mud, ash, eggs, or “blood.” She then concludes by magically transforming herself into a babaylan or shaman in a trance of healing. A cast of supporting performers, and a complex crew of installation and musical artists, light and sound technicians, and video-documentary staff support her semi-improvised gestures and monologues. She has also done sculptures that are conceptual, witty, and structural, drawing upon her engineering background. Her Toys for Grownups series are brightly painted plywood collections of creatures such as giraffes, complete with sound devices and illusory mirrors inviting viewer participation. In 2008, she and her husband Cesare held their first ever collaborative exhibit in Mag:net Gallery in Makati titled 2 Minds, Many Madnesses, a commemoration of their 30 years in marriage and in art. Whereas Cesare’s art was witty and challenged the viewer to question whether what he read or saw was true or not, Jean Marie’s pieces in the exhibit were more sentimental. Her installations portrayed the reality of death and impermanence, as seen in her installation where an egg lay abandoned in its nest, and in another piece which consisted of an empty wall with only a piece of rusty nail to suggest that a painting hung there before. In her Kites series, 2011, she cut up plain canvases, painted, and arranged them so that they looked like huge origami kites mounted on walls.

Together with her husband Cesare, she founded Art Lab, an atelier that serves as the family’s studio and exhibition space for works of their own and other artists. During the 1990s, Art Lab became a nesting ground for many conceptual and multimedia artworks. This art facility, initially located in Makati, was relocated to Ayala Alabang Village in Muntinlupa City in 2013. Like most independent, artist-run spaces, Art Lab’s mission is “to develop new directions and alternative new audiences for Philippine art.”

She participated in the second SEA Art Festival, Korea, 1990; the First ASEAN Artists Creative Interaction Project, Thailand, 1992; the Kayumanggi Presence ’93 (The Brown Presence ’93), a selection of Filipino artists from Hawaii, the US Mainland, Latin America, and the Philippines, Honolulu Academy of Art, Hawaii, USA, 1993; and the Fifth Havana Art Biennial, Centro Wilfredo Lam, Cuba, 1993. She also participated at the Lopez Museum’s 50th anniversary exhibit called Threads, 2010, held at Rockwell Power Plant Mall in Makati City, where contemporary artists were asked to produce their own interpretation of the museum through creating another artwork or through “cosplaying,” or costume-playing, characters from the museum’s iconic pieces. For her reference, Syjuco used Juan Luna’s [España y Filipinas] (Spain and the Philippines) and made them into Barbie dolls. In 2015, she joined the National Art Fair at SM Megamall with her Enigma series—abstract compositions of white geometric shapes suggesting spaces and corners of walls.

She won the gold medal for sculpture in the 1980 Art Association of the Philippines art competition for Traps: Approach to Mass and Insinuation, an installation of nylon cords and hookeyes; and gold medal for Slides OP #52, liquitex and gesso on canvas, in the 1983 East-West Center Small Works Competition. In 1990, she received the CCP Thirteen Artists award. Written byImelda Cajipe-Endaya, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Art Lab 2015; Art Radar 2010; Asia Art Archive 2015a; DTI’s Sikat Pinoy National Art Fair 2015; Lopez Museum 2015; Manila Fame 2015; Nova Gallery Manila 2015; Philstar.com 2010; Sillada 2008.

TABUENA, ROMEO (Romeo Villalva Tabuena)b. Iloilo City 22 Aug 1921. Painter. d. San Miguel de Allende, Mexico 15 Oct 2015. Tabuena studied fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP). He also studied at the Art Students League in New York, USA, in 1952 and at the Academie de la Grande Chaumiere in France in 1954. He lived in Mexico for several decades, but he has kept his Philippine citizenship.

One of the Neo-realists, he began his career with several exhibits of drawings and watercolors at the Philippine Art Gallery in 1949. He is best known for his watercolors, at times in a vertical format influenced by Chinese painting. These near-monochromatic watercolor landscapes of nipa huts, farmers, and carabaos are done in an exquisite style, with attenuated figures spread out in large tonal areas suggesting early morning fog.

Tabuena had another side to his art, and this was expressed in dark oil paintings, some of which seemed to reflect the “proletarian” concerns of the period, as in Coal Gatherers. Here the figures are short and squat, with expressionist distortion and with no bright colors to relieve the heavy atmosphere. He approaches expressionism, especially in such a work as Childbirth, in which the pangs of childbirth are expressed in elongated figures and dramatic lighting, which hints of fears of mythological beings. A later series consists of heads done in a monochromatic style with cubist influence, their jagged, angular features suggesting years of toil and arduous struggle.

When Tabuena settled in Mexico, he developed a colorful, prismatic style with folk subjects, including street sweepers, candle vendors, guards, and laundry women. Tabuena had several one-man shows both in the Philippines and in Mexico City, including a retrospective exhibit spanning 10 years of work at the Philippine Art Gallery in Manila in 1959. In 1965, he represented the Philippines as its official artist and art commissioner in the Eighth Biennial of Sao Paulo, Brazil. In 1995, the Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes sponsored his major exhibit for his long residency in Mexico and his passion for its artistic culture, particularly his town of residence, San Miguel de Allende, State of Guanajuato.

Tabuena won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: second prize, Agnus Dei (Lamb of God), 1949, and honorable mention, Black Christ, 1952. Aside from these, he also received numerous awards and citations in Europe, including the Golden Centaur Award from the Academia Italia; the Medaglia al Merito from the International Parliament; and the Master of Painting, honoris causa, given by the International Seminar of Modern Art in Bannierre Europeanne des Artes. He was also cited for his artistry and active participation in cultural events on the Golden Anniversary of Instituto Allende. In 1996, he received a presidential citation from then-president of the Philippines Fidel Ramos for “exemplifying the best of Filipino talent and excellence through his outstanding mastery in painting” and “elevating the quality of Philippine painting.” In 2000, he was granted a Millennium Show by the Philippine Embassy as a sign of cultural agreement between the Philippine and the Mexican governments. An exhibit called Rediscovering Romeo Tabuena: The Later Work was held in Ayala Museum in 2009. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Philstar.com 2009; Tabuena 2015a, 2015b.

TALAANDIG ARTISTS The Talaandig Artists belong to an indigenous community in Barangay Songco in Lantapan, Bukidnon, in southern Mindanao. They are known for their soil paintings depicting their epic tales and the worldview and spiritual beliefs of their people. The artists started the practice of soil painting in 1995 and have since participated individually and collectively in various exhibitions.

The Talaandig are one of the non-Islamized indigenous tribes living in the area around the Kitanglad Mountain Range. Communities are also to be found in North Cotabato, Agusan del Sur, and the Pantaron-Sumapay-Kubatungan and Minala mountain ranges. They are one of the lumad (indigenous people) who have been successful in preserving their traditional chants, weaving, and dance, keeping a strong belief in the spirit world and respect for the environment. To pass on the indigenous culture to their youth, the School of Living Traditions was put up by the Council of Elders of the tribe. The Talaandig community in Miarayon consider the elders as the original artists from whom they learn how to make crafts for livelihood and entertainment, embroidery of different patterns in cloth, healing dances and dances for special occasions, different songs with various themes to suit an event, and rituals using specific objects and materials.

Rodelio Linsahay Saway, aka Waway, is the cultural chieftain who first experimented with soil in the early 1990s as painting material and then taught other Talaandig the technique of using different shades of available soil as pigment with white glue as binder. Waway is a younger brother of tribal leaders Datu Migketay Victorino L. Saway and Datu Makapukaw Adolino Saway. Waway is a musician who makes and plays native instruments. He has recorded albums of tribal music and with his fellow lumad musicians has joined concerts and music festivals in as far away as South Korea, Taiwan, and New York. He is an educator and an advocate of lumad culture.

Other members of the collective who have made their mark in the artistic landscape are Marcelino Balugto Poonon Necosia Jr, a Mindanao regional winner of the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards (PAA), 2007 and 2009; Solimon Poonon, also a PAA winner in the regional level, 2009; Raul Sungkit Bendit, Adelfa “Nanay Ipa” Saway Kinuyog, Salima Saway, and Renjielou Salem who exhibit at the yearly Kalinawa Art Foundation shows.

Two major exhibitions participated in by the Talaandig Artists as a collective are NCCA’s co-curated exhibition Sungdu-an 5 Current: Daloy ng Dunong, 2009, at the National Museum in Metro Manila and the Singapore Biennale (SB) in 2013. For the Biennale, 10 artists from the Talaandig Indigenous community made a collaborative mural titled Memories of the Peoples of the Earth: The Talaandig R/evolution. It is a four-panel soil-on-canvas, 244 x 488 cm mural. This was shown at the Singapore Art Museum together with other selected works from the Southeast Asian region. This particular work veered away from the usual epic tales which are a favorite theme of the artists. The SB 2013 soil painting is a folk art rendition of a panoramic map of the Talaandig lands, showing conflicts between old traditions, new technology, and their material and spiritual worlds.

Another noteworthy project was to make 1,001 paintings in one year. It was called the Talaandig 1001 Millennium Soil Painting Project, 2009. Those already trained through past soil painting workshops made artworks on themes and issues identified as relevant to the tribe. This activity was spearheaded by the Indigenous Community of Artists of the Talaandig People. Talaandig soil painting methods have also been taught to the Manobo Pulangiyen tribe of Bendum Central Mindanao under the Bridging Leadership in Mindanao Project, 2011, of the Environmental Science for Social Change. Written byKelly P. Ramos

Sources:

Native Planet 2014; Saway 2013; Saway 2014; Singapore Biennale 2014; Sintaon 2014; Snippets 2009e; Sonza 2011.

TAM-AWAN VILLAGE Founded in 1998, the aggregation of salvaged traditional Cordilleran houses making up Tam-awan Village is situated in Pinsao Proper, along the border of La Trinidad and Baguio City, in an area that once served as a cattle ranch. The heritage project is fueled by the observation that the terrain of Baguio, the City of Pines, had been changing along with the shifting lifeways of ethnolinguistic groups based in the Cordillera mountain range. While their locations were still a destination for local and foreign tourists, Baguio-based tribes were seen as slowly replacing traditional methods of building homes, along with other practices and customs. Modern hardware and building implements as well as the need to strategically relocate nearer busy roads were increasingly favored by locals. Hence, the project was largely anchored on preserving, promoting, and making traditional Cordillera engineering and architecture more accessible to a general public.

Tam-awan was the brainchild of National Artist Benedicto “BenCab” Cabrera and other former members of the Baguio Arts Guild. They envisioned a living museum that would serve as a hub for Baguio’s artistic community. With the help of Chit Asignacion and artist Jordan Mang-osan, among others, the idea was realized. Chanum Foundation has managed the village from its inception.

Century-old houses in Banga-an, Ifugao, made up the first three huts that served as prototypes. Each one was meticulously dismantled, transported, and rebuilt. To ensure that traditional methods of building were carried out, local artisans were employed. Original materials such as timber for the main structure, and support posts made of hardwood were used in the reconstruction. Nails were notably absent while the roofing material, cogon grass and reed, required the most upkeep. For stability, stone walls were created to support the soil upon which the huts were built. In keeping with tradition, offertory rituals were done for the spirits therein. At present, there are seven huts from Ifugao and two from Kalinga assembled and laid out like a village though with much less spacing between houses as would be found in an actual terraced site. To ensure Tam-awan’s sustainability and self-sufficiency, eight huts are being rented out to itinerants and tourists who wish to experience living in the traditional dwellings. Also built into the village is a café and gift shop.

Artists from Baguio and the Cordilleras have since flocked to the village and considered it their haven, holding solo and group exhibitions in the village gallery, alongside other projects undertaken in art spaces outside of Baguio. A group of artists known as Tam-awan Village Artists, together with other locals, hold portrait sessions, livelihood demonstrations, lectures, workshops on printmaking, wood carving, weaving, papermaking, solar drawing, and rice-wine making. Art of different forms are showcased in one of the huts retrofitted into a gallery, while art installations are often strewn along the village’s nature trail. Some of the members of the Tam-awan artists are Jordan Mang-osan, Marc “Dungaw” Tandoyog, Leonard Aguinaldo, Arthur Lozano, Herwin Buccat, John Frank Sabado, Edwin Macadaeg, Jed Alangui, Patric Palasi, Tara Natividad, and Luisa Galang.

Invoking Tam-awan’s character as “vantage point,” Tam-awan artists launched an international art festival with the village as site for engaging discussions and dialogues on ideas of representation, authenticity, art, traditions, and culture. The annual Tam-awan International Arts Festival began in 2010 and has since been supported by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Written byThea C. Garing

TAMPINCO, ISABELO (Isabelo Lacandola Tampinco) b. Binondo, Manila 19 Nov 1850. d. 20 Jan 1933. Sculptor. He was the son of Leoncio Tampinco, a sculptor and wood-carver, and Justa Lacandola, a descendant of Tondo’s Raja Lacandola. He married Victoria Jocson, sister of sculptor Crispulo Jocson. They had nine children. He had a second wife, Carmen Rojas, by whom he had two children. Although his family was not wealthy, he was able to study under Agustin Saez and Lorenzo Rocha at the Escuela de Artes y Oficios, where Jose Rizal and Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo were his classmates at one time. In 1890, his atelier on what is now R. Hidalgo St was a thriving business. He was teaching at the Escuela de Artes y Oficios when the Philippine Revolution broke out and he became a volunteer in the Spanish military services. He resumed teaching at the Philippine School of Arts and Trades, 1908-10. He helped establish the Centro de Escultores in 1908 and served as its treasurer. In 1914, together with Graciano Nepomuceno, he set up a shop on Evangelista St, Quiapo, with a branch on Arlegui. When the partnership was dissolved in 1922, he continued the shop with his sons Angel and Vidal.

Tampinco’s greatest achievement, which was burned in 1945, consisted of the wood carvings he made for the San Ignacio Church in Intramuros, Manila. He devoted six years to this project, employing some 50-60 workers. Except for the pulpit and the La Inmaculada Concepcion (The Immaculate Conception), which was done jointly by his brother-in-law Crispulo Jocson and Manuel Flores, all the other figures of saints, the main altar, the fluted columns, and vaulted ceiling, the 14 Stations of the Cross, and other carved objects and decorative works were accomplished by Tampinco. The church was hailed as a masterpiece, “a monument worthy of any land” (Norton in Manuel 1955b, 444) with a splendidly carved interior unrivalled in “its exquisite conception, ornate execution and even in its artistic unity” (Manuel 1955b, 445).

Other examples of Tampinco’s art are the high-relief carving on the molave door of the Santo Domingo Church in Intramuros and the altars of the church of Laoag, Ilocos Norte, and Mangaldan, Pangasinan. The decorative wood carvings in Malacañan Palace, the Ayuntamiento, and the Ateneo de Manila were done by him and his sons. He also executed sculptures with religious themes for private individuals.

Tampinco is important for his advocacy of a native Filipino style in decorative art. As early as 1895, he exhibited architectural plans and models that became known later as the “Estilo Tampinco.” He used bunga (palm tree) trunks for columns, anahaw and banana leaves as details, and sala (woven mats) for arches and facades.
