These were used for picture frames (called “Tampinco frames”), window posts, curtain valances, arches, and furniture. “Estilo Tampinco” antedated the coming of Western Art Nouveau.

He received numerous awards for his work as sculptor and wood-carver: a silver medal and diplomas for the carved wooden cover of Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas (Plants of the Philippines) for the king of Spain, 1882; a civil merit medal from Gen Domingo Moriones y Morillo, 1880; a silver medal during the tercentenary celebration of Santa Teresa de Jesus, 1882; a silver medal in the Exposicion General de las Filipinas (Philippine General Exposition), 1887; gold medals in the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition), 1895; gold medal in the Exposicion Universal de Barcelona (Barcelona Universal Exposition), 1888; and gold and silver medals in the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in the United States, 1904.

Despite his achievements during his time and being named as “the Juan Luna of sculpture” (Valdez 2014), Tampinco is rarely known today for his art, due mainly to the damage the war imposed on his works and to insufficient research and scholarship on him and his oeuvre. In Aug 2014, an art book dedicated to his life and works was launched at the National Museum in partnership with Vibal Foundation. Santiago Albano Pilar, art historian, teacher, and author who wrote the book The Life and Art of Isabelo Tampinco, spent 10 years of rigorous research on the sculptor, interviewing families and sifting through old newspapers and magazines. He was helped by art collectors Ernie and Araceli Salas, who discovered Tampinco’s art during the 1980s. Aside from the book, a documentary titled Estilo Tampinco was also produced to tell the story of how they rediscovered Tampinco. It features talking heads, including Pilar, book editor and National Museum director Jeremy Barns, and Tampinco collectors. Written by E.Arsenio Manuel, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources :

Manuel 1955b; Valdez 2014; Zulueta 2014.

TAN, GERARDO (Gerardo del Mundo Tan) aka Gerry Tan. b. Manila 22 Jun 1960. Visual artist, curator, and art educator. He is the son of Arturo Parilla Tan and Teresita Lumibao del Mundo. Hefinished bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman College of Fine Arts (CFA) in 1982 and masters of fine arts, major in painting,at theState University of New York at Buffalo in 1992. He was a professorial lecturer at UP CFA from 1993 to 2000 and the former dean of the University of the East College of Fine Arts from 2002 to 2005.

As a conceptual artist, Tan explores the nature of art and how formsand materiality can be articulated in ideas andconcepts, be it through two-dimensional painting, sculpture, or installation art. HisPainting with Content, 2014,is rendered in gray monochromatic smudgesthat create a crustily marbled surface. While entranced with the energy of the painting’sapparently atmospherically pure form, itswholeness is disrupted by a small compartment on its lower left which conceals a photographof the same painting. The painting, which is a reconstruction of his earlier work done in 1986, deals with aesthetic questions related to the reproducibility of images and the spatial and temporal authenticity of a work.

Tan has participated in severalinternational exhibitions such as the 2nd Asian Art Show in Fukuoka Museum, 1982, and the1st Melbourne Biennale, 1999. He continues to work with contemporary artists making up the Bastards of Misrepresentation, which has aggressively and independently been exhibiting since 2010 in Berlin, Germany, Queens New York, and Paris, France. In This Is Not Sugimoto’s Drive-In Theatre, undated, Tan appropriated the black-and-white photographs of old American cinema houses taken by Japanese photographer Hiroshi Sugimoto. The painting touches on serial likeness among other recurring issues in Tan’s body of work which explores the capacity of art to rearticulate reality often in the most understated and ordinary of means.

Code, 2014, is a collection of found household objects, personal belongings, and quotidian materials he gathered from people. Similar to an earlier work done for the Melbourne Biennale, Tan created an inventory and catalogue of thecollected materials beforehanging these in the shape of a grid on the gallery’s white walls. The work comes across as anethnographic display of the everyday, with mundane materialshaving their own narrativeboth as art and as part of the social sphere of daily activities.

Tan was awarded the Cultural Center of the PhilippinesThirteen Artists Award in 1988. Written byClod Marlan Krister Yambao

TANIGUCHI, KITTY (Cristina Luces Sollesta-Taniguchi) Visual artist, organizer, curator, gallery owner. b. Manila 8 Jan 1952. Her parents are Francisco Sotelo Sollesta and Julita Andrada Luces. She is married to Kaoru Taniguchi.Her daughter Maria Taniguchi is also a visual artist, as well as her brother Danilo Sollesta. She attained her bachelor’s degree in mass communication in 1978 and master’s degree in English literature in 1985 from Silliman University, Dumaguete City. She also owns and operates Mariyah Gallery, which offers an exhibit space and meeting place for local artists. One of the major projects that emerged from this space is the international Terracotta Art Festival and Competition, 2005 and 2007, aiming to maximize the locally available terra-cotta as medium for art.

Dumaguete-based Taniguchi is a self-taught visual artist. She started out as a painter with her Paper City series, 1989, followed by a series of large-scale black and red paintings called Heroes and Dancers, 1994, in oil; and Tattoo and Tarot, 1998, a series in watercolor and handmade paper. In 1999, a major shift occurred in Taniguchi’s artistic vocabulary when she installed 50 life-size female torsos, her first attempt at terra-cotta sculpture. Titled Mannequins, 1998, the installation was shown at the Women Imaging Women Exhibit at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1999, featuring women artists from Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines.

These early works are peopled with human figures that interact with animal and spirit worlds drawn from memories of childhood, mostly in the mystical island of Siquijor, of travel in the cityscapes of Singapore and Japan, from personal and universal myths, and from the artist’s self-reflection on the role and status of women. These themes and the personal artistic iconography that would emerge in her body of work would resonate in later pieces, among them the Wrong Horizon series, 2004, and the three-panel Anthology of Myths and Muses, 2010. Variations on these themes and iconographic motifs would be inflected with observations from other cultures, resulting in artworks from various residencies such as White Carpet, 2013, in India; Ehipto, 2012, in Egypt; and a 400 x 200 m bronze piece sculpture Dreamer, 2011, which now sits in an ecological park in Jilin, China.

All in all, Taniguchi’s body of works are testimonies to the dislocations of the self as it travels through the contemporary landscape, thus expressing the permanence of change and the processual and transitional nature of cultures and identities. Written byFlaudette May V. Datuin

TANIGUCHI, MARIA b. Dumaguete City 21 Sep 1981. Intermedia artist. She is the daughter of painter and sculptor Cristina or Kitty Taniguchi. She received her bachelor of fine arts in sculpture at the University of the Philippines Diliman in 2007 and her master of fine arts in art practice at Goldsmiths, London, 2009. Taniguchi was selected to be part of the post academic LUX Associate Artists Program in London from 2009 to 2010.

Taniguchi’s works explore processes and translate concepts, frameworks, or systems into abstracted forms. Many of her works draw attention to the materiality of the media she employs. She is recognized for large-scale paintings assiduously rendered with patterns akin to brickwork in a series she began doing in 2008. These flat black canvases reveal subtle shapes with slight shifts in gradients appearing on the painting surface. Rather deliberately crafting narrative, her videos privilege elements such as lighting, color saturation and tonal gradations, motion, rhythm, composition, and sometimes sound. In the video Untitled [Celestial Motors], 2012, the jeepney’s body is captured in vivid detail, deprived of its usual baroque ornamentation and removed from the familiar context of the streets, the bare setting creating an aura of sophistication and glamor often elicited by product advertisements. The artist’s solo exhibition at the UP Vargas Museum titled Echo Studies, 2011, conflates process and the making of meaning through form by evoking interconnections. Her grid paintings and graphite drawings foregrounding negative spaces converse with the high-definition video Untitled [Dawn’s Arms]. The video features the foliage of Romblon and centers on a marble slab being transformed by a local craftsman into a sculpture alluding to a work by Georg Kolbe, evoking the intersections of stone, sculpture, maker, making, and place to an exhibition site.

The artist’s solo exhibitions include Maria Taniguchi, 2014, Silverlens Galleries, Singapore and Manila; Art Statements, 2013, Art Basel 44, Switzerland; and Rambler’s Association, 2012, Art Space Auckland. One of Taniguchi’s earliest exhibitions was Grave Findings: A Reclamation Project held at the Lopez Museum in 2005. She also participated in group exhibitions such as Don’t You Know Who I Am?: Art After Identity Politics, 2014, Museum of Contemporary Art Antwerp, Belgium; The Philippine Contemporary, 2013, Metropolitan Museum of Manila; A Reader of Materials and a Writer of Forms, 2012, MOT International, Brussels; and Roving Eye: Video from Southeast Asia, 2011, Sorlandets Kunstmuseum, Norway. Taniguchi participated in the following international residencies: Khalid Shoman Foundation in Amman, Jordan, 2013; Art Space Auckland in New Zealand, 2012; and Plastique Kinetic Worms in Singapore, 2003.

Taniguchi received the Ateneo Art Award in 2011 for her solo exhibition Echo Studies and in 2012 for Celestial Motors. Written byLouise Anne D. Marcelino

Source:

Taniguchi 2014.

TAPAYA, RODEL (Rodel Tapaya Garcia) b. Montalban, Rizal 10 Jul 1980. Painter and intermedia artist. He is the son of Rodolfo Garcia and Eutemia Tapaya. He is married to visual artist Marina Cruz. They live and work in Bulacan. He finished his certificate in fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts. In 2002, as part of his prize for the Nokia Art Awards, he went to the Parsons School of Design in New York where he took up intensive courses in drawing and painting. He then went to the University of Helsinki where he took further studies in art. Tapaya returned to the United States for an artist residency program in Vermont Studio Arts Center in 2008.

Tapaya’s early works are characterized by his use of grids that appear as a mesh that sometimes overlaps with the pictorial space and intervenes in the neat contouring of the subject as in Baka-Baka (Cows/Maybe), 2004. This mesh layer may also recede in the background as in Bulong Luntian (Green Whisper), 2006. In his later works, these grids would evolve into embellished patterns integrated into the subjects’ anatomy and as texture-filled garments with geometric designs, colors, and symbolisms as in the Parable series, 2006. Aside from employing this distinctive style element, he also integrated burlap as material for his paintings. Beginning in 2006, Tapaya explored folk motifs as subject for his art. His subjects, which used to be solitary creatures in a pictorial space, now become part of a community of characters that symbolize different archetypes in Filipino society.

The year 2008 marked a milestone in Tapaya’s practice as he started appropriating Filipino folk narratives. In Tapaya’s re-articulation of Philippine folk legends, myths, epics, and tales, the characters in these narratives become representations of contemporary realities and knowledge. This would lead to further shifts in his image-making in terms of scale as he started making large murals, and dioramas that house tableaus of Philippine folklore. He pursued this direction further in his 2010 exhibition Bulaklak ng Dila (Flower of the Tongue) at the UP Vargas Museum. In this exhibition, the pictorial space became larger and was filled with more characters situated in a vast array of flora and fauna. Tapaya also broadened his menu of materials with the introduction of resin sculptures, installations, paintings on glass, and decorative frames reminiscent of the platero’s (silversmith’s) traditional art.

Tapaya’s works have been exhibited in Singapore, China, Japan, the USA, and Germany in both group and solo shows. He represented the Philippines in the Nokia Art Awards Asia-Pacific Student Art Competition in Seoul, South Korea, in 2001 and won the grand prize. His works were shortlisted for the Ateneo Art Awards in 2004, 2006, and 2010. In 2011, he received the grand prize at the Asia Pacific Brewery Singapore Art Prize for Baston ni Kabunian, Bilang pero Di Mabilang (Cane of Kabunian Numbered but Cannot Be Counted). He received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award and the Ani ng Dangal Award from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2012. Written byManuel Kristoffer Giron

TAYAG, CLAUDE (Claude Suarez Tayag) b. Angeles City 7 Aug 1956. Painter, sculptor, furniture designer. He is the son of journalist Renato Tayag aka “Katoks” and Adoracion Suarez. He is married to Mary Ann Quioc. Tayag grew up in the ferment of lively discussions of art and culture among prominent painters like Vicente Manansala, Mauro Malang Santos, Emilio Aguilar Cruz (whom he considers his greatest influence), all friends of his father. Tayag is a self-declared autodidact; he derived his basic techniques from observing E. Aguilar Cruz, Sofronio Y. Mendoza aka SYM, Romulo Galicano, and other members of the Dimasalang Painters Group, who used to visit the Angeles countryside to render landscapes in plein air. He finished a bachelor of arts degree in economics at the University of the Philippines. Tayag is also a renowned chef, restaurateur, and food writer.

It was in 1978 that he appeared in the Philippine art scene. Tayag’s significant contributions to Philippine art lies in his elegant documentation of folk traditions like the Marinduque Lenten pageant in Moriones, 1982, at the Galerie Dominique, and vanishing colonial cultural objects like the carved and painted Christian images as in Santo, 1987, San Agustin Museum. In both themes, his works were characterized by a forceful spontaneity and a raw vigor almost verging on the crude that effectively capture the rich color, simple vision, and enduring appeal of these practices. In his large-scale sumi, Black Mountain, 1989, Cultural Center of the Philippines Bulwagang Carlos V. Francisco (also known as the Little Theater Lobby), on the other hand, he sought to trace the subliminal Oriental roots of his characteristic calligraphic handling of paints. Other than traditional Philippine folk practices, he has also exhibited European travelogue watercolor and Japanese ink paintings. In 1990, he had his first one-man show in wood at the Ayala Museum, Art Furniture, featuring art furniture from solid hardwood tempered by fine artisanship. Even before this exhibit, however, he had already been crafting traditional Filipino furniture such as tables, chairs, and plate containers, among others, with very simple, functional forms.

His sculptural works went through several phases, but the main perspective underlying each phase is the treatment of wood as a malleable plastic material to produce several possible forms that challenge what is traditionally expected of a rigid medium. His latest phase, consisting of the Totem Pole series, explores the different patterns created when a convex or a concave is placed adjacent a square log.

In 1997, he won the Guhit Award given by the Design and Architecture Magazine, recognizing his dexterity in the decorative arts. In 2005, he opened his own lifestyle store/gallery in Greenbelt, Makati City.

Since the beginning of his career as an artist in the late 1970s, Tayag has actively participated in several one-man and group exhibitions in the Philippines, China, the United States, and Spain, where he exhibited with both Filipino and Spanish artists. In 2003, he held a three-man show with Ben Cabrera and Patis Tesoro in a museum in his hometown, Angeles City. Other Filipino artists who exhibited in group shows with him include Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, Phyllis Zaballero, Soler Santos, Abdulmari Imao, and Sajid Imao. Tayag also participated in the 20th Asian International Art Exhibition at the Ayala Museum in 2005.

In 2013, his show Full Circle, held at the Bonifacio Global City in Taguig, showcased his latest huge black-and-white canvas paintings. It also served to commemorate his 35th year in the art industry since his first solo show in 1978. His artworks can be found in the public collections of establishments such as the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, PLDT, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, and Bank of the Philippine Islands. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Madrid Fusion, n.d.; Tayag, n.d.

TECSON, ASTER (Aster Valino Tecson) b. ca 1950. Painter. Formerly based in Baguio, his works were exhibited in Baguio cafés. He did several painting series of indigenous warriors of the Cordilleras. Many of these were vivid portraits rich in detail, possibly influenced by Masferre’s photographs. Other paintings dealt with the struggle of the indigenous communities for their ancestral lands, as when the projected Chico Dam threatened to engulf their lands. His vision of their struggle also went beyond limited sectoral issues to radical social change which would transform the entire Philippine society. He did several paintings couched in striking visual imagery which were made into posters because of their political content. One dealt with the subject of low intensity conflict, mainly psychological warfare that targets an entire population, including innocent children. Another work, Amerikanser (American Cancer), was strongly anti-imperialist and made use of various symbols. His works are visually complex, requiring a close and thorough study of their many elements.

Tecson won the third place in painting in the 1976 Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition. Written byAlice G. Guillermo

TEOTICO, DOMINGO (Domingo Eugenio Teotico) b. Santa Cruz, Manila 15 Sep 1853. d. 24 Feb 1904. Sculptor, wood-carver. He was the son of Santiago Teotico and Maria Eugenio. He married Braulia Domingo. After apprenticing under Leoncio Asuncion, he enrolled at the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura where he studied under Lorenzo Rocha. After eight years of apprenticeship, he opened a shop of his own on Palma St, Quiapo. He worked daily and far into the night such that he nearly went blind. He was a member of the Gremio de Escultores. He also served as cabeza de barangay (village leader). During the 1896 Revolution, he was communications chief and later commandant in the territorial militia.

Many of his works won awards. As a student he won second prize in the open competition held by the Sociedad de Escultores de Santa Cruz in 1880. His bust of Pope Gregory XV got a silver medal in the tercentenary celebration of Santa Teresa de Jesus in 1882. His wood carving Pobre Vencido (The Vanquished Poor) garnered a bronze medal in the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in Madrid in 1887, while another sculpture won an honorable mention at the Exposicion Universal de Barcelona (Barcelona Universal Exposition) in 1888. In the tercentenary celebration for San Juan de la Cruz in Manila in 1892, his San Francisco de Asis (Saint Francis of Assisi) received the second prize. A set of carved furniture he exhibited at the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas won him a silver medal in 1895, as well as a bronze medal at the Universal Exposition at Saint Louis in 1904. Most of his other works were wood carvings of santos for private homes such as the Sagrada Familia (Holy Family) for Martin Ocampo. Written by E. Arsenio Manuel

TESORO, PATIS (Ma. Beatriz Fabella Pamintuan Tesoro) b. Manila 29 Dec 1950. Fashion designer. She is the daughter of Ramon Pamintuan and Esperanza “Nena” Poblador Fabella. She is married to Atty Jose Claro Tesoro. Architect Augusto F. Villalon is a first cousin. As both designer and environmentalist, Tesoro gained media recognition as the “Grand Dame of Philippine Fashion” despite having no formal education in clothing design.

Her first exposure to clothing and fashion came from her mother, who ran a dress shop from home. Tesoro then learned to sew in grade school as part of the home education curriculum at Assumption, Iloilo. After attending Maryknoll (now Miriam College) from 1959 to 1968, she began studying art education at Marygrove College in Detroit, Michigan. She returned to the Philippines after only a year, upon her mother’s death in 1969. She returned to Maryknoll to continue her studies. As her husband’s family owned Tesoro’s, then the largest chain of stores specializing in Philippine handicrafts, she first ventured into the clothing business in 1972 initially with a line of embroidered blouses. By 1982, she launched her own label—Patis—followed by her first fashion show in 1984.

Tesoro’s first couture line came with the founding of thePatrones de Casa Manila, a group dedicated to preserving artifacts and creative expression relevant to Philippine history and culture. One of her advocacies with the Patrones was the establishment of a sustainable industry for the production and distribution of piña (pineapple) fabric. Handwoven and hand-spun from dried pineapple leaves, piña is traditionally associated with formal and elite Filipino clothing—specifically, the barong (traditional Filipino clothing for males) and the terno (traditional Filipino dress for females)—as it is notoriously difficult to produce and to weave. To revive piña cloth production, Tesoro lobbied Visayan local officials to set up courses that would train the next generation of piña weavers. She succeeded in doing this in 1985 (Milgram 2003). She also pioneered the development of piñaseda, a blend of synthetic fiber, silk, and piña fiber.

In 1992, Tesoro became the organizer of the Katutubong Filipino Foundation (KFF), which was devoted to providing tribal and rural-based Filipinos with livelihood opportunities while preserving their traditional arts and crafts. Under the supervision of Tesoro and then First Lady Amelita Ramos, the KFFparticipated in the Philippine Festival of Arts and Culture, held in France in 1994, and the Bonjour Manila exhibit in Printemps Department Store, Paris. Through such ventures, she showcased her talents all over the world, from New York, to Beijing, to Toronto.

In 2000, together with San Juan civic leader Guia Gomez, she introduced the “Ninay” doll, a collector’s item dressed in Philippine-made fabric and which was meant to depict Filipino customs and traditions. In 2013, she spearheaded the campaign to convert the Pamintuan ancestral home in Angeles City, Pampanga, into a museum that would showcase the best of Philippine textiles and social heritage. Written byAlice Sarmiento

Source:

Milgram 2003.

TING PING LAY b. Chunkong, Fukien, China 12 Apr 1927. Sculptor. Ting obtained his formative education at Fukien. He received his first schooling in art at Sinyu Normal College in 1945. Arriving in the Philippines in 1948, he studied at the School of Fine Arts, University of Santo Tomas (UST), where he obtained various prizes in the school’s art competitions, particularly the first prize at the UST Art Exhibition of 1954. Studying sculpture under Francesco Monti, Ting was to establish his reputation as a semiabstract sculptor through several winning pieces at the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) annual art exhibition.

Ting’s pre-1960 sculptures were described as “expressionistic.” These pieces were genre in subject matter, showing human figures apparently Oriental in proportion, in ordinary actions and poses, but animated with inner emotion. His forms and surfaces, however, are generally too polished and refined to be called expressionist. His work New Moon, 1960, presaged the style that he is best known for. The work in bronze depicts a nubile maiden, her form rendered semiabstract by simplification of the masses of her body, her contour and surface articulated with a minimum of texture to evoke shadows when the moon is yet small and young. Because of his sweeping, graceful but quiet contours, his shapes that are pared down to two or three groups of small curved masses, and his polished surfaces, Ting’s sensibility evokes the conciseness of Chinese nature poems. TingPingLay also produced elegant rubbings and woodcuts that recall traditional Chinese sources.

New Moon won for him the first prize in the 1960 AAP Annual Art Competition; Two Sisters, a sculptural piece, garnered second prize at the 14th AAP art competition in 1961; and Blue Night won the third prize at the 15th AAP art competition in 1962. In the same year, Ting represented the Philippines at the First International Art Exhibition in Saigon. A veteran of several solo and group shows in the Philippines and abroad, he exhibited his later sculptures in terra-cotta at the Hiraya Gallery in 1992.

In 2007, the exhibit Ting Ping Lay: Celebrating Figure and Form at the Yuchengco Museum in Makati featured his trademark small, freestanding sculptures as a celebration of his lyrical style that embraces the simplicity and fluidity of the female form. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source:

Yuchengco Museum 2007.

TOLENTINO, GUILLERMO (Guillermo Estrella Tolentino) b. Malolos, Bulacan 24 Jul 1890. d. Quezon City 12 Jul 1976. National Artist for visual arts. He was the son of Isidro Tolentino and Balbina Estrella. In 1932, he married Paz Raymundo. They had seven children. He was a pupil of Mrs H. A. Bordner who first instructed him in drawing at the Malolos Intermediate School. He finished his secondary education at the Manila High School. As a self-supporting student, he obtained his degree in fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1915. He left for the United States in 1919 and there, through his own merits, was granted a scholarship at Beaux Arts School, New York City, through the beneficence of Bernard Baruch, an American millionaire. In 1921, he finished his course at the Beaux Arts with awards. In the same year, he left the United States for Europe, visiting the famous museums and galleries in London and Paris. In 1922, he entered the Reggie Istituto di Belle Arti di Roma and graduated in 1923 with the highest honor partly through the support of the Italian colony in Manila. In Rome, he held his first solo exhibition, which included Saluto Romano (Roman Salute). In a sculptural competition held in the Eternal City, his Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse won second prize. Tolentino sailed back for Manila in 1924 and worked in his own studio for a year. In 1926, he was appointed instructor at the UP School of Fine Arts. In this school, he rose to professor, secretary, and finally director. He headed the school from 1953 until his retirement as Professor Emeritus in 1955.

Tolentino first attained nationwide recognition with the multifigural bronze cast Bonifacio Monument, which was designed in 1930 and unveiled in 1933. Other famous life-size statues by him are the Oblation, unveiled in 1935 at the UP campus on Padre Faura, the statue of President Ramon Magsaysay in the Government Service Insurance System Building lobby, and Alma Mater at the University of the East campus. He did numerous busts, like those of Lapu-Lapu, Antonio Luna, Gregorio del Pilar, Jose Rizal, Manuel Quezon, Epifanio de los Santos, A.V.H. Hartendorp, Fernando Amorsolo, Carlos P. Romulo, Jose Cojuangco, Manuel Roxas, Jaime and Sofia de Veyra. He gifted President Woodrow Wilson with a statue titled Peace, as a tribute to Wilson’s efforts to preserve peace in the world. He completed a suite of six oriental dancers, including that of the biblical dancer Salome, Maria Clara, and Persian, Javanese, and Chinese dancers, ca 1953. He did allegorical figures like Filipinas, also called Slave, a figure of a nude woman bound by ropes. He did religious images like the Immaculate Conception, 1936, and the Madonna and child, ca 1950. He designed the Maria Clara Award for film, and many other trophies and medals such as the official seal of the Republic of the Philippines and the medal of the Ramon Magsaysay Award.

A product of the classical academic tradition, Tolentino was a champion of classicism. From Jul to Oct 1948 in the Sunday Times Magazine and later in This Week, he engaged Victorio Edades in a written debate on classical and modern aesthetics, attacking “distortion” and reaffirming the value of classical art. Although Tolentino’s training was classical, his works were also permeated by the romantic sensibility that prevailed in the Western world from the early 19th century to the 1920s. Hence, his works were infused with drama and sentiment, particularly with nationalism since he was a fervent Rizalist.

Tolentino was also a guitarist, a spiritist, and translator. He could write in the ancient Tagalog alphabet, translated Rizal’s “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell) into Tagalog and Italian, and did the libretto for Felipe Padilla de Leon’s opera, Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), 1957.

Tolentino received numerous awards and citations in his lifetime. He was one of the two outstanding alumni of UP in 1933. He received the Sculptor of the Year award from the Philippine Institute of Architects, 1955; an award of merit from the United Nations Commission of the Philippines, 1959; the Rizal Pro-Patria award, 1961; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan award for sculpture, from the city of Manila, 1963; the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, 1967; the Presidential Medal of Merit, 1970; the Diwa ng Lahi Award, 1972; and the National Artist Award for visual arts, 1973. In 1976, the National Art Foundation of Malolos, chaired by Tolentino’s childhood friend Alfonso Calalang, published Tolentino, the first study of the artist written and designed by Rod Paras-Perez. On the artist’s 123rd birth anniversary in 2013, a retrospective exhibit titled Eskultor ng Lahing Filipino: Honoring the Life and Work of Artist Guillermo Tolentino was held at the National Museum of the Philippines. Written bySantiago A. Pilar and Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Paras-Perez 1976; Tejero 2013.

TORRES, EMMANUEL (Emmanuel Sinco Torres) aka Eric Torres. b. Manila 29 Apr 1932. Poet, essayist, art critic, curator. He is the son of Narciso Torres and Maria Sinco. He obtained a bachelor of arts in education from Ateneo de Manila University in 1954, and a master of arts in English from the State University of Iowa in 1957. Through a Fulbright-Smith-Mundt Fellowship, he was awarded an International Scholarship in creative writing and attended Paul Engle’s writing workshop at the same university. He taught English at the Ateneo College of Arts and Sciences from 1958 to 2001 and held the Henry Lee Irwin Chair in creative writing, 1990-91, and the Far East Bank and Trust Co. / Jose B. Fernandez Chair for art research, 1991-92. He served as curator of the Ateneo Art Gallery since its opening in 1960 until 2001.

He was editor in chief of the Philippine International, a cultural magazine, 1957-58; vice president of the Art Association of the Philippines, 1965; commissioner general of the Philippine participation in the 32nd International Biennial Exhibition of Arts (Venice Biennale) in Venice, Italy, 1964; chair of the Regional Museum Conference of Curators of the Philippines, 1974; member of the international jury in the Ninth Biennial Exhibition of Prints at the Museum of Modern Art in Tokyo, Japan, 1974; director of the liberal arts program at the SGV & Co. from 1978 to 1987; member of the exhibition committee of the Pacific-Asia Museum in Pasadena, California, for its exhibition 100 Years of Philippine Painting, 1984; member of the jury of the Fourth Kanagawa Biennial World Children’s Art Exhibition in Yokohama, Japan, 1986; and a founding member of the board of directors of the Concerned Citizens of the National Museum, 1988-89.

As art historian, he authored the books Kayamanan: 77 Paintings from the Central Bank Collection (Riches: 77 Paintings from the Central Bank Collection), 1981, and Jeepney, 1979, which examines the common man’s means of transportation as an expression of popular culture or folk art. His articles and critiques on art have appeared in Philippine Studies, Esso Silangan, and Manila Chronicle Magazine, among others. He ran a column on art, A Way of Seeing, in the Manila Times from 1965 to 1969; he wrote a column for the Sunday Times Magazine in the 1990s.

Torres’s poems are collected in three books: Angels and Fugitives, 1966; Shapes of Silence, 1972; and The Smile on Smokey Mountain and Other Poems, 1991. He also edited An Anthology of Poems 1965-74, published in 1975. He is listed in International Who’s Who in Poetry and International Who’s Who in Arts and Antiques, both in 1974; Contemporary Poets of the English Language, 1980; Contemporary Authors, 1981; and The Writer’s Directory 1980-82, 1982.

Torres received the following scholarships and grants: Fulbright travel grant and Smith-Mundt scholarship in 1955-57; international scholarship in creative writing from the State University of Iowa in 1956-57; United States State Department specialist grant in 1962; British Council travel grant in 1964 to observe art in the United Kingdom; John D. Rockefeller III grant in 1965; and fellowship in residence of the Asia Society in New York in 1965. He received the Joseph Mulry Award for literary excellence from Ateneo de Manila in 1954. He was chosen one of the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) by the Philippine Jaycees and Manila Times Publishing Co. in 1961. Two of his untitled poetry collections received second prizes in the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1964 and 1965. His two other Palanca awards were for the poetry collections Angels and Fugitives, first prize, 1966, and Having a Drink of Water from a Broken Fire Hydrant That Keeps Flowing All Night, third place, 1968. Kayamanan: 77 Paintings from the Central Bank Collection won the Gintong Aklat Award and the citation “Art Book of the Year” from the Book Development Association of the Philippines in 1982, the Anvil Award from the Public Relations Society of the Philippines in 1983, and the National Book Award for art history from the Manila Critics Circle in 1983. In 1992, he received the Gawad Pambansang Alagad ni Balagtas for poetry and art criticism from the Unyon ng mga Manunulat sa Pilipinas. Written byRosario Cruz-Lucero and Lolita R. Lacuesta, updated by Zeny May D. Recidoro

Source:

Panitikan.com.ph 2015.

TORRIJOS, SANDRA (Sandra Buñag Torrijos) b. Caloocan City 23 Jul 1960. Painter, sculptor. She is the daughter of Bernardino Torrijos Jr and Sol Buñag. She graduated with a degree in fine arts, major in visual communication, from the University of the Philippines in 1982 and was a fellowship grantee at the Vermont Studio School and Colony in the United States in 1988. She is a dual resident of the Philippines and Germany, and she travels back and forth to paint, sculpt, design, and teach art.

Spiritualism and feminism serve as the dominant themes and sources of inspiration of Torrijos’s art. Done in the expressionist style, her works are an attempt to capture the human soul. Emaciated forms, in a state of physical imprisonment and enveloped by garments, appear in both her paintings and sculpture. She has also used her paintings as a vehicle for questioning the traditional values regarding women. In her sculptures, she shows mummy-like figures in sheets and shrouds to express a person’s imprisonment by society’s rules or by personal fears. In recent works, she has introduced the theme of liberation: her figures are shown dancing, with their clothes swirling or hanging.

She has held at least 10 solo exhibitions since 1987. In 1988, she mounted Feminist Expressions at the Holiday Inn Gallery in Manila and Luna: Paintings, Drawings and Installations at the Kulay Diwa Art Galleries in Parañaque. Her succeeding works were shown in Sa Pagbangon ng mga Ina (With the Awakening of the Mothers), 1991, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), and Figures and Paradoxes (Sculpture and Drawings) at the Alliance Française in Manila. She has also taken part in 21 group exhibitions.

Torrijos was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1992. She won second prize at the Balagtas at Selya National Poster Competition, 1979, and was a finalist (painting) at the International Triennale Competition in Osaka, Japan, 1990. She also received an award from the V-Day Stop Rape Contest in New York. She co-founded WeDpro Inc, a nonprofit feminist organization that aims to support oppressed women and children, the poor, and other marginalized members of the society, designing its logos and other images. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source:

WeDpro 2015.

TUAZON, WIRE (Rommel Gagaring Tuazon)b. Angono, Rizal 28 Feb 1973. Painter, installation and performance artist. He is the son of Renato Tuazon and Narcisa Gagaring. He is married to the painter Katrina “Keiye” Miranda. Tuazon graduated in 1999 with a fine arts degree from the University of the Philippines Diliman College of Fine Arts (UP CFA) where he majored in painting. He is the founder of the now-defunct Surrounded by Water Alternative Art Space, the establishment of which marks a decisive moment in contemporary artist-run spaces. He is a core member and former president of the Neo-Angono Artists Collective, a nonprofit organization composed of visual artists, writers, musicians, filmmakers, and cultural workers who seek to engage the community of Angono in creative dialogue through research, education, production, and collaboration in art.

Believing that the legacy of National Artist for visual arts Carlos “Botong” Francisco, also a son of Angono, had been reduced by artists of his hometown to an industry of genre and landscape paintings, Tuazon deliberately pursued a more conceptual approach to painting. While retaining a strong sense of place, he also explored other non-illustrative forms such as installation and performance. In regard to his painting practice, Tuazon’s work is characteristic of his generation of painters from the UP CFA trained to brashly appropriate media-generated and found images, taking liberties in their pictorial rendering and potential juxtapositions with incongruent elements such as text and spatial context.

Tuazon held his first solo exhibition, called Angels of the Picture Tube and the Damned Collages, at The Mezzanine of Hiraya Gallery in 1996. His work has since been shown in solo and group shows, and performance art festivals, some of which he organized or directed himself under the auspices of Neo-Angono. Tuazon has held solo exhibitions annually since 1999, and is represented by Finale Art File in Makati City. He has also mounted shows abroad, including Chance Imagery in Malaysia, 2009; The Shape of Water in Singapore, 2010; and Alleged Legends in Beijing, 2010.

As an artist-curator, Tuazon’s projects include selection of Luzon-based artists for Sungduan 4: Ex-Tensions in 2007, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Thirteen Artists Awards exhibition in 2009, and the exhibition The Death of Death at SM Megamall Art Center in 2010.

Tuazon received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 2003. He received a residency grant at the Ashiya City Museum of Art and History from Japan Foundation Asia Center in 2001, and was one of the representatives of the Philippines to the 4th Prague Biennale in 2006, where works by Southeast Asian artists were presented in Central Europe for the first time. Written byJaime Oscar Salazar

Sources:

Achacoso, n.d.; Bianpoen 2009; Finale Art File 2014d.

TUPADA/TUPADA ACTION ANDMEDIA ART (TAMA) Tupada began in 2002 as a gathering of young artists interested in exploring the possibilities of performance art in public spaces, particularly with reference to sound, the body, and site specificity. Inspired by illegal cockfighting bouts that could apparently be traced back to the Spanish colonial period and which persist to our day, the first Tupada events were held every Sunday in Rizal Park, Manila. These were done without the permission of the National Parks Development Committee, the government agency that administers the site, and would go on to include guerrilla performances in other public places. These were intended to help emerging artists gain valuable experience and test their ideas before live, incidental publics.

In 2004, Tupada evolved into Tupada Action and Media Art or TAMA, an annual international performance art festival that serves as a platform for the convergence and exchange of diverse concepts and practices. It features exhibitions, fora, and workshops and has, since 2005, deliberately sought to broaden its public reach by taking the festival beyond Manila, in places such as Baguio, Batangas, Aurora, and Pangasinan. Its development into an international event has enabled exchanges with many performance artists, particularly those from or based in Southeast Asia. In contrast to how the practice of performance artists in other countries often come off as defiant of the art world mainstream, TAMA has opted for a more congenial relationship to state and commercial art world institutions. In Feb 2010, the seventh edition of TAMA was held in partnership with the National Commission for Culture and the Arts as part of the National Arts Month.

As the festival has grown, its organizers have expressed a desire to shift into a more self-reflexive and critical mode regarding their practices, and have, for example, established certain protocols to ensure the soundness of submitted proposals prior to execution at the actual event. Resorting to this mode of self-curation is presumably done in response to how provocative actions have been publicly received over the years. Such actions include fellow artists critiquing performers about the wasting of food during a performance at Densities: Making Sense of Dense Cities, 2003, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines and an offensively construed reference to the marginalized urban poor in a work done for TAMA at the Blueroom Gallery environs, Pasay City, 2006. The controversy that erupted around children being made to wrestle each other for the 2007 edition of TAMA at the CCP is also partially credited to the fact that proposals at that time were not screened. Such issues of voluntary curtailment of artistic license, the shift from guerrilla to festival mode, the farming out of traveling opportunities, among other potentially contentious issues, have also led to the changing of the membership core over the years. While participating artists have presented pieces in various locations, such as streets, parks, bus stations, and markets, TAMA has also brought performance into museums, galleries, independent art spaces, galleries, and schools, with the goal of heightening and broadening public perception about the art form and how it is produced, disseminated, engaged with, and understood. Written byJaime Oscar M. Salazar and Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources:

Berghuis 2010; de Mesa and Reamillo 2012; Tupada Action and Media Art 2010.

TY-NAVARRO, VIRGINIA b. Ermita, Manila 5 Jul 1923. d. 28 Jan 1996. Painter, sculptor. She was the daughter of Ty Engan and Tiu Sie-Engabu. She married Jerry Elizalde Navarro. Ty-Navarro graduated with a degree in fine arts, 1949, with highest honors, from the University of Santo Tomas where she taught immediately after graduation until 1960. She also taught at the College of the Holy Spirit, 1964-69. Her first one-person show was held at the Philippine Art Gallery in 1960.

Active in the art circles, she organized the Society of Philippine Sculptors of which she was president, 1969-82. In 1970, she became the director of the Hilton Art Center. Known for her “incision technique” in sculpture, she demonstrated this method in Cambodia at the University of Phnom Penh, where she received an award from Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and in India at the second Indian Triennale in 1971.

Ty-Navarro’s approach to art is multidirectional, favoring expression in different media and styles. In her work, no academic distinction exists between the fine arts and the applied arts, between sculpture and painting, or between jewelry and landscapes. In sculpture, she worked in bronze, wood, jade and mixed media. In the early 1970s, she did the Bird series in bronze. She likewise carved in jade, creating rounded, supple forms, human and animal. A series in bronze was created using an original technique in which the figure is made of tiny pellets of metal welded together. Her best-known sculpture is the bronze statue of Our Lady of Queen of Peace aka Our Lady of EDSA, 1989, located in Quezon City, to commemorate the religious aspect of the EDSA Revolt in 1986. She produced quiet, lyrical paintings of women. She received distinctions here and abroad.

In 1985, Ty-Navarro and Paul C. Zafaralla published Carlos V. Francisco: The Man and Genius of Philippine Art. Written byAlice G. Guillermo

TYSMANS, WIG (Herwig Funtanilla Tysmans) b. Manila 15 Apr 1953. Photographer. He is the son of Louis Joses Tysmans and Victoria Funtanilla. A longtime resident of Baguio City, he studied at Saint Louis University, Baguio. Tysmans may be considered a self-taught photographer. However, his career of more than four decades reveals how prolific and sought-after he has become among other formally schooled photographers in the country.

Tysmans is at ease with both black-and-white and color photographs, is familiar with a wide variety of equipment and materials, and has explored various photographic techniques. His portraits are generally straightforward, and are usually in black-and-white. While posed, they do not appear stiff and unnatural, and effort is made to capture significant aspects of the characters of the sitters.

Being an artist himself, he was among the founding members of the Baguio Arts Guild, a photographer among members who were predominantly painters. Among his body of work may be seen portrait images of his fellow Baguio artists such as National Artist BenCab, Santiago Bose, and Kidlat Tahimik. He has also photographed other artists and their works. Among them are Pacita Abad, Lee Aguinaldo, Gus Albor, and Phyllis Zaballero. At other times, he chose to collaborate with artists as they produced their own work. Tysmans has had artistic engagements with painters Bose and Aguinaldo, installation artist Ann Wizer, and performing artist Mae Paner (more popularly known as “Juana Change”). He has, of course, also appeared with fellow photographers in group photography exhibitions.

Though famous as a portrait and fashion photographer, Tysmans photographs structures, ethnographic objects, and artworks in pieces that have received critical attention. A portion of his production also consists of nudes and his experiments with infrared or IR film. More recently, he also ventured into travel photography. Tysmans’s fashion photographs are primarily accessed in the lifestyle sections of local newspapers and in fashion magazines. The publication Jamming on an Old Saya, 1995, however, functions like an art catalog to accompany an exhibition and fashion event with the same title. The fashion collection, done in collaboration with designers and installation artists, featured reworked old (but usable) cloth materials from writer and theater impresario Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s horde of clothes dating to her grandmother’s time. Of a slightly different character are the subjects featured in Tahor, 1992, a volume of portraits devoted to the country’s fighting cock breeders. Also, in Town and Country Magazine, an open publication on the web, published by Carewell Foundation and also in print, Tysmans tackled images of cancer survivors.

Works of a more documentary character are evident in Tysmans’s publication work such as the photographs of Malacañan Palace, 2005 and lime containers from the Cordilleras, 2006. The book project Sinaunang Habi, 1991, on the other hand, put together many never before seen traditional textiles from northern and southern Philippines that are now in private collections. In sections where the textiles are represented as dress, Tysmans did not work with professional models but with locals from the different ethnolinguistic groups who chose to wear their textiles in the manner they deemed appropriate. In the books Ginto, 2004, and Tanaw, 2005, Tysmans documented the gold and painting collections, respectively, of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas. He also did the exhibition catalogue for Lumina Pandit, 2011, which was made up of the rare book collection of the University of Santo Tomas. Other documentation projects include anniversary volumes for commercial institutions in the Philippines.

His photographs have been exhibited both locally and internationally, and have appeared in various publications such as broadsheets, glossy magazines, coffee-table books, and business reports. The photographs of Tysmans have been exhibited in institutional art venues such as the Ayala Museum, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, the Yuchengco Museum, the Luz Gallery, and Pinto Art Gallery. Others have also been viewed through expositions in more popular venues, such as the Power Plant Mall, Alabang Town Center, and the SM Malls, including a permanent collection of the Shell series at the St. Luke’s Hospital in Fort Bonifacio Global City. Because of his track record in various domains of both commercial and art photography, Tysmans has often been called upon to give workshops and serve as judge in numerous photography competitions. He was also designated a Canon ambassador. In Apr 2014, to celebrate his 40th year as a photographer, the BenCab Museum in Baguio City hosted Photographic Memories, a Tysmans retrospective. Written byMarilyn R. Canta

Sources: Acebu 2007; Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas 2005; Carewell Foundation 2008; Caruncho 1995; Fernando 1995; Inquirer.net 2013b; Macapagal 1992; PAGCOR 2014; Quezon, Alcazaren, and Barns 2005; Quintos 2006; Roces 1991; Tysmans 2011; Villegas 2004a.

UGATLAHI ARTIST COLLECTIVEFormerly Ugnayan at Galian ng mga Tanod ng Lahi, UGATlahi is a collective of progressive artists and activists based in the National Capital Region founded in 1992 as a cause-oriented organization of student artists from the University of Santo Tomas. In 1995, UGATLahi joined Sining Bugkos, a Manila-based alliance of cultural workers and formations and adopted its current advocacy for supporting nationalist culture and human rights. The group initiates art workshops, artists’ immersion programs in urban poor communities and workers’ organizations, organizing work among artists, exhibitions, mural projects, puppet theater performances, fora, and effigy projects. Among its members over the years were Mideo Cruz, Boyet de Mesa, and Raoul Ignacio aka Iggy Rodriguez.

UGATLahi has explored the use of popular and protest art forms to communicate the advocacies that the group supports. Its members started producing papier-mâché effigies for street demonstrations in the late 1990s, parading and burning the figures as part of these protests. Several of their larger and more elaborate effigies in the succeeding years, such as the Erapzilla, 2000, made for the welgang bayan (people’s strike) of 2000, attracted the attention of mass media and a broad public.

UGATLahi’s largest projects to date are the annual effigies for the protests during the annual State of the Nation Address delivered by the Philippine president before a joint session of Congress. These are all produced in collaboration with the political umbrella organization Bagong Alyansang Makabayan (New Patriotic Alliance). The group has produced various effigies of different presidents: Joseph Ejercito Estrada, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, and Benigno Aquino III. Symbolizing different government administrations through their heads of state, the effigies are usually burned to convey the protestor’s demands for social change. They are treated by the group as collaborative and collective works, produced in cooperation with volunteers and grassroots organizations. WrittenbyLisa Ito-Tapang

article_title: University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Design
text:
UNIVERSITY OF SANTO TOMASCOLLEGE OF FINE ARTS AND DESIGN (UST CFAD) The UST CFAD is the descendant of the Academia de Bellas Artes, which was founded by the Order of Preachers (OP) or Dominicans in 1785 under Fray Juan de Amador at UST in Intramuros. The school was established to train craftsmen in the proper techniques of painting religious imagery. It subsequently closed down due to lack of enrollees, and was replaced by the Estudio de Adorno that provided art classes for the various Dominican schools in Manila, such as UST and the Colegio de San Juan de Letran. The Estudio became the UST College of Fine Arts and Design in 1934-35 when it became evident that the modernization of Philippine industries required a corpus of trained designers and architects (Edades in The Varsitarian 1935, 5). UST Rector Fr Serapio Tamayo called for the establishment of a School of Fine Arts on 24 Feb 1934 that would help “build a more refined civilization” founded on morals and spiritual satisfaction derived from artistic works (Tamayo in The Varsitarian 1934, 1). It initially offered a bachelor’s degree in fine arts with two majors, interior design (later design) and public school art, patterned after the modern American pedagogical system, with a strong grounding in Catholic theology, humanities, and modern art. Sixteen students constituted its first batch of enrollees in 1935. Its first faculty consisted of Victorio Edades, Jose L. de Ocampo, and Severino Fabie.

In 1938, the two schools were separated from the College of Engineering and combined into the School of Architecture and Fine Arts. In 1946, it became the College of Architecture and Fine Arts (CAFA) under its first dean, Arch Jose Victor Rocha. Its first college regent was Fr Gregorio Garcia, OP. In 1950-51, the fine arts was reorganized into two departments: painting and sculpture, under chairpersons Victorio Edades and Francesco Monti, respectively. Two-year vocational courses in modeling, ceramics, painting, drawing and design, interior design and decoration, and commercial art were also offered from 1951 to 1957. The bachelor of fine arts in design was reorganized into the baccalaureate degrees for interior design, 1957, and advertising 1958, under their respective departments; while the Department of Sculpture was abolished in 1962. It was at this time that the UST CAFA was known as the home of modern art in the Philippines, with a faculty that included Edades, Galo Ocampo, Carlos V. Francisco, Vicente Manansala, Jeremias Elizalde Navarro, Cesar Legaspi, Diosdado Lorenzo, Bonifacio Cristobal, Ricarte Puruganan, Cenon Rivera, and Manuel Rodriguez Sr.

From 1960 to 1977, vocational programs in advertising, interior design, furnicraft, and commercial art continued to be offered, and were aimed at adult night school students and those who were not qualified to take the baccalaureate degree. The position of director of fine arts was abolished in 1972 under CAFA Regent Fr. Frederick Fermin, OP, and replaced with individual department chairpersons. In 1997, it was decided to separate fine arts from architecture via a two-year transition period from 1999 to 2001, with Prof Jaime de los Santos serving as associate dean for fine arts. Fine Arts officially became the College of Fine Arts and Design through a memorandum dated 13 Oct 2000 from UST secretary-general Fr Rodel Aligan, OP. The same memo also announced the appointment of Fr Isidro Abaño, OP, as the acting first dean of CFAD, as well as regent of CFAD and the College of Architecture.

The UST CFAD roster of alumni and alumni-faculty include Mario Parial, Angelito Antonio, Antonio Austria, National Artist Ang Kiukok, Virginia Ty-Navarro, Rosario Bitanga, Leon Pacunayen, Norma Belleza, Romulo Olazo, Jaime de Guzman, Danilo Dalena, Santiago Bose, Lito Mayo, Jose Tence Ruiz, Gabriel Barredo, Ronald Ventura, Alfredo Esquillo, Mideo Cruz, Andres Barrioquinto, Buen Calubayan, Iggy Rodriguez, Mark Salvatus, and Jaime Pacena. Written byReuben Ramas Cañete

Sources:

Carado 2013; Edades 1935; Tamayo 1934.

article_title: University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts
text:
UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES COLLEGE OF FINE ARTS(UP CFA) The oldest arts and design educational institution in the country, the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts first opened in Jun 1909 as the School of Fine Arts (SFA) on Calle San Sebastian (now Hidalgo St) in Quiapo, Manila. Together with the College of Medicine and the College of Agriculture, it is one of the earliest units in UP.

Most of the first nine instructors of the SFA, including Director Rafael Enriquez and his successor Fabian de la Rosa, had been students, faculty, or scholars of the Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado whose teaching system was based on the Academia de San Fernando in Madrid. Active from 1845 to 1898, the Escuela was reestablished as the Academia de Dibujo, one of the first official art academies in the Philippines, in 1823-34.

The SFA initially offered five-year nondegree certificate programs in painting, sculpture, and engraving. Students, including elementary students “who show marked proficiency in drawing,” were admitted through competitive examination (UP 1912a). Effective school year 1918-19, no new student was admitted who had not finished studies equal to those taught in the intermediate grades of the public schools. No tuition was charged until 1923-24. In 1926-27, the curriculum in painting, sculpture, and engraving was reduced to four years while illustration, cartooning, and commercial design programs were shortened to three years. Four-year degree courses leading to a bachelor of fine arts (BFA) in painting and a BFA in sculpture were offered by 1947-48.

Among the first batch of six graduates in 1914 was Fernando C. Amorsolo who later assumed directorship of the school in 1938. He was succeeded as director by Guillermo E. Tolentino in 1952 and Dominador Castañeda in 1955. The UP Fine Arts faculty during its first half-century was associated with the classical tradition in art. This led to an impassioned debate over the nature of art between Tolentino and the modernist Victorio C. Edades, then director of the University of Santo Tomas School of Architecture and Fine Arts, in a series of periodical articles in 1948.

In the 1950s and 1960s, younger faculty members such as Constancio Bernardo, Napoleon V. Abueva, Jose T. Joya, and Rod Paras-Perez received scholarships to the United States. Several revisions in the curriculum coincided with their return, reflecting the shift to modernist ideas. In 1955, the BFA in art education and BFA in commercial design were instituted. Since its inception, the commercial design program, since renamed visual communication, has consistently attracted the most number of enrollees within the college.

The SFA became the School of Fine Arts and Architecture in 1959 when the architecture program, which was initially offered by the UP College of Engineering in 1956, was transferred to it. The school was elevated to a college in 1961. The College of Fine Arts and the College of Architecture became separate academic units in 1970.

The college offers bachelor’s degree programs in art education, art history, industrial design, painting, sculpture, and visual communication. It also offers certificate programs as well as a master of fine arts. As of 2014, it has produced 10 of the 16 National Artists for visual arts—namely, Napoleon Abueva, Fernando Amorsolo, Benedicto Cabrera, Carlos “Botong” Francisco, Abdulmari Imao, Jose Joya, Cesar Legaspi, Vicente Manansala, Hernando Ruiz Ocampo, and Guillermo Tolentino. Written byRoberto Eliseo G. Paulino

Sources: Castañeda 1964; Hidalgo 1915; Jamias 1962; Metropolitan Museum of Manila 2008; Panao 2009; Pilar 1992a, 2002, 2003, 2007; Santiago 1989; 1992, 2007a; Tan 1956; Taylo 1985; UP 1912a, 1912b, 1921a, 1921b, 1925, 1926a, 1926b, 1929; UP Diliman 2014; Virata 1957.

article_title: University of the Philippines Department of Art Studies
text:
UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES DEPARTMENT OF ART STUDIES(UP DAS) The Department of Art Studies, is one of the five departments of the College of Arts and Letters of the University of the Philippines Diliman. It offers bachelor of arts programs following three tracks (art history, interdisciplinary studies, and Philippine art) and three master of arts programs (art history, art theory and criticism, and curatorial studies). It is, to date, the only academic department of its kind in the Philippines.

DAS, originally called the Department of Humanities and Philippine Institutions, was formed in 1959 when the English Department of UP Diliman split into three smaller units: the Department of English and Comparative Literature, the Department of Speech Communication and Theater Arts, and the Department of Humanities and Philippine Institutions. At that time, the department’s initial task was to teach art appreciation in the style of the University of Chicago as part of the general education curriculum of UP.

In the decades after 1959, the department shifted its approach from one which was heavily formalist and geared toward the appreciation of fine art, to one which acknowledged the value of popular and marginalized art forms and which was more suited to the study of Philippine art as implicated in its diverse social and historical contexts. In 1989, the Department of Humanities became the Department of Art Studies to reflect the newer paradigms and approaches advocated by its faculty, which included contextual as opposed to object-centric and formalist analysis, as well as a deliberately critical approach to elite, Euroamerican art discourse.

DAS has been committed to the foregrounding of the study of Philippine art from an inter-/multidisciplinary approach. Its faculty and students have produced significant scholarly works that have contributed to the better understanding and valuation of various art practices and traditions in the country, as well as to the formation and development of new theories and critical methods in the study of art. Its publications include Paths of Practice: New Directions in Art Studies and the Humanities, 2010, and Suri Sining: The Art Studies Anthology, 2011. These represent the range and diversity of knowledge and theoretical paradigms embodied by its faculty.

DAS has also been active in the development of pedagogical tools, methods, and instructional materials through its publications, fora, conferences, and workshops for teachers, art scholars, museum workers, curators, cultural workers, writers, and artists. Its projects include the Visual Literacy Workshops held in the summers of 2012 and 2013.

Apart from the department’s contributions to art scholarship and criticism, its faculty, several of whom are occasionally seconded to hold key positions in government institutions, are curators, artists and/or cultural workers. They have been at the forefront of many projects in collaboration with various institutions, local communities, individual artists, and artist groups. These endeavors highlight the department’s assertion that the study and practice of art are not divorced from social, political, and ecological issues concerning the nation. Written byPatricia Marion Lopez

Sources:

Lava 2011; Mirano and Lopez 2011; UP Department of Art Studies 2013.

VALDEZCO, MARIA CRISTINA (Maria Cristina Morot Valdezco) aka Mac Valdezco. b. 9 Jun 1976. She is the daughter of Asuncion Barbo Morot and Paterno Severino Valdezco. She earned her bachelor of fine arts degree, major in advertising, in 1997 from the Technological University of the Philippines.

Valdezco first gained attention from critics and curators when she began using cloth discards as molding element for her organically shaped sculptural forms. She continues to work in this vein but has included other materials, such as plastic, paper, twine, tape, and other industrial debris, among her range of materials. Valdezco’s body of work occasionally shifts between two- and three-dimensional, minimalist and more chromatic color palettes but what has remained constant is her playful approach to physical substance and their projectile potential into the spaces where her work is encountered bodily.

Artist-curator Imelda Cajipe-Endaya selected her as one of the participating artists in the national traveling exhibition Sungdu-an: Making the Local, first shown at the Pasig City Museum in 2003. Among Valdezco’s solo exhibitions are Metaforms, 2002, Avellana Art Gallery; 100% Cotton, 2005, Avellana Art Gallery; Soft-Shell, 2006, Avellana Art Gallery; Small Complete Units, 2007, University of the Philippines (UP) Vargas Museum; The Invisible Pilot, 2009, Avellana Art Gallery; Cut-out Atma, 2009, Slab 20 Square; Boneless, 2009, Avellana Art Gallery; In Focus: Mac Valdezco, 2010, Picasso Residences; I vs I, 2010, Avellana Art Gallery; Twin Cyclops, 2011, Capitana Gallery Talisay City; Sci-fi, 2012, Avellana Art Gallery; and Specimen, 2014, Finale Art File.

Among her group exhibitions are The Filipino Can: Ang Delatang Pinoy (The Filipino Can: The Canned Filipino), 1996, Hiraya Gallery; Pangunahing Udyok: Ikaapat na Yugto (First Impulse: Fourth Segment), 2001, Baguio Botanical Garden Gallery; Pangunahing Udyok III (First Impulse 3), Surrounded by Water Gallery, 2001; WAHANA, 2005, UP Vargas Museum; Global/Vernacular, 2007, Ateneo Art Gallery, 2007; Room 307-Inkling Gutfeel and Hunch, 2008, National Art Gallery, National Museum of the Philippines; Art Beijing, 2008, National Agricultural Exhibition Center (New Hall) Beijing, China; and Futuramanila, 2008, Osage Hong Kong; Everything Is Temporary, 2009, Blanc Compound; Futuramanila, 2009, Osage Gallery Singapore; Shoebox Dioramas 2, 2009, West Gallery; Collage Drop Outs, 2011, Finale Art File; Incidental Pleasures, 2012, Mo Space; Still, 2013, Blanc Gallery; Surface Area, 2013, Finale Art File; Bound, 2013, West Gallery; and Dwellers, 2013, Mo Space.

Valdezco received the grand prize in the sculpture category of the 56th Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition in 2003, and the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2006. Written byEileen Legaspi-Ramirez

VALERA, RAMON (Ramon Oswald Valera) b. Abra 31 Aug 1912. d. Manila 25 May 1972. Fashion designer. National Artist for fashion design. He was the son of Melecio Valera and Pilar Oswald. He finished his primary and secondary education in De La Salle, but dropped out of his first year of college at Far Eastern University.

He began his design career in 1935. Valera was best known for the innovations made to the baro’t saya (traditional blouse and skirt), which he combined into a single gown, now referred to as the terno. He also did away with thetapis (overskirt),andpañuelo (a stiff scarf that covered the shoulders and nape). Instead of hooks, he introduced the used of the zipper at the back, creating an A-line in the silhouette popularized in Western fashion design. Valera initially scandalized his conservative clientele with these innovations. But the controversy died down quickly enough because the elite continued to wear his terno featuring embroidery, bead work, and butterfly sleeves. Soon, the Valera terno became the iconic style on the national level.

His clientele included First LadiesAurora QuezonandImelda Romualdez-Marcos. Marcos was largely responsible for making Valera’s work internationally known. It was Valera who created Romualdez-Marcos’s wedding gown and many of the ternos worn by her for diplomatic functions. He also costumed actressGloria Romero, who played Marcos’s First Lady in the film Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), 1969. In 1960, Valera showed alongside Japanese couturier George Oka at a benefit show for the Fourth Cancer Educational Fund Drive. While Oka brought professional models from Japan to wear his work down the runway, Valera dressed a bevy of society ladies and actresses, including Marcos and Romero, Barbara Perez, Susan Roces, and Imelda Cojuangco, because there were no professional models at the time.

In 1994, the Cultural Center of the Philippines mounted the exhibit Ramon Valera and the Terno curated by Salvador Bernal at the Bulwagang Juan Luna.

His works are chronicled in the book Valera: Cada Traje es una Obra Maestra (Every Dress Is a Masterpiece), 2005, published by the Tantoco-Rustia Foundation and the National Museum of the Philippines. Freeway, a local ready-to-wear brand, paid tribute to Valera by incorporating his signature and beadwork patterns as prints and embellishments in their Holiday 2010 collection. Valera became the Philippines’ first National Artist for fashion design in 2006. Written byAlice A. Sarmiento

Sources:

Dizon 2003: Dolor 2014; Enriquez 2011; Impak ng Sikat 2012.

VELASQUEZ, TONY (Antonio Santos Velasquez) b. Paco, Manila 29 Oct 1910. d. 22 Apr 1997. Cartoonist. He was the son of Eusebio Velazquez and Andrea Santos. He was married to Pilar Tongco with whom he had two children. In 1926, while a boy of 16 in high school, he worked as photoengraver at the Banaag Press in Santa Cruz, Manila, which was later bought by Ramon Roces of Liwayway. Velasquez took courses in cartooning and advertising at the Federal School of Arts of America. In 1935, Velasquez was promoted to chief advertising artist for the six sister magazines: Liwayway, Graphic, Bannawag, Bisaya, Hiligaynon, and Bikolnon. In 1962, he also took up modern management at the Management Development Center in Manila.

On 11 Jan 1929, the first issue of his comic creation Kenkoy appeared in Liwayway, followed later by Ponyang Halobaybay. Except for the Graphic, Kenkoy appeared in all the magazines, either in Tagalog or translated into the regional languages. A major hit, Kenkoy inspired a song from Nicanor Abelardo and a poem from Jose Corazon de Jesus. Kenkoy soon grew into an extended family which included his parents Mang Teroy and Aling Matsay, his sweetheart Rosing, his rival Tirso, and the dimwit Talakitok. The comic strip survived the Japanese occupation and continued after the war, appearing twice weekly in Pilipino Komiks, at one point heralded as Di Retarn op Kenkoy, 1991-93.

After World War II, Velasquez became a freelance contributor to Liwayway, having put up his own advertising agency with his brother Damian, also a cartoonist. In 1946, he along with a number of pioneering cartoonists contributed to Halakhak. In 1947, he organized Ace Publications, which came out with its first comic magazine, Pilipino Komiks, for Ramon Roces, and later with Tagalog Klasiks, Hiwaga Komiks, and Espesyal Komiks.

Velasquez received the Best Komiks of the Year award from Graphic Arts Service Inc, 1963; a special award from the Citizens Council for Mass Media, 1971; the Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan sa Larangan ng Makasining na Komiks from the city of Manila, 1974; a special award from the Department of Public Information, 1975; and a Life Achievement Award from Komiks Operation Brotherhood, 1998. From the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), he received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining in 1993. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

de Vera 2011; Komiklopedia 2007a; Philippine Trivia 2013.

VENERACION, ROY (Rolando Santos Veneracion) b. Manila 31 Jul 1947. Painter. He is the son of Geronimo Veneracion, Doctor of Laws, and Aida Santos. His son Ian is a film and television actor and a painter. Intent on pursuing an artistic career, he enrolled at the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1970. Although he was in advertising from 1970 to 1973, he concentrated on painting.

He has worked in a number of series in different styles, media, and content. Around 1976, he worked in the abstract expressionist style, because of the influence of Jose Joya and other abstractionists. In 1981, he experimented with pastel works using sandpaper to create original textural effects. He also developed a “soaked” technique in which the paper is steeped in a sink of water with various elements, producing random strains and textures. From the outset, Veneracion placed importance on the role of the subconscious in art. He created compositions based on the free play of chance and accident, as in the throw of dice or joss sticks in Chinese fortune-telling which would finally fall into the pattern of I Ching hexagrams. He never relinquished figuration which sparked a connection between his art and events of the real world. Around 1983, he did a series of large-scale paintings in which the transition from Marcos to Aquino was interpreted in a dreamlike manner. Its surreal allegory featured dramatis personae such as military figures, as monsterlike robots in full armor, the Filipino people as the archetypal Malakas (Strong) and Maganda (Beautiful), and a beautiful nude gazing into a mirror below the crossed flags of the Philippines and the United States, suggesting the perpetual questioning of identity.

Around 1984-85, Veneracion summoned his drawing skills to draw nudes that combined spontaneity with a classical air. From these, he indulged his fascination with movement in sketches and watercolors of dancers, exploring the infinite agility of the human figure. At the same time, his passion for experimentation led him to use sinamay cloth pressed on randomly stained paper to obtain traces of the organic fiber in fine striations and patterns. Using the treated paper as background, he collaged simple decorative cutouts of folk designs, usually derived from Maranao okir. The 1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo inspired a series of paintings that went from textural interest to metaphysical reflection. Veneracion’s fascination with the concept of time, which he distinguished into “linear time and cyclical time,” resulted in semiabstract works combining texture and gestural painting, with figures of humans and beasts emerging like allegorical symbols in a metaphysical cosmic space.

He has had one-person shows and joined group exhibitions such as the Mini-Mini, Gallery Bleau; Fil-Art Exhibit, Ontario, Canada; Insights into Philippine Art, New York; Contemporary Philippine Art, Washington, DC; Seven Filipino Artists, San Francisco; and the ASEAN Travelling Exhibition in Southeast Asian countries and the People’s Republic of China. He also joined annual shows of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and Site Works in Los Baños, Laguna. His one-man shows include Unconscious, 1994, Galleria Duemila; Superimpose, 2000, West Gallery; Chakras: The Region of Power, 2004, West Gallery; Syncretism: Roy Veneracion, 2008, Union Center for the Arts, Los Angeles; Syncretism: Roy Veneracion, 2009, Jack Miller & Associates Gallery, Los Angeles; and The Essentiality of Polystyle Syncretism to a Multiple Personality Artist in the 21st Century, 2011, Nova Gallery.

Veneracion was a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1990. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Source:

Veneracion, n.d.

VENTURA, RONALDO (Ronaldo Cruz Ventura) aka Ronald Ventura. b. Manila 12 Jun 1973. Intermedia artist. His parents are Ruben Ventura and Rosalina Cruz. He received his bachelor of fine arts in painting at the University of Santo Tomas (UST) in 1993. Ventura was instructor of fine arts in UST from 1993 to 2001.

Employing various themes and techniques, Ventura’s works offer complex visual dialogues. His works meld imageries culled from Philippine folk traditions; iconic works from the West; religion; popular culture genres such as comics, advertisements, cartoons, and toys; as well as elements from subcultures like graffiti and tattooing. In the early part of his artistic career, the art historian Patrick Flores noted that Ventura’s paintings were done with “breathtaking naturalism” (Flores 2008). Many of Ventura’s large-scale compositions are filled up with hyperreal figures achieved through methodical techniques of drawing and painting. The compositions would sometimes incorporate found objects, digitally manipulated printouts, as well as stenciled figures. On the other hand, his initial forays into sculpture involved the use of fiberglass and resin glossed up with acrylic polyurethane paint, producing a sleek, industrial effect. In his later works, as in the exhibition Watching the Watchmen, 2012, held at the University of the Philippines Vargas Museum, Ventura’s industrial sculptures became more elaborate and unsettling. Translating the bulol (images of granary gods or anito, ancestor, and nature deities) to create contemporary imagery, the artist pronounces the musculature, making these figures look like anatomical models. Ventura also applied intricate drawings on the whitewashed bodies of the morphed bulol, and rendered some of the figures in appropriated poses from pop culture and religious icons—for example, Saint Michael trampling on a demon. His oil on canvas work Appetite, 2008, for his solo exhibit Mapping the Corporeal, 2008, at the National University of Singapore Museum features the coalesced image of two lavishly dressed men, their face obscured by an enlarged mouth, exposing its anatomy. Ventura’s works for this exhibition also features his Zoomanities series, fiberglass resin sculptures of part-human, part-animal forms. His images are reflections on postmodern conditions. Embracing the fluid exchange among belief systems, his works imagine fusions and transformations when barriers are broken down. His juxtapositions are ruminations on human desires and anxieties about the predominance of machines and high technology, urban blight, commodification, and mediatization of culture.

The artist has exhibited extensively in museums and galleries in the Philippines and abroad. His solo exhibitions include All Souls Day, 2000, Drawing Room Gallery; Cross Encounters, 2006, Ateneo Art Gallery; Major Highways, Expressways, and Principal Arterials, 2009, Akili Museum of Art, Jakarta, Indonesia; Humanime (I), 2011, Fine Arts Centre, Taipei, Taiwan; Recyclables, 2012, Singapore Tyler Print Institute; and Bulul: Ronald Ventura and the Traditional Art of the Philippines, 2014, Museo delle Culture, Lugano, Switzerland. Ventura’s work also appeared in international group exhibitions such as the Prague Biennale, 2010, Prague, Czech Republic; Nanjing Biennale, 2011, Nanjing, China; and Surreal versus Surrealism in Contemporary Art, 2011, Institut Valencia d’Art Modern, Valencia, Spain. In 2011, the book Realities was published by Grafiche Damiani, featuring selected works by Ventura and with essays by Alice Guillermo, Ramon E.S.
