Lerma, Igan D’Bayan, Adjani Arumpac, and Italian critic Daniela Palazzoli.

Ventura received the Ateneo Art Award in 2005, granting him a studio residency at Cross Art Projects in Sydney, Australia. In 2003, he received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award. He was conferred the award of excellence in the 9th Oita Asian Sculpture Exhibition Open Competition in 2008. Written byLouise Anne D. Marcelino

Sources:

Flores 2008c; Ventura 2011, n.d.

VERANO, FRANCISCO (Francisco Maravilla Verano) b. Negros Occidental 7 Aug 1938. Sculptor, painter. His parents are Edgar Victorio Verano and Alicia Maravilla. He married Elvira Santos. A graduate of the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts, he was a student of Napoleon Abueva. Like his mentor, Verano’s experience in materials is wide ranging, having worked in wood, stone, and metal (particularly bronze), with a definite penchant for experimentation. He was one of the first to use old wood from crumbling century-old houses to make statements on the human condition. His bamboo sculptures bring out the full expressive potential of the material. His Bamboo Fugue series, 1972, was inspired by the use of bamboo as musical instrument, the variedly shaped apertures individualizing each piece within the ensemble. While visual and tactile in appeal, they also make auditory allusions to bamboo pipes, such as the native flutes and panpipes. In 1972, he began experiments in acriweld, consisting of sawdust combined with strong glue. From this medium he created sculptures of stylized human figures eminently supple in form, doing light and airy gestures and dance movements as well as of genre themes, such as rice planting and various rural occupations.

Verano is also a painter of landscapes and still life. In his landscapes he enhances his painting surfaces with sand and modeling paste, thus creating a direct textural appeal. He has also consistently worked in watercolor in the wet technique, bringing out the freshness spontaneously and the atmospheric effects of the medium in misty landscapes and floral bouquets.

Verano won awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: first prize, Stone Idol, 1951; third prize, Composition No. 15, 1961; second honorable mention, Composition No. 16, 1962; honorable mention, Human Bondage, 1963; and best landscape, Tondo Tide Lands, 1977. He was also awarded third prize for Sea Dwellings, 1961, at the Shell National Students Art Competition. Written byAlice G. Guillermo

VICENTE, MAXIMO SR b. San Bartolome, Malabon 29 May 1883. d. 13 Sep 1964. Sculptor, painter. He was the only son of Antonina Vicente, a fish vendor, and of a certain Spaniard named Guardamonte who died a month before Maximo’s birth. His mother later married Pablo Santiago, a fisher from Navotas. They had five sons, Rafael (master carpenter), Felix (sculptor, painter, and altar designer), Dionisio (sculptor), Luciano (painter), and Roberto (sculptor), who all contributed to the success of the Talleres de Maximo Vicente from its founding in 1908. His formal education consisted of a month’s stint at the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts on Calle R. Hidalgo when it opened in 1909.

Vicente Sr learned the art of the santero or religious image maker from his maternal uncles Osmundo and Narciso Vicente who had ateliers in Quiapo and Santa Ana. In his childhood days, Vicente Sr was surrounded with lush trees in their huge backyard, and it inspired him to try to create something out of wood. He made a crucifix that impressed a parish priest who eventually bought the item and promised to order more. This inspired him to found the Talleres, a pioneering shop and the largest during its heyday in the late 1920s when it occupied the streets of R. Hidalgo and del Paso, Quiapo. Its services included carroza (float) making, plating, embroidery of costumes, encarnacion (rendering of flesh tones), gold leafing, wood carving, wig making, eyelash and glass-eye making, and designing and constructing altars, confessional boxes, holy water fonts, and even boats. Majority of its workers hailed from Malabon, Navotas, and Pampanga and were relatives of his wife Crispina Laxamana. His artists included Juan Flores, Rufino Rivera, Alfredo Contreras, Conrado Rubio, Rufino de Jesus, Jorge Santiago, and Ner Maglaqui. Vicente Sr believed in using only the finest materials in his shop. Sculptures were usually made of batikuling wood, ideal for its fine-grained structure and durability. The unparalleled craftsmanship of the religious images produced in the Talleres made Vicente Sr and his artisans popular, their works reputedly rivaled those produced by the best artisans in Europe. Vicente Sr was dubbed the “Master Sculptor of Religious Imagery.” The clients of his Talleres ranged from church establishments to government officials. Before World War II, they did the silverwork for the carozza of the image of La Naval. When he died, the Talleres came under the supervision of Mrs Soledad Hernandez-Vicente, wife of his architect-son Maximo. Later on, the shop was moved to M. Adriatico St in Ermita, where they now restore old statues made of plaster, marble, ivory, or porcelain.

Some of his works include Santo Niño de Praga (Holy Infant of Prague), ca 1915, San Beda Chapel; Birheng Milagrosa (Miraculous Virgin), ca 1920, San Marcelino Church, Manila; and Saint Gerard, ca 1920, Redemptorist Church, Baclaran.

In Jul-Aug 2015, a few of Vicente Sr’s original works were shown at Lilok (Sculpture), an exhibit dedicated to religious art held in San Beda College Alabang Museum in Muntinlupa. WrittenRita S. Borja and Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources: Godoy 2015; Jacinto-Lopez 2001; Manila Standard 2015.

VICTOR, PHILLIP (Phillip Cadid Victor) b. Hagonoy, Bulacan 1 May 1944. d. 19 Jul 2006. Painter. He was the son of Jose Victor and Dominga Cadid. As a grader in the Sagrada Familia Elementary School in Hagonoy, Bulacan, he was known as a child crazy about drawing. In high school, he continued to draw from his own imagination. After graduation, when he expressed the wish to pursue an art career, his father objected, thinking that it was neither a practical nor a profitable course. In order to realize his ambition, Phillip became a working student at the University of Santo Tomas, where he took both advertising and painting. It was only later, upon recognizing the seriousness of his purpose, that his father supported his studies.

Even as a young artist, Victor had a highly experimental kind of creativity. To develop his originality, he preferred to work from his own imagination, shunning models and references, even books, and not going out much. He followed a strict and solitary program, most of the time just working with pencil and paper. His creativity never failed him; in one sitting, he could produce a series of 5-10 drawings on oslo paper.

Constrained by family needs, he worked for a while as production manager at Philprom. But in 1972, he cut his links with advertising to become a full-time artist. It was then that he developed his highly original medium in mixed media of what he called “permanent embossed paintings” with a three-dimensional effect. This became his well-known Parik-Parik, Palikpik, Pikpik (Parik-Parik, Fins, Pikpik) series. These consisted of white minimalist works with sculptural features and color accents like rainbows or prismatic reflections. The artist pointed out that their whiteness was not that of snow but of the fishponds of his hometown. In these highly original works of a total concept, he first worked with a solid wood base which he sculpted with wood-carving tools to bring out hollows and mounds, and other convex and concave features, according to his conceived design of a particular painting. This done, he took the solid piece of canvas and glued it onto the wood base in a flawless technique, leaving no folds or wrinkles but creating a fluid undulating surface that becomes the landscape. He first exhibited this series at the Luz Gallery in 1979.

In his subsequent shows at the Luz Gallery where he had held five one-person shows (the last in 1991)—as well as his other shows at the Rear Room, 1981; Galerie Bleue, 1985; and Lopez Museum, 1988—Victor became increasingly experimental, turning to installations. In one work he attached a branch of driftwood like a lively calligraphic line on the frame of his canvas. He also incorporated mobiles, as well as streamers of white transparent plastic to suggest raindrops on his white landscape.

Victor won several times in various art competitions, with seven of them coming from the Art Association of the Philippines, including best entry for Alon Panik Panik at Palikpik (Wave, To Go Up and Fins), 1982, and a prize for abstract painting in 1983. He participated in about 200 group exhibitions, 12 of them held abroad, and a total of 14 solo shows, one of which was held in New York in Oct 2003. He was also an important member of two local art groups: the Hagonoy Art Group and the Lakan Sining ng Bulacan, where he served as president. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source:

Artepinas 2008.

VICTORIA, PABLO (Pablo Jacinto Victoria)b. 24 Jan 1915. d. 24 Feb 1986. Painter. He was the son of Simplicio Victoria and Justa Jacinto of Hagonoy, Bulacan. Victoria made his contribution as one of the first art educators in the country. He graduated in 1940 with a diploma in painting with highest honors from the University of the Philippines School of Fine Arts. In 1949, he finished bachelor of science in education from the Quezon College and became an art instructor at the Philippine Normal College (PNC). In 1952, he earned a master’s degree, major in art education, from the PNC and in 1953 was awarded a Fulbright study grant to Columbia University where he obtained a master’s degree in fine and industrial arts. In 1956, he was elected secretary of the Art Association of the Philippines.

He painted landscapes, genre, and portraits. He also made cards for all occasions, coffins that he decorated with carvings of saints and angels, and movie billboards. He worked in the impressionist style, stressing linear rhythms, using violet for shadows.

He represented the Philippines in the International Society for Education through Art conference at The Hague, Netherlands, in 1957. In 1960, he published his first book, Art in the Elementary School, followed by Art Activities in the Elementary School in 1966. After teaching for 12 years at the PNC, he transferred to the University of the East (UE) as full professor and director of the School of Fine Arts, which he developed extensively, becoming the model for the present UE College of Fine Arts. In 1975, he held his first one-person show at the Gallery One in Greenhills; he had a total of seven individual shows. Art historian and critic Paul Blanco Zafaralla wrote his biography titled Victoria: Scholar, Art Educator, Artist, Humanist, published in 1986. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Open Library 2015; UE 2015.

VILLA, CARLOS (Carlos Gorospe Villa) b. 11 Dec 1936. d. 23 Mar 2013. Painter, sculptor, and installation, fiber, and performance artist. He was the son of Pedro Corpuz Villa and Prisca Gorospe. Villa earned his undergraduate degree in education at the San Francisco Art Institute, 1961, and his master of fine arts at Mills College, Oakland, California, 1963. His earliest influence and tutor in art was a cousin, Leo Gorospe Valledor.

Villa began his professional practice primarily driven by a minimalist abstract aesthetic before developing a deep interest in exploring how traditional cultures manifest resistance to the influences of colonialism. Villa initially painted in an abstract expressionist vein, eventually shifting to a more multidimensional and transmedia practice. His visual language would expand by way of infusions of materials like blood, bones, feathers, saliva, semen, teeth, hair, glass shards, bronze plates, and the artist’s own scratched inscriptions tracking the human in the everyday. Villa would frequently apply these trace materials and physical marking on unstretched support which would sometimes get turned into cloaks or coats, along with other ritual garment accoutrements to construct a language of becoming rather than one that aspired to a static authenticity. Villa’s use of various membranes that alluded to skin and a put-on or built-up sense of self had constructivist equivalents. His installations would often be made up of cabinets, coffins, and doors—boxes and containers which were read as having identitarian and navigational innuendos. These enclosures were also intended to be read as spaces pregnant with possibility and the unexpected because they were objects that could be opened up to reveal what was inside. Not being inclined to the overtly political, Villa also painted straitlaced grids which were destabilized organically by such phenomenon as warping brought on by heat or cold. It was through such process-based aspects of his work that Villa played up imprecisions, as surfaces produced in standardized dimensions would give way to corrosive elements.

Villa’s early minimalist phase was spent in New York where he began exhibiting professionally in 1958. He had his first solo exhibition at the Poindexter Gallery, New York, in 1967. His return to California engendered a noticeable shift in his work as he encountered Chicano and specifically El Movimiento members Rene Yañez, Rupert Garcia, and Amalia Mesa-Baines, artists and thinkers who took their creative practice into the barrios. On top of these engagements, Villa was also doing an art residency at Telegraph Hill Center amidst students from African-American and Asian families. Taken together, these circumstances exposed him to ideas such as “the recuperation of heritage” and rasquache or the making of new culture from the “shards of old culture.” These would inform his practice progressively particularly in shifting to a mode of community action he would locate within the stream of performance art via Joseph Beuys’s notion of social sculpture. In Villa’s case, action translated to organizing within the circles he moved in, and this included putting together overtly art historical projects such as the canon-challenging “Rehistoricizing the Time around Abstract Expressionism: Late 1950s to Late 1960s,” done in 2005-7 with another iteration in 2010, as well as the four-part seminal 1988-92 symposium series and publication Worlds in Collision: Dialogues on Multicultural Art Issues, 1995. These ventures, which Villa called art actions, were preceded by undertakings such as “Multicultural Symposium: Agenda for the 1990s” at the San Francisco Art Institute (SFAI), 1989. Pursued alongside his pedagogical practice at SFAI among other institutions he taught in, Villa became keen on excavating community social histories and overlooked or unarticulated art histories of artists of color, of women, and groups not legible in mainstream narratives.

Even while cultivating a multifaceted practice that went beyond object-making, Villa did still keep visible within the parameters of the art world. His exhibitions would often consist of conceptual allusions to the backdoor or impeded entry of migrants, specifically the Filipino manong generation and their desire to be regarded as gentlemen all spruced up in suits and bowler hats as they came off the fields doing menial labor. One illustrative example of his process-based constructions possibly alluding to such aspirational mobilities is the 1999-2004 Campo Santos consisting of makeshift ladders hanging from tree branches in a non-gallery/museum location.

Villa’s other solo exhibitions include those at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery, 1973; the American Academy, Rome, 1988; and a major retrospective at the Hearst Art Gallery, 2007. Villa showed with Santiago Bose in Colonialism, Immigration and Manongs, 2000, Pacific Bridge Gallery, and in Memories of Overdevelopment: Philippine Diaspora in Contemporary Visual Art, 1996, University of California at Irvine Fine Arts Gallery. Other group shows were at Spatsa Gallery, 1958; the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, 1960, 1976-77, and 1982; the Houston Museum of Contemporary Art, 1963; Noah Goldowsky Gallery, 1964 and 1967; Park Place Gallery, 1965, 1966, and 1968; the Oakland Museum, 1971 and 1996; Whitney Museum of American Art and the De Young Museum, 1972; Krannert Art Gallery, 1974; Hayward Art Gallery, 1987; the Havana Biennial, 1989; INTAR Gallery, 1990; the Museo de Bellas Artes, Chile, 1991; Bomani Gallery and Galeria Likovnih Umetnosti Slovenj Gradec, 1997; and the Triton Museum, 1999 and 2006. Villa’s pieces are in the collections of the Smithsonian Institution, the Whitney Museum of American Art, and the Crocker Art Gallery, among others. His performances include Manila Gorilla from Manila, 1989, Jennifer Pauls Gallery, and Doin’ the Do, 1990, California Wig Shop, again in reference to the off-duty dressing up of the manong.

Apart from his toggling between teaching and making art and engaging in what historian Mark Dean Johnson calls “archive activism,” Villa was also one of an early generation of artist-curators. He co-curated International Hotel, 1994, at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, and Other Sources: An American Essay, 1975, at the San Francisco Art Institute. Other Sources particularly enabled Villa’s long-term goal of pitting academe vis-à-vis street scholars on Third World art, this time on the occasion of the American bicentennial of independence. Villa also co-curated Sister City Sisters: San Francisco Babaylan, 1998, one of the few but seminal stagings of diasporic Filipino-American work, first mounted at the San Francisco State University Gallery then at the Museo ng Maynila. Villa also collaborated with the art collective Mail Order Brides / M.O.B. in Chatsilog, 2010, a video installation project that physically brought together the four “talking heads” who at the time were living out of four distinct locations but virtually caught on TV monitors at Green Papaya Art Projects. Through his senior years and over a period of four decades, Villa taught at the painting and interdisciplinary departments of the San Francisco Art Institute, which was later renamed the California School of Fine Arts. It was in this teaching context that he influenced artists such as Jenifer Wofford, Jessica Hagedorn, and Manuel Ocampo. Villa received a Guggenheim Fellowship for Creative Arts, 2012, and was also awarded grants by the National Endowment for the Arts, the Rockefeller Foundation, and the Pollock-Krasner Foundation. Written byEileen Legaspi-Ramirez

Sources:

Archives of American Art 2015; Gonzalves 2011; Villa 2015.

VILLANUEVA, ESTEBAN (Esteban Pichay Villanueva) b. Vigan, Ilocos Sur 1 Sep 1797. d. 23 Jan 1878. Painter. He was the son of Placido Villanueva and Tulia Pichay. He was a successful entrepreneur who was known for the set of 14 paintings depicting the Ambaristo rebellion known today as the Basi Revolt. The Basi Revolt paintings are presently kept at the Burgos Museum of the Filipinas Foundation Inc, Vigan, Ilocos Sur. They were painted in 1821, commissioned by the Spanish government to remind the locals about the bloody consequences of the revolt and discourage future rebellion.

To raise revenues, the Spanish colonial government established in 1785 a monopoly of basi or sugarcane wine. The imposition was resented, for the Filipinos were accustomed to a hearty enjoyment of their homemade wines. On 16 Sep 1807, the people of Piddig, Ilocos Norte, took up arms. This revolt quickly ignited the neighboring towns. The basi warriors were later crushed, their forces scattered and their leaders hanged. What began in true fervor ended in crushing defeat that no small quaff of the basi could quench.

The Basi Revolt paintings chronicled the event from the Spanish point of view. In sequence, the paintings show the following scenes: alcalde mayor (mayor) Juan Ybañez and local troops at vigil; Ybañez calling the chiefs of Bantay, San Vicente, and Santa Catalina; the chiefs of Candon and Santiago being reprimanded for tardiness; rebels of Ilocos Norte marching to Ilocos Sur; troops being sent to confront the rebels; an arrested rebel dying of lashing; Vigan troops being sent to repel enemies; natives fleeing to Bantay Church; bloody battle being waged at Bantaoay; dead rebels being buried; Spanish victory coming on 7 Sep 1807; convicts being brought to the gallows; rebel leaders being hanged; and the condemned being decapitated.

Villanueva did not take formal lessons in an established artistic tradition, which can perhaps explain the naive style and the use of flat perspective. He derived artistic devices from those in his environment. He stylized clouds in the manner of the carved santo (religious image). He used the hierarchical perspective where principal figures, the Spaniards, loom largely over dwarflike commoners.

While the paintings were commissioned initially as a means for propaganda, an alternative interpretation involving local resistance is possible. The inclusion of Halley’s comet in the painting has been considered by others as Villanueva’s subtle message of urging the people to keep fighting and to hope for victory, for in local belief, a comet signifies the coming of a revolution.

Restoration efforts have been recently concentrated on the Basi Revolt paintings, which have been damaged severely due to neglect and previous restoration efforts, to retain its authentic appearance and determine the original materials used by Villanueva. The procedure also aims to uncover possible hidden meanings that have been overlooked or were unclear before. Written bySantiago A. Pilar, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Museum Foundation of the Philippines 2014; Vigan.ph 2015.

VILLANUEVA, ROBERTO (Roberto Villanueva Villanueva) b. Olongapo, Zambales 25 Jun 1947. d. 26 Feb 1994. Installation and performance artist, painter, filmmaker. He was the son of Napoleon Villanueva and Trinidad Villanueva. He finished a bachelor of fine arts degree at the University of Santo Tomas in 1973, after which he taught at the Philippine Women’s University in 1974-81.

Villanueva began as a surrealist painter in the 1970s. When he moved to Baguio City in 1980, he became a founding member and later vice president of the Baguio Arts Guild, which consists of other local artists such as BenCab, Santiago Bose, and filmmaker Kidlat Tahimik. He has done documentary films like Linang (Cultivated Field), The Ilocano Tradition, and Runsai, all in 1980, for the Council for Living Tradition. In 1983, as a member of the Board of Directors of the United Filmmakers Organization, he did ethnographic films of Cordillera festivals and documentaries on ecology. His documentary Bagong Sibol ang Gubat (Newly Sprung Is the Forest) won as Best Documentary Film in the Catholic Mass Media Awards, 1980, and the Berlin Film Festival, 1981.

He is known for creating art inspired by and built from the basic materials of the environment. He won critical recognition for Archetypes: A Cordillera Labyrinth or Uma ti Biag (Garden of Life) set up on the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) grounds in 1989. The installation, 45 m in diameter and 600 m in length, consisted of a spiral labyrinth made of bamboo and reeds. Its center was covered with rocks from a river bed, creating a space peopled with bulol or spirit figures. Another installation was Atang ti Kararua (Soul Offerings), consisting of three bamboo floats carrying offerings on a lake for the souls of those who perished in the big Baguio earthquake. His painting Pitong Sining (Seven Arts), 1990, used naked figures inspired by the Manunggul jar rowers, creating a circular group at the center enclosed by three lizards biting each other’s tails. Originally used for the Baguio Arts Festival in 1990, it became part of the CCP art collection as a mural installed on the wall of the staircase from the Main Theater lobby to the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino lobby. The image was later used as cover for the Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art) book and DVD edition, also produced by the CCP.

The artist also incorporated the participation of the locals of Pampanga and conducted a ceremony with a shaman to pacify the spirit of Mount Pinatubo, after its destructive eruption in 1991. In his works, Villanueva sought to restore the communal function of art and its primitive life force and to recover and understand the animism in the heart of Philippine culture.

He held at least four solo shows, the first being at the Ateneo Art Gallery in 1972, and participated in more than 50 group shows. In 1990, he was invited to New York as artist in residence of the New York State Council of the Arts. A year later at the Lincoln Square, he performed an indoor installation called Surrender to Nature, wherein he lit candles while in the middle of a sea of stalks. In an exhibition in Naguri, Japan, he combined Cordillera animism with Shintoism as he placed a bulol on a rushing stream and formed an arch using two reed stalks. He participated in the first Asia-Pacific Triennial of Contemporary Art in Brisbane, Australia, in 1993, where he created and performed Ego’s Grave at a mall’s courtyard. As one of his last major installations before his death in 1994, he carved a human figure within a deep pit made of terra-cotta, which he fired and glazed afterward. During his four-month stay in Brisbane, he would perform various ceremonies at the installation site, one of which was an indigenous Australian smoking ritual. He was a Thirteen Artists awardee of the CCP in 1992. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Antoinette and Turner 2014; BenCab Museum 2014; Lerma 2005b.

VILLASEÑOR, VICENTE Active 1860-82, Lucban, Quezon. Painter. He married Policarpia Manrique. The artistic education of Vicente Villaseñor is unknown, but it is a fact that there had been icon painters in Lucban as early as the 1820s. By the 1870s, portraiture was also a firmly established craft in Lucban. The writer Juan Alvarez Guerra in De Manila a Tayabas, 1878, wrote: “If you want a portrait while passing by Lucban, have no fear for you shall have one. There are indios (native Christians) in this vicinity who will capture you in oil, just having seen you once.” This statement might have been primarily alluding to Vicente Villaseñor.

Villaseñor did several religious paintings but he was best known for his portraits. In the latter, his work does not exhibit the detailed style of Manila’s miniaturists nor the solid modeling of the products of the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura. Nevertheless, he depicted resemblances as closely as his skills allowed and enhanced the personality of his sitters with objects that reflected their status, a convention he certainly observed in city portraits. His self-portrait, 1860, shows him garbed in a pale violet-brown coat and dark necktie. His features show him to be of Chinese descent, their delicateness suggesting his sensitivity as a youth immersed in art. In 1870, he painted the portrait of his wife Policarpia. Striking for its vibrancy brought about by the realistic rendition of her engaging gaze and her palpably soft, full chin, this piece followed portraiture conventions. Her right arm is propped on a table while her left holds a handkerchief to suggest that she comes from an influential family. The presence of the puppy at her right makes this piece unique among all 19th-century portraits. Villaseñor also painted the portraits of Antonio Limcuico and Feliciana Dollosa Limcuico, both in 1882, and Bartola Estrella. All his known paintings are on panel, except Bartola Estrella. Written bySantiago A. Pilar

VILLAVER, ARLENE (Arlene Suico Villaver) b. 14 Oct 1960. Painter. She is the daughter of Zacarias Josep Villaver and Ester Suico. Her father and grandfather are musicians. She studied fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) Cebu from 1977 to 1982, and was mentored by Professor Martino Abellana. Her engagements revolve around art education, being an art teacher at various schools such as St. Scholastica’s College in 1988, St. Benedict Learning Center in Cebu City in 1983-84, and the Learning Tree at Quezon City in 2002-8. She was also an art professor and coordinator at the fine arts program of Kalayaan College in 2004-8. From 1982 to 2012, Villaver conducted art workshops in Cebu, Leyte, Metro Manila, Cotabato, Baguio, and Osijek, Croatia. She is also a choreographer, Bible study facilitator, and curator. From 1982 to 2009, she was a member of the following groups: Cebu Art Association, Watercolor Society of the Philippines, Cebu Artists Guild, Visual Arts Committee of the Presidential Commission on Culture and the Arts, Kasibulan, Sining Biswal para kay Hesu-Kristo, Antipolo Thursday Group, Institute for Asian Church and Culture, and Binhi Art Group.

With watercolor as her main medium, Villaver composes abstractions and narrative pieces which incorporate her strong spiritual beliefs as a born-again Christian. The works embody a worldview born from steadfast faith accounts in calm yet bright colors on themes mainly surrounding childhood. Villaver, however, does not wholly stay within what would be construed as the perspective of an innocent and pure child as demonstrated by works like Rugby Boy— A Death Sentence, 2009, which includes the image of a drugged boy whose presence reaffirms that despite a childlike sensibility, the artist possesses an awareness of corruption that cannot be ignored even as it remains on the sidelines.

Villaver believes that her exhibitions were “born of interactions with individuals and communities” (Villaver 2014). She has been part of 80 group exhibits in Cebu City, Metro Manila, Baguio City, Pangasinan, Bacolod and Iloilo, as well as in Japan, Singapore, South Korea, Malaysia, England, Croatia, and Bulgaria. Among her significant solo exhibits are Daguioman (in Abra province), 1991, Liongoren Gallery; Larawan ng Buhay I: the Mount Pinatubo Series (Portrait of Life I: the Mount Pinatubo Series), 1993, West Gallery, Art Walk, SM Megamall; Larawan ng Buhay II: The Mount Pinatubo Series (Portrait of Life II: Mount Pinatubo Series), 1994, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP); Isang Dekada sa Maynila (A Decade in Manila), 1995, De La Salle Art Gallery; Understanding Hope and Poverty, 1995-99, at various venues in Metro Manila, Cebu, and Malaysia; Your Labor in the Lord Is Not in Vain, 2000, Artscape Gallery; and The Father’s Heart, A Father’s Heart, 2008, Artist’s Space, Ayala Museum.

In 1992, Villaver received the Joya Award, an annual prize funded by the late National Artist’s estate and given to young artists in cooperation with the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and the UP Cebu Arts and Culture Committee. Villaver became a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 1994. Written byZeny May D. Recidoro

Source:

Villaver 2014

VILLEGAS, RAMON N. (Ramon Nazareth Villegas) aka Mon Villegas, Boy Villegas b. Manila 23 Sep 1953. d. Makati City 6 Aug 2017. Curator, essayist, art historian, jeweler, and poet. He was the son of Rosendo Villegas and Illuminada Nazareth of Batangas. He finished his primary and secondary education at De La Salle Greenhills in 1966 and 1970 respectively, and graduated with a bachelor’s degree in literature, with honors, at the De La Salle University Manila in 1976. He later served as a lecturer in the said university and taught courses on Filipino Literature. Villegas was a member of the Galian sa Arte at Tula, a group of Philippine modernist poets in Filipino mentored by Virgilio S. Almario (later National Artist for literature). His poems were anthologized in Kamao: Panitikan ng Protesta 1970-1986 (Fist: Literature of Protest 1970-1986), 1987. Villegas left the academe to pursue his interests in art and history and served in various capacities as an independent curator, consultant, and appraiser for several public institutions including the Intramuros Administration, the National Museum of the Philippines, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the National Historical Commission of the Philippines, the Metropolitan Museum of Manila, the Ayala Museum, the Museo De La Salle, and key private collection, particularly the Paulino and Hetty Que Collection. He has also worked for the Asia Society of New York, the Asian Civilizations Museum of Singapore, the Musee du quai Branly-Jacques Chirac in Paris, and other leading international institutions. Villegas also ran his own antique and jewelry shop, Yamang Katutubo Artifacts and Crafts, which featured Philippine jewelry and antiques. He has authored and edited numerous books and publications on Philippine art and antiques namely: Kayamanan: The Philippine Jewelry Tradition, 1983; Hiyas: The Philippine Jewelry Heritage, 1997; Sining ng Panahong Ginintuan (Art of a Golden Age), 1999; Tubod: The Heart of Bohol, 2003; Ginto: History Wrought in Gold, 2004, National Book Award for Art; Power+Faith+Image: Philippine Art in Ivory from the 16th to the 19th Century, co-authored with Regalado Trota Jose, 2004; The Real H.R. Ocampo: From the Paulino Que Collection, 2013; and Filipinos in the Gilded Age: An Exhibition of Important Paintings, Ivory and Furniture, co-authored with Michael Manalo, Carmen Guerrero Nakpil and Lisa Guerrero Nakpil, 2014. His essays which have been published in several important publications on the arts and culture of the Philippines include “Life in the Colony” in Kasaysayan: The Story of the Filipino People, Volume IV, 1998; “A Visual Narrative of the Philippine Imagination” in Arts of Asia Magazine, 2004; “The Igorots of the Northern Philippines: Identity and Anthropological Perspectives” in A Passage to India: 25 Century of Exchange between Asia and Europe, 2013; and “Arts and Peoples of Northern Philippines” in Philippines: Archipelago of Exchange, 2011. Written byMatthew Benjamin P. Lopez

VINLUAN, NESTOR (Nestor Olarte Vinluan) b. Pozorrubio, Pangasinan 17 Mar 1949. Painter. He is the son of Numeriano Vinluan and Lelis Olarte. He is married to Linda Romualdez, an interior designer and weaver, with whom he has three children. Their son Paolo and daughter Liv Victoria are both artists. He finished a bachelor of fine arts degree in painting in the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (UP CFA). In 1982, he earned a master of fine arts in painting, minor in printmaking, at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York, on a Fulbright-Hays scholarship. Upon his return, he taught at the UP CFA and served as dean for three consecutive terms from 1989 to 1998.

He was one of the first artists to work on shaped canvases, as in his Windows series, which combined soft-focus and geometric forms to create a surrealist effect. His later works have been generally abstract with colored shapes in interaction.

He represented the Philippines in the ASEAN Travelling Exhibition and Symposium on Painting, Photography, and Children’s Art in Jakarta, Indonesia, 1988; in the 2nd Asian Art Show in Fukuoka, Japan, 1985; and in the Hong Kong Arts Festival, 1977. He has held one-person shows, including those at Sining Kamalig, 1974, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), 1975 and 1983; Luz Gallery, 1980, 1984, and 1986; the Pratt Institute, 1981; and Pinaglabanan Gallery, 1983. His later solo exhibitions include Of Earth, Sky and Spirit, Art Walk, 1999; From Blue to Earth with Red, Ayala Museum, 2001; Recent Paintings, Luz Gallery, 2002; Paintings/Installations/Objects II, Mag:net Gallery, 2003; Paintings/Installations/Objects III, Sculpture Square Singapore, 2004; From Sculpture Square and Other Recent Works by Nestor Vinluan, Mag:net Gallery, 2006; Radiance: New Works by Nestor Olarte Vinluan, Ayala Museum, 2008; and Selected Works, Mag:net Gallery, 2010. He has been a juror for the Design Idea Competition, 1996; Philip Morris Awards, 1996; Heritage Park Gateway Monument Design Competition, 1996; the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) Annual Art Competition, 1999; and Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards, 2000 and 2001.

Vinluan won a certificate of merit in the on-the-spot painting contest of the Shell National Students Art Competition, 1970, and first prize in the same category, 1971. In 1973, he won the grand prize in the AAP art competition, painting category. In 1974, he received the CCP’s Thirteen Artists Award. He received the professional achievement award in the arts (fine arts–painting) from the UP Alumni Association in 1993 and the Fernando Amorsolo Professorial Chair from the UP CFA in 1993, 1994, and 2004. In 2001, he was awarded the Gawad Chanselor para sa Pinakamahusay na Alagad ng Sining by the University of the Philippines Diliman. He was an artist-in-residence at the Sculpture Square, Singapore, in 2004, and at the Stadt-Atelier, Kunstlerhaus, Salzburg, in 2007. In 2008, he was awarded as Most Outstanding Fulbright Alumni in Arts and Humanities by the Philippine Fulbright Scholars Association. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Art for Volunteerism 2011; Ayala Museum, n.d.a; Cañete 2003; Philippine Art Scene 2006; Philstar.com 2013d.

VITALIS, MACARIO (Macario Cruz Vitalis) b. Laoag, Ilocos Sur 8 Mar 1898. d. Iligan City 8 Jun 1989. Painter. He studied at the Colegio de la Inmaculada Concepcion in Vigan. At 17, he decided to devote his life to painting, taking private lessons with Jose G. de Ocampo, a classical and figurative painter. In 1917, he left the Philippines for San Francisco where he studied at the California School of Fine Arts and took further studies in Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in 1924. After a brief stay in the United States, he went to France to pursue his art at the Academie des Beaux-Arts de Montmartre in 1926. Through all the years, he kept his Filipino citizenship. He died on his last visit to the Philippines in 1990.

His earliest paintings date back to the 1930s and were of the French working class in the Depression years. He engaged in painting portraits during World War II when he was interned in a concentration camp in France. After the war, he painted still lifes and abstracts, showing the influence of Jacques Villon and his circle, who had earlier established themselves in Puteaux where Vitalis put up his studio. It was in Puteaux that he also met a few modernist artists, one of whom was Pablo Picasso. He met Picasso at a restaurant owned by his friend Camille Renault, who let him stay there. Dining Chez Camille Renault (Dining at Camille Renault’s) marks the peak of his Paris years, when he worked in Renault’s restaurant which exhibited his paintings on its walls. The painting shows the influence of impressionism, although subsequently his works became more prismatic with interpenetrating planes of blues and yellows. From the 1960s, landscapes dominated his works as he settled in Plestin-les-Greves, a village in Brittany, Northern France. In 1963, he resumed contact with the country of his birth through the Bayanihan Dance Company which visited France and facilitated his first visit to the Philippines. He exhibited at the National Library in Manila—where his featured works were mostly spiritual and religious—sponsored by the French ambassador Francois Brier. Back in France, he pursued his prismatism in a number of landscapes of the period, at the same time that he took up religious themes.

Upon his return there in Plestin-les-Greves, he was commissioned by the Municipal Council to paint a mural for the Plestin Town Hall and the Maison de Retraite. In 1975, he was cited by then Plestin mayor Marcel Harmon as “the only honorary citizen” of the town at an event where his works were exhibited. In 1981, his works were featured, along with the paintings of Nena Saguil and Ofelio Gelvezon-Tequi, at an exhibition called Six Artistes Contemporains Philippins en Europe in Paris. A year later, during his 84th birthday celebration, the Community of Plestin presented Vitalis with an oak bust carved by Breton sculptor Lucien Prigent. In 1984, he opened a retrospective exhibition in Plestin, featuring his works which spanned 50 years. It was also in that same year that he received an award of excellence from the Institut Academique de Paris for his painting La Crêperie.

In 1986, he visited Manila for his first retrospective exhibition at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Main Gallery. He went to Iligan City after the show, where he was able to paint a few more works. These paintings were exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila in 1987 and at the Finale Art File in 1988. His works can be viewed at the Lopez Museum, Pasig City. Written byAlice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Sources:

Geringer 2015; Tayag 2011; Tiu 2013.

VITUG, JEVIJOE (Jevijoe Batac Vitug) b. Santa Rita, Pampanga 20 Jul 1977. Visual and performance artist. He is the son of Ernesto Vitug and Marieta Batac. He grew up in Bacolor, a municipality in Pampanga that was devastated by the lahar that came upon the province during the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in 1991. His family was among those relocated to a resettlement in San Fernando, Pampanga. He is married to Antoniete Vitug and has two sons, Aegean and Jevhanni. He graduated cum laude with a degree of bachelor of fine arts in painting from St. Scholastica’s College, Manila, in 1998 and has gone on to take courses toward a master of fine arts in the new genres program of the San Francisco Art Institute. After graduating from St. Scholastica’s College and while holding a day job as a visual merchandiser, he served as a painting assistant for artists such as Renato Habulan. Vitug also took classes under Roberto Chabet and Manuel Ocampo. He was also able to take short courses in production design under the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and a production class with Leo Abaya. This latter training equipped him to work as a production designer and television production specialist for the television network GMA. He migrated to the United States in 2008, initially living in San Francisco, California, but later moving to Las Vegas, Nevada. Vitug is the founder of the artist initiative Re: Source Art and Development, which is dedicated to collaborating with local communities and nonprofit organizations to help realize advocacy goals.

Vitug’s art practice encompasses painting, performance art, video art, installation art, and socially engaged art. He also curates and writes about art, and has worked as an art teacher. The forms in which Vitug’s works come significantly vary since this is a result of his deliberating upon the best medium to use for expressing a certain idea. Even as a painting major in college, he joined Sining Tanghalan, a St. Scholastica’s College theater group, which prepared him for the performance art he would take up later in his practice. His earlier paintings, which were heavily influenced by his lahar experience, were made with a limited palette of mostly earth colors. These days, however, his paintings at times include brighter colors reminiscent of the neon lights found in Las Vegas. Some paintings he has done are a combination of abstraction and realism, including works in Suspending This Belief, 2005. The paintings in the 2014 exhibition Terra Infirma are realistic renditions of satellite imagery showing the effects of oil spills, nuclear tests, and other environmental catastrophes, which appear as abstract elements in his work.

His solo shows in the Philippines include Suspending This Belief, 2005, Big & Small Art Gallery; I Painted the Presidents, 2005, Dateline Gallery, Cubao Shoe Expo; Lessons from the Masters, 2005, CCP; Source of Living, 2010, Pablo Gallery; and The Truns, 2011, Manila Contemporary. In Las Vegas, his solo exhibitions include How To’s, 2012, CCP; Before/After: Nuclear Weapons Testing Legacy, 2012, Fifth Wall Gallery; Casino Capital, 2013, Momas and Dadas Project House; Wasteland/Oasis, 2013, Fifth Wall Gallery; and Terra Infirma, 2014, Left of the Center Gallery. Vitug has also shown in group exhibitions in Japan and Germany.

Vitug’s first significant art citation came in 1991 when he represented the Philippines in Geneva, Switzerland, as the Philippine Red Cross Painting Competition first place winner. As a college student from 1994 to 1998, he was a consistent finalist in various painting competitions. He won awards at the Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition: honorable mention in 1998, third prize for representational painting in 1999, and the Leo Benesa Award for Art Criticism in 2003. The Philippine Art Awards recognized him thrice as a finalist—from 2000 to 2003. Vitug became a CCP Thirteen Artists awardee in 2006. He received grants from the Nevada Art Council Jackpot Award in 2010 and 2012 and he was also part of the Metro Arts Council of Southern Nevada’s Zap! Public Art Project, 2010. Written byIris S. De Ocampo

WILWAYCO, EDWIN (Edwin Cinense Wilwayco) b. Guimba, Nueva Ecija 18 Jul 1952. Painter. He is the son of Nicodemus P. Wilwayco and Josefina Cinense. He is the nephew of fashion designer Tente Wilwayco, a protégé of National Artist Ramon Valera. He took up continental design studies in Los Angeles, California, 1968, and earned a bachelor of fine arts at the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman, 1972. Wilwayco received the British Council Scholarship for Painting at the West Surrey College of Art and Design in Farnham, England, 1982.

Wilwayco looks to music and his strong sense of faith as his inspirations. He has a penchant for the orchestral and his works are described as “nothing short of symphonic” (Magsaysay 2014). This affinity to the spiritual and musical is best exemplified in his works River Circles, 2010; shaped screens called Birds of Paradise, 1995; and Second Nature, 2011. There are also direct references to music such as Homage to Bach, 2010; Homage to Vivaldi, 2010; and Silent Music, 2006. These works are marked by their particular use of color and brushstrokes evoking either grand or subdued sounds. In Well Tempered Clavier (from Homage to Bach), muted colors are given hints of brightness and minute movements. Within the stately stillness is a spirit that wishes to be unleashed from its frame. This evokes the mathematical precision and organization, as well as spirituality and a certain joie de vivre of Bach’s compositions. While the works possess their earthly overtones, it would be difficult not to be lifted and to see the metaphysical in Wilwayco’s works. His appropriation of Filipino motifs, as with the bold colors and dynamic geometrical configurations of Birds of Paradise and Second Nature, and combining these with his eclectic experience and education has enabled Wilwayco’s paintings to contribute to the lineage of vibrant abstract expressionist works in the Philippines. Wilwayco himself cites Hanger Wires, Cathedrals, Jeepney Fantasia, Heliconias and Birds of Paradise, In Nature’s Realm, 2012, and Recalibrations, 2014, as some of his landmark series.

From 1976 to 2012, he exhibited widely in the Philippines as well as internationally in sites like Providence, Rhode Island, Paris, France, and Essen, Germany. Among these solo exhibitions are Images of Exuberance, 1976, at Hidalgo Gallery, Philippines; Gaudeamus, 2006, at St. Kamillus Centre, Essen, Germany; Silent Music, 2006, at Galerie Etienne de Causans, Paris; and Homage to Gluck, 2009, at BankRI Gallery, Providence, Rhode Island, USA. Wilwayco received an Award of Excellence for his UP Fine Arts thesis in 1972, the Italian government scholarship for painting in 1982, the Achievements Award from the Mees Music Foundation of Guimba Inc, and the UP Alpha Omega Fraternity Oblation Run Award for visual arts in 2003. He received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1994. Written byZeny May D. Recidoro

Sources:

Magsaysay 2014; Wilwayco, n.d.

YAN-SANTOS, PAMELA (Pamela Valera Yan-Santos) b. Quezon City 4 Aug 1974. Visual artist. Her parents are Relly Yan and Susana Valera. Yan-Santos graduated with a degree in painting from the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts in 1995. She taught studio courses at the same college from 1997 to 2000.

Yan-Santos explores art and womanhood through a wide range of creative methods and forms. A highly skilled printmaker and painter, she combines mediums such as stencils, collage, serigraphy, image transfer, and painting to mount installation pieces that often incorporate wall-bound works, video, and sound. Her works are highly tactile, meticulously rendered, and thoughtfully assembled. She explores the links between materials and attendant techniques, the potency of image, the codes of language, and the immersive potential of three-dimensional forms in space. She explores her life as a woman artist across themes of femininity, domesticity, and child-rearing. Her recollections are far from sentimental; they are serene and incisive explorations of her inner and outer worlds and the self that is realized in between these spheres. Drawing from her personal life, the artist also succeeds in involving us in the act of recollection by expanding how we grasp memory through mundane acts.

Yan-Santos has exhibited solo since 2002 at various local galleries and museums, delving into themes close to hearth, bringing depth and uncommon insight into what has come to be accepted as commonplace. In her exhibition Imperfections, 2013, at the BenCab Museum in Baguio, period furniture was encased in pages taken from old school textbooks. The furniture set with their low seats and turned legs hark back to the past as did paintings of kitchenware, a wooden toy, the skeletal frame of a lamp that all show wear from the passage of time. The artist rendered these pieces and domestic scenes devoid of nostalgia for the past, highlighting instead current predicaments about education and womanhood. Her work therefore attempts to elevate the ordinary into the realm of deep thought and the everyday to the sphere of larger beliefs.

Group exhibitions she participated in include the 5th Mondial Triennale of small-sized prints in France in 2000, Art Beijing in 2008, Art Stage Singapore in 2013, and Art Basel Hong Kong in 2013. Philippine exhibitions include Sungduan 4: Extensions at the Museum of Three Cultures, Cagayan de Oro, and Postcards from the Philippines, Utterly Art Gallery, Singapore, 2007. Yan-Santos received the first prize in the print category of the 1993 Art Association of the Philippines Annual Art Competition and the Thirteen Artists Award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2009. Written byTessa Maria Guazon

Sources:

Asia Art Archive 2008, n.d.b; Ateneo Art Gallery 2009; Snippets 2011b.

YONZON, HUGO JR (Hugo Carlos Yonzon Jr) b. Manila 24 May 1924. d. Oct 1994. Illustrator, cartoonist, painter. He was married to Vitaliana “Betty” Dagani, and father of their 13 children. He graduated with a bachelor of arts degree in fine arts from the University of the Philippines (UP) on a Ramon Roces scholarship. When he was a small boy in grade school, he did pencil drawings of the dominant images of the media and cinema, cowboys and film stars, such as Janet Gaynor and Shirley Temple. He also enjoyed copying characters from the comics such as Captain Marvel. His schooling was interrupted by the World War II. After the war in 1947, the Ramon Roces Publications was in need of artists to illustrate the Liwayway magazine. It held a national art contest and created scholarships for the top 10 artists to study for a year at the UP School of Fine Arts. Yonzon belonged to the first batch of scholars.

Yonzon worked at the Liwayway and the Evening News for one year and then became the first artist of the advertising agency Philprom. At Philprom from 1947 to 1950, he worked with artist colleagues Cesar Legaspi and Slim Torres. When his boss, A.G. Palileo, put up Adcraft, he brought Yonzon with him as artist. There he worked for more than 10 years and in 1960 transferred to the Philippine Advertising Counsellors.

Yonzon’s break as an artist came when Lyd Arguilla, founder of the Philippine Art Gallery, commissioned him to do a six-meter long mural for the New York World Fair in 1964. The mural in oil was a panoramic view of Philippine life and culture, focusing on festivals. It was the same international fair which featured carved panels representing episodes of Philippine history designed by Carlos V. Francisco and executed by Paete artists. In the Philippine Pavilion, which was shaped like a rounded nipa hut, Francisco’s panels were on the ground floor and Yonzon’s mural was displayed in circular form around the central beam of the second floor. Other artists who exhibited their works were Napoleon Abueva, J. Elizalde Navarro, and Rodolfo Paras-Perez.

His first one-person show was held in 1968 at the Solidaridad Gallery on Harrison. His second was held the following year. His sixth and last one-man exhibit was held at the Lopez Museum in 1989, which featured figurative oil paintings, a diversion from his cubist-neorealist style. Aside from painting in oil, he did significant work in cartoons and caricature.

His works often show a tension between the conservative and the modern. Being versatile, he also had the tendency to work in different styles, so that an exhibit of his can give the impression of a five-person show. Later, however, he settled for one style, cubist of influence, as in Manansala and the Neo-Realists, and maintained a preference for acrylic as medium.

He received awards from the Art Association of the Philippines: sixth prize, painting, Squatters, 1949; first prize, caricature, Cuenco, 1951; honorable mention, modern category, Tindahang Sari-sari (Variety Store), 1952; first prize, photography, Still Water, 1953; first prize, photography, Scat, 1953; first prize, painting, Harana (Serenade), 1954; and third prize, painting, Procession, 1955. Almost 20 years after his death, a major exhibit called A Glimpse of Hugo Yonzon Jr.: Life and Works was held at the Main Gallery of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

Source:

Yonzon 2014.

YU, MM (MM So Yu) b. Manila 3 Jan 1978. Painter, photographer, installation artist. She is the daughter of Rogelio Yu and Hannah So. She graduated with a fine arts degree from the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman in 2001.

Yu’s practice spans a variety of media including painting, photography, video, installation, and elements of performance. The visual impact of her works is heightened by its conceptual power. She is known for her drip paintings, which she began doing in 2000. Grappling with chance and control, Yu allows paint to fall onto canvas to create linear patterns and multiple color combinations. Her drip paintings transcend the usual support of the canvas, dripping on to plinths or splattering upon a building’s columns. If You Could Hear a Pin Drop and White Elephant consist of drip paintings and video that challenge the viewer’s perception and reveal the immaterial aspects of the works.

As a photographer, Yu counts on her discerning eye’s inclination toward the commonplace. Her works reconcile binaries and contradictions in everyday surroundings as in the photographs that made up the exhibitions Common/Oddities at Silverlens Galleries and Subject/Object at Mag:Net, 2009. She draws upon photography’s documentary capability while underscoring her subjective inclinations as an image-maker. She defamiliarizes found objects, recognizes various configurations amid “visual garbage,” and captures recurring texts and images on the streets. Yu continues to explore various ways of presenting photographs, turning to the light box, to wall paper, or to do-it-yourself photo books as in Thoughts Collected, Recollected, 2007. An early work titled Cool Pieties, 2001, is made up of a thousand multi-exposed photographs occupying the entire wall of a gallery. 18th Ave Kodakan (18th Ave Picture Taking), 2004, consists of 200 photographs of the artist posing with residents and bystanders along a street in Cubao. The work literally gives viewers a glimpse of the artist and her process.

Her solo exhibitions include Landpaintings, Silverlens Galleries, Makati City, 2014; Left of Here, West Gallery, Quezon City, 2013; Miscellaneous, Galeri Canna, Jakarta, Indonesia, 2012; Inventory, Galerie Zimmermann-Kratochwill, Graz, Austria, 2011; If You Could Hear a Pin Drop, West Gallery, Quezon City, and Waste Not, Want Not, Finale Art File, Makati City, 2010. She has participated in group exhibitions in Manila and abroad such as Local Futures: The Culture China Young Overseas Chinese Invitational Exhibition, He Xiangning Art Museum, Shenzen, China; Manila Vice, Musee International des Arts Modestes (Miam), Sete, France, 2013; Bastards of Misrepresentation, Queens Museum of Art, New York; Grid 2012 Bi-Annual Photography Festival, Amsterdam, The Netherlands; Bastards of Misrepresentation: Contemporary Art from Manila, H Gallery, Bangkok, 2012; Chongquing Youth Art Biennale, Art Museum of Sichuan Fine Arts Institute, China; Salvation in a Nest of Vipers, Lost Projects with Y3K Gallery, Melbourne, Australia; and Space and Two Points, MO Space, Taguig, 2011.

Yu received the Ateneo Art Award in 2007 and the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2009. She was artist in residence at Cite International des Arts, Paris, 2013; at Common Room, Bandung, Indonesia, 2007; and at Big Sky Mind, Cubao, 2003-4. Written byLouise Anne D. Marcelino

YUSON, REGGIE (Reginald Sison Yuson) b. 5 Jul 1974. Sculptor and painter. He is the son of Jose Palma Yuson and Carmen Sison. He took up fine arts, major in sculpture, at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts in 1995.

As part of a postwar generation of sculptors influenced by abstraction and modernism and deviating from the representational tradition of large monumental commissions, Yuson’s works emphasize the abstraction of form and the qualities of the material itself. Yuson’s earlier sculptural pieces exhibit a strong sense of minimalism, stressing the physicality of industrial and natural media.

Since 2005, Yuson has increasingly moved away from creating discrete abstract objects and explored how sculpture redefines the viewer’s experience of the surrounding space, such as gallery or outdoor areas. Site+Works, 2005, marked this engagement with physical site through an installation that explored the use of reflective surfaces and materials, such as black auto paint and sheet metal, as means to make objects engage with their surroundings. Another solo exhibition, R. Muck, 2010, featured parabolic black bobs fabricated from fiberglass scattered across the gallery floors and walls in random clusters.

Since the early 2000s, Yuson has created large-scale public art projects and sculptural commissions. His corporate commissions include works for Greenbelt Makati, 2003; Fort Bonifacio High Street Sculpture Park, Taguig, 2006-7; the Renaissance Harbor View Hotel, Hong Kong, 2007; Marquee Mall Civic Plaza, Pampanga, 2009; Manila Hotel, 2011; and The Mind Museum, Taguig, 2011-12. Among these commissions are Specific Gravity, a boulder fountain comprised of an immense and apparently heavy mass suspended in air, precariously propped up by gently sloping steel rods, and Hearsay, composed of twisted industrial pipes through which sounds travel.

Yuson held his first solo exhibition at UP and has since then held exhibitions of his sculptures, paintings, drawings, and furniture sculptures at the West Gallery, Pinto Art Galllery, Mag:net Gallery, ART Forum Gallery, Singapore, and Manila Contemporary. His works have been included in group exhibitions in the Philippines, Hong Kong, and France.

Yuson was a member of the Art Association of the Philippines, 1993; the Society of Philippine Sculptors, 1993-2000; and the Philippine Native Plants Conservation Society Inc, from 2011 to present. He served as a member of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts Committee on Visual Arts from 1996 to 2001. He received the Thirteen Artists award from the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2003. Written by Lisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Bonifacio Global City, n.d.; Legaspi-Ramirez 2015; Plot Public Art, n.d.; Secret Fresh Gallery 2011; Waytogo 2007; Yuson 2006.

ZABALLERO, PHYLLIS (Phyllis Panganiban del Rosario-Zaballero) b. Rosario, Cavite 2 Jan 1942. Painter, art educator. She is the daughter of Fermin O. del Rosario and Felicitas Panganiban. She married Augusto M. Zaballero with whom she has three children. She graduated with a bachelor of arts in economics in 1964, and a bachelor of fine arts, major in painting, magna cum laude, from the University of the Philippines (UP) School of Fine Arts in 1978. Prior to her studies in UP, she got several certificates in French language and literature from the Universite de Geneve in Switzerland and from the Universidad de Barcelona in Spain in 1957 and 1958, respectively. She was an instructor of painting in 1979-82 and 1994-96 at the Department of Studio Arts, UP College of Fine Arts. She was also a lecturer in the Summer Arts Workshop in the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1980-85.

Her field is painting and art education, and her area of expertise is painting large-scale abstractions. She had 36 solo shows from 1978 to 2009 in the Philippines, Asia, Europe, and the United States, including her first show at the CCP Small Theater (now also known as Bulwagang Fernando Amorsolo) in 1978; at the Sining Kamalig, Hiraya Gallery, and the Alliance Française in 1984; at the Finale Art Gallery in 1985; and a two-person show in the National Museum of Jakarta, Indonesia, in 1989. From 1974 to 2009, she joined group exhibitions in the Philippines, Southeast Asia, Bangladesh, Japan, China, Hong Kong, and the United States.

In 1988, she received a study grant to Washington, DC. In 1989, she won a professional study grant to the Federal Republic of Germany from the Goethe Institut and also enjoyed a visitorship study grant to the United Kingdom for Art and Museums from the British Council. In 1992, she received the French Cultural Ministry study grant for stained-glass technique in France. In 1995, she completed a lithography course at the Art Students League in New York City, and in 1998 a drawing marathon course at the New York Studio School. Her international experience in the arts had led her to work in various media, including stained glass. She received the CCP Thirteen Artists Award in 1979. Written by Alice G. Guillermo, updated by Katrina Yap and Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source :

Zaballero, n.d.

ZAFARALLA, PAUL (Paul Blanco Zafaralla) b. Pinili, Ilocos Norte 22 Jun 1938. Essayist, art critic, painter. He is the son of Tito C. Zafaralla and Mauricia T. Blanco. He married Macrina Tamayo, and they have four children. He obtained his bachelor of fine arts, master of arts in education, and doctor of philosophy in communications at the University of the Philippines (UP). He was a faculty member of the College of Arts and Sciences, UP Los Baños (UPLB). He is a member of the International Society of Education through Arts, and is on the board of directors of GungloDagitiMannuratngaIlokano or GUMIL Metro Manila.

As an art critic, he authored Victoria: Art Educator, Artist, Humanist, 1986; coauthored Carlos V. Francisco: The Man and Genius of Philippine Art, 1985; and was one of the five essayists of APortfolioof 60PhilippineArtMasterpieces, 1986. In 2004, he edited the award-winning anthology Rice in the Seven Arts, published by the Asia Rice Foundation, with essays exploring the relationship of rice and the arts.

Zafaralla has published monographs and critiques. He was an art critic for the Manila Chronicle, Times Journal, Philippine Daily Express, Philippine Daily Inquirer, and columnist for the Ginoo Magazine. He also contributed to PhilippinesFreePress, Graphic, Philippines Quarterly, Panorama, Celebrity, Pamana, and Philippine Communication Journal. He is a regular columnist of Marie Claire Magazine and contributes to Bannawag magazine. As an Ilocano writer, he has published poems, short stories, and stories for children.

As a painter and art critic, he received the following awards and fellowships: bronze medal, modern category, UP Student Catholic Action art competition, 1961; special award for art criticism, Art Association of the Philippines, 1972; holder, UP Professorial Chair in Humanities, UPLB, 1978-80; art critic in residence, UP System, 1981-84; and special recognition, research in the creative arts, UPLB, 1988. In 2004, the Manila Critics Circle awarded him the National Book Award for Rice in the Seven Arts. In 2006, he was awarded the Don Ignacio Lafrades Award for distinguished achievement by the Pinili-Metro Manila Residents Associations Inc. Written byReynaldo Duque and Cecilia S. De La Paz

Source:

Panitikan.com 2016.

ZAFRA, ALVIN (Alvin Palomer Zafra) b. Quezon City 19 Nov 1978. He is the son of Benjamin Zafra and Evelinda Palomer. He studied fine arts, major in painting, at the University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts (UP CFA) from 1996 to 2000.

Zafra was among the students mentored by Roberto Chabet at the UP CFA in the late 1990s. Exposed to conceptual and experimental ways of art-making through his participation in group shows such as Racing Thoughts, 1999, at the West Gallery, Zafra started his long-running Objects/Medium project, where he uses real objects, such as bullets or bottles, as both media and subject for drawing. This formal exploration of materials and process later merged with sociopolitical commentary in the series Headshot, 2008, and Killing Box, 2010, where Zafra uses M-16 bullets as drawing tools on sandpaper to create portraits in response to the extrajudicial killings and enforced disappearances of Philippine activists and journalists.

More broadly associated with Zafra are his “skull paintings,” which he produces using animal and human bones and sandpaper. For his undergraduate thesis work Argument from Nowhere, 2000, Zafra repeatedly scraped a human skull on three sandpaper panels, producing an abstract painting by grinding the form into powder residue, and documenting the process through video. The work was later exhibited at the Mori Art Museum, Tokyo, in 2009 and at the 3rd Mediations Biennale, 2012, at the National Museum of Poznan, Poland. This process is echoed in the works No. 80 Versus Complex, 2001, and Aso’t Pusa (Dog and Cat), 2013, where the skulls of a dog and a cat are ground upon two acrylic cubes covered with sandpaper. This process-centric mode of work extended to employing the artist’s own body in 2006, when Zafra started producing nail portraits using his own fingernails abraded against sandpaper to produce a series of portraits.

He held his first solo exhibition, Destroy, Erase, Improve, 2001, at Big Sky Mind and his second solo exhibition, Paper Trails, 2006, at Future Prospects. Since then, he has held solo exhibitions at West Gallery, Nova Gallery, Mo Space, West Gallery, and Finale Art File. He has been part of numerous group exhibitions since 1997, including Bisa: Potent Presences, 2011, at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila and The Topology of Signs, 1999, Cultural Center of the Philippines. He has also participated in group exhibitions in Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, Poland, Singapore, and Taiwan. These include Thrice upon a Time, 2009, at the Singapore Art Museum and Crossing Space, 2013, in Albert Schweizer Schule, Hanover, Germany. Zafra was a finalist in the 2011 Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Tanaw Art Competition. He received an honorable mention in the 1998 Art Association of the Philippines Centennial Painting Competition. Written byLisa Ito-Tapang

Sources:

Asia Art Archive 2014c; GMA News Online 2011a; Lumbao 2014; West Gallery 2013; Zafra 2014.

ZALAMEDA, OSCAR (Oscar Deveza Zalameda)b. Lucban, Quezon 24 Sep 1930. d. Lucena City 10 Jul 2010. Painter. He was the son of Eladio S. Zalameda and Julia Deveza. Finishing his bachelor of fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas in 1950, he went abroad to further his studies at the Art Students League of California, the Ecole nationale superieure des Beaux-Arts, and Paris-Sorbonne University.

Zalameda’s early works are exemplified in two watercolors: After the Rain and Still Life. After the Rain is essentially a representational work showing two women at the center, their backs to the viewer as if about to cross what appears to be a rain-soaked street. The pavement that occupies the foreground glistens with rain. The other side of the street is rendered impressionistically, with the buildings foreshortened to give the painting a pleasant sense of depth. The watercolor technique is used for both representational and stylistic effect. The rendition of the street, on the other hand, with an explicit reference to its Chinese name locates the scene. Still Life shows Zalameda experimenting with cubism. A few lines are made to suggest the shape of a bottle, a fish, an old dish, and a fruit. The lines of the fish crisscross with those of the bottle, thus negating the work’s realism. The conciseness of the forms also give the painting an Oriental minimalist feel. In the 1960s, Zalameda’s shapes became bolder. In Sailboats, 1964, the artist’s juxtaposition of bold colors transforms his sails of boats and the blue sea into an abstract pattern. From the 1970s onward, bold shapes of loud colors were used by the artist to execute genre scenes.

Among the artist’s most prestigious shows was his exhibition at the National Palace of Fine Arts in Mexico City, 1965. He also held exhibitions at the Malacañan Palace, 1966, and the Palace Lausanne, Switzerland, in 1988.

Zalameda received numerous awards and citations, including the Chevalier des Arts et Lettres from the French government. In 2006, he was awarded a Presidential Medal of Merit. Written by Santiago A. Pilar, updated by Rosa Concepcion Ladrido

Sources:

Lerma 2010; Mallari 2010; Silvestre 2010.

ZAMORA, CRISPULO (Crispulo de Guzman Zamora) b. Sampaloc, Manila 28 Jun 1871. d. 11 Oct 1922. Silversmith, engraver. He was the fourth child of Mauricio Zamora and Gervasia de Guzman, the “Lola Basyang” of SeverinoReyes. He married Pelagia Mendoza, a bemedaled sculptor. His father was himself an engraver and maintained a shop where his children had their first lessons in the art of engraving. Zamora went to a school directed by the schoolmaster Jose Flores. His father, seeing the boy’s unusual interest in his art and business, sent him to the Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado in Intramuros. He studied painting under Lorenzo Rocha, then director of the school, and engraving under MelecioFigueroa, an accomplished artist who had just arrived from the Peninsula. For three years, 1890-93, Zamora studied assiduously in the school while gaining much practical knowledge in his father’s shop. He also studied at the Escuela de Artes y Oficios where he learned casting under RamonMartinez while simultaneously serving as an assistant to Professor Campa. After graduation from the Escuela, he joined his father’s establishment on Crespo (now Hidalgo) St. He was 24 years old when his galvano-plated bust of Father Anaya, cantor (singer) of the Manila Cathedral, was awarded a prize in the Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (Philippine Regional Exposition) in 1895.

Upon his father’s death, he took over the engraving business, manufacturing with bare hands and inadequate handmade tools. He made insignias, buttons, and other military decorations for the revolutionary army. During the American period, his business grew steadily, enabling him to acquire and import modern machinery from abroad. During this time he had no strong competitor in the field, thus allowing his enterprise to prosper. At the time of his death he was manufacturing on a large scale, with about 50 workers employed in his engraving plant.

Among the more notable products of his art is the crown for the Virgin of Naga, which cost 34,000 pesos, and four elaborately designed plaques made for United States presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson, the third for the king of Spain, and the fourth for the emperor of Japan.

After his death, his wife continued the engraving business, passing it later to their children. Written byE. Arsenio Manuel

ZAMUCO, ERIC (Eric de Leon Zamuco) b. Manila26 Apr 1969. Multimedia artist. He is the son of Jaime T. Zamuco and Medarle de Leon. He earned his bachelor of fine arts in visual communication from the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Fine Arts in 1991, and his master of fine arts in sculpture from the University of Missouri, Columbia, in 2009.

Zamuco began his art practice primarily as a photographer and painter. His early work consisted of collaged images overlaid with drawn elements and soberly toned color interventions. His image-making shifted to a definitively more tactile phase when he embarked on graduate studies in Missouri, and as he reckoned with the American state’s seminal role in the 1904 Saint Louis World Exposition. This phase in his practice is marked by a more acute sense of the meaning-making potentials of memorial residue that could be activated by manipulating such historically charged materials as anecdotes of racial slurs, dog treats, ash, food, a marching ditty, soap, and subtle references to American consumerism.

Among his solo exhibitions are Laman (Flesh), West Gallery, Quezon City, 2001; Consisting Upholding, Vermont Studio Center, Johnson, Vermont, 2002; Consisting Upholding, The Corredor, UP, and Ayala Museum, 2003; Fine Line, West Gallery, 2004; Karga (Load), 2007, West Gallery; Banal: Sculptural Meditations on the Unfamiliar (Holy: Sculptural Meditations on the Unfamiliar), 2009, George Caleb Bingham Gallery, Columbia, Missouri; Out of Ordinary Spectacles, 2011, Silverlens, Manila; Inconspicuously Consumed, 2012, Bliss on Bliss Art Projects, Queens, New York; Another Please, 2012, Phoenix Gallery, New York; Site of Marks, 2013, Silverlens; Balat (Skin), 2013, West Gallery; Private Pool, 2014, Mo Space, The Fort; and Another Other, 2014, Ateneo Art Gallery, Quezon City. His group exhibitions include Southern Comfort, 2007, National Academy of Oslo, Norway; It’s Not Easy, 2008, Exit Art; FastX3, 2009, White Flag Projects, Saint Louis; Puzzling(a)Space, 2010, Hillyer Art Space, DC; Cosmetic Order, 2011, Mo Space, The Fort; An Exchange with Sol LeWitt, 2011, Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art; Grounded, 2012, Lopez Museum; The Hope & the Dream in Filipino, Canon Open Gallery, Tokyo, 2012; Hugot (Pull), 2013, Sining Makiling Gallery; Marking Time, 2013, Ateneo Art Gallery; Unbearable Lightness of Being, 2013-14, Finale Art File; and Pamumuhunan (Waiting for a Capital), Lucban, Quezon, 2015.

Zamuco received an Ayala Foundation scholarship in 2002 and an artist’s residency grant in the Vermont Studio Center in 2003. He also received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2003 and was among the three winners of the first Ateneo Art Awards in 2005. He received several fellowships and grants, which allowed him to take on further art studies: a University of Missouri Center for Arts and Humanities grant, the Donald L. Bartlett Memorial scholarship, as well as a Phoenix Gallery fellowship award in 2011-12, New York. He was the winner of the 2015 Alliance Française de Manille Philippine artist residency program. Written byEileen Legaspi-Ramirez

ZARAGOZA, EFREN b. Libon, Albay 1940. d. 20 Jun 1989. Printmaker. He studied fine arts at the University of Santo Tomas in 1957-71, at the University of the Philippines in 1961-64, and at Philippine Women’s University in 1964-67. He worked closely with the Rodriguez family of printmakers, Lucio Martinez, and VirgilioAviado in graphic arts workshops. His best medium is woodcut, which he exhibited at the 1971 Paris Biennale, the 1976 Western Pacific Print Biennale in Australia, and the 1980 show titled The Art of Fine Print: A View of 25 Years at the Museum of Philippine Art.

Done mostly in black ink on rice paper, Zaragoza’s prints recreate the human face or figure into ornamental leitmotif. Laced Voodoo, 1966, is made up of four faces stylized into decorative radial forms that echo the sun’s rays, water waves, and flower petals reminiscent of animistic symbols. Love at the Mardi Gras, 1971, suggests images of the Moriones and Ati-Atihan festivals arranged in lively linear compositions of flowers and faces. Veronica’s Veil, 1969, appears like crisscrosses of magnified weaves or knots but actually facial patterns in rhythmic recurrence.

Zaragoza won the grand prize for Africana II in the 1970 Philippine Association of Printmakers competition. From the ArtAssociationof thePhilippines, he received third prize for Sacred Rehis and third prize for Inferiority Complex in 1966. He won at the Shell National Students Art Competition: certificate of merit, Nightmare, 1965, and first prize, Trivials and Vicars, 1966. Written byImelda Cajipe-Endaya

ZARAGOZA, MIGUEL (Miguel Aranquizna Zaragoza) b. Gapan, Nueva Ecija 29 Sep 1842. d. 5 Mar 1923. Painter. He was the son of Rafael Zaragoza and Gregoria Aranquizna. Attending the Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, he obtained a scholarship from the Spanish government, leaving with FelixResurreccionHidalgo for Madrid in 1879. He was one of the illustrators of the deluxe edition of Fr Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas (Plants of the Philippines). In 1877, his drawing La Lechera (The Milkmaid) appeared in La Ilustracion del Oriente. He refined his painting at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando, Madrid, 1879-82, and at the satellite academy in Rome, 1882-85. Returning to Manila in 1891, he taught at the Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado, Ateneo de Manila, and Liceo de Manila. From 1891 to 1895, he wrote more than 100 articles on art, culture, and history, mainly for La Ilustracion Filipina, published by his brother Jose. In 1908, he became one of the founding members of the faculty of the UP School of Fine Arts.

A typical academic painter of the 19th century, Zaragoza was fond of dark colors and impasto brushwork along the style of the 17th-century Spanish master Velazquez. In 1921 and 1922, however, he experimented with pointillism, applying his paints in tiny specks with a worn-out brush, as in his views of Guimaras at the University of the Philippines Vargas Museum Collection and at the University of Santo Tomas Museum. Most of Zaragoza’s work did not survive the World War II. His most famous painting, ElVioloncellista (The Cellist), 1891, is now at the Malacañan Palace. The Central Bank owns the portrait Pedro Paterno, 1882, and El Gobernadorcillo (The Mayor), 1891. The Pagrel collection has Old Mestiza from Quiapo, El Lego (The Layman), and the portraits Manuel Zaragoza and Luciano Santiago. The Mara collection has the portrait Jose Valer Calderon.

Zaragoza received a silver medal at the Exposicion Universal de Barcelona (Barcelona Universal Exposition) in 1888 and the Exposicion Regional de Madrid (Madrid Regional Exposition). At the Saint Louis Universal Exposition of 1904, he received a gold medal for his overall participation, while individual awards were accorded to specific works—namely, gold medal for Portrait of Fr.
