Jose Guerrico, silver medal each for Sculptor Phidias at Work and El Violoncellista, and honorable mention for Returning from the Market. Written by Luciano P. R. Santiago and Santiago A. Pilar

ZICARELLI, COS (Costantino Pedro Ubaldo Marquez Zicarelli) b. Al Jahara, Kuwait City 15 Sep 1984. Painter and installation artist. He is the son of Angelo Zicarelli and Zenaida Marquez. He spent part of his childhood living in Kuwait and Italy before moving to the Philippines and living in Ilagan, Isabela, and later Manila. He graduated from the University of Santo Tomas with a degree of bachelor of fine arts in advertising. He attributes his body of work to substantial self-training. In 2009, he completed a residency at Point B Work Lodge in Brooklyn, New York. In 2012, he did residencies in Small Projects in Tromsø, Norway, and KINOKINO Air in Sandnes, Norway.

Zicarelli’s drawings, paintings, and sculptural installations feature dark subject matter. He frequently works with graphite on paper. Even while the material is unexceptional, the monochromatic drawings are detailed and laboriously made. The artist’s installations, though not as painstakingly crafted, echo the monochrome quality of his graphite drawings in their being chromatically limited to black, white, gray, and glossy silver. Despite the patently distressful tone emanating from Zicarelli’s pieces, there is a cleanliness that can similarly be found in the works of other artists who, like Zicarelli, majored in advertising.

In 2005, Zicarelli participated in shows held in Big Sky Mind, Cubicle Art Gallery, and Goliath Visual Space in Brooklyn, New York. In 2006, he had his first solo show in Cubicle Art Gallery called The Ghost and the Holy Abortion: A Leaving Process. Over the years, he has also participated in group exhibitions held in Future Prospects Gallery, Art Informal, Blanc Gallery, Gallery Orange, West Gallery, Boston Gallery, Finale Art File, Manila Contemporary, Light and Space Contemporary, Silverlens Galleries, Museo Vicente, and Pinto Art Museum. Outside the Philippines, he has participated in group shows held in Singapore, Beijing, and Kuala Lumpur. He has held two solo shows in his residence: I’m with Stupid / I’m Not with Stupid, 2007, and I Put Fun Back in Hell, 2009. His solo exhibitions in galleries include the following at Art Informal: The Mind Is a Terrible Thing to Taste, 2009; We Are the Kids That Your Parents Warned You About, 2010; Into the Abyss (Black Album), 2011; and Swallowed by Shadows, 2012. In Silverlens Galleries, which represents him, he held solo exhibitions such as Into the Abyss: (White Album), 2011; Empire, 2012; and As White as Moonlight, as White as Bone, as Dark as the Snake, as Dark as the Throne, 2013. He also had a solo show, Untitled Soundtrack (Ghost Film 1984), for Silverlens’s participation in Art Stage Singapore, 2012. The solo shows related to his 2012 residencies in Norway were called Black Noise / Untitled Void (Ghost Film 1984). He received the Cultural Center of the Philippines Thirteen Artists Award in 2012. Written byIris S. De Ocampo

ZOBEL, FERNANDO (Fernando Zobel de Ayala y Montojo de Torrontegui) b. Manila 27 Aug 1924. d. Rome 2 Jun 1984. Painter. He was the son of Enrique Zobel de Ayala and Fermina Montojo. He is the uncle of photographer JaimeZobeldeAyala. When he was nine years old, his family moved back to Europe and stayed in Madrid, Spain. Upon their return to the Philippines in 1936, Zobel studied in De La Salle College and later pursued a pre-med course at the University of Santo Tomas. In 1946, he went on to finish a course in philosophy and letters at Harvard University, USA, graduating magna cum laude.

Zobel came from a family of artists. Both his father and grandfather were amateur painters. As a young boy, Zobel was fond of drawing. To encourage him, his father brought him to museums in their travels around the world. Zobel learned to paint from painters he knew in Boston and Cambridge, like Reed Champion, Jim Pfeuffeur, and Hyman Bloom. Later, he began to take up painting seriously.

He held his first solo exhibition at the PhilippineArtGallery in 1952. His entrance to the art scene during the postwar period helped invigorate the scene. His paintings were described as “subtle,” “subdued,” and “understated.” Over the years of his career as a painter, he became known for his Saeta paintings, described as “brief, acidic and highly emotional” (Reyes 1989), like the Flamenco repertory. He went back to Spain in 1958 and befriended abstractionists such as Saura, Sempere, Chirino, Magaz, and Rueda. Zobel quit the family business in the Philippines in 1960 to devote his time to painting. Although he settled permanently in Madrid, his works continued to be exhibited at the Luz Gallery.

His collection of Philippine paintings were donated to Ateneo de Manila and became the core of the Ateneo Art Gallery. He also lectured on art at Ateneo. In 1963, Ateneo published his landmark book, PhilippineReligiousImagery. He also published many articles on Philippine colonial art in journals like Philippine Studies. He was a regular member of the Instituto de Cultura Hispanica in Madrid. He collected Spanish abstract art, which later formed the nucleus of the Museum of Spanish Art in Cuenca, Spain.

He was named honorary cultural attache of the Spanish Embassy in the Philippines. When he died in 1984, he was buried with honors in Cuenca. He was also awarded the gold medal for fine arts by King Juan Carlos of Spain. A book on him, Zobel, was written by RodolfoParas-Perez in 1990.

Zobel de Ayala won awards from the Art Associationofthe Philippines: first prize, Carroza, 1953; second prize, Number 344, 1960; and first prize, Painting, 1962. Written by R. Chu

ZOBEL DE AYALA, JAIME (Jaime Pfitz Zobel de Ayala) b. 18 Jul 1934. Photographer. He is the son of Alfonso Zobel de Ayala and Carmen Pfitz. He married Beatriz Miranda and they have seven children, one of whom, Sofia, is a ballet dancer. Zobel was educated in Spain where he received a baccalaureate degree from La Salle, and in the United States where he got a bachelor of arts and architecture sciences degree from Harvard University. In 1957, JaimeZobeldeAyala joined his family’s corporation, the first commercial house in the Philippines established in 1834 by his ancestors. Before becoming chairman emeritus of Ayala Corporation, he served as its president from 1984 to 1994, continuing as its chairman until 2006. From 1970 to 1975, he was ambassador to the Court of St. James and the Scandinavian countries. He also served as first president of the CulturalCenterofthe Philippines (CCP), 1969-76, and member of its board of trustees in 1986. He and his wife have supported the CCP Dance Company (now Ballet Philippines) for many years. He was also the president of the Camera Club of the Philippines in 1988.

Zobel published his first photographs in Goodman Magazine (now defunct) in a photo essay, “Makati through My Eyes.” In the same year, he joined the Camera Club of the Philippines and participated in its regular competitions. Soon he was going from one place to another, around the country and abroad, organizing photographic expeditions with his fellow artists: from Batangas to Tawi-Tawi, all the way to New Guinea.

In 1980, Zobel submitted 10 photographs with the dancers of Ballet Philippines as subject matter, to the Royal Photographic Society of London. For these he earned the title of Licentiate.

In 1978, he held his first one-person show and from then on continued having one, at least once every year, either solo or with a group. In 1981, along with other photographer-friends, Zobel published his works in a book called Encounter with Paradise. Later, he published his own collections of photographs in Zobel Photography, 1983; Filipino Portraits, 1987; Zobel: Dancer, 1988; The Sea, 1989; StillLife, 1990; Glory and Gold, 1992, Homage, 1994; Journeys with Light, 2005; and The Island, 1995, among others. He was also commissioned by the Swiss watch brand Swatch to design timepieces to commemorate the country’s centennial independence, and a tribute to the former president Corazon Aquino in 2010.

In 1979, Zobel earned the title “Master of the Year” from the Camera Club of the Philippines. The same club awarded one photograph in his series on the CCP Dance Company Dancers as “Picture of the Year” in 1980. He was conferred the title of Chevalier dans l’Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the French government and the title of Comendador of the Order of Civil Merit by the Spanish government. Written by Rachel Mayo, updated by Katrina Yap and Cecilia S. De La Paz

Sources:

Camera Club of the Philippines 2015; Sta. Maria 2006; Zobel 2015.
